title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, SHEILA DINEEN
description: BAKER-Sheila Dineen. OPEIU Local 153, AFL-CIO, mourns the loss of Sheila Dineen Baker, 78, who died Friday, March 28, at her home in Asbury Park, NJ. Sheila was our leader and friend. She was the first female President of Local 153-a local union of 20,000 members-in its 50-year history. Long before becoming president, she led the employees in organizing at Fordham University, even before they were covered by the NLRA. For years, she remained their chief representative in bargaining and union representation. In addition, she was instrumental in organizing other university members, helping to build what is now the Local's college and university division with 4,000 members throughout the tri-state area. Her leadership abilities led her to serve on the union's executive board from 1968. She also served as the Local's recording secretary and vice president, before she became president in 1983. She retired from the presidency in 1988, although she remained very active in the Local 153 Retirees' Association and served as trustee of the Lavina Michl Wright Scholarship for members' children. Throughout her years in the labor movement she received numerous awards, including the YWCA's Woman of Achievement Award in 1983 and an award from the AFL-CIO's Union Label and Service Trades Department. Sheila also served her own community as a member of the Asbury Park Woman's Club, a communicant of St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church and a member of its Cartonian Club and choir. Sheila was born in New York City, the youngest of nine children. She was married for more than 50 years to Jack Baker who died in 1993. She is survived by her two sons Thomas of Paris and John of New York, and three grandchildren. To them we send our sincerest condolences for their loss. It is a loss we share for an incomparable woman of both strength and gentleness, integrity, selflessness and love for humanity. We deeply mourn her passing. For more information, Buckely's Funeral Home in Asbury Park, New Jersey (908) 775-2455. Her funeral mass will occur at 10 AM, Tuesday, April 1, at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Deal, NJ. Michael Goodwin, Business Manager Richard Lanigan, SecretaryTreasurer Local 153, Office and Professional Employees International Union, AFL-CIO

title: Young Witness to Rwanda Massacre
description: Valentina Iribagiza had a victim's-eye view of the 1994 massacre in Rwanda. For weeks, Valentina, a wounded 13-year-old, lay among the dead in the church where Tutsi villagers of Nyarubuye had sought refuge from their Hutu neighbors. Along with a few other orphaned children, she survived. ''Valentina's Nightmare'' is darkened with memories of parents, friends and babies stoned, clubbed and hacked to death in a four-day orgy.

title: Winter Devastates Island's Moose
description: WHEN Dr. Rolf Peterson reported a year ago that the moose population on Isle Royale National Park in Lake Superior had collapsed from a peak of 2,400 animals in the winter of 1994-95 to 1,200, he did not anticipate that the spectacular crash had barely begun. New surveys show that there are only about 500 moose left on the 210-square-mile wilderness island, the lowest number in 40 years. He said this is good news indeed for a badly overbrowsed forest.

title: READER'S DIGEST STOCK FALLS 12% ON EARNINGS REPORT
description: The stock of Reader's Digest Association Inc. fell 12 percent yesterday after the company said its fiscal third-quarter earnings would be below Wall Street's expectations. The publishing company, which is based in Pleasantville, N.Y., blamed disappointing responses to many of its promotional mailings and weak sales in Europe. Analysts had forecast earnings of 50 cents a share for the three months ending yesterday. The company's third-quarter results are scheduled to be reported at the end of April. Reader's Digest added that it expected earnings for the year ending June 30 to be between $1.70 and $1.80 a share, which is also less than analysts' expectations of $2.15 a share. Its stock dropped $4 yesterday, to $28.75 a share.

title: Off, Then On, Now Waiting
description: The State Attorney General's office says that if you can't vote, you can't run for office. So when the Hudson County Superintendent of Elections struck the name of the former Jersey City Mayor, Gerald McCann, from the voter registration rolls yesterday because of his bank and tax fraud convictions, it seemed to end his attempt to win back his old job. But not for long. Judge Arthur D'Italia of Superior Court in Jersey City ordered Mr. McCann's voting status restored pending a final ruling on Friday. He is one of three challengers trying to unseat Mayor Bret Schundler in the May 13 election.

title: Alice Sachs, 91, a Stalwart Among Manhattan Democrats

Survivors include her brother, Robert Sachs of West Granville, NY and one nephew, Charles Sachs of Kansas City, MO. Also two great nephews. She is making an anatomical gift of herself to Albany Medical School, in Albany, New York. Services will be held at a later date.

title: INTEGRATED REVISES ITS ACQUISITION OF CORAM HEALTHCARE
description: Integrated Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it had reduced the stock part of its planned acquisition of the Coram Healthcare Corporation to about $186 million. Integrated, based in Owings Mills, Md., is a home health care concern. Coram, based in Denver, operates clinics that provide intravenous drug therapy. Under the new agreement, Integrated would swap 0.15 of its shares for each Coram Healthcare share, down from 0.2111 share. If the merger is not completed by May 31, Integrated Health will pay Coram $25 million. Reasons for the changes were not disclosed. Shares of Integrated rose 25 cents, to $29.25, while shares of Coram were unchanged at $4.

title: Kidnapped Man Is Released
description: A Ridgefield man kidnapped from his home last Tuesday has been released unharmed, officials said yesterday. Ricardo Marte, 28, was abducted by four gunmen who demanded cash and drugs and stole a new Mercedes-Benz. The Bergen County Prosecutor, William H. Schmidt, said Mr. Marte's release was reported by a lawyer retained by Mr. Marte's family, but further information was not disclosed. When Mr. Marte was abducted last week, the Ridgefield police said he had a record of drug arrests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOZNIAK, BROTHER ALBERT

title: 2 Bleak Days Could Test The Patience Of Investors
description: In the eight years since share prices recovered from the 1987 stock market crash and began setting new highs in 1989, it has become an article of faith for many investors that weakness in the stock market provides a buying opportunity. So while the stock market has had any number of bad days, there have rarely been two consecutive ones when prices fell sharply.

title: Bre-X Explains Its Gold-Testing Methods
description: The badly battered shares of Bre-X Minerals Ltd. were kept off the trading floor again today as more perplexing questions were raised about the validity of the company's estimates for its Indonesian gold strike.

title: THERMO CARDIOSYSTEMS TO BUY TECHNIDYNE IN STOCK DEAL
description: Thermo Cardiosystems Inc., maker of the Heartmate pumping device, said yesterday that it planned to buy an affiliated company, the International Technidyne Corporation, for 3.36 million shares of stock, valued at $69.6 million, to expand its line of cardiac support devices. Both companies are subsidiaries of the Thermo Electron Corporation of Waltham, Mass. The Heartmate helps pump blood through the left ventricle in patients awaiting heart transplants. International Technidyne, based in Edison, N.J., makes the Hemochron analyzer, which monitors coagulation. The stock of Thermo Cardiosystems, based in Woburn, Mass., fell $1.375 a share, to $19.375.

title: The Theater As Patient, Clearing Its Throat
description: When theatergoers complain about a theater, the criticism is often about the sound: they cannot hear the dialogue, or the actors are overmiked and the voices do not seem to be coming from the stage. Such annoyances are frequently caused by flaws in the acoustics rather than the performers. Enter the new technicians: acousticians who treat a theater like an operating room. By their measure, all defects are curable, but the diagnosis must be correct.

title: Money From Stocks Buoys Short-Term Issues
description: With the exception of the Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond, Government securities were mostly higher yesterday, as investors moved money out of a plunging stock market to the more secure short end of the Treasury market, temporarily at least.

title: Putting the Cheesy on a Pedestal
description: The scene is a chintzy set presided over by a sleazy host named Mr. Laupin (pronounced lah-PAAN, a little like the rabbit), who fancies himself to be Mr. Show Biz. His co-host is the haughty Agatha, the former Mrs. Laupin, for whom he still hopelessly lusts. Their eager sidekick, sporting a pompadour out of a fourth-rate tour of ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' is Johnny Blue Jeans, who yearns for people to look at him and say in awe, ''Hey, that guy can party!''

title: Cyber Close-Out Firm Matches Seekers to the Sellers
description: Henry Kauftheil is a bearded, burly guy from Brooklyn who will talk for hours -- more hours than most people could probably take -- about the unusual arc of the business he is creating. It is not easy to explain, which is only one reason a chat with Mr. Kauftheil can take so long. But a good way to start is to watch a computerized ticker on the wall of his offices in Chelsea. It lists cheapo merchandise from around the world: whistle with chain (69 cents each), picnic umbrella, something called a floating eagle (at only $7.80 a dozen, whatever it is).

title: ST. JUDE MEDICAL TO PAY $135 MILLION LESS FOR VENTRITEX
description: St. Jude Medical Inc. said yesterday that had it reduced the value of its proposed acquisition of Ventritex Inc. to $365 million after problems with some Ventritex defibrillators. In October, St. Jude, based in St. Paul, agreed to acquire Ventritex, of Sunnyvale, Calif., for just over $500 million. But the deaths of three patients with older Ventritex defibrillators threatened the deal for the last two months. Under the new agreement, expected to be completed this spring, each Ventritex share would be converted to five-tenths of a St. Jude share, instead of the original six-tenths. Shares of St. Jude were down $1.25, to $33.375. Shares of Ventritex slipped 81.25 cents, to $16.75.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TICKER, MARVIN W.
description: TICKER-Marvin W., of White Meadow Lake, New Jersey and Palm Beach Garden, FL., 72, at home Monday, March 31st after a courageous 12 year fight with melanoma. A trusted businessman, he was founder and President of Frances Yarn Corp. since 1954. Proud member of the Jewish War Veterans, he served his country in WW II. Respected civic and community leader, he was active in Jewish Federation of Metro-West and President of its Jewish Vocational Service, 1993-95. He had also been a VP of White Meadow Temple, President of Rockaway Township Lions Club and a Board Member of WMLPOA. Beloved husband of Frances (Blechman), his adoring wife of 47 years. Loving father to their children: Susan Ticker and Hazzan Henry Rosenblum, IL, Ronni Ticker and Dr. David Roth, NJ, David and Susan Ticker, NJ and Dr. Jonathan and Alyse Ticker, NY. He will be remembered with love by his grandchildren Leora, Shira, Alexandra, Aviva, Marielle, Daniel, Sam, Ari, Michael, Jordan and Anna. May he continue to serve as a shining example to those who knew him. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, White Meadow Temple. Interment Mt. Ararat, Farmingdale, NY. Shiva at family home. Contributions to Jewish Vocational Service, 111 Prospect St., E. Orange, NJ 07017

title: Altering Labels, Not Clothes, China Sidesteps Trade Limits
description: Every day, shiploads of clothing cranked out by China's prodigious textile industry are unloaded on the docks of this commercial crossroads and taken by truck to back-alley factories. Nimble-fingered workers add a few finishing touches and, most important, a label that reads, ''Made in Hong Kong.''

title: Inquiry Winds Down In Deaths of Cultists
description: As they made public the names of the last two members of the Heaven's Gate cult who committed suicide in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., the authorities said they had no evidence that a crime had been committed. Consequently, they said they were preparing to close the investigation into the 39 deaths.

title: Cloning as an Anticlimax
description: With all the hand-wringing over the cloning of sheep in Scotland, it is easy to forget that society confronted a far more radical biological breakthrough a quarter-century ago and has emerged none the worse for it. That earlier revolution, known as ''gene splicing'' or ''recombinant DNA technology,'' gave scientists the awesome power to snip genes from one species and insert them into another, producing creatures with characteristics never before seen. It has spawned such useful advances as bacteria that make human insulin and crops that resist insect attacks. But it has also produced some pretty freakish creatures in the name of science.

Larry Whitman, vice president and corporate controller, will take over the post vacated by Cynthia M. Deysher, Shiva said. Ms. Deysher, who had been with the company for three years, said it was time to try ''something new.''

description: Chief Judge Judith Kaye has come forward with a sensible reorganization plan for New York State's notoriously tangled court system. Gov. George Pataki and Republican and Democratic legislative leaders should seize this moment to make sure reform finally happens.

title: School Law Favoring Crew Takes Effect
description: The new state law that strengthens Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew's authority over the city's 32 community school districts is scheduled to take effect today. But whether the law could actually be enforced remained in question yesterday, as the Federal Justice Department continued its inquiry into whether the law violated the rights of minority voters by weakening the district boards.

title: Ned Rorem, Subject Yet Also The Leader
description: For her Making Music 1997 series at Weill Recital Hall, the composer Ellen Taaffe Zwilich has invited a handful of composers to present programs of their works and to expound on their music and philosophy to listeners between selections. Ned Rorem, the subject of an installment last week, seemed a natural choice for this approach. As a composer best regarded for his song settings and as a prolific diarist and writer, he is on more intimate terms with language than many composers. Yet it was Mr. Rorem -- not Ms. Zwilich, who conducted the interview segments -- who insisted on cutting short the discussion on Wednesday night and getting to the music.

title: Medical Examiner Tough Yet Calm
description: In forensic pathology, the investigation of a mass disaster inevitably thrusts a doctor into the national spotlight. For Dr. Brian D. Blackbourne, the San Diego County medical examiner, the call came last week, when he began the grim task of leading the team of pathologists who are performing autopsies on the 39 members of a millennialist group who committed mass suicide in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif.

title: Artificial Human Chromosome Is New Tool for Gene Therapy
description: BIOLOGISTS have accumulated wonderfully detailed insights into the genetic causes of human disease but in many cases still lack the tools to make use of the knowledge. A treatment of great promise, gene therapy, has long been stalled by the lack of suitable vehicles to get genes into human cells and maintain them in working order. But that obstacle could dissolve if a strange new biological invention works as well as its makers hope.

title: Royal Machinations, Through a Haze

title: New View Sees Breast Cancer As 3 Diseases
description: FOR years, cancer specialists repeated their hypothesis as if it were a mantra: virtually all breast cancer has spread by the time it is detected. But now, seemingly overnight, that prevailing view of breast cancer has changed.

title: The Hard Life in Taiwan
description: Chang Tso-chi's film ''Ah-Chung,'' unlike most Taiwanese movies shown in American film festivals in recent years, is not a reflection of the gold-rush fever igniting the affluent sectors of the Pacific Rim. This bleak, atmospheric little movie presents scenes in the life of a strife-ridden family eking out a precarious existence in a boggy area of Taipei.

title: AHMANSON SAYS GREAT WESTERN INVESTORS FAVOR ITS BID
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company said yesterday that 80 percent of the shares of the Great Western Financial Corporation voted so far in a referendum were in favor of its $6.18 billion hostile takeover bid. Shareholders support nonbinding resolutions requiring Great Western's board to open its books and reschedule its indefinitely postponed annual meeting, Ahmanson said. It would not say how many shares had been voted. Ahmanson, of Irwindale, Calif., is the nation's largest savings institution. It asked Great Western shareholders to support its takeover offer after their board rejected it for a rival offer of $6.14 billion from Seattle-based Washington Mutual Inc. Great Western, based in Chatsworth, Calif., would not negotiate with Ahmanson.

title: Brearley School Selects a New Head
description: The Brearley School, one of the most prestigious private schools for girls in the nation, has selected Priscilla M. Winn Barlow, a British-born educator, to be the 10th head in its 113-year history.

title: In Period Style, but Fresh as a Daisy
description: Two generations have grown up thinking of Emma Kirkby as the favorite soprano of Bach and Handel (not to mention many other composers), and still she sounds as fresh as a daisy. On Sunday afternoon she was with Christopher Hogwood and his Academy of Ancient Music in Avery Fisher Hall, which is by no means the ideal place for 18th-century music done in period style. Even so, her singing was clear, focused and unforced.

title: Arthur Clarke Resumes Writing To Be Famous Again
description: Arthur C. Clarke, author of ''3001: The Final Odyssey,'' a chronicle of deep-space travel 1,000 years hence that is pushing its way up best-seller lists, chuckles at the friends who still puzzle over his decision more than 40 years ago to flee the roots of his success as a science fiction writer in England, and briefly in the United States, for a home on this lovely Indian Ocean island.

Both of the Sapporo-based banks are struggling to overcome bad loans made in the late 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLIEGMAN, BENJAMIN

title: U.S. Finds Supercomputer Dumping by 2 Japan Makers
description: The Commerce Department issued a preliminary finding today that two Japanese computer makers, the NEC Corporation and Fujitsu Ltd., were guilty of dumping by bidding below cost in an effort to sell a supercomputer to an American weather research laboratory.

title: Nine Survivors Of Holocaust Sue Insurers
description: Nine Holocaust survivors sued seven European insurance companies in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, claiming that the companies have cheated them by refusing to honor policies purchased by their relatives before World War II. The suit says that instead, the companies used the policies' funds for the Nazi war effort, to enrich individual Nazis or to help postwar Governments.

title: Where Africa's Hopes Lie
description: As with any crisis, the civil war in Zaire points to both danger and opportunity. Zaire, with nine neighbors, is the continent's third-largest state -- four times the size of France. What happens in Zaire can make or break sub-Saharan Africa. If the country remains a vast zone of economic decay and political failure, it limits and threatens a whole region. A Zaire on the road to reconstruction and development could open the way to a regional renaissance. There is no more important challenge in Africa.

title: What's Next at Tennessee? 3 Top Recruits
description: Tennessee won its second straight women's national basketball championship Sunday night, and the truth of the matter is that Pat Summitt and her resident star, Chamique Holdsclaw, are just warming up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENEDICT, MITCHELL M.
description: BENEDICT-Mitchell M. Sr. MD, Veteran of 3 Wars, W.W. I, W.W. II & Korea. Dr. Mitchell M. Benedict of Stuart, Florida and Williamstown, MA., died on Saturday, March 29, 1997 at North Adams Regional Hospital, N.A., Mass. He had been a resident of Sweetbrook Nursing Home for the past five years. He was 98. Born in Argrigenta, Italy in 1898, he came to this country as a three year old with his parents and siblings and settled in Brooklyn, N.Y., where he grew up. He enlisted in the army during high school in April of 1918 and served with the 219 Tank Corp Battallion, Medical Detachment, in France in World War I. He was wounded by an exploding German shell on Columbus Day, 1918, less than a month before Armistice Day. He graduated from West Virginia University and received his Medical Degree from New York University. He interned at Bellevue Hospital in New York City. His private practice was in Yonkers, NY. In the 1930's he was appointed Medical Officer of the U.S. Veterans Administration. In 1942, he returned to military service and held the post of Medical Director at Fort Monmouth, NJ until 1954. He retired and moved to Stuart, Florida in 1955. During his military career he was the recipient of the Purple Heart, The W.W. I Victory Medal for service at Meuse-Argonne, France and the W.W. I Victory Button. He was a recent recipient of the WWI Commemorative Medal at a ceremony to honor the 75th anniversary of that war. He was a member of the Martin County, Florida Veterans of WWI. These details appear in ''Last Dinner on the Titanic'' by Rick Archbold and Dana McCauley (Hyperion, $24.95). Titanic buffs recreate the dinner annually. One such dinner, with six courses, will be served on April 14 at 8 P.M. at Halcyon, 151 West 54th Street. The production, taped in Santa Fe last summer, is ''Emmeline,'' an opera by Tobias Picker. J. D. McClatchy's libretto is based on the 1980 novel of the same name by Judith Rossner, who also wrote ''Looking for Mr. Goodbar.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RANZAL, EDWARD
description: RANZAL-Edward. The family of Edward Ranzal mourns his passing on April 1, 1997. He is survived by his two sons and their wives, Ted and Eleanor, and Gerry and Barbara, and his 4 grandchildren, Robin, Susan, Scott, and Stacey. He joins his wife Celia who passed away April 9, 1996. He was a newspaper reporter on the staff of the New York Times for over 50 years. During that time his beat included the Bronx courthouse, the federal courthouse at Foley Square, and Mayors Lindsay and Koch. Since his retirement he has been a resident of Deerfield Beach Florida. If so desired, a memorial donation may be made to: The Alzheimer's Association, or The Jacob Perlow Hospice at Beth Israel Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTH, MURRAY
description: ROTH-Murray. We mourn the tragic and sudden loss of our beloved friend & mentor. He was everything a friend ever could be, true, devoted and loving. He stood by his friends and helped them navigate through the ups and downs of life. His words and sage advice will never die. Nor, will the results of his many acts of kindness. We, and many, many others, will forever have him in our hearts, minds and souls. We will miss him so and love him forever. Pam, Catherine, Dawn and Philip

title: Assembly Adopts Own Version of Budget
description: Staking out an unusually clear position in the state's annual budget struggle, the Assembly today adopted its own version of the budget, one that would spend as much as $4 billion more than Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed, and it passed a softened version of Mr. Pataki's welfare overhaul program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENNEDY, UNA M.
description: KENNEDY-Una M., on March 24, 1997. Daughter of Thomas P. and Kathleen (nee Mc Dermott) Devoted mother of Brian and Barbara, loving grandmother of Kerry and Kelly, mother-in-law of Donna. Memorial Mass at Epiphany RC Church, (2nd Ave & 28 St NYC) 11 AM, Friday, April 4, 1997.

title: Old Sleuths Never Die
description: Starting today, Bill Cosby joins Peter Falk, Dennis Weaver and Jack Klugman in the happy hunting ground where all good detective shows go to live forever, the daytime mystery lineup on A&E.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SASLOW, BERNARD
description: SASLOW-Bernard. On March 31, 1997. Beloved husband of Lillian. Devoted father of Joy and Jerry. Cherished grandfather of Julie and Craig. Loving father-in-law of Linda and Norman. Services on Wednesday, 1 PM, ''Gutterman's,'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Giants, Jets, And Now Part Of Ellis Island
description: SO, this Federal master decides that most of Ellis Island sort of belongs to New Jersey while New York gets to keep the museum and a few acres. It's all official in a big fact-finding report that Paul R. Verkuil -- the master -- submitted to the Supreme Court, which will one day issue a suitably sage ruling filled with precedents, footnotes and assorted legal whatnots.

title: Not the Usual Retirement Ahead For a Master of Corporate Zen
description: It's not every day that a corporate chieftain calls it quits and becomes a monk. But for Kazuo Inamori, this planned step is not such a big change. He already runs his companies like religious orders and is revered as almost godlike.

title: National Rifle Association Is Turning to World Stage to Fight Gun Control
description: The National Rifle Association is going global.

description: To the Editor:

title: Liberalizing A Vegetarian Peanut Sauce
description: Gado gado, from Indonesia, is the marvelous peanut sauce with vegetables. Some liberties have been taken here, but the tastes and textures are true. This is a vegetarian dish, but the sauce is so good it makes perfect sense to add shrimp to it or, if you prefer, chicken breasts or pork, and have a meal in a dish.

title: Several Guns Found Among Cultists' Belongings
description: Acting on a tip from a warehouse operator, sheriff's investigators in San Diego County today found several weapons among a cache of books, videotapes and other items in two storage units rented by the Heaven's Gate cult, the authorities said.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT'S spring cleaning time, and like a lot of other folks, Tawfiq Khoury has been tidying things up, especially his wine cellar. He gathered a lot of wine he no longer needs and got Christie's auction house to sell it. The sale, held two weeks ago in Manhattan, brought in more than $3 million.

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AKHTAR, M. AKBAR
description: AKHTAR-M. Akbar, of Manhattan, died suddenly Sunday, March 30. He was a vice president at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and an economist who was widely known and respected. A warm, kind man, he will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Condolences to his son Erik, who lives in Manhattan, and to his mother and sister, who live in Pakistan. Services will be held on Thursday, April 3, 1:30PM, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in Akbar's memory to St. Hilda's and St. Hugh's School, 619 West 114th Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10025.

title: Dinner as Theater, Or a One-Chef Show
description: A former apothecary's shop on a quiet residential street seems an unlikely place to find a fine restaurant. But the Harlequin Cafe is worth searching out because of the chef's showmanship and masterful sauces.

title: Lager With Pork: Now That's German!
description: The Penn Brewery Restaurant in the historic German section of the city's North Side looks, sounds and feels like the brew houses typically found in German cities like Munich and Dusseldorf.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, LAWRENCE
description: BERNSTEIN-Lawrence March 28, 1997 in Miami, Florida. Formely of New York. Father of Karen, Steven, and Howard. Grandfather of David, Sean, Ryan, Megan, Kyle, Graham, Katie, Allison, and brother of Jay. Services at Pine Lawn Cemetary, Farmingdale, Long Island. Friday April 4th at 1pm.

title: Let Politics of Breast Cancer Serve as Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, CHARLES
description: COHEN-Charles. On March 29, 1997. Loving brother of Nathan. Dear uncle of Mark and Eric Pollak and Danny and Debbie Cohen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEPTEE, MOE
description: SEPTEE-Moe. On April 1, 1997. Of Philadelphia, PA. and Deal, N.J. Husband of Ruth Attermann. Father of Yael Septee Kane, Elisa Septee Lunzer, Rena Septee Goldstein. Brother of Esther Glyn and Shirley Levitan. Also survived by five loving grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to services on Wednesday 10 A.M., Joseph Levine & Son, North Broad Street, above 71st Avenue, Philadelphia. Interment Beth El Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. The family will return to the late residence in Philadelphia and respectfully requests that contributions in his memory be made to the Moe Septee Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Kathy Mellon at the American Israel Cultural Foundation, 317 Madison Avenue, Suite 1605, New York, New York 10017.

title: Adviser Invoked Giuliani's Name in Lobbying, Officials Say
description: A company that has repeatedly been accused of mismanaging a $16 million contract with New York City's hospitals agency was allowed to keep the contract last year after one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's closest advisers intervened to lobby on the company's behalf, according to interviews and agency records.

title: The Assassin's Name Is James Earl Ray
description: Twenty-nine years after James Earl Ray killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Dr. King's son Dexter has shaken Mr. Ray's very hand, looked him in the eye and declared his belief, which he asserted is shared by the King family, that James Earl Ray is innocent of any involvement in the assassination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LARA, JONNE ELIZABETH STEWART CLAFLIN LOW
description: de LARA-Jonne Elizabeth Stewart Claflin Low. Died on March 29, in New Canaan, Conn., after a long illness. Devoted wife of Juan Jacobo de Lara and mother of Julian de Lara (died in 1960) and Angela Dulce de Lara of Fairfield, Conn. Private memorial service held on April 2 at her home, with burial at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: The Yankees' Encore Folds Under Griffey's Bat
description: The Yankees cruised into the always raucous Kingdome as the defending World Series champions, intent on beginning their long journey to another title with a sliver of an encore. But Ken Griffey Jr. stole the microphone, stole the show and upstaged David Cone and the champs by clubbing home runs in his first two at-bats tonight. Call it Griffey's encore.

title: Data Point to More Growth, But With Inflation in Check
description: Evidence mounted today that the economy accelerated markedly in recent weeks, though inflation appeared to remain in check.

title: Ernest Goodman, 90, Civil Rights Lawyer
description: Ernest Goodman, a Detroit lawyer specializing in First Amendment and civil rights cases who served as president of the National Lawyers Guild, died last Wednesday at Harper Hospital in Detroit. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, FRANCES (NEE SIEDERER)
description: SCHWARTZ-Frances (nee Siederer). On March 31, 1997 in Phoenix. Originally from Brooklyn. Wife of Leonard. Mother of Michael, JoAnn Friedman-Rapaport and Herbert. Sister of Herman Siederer. Loving aunt and grandmother. Graveside service on Wednesday, 2 P.M., King Solomon Memorial Park, Clifton, New Jersey.

title: Solomonic Ruling Would Divide Ellis Island
description: Ruling in a dispute that has kept New York and New Jersey at loggerheads for 200 years, an arbitrator appointed by the United States Supreme Court recommended yesterday that Ellis Island be divided between the two, drawing the line largely where New Jersey wanted it.

title: Report Was Not Filed on a Boy Who Died
description: The child welfare worker monitoring a 5-year-old boy who prosecutors say was beaten and starved to death by his mother failed to file a mandatory status report for a family court judge after the troubled family was reunited last year, a court official said yesterday.

title: Tokyo Stocks End Higher
description: Stocks rose here today after the Bank of Japan's release of its quarterly economic survey. The Nikkei index of 225 issues gained 167.71 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 18,037.30. On Tuesday, the Nikkei fell 133.81 points. Traders said the economic survey confirmed that the confidence of major Japanese companies was better than four months ago, when the last survey was released.

title: A GAY BAN BACKED BY PRESBYTERIANS
description: Racked for years by internal debate over its policy against ordaining practicing homosexuals, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) said yesterday that a majority of its regional bodies had voted to make that policy law, amending the church's constitution to bar anyone who is sexually active outside marriage from becoming a clergy member, elder or deacon.

title: Pakistan Acts To Cut Power Of President
description: Less than two months after winning a landslide victory in a general election, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan won parliamentary approval today for a measure eliminating a crucial vestige of the country's years under military rule: the power of the country's appointed President to dismiss elected governments and to appoint armed forces chiefs.

title: Court Upholds Suspension Of Student Carrying a Gun
description: In a decision that New York City school officials said would strengthen their ability to keep weapons out of classrooms, the state's highest court ruled today that a school superintendent had acted appropriately in suspending a 15-year-old student caught carrying a loaded gun in a Bronx high school even though a judge had ruled the search illegal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRONETHAL, WILLIAM
description: KRONETHAL-William. The associates and staff of the Stein-Knox Agency mourn the untimely loss of our dear colleague and friend. Bill was affiliated with our agency for nearly thirty years and during that time, he enriched our lives along with the lives of his many clients. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the Kronethal family. He was a kind and generous person, we will miss him.

title: Labor's Latest Ads Don't Spare Democrats
description: For years, organized labor has focused on Republican lawmakers as the main political enemies of rank-and-file workers.

title: When the Tough Get Going
description: Paul Robert Verkuil, the legal scholar who recommended yesterday that the 200-year dispute over Ellis Island be settled by divvying the island up, has never been known for passing up a challenge just because it looked impossible to win.

title: A Plain School Uniform as the Latest Aphrodisiac
description: With a shy, quivering glance that she had practiced a thousand times, eyes slightly downcast but luminous with innocence and apprehension, Kaori sat at her desk in her prim school uniform, framed by a blackboard, waiting for a ''teacher'' to walk into the classroom and rip her clothes off.

title: Fear of Contagion Sets Off Heavy Losses In Europe and Asia : Markets Fall Worldwide, Alarmed by Wall Street
description: LONDON  World stock markets racked up some of their worst losses in months Tuesday, shedding billions of dollars in share value, as equities plummeted in response to two days of heavy losses on Wall Street.

title: 57th St. Site in Demand By Theme Restaurants
description: At the busy northwest corner of 57th Street and Avenue of the Americas, on the faded storefront of a shuttered delicatessen, sits a sign with bright red letters: ''Retail Space for Lease.'' It has not gone unnoticed.

title: Lyman Spitzer Jr. Dies at 82; Inspired Hubble Telescope
description: Lyman Spitzer Jr., a visionary theoretician of astrophysics and plasma physics who inspired the Hubble Space Telescope and an array of orbiting observatories now tracking X-ray emissions and assorted other heavenly phenomena, died on Monday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 82.

title: INFORMIX PROJECTS LOSS FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: The Informix Corporation said yesterday that it expected to report a loss for the first quarter due to a substantial shortfall in revenue during the period. The news sent Informix shares plummeting in heavy trading. Informix, the world's second-largest producer of data base software, attributed the shortfall to poor sales across all its markets. Informix shares closed at $9.875, down $5.25. Informix, based in Menlo Park, Calif., said that official results would be announced at the end of the month, but that first-quarter sales were expected to be $130 million to $145 million, compared with $204 million a year ago, and that the shortfall would result in a substantial operating loss and net loss. Analysts had expected the company to earn 12 cents a share.

title: WHITE HOUSE AIDES HELPED JOB HUNT OF CLINTON FRIEND
description: The White House acknowledged today that President Clinton's top advisers and confidants, including his chief of staff, mounted a campaign in 1994 to help find lucrative employment for Webster L. Hubbell, who is one of Mr. Clinton's closest friends and was facing a criminal investigation shortly after he left the Justice Department.

title: For Sharing Ellis Island
description: Ruling in a dispute that kept New York and New Jersey at loggerheads for roughly 200 years, an arbitrator appointed by the United States Supreme Court recommended yesterday that Ellis Island be divided between the two, drawing the line generally where New Jersey wanted it.

title: New Health Insurance Rules Spell Out Rights of Workers
description: The Clinton Administration today issued rules making health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans who lose their jobs or change jobs.

title: Losing Count Of Calories As Plates Fill Up
description: TRYING to estimate how many calories you eat in a day is risky business. You already know this if you have ever taken the time to compare your guesses with the numbers in a calorie guide.

description: It was not turn-back-the-clock night. But it was close.

title: NFO Research Buys Prognostics
description: NFO Research Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it had acquired Prognostics in Palo Alto, Calif., a provider of customer satisfaction measurement for information technology companies, for 1.726 million shares of NFO stock worth about $30 million.

title: Nor'easter
description: ''Nor'easter'' is a word that people who live in the Nor'east get to use from time to time, as they did on Monday night. Even the hill dwellers of western Massachusetts find it hard to say the word without feeling temporarily nautical, without imagining that when the storm settles, the yard will be filled with sea wrack and surprising pelagic debris.

title: Insisting It's Nothing, Creator Says SAT, Not S.A.T.
description: Like the corporate monikers of KFC or AT&T, the initials SAT, denoting the test that has been the scourge of generations of high school students, now stands for nothing, officials with the College Board say.

title: Japan to Rescue 2 Top-Tier Banks From Bad Debt
description: The Japanese Government announced plans today to effectively rescue two of the nation's 20 largest banks and have them withdraw from international business.

title: Man Held on Charges Of Molesting Teen-Ager
description: A 54-year-old man was arrested on charges of slashing and groping a 15-year-old Brooklyn boy whom he had been propositioning on a city bus, the police said yesterday.

title: Bitterness as Germany Sends 30 Bosnian Children Home
description: Hugging toys, dolls and pillows for comfort, 30 Bosnian children were sent back home today, more than four years after they were plucked from the siege of Sarajevo under fire from snipers who shot two others dead.

title: Snow Leaves Thousands Without Power
description: Tens of thousands of households in Connecticut and New York State were still without electricity tonight after a sudden spring blizzard dropped as much as three feet of wet snow on the northern parts of the two states as well as sections of New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Styles pages on March 23 about the author Michael Ondaatje, who wrote the novel ''The English Patient,'' referred incorrectly to Kathryn Falk and Romantic Times magazine, whose February issue praised the film that was made from the Ondaatje novel. She is the owner of the magazine, not the editor. It is a consumer magazine, not a trade magazine for the romance-novel business.

description: An undercover Port Authority police officer on an assignment to ferret out illegal gypsy-cab drivers at Kennedy International Airport was briefly kidnapped yesterday morning when a driver he was trying to arrest drove off with him in the back seat, officials said.

description: Predicting that companies will increasingly give their tax, audit, payroll and other services to other companies to handle, Price Waterhouse has created a $145 million division for those tasks.

title: Link Found in Meningitis Outbreak: Toddlers Played Together
description: A fatal meningitis outbreak here spread from one seemingly healthy toddler to another when their baby sitters let them play together, state health officials said today. Within three weeks both toddlers were dead and a relative of the first one, who had cared for her when she was sick, had been hospitalized in a coma.

title: Quick Fix Makes Sense For Opener
description: IT is bizarre to think that one five-game playoff series could affect the course of baseball history. But the night watchman who runs baseball must believe it, because the Mariners and the Yankees were delegated to give another season a jump start.

Survivors include step-brother Paul Roy and step-daughter Barbara Kaufman. Funeral arrangements private. Memorial gifts may be made to Danbury Hospital Development Fund, Danbury Hospital, Danbury, Connecticut 06810.

title: Pataki Urges New York Undo Sale of Attica Prison to Itself
description: In a move with more symbolism than substance, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed undoing one of the most remarkable fiscal sleights of hand in New York history: the state's $200 million sale of Attica prison to itself.

title: Airports, Seaports and Mideast Peace
description: Rebuilding some mutual confidence between Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, is an essential condition for resuming progress toward peace in the Middle East. Their relationship has been battered by Israeli construction in East Jerusalem, disputes over Israeli withdrawals in the West Bank and, most seriously, Mr. Arafat's ambiguous attitude toward Hamas suicide bomb attacks.

description: Santoni, a designer and manufacturer of handmade men's Italian shoes and accessories, is coming to Madison Avenue's designer's row.

title: A Rundown School, an Abandoned Factory
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has introduced 30-second radio and television advertisements in the districts of 19 House Republicans and Democrats.

title: More Prospective Jurors Screened in Oklahoma City Bombing Trial
description: Jury selection in the Oklahoma City bombing trial continued today at a measured pace, with some potential jurors on the stand for an hour or more. One, a woman who immediately broke down in tears and is taking medication for stress, was excused within minutes.

title: Woman Arrested in Burning of Daughter
description: A Harlem woman was arrested last night on charges that she severely burned her 7-year-old daughter by forcing her to sit on a radiator as punishment for fighting with her siblings, the police said.

title: Here's Everything From Soup to Soup
description: TWO new soup cookbooks that focus on Italy have the same title, all the way down to the exclamation point: ''Zuppa!'' The only way to tell them apart is by their subtitles.

title: Orthodox Conversion Bill Gains in Israel
description: Angering Conservative and Reform Jews here and abroad, the Israeli Parliament gave preliminary approval today to a bill that would give Orthodox rabbis sole authority to conduct conversions to Judaism in Israel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, ANNE
description: ALPERT-Anne. Passed away March 30. Pajarito, the name bestowed on her by her first husband Matta, the father of two sons Gordon Matta-Clarke and SebastianMatta both deceased, will be sorely missed by her friends and family. She was an extraordinary gracious and loving lady. Memorial service will be held in Sag Harbor, where she had a summer home, in late spring.

title: Columbia/HCA Hospital Must Bargain With Union
description: An administrative law judge has ruled that a flagship hospital owned by Columbia/HCA Healthcare violated Federal labor laws in efforts to prevent nurses from unionizing.

description: BRITTON-Virginia C. (nee Cummings) on March 31, 1997. Beloved wife of the late John T. Loving sister of Eileen Cummings and the late Ruth Harrington. Devoted aunt of Rev. Donald Harrington, C.M., John and Jay Harrington. Fond stepmother of Priscilla Pezzati and John Britton. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193 Street. Visiting hours Thursday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Services private.

title: Former Cultists Warn of Believers Now Adrift
description: The mass suicide of followers of the Heaven's Gate cult left many other believers spiritually adrift across the United States and Canada, say two former cult members who talk frequently to followers.

title: Tanqueray puts a new twist on its Sterling vodka campaign.
description: CAN the antics of a saucy young British woman named Mel persuade consumers to buy a brand of vodka that has gone over about as well as martinis at a temperance meeting?

title: Pitino Gives Kentucky Humanity in Defeat
description: Maybe a championship really does soften the edges a little. Maybe when Rick Pitino conceded defeat in the final seconds of overtime Monday night, choosing instead to take the first steps of his last and longest walk of the season, he could call upon the comfort of a year-old celebration. Perhaps he was admiring the ability of his Kentucky Wildcats to fight through every obstacle until five extra minutes posed too many problems.

title: Princeton Names Nobelist To Be Its Dean of Faculty
description: Princeton University has named Joseph H. Taylor, the 1993 Nobel Prize winner for physics, to be dean of faculty.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KALIKOW, NORMAN
description: KALIKOW-Norman. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Devoted father of Richard, Dale and Marc. Brother of Charles. Grandfather of Liat, Leora, Brett, Wade, Galee and Weslee. Services 11:30, on Wednesday, at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 257 West 88 St., NYC.

title: The Knicks Savor One That Didn't Get Away
description: When Bob Sura made a 3-point shot to put the Cavaliers ahead with 1 minute 37 seconds left, the game seemed to resemble many of the Knicks' losses this season. The letdown against an inferior team was near.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, JON
description: STONE-Jon. The Board of Directors of the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Association (ALS) Greater New York Chapter is deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and supporter Jon Stone, after a courageous battle with Lou Gehrig's disease. We send our heartfelt condolences to his daughters Polly and Kate and to the entire Stone family. John L. Ernst, Chairman Dorine Gordon, President Lauri Novick, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONWAY, TERENCE J.

Conway. Funeral, Friday 9:15 AM from the Oakland Memorial Home, 330 Ramapo Valley Road, Oakland and 10 AM Mass at St. Catherine R.C. Church, Ringwood. Cremation private. Visiting on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers donations to St. Catherine School would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLING, ARTHUR S., M.D.
description: KLING-Arthur S., M.D. died on Friday, March 28 at his home in Los Angeles after a long illness. Dr. Kling was Chief of Psychiatry at the Sepulveda VA Medical Center and former Vice Chair of the Department of Psychiatry at UCLA School of Medicine. He was Professor of Psychiatry at Rutgers Medical School, 1970-1980. Funeral services were held on Monday, March 31 in Sepulveda, CA. Dr. Kling is survived by his mother Rose, his wife Rosalyn, his sons Mitchel, Joel and David and three granddaughters. Contributions in his name may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: New Faces Star in a Recurring Nightmare
description: The dust of a long winter's worth of construction had barely settled on Jack Murphy Stadium yesterday when the San Diego Padres' president, Larry Lucchino, looked out at the billboards shielding unfinished bleachers and triumphantly asked whether that didn't just remind everyone of Ebbets Field.

title: B Sky B Seeks Financing For Digital-TV Venture
description: The British Sky Broadcasting Group is looking for as much as $:700 million ($1.15 billion) in financing to get its digital-television joint venture with British Telecommunications P.L.C. off the ground, about $:200 million more than expected, The Financial Times said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WALTER CRONKITE underwent quadruple-bypass surgery yesterday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, BRENNER, ELIZABETH R.
description: MORGAN - BRENNER - Elizabeth R., Dr. Born in Roumania 1907. Died on March 31, 1997 after a long illness. She was educated in prestigious unversities in France, Switzerland and the United States. She was known to support many charities in the United States and Israel. Beloved by her late husband Dr. Herman Brenner, several of her surviving cousins, many, many friends. She will be remembered as a generous, loyal person, dedicated to family and friends & highly esteemed by her patients. Services ''The Riverside'', 76 St. & Amsterdam Ave., Friday 11 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLWELL, WARREN
description: OLWELL-Warren. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Warren Olwell, associated with The Times from 1959, until retiring in 1982.

title: Five Big Girls With a Sense of Humor and Style
description: ''Remember a sound from childhood,'' the Zairian-Belgian singer Marie Daulne of Zap Mama told the audience at Irving Plaza on Saturday night before beginning a song that included blowing into bottles and miniature flutes. It was an advisory that served for most of the concert. This international five-woman, two-man band, essentially an Afropop a cappella group that has now added funky backdrops on bass and drums, kept the giddy spirit of a girls' sleep-over party in motion for an hour and a half.

title: Private Schools to Share in Giuliani's Extra Textbook Aid
description: In November, facing criticism of his cuts in the education budget, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said he was giving $70 million to the Board of Education to replace the dog-eared, outdated textbooks used by thousands of public school children. But school officials now say that because of a provision in state law, more than a fifth of that money will go to buy books for students in parochial schools.

description: A new Federal law that will curb immigration went into effect today as lawyers for refugees and the poor continued to fight it in court.

title: Pupul Jayakar, 81; Led Revival Of Arts and Handicrafts in India
description: Pupul Jayakar, who became known as India's ''czarina of culture'' when she melded her passion for Indian arts and handicrafts with a close and influential friendship with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, died on Friday at her home in Bombay, Indian press reports said. She was 81.

title: Few Heed Shifts on Mammograms
description: THE hot line volunteers at the National Women's Health Network were prepared for a deluge of calls this week from confused women asking what to do about mammograms. But the calls did not come, and a recent survey, as well as comments by practicing doctors and some social scientists, suggest that the reason is that when it comes to mammograms, women pay attention to what their doctors say, not to panels of experts.

title: Phi Delta Theta Fraternity Plans to Eliminate Alcohol
description: The college fraternity Phil Delta Theta has said that all of its 180 chap ters will become alcohol-free by 2000, because that is what freshmen want.

title: Suez Board Backs Merger With Utility
description: Compagnie de Suez S.A., a holding company striving to return to its industrial roots, said yesterday that its board had unanimously approved in principle a planned merger with the utility Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. Details of the merger were not disclosed, but it is expected to take the form of a share swap, with two shares of Suez being traded for one in Lyonnaise.

title: The Rangers Give a Little, Take a Little
description: Shortly after forward Esa Tikkanen of the Rangers beat goalie Dominik Hasek of the Buffalo Sabres to secure a gritty 1-1 tie last night at Madison Square Garden, the two men could be seen laughing over something Tikkanen said.

title: Amstrad to Sell Unit To Bosch of Germany
description: Amstrad P.L.C., the British consumer electronics maker, said yesterday that it was selling the mobile telephone unit Dancall Telecom to Robert Bosch G.m.b.H. of Germany for $:92 million ($150 million). Dancall's sale is the latest step in a reorganization by Amstrad. Last year, it took a charge for pulling Amstrad Consumer Electronics Ltd. out of France and the Benelux countries.

title: Chewing-Tobacco Withdrawal Shakes Harnisch
description: Pete Harnisch nearly missed his opening-day starting assignment for the Mets today after suffering from severe withdrawal symptoms from having given up chewing tobacco. The pitcher's symptoms, which included cold sweats and the shakes, stopped only when Harnisch reluctantly reindulged in tobacco before the game.

title: Making Cheese From Sheep's Milk
description: Small-scale farming often seems like a losing proposition, but David and Cynthia Major have come up with a recipe to keep Vermont sheep farms in business: making prize-winning cheese.

title: Personal Health
description: A SURVEY of cancer patients has concluded that fatigue, not pain, is their most common complaint and the symptom most likely to disrupt their lives. The survey, released by the Fatigue Coalition, a consortium of medical practitioners and patient advocates who want to raise awareness of cancer-related fatigue, was conducted among 419 cancer patients, 200 care givers and 197 oncologists. The coalition reported that four out of five cancer patients experienced life-disrupting fatigue.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday about baseball's schedule for opening-day games described the Los Angeles stadium incorrectly. It does not have a dome.

title: Billeter Joins St. John's Coaching Staff
description: Coach FRAN FRASCHILLA of St. John's yesterday announced the appointment of TOM BILLETER as an assistant coach. He replaces BRIAN COUSINS, who left to join the Clemson staff.

title: Belle Proves Worth for White Sox
description: Other owners can say what they want about the $11 million a year Jerry Reinsdorf forced on Albert Belle, but they have to admit that the Chicago White Sox owner believes in truth in advertising.

title: Two Artists, Neither Aboriginal (Nor Original) After All
description: The novel is by a purported Aborigine named Wanda Koolmatrie, who tells the story of an Aborigine who is abducted from her bush family and grows up in a white environment in Adelaide. ''I was certainly growing, but I stayed black,'' reads an early passage. ''Would I fade or what?''

title: Help for Parents
description: With many parents expressing concern about violence and vulgarity on television, and with some pointing the finger especially at cable because of its wide range of programs, cable executives decided late last year they needed a public relations boost.

title: MACY'S TO PHASE OUT SALES OF ELECTRONIC ITEMS
description: Macy's said yesterday that it planned to clear out television sets, VCR's and stereos to make more room for clothing and bedding. Macy's, a unit of Federated Department Stores, said its electronics departments involved disproportionate investments of money, management time and other resources. The company said it would use the store space for women's ready-to-wear, men's apparel, home furnishings and other departments. Macy's said affected sales employees would be offered other positions or a severance package.

description: The Dow Chemical Company sued the General Electric Company today, accusing it of ''systematically and aggressively'' hiring Dow employees privy to trade secrets, the latest in a series of moves by American companies to prevent important officials from going to work for competitors.

title: More Than a Friend
description: David Schwimmer, a star of NBC's ''Friends,'' has not given up his dreams of expanding beyond his role as Ross on that hit comedy.

title: The Missing Drug Millions: Just a Misunderstanding?
description: When United States officials learned recently that a suspected Mexican drug trafficker had managed to hold onto tens of millions of dollars that had been ordered frozen in a money-laundering investigation, they wasted no time denouncing what they saw as new evidence of corruption south of the border.

title: U.N. Committee Puts Off Decision on Parking Issue
description: A United Nations committee yesterday postponed until April 10 a decision on whether to ask the General Assembly to condemn Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan for forcing diplomats to pay their parking fines as a breach of international law and demand its suspension.

description: In more than five years as Governor, Boris Nemtsov has labored mightily to make this Volga River region a bastion of free-market reform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARFUNKEL, LOUIS
description: KARFUNKEL-Louis. The administration, faculty, and students of Touro College record with sorrow the passing of the beloved father of Mr. Michael Karfunkel, a member of the Board of Trustees of the College, and chairman of the Flatbush Division Board of Directors, & his brother Mr. George Karfunkel, a member of the Flatbush Division Board of Directors. Mr. Louis (Yisroel Yehudah) Karfunkel, an author of scholarly Talmudic treatises, together with his beloved wife, Clara, imbued his sons with a passion for Torah learning, a commitment to tzedakah, & a dedication for nurturing future generations of the Jewish people through philanthropic support and leadership of 7enters of Torah scholarship and institutions of higher learning. His legacy lives on in the examplary deeds and generosity of his sons, Michael and George. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Mrs. Clara Karfunkel, the matriarch of the family, and to her sons. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Bernard Lander, President Mr. Mark Hasten, Chairman of the Board

title: Not All Plastic Is Created Equal When It Comes to Renting a Car

title: DYNATECH SHEDS UNITS FOR $61 MILLION IN CASH AND STOCK
description: The Dynatech Corporation, a maker of communications equipment, said yesterday that it had sold three units for $50 million in cash and $11 million in securities. Dynatech, based in Burlington, Mass., said it had sold Computerized Medical Systems Inc., Dynatech Video Group Inc. and the products and international distribution business of Dynatech Communications Inc. Dynatech said the units were sold to three different buyers. In February 1996, the company said it would shrink itself by 40 percent by selling its broadcast video equipment and selected data transmission units. At the time, the businesses represented $290 million in annual revenue.

title: Hints of Horror, Shouts of Protest
description: For budget-strapped school librarians, the gift of a box of books is often greeted like a favorite long-lost cousin.

title: For Now, Pettitte Puts Money Matters Aside
description: When Andy Pettitte strolls to the mound against the Mariners on Wednesday night, his focus will be on their mighty lineup. Fortunately for his own team, Pettitte said he would not be thinking about the way in which the Yankees have treated contract matters in his brief career.

title: JOHN ALDEN FINANCIAL PLANS TO ELIMINATE 725 JOBS
description: The John Alden Financial Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 725 jobs this year to cut costs and focus on its group health insurance and managed-care businesses. About 250 of the jobs being cut are in annuity and credit card businesses, which John Alden, an insurance company based in Miami, is leaving. The other 475 job cuts, representing 20 percent of the company's remaining staff, are ''a necessary step in successfully positioning this company for the future,'' its chief executive said. The company said it would take a $15 million charge against earnings for the cost of dismissing workers.

title: Death By Duck
description: There is a phenomenon in Beijing called ''death by duck.''

title: Fiscal Oversight for Camden
description: The final straw came last November, when Mayor Arnold W. Webster of Camden refused to lay off 67 city workers to balance his 1997 budget, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday. Convinced that the city was unable to cope with its financial crisis, the Governor said she would submit legislation to create a fiscal oversight board.

title: Messinger Joins Battle Over Denied Records
description: Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President and a Democratic candidate for mayor, joined the battle over the Giuliani administration's information policy yesterday by demanding that 33 city agencies disclose requests for information that were denied.

title: Saudi Arabian Prince Says He Bought Stake in Apple
description: Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia has purchased more than 5 percent of the shares of Apple Computer Inc.

title: Inflation Data Help to Lift Bond Prices
description: Prices for Treasury securities rebounded from early losses yesterday as new data suggested that inflation was still subdued, even as manufacturing continued to hum along.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, FRANCIS JOSEPH
description: O'BRIEN-Francis Joseph, 71, of Spring Lake, N.J., formerly of Bklyn, NY on April 1, 1997. Beloved husband of Ellin (nee Amorosi). Dear father of Dr. Francis J. of Manhattan, Paul E. of New Canaan, CT, Matthew L., Christopher J. of Spring Lake and beloved grandfather of two. He was a graduate of Regis High School, Holy Cross College and Fordham Law School. He was a partner for many years at Hill, Rivkins, Loesberg, O'Brien, Mulroy & Hayden, an admiralty law firm in NY City, an internationally known lecturer and authority in maritime law. He was past-president of the Maritime Law Association of the U.S., a member of the Comite Maritime Int'l, and associate editor of the Journal, American Maritime Cases. He also served on the Board of Governors of the Downtown Athletic Club and India House in NY City and was a member of the Lake Placid Club and the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club. Funeral from the Meehan Funeral Home, 55 Warren Avenue, Spring Lake Heights, NJ on Thursday, April 3, 1997. Mass of Christian burial 9:30 AM, St. Mark's RC Church, Sea Girt, NJ. Interment St. Anne's Cemetery, Wall, NJ. Visitation Wednesday 2:00-5:00 PM, 7:00-10:00 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to Regis High School, 55 East 84th Street, NYC would be appreciated.

title: Chrysler Reports Flat Sales In Key Light-Truck Market
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which rode demand for its rugged Jeeps and roomy mini-vans to near-record profits last year, said today that its sales of the high-profit vehicles had leveled off.

title: Right Decision on 'Must Carry'
description: Ending a five-year legal struggle with major implications for the future direction of telecommunications, a closely divided Supreme Court this week upheld a 1992 Federal law that requires cable television systems to carry the signals of local over-the-air broadcast stations. In an environment where cable monopolies still have the power to control what programs most Americans see, this was the right outcome to insure the wide dissemination of information from diverse sources.

title: Tolls Not Expected to Rise
description: The Port Authority lost $67 million on its bridges and tunnels last year, but tolls will remain at their current level because profits from the area's three airports are rising, officials said yesterday.

title: Taking a Bolder Step in Adding Depth to the Dazzle
description: Yevgeny Kissin was a callow youth of 18 when he made his American debut at a New York Philharmonic concert in 1990 and his recital debut at Carnegie Hall two weeks later, but he impressed a tough audience as a mature, technically proficient player for whom the densest scoring of Chopin, Schumann, Liszt and Prokofiev held no terrors. The question that remained was whether Mr. Kissin would be as eloquent in repertory that demands depth and acuity as he was in dazzling showpieces.

title: Old Foe of Mobutu Is Chosen Premier of Zaire
description: In an effort to mollify a growing rebel movement, Parliament elected as Prime Minister a longtime foe of Zaire's dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, after nearly eight hours of intense debate today.

title: A New Butterfly Makes Her Debut at the Met
description: The young soprano Michele Crider has already sung at Covent Garden, La Scala and other major international houses. But her Metropolitan Opera debut on Monday night in the title role of Puccini's ''Madama Butterfly'' had to have been a touchstone for this Illinois-born singer. It also must have put her under a lot of pressure, which probably accounts for the shakiness of her work in Act I. But as the performance progressed, the special qualities of her talent became clear.

title: Pollution Hurts Clammers
description: A sewage spill that has raised pollution levels in Lakes Bay west of Atlantic City is forcing commercial clammers to miss out on one of the best weeks in the local clamming season, an industry representative said yesterday.

title: Georgetown University Fills Shakespeare Gap
description: Attacked a few years ago for allowing English majors to graduate without studying any Shakespeare, Georgetown University, with the help of Cambridge University Press, is publishing a magazine called Shakespeare.

title: Ratings In for N.C.A.A. Final
description: Arizona's overtime victory over Kentucky in the men's basketball national championship game Monday night produced an 18.9 Nielsen rating for CBS, up 3 percent from an 18.3 last year when Kentucky beat Syracuse for the title. The rating for the final game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament had declined each year since 1992. The entire tournament generated a 7.2 rating, down by 4 percent from 1996.

title: Unpersecuted, an Old Faith Withers in Japan
description: When Kinshiro Ichinose was beheaded here in 1622 for believing in Jesus, his last words were, ''The time will come when the teachings of Christianity will spread once more.''

description: KATZ-Stanley. Together again with Roy. Always in our thoughts. Happy Birthday Love, Geri

title: ST. LAURENT PAPERBOARD TO BUY CHESAPEAKE ASSETS
description: St. Laurent Paperboard Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a paper mill, four plants and other assets from the Chesapeake Corporation for about $508 million. St. Laurent Paperboard, a forest products company based in Montreal, would pay about $425 million in cash and as much as $75 million in stock. It also would assume about $8 million in tax-exempt debt, Chesapeake said. Chesapeake's products include napkins, tablecloths, towels, facial tissue and bathroom tissue. Chesapeake, which is based in Richmond, said that it wanted to focus on its faster-growing packaging and tissue operations. Chesapeake stock was up $2.75, to $30, in trading yesterday.

She is the second-youngest golfer to qualify for an L.P.G.A. event.

title: Like Showers, Bears Appear Each April
description: WINTER blew in for half a day, and life here tumbled back about a hundred years. The two feet of snow on Route 23 kept the kids home from school, toppled trees over the power lines and turned the fireplace into the hub of the household. This is not something people get used to, even when it happens time and time again.

title: Carlton of Britain Buys Rank's Film Library

title: Quitting Smokeless Tobacco Exhausts Harnisch
description: Pete Harnisch stared at the darkness of his hotel room in the early-morning hours on Tuesday, wondering why he could not sleep, wondering why he suddenly felt chilled and covered with perspiration. He looked at Donna, his wife, who was dozing, and Harnisch decided not to wake her.

title: OMEGA HEALTHCARE BUYS 12 CARE HOMES FOR $58 MILLION
description: Omega Healthcare Investors Inc. said that it had purchased 12 health operations for a total of $58.4 million. Omega Healthcare said in a statement that it had bought 11 nursing homes in Alabama, Texas, Illinois, Louisiana and Florida for $52.5 million from four partnerships, including Qualicorp Inc. The properties were then leased back to the sellers at rents that total about $5.7 million annually. Omega also said that it had purchased one operation in Washington State from Sun Healthcare Group for $5.9 million. Omega Healthcare Investors is a real estate investment trust based in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Welfare for Webster Hubbell
description: The White House would like everyone to believe that its interest in Webster Hubbell's welfare was purely altruistic, but as disclosures accumulate, baser motives seem increasingly plausible. The evidence points to a possible effort to obstruct justice by securing Mr. Hubbell's silence on crucial elements of the Whitewater case. That effort may have overlapped with the White House fund-raising abuses.

title: Uncertainty Undercuts Case Against Saudi Bomb Suspect

title: Idle Time, Petty Crime: Night of the Scavenger Hunt

One minute a figure in black was hacksawing through a handicapped-parking sign in the Waldbaum's parking lot, the next minute a thief with more modest goals was stealing plastic straws from a McDonald's restaurant. Stop signs everywhere were vanishing.

title: Credit Card Processor Sold

He also served on the Board of Governors of the Downtown Athletic Club and India House in NY City and was a member of the Lake Placid Club and the Spring Lake Golf and Country Club. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUHMANN, FREDERICK J.
description: SCHUHMANN-Frederick J., age 69, died April 1st. Mr. Schuhmann served in the U.S. Army during World War Two in the Philippine Islands. He started his career at ABC Television in 1949 as a part time page in a live theater while attending St. Francis College in Brooklyn, New York. He was named Director of Production Services in 1960. In 1965 he was promoted to Vice President T.V. Facilities and Services Broadcast Operations and Engineering-East Coast. He retired from ABC in June of 1985 as Vice President and Director of Tape ProductionsEast Coast. From 1985 to 1990 he was Vice President and General Manager of Riverview Productions for D'Arcy Masius Benton and Bowles. He remained as a television production consultant until his death. He was an Adjunct Associate Professor at St. John's University from 1970 to 1986 and received the ''President's Medal'' for outstanding service from St. John's University. He was a member of the Instructional Television Advisory Board for the Archdiocese of New York from 1970 to 1990. Mr. Schuhmann was a respected member of the Village of Rockville Centre, NY, where he lived for 40 years. He will be remembered for his 20 year service to the Rockville Centre Boys Basketball League, as Commissioner of CYO Basketball and his production of various variety shows for St. Agnes Cathedral. He was an active member of the Knights of Columbus and leaves behind a legacy of giving. Beloved husband of Miriam of 44 years, and loving father of Jeanne Ehmann, Mary Lilly, James, Paul, Ann Occhipinti, Elizabeth Arianas, Andrew, Therese and Michael. Loving grandfather of Terrence, Paul, Bernadette, Maureen, Kelly Ann and Michael. Loving son of Marie Schloderer of Watertown NY. Loving brother of Frances of Oakdale NY, and Marie Heitmann of Santa Barbara, California. A Wake service was held at 7:00 PM Wednesday, April 2nd, at Forest Hills Funeral Home in Palm City. A Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated 9:30 AM, on Thursday April 3, at Holy Redeemer Catholic Church in Palm City. Burial will be private at Forest Hills Memorial Park in Palm City. Visitation was from 2:00-4:00 PM and 6:00-8:00 PM on Wednesday at the funeral home. Memorial contributions may be made to Martin Memorial Foundation, Post Office Box 9010, Stuart, Florida 34995.

title: STAPLES AND OFFICE DEPOT CLOSER TO MERGER
description: The staff of the Federal Trade Commission recommended that the agency approve the proposed $4 billion merger of the office supply discounters Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc., officials said yesterday. In a draft settlement agreement, staff members who studied the merger urged the five-member panel to approve the deal on condition that the two companies divest themselves of 63 stores to their sole competitor, Officemax Inc. The commission has scheduled a meeting tomorrow at which the merger is expected to be considered. The commission voted 4 to 1 three weeks ago to block the merger, contending that it would violate Federal antitrust laws and lead to higher prices. Staples and Office Depot countered with the plan to sell the 63 stores to Officemax in markets where the combined firm would have no competition.

Indeed Labor and the ruling Conservatives now have nearly identical positions on a wide range of issues. Still, a victory for Labor on May 1 would have significant domestic and international consequences.

title: A Boy's Rude Introduction to a Fearsome Sexual Reality
description: ''Sous-Sol,'' Pierre Gang's film about an 11-year-old boy's traumatic sexual awakening, is notable mostly for the direction it doesn't take. Late one night, Rene (Richard Moffatt), the imaginative only child of a troubled marriage, steals into his parents' bedroom and surreptitiously watches them making love. What appears to be an act of violence (his father is tethered to the bedpost, and his mother looms over him), is confirmed in his mind the next morning when his father is found dead. Naturally the youngster, who feared his gruff, ill-tempered father, believes his mother, Reine (Louise Portal), murdered him, and he is secretly glad.

title: Pro-Choice and Pro-Life

The Senate may soon address the issue, but even if it fails to override President Clinton's promised veto, the pro-choice movement is staring at a great symbolic defeat.

description: Amid the peaceful, rapturous purity of the Mongolian steppes, Xie Fei's lovely new film tells a simple and resonant story. With dreamy tranquillity, ''A Mongolian Tale'' tells of two children raised in an idyllic paradise. It progresses from the time when a boy named Beiyinpalica and girl named Someyer are taken in by the kindly, grandmotherly Nai Nai (Miss Dalarsurong) to when these childhood sweethearts are separated by their adult destinies.

title: ABC Does Drugs
description: In the no-good-deed-goes-unpunished sweepstakes, pity poor ABC. Unable to win Nielsen rating points, the number-3 network spent all of March in search of Brownie points by staging a ''March Against Drugs,'' in which everyone from its soap-opera stars to its news anchors enlisted in the drug war by participating in public-service commercials and special drug-oriented programming. The payoff? ABC's efforts have been sniped at by journalists and drug-war reformers like Common Sense for Drug Policy and ignored by most everyone else. The heavily publicized grand finale of ABC's long March -- a town meeting with kids and parents conducted by Peter Jennings on Sunday night -- drew a pitiful 6 percent of the TV audience, the smallest of the network's season. Billed by ABC as the ''D-Day'' of its anti-drug offensive, it was more reminiscent of Tet.

title: Rider's Bannon Is Named Rutgers Coach
description: Rutgers ended its 28-day-old search for a head basketball coach last night by hiring Kevin Bannon of Rider, who led the school to two National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament appearances in eight seasons.

title: In Agassi He Trusts
description: TOM GULLIKSON, captain of the United States Davis Cup team, said yesterday from Newport Beach, Calif., site of this weekend's quarterfinal against the Netherlands, that he is not worried that one of his team's two singles players, ANDRE AGASSI, is mired in a five-match losing streak.

description: FASHION groupies, take note: bridge may become de rigueur this spring. Or then again, perhaps, strip poker.

In Warren, Sussex and western Morris Counties, 18,000 GPU Energy customers were waiting for power to come back on, said Ron Morano, a company spokesman. The company hoped to have electricity fully restored by midday today, he said.

description: Scientists have been accused of playing God when they clone sheep, and of naysaying God when they insist that evolution be taught in school, but as a new study indicates, many scientists believe in God by the most mainstream, uppercase definition of the concept.

description: An appeals court ruled today that a man should be executed by firing squad and his body crucified for three days near where he shot four children and two teachers to death.

description: The Federal Reserve, still smarting from the unauthorized disclosure last September of highly sensitive financial information, has acted to clear up what it called a ''misunderstanding'' that resulted in an outside consultant taking part in a meeting at its Chicago regional bank where classified data were discussed.

title: Westpac Makes Offer For Bank of Melbourne
description: The Westpac Banking Corporation, which is based in Sydney, said today that it had made a takeover bid of $1.44 billion (Australian), or $1.13 billion (United States), for Bank of Melbourne Ltd., a regional bank in Australia's Victoria state. Bank of Melbourne directors recommended that shareholders accept the bid.

title: Brokers Shed Old Habits to Attract New Investors
description: David H. Beyer's luck had run out. The stockbroker's best client, a 56-year-old heir to a garment fortune who loved playing the market, died of a heart attack. Overnight, Mr. Beyer's commissions at Paine Webber Inc. took a dive, jolting him into action.

description: The Rite Aid Corporation, which owns and operates drugstores, said yesterday that it had named DeWitt Media in New York to handle the media planning and buying portions of its account, with billings estimated at $40 million to $45 million. The account had been handled by Marc Advertising in Pittsburgh since June 1995.
