description: So what if Michael D. Eisner, the chairman of the Walt Disney Company, referred to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as Mayor Cuomo? There were no hard feelings. And anyway, no less a personage than Gov. George E. Pataki reassured Mr. Eisner that the Mayor did not plan to retaliate ''and refer to you as Chairman Ovitz.''

title: Dividing Ellis Island
description: The decision by a special arbitrator for the United States Supreme Court to award a large chunk of Ellis Island to New Jersey is obviously dismaying to New Yorkers. This page has long argued that New York's claim to be the gateway for millions of immigrants to America is rooted in history and symbolism, and we wish Attorney General Dennis Vacco well when he appeals the decision to the Supreme Court itself in the fall.

title: New Orders To Factories Rose Again In February
description: New orders received by United States factories rose in February for the second consecutive month, the Government reported today in the latest sign of strong economic growth.

title: MCDONALD'S TO DROP PRICE OF BREAKFAST SANDWICHES
description: The McDonald's Corporation said that it would begin to sell breakfast sandwiches for 55 cents tomorrow, kicking off a price-cutting campaign the company is counting on to increase its sluggish United States sales. The fast-food chain is also restructuring its Value Meal program by creating a My Size Meal promotion to accommodate light eaters, said Ed Rensi, chief executive of McDonald's USA. Damon Brundage, an analyst with NatWest Securities Inc., said the problem at McDonald's ''isn't the pricing, it's the food. They're making a huge bet here that they can charge less for mediocre food and people will beat a path to their door.''

title: F.C.C. Is Ready To Ease Timing On Digital TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission reached general agreement today on a new rule that would require network television stations in the nation's 10 largest broadcast markets to begin transmitting digital programming within two years.

title: Abundance of Enzyme Found Within Cancerous Breast Cells
description: Scientists have found that many breast cancer cells have elevated levels of an enzyme associated with cell growth.

title: American Express Redesigns Checks to Keep Ahead of Forgers
description: Hoping to foil counterfeiters, American Express introduced redesigned traveler's checks yesterday that it said were safer and easier for merchants to verify. The new checks, in denominations of $50, $100, $500 and $1,000, are on sale in the United States and will be available in other countries in September.

title: Memos to Clinton and Gore Detailed Party Fund-Raising
description: President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore received a constant stream of memorandums providing them the most minute details of the Democratic Party's fund-raising in 1996, including monthly dollar tallies and projected sums to be raised at scores of events, White House coffees among them, according to documents released by the White House today.

title: No Headline
description: ''We have a lot of traffic problems here. But Reinhold helps a lot, providing a very real patrol presence. He works 24 hours a day, and we don't have to pay him overtime or benefits.''

title: Casually Justifying Why They Killed Gay Men
description: Bizarre civility permeates Arthur Dong's chilling documentary ''Licensed to Kill.'' The film maker politely interrogates a series of convicted killers about their crimes, all of which involved hatred of gay men. Himself the victim of a gay-bashing attack in San Francisco 20 years ago, Mr. Dong brings an implicit sense of outrage to these interviews, but he keeps it carefully in check. That lets him coax forth the killers' astonishing casualness and the shocking sense of entitlement with which they justify this brand of murder.

title: Corrections

The evidence they provided suggested that if Rigoberto Gaxiola Medina, a drug-trafficking suspect, had been told his assets were going to be frozen, that must have happened long before his accounts were ordered seized, and not afterward.

But donations are always encouraged. The New York City Department for the Aging can make further referrals; (212) 442-1000. The Jewish Association for Services for the Aged will mail a home-safety checklist to identify problem areas. Write to the JASA Help Center at 40 West 68th Street, New York 10023.

That appears to be the view of officials from the Treasury, the Office of Management and Budget and the President's Council of Economic Advisers, whose recently disclosed comments question the rationale for the Environmental Protection Agency's proposed air quality standards for ozone and soot.

Millions now know enough about endorphins, blood pressure, cholesterol and the effects of various drugs to talk a decent beginner's game of medical self-analysis. But the Los Angeles performance artist who is the subject of Kirby Dick's unforgettable documentary film, ''Sick: The Life and Death of Bob Flanagan, Supermasochist,'' specialized in a kind of physical self-knowledge many of us would rather not contemplate.

He sent out the filly Winning Colors to win this race in 1988, and he will be trying to do it again on Saturday here at Santa Anita with another filly, Sharp Cat.

title: KOHLBERG KRAVIS TO INVEST IN TEXAS GROCERY CHAIN
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company said yesterday that it would invest $225 million in Randalls Food Markets, getting a majority stake in the closely held grocery store chain. Randalls, which operates 70 Randalls stores in Houston and Austin, Tex., and 51 Tom Thumb stores in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, has annual revenue of about $2.4 billion. The investment by the New York-based buyout firm will allow the chain to reduce its debt, remodel stores and buy locations. Kohlberg Kravis has invested heavily in supermarket chains, including Fred Meyer Inc., Bruno's Inc., Safeway Inc. and Stop and Shop.

title: Test Reactor For Fusion Shuts Down In New Jersey

title: Kohl Tells Germans He'll Run For an Unparalleled 5th Term

title: Blood, Fire and Bombs Before an Impassive Face

It has these three meet violently in Rome for a showdown in the Colosseum involving land mines, a baby and a Bengal tiger, eventually leaving the great landmark engulfed in special-effects flames. If you have to ask why, then the flashy, cheesy, overheated ''Double Team'' is not for you. Anyway, don't confuse it with ''Double Impact,'' an earlier Van Damme outing in which the star played twins.

title: Restaurants
description: The couple in the corner were staring glumly at their plates as the carnival atmosphere swirled around them. In the huge room, they were the only people not having fun. ''It's so much food,'' the woman said with distaste. She shoved her plate away just as a waiter arrived with another skewer of meat. Looking at the ribs threaded along it with something akin to loathing, she said insistently: ''I can't eat any more. Really.'' The waiter moved sadly away, his shoulders slumped, as if he had been personally rejected.

title: Hard Times for Immigrants

The law strips even legal residents of the right to go to court to challenge decisions on deportation by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. It also attempts to remove most judicial checks on the I.N.S., an agency with a record of mismanagement, discrimination and brutality.

description: With every emotional syllable about his deceased mother, David Wells's face turner redder, his eyes turned more moist and his speech turned slower. With every thought of returning to California knowing she is gone, Wells acted like any tearful son who is suddenly trying to cope with a void that can never be filled.

description: WESTHEIMER - Manfred. Fred was an aficionado of classical music and an active supporter of our Sunday Concert Series. He loved the Washington Hts. community, especially Ft. title: Diner's Journal

title: The Appeal Of Modest Durability
description: One line of thinking advanced by the new production team at the New York City Opera is to stage standard repertory works less expensively than in the past so that the productions can be discarded and restaged more often. Operagoers who find it difficult to imagine some of the company's stagings becoming even less elaborate may find this alarming; yet its presentations of contemporary operas, mounted inexpensively because the prospect of their return was slim, have shown that inventiveness can be had on a tiny budget. And there is much to be said for the flexibility this approach can offer.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN SAYS IT WILL SELL STAKE IN 10 BUSINESSES
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation agreed yesterday to sell a controlling stake in 10 aerospace and military communications businesses to an investment group led by Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. The transaction is valued at $525 million. Lockheed is paring its businesses after combining with Martin Marietta in 1995 and the Loral Corporation in 1996. The businesses had combined 1996 revenue of more than $650 million. Lehman Brothers Capital Partners III L.P., a merchant banking partnership, will own about 50 percent of the new company, which will be called L3 Communications Holdings Inc. and will be based in New York. Lockheed Martin will hold 35 percent and management will hold the rest. Lockheed Martin's shares fell $2.25 yesterday, to $79.25.

title: Having Some Playful Fun With Contemporary Works
description: Humor is not something listeners immediately associate with contemporary music, although anyone who spends time with the repertory is likely to encounter some, even among the works by composers generally considered dour. Speculum Musicae offered an unusually cheery view of the new-music landscape on Tuesday evening at the Miller Theater. Stopping short of tomfoolery (April Fool's Day notwithstanding), the musicians presented works with a wry humor that undercut the self-importance from which so many new works suffer.

title: Official Attacks Plan for Mining Project
description: Standing at the Okefenokee Swamp, an alligator lounging behind him, Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt took an unequivocal public stand today against the Du Pont Company's plans to strip mine along the eastern ridge bordering this wildlife refuge.

title: Not the Man She Thought He Was
description: A well-worn narrative strategy adopted by film makers hoping to give their movies an edge in the sensitivity sweepstakes is to cloud their characters in mystery for as long as possible. That way we can let our imaginations run wild just as they would if we were fantasizing the life story of a stranger based on nothing more than appearance, dress and body language.

title: U.S. Sues Election Board on School District Vote Tampering
description: The Justice Department filed suit against the New York City Board of Elections yesterday, charging that poll workers violated the rights of minority-group voters in a Bronx school district by tampering with ballots in favor of a white candidate in last spring's election.

title: Chicago 7 Survivor Hopes to Be No. 1 in Los Angeles

title: MARRIOTT TO SELL 14 HOTELS TO HOSPITALITY PROPERTIES
description: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell 10 Residence Inns and four Courtyard hotels to Hospitality Properties Trust for about $149 million in cash. Marriott, which is based in Washington, said it would continue to operate the 14 hotels under long-term leases. Seven of the hotels are in operation; the other seven are under construction and are expected to open during 1997. The 14 hotels have 1,819 rooms, Marriott said. Hospitality Properties, which is based in Newton, Mass., is a real estate investment trust.

During President Clinton's first Administration, officials at Defense made a start in abandoning this cold war policy. But they have a long way to go.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS SAYS IT IS STILL INTERESTED IN RIVAL

The executive, Morry Weiss, said that although American Greetings was not pursuing Gibson, he would like to reopen discussions about a possible combination of American, the second-largest maker of greeting cards, and Gibson, the third largest. Gibson's president and chief executive, Frank O'Connell, declined to comment. Only the closely held Hallmark Cards Inc. is larger than American Greetings.

description: BECAUSE we're used to thinking of Louise Nevelson (1899-1988) as a creator of large works and grand effects, the scale and subject matter of her early sculptures and drawings at the Washburn Gallery come as a bit of a surprise. The squat, blocky Cubist-derived figurative imagery of her sculptures is a far cry in form and content from the big, architectural grandiosities she produced later. But these early pieces are intriguing, the more so because they represent a period in which she learned how to work in sculptural forms.

Activists have complained that the law, which applies mainly to illegal immigrants, is, in the overused word of the day, Draconian.

title: Geography at the Next Level
description: Thomas Brazda knows the current name of the body of water once known as the Sea of Cortez and the Vermilion Sea. And because of that, Thomas, an eighth grader from Ringwood, will soon visit the banks of the Potomac to compete in the finals of the National Geographic Society geography bee. Thomas won the state contest yesterday in Piscataway by correctly identifying the Gulf of California, which separates Baja California from the mainland of Mexico, as being formerly called the Sea of Cortez. He won $100 for his troubles, plus the right to compete for a $25,000 scholarship in Washington next month. If he wins, he will be upholding a proud tradition: last year's national champion was Seyi Sayanju of Verona. ANDY NEWMAN

title: Thwarting the Drug Trade
description: Despite a $20 billion interdiction effort over a decade, supplies of cocaine and heroin continue to flood in at a level more than adequate to meet the demand of American drug users. That is the dismal judgment of the General Accounting Office in a recently released report. The G.A.O., a research agency for Congress, blames the nation's lagging effort to control the flow of drugs on a lack of long-term strategic planning. The Clinton Administration's latest budget request makes a start on addressing these shortcomings. Congress should follow and even enhance the new effort.

title: Lesson of the Bamboo Crates
description: Following are excerpts from some winning essays in Barnard College's annual writing competition for 11th-grade girls in New York City's public schools. The theme is ''A Woman I Admire.'' Di Yin Lu of the Bronx High School of Science won first prize.

title: Relievers Are Goats Again for Mets, As Mlicki's Solid Effort Is Wasted
description: The Mets' bullpen did not blow a lead tonight, which is news. But the relievers botched another game, which is also news.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the restoration of screenwriting credits to blacklisted authors who wrote under pseudonyms in the McCarthy era misattributed ''The Defiant Ones.'' The film was written by Nedrick Young (who used the pseudonym Nathan E. Douglas) and Harold Jacob Smith, not by Albert Maltz.

title: Informer Tried to Sell Information to Indicted Nightclub Owner
description: Court documents filed in the drug-racketeering case against Peter Gatien, the nightclub owner, show that a Government informer offered to sell Mr. Gatien information about Government misconduct in the case.

title: Deregulation Won't Bring Higher Phone Bills
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., agreed to buy the Tridom satellite communications unit from AT&T for an undisclosed sum.

description: SCHNEIDER-Stanley Jerome, on Thursday, April 3, 1997. Stanley Jerome of Evanston, IL. Beloved husband of June (nee Glickman) and for thirty-seven years the late Goldelie (nee Meyer). Devoted father of Daniel Schneider, Naomi Schneider and Judith Leah Schneider. Dear brother of Martin Schneider. Loving grandfather of Gabrielle, Jacob Louis, Rebecca Sara, Nathanael Oscar, Mara Goldie, Eli Abraham and Emily. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vaux Hall Road, Union, New Jersey, on Sunday, April 6, 1997 at 10:00 A.M. Interment in the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. A memorial service will be held at the Evanston Public Library, Evanston, IL on April 19, 1997.

description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: ''All my family is dead. Father, mother, all my brothers and sisters. I want to go back to Rwanda. I have nobody. I am alone.''

title: Barney's Indicates Other Bids Are Near
description: Barney's Inc., the New York retailer that has been operating under bankruptcy protection, indicated yesterday that it was close to receiving more takeover offers.

title: Knight-Ridder to Buy 4 Newspapers From Disney for $1.65 Billion
description: Knight-Ridder Inc., the nation's second-largest newspaper company, said yesterday that it was buying The Kansas City Star in Missouri, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram and two smaller newspapers owned by the Walt Disney Company for $1.65 billion.

title: Hedi Kravis, Chic Society's Interior Designer, 49
description: Helene-Diane Shulman Kravis Ruger, an interior designer known professionally as Hedi Kravis, died on Wednesday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Ms. Kravis, who maintained homes in Manhattan and Bedford, N.Y., was 49.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

description: KAGAN-Shlomo. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, NY mourns the untimely passing of our beloved member Shlomo Kagan and extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Naomi and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Dr. Philip Adler, President

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, a picture on Thursday showing Rubens's ''Raising of the Cross,'' a painting seized by the Nazis and recovered by France, was reproduced in mirror image in some editions. In the center panel of the triptych, Jesus' head actually points to the left.

title: Japan Pledges To Monitor Its Trade Surplus
description: Responding to American concerns, Japanese leaders said today that they would try to hold their resurgent trade surplus in check.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, JOSEPHINE M. (NEE SAVINSKY)
description: HOGAN-Josephine M. (nee Savinsky), of Highland Falls, NY, died April 1, 1997 on Kiawah Island, SC. Wife of the late William. Devoted mother of Carol, W. Daniel, Mary, Jo Ann, Michael, Rita, Sara, Elizabeth and William. Beloved sister of Teresa O'Haco. Cherished grandmother of 17 and greatgrandmother of three. Longtime friend of Gene Benner. Friends may call 1-5PM & 7-9PM, Sunday at the William F. Hogan Funeral Home, Highland Falls, NY. Funeral Mass on Monday at 10AM at Sacred Heart Church, Highland Falls, New York. Interment will be in Peacedale Cemetery, Highland Falls. Contributions to the Orange County A.H.R.C. Hogan Memorial, 249 Broadway, Newburgh, NY 12550, attention: Pat Carfizzi, or to the Leukemia Society, would be appreciated.

title: A.& P. to Return to Old Site
description: For more than two decades, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company -- A.& P. to shoppers -- had its Eastern Region office in Paterson. But in 1982, the company moved all but 20 or so employees from the office to its world headquarters in Montvale. Now, A.& P. will restock its Paterson office with 325 administrative, accounting, and computer workers, Michael Rourke, a company spokesman, said yesterday. About 125 of those jobs will be filled by people recently hired, many from the area, Mr. Rourke said.

title: France Rejects G.E. of Britain
description: France said today that it had rejected the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain as a prime bidder for the state's 58 percent stake in Thomson-CSF, saying that allowing the British company to control the maker of military electronics would be contrary to ''essential interests of national security.''

title: The N.H.L. Loves to See That Blood
description: I WENT to a hockey game the other evening at Madison Square Garden, and when it was over I had a mind to sue the National Hockey League for false representation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRA, CATHERINE ANNE
description: BARRA-Catherine Anne. On April 3, 1997. Beloved wife of Dr. Francis X. Barra, loving mother of Thomas and Allison, dear daughter of Elizabeth and the late Joseph Keane, fond sister of Mary Spiess, Patricia Dunleavy, Eileen Luby, Gerard, Anne Heinzerling, Joseph, Susan Ehler and James. Reposing Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach. Funeral Mass at St. Francis De Sales Church Monday at 9:45 AM. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9.

title: Judge Orders Legal Fees Paid To Settle F. Lee Bailey's Debt
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered a former law partner of the famed defense attorney F. Lee Bailey to release $700,000 in disputed legal fees and turn the money over to the Federal Government, settling a debt that might have sent Mr. Bailey back to prison if it had not been paid by April 19.

title: Feel-Good Opening For Giants
description: When Giants Coach Jim Fassel met with the team Thursday night, he had the attention of everyone in the room. He told the players that if they thought last season's problems walked out the door with the former coaching staff, they were wrong.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARFUNKEL, LOUIS
description: KARFUNKEL-Louis. The Board of Directors and Staff of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourn the loss of Louis Karfunkel, beloved father of our esteemed Board member Michael Karfunkel. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Tom L. Freudenheim, Exec. Dir. YIVO Institute for Jewish Research

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CEASER, DOROTHY (NEE LEFKOWITZ)
description: CEASER-Dorothy (nee Lefkowitz). Age 95. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Betty Savage, Roslyn Singer and the late Vincent. Loving grandmother of 7. Darling great-grandmother of 12. Graveside services on Sunday 2 PM at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: Pathetic, Not Tragic
description: To the Editor:

title: The Adventures of Alcott's First Feisty Heroine
description: Just a year ago, scholars announced the rediscovery of Louisa May Alcott's first novel, ''The Inheritance,'' written when she was around 17. For decades the manuscript had languished at Harvard, misfiled. Though the book has still not been published, it turns up tomorrow night as ''Louisa May Alcott's 'The Inheritance,' '' an unexpectedly charming and pretty family film.

title: Kitty Carlisle Hart's Little Something Extra
description: For Kitty Carlisle Hart, her new role performing a one-woman show is ''lagniappe.'' She draws that Creole word from her New Orleans childhood and says it means ''a little something extra.''

title: Shuttle Lifts Off on Mission to Explore Lack of Gravity
description: The space shuttle Columbia rose on yellow blasts of flame today into a deep blue sky, carrying a crew of seven on a 16-day mission to explore the subtleties of a lack of gravity.

title: Requiem for and by Brahms, Blessed for a Hundred Years
description: The 100th anniversary of Brahms's death, on Thursday, was occasion enough to fill the evening, as Robert Shaw led a performance of the composer's ''German Requiem'' at Carnegie Hall. But another anniversary, one that passed last year with little note, crowded the mind as well.

title: Spring Sprang Sprung
description: It's hard to keep your mind on chicanery in the spring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, PAUL
description: SILVERSTEIN-Paul, on April 4, 1997, in his 87th year. Beloved husband of Dorothy. Cherished brother-in-law of Joyce. Loving uncle of Gail, Lila, Janice, Francine, William, Jonah and Isaac. Services Sunday, 12:15 PM, ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be sent to The Alzheimer's Association of New York, Brandeis University National Women's Committee Manhattan Chapter or The Lucy Moses School of Music in New York City.

title: Jury Acquits Officer Accused of Sex Abuse
description: After seven days of deliberation, a Nassau County jury late yesterday acquitted George Alvarado, a 29-year-old New York City police officer from Bellmore, L.I., of charges that he raped and sodomized his 9-year-old daughter.

title: Tuition Gifts From a Son Of Immigrants
description: IN this season of college admissions, a thick envelope means nothing unless you've got a wallet to match. Even the City University of New York -- where everybody gets in -- charges enough tuition to make it seem inaccessible to some students. No wonder that many students who have to work their way through school take more time to graduate than hoodlums spend doing hard time.

title: Ruling Against Ex-Mayor
description: A Superior Court judge ruled yesterday that former Mayor Gerald McCann of Jersey City cannot run for his old job next month because he is still technically serving part of the Federal sentence for bank and tax fraud that forced him from office in 1992.

title: A Dissident Can Now Embrace the Legacy
description: Fifty years ago, Bobby Bragan, an Alabama-born third-string catcher for the 1947 Brooklyn Dodgers, did not want Jackie Robinson as a teammate.

title: A Cosmetics Heir's Joint Venture Is Tainted by Ukrainian's Past
description: Ronald S. Lauder and Vadim Rabinovich could scarcely be more different. An urbane former United States Ambassador to Austria, Mr. Lauder is heir to a cosmetics fortune, chairman of the board of Museum of Modern Art and a former candidate for Mayor of New York. Mr. Rabinovich, a self-made Ukrainian millionaire, spent nine years in a Soviet prison for theft and has been linked to a suspected Russian criminal figure.

title: WEBSTER FINANCIAL AGREES TO ADD PEOPLE'S SAVINGS
description: The Webster Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the People's Savings Financial Corporation for $67.5 million in stock. Webster Financial, based in Waterbury, Conn., operates 63 Webster Bank branches in the state and had 1996 profits of $25.6 million. People's Savings, based in New Britain, Conn., has assets of $482 million and 1996 profit of $4 million. Under the agreement, People's Savings shareholders will receive the equivalent of $34 in Webster common stock for each People's share held. Shares of People's Savings fell 50 cents, to $31.50, in Nasdaq trading, where shares of Webster Financial fell 6.25 cents, to $35.4375.

title: Lawyers in Oklahoma Bombing Hope Rapport With Jurors Pays Off Later
description: During this week's questioning of prospective jurors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial, one of the prosecutors, United States Attorney Patrick M. Ryan, asked Juror No. 294 whether his dog, a Labrador retriever, was golden or black. His own dog, Mr. Ryan volunteered, was a golden retriever.

title: Rowland Says He Violated Ethics Law
description: Gov. John G. Rowland, the first baby boomer to hold Connecticut's highest office, yesterday admitted to violating the state's ethics law and blamed a culprit that has swayed so many in his generation: rock-and-roll.

title: Teen-Agers Alter Sexual Practices, Thinking Risks Will Be Avoided
description: For parents wondering just how much things have changed since the days when they were first experimenting with dating and sex, the answer is right there in the nurse's office at Hunter High School, a New York City public school for gifted students.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot Ten years, eight months. April 5, 1997. On this his birthday...and every day...always loved, always remembered, ''and the memories linger on.'' Children, Grandchildren and Joyce

title: Rangers Can't Escape Their Bad Play This Time
description: For the second time in two nights, the Rangers put on a dreadful performance. This time, though, because they were playing a good team instead of a bad one, they did not escape with a shabby victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, DANNY
description: KATZ-Danny. Our lifetime friend. We'll miss your humor and the twinkle in your eyes. The game isn't over yet. All the Siegels and Lindenauers.

title: Death Penalty Injustice
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WITTEN, KATHLEEN R.
description: WITTEN-Kathleen R., 79, widow of John D. Witten and daughter of Raymond and Regina Rubicam, died at Manatawny Manor, Pottstown, PA. Saturday, March 29. Mrs. Witten, who was born in Philadelphia, was a resident of Bronxville, NY, Portland, CT and West Boothbay Harbor, ME. She was a graduate of the Rosemary Hall School, Vassar College and Columbia University. She was a reference Librarian at Wesleyan University, Sarah Lawrence College and the State University of New York at Purchase. Mrs. Witten is survived by two sons, two sisters, a brother and two granddaughters. Burial will be in Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, on May 12, 1997 at 1:00 P.M. The family suggests that memorial contributions be made to the Sierra Club.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Leaders of Pilots' Union Back a Pact With American Airlines
description: Union leaders representing American Airlines' pilots endorsed a tentative contract with the carrier today and will send it to their 9,300 members for a ratification vote to be completed early next month.

title: Dominicans Arrest Suspect In Bronx Murders for Hire
description: Francisco Medina, a man described by the police and prosecutors as a killer for hire whose bloody handiwork on behalf of drug gangs in the early 1990's made him one of the Federal authorities' most sought-after suspects in New York City, has been arrested in the Dominican Republic, an official at the United States Embassy in Santo Domingo said yesterday.

title: Hearing Planned on Route
description: The long-delayed plans to build a toll road to connect the New Jersey Turnpike and Route 1 were delayed again yesterday when the State Department of Environmental Protection declined to issue a wetlands permit to build the highway. Instead, the agency's Federal counterpart, the Environmental Protection Agency, will hold a public hearing on the New Jersey Turnpike Authority's latest proposal to ease traffic in the center of the state.

title: Winery Cleared in Suit Over Similarity of Labels
description: In a victory for the E.& J. Gallo Winery, a Federal jury here ruled today that Gallo's Turning Leaf brand did not deliberately duplicate the appearance of Kendall-Jackson's Vintners Reserve to fool consumers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DAVID C.
description: MILLER-David C. The Albert Schweitzer Fellowship mourns the loss of a cherished friend and former Board member. Dr. Miller's lifelong embodiment of Albert Schweitzer's ethic of Reverence for Life and his own insistence that ''My life is my argument'' provide an example that continues to inspire us all. We extend our condolences to his wife, Rhena Schweitzer Miller, and all of his other family and friends.

title: The Countdown Begins: 1,000 Days to 2000
description: ''I should start by asking how many think 1,000 days is a long time,'' Gretchen Dykstra said yesterday at a City Hall news conference. People may have nodded in assent, but Ms. Dykstra, who is the president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, was not among them. Her remarks were part of the announcement of New York City's plans for the celebration of the turn of the millennium, which, as of this morning, is 1,001 days away. And the message was clear: Look out!

title: Haiti's Democratic Troubles
description: Two and a half years after American troops intervened to end a murderous dictatorship in Haiti, that country faces daunting troubles. Its ministries are inept, its Parliament paralyzed and its police quick on the trigger. Yet these problems represent progress of a sort. Haiti has gone from a government dedicated to brutality and corruption to one of inexperience and incompetence. That is a sign that the United States and the international community can best help by staying involved.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ZURAWIN, ADAM
description: ZURAWIN-Adam. April 5, 1994. Loving husband and father, devoted grandfather and caring friend. You are always in our hearts. We love you and miss you. Liza, Michael, Sandy, Iris, Jimmy, Sasha, Gaby, Nicole, and Olivia

title: Memories of Mulligan, Played at a Walk
description: The pleasures of the Gerry Mulligan All-Star Tribute Band were in contrast to much else that was being played in downtown jazz clubs on Thursday night: they came in slow passages. Not slow as in luxurious, but slow as in deliberate, pushing against the forward spin of the rhythm section.

title: It Takes Two, Plus Spirit, to Tango
description: At the start of ''Shall We Dance?,'' a Japanese businessman goes to a ballroom dancing school so furtively he might be visiting a bordello. ''In Japan, ballroom dancing is regarded with much suspicion,'' an opening title explains. Yet 42-year-old Shohei Sugiyama (Koji Yakusyo) is so unsatisfied by his wife, child, house, car and accounting job in a sterile office that he desperately needs a change of pace.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHATTUCK, H. FRANCIS, JR.
description: SHATTUCK-H. Francis, Jr. Husband of Julie, father of Christina and John, brother of Roger and grandfather of Jessica, Rebecca, Peter and Susannah. Service on Sunday, 1:30 P.M., at St. James Episcopal Church, 71 Street and Madison. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the International Security and Peace Foundation, C/O M. Pulsifer, Fiduciary Trust Co., 2 World Trade Center, NYC 10048-0772.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, IRVING DANNY
description: KATZ-Irving Danny. On April 3rd in New York. Our family lost its beloved patriarch. His friends lost their first officer. He brightened the lives of all he touched with his kindness and generosity. His independent spirit will live on in all of us. Sleep tight, Big D. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, (at 81 Street), Saturday, April 5, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. with service at funeral home on Sunday, April 6th, 11:30 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the On Stage, and Off column yesterday about a new Mimi for the Broadway musical ''Rent'' misspelled the surname of the actress who will take the role. She is Marcy Harriell, not Harrell.

title: 3 Companies Seek to End Phone Subsidy
description: In a move that could galvanize the debate on telephone deregulation, AT&T, Bell Atlantic and Nynex made a joint proposal yesterday to eliminate $2.5 billion in subsidies from the industry while increasing local phone bills by 75 cents a month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMENITZ, ELEANOR A.
description: DOMENITZ-Eleanor A. Devoted wife of Leonard. Loving mother to Joel, Amy and Lyle. Adoring grandmother of Melanie and Carly Miller. Beloved sister to Udelle and Florence, and twin brother Irwin (Dicky) Pollack. Forever in our hearts.

title: U.S. DIAGNOSTIC REJECTS MEDICAL RESOURCES BID
description: U.S. Diagnostic Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected Medical Resources Inc.'s stock takeover offer of $6.25 a share, or $212.5 million. On Thursday, Medical Resources offered to buy U.S. Diagnostic, a move that would combine the two biggest United States operators of medicalimaging centers. ''The highly conditional terms and the irresponsibly low proposed purchase price make the suggested combination of no interest,'' U.S. Diagnostic said. The company, based in West Palm Beach, Fla., retained the investment firm Smith Barney to help it explore acquisitions, divestitures and other ''strategic alternatives.'' U.S. Diagnostic said no decision had been made to sell the company. Its shares jumped $1.625 yesterday, to $7.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Rebecca Shulman, 100, Leader In Hadassah and Israeli Causes
description: Rebecca Shulman, who devoted a lifetime to Jewish and Israeli causes, most of all through Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, died on Sunday at her home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. She was 100.

title: Zairian Rebels Seize Capital of Rich Region
description: Continuing their advance, Zairian rebels marched today into a regional capital in an area rich in minerals after Government troops fled.

title: Alien And Alone In His Own Country
description: Irreverent humor, frustrated idealism and earnest compassion are blended with a keen sense of character, place and political reality in the auspicious ''English, August.''

title: Protection for Farm Labor
description: Few laborers have as little clout with their bosses as farm workers. The work is unskilled and the labor pool huge and mobile. Many farm workers are illegal immigrants and therefore reluctant to report employers who do not pay the minimum wage or Social Security or fail to provide water and toilets in the field. Farm wages have been dropping for 20 years.

title: Without the Old 1-2 Punch, the Yankees Get Knocked Out
description: The debut. David Wells spoke about his first game with the Yankees reverently, as if he were visiting the White House or George Steinbrenner's house. Wells would point at his new uniform, wave his hands frantically and raise his voice to illustrate how inspired he was to finally be a Yankee.

title: What Freud Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALPEER, IRVING J.
description: GALPEER-Irving J., 87, of Harwich, MA. formerly of Hartsdale, NY and New York City. Beloved husband of Lillian ''Nicki'' (Jaffin) Galpeer. Devoted father of Nina Galpeer Danielson of Harwich, MA and Carla Galpeer Horton of Santa Monica, and the late Moss Andrew Galpeer. Loving brother of Minnette Bell of Boynton Beach, Fl. He is survived by four adoring grandchildren, five nieces and three nephews. A funeral service will be held in Temple Israel Cemetery, Ardsley, N.Y., Sunday, April 6, 1997 at 11:00 A.M. Expressions of sympathy may be made to Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School, Hawthorne, NY. For more information contact Nickerson Funeral Home, Orleans, MA.

title: F.A.A. Going Public on Airline Faults
description: Under pressure from Congress to tell the public more about airline safety problems, the Federal Aviation Administration has begun announcing significant violations by airlines and the fines they bring.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Clinton Administration decision regarding the sale of F-16 fighter jets to Chile misstated it. The Administration has permitted Lockheed, the maker of the F-16, to submit bids to the Chilean Government, but President Clinton has not approved any sale of the planes to Chile.

title: Indictment in Drug Slaying
description: A Bloomfield man with a history of drug dealing was indicted on charges of killing a rival drug dealer who had become a Government informant, Federal prosecutors said yesterday. Last November, after learning of Ricardo Santiago's cooperation with the Drug Enforcement Administration, David Cruz, the Bloomfield resident, shot Mr. Santiago, 29, as he sat in a car outside his home in Garfield, prosecutors said.

title: Town Wants to Impose Auto Speed Limits, but It Hates Those Ugly Signs
description: This affluent town, where backyards are as big as Rhode Island and more than a few people take pride in talking like George Plimpton, is committed to maintaining its image as a sanctuary for those with wealth and taste.

title: Gusts Delay Ad On Water Tank
description: New York City will have to wait a few more days for its first water tank billboard.

description: BRODY-Dorothy. On April 3, 1997 of New York City. Beloved wife of the late George. Devoted sister of Selma Cooper and Mathilda Sklar. Cherished aunt. We will all miss you. Graveside Services Sunday 11:30AM, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, New Jersey.

description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE METRO
description: CASE OF THE SECRET SEXTUPLETS -- A Queens couple managed to keep the births of their four daughters and two sons quiet for more than a week. But word is out, and the offers are pouring in. 25.

title: A 3,000-Mile Chapter In a Quest for Survival
description: Having completed the Hawaii Ironman Triathlon and the New York City Marathon on successive weekends last fall, Jim Howley of Carpinteria, Calif., is going to even greater extremes to trumpet his belief in vigorous exercise for those who suffer from AIDS.

description: To the Editor:

title: Battery Reminder
description: Daylight time begins at 2 A.M. tomorrow; clocks should be set ahead an hour.

description: To the Editor:

title: Low-Income Houses and a Suburb's Fears
description: Beneath the racial overtones of the debate here over a 25-year-old proposal for low- and moderate-income housing is the disquiet of a once rapidly expanding suburb suddenly grown wary of more growth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWE, MARION CHAIT
description: HOWE-Marion Chait. On April 2, 1997. Devoted and loving sister of Allan Chait, beloved sister-in-law of Jocelyn Chait, adored aunt of Andrew and Steven Chait and Madeleine Brand, caring stepmother of David Howe and her step-grandchildren. Friends may call Saturday evening 7 to 9 PM. Services Sunday, April 6, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to The Philanthropic Fund of Temple Emanu-El, 1 E. 65 St, NYC 10021 or Channel 13.

title: Cultists' Tragedy Defies Our Understanding
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Adapt to Life as H.M.O. Employees
description: Sixteen years ago, a group of physicians here set up their own health maintenance organization. Two and a half years ago, they sold their practice and the H.M.O. to a California company, getting $3.2 million each. Then, in December, they joined a union to fight the very managed-care company they helped create.

title: Bombs Tied to U.K. Vote Take an Economic Toll
description: A British election campaign has again brought Northern Ireland terror tactics to the mainland with a bomb scare that officials said appeared to be intended to cause maximum damage to the economy.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Cooking With Mattie
description: Following are excerpts from some winning essays in Barnard College's annual writing competition for 11th-grade girls in New York City's public schools. The theme is ''A Woman I Admire.'' Di Yin Lu of the Bronx High School of Science won first prize.

title: Pregnant Woman Survives Fall in Path of a Train
description: Standing on the platform, watching a screeching subway train pass over the inert body of her pregnant cousin, Olga Reyes was sure that the 22-year-old had been crushed to death seconds after she tumbled onto the tracks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRAMPTON, HONOR L
description: CRAMPTON-Honor L, of Manasota Key, Florida, died on April 3, 1997, age 95. Beloved wife of Savington. Mother of Honor MacLean of Lawrence, NY. Stepmother of Claudia Clingman of Easton, CT. Sister of Esther L. Tuttle of NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon St. Brooklyn, NY 11202

title: From Russia, Bridging Folk and the Scholarly
description: ''Russian Folk Festival: From the Village Fair to the Stage'' is an aptly descriptive title for the splendid sampling of traditional songs and dances that the Brooklyn Academy of Music has imported for this weekend from seven parts of Russia.

title: A Cool Debussy Tied to an Overheated Poet
description: With every playing of ''Le Martyre de Saint Sebastien'' (''The Martyrdom of St. Sebastian'') we like the music more and better understand why history has left it behind. It is to Kurt Masur's credit that Debussy's enigmatic stab at performance art has come to Avery Fisher Hall at all, even though nervous New York Philharmonic subscribers on Thursday did not know quite what to make of it.

title: Agassi and Courier Give U.S. a 2-0 Lead
description: Desperately in need of reinventing himself in the event where he has done his best work, Andre Agassi gave himself and his country a jump-start this afternoon with a straight-sets victory in the opening singles of this Davis Cup quarterfinal between the United States and the Netherlands.

title: Mother Is Indicted In Starvation Case
description: A 28-year-old woman who prosecutors say starved and beat her 5-year-old boy to death was indicted on murder charges yesterday by a Bronx grand jury.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES AND ARTZ AUTOMOTIVE TIE SET
description: Republic Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Artz Automotive Group, a Cleveland auto dealership, for $15.7 million in stock. Republic, a holding company controlled by the financier H. Wayne Huizenga, has spent over half a billion dollars to acquire more than 40 auto dealerships to create a nationwide chain. The company, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., also holds substantial interests in the waste management industry. Artz Automotive had 1996 revenues of $50 million.

title: Auto Kills Judy Flannery, 57, A Powerhouse in Triathlon

A resident of Chevy Chase, she was was 57 and had won six American and four world age-group championships in the sport, which combines running, swimming and cycling.

This seemed doomed to lose a spade trick and a heart trick, but the slam was difficult to defeat.

title: SUNBEAM EXPLORES TAKEOVER AND SALE OPTIONS
description: The Sunbeam Corporation is interviewing investment bankers to explore options, ranging from making hostile takeovers as big as $5 billion to selling the company, the company's chairman and chief executive, Albert J. Dunlap, said yesterday. Investors and analysts expect Mr. Dunlap, called Chainsaw Al for his cost-cutting exuberance, first to snare a competitor or two to help meet his goal of doubling sales to $2 billion in three years and then to sell Sunbeam. Mr. Dunlap said he would not decide which route he would take until the second half of the year. Shares of Sunbeam, based in Delray Beach, Fla., rose $1.125, to $32.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares were about $12 when Mr. Dunlap took charge last July.

title: Whitman's Car Insurance Plan Is Stalling
description: Prospects dimmed this week that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan for a major overhaul of automobile insurance in New Jersey will be approved by Election Day.

description: The unemployment rate edged down to 5.2 percent last month -- matching its lowest level in eight years -- as the reinvigorated economy continued to produce a bountiful labor market for legions of Americans.

title: Pleasing Their Allies

They exist mainly for symbolic purposes, often to placate powerful interest groups. So when the Democratic-controlled Assembly approved a sweeping revision of state welfare laws this week, it was clear that the Democrats were in large part trying to calm the fears of one of their most powerful constituencies: organized labor.

Armed with hammers and knives, they entered the house of the woman who they said had cast a spell on them and started swinging.

The executive, Paul Wilhelm, did not identify potential acquisition targets or say talks were being held when he spoke on Wednesday, the company said yesterday. Analysts said Mr. Wilhelm mentioned Inland Steel Industries and the National Steel Corporation as having strategic strengths, including significant supply contracts with American plants of Japanese auto makers.

And while the parents, a Queens couple, were still safely anonymous, a hospital on Long Island was under siege by the news media, television scouts, book publishers and entrepreneurs with offers ranging from minivans to diapers.

This evidence is normally out of bounds, except in certain instances, such as when prior acts can be seen as showing motivation for fresh crimes. But two recent rulings by the State Supreme Court appearing to open the door to prosecutors have provoked debate in legal circles about whether defense lawyers face potentially rougher times ahead.

The Iron Lady herself had no time for arty types, whom she presumed to be leftists bent on living off Government subsidies. She naturally frowned on official promotion of culture. Their activities, and the public's panic after a few high-profile mass killings by lone gunmen in Scotland and Tasmania, have inspired interest in having the United Nations clamp down on gun manufacturers, exporters and owners the world over.

The township, worried that it might be sued, closed the beach, enraging surfers. So last month, two surfer groups, the Surfers' Environmental Alliance and the Surfrider Foundation, responded by drafting a bill to protect surfers' rights.

title: Trailing Lonesome Pines
description: THE sensation was of soaring, as my car swept down a long, smooth grade into Powell Valley. This deeply fissured landscape at the juncture of Kentucky, West Virginia and Virginia is a world of huge, airy spaces grounded in swells of forest-covered mountains. Here lies the heart of that state of mind and country called Appalachia. It is filled with potent images of American self-identity -- the log cabin hearth, the self-sufficient yeoman. I sped downward through the blue vistas that had flanked America's first frontier, and wondered about the route through the pass that had given the town of Big Stone Gap, Va., its name. Over a long summer weekend, driving a loop off Interstate 81 and taking day hikes, I found the excellence of its roads to be one of many mismatches between Appalachian legend and reality.

title: A Walk Through 130 Years of Howard's History
description: As an undergraduate architecture student at Howard University in the mid-1980's, Hazel Ruth Edwards says, she paid little attention to the Washington school's history. But a year and a half ago, Ms. Edwards, a special assistant for planning and development at the university, began work on a project that helped her fill in the gaps on the 130-year history of one of the nation's preeminent black universities.

Designed by one of Britain's leading golf course architects, Dave Thomas, the 7,111-yard course is situated near the banks of the River Teviot and follows the contours and features of the landscape, a mixture of mature woodland and rolling parkland.

title: Founding Fathers Get Lost
description: Dead white men, we're constantly told, are on the way out at America's universities, done in by multiculturalism and radical feminists. But the biggest single threat in decades to the future academic standing of America's most august dead white men -- Washington, Jefferson, Franklin, Adams, Madison -- turns out not to be a campus plot but a case of what one historian calls ''bipartisan political fecklessness.'' Over the past two years, such unlikely bedfellows as William Bennett, Lynne Cheney and the Clinton Administration have all played leading roles, largely unreported, in threatening to extinguish the Founding Fathers projects: the scholarly effort to document our patriots' lives by collecting and annotating their voluminous papers (18,000 letters by Jefferson alone) in books available to anyone with a library card.

title: A Long and Winding Sonnet
description: Fifth Avenue's Easter parade is all about tradition: in its way it is a perfect mirror of the society of its times. From its earliest beginnings after the Civil War through its golden period at the turn of the century, a rigid decorum and a fashion dictated by high society ruled. The parade took a turn to carnival-like headdresses with the arrival of television after World War II. Last Sunday's spectacle captured precisely today's confused scene, with street performers drowning out the musicians playing Irving Berlin's famous melody. A rare glimpse of the dignity of Easters past could be seen as parishioners left churches in top hats and serious bonnets trimmed with fresh flowers. More typical of the progressive spirit were families on rollerblades and an elegant blind man, arm in arm with his companion and wearing a straw hat he had decorated himself.

description: THE capital's money machine is once again cranking out big bucks to pay for the prosecutors, investigators and defense lawyers of the nation's freshest scandal: the fund-raising practices of the Clinton White House and the Democrats.

title: Movies Find a Way to Close the Class Divide
description: ''INVENTING THE ABBOTTS,'' A new movie about an old story -- the struggle of love against the barriers of social class -- saves its most telling moment for last. On screen is the film's working-class hero, Doug Holt, standing alone on a sidewalk along a dark, puddled street in Chicago. He is peering through a dress shop window at his heart's desire, Pamela Abbott, a daughter of wealth. Doug, played by Joaquin Phoenix, has finally caught up with Pam after a fitful pursuit that began where they both came from, an idyllic Illinois town of the late 1950's, a place of malt shops, swinging screen doors and well-tended hedges separating the haves from the have-nots.

title: Nostalgia Time: A Beloved Revival Revived . . .
description: A DESIRE to return in thought or in fact to a former time in one's life, to one's home, or to one's family and friends.'' That's nostalgia, according to the Random House Dictionary of the English Language. Always was, always will be and -- all the rage or not -- it's always with us in some measure, this yearning that time and memory effect.

title: Rock of the Middle-Aged
description: TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGO, Aerosmith perfected the cosmic power-ballad. Songs like ''Dream On'' and ''Seasons of Wither'' remain examples of an amazing convention: an overwrought minor-key plaint that unites high school diary entries with high-voltage riffs. Such ballads became the standard form for the rock elegy, and an endless number of hard-rock acts ever since have used it -- even Nirvana, with its predictable swells and decrescendos.

They call one another ''brother'' or ''partner'' in Spanish, trade stories about past adventures and talk politics but rarely argue. They are all staunchly anti-Castro.

title: Testing the Home for Lead Paint
description: IN historical times, lead poisoning was common. That's because lead or lead compounds were used to sweeten or preserve foods. Roman wine merchants added an aromatic liquid, called sapa, to keep their wine from turning into vinegar. Sapa was made by boiling grape juice in lead kettles. The acidic grape juice leached lead from the vessel turning the sapa into a poison.

title: Animal Magnetism
description: When your store is located near nothing but corn, you've got to go all out to attract foot traffic. Most of the customers who trek to Cabela's, a hunting- and fishing-equipment company in Sidney, Neb., come to gawk at one thing -- the 550-piece taxidermy exhibit, which features ''trophies'' perched on a 45-foot ''snow-capped mountain'' in the center of the store. ''We're the second-largest tourist attraction in the state,'' hoots Keith Yocum, Cabela's retail director. ''Right after the Omaha Zoo.'' Unlike those at the zoo, these critters don't move -- they're frozen in dramatic poses: big-horn sheep frolic atop the peak, timber wolves howl from a narrow ledge and dueling elk thrust racks at each other. In a window, an African lion descends on a cape buffalo, and up near the skylights Canada geese soar. Since Cabela's -- which mails 55 million catalogues to more than 120 countries -- draws most of its one million annual customers from more than 500 miles away, Yocum insists that location is a matter of perspective: ''We've got 73,000 square feet out in the middle of everywhere.''

title: Putting Out a Welcome Mat for New Jersey's Ellis Island
description: It was three o'clock on a wind-ripped Wednesday and Louie Scerbo was at the wheel, ferrying tourists just off the boat from back into civilization, which he roughly defined as New Jersey. It was a territory that now appeared to include a good portion of America's most famed immigrant way-station: Ellis Island.

title: Bravo, Yes, But Hold The Encores
description: I WAS CAUGHT LEAVING A VIENNA PHILHARMONIC concert not long ago without waiting for the encore. ''How could you walk out on one of the great orchestras of the world, especially when they are offering more?'' said a friend, having noticed the crime in commission from her upstairs seat at Carnegie Hall.

title: Extra! Extra!
description: DAYBREAK was still an hour away, but Ernie Campbell couldn't wait any longer to get his fix. ''Sometimes I find myself staring wide-eyed at the ceiling at 4 A.M. and I just gotta have 'em,'' said Mr. Campbell, 69, a retired waiter, as he stumbled toward ''his source'' last Sunday morning. As usual his dealer, Dushyant Patel, was there, looking somewhat dazed himself after 12 hours working in the harshly lit, weather-beaten shack on a traffic island in Sheridan Square, the heart of Greenwich Village. Without saying a word to his regular customer, Mr. Patel nodded, reached down and handed over the goods: a bag of Skittles. ''Thanks, pal,'' Mr. Campbell nearly grunted as he waddled off into the darkness. By then, Mr. Patel was lost in a whirl of other transactions: a pack of Rolaids for a New Jersey man who had had one too many martinis, a map for a bewildered British tourist looking for Edna St. Vincent Millay's home, and a copy of Playgirl for a Charles Street resident of indeterminate gender wearing gold platform shoes and an aquamarine miniskirt. After exchanging a panhandler's cup of quarters for a $5 bill, Mr. Patel took advantage of the pre-dawn lull to eat his breakfast, a plate of rice and beans prepared for him by the 24-hour Greek diner across the street.

title: Fit to Be Tried and True

title: A World Away, A Generation Later
description: Books that last, books that still matter, change from generation to generation. Two decades after it first appeared, ''World of Our Fathers,'' Irving Howe's classic history of Jewish immigrant life on New York's Lower East Side, is at once the same book and subtly different. Its world is more remote, with few survivors still among us, yet more immediate, because of the bustling new immigration today. This is a paradox worth exploring. What kind of book was it, and how did Irving Howe of all people come to write it? How has it changed, especially for young people encountering it for the first time?

title: If Your Typeface Isn't Broken, Don't Fix It
description: IN the Middle Ages, when monks spent their lives laboring over manuscripts, their quill pens scratching hand-mixed ink onto vellum, they didn't run the scrolls through the spell-checker. The abbot didn't say: ''Hey, aren't these margins a bit wide? Can you print it again, this time formatting them for half an inch?'' No one objected to the uncial script or suggested that another version be drawn up in Helvetica Condensed -- or in Times Roman, for that matter. No, everyone was satisfied with one draft and venerated it for, oh, 800 or 900 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGLER, FLORENCE (NEE STERNLIEB)
description: SIEGLER-Florence (nee Sternlieb). Age 87, of Deerfield, IL, formerly of Forest Hills, NY, died in Chicago on Wednesday, April 2, 1997. Preceded in death by her devoted husband Al. Beloved mother of Mark, Michael and Donna Meibach; grandmother of Dillan, Alison, Richard and Jessica Siegler of Chicago; Brooke and Heather Meibach of Deerfield, IL; and Alexander and Daniel Siegler of Dayton, OH. Beloved sister of the late Beatrice Presser and the late Harold Sternlieb. She loved children and was a kindergarten teacher in NYC for 50 years. She dedicated herself to teaching the next generation, both her own children and her students. Funeral services were held on Friday, April 4, at Mt. Hebron Cemetery, NYC. Those who wish to make a contribution in her memory may send donations to the University of Chicago Children's Hospital (Development), 5841 South Maryland Ave, Chicago, IL 60637.

title: Looking for an Outlet
description: On the kind of tepid, overcast morning that signals the early arrival of ''mud season'' in southern Vermont, a green four-door Corsica with half a tank of gas, an old Della Reese tape in the dash and an empty trunk meanders north on Route 7A. It eases past a gold-domed courthouse, a white-steepled church, a museum dedicated to the art of fly-fishing and the pillars of a colonial-style hotel with a sign out front that reads VACANCY BRUNCH. Then it turns into a parking lot and finds a space in front of a gray one-story building with a Christmas wreath still up although Valentine's Day has come and gone. Through the driver's side window -- half rolled down, it's so warm for February -- a familiar sound shatters the New England idyll: a New Jersey father says to his New Jersey son, ''You want to look at socks? Get your fingers out of your mouth!''

description: The hour is late. The child is stumped. The science homework ques-tion boggles the mind of the exhausted parent, too. What happens now?

There, where the kindergarten's guinea pig is lovingly named Yitzhak for the slain Israeli leader Yitzhak Rabin, registration is booming, administrators report.

So in the quarter just ended, the stock wound up as the Big Board's biggest dud, down a whopping 78 percent.

title: The Sameness Of Things
description: At the San Francisco headquarters of Williams-Sonoma, Gary Friedman operates what amounts to a mass-market taste laboratory. Several dozen designers and buyers work here, surrounded by vases and chairs and picture frames and glasses and clocks, charged with turning the things they see in the world into objects they can sell through the company's various holdings, which include Hold Everything and Pottery Barn. It is the opposite of alchemy: money is made not by rendering each object more valuable but by rendering it less valuable and less rare, so that it can be owned by anybody.

title: Pass Go, Collect Millions
description: IT doesn't take long for most visitors to the Boardwalk and Park Place to notice something familiar about the street map. Atlantic City's boulevards, named mostly after the states and bodies of water, bear more than a passing resemblance to the Monopoly game board.

title: Flipping the Race Card
description: AS in many aspects of Staten Island politics, they play the race card backward here.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Jedi Knight on the Town? Go Here for a Quick Zap

title: An Endgame for the Mideast
description: President Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright like to talk about America as the indispensable nation, the only country with the power and prestige to help bring peace to troubled regions like the Middle East. They now have a chance to deliver on that grand image. The unfinished peace between Israel and the Palestinians is near collapse and Washington's role as avuncular mediator will no longer suffice. Mr. Clinton and Ms. Albright must make some hard decisions and take some political risks to end the conflict.

title: Superstore Inflation
description: The superstore -- that cropland-encroaching or square-city-block-swallowing shrine to seemingly limitless supply -- is shaping up to be the defining shopping experience of the 1990's. It has established the scale that shoppers now demand and a strategy that retailers giddily emulate, and it has done both to an extent that would have been unimaginable only 10 years ago. Whatever bigger was, now it's more.

title: Shop Till You Pop
description: What's bad for the bedroom might be good for the credit-card balance. While seratonin re-uptake inhibitors (prozac is one) have been found to dampen sex drives, Donald Black, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Iowa, reports that one drug in that category, fluvoxamine, might also curb a lust for shopping. In the first study of its kind, Black has been testing the drug as a treatment for shopaholics, who, he says, represent between 2 and 8 percent of the American population. So far, almost all of the participants (16 women and 1 man) in his study report that their shopping ardor has cooled. Black says that by enhancing the efficiency of the seratonin, a brain chemical that elevates mood, fluvoxamine appears to reduce anxiety, inappropriate urges and impulsiveness. Lesley Quinn, 42, who joined Black's study in October, says: ''Now I can shop with a list for a few things I need. I cut up all my credit cards.'' She has had little trouble with the drug's side effects -- sleep disturbances and nausea. Eric Hollander, a professor of psychiatry at Mt. Sinai medical school and a consultant on the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, cautions that the study is preliminary but says that Black's work is ''very promising, very exciting.''

title: Bruce Variety
description: Bruce Variety, a supply shop for the imagination, is buried in the suburban sprawl of Bethesda, Md. The contents spill out onto the sidewalk. Shovels, sleds, a huge seed rack that spins. Ersatz general store, dark and dusky, suspended in time, official depot for Buster Brown socks, high white underwear, pencil cases, snub-nosed scissors, compasses and composition books. It was here that I learned to shop, spending the first coins of my allowance on things my mother deemed undesirable: cap guns and cowboy hats, padlocked secret diaries, bows and arrows, Superballs and Glop, glass piggy banks that you ''accidentally'' had to drop in order to retrieve your loot. And this is the place where every project got its start -- pipe-cleaner jewelry, cotton-ball skylines, popsicle-stick forts, Halloween outfits and Christmas stockings. The shelves overflow with the stuff of booty bags and birthday parties, the makings for every glitter-and-glue mass you could dream of.

title: Legislators Press the Swiss To Set Up Holocaust Fund
description: The Swiss Government has promised to set up a $5 billion fund to pay Holocaust survivors and victims' descendants who put money and valuables in Swiss banks before and during World War II to protect it from the Nazis. Two New Jersey legislators want to see that the Swiss keep that promise.

title: Managua
description: To the Editor: The picture of the abandoned cathedral in Managua (''Nicaragua on the Mend,'' Feb. 16) brought memories of a 1959 State Department-sponsored singing tour of South and Central America with the Los Angeles-based Roger Wagner Chorale. I was a tenor with the 24-voice group, and we were nearing the end of an exhausting, 19-country, three-month trip. We had sung in Managua the night before, but Roger had offered our (unscheduled) services at a 7 A.M. Mass in the cathedral the next day -- a Saturday. This was well before the earthquake that leveled most of Managua. Your photo of the multiple beehive roof of the new cathedral makes one wish for the restoration of the older building.

title: Care and Feeding
description: "A Natural History of Parenting: From emperor penguins to reluctant ewes, a naturalist looks at parenting in the animal world and ours. Harmony Books, New York, TK pp. $23

Other students sand, chisel and plane different sections of the 15-foot wooden craft, supported on each end by wooden A-frame stands.

title: Brookhaven Looks for Plans to Deal With Contaminated Water
description: CONCEDING that they may be powerless to stop a 10- to 12-year-old leak of radioactive tritium from a nuclear reactor at the Brookhaven National Laboratory for at least nine months, Federal officials are pressing plans to deal with contamination that the leak has caused.

title: The Store Strikes Back
description: The first thing you think when you see Nike's new flagship store on East 57th Street in New York City is that this is not a store at all. Niketown's facade is a takeoff on an old New York high-school building. You enter through turnstiles, in the manner of a sports arena, to find yourself in a sleek, futuristic, five-story atrium into which, at 30-minute intervals, a three-story-high screen descends and a video softly plugging Nike products is played along with a crescendo of recorded music. There are displays of sports memorabilia and a chance to hit a punching bag. Where are the sneakers?

title: Fuller Seminary Bookstore
description: I was in Los Angeles for the first time in 20 years. The work I came to do left me plenty of free time. Naturally, I drove around a lot in my rented car. After a few days, I got sick of that and decided to walk. I set out from the Sage Motor Inn in Pasadena, where I was staying. The sidewalks were chalk-white and led among azalea blossoms the size of sofa pillows. In other neighborhoods, the sidewalks were less nice, or nonexistent. Sometimes I walked along avenues so wide that the other side of the street seemed as far away as the point up ahead on the horizon where the left lane and the right lane converged. At a corner I've now forgotten, I stepped into a store to get out of the heat. I thought it was a bookstore -- an oddity out there, apparently; I had seen no others.

title: Neighborly Act: Domesticating a Compost Heap
description: There is a classic battle going on in my backyard in Red Hook, that little elbow of Brooklyn that stretches out into the Buttermilk Channel. The war is being waged over the compost pile, which is wedged between a high wooden fence and an outdoor fireplace where the owners of the house, Henry and Sandra, like to sit, even on a fine day in winter, and enjoy a glass of wine by the fire.

title: Taking Storytelling To the Shelters
description: MIRIAM EPSTEIN of Manchester was volunteering in soup kitchens when, she says, ''I noticed something tragic -- how many children I was serving. It bothered me greatly.'' So, she said, she quit teaching, a career she had pursued for almost 30 years, and devoted her efforts to helping homeless children living in shelters.

title: The Life Cycle of a Price
description: They say nobody pays retail anymore, and with so many other options, why would they? As this women's suit from the Calvin Klein Collection shows, it's a long drop from the designer floor of a department store to the bargain basement. * At Saks Fifth Avenue recently, this suit was selling for $1,380. If it remains unsold, toward the end of the season it will be marked down, usually 30 to 40 percent, to about $830 to $965. After four to six more weeks, the suit will probably run about $415 to $550, more than $100 below wholesale. * At Century 21, an ''off-price'' store in lower Manhattan, the suit was selling for only $499.97. But Century 21 had it in sky blue (last year's color) rather than indigo (this year's). * This suit may end up in one of many Calvin Klein outlets, though a recent check with the Secaucus, N.J., store revealed that it hadn't made it there yet. If it does, it will probably sell for about half of Saks' full price, or $690. * If someone buys the suit but then decides that indigo is not her color, she can take it to a consignment shop like Ina, which specializes in samples and couture items and would sell this suit for an estimated $350. * If the suit hasn't sold after three months, Ina will either return it to the consignor or donate it to a charity like the Housing Works Thrift Shops, which would probably offer it for $175 to $200. At that price, it wouldn't last long there.

title: The Existential Burger
description: ASK the average American to discuss his philosophy and he's likely to declare that he believes in rotating his tires every 10,000 miles. Ask almost any Frenchman to discuss tire rotation and he's apt to produce a disquisition on cosmic verities, delivered in neat syllogisms complete with verbatim quotes from Descartes, Voltaire, Derrida and Sartre. The Gallic conclusion seems to be that although Americans may cruise down the rough road of life with plenty of rubber between the potholes and their rumps, they haven't the foggiest idea of the metaphysical implications of their journey.

title: A Turn of the SKU

As your purchase is checked out of any major store, a laser beam registers the bar code stamped on the label. In it is encrypted the numbers assigned to your item -- or stock-keeping unit (SKU, pronounced skew) in store-speak. A price and description appear on a screen above the cash register. You pay up and you're done.

title: A Faustian Tale to Give Heart?
description: FOR MANY PEOPLE who love music and literature, Thomas Mann's ''Doktor Faustus'' is the book. It is certainly the most formidable novel ever written with music as a subject. As a work of modern legend, it tells of a composer who makes a pact with the devil and achieves a temporary but total mastery of his art. As a work of historical fiction, it shows a German artist disappearing into the maelstrom of 20th-century history. Most original, as a work of musical imagination, it builds the illusion of a whole compositional career, a real-life musical identity. Adrian Leverkuhn, the novel's composer hero, has reached outside fiction to exercise an influence on music of the later 20th century.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Henry Clay Frick always intended to leave his art collection and sumptuous house at 70th Street and Fifth Avenue to the public. A millionaire by the time he was 30 years old, Frick (1849-1919), who made his fortune in the coke and steel industries, was a bold and discriminating collector. Not only did he acquire some of the greatest Old Masters in the world, as Charles Ryskamp, the director of the Frick Collection, writes, but his eye for contemporary works proved infallible. In ART IN THE FRICK COLLECTION: Paintings, Sculpture, Decorative Arts (Abrams, $60) Mr. Ryskamp has chronicled the evolution of Frick's collection, from the young millionaire's first trip to Europe in 1879, which laid the foundations for his later acquisitions, to his architectural plans for the house and grounds and his purchasing habits, which included living with paintings for months before deciding whether to buy. The museum's curators, Bernice Davidson, Susan Galassi, Edgar Munhall and Nadia Tscherny, have supplied brief though exceptionally lively and informative notes on the history and esthetic highlights of the artworks illustrated. The effect is that of being given a private tour of the museum's masterworks, including paintings by Piero della Francesca, Titian, Bronzino, Rembrandt and Vermeer, Renaissance bronzes, Chinese porcelains and French furniture and clocks. Though few people realize it, the Frick collection is anything but static: at least a third of the paintings now on view were acquired after Frick's death. This is an unusually elegant book that underscores how Frick's style of collecting became the prototype for many of the great American collections. Andrea Barnet

title: Agnes B.
description: I was broke when I discovered Agnes B. -- the one on Madison. Loftlike, funky music and old French film posters on the walls. A vase of tulips in the window. Clean, spare. Impossibly pale and thin and chic saleswomen drifting here and there, aloof. A dancer's studio lined with clothes made of fabulous silks and cottons and leathers, simple colors, simple cuts, angelic collars, little buttons at the neck and the wrists, pants with perfect flare. A basket of scarves, cashmere and chiffon. There was a small selection, but I wanted everything. Everything looked good on me. I loved that store even if a T-shirt cost more than I'd spent on a winter jacket that year. Walking in there was like stepping into possibility. A new shirt could make you feel brand-new yourself for days. Sometimes I'd spend hours trying on the clothes, imagining what it would be like to wear them into the world. In the mirror I became French and sophisticated. I was walking in the Tuileries, surrounded by tulips. I was racing up the steps of the Eiffel Tower or drifting down the Seine on the deck of a boat. I was at Fouchon gorging on pastries. Until one day I shared the fitting room with Tama Janowitz and all her hair. She had a pile of beautiful things, and she could buy them all. The saleswoman, no longer aloof, gently took her selection, asking, ''Will that be all?'' Of me she asked, ''Anything for you?'' I slipped out of the clothes and left the store, wilted.

title: Morocco
description: To the Editor: I was interested to read Susan Spano's ''Tough Trek Through Rugged Morocco'' (March 9) as I had just returned from two weeks in this richly diverse country. No stranger to cultural immersion in my travels with Outward Bound, I opted in this case to forgo digging my own latrine and traveled first class. It was the right decision. Our small group of nine enjoyed the constantly changing scenery while bicycling through casbahs and mud forts in the Dra Valley and along the Atlantic coast, hiking to remote villages in the High Atlas, similar to those described in the article, and riding camels over the sand dunes to our tented Berber camp. Our journey explored more completely than Ms. Spano's the exoticism and romance of Morocco -- from picnics under the argan trees to our farewell dinner at Yacout in the heart of the Medina. Our hotels were the Villa Maroc in Essaouira, the Palais Jamai in Fez, and the incomparable La Mamounia in Marrakesh. And of course our knowledgeable local guides led us through the souks and medinas, expanding our experience of the country's artistic and cultural heritage.
