title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: It's always a pleasure to read the work of the British novelist Joanna Trollope. In A SPANISH LOVER (Random House, $23), as in ''The Men and the Girls,'' ''The Rector's Wife'' and ''The Choir,'' she offers us picturesque English villages and their appealing if troubled inhabitants. But this time, the Ur-Britishness seems less central to our enjoyment of the novel. Lizzie (happily married, professionally proficient, mother of four) and Frances (none of the above) are twins who have the sort of relationship in which Frances' needs are subsumed within Lizzie's bustling family life. But when Frances becomes passionately involved with a married Spaniard, everything changes, and her actions touch off a series of events that spiral downward as her relationship heats up: Lizzie's children run amok, Lizzie and Frances' mother leaves their father, and finally Lizzie's business and then her own marriage begin to falter. When disappointed by life, nearly all of Ms. Trollope's well-realized and likable characters blame only themselves, making every effort to shape up without undue whining or finger pointing. Along the way, Ms. Trollope gives us much to savor. Her story is filled with lively, astute and always affectionate insights into the abiding issues of marriage, motherhood and materialism, not to mention the destructive power of envy and the importance of living one's own life. Betsy Groban

title: San Francisco
description: To the Editor: As a former resident of San Francisco, I was amused by Christopher Hall's ''What's Doing In San Francisco'' (March 2), especially about the imminent flood of visitors from Britain. They will certainly be interested in visiting the Point Reyes National Seashore, a few miles north of the city, where Francis Drake is believed to have landed and spent some time. They can even visit the University of California Berkeley campus to see the (in all likelihood phony) medallion or coin Drake is supposed to have inscribed -- claiming the area for England -- and nailed to a tree. What is surprising is the failure to mention that the city was really founded by another Briton, William Richardson, in 1822 and called Yerba Buena by him. Richardson was second mate on a British whaler and he established the first settlement that lasted and became, eventually, a city, aided greatly by the 1849 gold rush. His little settlement, near what is now Market and Montgomery Streets, was intended as a trading post and resupply point for the ships visiting San Francisco Bay.

Certainly no amount of wizardry can expand the perimeters of the restaurant. Space is at a premium, and that might be why no reservations are taken. But at peak moments the wait for a table was only about 20 minutes, and the attractive bar is a congenial place. Once diners are seated, prompt service brings a small tub of hummus and a saucer of olive oil with garlic -- dips for decent bread.

title: H. Kauffman & Sons
description: There's a sensual quiver felt in the face of the functional. I have friends who linger in hardware stores, fingering the ratchets. Writer friends seek solace in stationery stores: the intricate clips, the promise of all that paper. I seek out saddlery shops. In New York City, H. Kauffman & Sons Saddlery Company used to be down the street from my computer store. A year ago, H. Kauffman & Sons closed to the public. You can still order through their catalogue, but the sensual pleasure of visiting the physical store remains vivid. A legitimate, thrifty reason sent me there. Shoes. A fashion season ago there were all those neophytes stamping about in rip-off designs, pagan jodhpur boots that would fall apart at the mere sight of a horse. Why not get the real thing? Built twice, make that five, times as sturdy, and a third of the price. Such a good feeling: a justified purchase.

title: Art of the Explosive 80's And Issues of Endurance

title: Sharks and Flowers In Albuquerque
description: Two new nature attractions have opened in Albuquerque: the Albuquerque Aquarium and the Rio Grande Botanic Garden. The aquarium's exhibits reproduce aquatic environments along the Rio Grande, from its headwaters in southern Colorado to the Gulf of Mexico. The showpiece is a 285,000-gallon shark tank with 15 to 20 sharks and several other species of fish. A tank with several hundred tropical fish in an artificial coral reef depicts the Flower Garden Banks, the northernmost of the Gulf of Mexico's coral reef communities. Other exhibits, including a jetty tank that dramatizes unintended consequences of controlling beach erosion, show the human impact on the Texas coast.

title: Warden's Work Can Be Women's Work

This is a maximum security prison housing 540 inmates. It has no large courtyard for inmates to lift weights or just hang out, kicking dirt around. Outside areas, each about the size of a patio, where small groups of inmates can talk and smoke, do exist. But for many of the inmates, outdoor recreation time is spent in steel bar cages no larger than a bedroom closet.

title: Once the Hope of Secular Turks, Ex-Leader Is Now Widely Reviled

She seemed the ideal figure to lead her country toward the next century: an English-speaking economist, a woman in a Muslim country, and a dedicated secularist in a region where fundamentalism was making steady gains.

title: Philadelphia School Wars
description: Plagued by truancy, violence and underachievement, Philadelphia's public schools are among the nation's worst. As of last year, fewer than 6 percent of the city's high school students tested as competent in reading. The children of the city's middle class -- including its politicians -- have fled to private or parochial schools. Yet despite all these obvious signs of failure, Philadelphians were stunned when their superintendent of schools seized control of two high schools and announced that teachers there would be transferred for failing to raise achievement levels. The takeover provoked demonstrations, vandalism, a lawsuit by the teachers and a scolding from political leaders who knew perfectly well that the superintendent, David Hornbeck, had no choice.

title: Creating a Pedophile Who Is Sympathetic
description: A DRIVE, AS STUDENTS OF BASIC PSYCHOLOGY know, is an unconquerable urge. It can also mean a spin in a car. For Uncle Peck, the frighteningly charming sexual predator in Paula Vogel's play ''How I Learned to Drive'' at the Vineyard Theater, it is both things at once. A driven driver, he patiently practices the art of seduction on his young niece (Mary-Louise Parker) by luring her to his car and teaching her two kinds of lesson.

title: The Shop
description: Two spindly legs swimming in gray corduroy trousers made loose by frequent wear, the seat of the trousers made especially smooth from sliding in and out of the big blue plastic chair with its square steel footrest. This was the chair her customers always sat in as she styled their hair, facing the mirror, facing themselves. At the end of those two legs -- my 7- or 8-year-old own -- my feet encased in down-at-the-heel black oxfords with round toes; they do not reach the footrest. When I tap the sides of my shoes together, hair falls from the soles, as if from a prehistoric monster's appendages, appendages given to shedding hair dyed red or gold or pressed by a hot comb.

title: Department-Store Groupie

One sunshiny September day, I was crossing 37th Street when I saw three militant Hummer vehicles barreling down Fifth Avenue. Upon noticing that each of the vehicles was bedecked with flags reading ''Hanes Resilience hosiery'' and with a bevy of preternaturally attractive women, I feared that fashion models had mobilized, with pantyhose as their broadswords. But a moment later reality set in. I realized that a promotional campaign had been loosed upon midtown like a virus and that I had become a most willing human host.

For about $8 for a three-hour session, a kid can surf the Net, talk to long-distance grandparents via videophone or choose from 85 software titles -- which just happen to be among the 600 titles that Cyberplay sells. title: Ex-Professor Recalls Harvard's Days of Rage During the 1960's
description: IMAGINE you are a favored teacher at a prestigious university, not just admired by your colleagues and students but golden boy. Everything seems handed to you on a silver platter -- a beautiful wife, a baby on the way and rent-free housing. You are even, at one point, on the short list to be the university's president. Imagine, too, that it is 1969. The Vietnam War is raging in Southeast Asia while in the United States students rage in protest. Suddenly the walls of tradition and safety cave in around you, and you find yourself in the middle of your own personal war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAULL, GERALD E., M.D.
description: GAULL-Gerald E., M.D. Of Washington, DC. On April 2, while on vacation in Quito, Ecuador. Scientist, educator, pediatrician and founding director of Georgetown Center for Food and Nutrition Policy, Georgetown University. During a four decade scientific career, Dr. Gaull made ground-breaking discoveries about development of the human brain during pregnancy and infancy. He identified the role of amino acid taurine in brain development and patented its addition to infant formula, now an industry nutritional standard. In 1978 he won the Borden Award of American Academy of Pediatrics for his work in nutrition. He was the beloved husband of Florence McSherry Heffernan Gaull, the proud and loving father of Erik S. and Stephen B. Gaull, and the loving brother of Ricky G. Silberman. Also survived by devoted stepchildren Shelagh Ellman-Pearl, Thomas Ellman, Barat Ellman, Kitsey Canaan, Nancy Ellman and four cherished step-granddaughters. Memorial service at Dahlgren Chapel, Georgetown University, Monday, April 7, at 2 PM. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospital Metropolitano, Quito, Ecuador; contact: CFNP, 202965-6400.

title: Oops! Wrong War

What Mr. Albert remembered most, he told me, was the thief who showed up, took out a ''big, big gun,'' demanded the car of one of the evacuees and then sped away. Ten minutes later, the thief returned and pointed the same gun at the same man, only this time demanded his license and car registration. The thief apparently had an inkling that if real law and order ever came to Albania, he might need the license.

title: Cursive, Foiled Again: Mourning the Demise of Penmanship

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARDING, ERROL NICHOLSON, M.D.
description: HARDING-Errol Nicholson, M.D., died on Sunday, March 2, in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida of complications of Parkinson's disease. Born on July 8, 1920 in Montreal to Dorothy Walcot Nicholson and Jay Wentworth Harding. He obtained a B.A. degree from McGill University. After serving as a Lieutenant in the second Canadian Light anti aircraft regiment in Europe in World War II he returned to McGill Medical school. A diplomate of the American board of Anesthesiology. He was an assistant professor of Anesthesiology at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, D.C. in the 50's. He subsequently practiced at St. Lukes/Roosevelt Hospital center in New York City until he retired in 1981. He had been living in Palm Beach Gardens and in East Hampton. He is survived by his friend Gerald Clavet.

description: MARCUS-Helen. Of Fort Lauderdale, passed away peacefully on Sunday, April 6, 1997. Mrs. Marcus made her home here for the past 22 years, coming from Teaneck, NJ. A devoted wife of the late Herbert Marcus, M.D., she was a beloved mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister and friend. ''Amah,'' as Helen was known to all, was mother of Robin (Thomas) Costa, Robert Rein and Barbara (John) Hedman, and mother to Martha (Ron) Krauss, and the late Leslie Marcus. Her sister Alva Scharf, friend Shirley Raybin and sister-in-law Edna Silverman will always remember their dear Helen. She was the adored grandmother of Mark (Aurlie), Debbie (Derek), David, Rachel, Adam and Rebecca. Loving great-grandmother of Liav and Elital, Zachary and Jacob, and caring aunt to her numerous nieces and nephews. She was a member of the I Can Cope Group at Holy Cross Hospital for many years. Aside from being a businesswoman, her primary devotion was to her family. She took pride in their many achievements and loved them all dearly. She will be greatly missed by all. A truly selfless person, when Amah died, everyone cried. Services will be held on Tuesday, April 8, 1997, at 2 PM, at The Riverside-Gordon Memorial Chapels, Tamarac, Florida, 954523-5801. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the charity of your choice.

But then, this is a virtuoso with a sense of humor who reads ''Calvin and Hobbes'' and ''The Far Side'' when she is not studying Goethe or Heine in preparation for playing Schubert. He was graduated from Fordham University in 1947 and later earned graduate degrees from New York University in meteorology, mathematics and business. After beginning his career in public accounting and Exxon Corporation, he joined the investment firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1961. For twenty seven years Bill Tuite was one of the financial services industries pioneers retireing in 1988 as Senior Vice President for Data Processing. He is survived by his wife Paula McCarthy Tuite of Stuart and his children. Ipsilon pioneered IP switching, a technology that Cabletron's chairman, Craig R. Benson, said could challenge the Cisco Systems' routers as the dominant means of sending data across the Internet. Cabletron's investment is designed to help finance Ipsilon's push for its IP standard. Cabletron said it would offer Ipsilon's IP switches as part of a Cabletron system.

title: Firefighters Reach Accord With a Raise

title: High Cancer Rate Confirmed
description: The high incidence of cancer among children in the Toms River area, long suspected by residents and the authorities, was confirmed for the first time yesterday, and it is not a statistical fluke, state health officials said.

title: Autopsy Reveals That Officer Shot Youth in the Back
description: A Manhattan teen-ager killed by the police as he carried a machete on a Washington Heights street early Sunday was shot in the back, according to an autopsy, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday as a growing controversy swirled around the case.

title: The Tenants, Full of Fear, Aim at Bruno
description: SOMEBODY must have told Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, that a bunch of insurrectionists from New York City were about to descend on him. How else to explain the show of force yesterday outside his door in the Legislative Office Building? Four state troopers stood there, stone-faced, the moment that a band of New York tenants showed up at the building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKSCHER, AUGUST
description: HECKSCHER-August. Was a valiant and inspirational member of the New School community, serving with great devotion for 41 years as a Trustee and Life Trustee, as Chair of the Board of Trustees, Chair of the Board of Governors of Parsons School of Design, and member of the Board of Governors of Eugene Lang College and Mannes College of Music. He believed deeply in the mission of higher education and in the responsibility of each individual for the environment of our cities. The Board extends its heartfelt condolences to his wife Claude, their sons Stephen, Philip and Charles, and their 6 grandchildren. John L. Tishman, Chair, Board of Trustees Jonathan F. Fanton, President New School for Social Research

title: Tuning In to the Hidden Message in Some Fruits' Siren Songs
description: EVOLVED over eons to entice, a lusciously ripened fruit is pure temptation. But as Adam and Eve, as well as other intrepid fruit samplers, discovered, what hangs on vine and tree is not always the sweet treat it seems and can even be downright dangerous. Even though a fruit's job is to be eaten by animals that could transport its seeds elsewhere, biologists say most fruits in the wild actually range between horrible tasting and deathly poisonous.

title: A World of Corruption and Personal Enrichment
description: If you got the impression over the years that the Mexican Government was a stew of corruption, nothing in ''Murder, Money and Mexico'' is likely to change your mind. Tonight's edition of ''Frontline'' tells of influence-peddling, money laundering, drug dealing, murder and associated activities by the Salinas political family, which appears to have set a record, even for Mexico, of self-enrichment.

title: Pain and Profit for Investors as Computers Confront Year 2000
description: It's human nature: When fire swept through the primeval forest, some primitive man must have furrowed his heavy brow and thought, ''I can profit from this.'' Thus started the first shish kebab stand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GINSBERG, ALLEN
description: GINSBERG-Allen. The Brooklyn College community deeply mourns the passing of Distinguished Professor of English Allen Ginsberg. His 18 years of teaching and service wil be long remembered. Vernon E. Lattin, President Brooklyn College

title: Teen-Ager in Beating Dies
description: The Bronx teen-ager who was beaten by a gang of young men on Madison Avenue in Manhattan during the St. Patrick's Day Parade last month died last night at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, the police said.

title: 20 Pulitzer Prizes Are Announced With a Theme of Personal Impact on Lives
description: Steven Millhauser is an English professor at Skidmore College and a novelist little noticed outside publishing circles. But he moved quickly onto center stage yesterday when his fourth novel, ''Martin Dressler: The Tale of an American Dreamer,'' won the 1997 Pulitzer Prize for fiction.

title: The Gutsy, the Greedy, the Humble
description: ''Is this New York's version of Swinging London?'' asked Michael Roberts, the British artist and writer who was just named the director of fashion visuals for The New Yorker. He was seated on the floor of a dank, empty store in TriBeCa, watching models performance-art their way through Susan Cianciolo's disturbing collection.

title: European Merger Runs Aground
description: Framatome, a French nuclear reactor maker, said yesterday that its planned merger with GEC Alsthom was unlikely to succeed. The merger between the state-controlled Framatome and GEC Alsthom, a venture between the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain and Alcatel Alsthom S.A., failed after General Electric of Britain refused to accept the French Government's condition that it hold less than 50 percent in the new company, Framatome said.

title: Volcano Captured Corn, Chilies and House Mice
description: IT was early evening in the rainy season when the villagers felt the ground shake and then probably trembled themselves at the sight of blasts of steam in the distance. They dropped what they were doing and fled, abandoning their thatch-roofed huts, fruit trees in full ripeness and unwashed dinner dishes.

title: Deflection Just About Finishes Islanders
description: Nobody, as Coach Rick Bowness pointed out, can accuse the Islanders of going down without a fight. But down they went anyway -- to a crushing 2-1 defeat to the Montreal Canadiens tonight on a deflected Benoit Brunet backhander with 3 minutes 10 seconds left.

title: Sybase Puts Account in Review
description: Sybase Inc., a software company in Concord, Mass., said yesterday that it had placed in review its account, which had been at Dahlin Smith White in Salt Lake City. Billings were estimated at $12 million to $15 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, BERTHA
description: GREEN-Bertha. The American Friends of Bar-Ilan University in Israel extend deepest condolences to the immediate Past Chairman of the Global Board of Trustees, Dr. Morris L. Green, his wife, Charlotte, and the entire family on the passing of his mother, Bertha Green. Morris and Charlotte supported especially the University's Jesselson Institute for Advanced Ed Torah Studies and Midrasha for Women, the Presidential Founders Society, the Adopt-a-Student Program and the Lookstein Center for Jewish Educators in the Diaspora. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Jane Stern Lebell Pres., American Friends Gen. (Res.) Yehuda Halevy Executive V.P.

title: Saab May Join Airbus Project
description: Saab A.B. of Sweden said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft maker, to evaluate whether it will enter as a risk-venture partner in building the new super-jumbo A3XX aircraft.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Show Rise
description: Treasury prices recovered yesterday from Friday's sharp fall, bolstered by a strong dollar and by thin trading.

title: Travis Bogard, 79, Author, Teacher and Scholar of Eugene O'Neill
description: Travis Bogard, an author, teacher and one of the foremost scholars on the life and work of Eugene O'Neill, died on Saturday at a hospital in Berkeley, Calif. He was 79 and lived in Berkeley.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EICHENBAUM, RICHARD
description: EICHENBAUM-Richard. Beloved husband of Ginger. Devoted father of Zachary. Dear brother of Merle Lipman. Services and interment were held on Sunday, April 6, 1997.

title: Northeasterners Unite to Derail Transportation Aid Cuts
description: With lawmakers from states in the South and Middle West seeking to eliminate billions of dollars in Federal transportation aid to the Northeast, an unusual alliance of politicians, labor leaders, environmentalists and others from the region urged the United States Senate yesterday not to tinker with the existing aid formula, which affects everything from highways to bicycle paths.

title: Fast-Paced Derring-Do and a Love Quadrangle
description: If ''Nabucco'' made Verdi famous, ''Ernani'' insured that he would stay that way. The two operas formed a package deal: a pair of events that would begin the composer's long association with Teatro La Fenice in Venice. The first of them simply took up Verdi's strong success in Milan in 1842 and repeated it in Venice; the second was a whole new opera. Solidifying the reputation gained from ''Nabucco'' was essential to Verdi, and the first performances of ''Ernani'' in 1844 were a striking success.

title: Unions Demonstrate Near Office Building
description: Union construction workers demonstrated yesterday outside a downtown office building that they said a developer was transforming into apartments using state tax incentives but with nonunion labor.

title: Terror Threat in Bahrain Brings U.S. Alert
description: The United States has uncovered the outlines of a terrorist plan by dissidents in Bahrain to attack American troops stationed in the country and has put its forces there on alert, Administration officials said today.

title: Gas Line Near School Broken
description: A backhoe operator digging next to an elementary school ruptured a 4-inch natural gas pipeline yesterday, forcing the evacuation of 330 children and 45 staff members, the authorities said. The contractor at the site failed to make a required check on the location of underground lines, state regulators told The Associated Press. No one was hurt, but students at the Hawthorne School lost half a day of school.

The incremental plan will disappoint those who believe that no American child should go uninsured. But it offers a politically realistic step in a worthy direction.

title: Meeting of Computers and Biology: The DNA Chip
description: IN a ''clean room'' similar to many others in Silicon Valley, a group of technicians is assembling batches of chips with the usual machines of a semiconductor factory. But these chips are not fabricated from layers of silicon. They are being made from DNA, the stuff of genes. And they are designed not to do computations but to read out the turbulent streams of information that evolution has packed into the genomes of living organisms.

title: People

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOVER, PLINY GILES
description: DOVER-Pliny Giles, of Millburn, NJ, on April 4, 1997. A retired transportation engineer, he was the New Jersey Turnpike's original Engineer of Design from its inception in 1949 through its opening and first five yars of operation and expansion. He was instrumental in developing the geometric design standards and features that brought the Turnpike national prominence among major highways for safety and efficiency. Many of these design concepts saw further use and success in the Interstate Highway program that followed. Mr. Dover later headed the highway design section at the consulting engineering firm of DeLeuw, Cather and its affiliates during which time he served two years in Perth, Australia. Surviving are his daughter, Pamela Finney of Bronxville, NY, his sister, Mary Jane Lott of Richmond, VA, his brother, John R. of New Vernon, NJ, six nephews and nieces and their children. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Thogmorton-Dover Scholarship Fund, Central Methodist College, Fayette, MO 65248 or The Corner Store Dance Company, 1428 Midland Ave., Bronxville, NY 10708.

title: Toppling Theories, Scientists Find 6 Slits, Not Big Gash, Sank Titanic

Everyone agrees that an iceberg was the proximate cause. title: VOXWARE STOCK GAINS ON NEWS OF DEAL WITH MICROSOFT

Terms were not disclosed. Microsoft plans to embed Voxware's technologies in Microsoft Netshow 2.0, a system for broadcasting live audio, video and multimedia on the Internet and corporate computer networks. Voxware's products allow the transmission of high-quality speech and sound over computer networks. Its stock gained 87.5 cents to close at $4.875.

description: ALBERIO deCELLARIO-Raquel. Of New York City & Buenos Aires. On April 5, 1997, on the eve of her 81st year. Loving wife of the late Alberto Cellario and devoted mother of Raquel, Maria Ines and Maria Rosa and their husbands, Humberto, Anthony, and Vincent. Beloved grandmother and great grandmother of Marisa, Alberto, Mariana, Nicholas, Rafe, Santiago, Juan, Carlos, and Sebastian. The family will receive friends and well wishers at home April 8 and 9 from 6 to 9 P.M. A funeral mass will be celebrated Saturday, April 12, 2 P.M. at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue. Her garden will forever grow.

title: Students Take Hospitality
description: The Hospitality Consulting Group of Coopers & Lybrand, the Manhattan accounting firm, is getting an extra hand these days from three sophomores from the Frederick Douglass Academy, a public high school in Manhattan.

title: Ex-Sergeant Pleads Guilty To Having Sex With Trainees
description: As the first major trial in a sex-abuse case at the Army's Aberdeen Proving Ground in Maryland is about to begin this week, the defendant, a former drill sergeant, today pleaded guilty to 11 counts of having sex with female trainees.

title: Witherspoon Jabbed
description: The two-time heavyweight champion TIM WITHERSPOON and the hard-hitting JIMMY THUNDER sat beside each other yesterday at Madison Square Garden, where they will stand toe to toe on May 16 as part of the ANDREW GOLOTA-RAY MERCER fight card.

title: Classical Pirates Made New In a Swashbuckling Revival
description: Experiment in dance is not necessarily synonymous with the avant-garde, as the Boston Ballet is demonstrating with surprising success at the Wang Center for the Performing Arts here in the first American production of ''The Pirate,'' otherwise known as ''Le Corsaire,'' a 19th-century French-Russian ballet.

title: Bankers Trust's Deal a Bet on Growth-Company Prosperity
description: With its planned acquisition of Alex. Brown & Sons, the Bankers Trust New York Corporation is making a couple of bets.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 28 about the Vienna Philharmonic's decision to admit women as full members referred incorrectly in some editions to the orchestra's annual subsidy from the Austrian Government. The orchestra has received 2.5 million Austrian schillings a year ($210,000), not $2.5 million. The orchestra says the subsidy has been discontinued. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, HERBERT S.
description: ROSEN-Herbert S. On Sunday, April 6, a month after the death of his wife of 58 years, Shirley. He was a devoted husband, beloved and loving father of David Rosen and Jane Barowitz. Father-in-law of Barbara Goren and Elliott Barowitz and perceptive and indulgent grandfather of Zack and Jordan Barowitz, Nick, Adam, Annie and Sarah Rosen. An executive, a builder and developer and a business consultant, Herbert Rosen brought energy, imagination and passion to all his endeavors. Deeply attached to life, he endured years of illness with heroic optimism and tenacity. We miss him very much.

description: ARTS

title: Starwood to Buy 2 Hotels
description: The Starwood Lodging Trust said today that it would buy two hotels in Chicago, the Raphael and the Tremont, for a total of $32.2 million. Starwood agreed to buy the 172-room Raphael from the closely held Raphael Group for $17.75 million. It plans to renovate the rooms and public areas at an expected additional cost of $6 million. In a separate transaction, Starwood, based in Phoenix, bought the 129-room Tremont from the Morgan Stanley Group.

title: G.O.P. Wins First Test in Albany In an Effort to End Rent Controls
description: In the first test of strength in Albany's bitter battle over rent control, the Republican leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, beat back a Democratic effort today to extend the regulations limiting rents on more than a million apartments in New York City and its suburbs.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Woman Charged in Cocaine Ring
description: A woman employing several female lieutenants in a lucrative drug operation has been charged with running a multimillion-dollar cocaine trafficking operation that moved the drugs from Colombia, through Miami, to the Midwest, and to the streets of New York City, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Parcells Listening To Offers For No. 1
description: In his clearest statement about the college draft, Bill Parcells said today that he had not ruled out trading the Jets' No. 1 draft pick.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: MATERIAL SCIENCES STOCK SLIDES ON FALSE DATA
description: The stock of the Material Sciences Corporation skidded 16 percent yesterday after the company said fake bookkeeping entries had forced it to restate profits for the last three years. The company, a maker of coated materials based in Elk Grove Village, Ill., said the discovery might put it in violation of some of its credit agreements. Material Sciences said the plant controller of its laminates and composites unit falsified the unit's financial results starting late in the fiscal year 1995. It restated profits for the 1997 fiscal year to $16.1 million, from $18.2 million. Profits for 1996 were restated to $9.8 million, from $12 million. Profits for 1995 were restated to $16.4 million, from $16.7 million. Shares of Material Sciences dropped $2.875, to $14.50.

Mrs. Horowitz was an administrator with JCCA for many years and a consummate social worker, teacher and advocate for children and families. Irwin U. Goldberg, President Stephen Sokoloff, Chairman of the Board Paul Gitelson, DSW, Exec. VP

title: A Former Child Prodigy Talks of Physical Abuse, Broken Dreams and Learning to Forgive
description: This is the year for prodigies in sports. Martina Hingis, 16, is the youngest No. 1 player in tennis ever. Tara Lipinski, 14, is the youngest world champion figure skater in history. Tiger Woods, 21, will try this weekend to become the youngest player to win the Masters. And a 14-year-old girl named Natalie Gulbis qualified for a tournament at Lincoln, Calif., last week, becoming the second-youngest golfer to play in a Ladies Professional Golf Association event.

description: GREENE-Natalie S., on April 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Jay E. Loving mother of Robert, Howard and Marjorie. Services Wed., 1 PM, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows.

title: John Daly's Visitor Has Been There
description: ORIGINALLY, their bond was having been Razorbacks at the University of Arkansas, even though they were there some 30 years apart. Now they have developed another bond from going to another institution, five years apart.

title: Wave of Riots Against Chinese and Christians Sets Indonesia on Edge
description: It was just before 3 A.M., and the Muslim feast-day drumming had been going on for almost an hour. Liu Kim Cuang, the Chinese merchant who lived next door, was furious, the 17-year-old drummer recalls.

title: A Kremlin Telltale Expose From the Provinces
description: Most government officials wait until they are out of office to publish kiss-and-tell memoirs. Others let it all leak out while they are still on the job.

title: A Leader Needed on Rent Control
description: In just 10 weeks the laws protecting more than a million tenants in New York City from unrestricted rent increases will expire. Already the State Legislature is in a familiar uproar over one of the most emotional and complicated issues it will face this year. Yesterday, as tenant groups protested, the Republican-controlled Senate rejected a Democratic attempt to renew the current system of controls. That was a sensible step, because the existing setup is outmoded and unfair to tenants and landlords alike. But the process cannot stop there. What is needed now is an agreement to phase out rent control over the long term with protections for those tenants who need it the most.

title: Grossman's Files For Chapter 11
description: Grossman's Inc., a building-supply retailer that has been suffering from a cash shortage, said today that it had filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors.

title: Documents Like Living Wills Are Rarely of Aid, Study Says
description: Despite intense publicity and exhortations to the public to write advance directives to guide decision-making at the end of life, almost no dying patients have them, researchers find. And when patients do have these directives, the documents make little or no difference in medical care.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMAN, DONN E.
description: HARMAN-Donn E. On Friday, April 4, 1997 after a long illness. Born January 27, 1917 the son of Henry Harman and Beth Soper Harman in Summit, New Jersey. In the early '50's he wrote plays and television shows with George Batson. He join the Katz Agency in the early '50's and became Financial Director of Katz, and later was Controller of Media Payment of the Katz Agency. After his retirement, he co-founded Tollett and Harman Autographs with his companion Robert Tollett, retiring from that when he became ill. He is survived by brother Henry Harman, sister-in-law Irene Harman, a cousin Gordon Genung and his companion of forty-five years Robert Tollett.

title: Dumb and Whiney
description: We are fortunate today to have with us Dr. B. B. Braithwaite, the eminent authority on self-help, diet, getting rich quick and finding spiritual peace in 30 days. Dr. Braithwaite has kindly agreed to answer a few questions from our readers.

description: HECHT-James R. Devoted husband of Beatrice. Beloved father of David and Arnie. Also survived by 7 grandchildren. Services today at 12 noon at Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel, 152 2 Ave., NYC.

title: Body of Missing Fordham Student Is Found Off Pier
description: Patrick McNeill, the 21-year-old Fordham University student whose disappearance on Feb. 16 led to a citywide search by his family and more than 1,000 volunteers, was found dead yesterday morning, his body floating near a pier in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: USX-U.S. STEEL AND INLAND STEEL DISCUSSED A MERGER IDEA
description: USX-U.S. Steel Group and Inland Steel Industries confirmed yesterday that they had discussed the idea of possible business combinations but that the idea was dismissed. USX-U.S. Steel's president, Paul J. Wilhelm, told analysts last week that his company, a unit of the USX Corporation based in Pittsburgh, was considering growth options, including acquisitions. That led to speculation that USX-U.S. Steel might acquire either Inland Steel or the National Steel Corporation, 51 percent of which is owned by the NKK Corporation of Japan. In separate statements, USX-U.S. Steel and Inland, which is based in Chicago, said yesterday that they had discussed combining some of their steelmaking businesses early last year. USX-U.S. Steel also said that ''no merger discussions with other integrated steel companies are ongoing.''

title: New York State to Sell 14th Street Armory
description: The state armory on West 14th Street in Manhattan, a hulking gray masonry building that has been closed and mostly vacant since 1993 and derided by local residents as an eyesore for years before that, is being put up for sale by the state.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Companies Are Finding Tasty Profits in Fancy Food
description: In the large white kitchen, a woman with a white apron stirs a plastic tub of deep red tomato sauce and black olives. Next to her, a woman squeezes dollops of black beans onto dough. Not far from her, another woman delicately closes the tiny bean hors d'oeuvres with her fingers.

title: Looking Back, in Fondness
description: Lessons in history are seldom as warm, funny and inspiring as ''A D.T.W. Founders Celebration,'' a salute to the choreographers and dancers who helped create Dance Theater Workshop 30 years ago, when that hoary, invaluable cultural institution was simply a sliver of a loft where friends made dances. The program, presented on Friday night by the workshop, should be an annual event and required viewing for each new generation of dancers.

title: FOAMEX STOCK RISES 14% ON POSITIVE EARNINGS PREDICTION
description: The stock of Foamex International Inc. rose 14 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of polyurethane and foam products based in Linwood, Pa., said it expected first-quarter earnings to exceed figures a year ago. It said it expected earnings of 29 cents to 33 cents a share for the three months ended March 31. It also said it had begun a review of its capital structure to reduce interest expenses and improve flexibility. Its long-term debt was about $483 million as of Dec. 29, 1996. Foamex stock gained $1.75 to close at $14.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, ARTHUR
description: WARD-Arthur, of Marlboro, NJ. Beloved husband of Bess and devoted father of Carole (Jack Scheckner). Cherished grandfather of Stacey and Meredith. Funeral services Wednesday, 11:30AM at Bloomfield-Cooper Memorial Chapels, Manalapan, New Jersey.

title: Gooden's Pain A Mystery
description: Dwight Gooden's mysterious lower abdominal pain has not disappeared, so the Yankees sent the pitcher back to New York today to undergo more medical tests on Tuesday. The Yankees are unsure why Gooden is still ailing and they are unsure whether he will need to be put on the disabled list.

title: Group Will Study Racing
description: A new nonprofit group created to benefit the thoroughbred racing industry in New York State was unveiled yesterday, targeting for research and review such issues as the franchise renewal for the New York Racing Association, casino gambling, simulcasting and track safety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEBZEHNER, HIRSCH, D.M.D.
description: SIEBZEHNER-Hirsch, D.M.D. The Mount Sinai Alumnni records with sorrow the passing of their longtime colleague and friend. He will be missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Albert M. Lefkovits, M.D., Pres. Alisan B. Goldfarb, M.D., Secy.

title: With Kitsch and Bongos, A Lounge Lizard Life
description: The Windows on the World bar atop the World Trade Center is an oddly designed place, caught somewhere between kitsch and style. So too are the bands that the bar is bringing in for its new weekly lounge-music series, which began on Thursday and Friday nights with performances by Combustible Edison, a Boston band that revels in 1950's camp culture.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ITI TECHNOLOGIES INC., North St. Paul, Minn., a maker of wireless security systems, agreed to buy Caddx-Caddi Controls Inc., Gladewater, Tex., from four individual shareholders for $19 million.

title: Public Housing Needs Reform, Too
description: Across the country, seismic changes to welfare, schools and social programs like foster care are under way. Yet the nation's public housing system has remained holed up, largely immune from these sweeping reform movements.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGH, SINA
description: SINGH-Sina. Born May 1, 1955, died April 5, 1997. Raised in India, lived in NYC since 1975. Cherished son of Ram and Nancy Singh. Beloved brother of Mike and Raj. Loving brother-in-law of Joanna, uncle of Jacob and Kiva. A magical artist of brilliance and grace. He lived for painting, music, cooking, laughter and giving. He greeted neighbors from his stoop with tea and dazzling wit. The world's most wonderful guy, we love you, we will miss you.

title: NETANYAHU HOLDS WHITE HOUSE TALK
description: Trying to shore up the Middle East peace effort, President Clinton met today for almost two hours with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, but emerged with no immediate plans for any extraordinary step, like a summit meeting, to restart talks in the region.

title: Draining the Drug War
description: In the decade I have been writing about drugs and the drug war I have been getting a bonus that gets bigger every year, and more valuable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAULL, GERALD E., M.D.
description: GAULL-Gerald E., M.D. Of Washington, DC. On April 2, while on vacation in Quito, Ecuador. Scientist, educator, pediatrician and founding director of Georgetown Center for Food and Nutrition Policy, Georgetown University. During a four decade scientific career, Dr. Gaull made ground-breaking discoveries about development of the human brain during pregnancy and infancy. He identified the role of amino acid taurine in brain development and patented its addition to infant formula, now an industry nutritional standard. In 1978 he won the Borden Award of American Academy of Pediatrics for his work in nutrition. He was the beloved husband of Florence McSherry Heffernan Gaull, the proud and loving father of Erik S. and Stephen B. Gaull and the loving brother of Ricky G. Silberman. Also survived by devoted stepchildren Shelagh Ellman-Pearl, Thomas Ellman, Barat Ellman, Kitsey Canaan, Nancy Ellman and four cherished step-granddaughters. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospital Metropolitano, Quito, Ecuador; contact: CFNP, 202-965-6400.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No one ever said ELTON JOHN was understated, but the singer may have hit a high note for flamboyance at his 50th birthday celebration in London. His costume was so elaborate that he had to be transported to the 600-guest party at the Hammersmith Palais in a trailer truck decorated to resemble an 18th-century French drawing room, The Times of London reported yesterday. The costume, which cost more than $80,000, included a 15-foot train of white ostrich feathers and a silver wig three and a half feet high, topped with a silver ship under full sail. The singer had to be lowered from the truck with a pneumatic lift. At the party he was seated on a golden throne.

title: Knicks Look to Backcourt
description: The Knicks' fortunes depend on the shooting accuracy of their starting backcourt.

description: WHYNE-Eva. On April 6, at 104 years. Beloved wife of the late Alfred, loving mother of Sam, Ruth Boroshok and the late Phil. Devoted aunt of Mike Novack and Pola Akeraisen. Cherished grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of 15. Services Wednesday at 12 noon at the Westchester Riverside, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, New York.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Reuters on Friday about a pullout date for the United Nations force in Haiti misidentified the representative of Portugal, which holds the Security Council presidency this month. He is Antonio Monteiro; Pedro Catarino was his predecessor.

title: Report Links Crimes to States With Weak Gun Controls
description: A new Congressional study using data from the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms shows that a handful of states, most in the South, with weak gun control laws are responsible for supplying a large percentage of the guns used in crimes in other states.

title: Pataki Says He's Seeking To Resolve Rent Fight
description: Under fire from Democrats and tenants' groups for not playing a more active role in resolving the fight over New York state's rent laws, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that his staff had begun talks with both tenants and landlords about a possible compromise.

description: BENZIGER-Signe. On April 5, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Gerard N. Benziger. Loving sister of Elizabeth Stern. Mass of Christian burial at St. John & Paul Church, Larchmont, NY on Friday 10:00 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. For further information contact John J Fox, Funeral Home, Larchmont.

title: A Rest for Roseanne
description: After a late attempt to create a spinoff of her hit comedy ''Roseanne'' that would keep the central character alive in a new series, Roseanne and the company that produces her show, Carsey-Werner, have now agreed ''to call it a day,'' said Peter Tortorici, an executive with Carsey-Werner.

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS $18 BILLION MORE IN MEDICARE CUTS
description: The Clinton Administration offered today to make additional cuts of $18 billion in projected Medicare spending over the next five years to help reach agreement on eliminating the Federal deficit, people involved in the budget negotiations said today.

title: Panel Urged To Investigate Senate Race In Louisiana
description: Senate investigators today recommended a limited inquiry into election fraud accusations in the narrow victory of Mary L. Landrieu, the freshman Senator from Louisiana, over her Republican opponent, Louis Jenkins.

title: Riordan Is Re-elected Los Angeles Mayor
description: Mayor Richard J. Riordan, who told voters he had delivered on his promise to turn the nation's second-largest city around, was re-elected today over Tom Hayden, a 1960's radical-turned-legislator.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, SELMA SALINGER
description: GRUBER-Selma Salinger. On April 8, 1997. A warm, wise and gentle woman. Her youthful, vital spirit touched so many. A true gourmet who loved to bring people together in celebration. A wonderful and loving mother of Julia and Jessica. Devoted, caring wife of the late Manny Gruber. A special mother-in-law of Larry and Hunter. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Developmental Chemotherapy Service at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital will be appreciated. Service Thursday, April 10, 12 Noon, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street.

title: As His Legacy, Clinton Seeks to Improve Race Relations
description: President Clinton has ordered his staff to suggest a way for him to play a prominent role this year in improving American race relations, a goal that he is trying to make a focus and legacy of his second term.

title: EVERGREEN TO SELL 3 RADIO STATIONS FOR $64.1 MILLION
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell two radio stations in Chicago and one in Philadelphia for $64.1 million. Evergreen, a radio broadcasting company based in Irving, Tex., said it would sell WEJM-FM in Chicago to Dontron Inc. for $14.8 million; WEJM-AM in Chicago to Douglas Broadcasting/Personal Achievement Radio for $7.5 million, and WFLN-FM in Philadelphia to Greater Media Radio Inc. for $41.8 million.

title: Truncated Shuttle Flight Ends, but Ship May Fly Again Soon
description: Forced to return to Earth early because of a faulty power unit, the space shuttle Columbia landed safely today at the Kennedy Space Center, and officials raised the possibility that the mission might be reflown this summer.

title: HUNT TO CUT WORK FORCE AND TRIM PRODUCT LINE
description: The Hunt Manufacturing Company said yesterday that it would lay off 15 percent of its staff and take a charge of $14 million to $16 million this year as it concentrates on the most profitable segments of its office-supply business. The Philadelphia-based company said it planned to cut 300 jobs and to trim the variety of products it makes by 71 percent. The company also said it might sell its Bevis office furniture unit. Hunt said it would focus on three areas: consumer products like X-Acto brand knives; presentation graphics like laminating and mounting equipment, and substrates like its Bienfang brand foam board. The company currently has about 2,000 employees.

title: What Vanity and Casual Fridays Wrought
description: After years of blue suits, Patrick Yalung has started to think about clothing and has come to this conclusion: he likes it.

title: DAWSON SCIENCE MAKES $102 MILLION ACQUISITION IN CHINA
description: The Dawson Science Corporation of Reno, which has been buying Asian businesses, said yesterday that it had acquired a vehicle-leasing and transportation company in southern China for more than $102 million in stock. The acquired company, the Shenzhen City Zhenghua Traffic and Transportation Main Group, owns more than 1,000 taxis and trucks. The company, based in Shenzhen, is a unit of the Shenzhena Zhenghua Group. Shenzhen City plans to expand its small vehicle leasing and transportation business throughout China, modeling itself after similar businesses in the United States.

title: Czar and Lenin Share Fate: Neither Can Rest in Peace
description: Two of the greatest antagonists in Russian history are once again pitted against each other in an odd and passionate debate currently obsessing Russians: their burials.

title: Orange Rejects a Big Dairy Store, but West Haven Beckons
description: After months of bitter debate, zoning officials have rejected plans by Stew Leonard Jr. to build a $25 million dairy store here. But just a mile up the road in West Haven, the dairy store entrepreneur's plan appears very much alive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, SALLY FLOWER
description: ZIMMERMAN-Sally Flower. Born 1911. Loving wife of Herman. Devoted mother and mother-in-law Doreen and Allen Jacobson of New Jersey, Joel of Brooklyn, and the late Norman of Missouri. Dear sister of Gussie Gordon and the late Anne Askenas. Graveside service 3 P.M. today, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: Yankees' Bullpen, Especially Rivera, Fails to Get It Done
description: Mariano Rivera joined the human race again tonight, showing that he is mortal as a closer and that he can mishandle save opportunities just like any other reliever in the ninth inning.

Mass of Christian Burial Immaculate Heart of Mary Church, Thursday, 10 A.M.

title: In a magazine's test, eight laptop computers prove they can take a beating on the road.
description: EXECUTIVES worried about damaging their laptops when they travel will find some comfort in PC Computing magazine's fifth annual ''torture test,'' out this month.

description: Islanders Coach Rick Bowness didn't fall asleep until early yesterday morning, hours after arriving home from Monday night's crushing 2-1 defeat in Montreal.

description: CHIQUE-Robert. Born 8/25/36. Son of the late Theresa and Diego Chique. Deceased 4/4/97. Any family or friends of the late Robert Chique, most recently residing at Oswald D. Heck Developmental Center, Schenectady, New York, please contact the Director of the Center at 518-370-7370.

title: Comet's Discoverer Laments Status of Careers in Science
description: Dr. Alan Hale, a co-discoverer of the Hale-Bopp comet, has denounced prevailing American attitudes toward science and says that unless drastic changes are made, he would not recommend that young people seek careers in science.

title: PROTECTIVE LIFE TO ABSORB WEST COAST LIFE
description: The Protective Life Corporation of Birmingham, Ala., said yesterday that it would buy the West Coast Life Insurance Company for about $257 million in cash from the Nationwide Corporation, a unit of the Nationwide Insurance Enterprise of Columbus, Ohio. The transaction would create a life insurer with annual revenue of about $1.2 billion, based on last year's figures. West Coast Life, based in San Francisco, has assets of $750 million and had 1996 revenue of $150 million. Protective Life's controller, Jerry W. DeFoor, said the company had not decided if job cuts would be necessary. The transaction will be Protective Life's 31st in the last 25 years, and news of the deal sent its stock up $3.25, to $45, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Gino P. Santi, 81, Developer Of Pilot Ejection System, Dies
description: Gino P. Santi, a Brooklyn-born Air Force engineer who developed the modern pilot ejection system, died on Thursday at a hospice near his home in Dayton, Ohio. He was 81 and had spent most of his career at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base there.

title: Pay for Nixon Library?
description: To the Editor:

title: Torricelli and Blacks Feud
description: In the latest salvo in their feud with Senator Robert G. Torricelli, a group of black clergy members demanded yesterday that he appoint an African-American to one of his three top staff positions. The Rev. Raiford S. Wheeler, political chairman of the Black Ministers' Council of New Jersey, said the group also wanted Mr. Torricelli to admit that he broke his campaign promise to the clergy members who helped him get elected and to apologize for having done so.

title: ROCKWELL TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF VIDEO AND DATA CHIPS
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the Comstream Corporation's Hi-Media semiconductor unit, which develops video and data chips for direct-broadcast satellite and cable television companies, for $50 million. Rockwell's shares fell 37.5 cents, to $63.125. Comstream, based in San Diego and a unit of Canada's Spar Aerospace Ltd., makes products for wireless communications systems. Spar Aerospace's shares rose $1.35, to $14.95, on the Montreal stock exchange. Rockwell, based in Seal Beach, Calif., makes electronics products and transmissions for trucks and buses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKMAN, CARL L.
description: ZUCKMAN-Carl L., at home on April 7th, 1997 at age 74. Decorated veteran of W.W. II. Beloved husband of Doris Brady Greene, devoted father of Jane Panza and Julie Zuckman. Loving grandfather of Katharine and Joseph Panza and David Haas. Dear brother of Jean Jacobson. Services ''Wien & Wien'', 129 Engle St., Englewood, New Jersey, Wednesday, 11 AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONDAR, ANITA
description: BONDAR-Anita, 64, beloved wife of Ralph. Caring mother of Willie and Milton. Devoted grandmother of Matthew and Ryan. Services Thursday, April 10 at Parkside Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Avenue. She will always remain in our house.

title: Objections to Ratings
description: Eighteen interest groups ranging from the National P.T.A. to the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America filed formal comments with the Federal Communications Commission yesterday asking it to reject the television industry's fledgling program-rating system.

title: New Video in Brazil Captures Police Brutality; 6 Are Arrested
description: A week after police officers were shown kicking and shooting people stopped at a checkpoint in Sao Paulo, a second secretly made video of policemen battering residents in a poor neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro has outraged Brazilians and led to an unusual response: the arrest of the officers involved.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HECKSCHER, AUGUST
description: HECKSCHER-August. Memorial service at 11 AM on Friday, April 18, at St. James Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street.

title: Rise in Merit-Based Aid to Students Alters the Landscape of the College Market
description: If you aced the college boards, do we have a bargain for you! That's the not-so-subtle message sent this month to tens of thousands of high-achieving high school seniors, who have been offered hefty college scholarships in spite of the ability of their families to pay full tuition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAULL, GERALD E., M.D.
description: GAULL-Gerald E., M.D. Of Washington, DC. On April 2, while on vacation in Quito, Ecuador. Scientist, educator, pediatrician and founding director of Georgetown Center for Food and Nutrition Policy, Georgetown University. During a four decade scientific career, Dr. Gaull made ground-breaking discoveries about development of the human brain during pregnancy and infancy. He identified the role of amino acid taurine in brain development and patented its addition to infant formula, now an industry nutritional standard. In 1978 he won the Borden Award of American Academy of Pediatrics for his work in nutrition. He was the beloved husband of Florence McSherry Heffernan Gaull, the proud and loving father of Erik S. and Stephen B. Gaull and the loving brother of Ricky G. Silberman. Also survived by devoted stepchildren Shelagh Ellman-Pearl, Thomas Ellman, Barat Ellman, Kitsey Canaan, Nancy Ellman and four cherished step-granddaughters. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospital Metropolitano, Quito, Ecuador; contact: CFNP, 202-965-6400.

title: S.E.C. QUESTIONS MOTOROLA'S ACCOUNTING IN NEXTEL DEAL
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has questioned Motorola Inc.'s accounting in deferring a gain on a $1.65 billion deal with Nextel Communications Inc., Motorola said in its latest proxy statement. In the deal, announced in August 1994, Nextel acquired Motorola's wireless licenses in the United States in exchange for a 20 percent stake in Nextel. Motorola considered the deal a swap of assets and recorded no gain for 1995. But ''the S.E.C. asserts that the company should have recognized a gain by accounting for the transaction at fair value,'' according to the Motorola filing. If it adopted the S.E.C. position, Motorola would have recorded a gain of $429 million after taxes, the March 20 filing said. A subsequent drop in the shares of Nextel would have led Motorola to report a loss of $157 million after taxes in the 1995 fourth quarter. Motorola said in the filing that it had not decided whether it would change its accounting of the Nextel deal.
