description: WHEN a disease is uncommon, its symptoms diffuse and its usual victims female, the correct diagnosis is too often overlooked by one doctor after another and patients are labeled nuisances or referred to psychiatrists. So it is with two rare disorders of the adrenal glands: Addison's disease and Cushing's syndrome. Both are deadly without proper treatment. The deaths of two women underscore the need for patients as well as doctors to recognize the symptoms of adrenal malfunction before it is too late. Their last names are being withheld at their families' request.

title: Jones Banishes Dodgers, and Mets' Woes
description: The Mets have had more than their share of adversity in this young season, but they have established one positive. When Bobby Jones takes the mound, they can beat anybody.

title: Health Watch
description: A Noisy Cure for Colic

title: Executive Changes
description: DAINIPPON INK AND CHEMICALS, Tokyo, named Henri Dyner, executive vice president of Sun Chemical, Fort Lee, N.J., its printing ink and graphic arts material manufacturing unit, to the positions of president and chief operating officer of Sun Chemical.

title: From Realism to Powerful Movement
description: At the start of Marlies Yearby's ''Tears of Silver Dreams of Glass,'' the dancers looked like ordinary people coming and going on a city street. There was a believable sense of urban reality throughout this panoramic two-act work, which Ms. Yearby's Movin' Spirits Dance Theater presented on Sunday afternoon at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center at Borough of Manhattan Community College.

title: Lawrence Appley, 92, an Expert on Management
description: Lawrence A. Appley, a Methodist minister's son who served on the boards of 35 corporations and for almost 45 years preached the gospel of quality management in corporate life and Government service, died on Friday at his home in Hamilton, N.Y. He was two weeks short of his 93d birthday.

title: Gephardt Wants to Fix Nafta, Not Sabotage It
description: To the Editor:

title: After-Hour Oddities in Mets Defeat
description: Thirty-five years after Casey Stengel managed the most notorious team in major league history, the 1962 Mets seem to be reincarnated, wackiness intact.

title: POP
description: So Long, Angst: It's Time To Have a Little Fun

title: Federal Appeals Court Upholds California's Ban on Preferences
description: A Federal appeals court here upheld the constitutionality of California's Proposition 209 today, ruling that the voters were well within their rights to ban the use of racial and sex-based preferences in affirmative-action programs run by the state.

title: Senate Vote Is Now Likely On Chemical Arms Treaty
description: With Democrats threatening to stall action on most other legislation, the Senate's Republican majority leader, Trent Lott, indicated today that the full Senate would vote on whether to approve a treaty to ban chemical weapons.

title: State's Notification Law Faces New Challenge, This Time From Public Defender
description: Already hobbled for months in Federal court, New Jersey's ''Megan's Law'' now faces a new legal challenge that is potentially more far-reaching and crippling.

title: Conservative Intellectual Picked As New Archbishop of Chicago
description: Offering an important indication of the type of leadership it is seeking for America's Roman Catholics, the Vatican announced yesterday that it had selected Archbishop Francis E. George of Portland, Ore., a theologically conservative intellectual, as the new Archbishop of Chicago.

title: Keith Jarrett Cancels
description: The pianist Keith Jarrett has canceled his trio concert with Gary Peacock on bass and Jack DeJohnette on drums at Avery Fisher Hall on April 18 because of illness. The concert is not being rescheduled. Tickets can be refunded at the place of purchase, at the Avery Fisher Hall box office or by calling Center Charge, (212) 721-6500, or the Avery Fisher Hall box office, (212) 875-5030.

title: Chain Letter Writer Erred Only on Taste
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Breaks Preserve Jobs
description: The New York City Industrial Development Agency approved more than $1.3 million in tax incentives yesterday to induce two manufacturers -- and their 426 jobs -- to stay in the city rather than move to the suburbs.

title: An Improved Watershed Deal
description: The one official who could have delayed and possibly derailed the historic agreement between New York City and upstate communities to protect the city's water supply has now approved it. Alan Hevesi, the City Comptroller, spent nearly six months reviewing every line of the deal and demanding changes, but it was time well spent. The agreement he formally approved yesterday provides for much tighter controls on spending and for periodic scientific reviews that could lead to stronger regulations down the road.

title: Two Groups Name Award Winners
description: Two organizations in New York bestowed their annual awards yesterday.

title: Consider the States
description: To the Editor:

title: Salomon Rehires A Top Executive
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. said today that Ronald Freeman, who left in 1991 after 17 years to join the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, was rejoining it in a new position as co-head of global investment banking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALL, SONIA
description: BALL-Sonia. On April 8, 1997. Beloved wife of Jacob (deceased), devoted mother of Martin (deceased) and Ina, and Arthur. Cherished grandmother of Stuart and Melinda, Steven and Sharon. Proud great-grandmother of Lauren, Andrew, Marissa, Matthew and Danielle. Loving sister to Celia DeSaretz (deceased), Jean Stein, Alex and Max Love. May she rest in eternal peace. Her Family

title: Another Bad Sign on the Road to the Postseason
description: Forget the previous collapses and subsequent revivals. The team that cries wolf -- ''We're in trouble; we're in trouble'' -- is in real danger of early playoff elimination.

title: Pedestrian Death Risk Is Seen As Major Public Health Crisis
description: More than 6,000 pedestrians are killed by cars and trucks every year, one-seventh of all the people who die in traffic accidents, but 99 percent of the Federal transportation safety money is spent on improvements for drivers and passengers, not people walking, says a study released today by advocates of pedestrians.

title: Building's Big Attraction: Big Floors
description: When officials of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company were trying to figure out what to do with their 1930's building on Madison Avenue between 24th and 25th Streets, they knew they had one big advantage: huge floors in the block-square building.

title: Images of Pain And Despair From a Region Raked by War
description: After months of trekking through dense forest ahead of a rebel advance, some 100,000 hungry and exhausted refugees have ended up huddled in camps near Kisangani, Zaire's third-largest city. With more than 100 refugees a day dying of starvation and disease, the United Nations is hurriedly preparing to fly them home, in a massive evacuation that is expected to begin within 10 days and to last for as long as three months.

title: 'The Answer to That Is No'
description: The Last of the Clinton Mohegans left at the top silent, conspiratorial Bruce Lindsey -- may be in big trouble.

title: Prescription Ray-Ban Deal
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. and Essilor International S.A. of France said today that they had agreed to make prescription sunglasses based on Bausch & Lomb's Ray-Ban line of sunglasses. Financial terms were not disclosed. The agreement calls for Essilor, a manufacturer of optical lenses under the Varilux, Silor and Essilor brands, to produce prescription lenses for the Ray-Ban sunglass styles. Bausch & Lomb, which is based in Rochester, said that the Ray-Ban prescription line would be phased into distribution nationally in the second quarter of 1997.

title: Elizabeth Snapp, 50, Music Publicity Agent
description: Elizabeth Snapp, a publicity agent who worked primarily with composers and new-music ensembles, died on Friday at North Shore Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. She was 50 and lived in Glen Cove.

title: Wall Street Space Leased
description: A small consulting company that advises developers on how to build environmentally sound buildings has leased a floor at 40 Wall Street, where it will open a showroom on the latest ways to reduce energy costs, control harmful emissions and improve indoor air quality.

title: Old-Time Chicken Flavor
description: To The Living Section:

title: Parcells Is Not Giving Secrets Away
description: Coach Bill Parcells remained consistent today: he is keeping everybody in the dark about his draft plans, even two of college football's most acclaimed players.

title: Norman Memory Free Of '96 Masters Collapse
description: Greg Norman was sitting at a dais here today, his face serene, his shoulders squared. A year after a Masters defeat so ghastly it has been called the worst collapse in major championship golf history, Norman was wearing an almost beatific expression.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton as Racial Mediator

title: Dow Gains 53.25 in Late-Afternoon Rally
description: Stock prices gained for the third consecutive session yesterday after a late-afternoon rally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, JOHN KREMER
description: ARMSTRONG - John Kremer. Died of heart attack on April 5, 1997 at his home in Lawrence Park West, Bronxville, New York. He is survived by his wife, Mieke, his children Marca and Jeb, his brother Alan Armstrong and by his future son-in law Kevin Ewy. He was a partner at the New York law firm of Carter, Ledyard & Milburn. Services at 3PM, Thursday, April 10, 1997 at Christ Church, 17 Sagamore Road, Bronxville, NY.

title: Scientists Find Signals Suggesting That Hanky-Panky, Not Monogamy, May Rule the Long Island Roost
description: Ruby-throated hummingbirds, red-wing blackbirds and great blue herons inhabit the salt marshes, freshwater ponds and pine swamps that make this storied island one of the last nature refuges of Long Island.

title: Cuban Pitcher Is a Free Agent
description: Rolando Arrojo, the latest front-line pitcher to leave Cuba for baseball in the United States, will be free to sign with any team beginning next Wednesday, the commissioner's office notified major league clubs yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a tentative contract agreement between New York City and the firefighters' union misstated the title of James F. Hanley. He is the city's Labor Commissioner, not Deputy Labor Commissioner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, BERTHA K.
description: GREEN-Bertha K. We mourn the passing of the mother of Morris L. Green, who along with his beloved wife Charlotte, were of the original founders of the new Shaare Zedek Medical Center. The tradition of tzedaka and chesed faithfully fulfilled by Morris is a legacy of a mother who imbued her son with Torah values. There is no institution or cause that furthers the survival of Klal and Yisrael, be it spiritual or physical continuity, where the name of Morris Green is not found. The memory of Mrs. Green will long remain through the acts of commitment of Am Yisrael, Torat Yisrael and Eretz Yisrael as expressed in so many ways by Morris and his beloved wife. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Charles H. Bendheim, President Erica Jesselson, Chairperson of the Board Sidney G. Adler, Treasurer International Board of Governors Menno Ratzker, Chairman Morris Talansky, Executive Vice Chairman

title: Next Course On the Plate At Wall St. Rumor Feast
description: These days, it seems, merger deals don't leak. They flood.

title: Democrats Seek Wider Campaign Inquiry
description: House Democrats today pressured moderate Republicans to buck their party leaders and support an inquiry into questionable fund-raising practices that would investigate Republicans as well as Democrats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, ISRAEL
description: STERN-Israel. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a dedicated longtime friend and leader, the dynamic and inspiring founder of the Upstate New York Friends of YU who, with his beloved wife, Pearl, was a YU Guardian; father of Jules (and Lila) Stern; and brother of Bessie (and Jack) Gulker, Irving (and Eve) Stern, Anne (and Joseph) Osofsky, and Dr. Abraham (and Malka) Stern. We extend our heartfelt condolences to grandchildren, great-grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHREIBER, BEATRICE C.
description: SCHREIBER-Beatrice C., on April 8, 1997. Retired NYC Housing Authority. Beloved wife of the late Max. Dear aunt of James, Patricia, Barbara and Ronald. Fond step-mother of Paul and David. Devoted sister of the late Gertrude and James Curry. Friends may call at the Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20 St), NYC, Thursday 2-5 PM only. Mass of Christian Burial, Epiphany RC Church, on Friday at 11 A.M. Interment in Calvary Cemetery.

title: Turning Other Cheek, Despite a Broken Nose
description: After pounding the helmeted head of an opponent with his fist in an exhibition game, Shane Churla of the Rangers missed the beginning of the regular season with a broken hand. When he returned, a punch to his face fractured his orbital bone and put him out again.

title: Yanks May Lose Gooden and Strawberry
description: The comeback tales of Dwight Gooden and Darryl Strawberry as Yankees were filled with inspiration in 1996, but the second-year stories for the two former Mets have started with exasperation. Gooden may need surgery for a hernia and could miss at least six weeks. Strawberry will most likely be put on the disabled list because of fluid on his left knee and could miss two weeks.

title: Helen Bernstein, 52, Ex-Leader Of Los Angeles Teachers Union
description: Helen Bernstein, a former president of the Los Angeles teachers union known for her forceful style and dogged support of higher standards for students and a decentralized administration, died here Thursday night. She was 52 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORTEGGIANO, JOSEPH
description: CORTEGGIANO - Joseph. Died April 7, 1997. Robert Lombardo Associates mourns the loss of our friend and client Joseph Corteggiano. Long associated with New York City Opera and many other American opera companies and orchestras, we will miss his zeal for performing, his marvelous sense of humor & his warm loving personality. Our deepest condolences to his mother Charlotte and his sisters and brothers. At Joseph's request donations in his memory may be sent to: HERO (Health Education Resources Organization), 101 W. Read Street, Suite 825, Baltimore, MD. 21201. Robert Lombardo Michael Rosen Lewis Ehlers Mark Lemeier Annamaria Pace

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ARTHUR L.
description: KLEIN-Arthur L. Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Arthur Luce Klein. A wise, generous and courageous man, Dr. Klein graced the Medical Center with his presence and support. We who were privileged to know him will always treasure the memories of his kindness to everyone he encountered, his brilliant ability to infuse common language with eloquence, his endurance of pain with humor and dignity. His spirit will remain with all of us, and his benevolence will continue to benefit the patients served in The SSMC Arthur and Luce Klein Renal Dialysis Center, Antepartum Testing Laboratory, Level II Nursery and Geriatric In Patient Unit. Go gentle into that good night, dear friend, and rest in peace. We extend our deepest sympathy to Luce, his wife of fifty years and their children Judith, Joel and Rosine. Clark E. Walter, Chairman Board of Governors John R. Spicer, President and Chief Executive Officer Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester

title: Debt
description: * Federal Farm Credit Bank is selling $100 million of medium-term notes due in 2002 through Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. and Morgan Stanley & Co.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with the obituary of Allen Ginsberg included erroneous identities from the Magnum photo agency for the two men shown standing. The one at the far left was Barney Rosset, the founder of Grove Press, not the poet William S. Burroughs. The man standing at the right was Julius Orlovsky, not his brother, the poet Peter Orlovsky.

title: Good and Bad Mergers
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Seeks Harmony, for Now, As He Tries to Cut Labor Costs
description: It is the story of the airline industry these days. With carriers generating record profits, many union workers want raises, testing their leverage against executives who say big pay increases would make their airlines less competitive. Pilots and managers have squared off at American and United, and Continental's pilots said last week that they wanted a 38 percent raise.

title: Columbia/HCA Hospital Deal Is Delayed
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation's plan to buy a nonprofit Rhode Island hospital has been delayed, after the state health department decided to postpone its review of the transaction.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SUPERGEN INC., San Ramon, Calif., a drug development company, agreed to sell a 9 percent stake to Lawrence J. Ellison, the founder and chairman of Oracle Corp., for $9 a share, a total of $15 million.

title: Tucker Award Winner
description: David Daniels, a countertenor, is this year's recipient of the Richard Tucker Award, given annually to a promising American opera singer. The award, which was created by the Richard Tucker Foundation in 1978, consists of a cash prize of $30,000 and a concert appearance. Mr. Daniels, 31, will perform with other singers, many of them past winners of the Tucker Award, on Nov. 2 at Avery Fisher Hall. Past recipients include Deborah Voigt, Renee Fleming, Aprile Millo, Dwayne Croft and Richard Leech.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE bad news is that prices for the best Bordeaux wines have never been higher and that all indications are that the increases are not about to stop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORMAN, MURIEL
description: GORMAN-Muriel, my deepest sympathy to her beloved husband, Jack and to the bereaved family. Edna Solomon

title: Two Take the Money and Produce
description: Money has ruined plenty of designers. They get a taste of success, and their creative stuff is shunted aside for more commercial stuff. Their collections become less daring. They grow lazy. Money buys a lot of sycophants, and the yes factor kills designers even faster than it kills actors and artists. And soon, no one remembers what made them successful in the first place.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Inspired By Nomads And Czars
description: Some American designers find their inspiration in Milan or Paris, producing clothes with a familiar, tired sameness. Others go as far as Asia but filter the foreign culture through their own imaginations to make a personal statement.

title: Pill for Abortion Ends Production
description: Roussel Uclaf, the French pharmaceuticals company, said today that it had stopped production of its unprofitable abortion pill RU 486, ending its battle with anti-abortion campaigners who lobbied against its sale, particularly in the United States.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Dow Jones Forms Alliance With Microsoft
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that it had formed a technology and marketing alliance with the Microsoft Corporation as part of its effort to revive Telerate, its faltering financial data division that was recently renamed Dow Jones Markets.

title: Nothing Fails Like Success
description: At first blush, John Major and Newt Gingrich are about as different as two politicians could be. For six interminable years, John Major has mercilessly bored the British public, his fathomless grayness now an emblem of English ennui. Newt Gingrich, on the other hand, bursts with messianic enthusiasm that alternately inspires and bewilders. One exudes the charisma of a mildly panicked bank manager; the other the maturity of a student debate coach.

title: SEAGATE'S THIRD-QUARTER EARNINGS EXCEED EXPECTATIONS
description: Seagate Technology Inc. yesterday reported earnings for its third quarter that easily exceeded Wall Street forecasts. The company, the world's largest maker of computer disk drives, earned $256.7 million, or $1.01 a share, in the quarter. A year ago, Seagate had a loss of $157.4 million, or 78 cents a share, including charges related to the acquisition of Conner Peripherals Inc. In the most recent quarter, Seagate took pretax charges of $24.3 million. Without the charges, earnings would have been $1.07 a share. Analysts had expected earnings of 94 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by I.B.E.S. International Inc. Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., released the results after the stock market closed. Earlier, its shares rose $1.25, to $52.

title: Pondering Fire, Infinity and a Head of Lettuce (Cool!)
description: OUTSIDE, it was the kind of soupy spatter of a day that keeps the rest of the country from moving here.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the calendar column of the Westchester Weekly on Sunday about a celebrity salon with Donald Bain, author of the ''Murder, She Wrote'' novels, misstated the date. It is May 10 at 5 P.M. in Hartford Hall at Westchester Community College in Valhalla; it is not tomorrow.

title: U.N. Report Accuses Zaire Rebels of Mass Killings
description: A United Nations investigator told the organization's Human Rights Commission in Geneva today that the rebels in Zaire had rounded up and killed hundreds of Hutu refugees and local civilians since beginning their insurgency last year.

title: Wary of Speeded-Up Mideast Talks, Clinton Wants Israelis to Show Sincerity
description: President Clinton emerged from his meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Monday deeply wary about Mr. Netanyahu's idea of a dramatic, six-month push toward a final settlement between Israel and the Palestinians, American officials said today.

title: Inmate Is Convicted Of Murder in a Robbery
description: A convict serving a life sentence on Federal drug charges was found guilty yesterday of murdering a graphic artist during a robbery in Manhattan almost four years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, REV. MATTHIAS J.
description: WOLF-Rev. Matthias J. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the former member of Cathedral College Faculty, Douglaston, on April 7. Reposing in Stutzmann Funeral Home, 22439 Jamaica Ave, Queens Village, Wednesday, April 9, 2-5 PM. Mass of Transferral Wed., 7:30 P.M., in Immaculate Conception Center Chapel, Douglaston. Funeral Mass Thursday, April 10, at 10:30 AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: McGreevey Announces Campaign Against Whitman
description: Characterizing Christine Todd Whitman as a Governor ''more intent on looking good than doing good,'' James E. McGreevey, a State Senator and Mayor of Woodbridge, New Jersey's fifth largest municipality, officially began his campaign today for the Democratic nomination in this year's gubernatorial race.

title: Ukraine Staggers on Path to the Free Market
description: Despite hundreds of millions of dollars of American aid, Ukraine is stumbling badly in its transition to a free-market economy, and diplomats and foreign executives blame rampant official corruption, which they say is remarkable even by standards of the region.

title: Rival Railroads Agree on Conrail's Assets
description: The CSX Corporation and the Norfolk Southern Corporation announced an agreement yesterday that details how the two companies would split the assets of Conrail. A deal, which has been expected since Conrail abandoned its merger with CSX a month ago, will bring competition in freight rail service to New York for the first time in 29 years.

title: Man Throws Firebomb In Illinois Courtroom
description: A man hurled a molotov cocktail in a Champaign County courtroom here today, slightly injuring a judge and raising questions about building security.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, RAY
description: O'CONNOR-Ray. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of Ray O'Connor, colleague, friend and talented writer whose lifelong devotion to human rights and intergroup relations skills enhanced ADL's development public relations efforts for fifteen years from 1964 to 1979. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Hope, who has spent her own lifetime career working with ADL, and to his entire family. David H. Strassler National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: U.S. Says F.B.I. Erred in Using Deception in Olympic Bomb Inquiry
description: The Department of Justice has concluded that F.B.I. agents made ''a major error in judgment'' last July when they used deceptive tactics in an effort to persuade Richard A. Jewell to waive his constitutional rights in an interview about the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park, according to a memorandum from the F.B.I. Director, Louis J. Freeh.

title: Spirited Cooking
description: To The Living Section:

title: Paying for One Big Party
description: Politicians make it a business to be sensitive to the most minor wobbles of public opinion. Yet in recent weeks, the leaders of Washington's all-inclusive Incumbent Party have been assuring each other that Americans do not really care about campaign-finance reform. The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll this week exposes their lie. It offered a startling portrayal of a nation that, far from being indifferent, yearns for abolition of a system clearly viewed as corrupt. By ignoring such warnings, Congress deepens the public's already considerable disgust and cynicism.

title: 'No More of This Mayonnaise!' and Other Linguistic Teasers
description: Last May the Cannes International Film Festival unveiled Steven Soderbergh's ''Schizopolis'' as a special mystery selection. The audience had no idea beforehand what it would be seeing and, unfortunately, hardly any better idea when the film was over. Shown under ideal circumstances to an eager group of international cineastes, ''Schizopolis'' still managed to excite jaw-dropping indifference. Mr. Soderbergh had evolved from the much-admired director of ''Sex, Lies and Videotape'' into the perpetrator of a goofy, ineffectual prank.

title: Volvo and Mitsubishi Weigh Truck Venture
description: Volvo A.B. of Sweden said yesterday that it was exploring ways to work with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan on truck production but denied that it was considering buying the American truck maker Mack Trucks Inc. from Renault S.A. Renault said it had no plans to sell its truck business, denying a report in the Swedish newspaper Svenska Dagbladet, which said Volvo's truck division was planning to buy Mack to increase its United States market share to 19 percent from 10 percent.

title: Trying to Calm Dead Youth's Neighborhood
description: The police have held two meetings with the residents of Washington Heights to discuss the killing of Kevin Cedeno, the 16-year-old who was shot in the back by a police officer early Sunday morning, and politicians, community leaders and priests have asked neighbors to keep the peace despite anger over the shooting. But of all the voices asking for calm in the neighborhood, perhaps the most poignant was that of Mr. Cedeno's mother, Roma.

title: Complaints Are Renewed On Pensions In Fire Dept.
description: Five top Fire Department officers who recently retired have applied for disability pensions that would provide them with tax-free yearly stipends of more than $110,000 each.

title: A School for Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Benefit of the Doubt
description: Faced with the Medical Examiner's ruling that a young man carrying a machete had been shot in the back on Sunday by a police officer, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did something on Monday that he intensely dislikes: he backed away from his defense of the officer the day before.

title: Weak Sale of Inflation Notes Hurts Bonds
description: The prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday under the weight of more data showing strength in the economy and disappointment over the latest auction of the Government's new inflation-indexed securities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, STEPHEN H.
description: PARKER-Stephen H. Of Pelham Manor, NY. Died April 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Patrice Buhrig Parker, devoted father of Alexandra and Stephanie. Also survived by mother, Polly W. Parker of Bronxville, father, Joel J. Parker of Hilton Head, sister, Cynthia W. Landis of Plymouth, MN, brother, Joel J. Parker, Jr. of Copallis Beach, WA., and grandmother, Barbara H. Wardwell of Naples, FL. The family will receive friends at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville Wednesday, April 9, from 5 to 9 PM. Funeral service at the Reformed Church of Bronxville, Thurs, April 10, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers donations to the American Heart Association would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRADENBAUGH, BAKER A.
description: BRADENBAUGH-Baker A., age 77, died on Tuesday, April 8, 1997. He had been a winter resident of Naples for eighteen years. His home is in New Milford, CT. Mr. Bradenbaugh attended Shadyside Academy in Pittsburgh, PA. He graduated from Princeton University, class of '41. He was a Navy Carrier pilot in W.W. II, and received the Distinguished Flying Cross. He was a corporate officer with U.S. Aviation Underwriters. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Eleanore. Services will be private and interment will be at Arlington National Cemetery at a later date. For more information contact Hodges Funeral Chapels (941-261-1237).

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with a review of the Boston Ballet's performance of ''Le Corsaire'' on Saturday misspelled the surname of one dancer. She is Larissa Ponomarenko, not Ponomarkeno.

title: Ellis Island Decision Revealed New York to Be Rightful Owner
description: To the Editor:

title: Standard for Equivalency Degree Is Raised
description: For high school dropouts seeking a high school equivalency degree, the bar has just been raised a little higher.

title: The Mission Is to Shine Up A Grimy City
description: ''THIS is what you call a stress area,'' Bill Maxwell said as he approached 30 Rockefeller Center. The weary faces on the 9-to-5 stragglers who slowly walked out into the night confirmed that. His solution for that worn look? Acetone.

title: Chicago's Catholics Don't Hesitate to Put Their Faith in a Native Son
description: In this city that so reveres its hometown heroes, Chicagoans were showering praise today on Archbishop Francis E. George, a native son of the Northwest Side, even as they acknowledged not knowing much about him.

title: Genghis Newt
description: Surely it was the first time this sentence had been spoken by a Congressional aide.

title: Food Stores Busting Out All Over
description: GOURMET GARAGE is opening its third and largest store today, at 2567 Broadway (96th Street). The food dealer started on Wooster Street in a former garage but moved to larger quarters at 453 Broome Street (at Mercer Street). Its second store, 301 East 64th Street, is in a converted garage. The new 11,000-square-foot space (not a garage) will carry mostly organic produce and prepared foods and will have a kosher food department. Delivery is available on the Upper West Side. Information: (212) 663-0656.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Saturday about ''Louisa May Alcott's 'The Inheritance,' '' broadcast on Sunday by CBS, included a misstatement from the network about the story's history. ''The Inheritance'' was indeed published, in February by Dutton.

title: Apparel Industry Group Moves to End Sweatshops
description: A Presidential task force that includes human rights groups, labor unions and apparel industry giants like Nike Inc., Reebok International Ltd. and L.L. Bean has reached a groundbreaking agreement that seeks to end sweatshops by creating a code of conduct on wages and working conditions, including a maximum 60-hour workweek, for apparel factories that American companies use around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, DOROTHY SHAMES
description: KAPLAN-Dorothy Shames, April 6, 1997, Rochester, NY. Survived by the families of Frank J. Shames and Leo Kaplan.

title: The Met's 'Ring' Gallops On With 'Walkure'
description: Given the choice, most Wagnerians would attend the four ''Ring'' operas in close succession; that way, the cycle's musical cohesiveness and grand dramatic sweep are best savored and the intensity of the effort transforms the experience of operagoing into a kind of pilgrimage. The Met is offering this kind of full immersion experience twice at the end of the season, and in preparation, the company has been presenting individual installments. The second part of the saga, ''Die Walkure,'' returned to the house on Monday evening.

title: Malone Is Making a Case for M.V.P.
description: A 13-game winning streak has virtually assured the Utah Jazz of finishing with the best record in the Western Conference. It has also helped Karl Malone in his bid to win the National Basketball Association's most valuable player award.

title: CHRONICLE

title: WHX RAISES BID FOR DYNAMICS CORPORATION OF AMERICA
description: The WHX Corporation said yesterday that it had strengthened its offer to acquire 17 percent of the outstanding shares of the Dynamics Corporation of America to $45 a share from $40 a share. The new offer is valued at $29.2 million, up from $25.9 million. Dynamics' shares gained $3.75 to close at $43.875. Shares of WHX, a holding company based in New York, slipped 12.5 cents to close at $6.875. Dynamics, based in Greenwich, Conn., makes electronic components and consumer appliances like Waring blenders. WHX wants to keep its Dynamics stake under 20 percent to prevent an anti-takeover defense from taking effect. Dynamics called WHX's initial offer ''totally inadequate.'' It had no immediate response to the new offer.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UROMED CORP., Needham, Mass., which makes products for urological and gynecological disorders, bought the rights to an incontinence device from Johnson & Johnson Medical Inc., for undisclosed terms.

title: A Police Shooting
description: Crime rates are falling sharply in New York City, thanks in large part to better policing, but this fine record is stained by a continuing fear of police brutality in black and Hispanic neighborhoods. New York police officers have shot and killed more than 100 civilians over the past five years, and while those numbers are far below the total of fatal shootings in the early 1970's, the vast majority of victims were African-Americans and Hispanics.

title: Corrections

Morgan & Company stemming from its financing for the Sumitomo Corporation's copper trading business included one American institution erroneously as among those that also provided such financing. American International Group Inc. was not involved in financing the activities of Sumitomo's former chief copper trader.

title: School President Retiring
description: Dr. Stanley S. Bergen, who built a small medical school into the nation's largest public health and science university, said yesterday that he plans to retire from his post as the University of Medicine and Dentistry's first and only president.

title: Omnicom to Acquire Fleishman-Hillard
description: Omnicom Group, the giant agency holding company in New York, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Fleishman-Hillard Inc., the public relations agency based in St. Louis, for cash and stock. As part of the deal, Omnicom plans to merge Fleishman-Hillard with one of its public relations units, Porter Novelli International in New York, to form what Omnicom is describing as the largest global public relations group. Further terms were not disclosed.

title: Washington Mayor Paints Rosy Picture of Future
description: Sounding much like a mayor who loves his work enough to serve another term or two, Marion S. Barry Jr. tonight described the nation's capital as ''a good city getting better'' in his annual state of the District address.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARIAN McPARTLAND, the jazz pianist, has performed in many places in her 50-year career, but even so she could not be blase about an upcoming gig: at the Supreme Court.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about an agreement on workplace standards for apparel factories reached by a Presidential task force misidentified its co-chairwoman, Linda Golodner. She is president of the National Consumers League, not the National Consumers Federation.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE REINSTATES LAWSUIT AGAINST PHILIP MORRIS
description: A shareholder lawsuit against the Philip Morris Companies was reinstated yesterday by a Federal judge who said recently disclosed company documents raised concerns about what the cigarette maker knew about nicotine addiction. Judge Michael B. Mukasey of the Federal District Court in Manhattan reinstated the suit filed in 1994 by Philip Morris investors who bought shares from June 11, 1991, to May 6, 1994. The plaintiffs said their shares fell on reports that Philip Morris knew that nicotine was addictive, in contrast to the company's claims that smokers could quit when they wanted. The judge, who had earlier dismissed the suit, ruled that the case should go forward because the plaintiffs gave him internal company documents supporting their claims. Philip Morris called the suit and the allegations baseless.

title: Employment Of Minorities Stalls at Papers
description: The number of minority journalists working for the country's newspapers failed to grow last year after nearly 20 years of unbroken annual increases, according to a survey made public today. The proportion of minority reporters and editors increased slightly, but only because total newsroom employment declined.

title: With Mitsuko Uchida at Play In the Fields of Romanticism
description: Romanticism comes in many forms, and in her probing, eloquent recital on Tuesday evening at Carnegie Hall, the pianist Mitsuko Uchida explored three of them, each distinctive in its language and scope. Her subjects were Beethoven's final Sonata, the C minor (Op. 111), Schumann's ''Davidsbundlertanze'' (Op. 6) and Berg's Sonata (Op. 1), and by playing them in reverse chronological order, she offered a surprising view of the flow of musical history.

He was 73 and lived in Morningside Heights in Manhattan.

title: Jupiter's Moon Might Be Cradle for New Life
description: Looking at the most detailed pictures yet of Europa, a large moon of Jupiter, scientists said yesterday that they were more confident than ever that a global ocean of liquid water or slush was lying just beneath Europa's thin crust of cracked ice. And this, they said with rising enthusiasm, might just be the place to look for extraterrestrial life.

title: The 'Ellen' Striptease
description: Only in America -- Disney's America, at any rate -- can the act of a TV sitcom heroine declaring her lesbianism be turned into a media epic that plays out over seven months, generating a striptease of publicity that in a simpler age would be beyond the imagination of even P. T. Barnum, if not Gypsy Rose Lee herself.

title: When a Label Takes On A Life of Its Own
description: There is something poignant about a designer name on a label, a personal risk obscured and forgotten by the time it is emblazoned around the elastic band of underwear. The first time a designer ever sees it stitched inside a dress, it must raise remarkable emotions, of pride and also certainly of fear. After the creator is in business for a while, the label takes on a life of its own, not unlike Frankenstein's monster. That battle with the label, to live up to it, to go beyond it, is a designer's biggest drama.

title: Italy Convicts Fiat Chairman; Bars Him From Corporate Posts
description: The chairman of Fiat S.p.A., Italy's biggest corporation, was convicted yesterday of having falsified company accounts, committing tax fraud and making illegal payments to political parties. He was barred from holding corporate office in Italy.

description: Mexican prosecutors released evidence today suggesting that former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari took part in a cover-up of the role his brother is accused of playing in a 1994 political assassination.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SIMOR, GEORGE
description: SIMOR-George. Died suddenly on July 3, 1996, on Nantucket Island. Medievalist, librarian & archivist. Librarian at Columbia University (1963-64), Rare Book Librarian at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri (1964-66), Head of Rare Book Cataloging and Bibliography in the Research Libraries of the New York Public Library (1966-71), Chief Acquisitions Librarian of the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York (1971-91). Taught at Fordham University (1958-61), Washington University in St. Louis (1964-66), St. John's University (1968-95), and Pratt Institute (1967 to his death). A memorial will be held at 2 P.M., on Sunday, April 20, at Pratt Manhattan Center, The Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street-Second Floor, New York City.

description: The Lincoln Park Board of Education plans to continue its fight to bring school vouchers to the school district, despite objections that it would be unconstitutional.

title: 14th-Inning Error Helps Dodgers Gain Victory
description: The Mets can't get enough of extra innings, but they are gluttons for punishment. Playing their third extra-inning game of the young season tonight, they lost to the Dodgers, 3-2, when Mike Piazza singled home Brett Butler in the bottom of the 14th inning.

title: Barrier Is Lifted for Trial in King Killing
description: The first barrier to a trial for the man who is prison for the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has been lifted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARPENTER, WILLIAM J.
description: CARPENTER-William J. Age 69. On Tuesday, April 8, 1997 in Nantucket, MA. Services will be held Sat, April 12, 11AM, Saint Mary's Church, Nantucket. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Nantucket Cottage Hospital or to Hospice Care of Nantucket.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOFF, JOHN
description: GOFF-John Stewart of Ridgefield, CT. On April 6, 1997. At the age of 70. Formerly of New Canaan and Stamford, CT. Former negotiator for American International Oil Corp, most recently Manager of Acquisitions for Mobil Oil. Father of Craig, Andrea and Leslie. Former husband of Marie Scudder Dix. Brother of Anne Alexander. Grandfather of three. Funeral Services Friday at 2 PM at Jesse Lee Church, Main St, Ridgefield. Burial will be private. No calling hours. Contributions to the New Canaan Library or to the Westchester Golf Association Caddie Scholarship Fund, C/O Waccabuc Country Club, Waccabuc, New York 10597.

title: TENET AND MEDPARTNERS TO FORM HEALTH CARE NETWORK
description: The Tenet Healthcare Corporation and Medpartners Inc. have agreed to form a health care network serving more than one million people in Southern California. Tenet, the nation's second-largest hospital chain, said yesterday that it had also agreed to acquire Medpartners' 99-bed Pioneer Hospital in Artesia, Calif. Terms were not disclosed. Under the alliance, the 1.2 million people served by Medpartners' doctors would have access to services at Tenet's 33 hospitals in the region. Medpartners, based in Birmingham, Ala., would build an outpatient operation near the hospital. Tenet, based in Santa Barbara, Calif., owns or operates 125 hospitals in 22 states.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETRIE, THELMA DEVRIES
description: PETRIE-Thelma DeVries, 81, of Pinehurst, N.C., and Quogue, New York, on April 5th in Pinehurst. Everyone who knew her will remember her as a loving, generous and kind friend. She will be deeply missed by all whose lives she touched. We would all hope to live by her example and her motto that ''life is for living, loving, and giving''. Beloved mother of Nancy DeVries Mullan of New York, NY and David J. Field, Jr. of Long Beach, CA; loving sister of Clara Zehr and Jane Stuckey, both of Wauseon, Ohio; cherished grandmother of Alexandra DeVries Mullan Jain of London, England, Peter Downing Mullan of New Haven, CT., and David Joseph Field of Long Beach, CA., devoted aunt of all her nephews and nieces; generous benefactor of so many organizations & individuals and a wonderful friend to many others. Contributions in her memory may be made to a favorite charity. A gathering to celebrate her life will be announced later.

title: Gang Took Over Man's Queens House, Police Say
description: For weeks, neighbors had noticed something odd around the home of Willard Costello, a courteous 89-year-old man who had lived in his two-story house in Cambria Heights, Queens, for nearly six decades. Young men came and went at all hours. Cars crowded the curb. The front lawn grew dense with discarded bottle tops and empty vials.

title: Museum Goes More Public
description: Since its founding in 1988, the Museum of American Financial History has been a cramped, hard-to-find warehouse of financial arcana. Now, the museum is making a bid for recognition by moving into roomier quarters in lower Manhattan.

title: Propaganda Vehicle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRABOWITZ, STEVEN
description: GRABOWITZ - Steven. Beloved husband of Ellen. Devoted father of Noah, Laurel and Robbie. Adored son of Ruth and Bill. Cherished son-in-law of Lee and Larry. Unexpectedly on April 9. Services April 10 at 1PM, First Hebrew Congregation, Peekskill, New York.

title: Wives of Peru Hostages Speak Out
description: Like many relatives of the 72 hostages that are in the Japanese Ambassador's house, Lucy de Cordova did not sleep Easter night, after hearing that negotiations to end the crisis had failed and that the military was planning a raid at 3 A.M.

title: 3 Senators Set To Oppose Tax For Health Bill
description: Three of the seven Republican Senators who were identified on Tuesday as co-sponsors of bills to provide children's health insurance by raising the cigarette tax said today that they supported the insurance but not the tax. So did the Senate minority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota.

title: Agency Association Names New Officers
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies, known as the Four A's, elected three new leaders yesterday.

title: When Money Counts
description: A GOOD cart can be used for more than just cocktails. It is a table or bookshelf when you need it, a vehicle for spiriting a mass of clutter into a closet when the doorbell rings -- even an easy way to put a television in every room. Following are seven ways to get rolling, from room to room or from indoors to out.

title: Lighter Side of Downsizing
description: The new series ''Fired Up'' comes with a topical premise and an edgy lead character, just what most sitcoms lack. Sharon Lawrence (far from her role as the smart but dowdy Sylvia Costas on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'') plays Gwen, a chic, aloof public relations executive downsized out of a large company. When she is finally forced to apply for unemployment, the woman who takes her application asks, ''What brings you here, Duchess?''

title: Revenge of the PIN
description: The automated phone message was portentous: My voice mail password was more than 180 days old and about to expire. If I didn't change it right away, an E-mail message about my delinquency, also automated, would be immediately sent to my boss.

title: Color Issue Reaches People in Seats
description: The 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's breaking of the color barrier in baseball will be greeted with all the appropriate ruffles and flourishes next Tuesday, no more so than at Shea Stadium, where the Mets and the Dodgers will be joined in their salute by President Clinton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORTEGGIANO, JOSEPH
description: CORTEGGIANO - Joseph. New York City Opera mourns the passing of our good friend & colleague, Joe Corteggiano. After joining the City Opera in 1990 he sang in many of our productions, including several major premieres. He became a valued member of the company and a good friend. We'll miss his enthusiasm, his support and his friendship. Our deepest sympathies go to his family, his colleagues and to his many friends throughout the Country. Paul Kellogg General Director

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the Nassau County District Attorney, Dennis E. Dillon, criticizing United State Representative Carolyn McCarthy's vote to permit late-term abortions referred incorrectly to his description of the measure. He said the bill allowed such abortions to protect a mother's life, not to protect her health.

title: Heat Keeps Eye on Prize And Knicks
description: FOREHEAD dripping with sweat, knees packed in ice, Alonzo Mourning looked up from a seat in the visitors' locker room at Continental Airlines Arena Tuesday night and asked if a final had come in from across the river in New York.

title: A Wider Circle at White House Knew of Efforts to Help Hubbell
description: In the spring of 1995, a few months after his fraud conviction, former Associate Attorney General Webster L. Hubbell and his wife asked a recently retired White House aide whether the Riady family of Indonesia, which had already paid Mr. Hubbell $100,000, would be keeping him on its payroll even as he faced prison.

title: Andrews Joins Democratic Primary Race for Governor
description: In the first of three stops on a bus tour across the state, United States Representative Robert E. Andrews officially began his Democratic campaign for governor here today, focusing on his plans to improve education and criticizing Gov. Christine Todd Whitman for ''failing to use the power of her office to do the right thing.''

title: EVERGREEN TO SELL FM DIAL POSITION TO SUSQUEHANNA
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation said yesterday that it would sell the dial position and transmission equipment for an FM radio station in San Francisco to Susquehanna Broadcasting for $44 million. Susquehanna would also acquire the call letters for another station, KSAN-FM, from the Chancellor Broadcasting Company. The moves would allow Evergreen and Chancellor to meet Federal guidelines on station ownership for Evergreen's pending $567 million acquisition of Chancellor. Evergreen said that it had sold the 107.7 dial position and transmission facility currently used by KYLD-FM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIEDLER, MICHAEL
description: FIEDLER-Michael. Temple Israel of New Rochelle records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family. Amiel Wohl, Rabbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKSCHER, AUGUST
description: HECKSCHER-August. The Grolier Club of New York mourns the passing of our fellow member and accomplished bookman, August Heckscher. A member of the Club since 1965, he served on the Club's Council and chaired its Modern Fine Printing Committee. As proprietor of the High Loft Press, he demonstrated superb skills as a printer and we are grateful for the lovely examples of his bookmaking which he donated to our library.l William B. Warren President

title: Jam Session: Van Gundy Speaks Mind
description: Defending the pick and roll was not on the agenda. Neither was cutting off Scottie Pippen's drives to the basket or getting a hand in the face of Michael Jordan. The Knicks did not come to SUNY-Purchase today to practice. They came for group therapy.

title: Italians Vote To Send Force Into Albania
description: After a day of intense political bargaining, Prime Minister Romano Prodi won parliamentary approval tonight to send an Italian-led multinational force to Albania next week, but at a price that seriously weakened his center-left coalition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURLEY, JOHN F. SR
description: CURLEY-John F. Sr, of Ardsley on Hudson, NY, died April 8, 1997, age 84 after a long illness. Survived by his wife Anne, daughter Marilyn Heavener of Gaithersburg, MD, son John F. Curley, Jr., of Baltimore, MD, 4 grandchildren and a great grandchild. Retired partner, Paine Webber Jackson & Curtis. Services are private. Contributions in his memory may be made to Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, 622 West 168th Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10032 or Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, Boston, MA 02163.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, GEORGE
description: WIENER-George. Died peacefully April 8, 1997, in Encino, California. Born in New York City February 25, 1901, he was 96 years old and lived through every decade of this century. He was a music publisher, a Brill building original and one of the colorful music men who made up the Tin Pan Alley scene. His card playing skills were legendary. Devoted husband to the late Evelyn, he was a loving father, grandfather and great-grandfather. He leaves his sons, Robert and Stuart; daughters-in-law, Claire and Marlene; grandchildren, Richard, Michael, Allen, Wendy, Jill, Joshua and Katie; and great-granddaughter, Jamie. Services will be held April 11, 1997 in Los Angeles.

title: Gerald Gaull, 66, Pediatrician And Expert on Infant Nutrition
description: Gerald Edward Gaull, a pediatrician whose research on the development of the human brain prompted the addition to baby formulas of a vital ingredient of mother's milk, died April 2 while vacationing in Quito, Ecuador. He was 66 and lived in Washington.

title: Coffee Prices Rise on Report Of Disappointing Latin Crops
description: Coffee prices jumped yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after a Colombian official indicated that disappointing crops in Colombia and Brazil could leave world supply dangerously low, traders said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, HERBERT
description: SINGER-Herbert, on April 9, 1997. Beloved husband of Leona, loving father of Ellen and Gordon, Connie and Richard, most loving grandfather of Rod, Cliff, Brad, Pam and Keith. Loving brother of Charlotte Rose. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Av at 81 St, Thursday April 10, 79PM, funeral service, Frank E Campbell Friday, April 11, 12:30pm

title: So What Will It Be, the Moral Thing or Ill-Gotten Gains?
description: Gottfried von Einem's ''Visit of the Old Lady,'' at the New York City Opera on Tuesday night, is an example of operatic music being overpowered by literary sources. Opera historically does it the other way around, as witnessed, for example, by ''Ernani,'' heard in concert at Carnegie Hall on Sunday. Here, it is Verdi's powerful music that redeems Piave's jerry-built melodrama.

title: Officers Give Another Version of Fatal Police Shooting
description: At least one officer who was present at the fatal police shooting of a 16-year-old in Washington Heights on Sunday has told investigators that he thought the machete the teen-ager carried was a shotgun, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Storm on Sun Is Viewed From Spacecraft
description: Using instruments on a new spacecraft a million miles from Earth, scientists have made their first detailed observations of a storm on the surface of the Sun, in hopes of confirming new theories about solar events that can affect life on Earth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUNK, ADA (NEE COHAN)
description: FUNK-Ada (nee Cohan). On April 7, 1997, at age 94. Beloved wife of the late William, devoted mother of Richard and the late Edward, beloved mother-in-law of Barbara. Cherished grandmother of Eric, Jon, Andrew and Wendy. Graveside service on Friday, 11 A.M., at Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, Queens.

title: G.O.P. and Mongolia
description: To the Editor:

title: Social Security Closes On-Line Site, Citing Risks to Privacy
description: The Social Security Administration said today that it had shut down an Internet site that supplied information about people's personal income and retirement benefits because of concern that it might violate privacy rights.

title: For the Tony Awards, A Little More Pizazz
description: In an effort to reverse dismal television ratings and sell Broadway to a mass audience, the Tony Awards are taking a more aggressive approach.

title: Dow Jones Reports Earnings Fell 32.5%
description: Dow Jones & Company, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings fell 32.5 percent, hurt by a steep drop in operating income at its troubled Telerate financial information unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYDE, HENRY B.
description: HYDE-Henry B. On April 5, 1997. Beloved husband of Liza Prokoff Piper, father of Lorna de Wangen and Isabel Jasinowski, stepfather of Anastasia Piper and Kelly Piper, grandfather of Stephanie de Wangen and Anne-Marie and Paul-Henry Jasinowski and stepgrandfather of Nicholas Locker and William and Belle Laure Piper. Service on Friday, 10:00 A.M., at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Ave. between 71st and 72nd. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The French Institute/Alliance Francaise or the Hospital for Special Surgery, NYC.

title: Government Will Reserve Bills in Auction
description: The Government is so awash with cash that it is afraid there will be too much demand for its Treasury bills at its auction Monday. So it is taking steps to assure that Americans can get their fair share of the auction.

title: Designers Who Know Their Customer
description: Designers who slavishly follow trends, changing their styles with the prevailing winds, showing structured clothing one season and ultrafeminine dresses the next, never really develop a signature.

title: Federal Arts Agency Slices Its Smaller Pie
description: The National Endowment for the Arts announced a set of drastically reduced grants yesterday to cultural institutions across the nation. The total support for the current fiscal year is 40 percent lower, and comprises 70 percent fewer grants, than before Congress slashed the agency's budget and began a furious debate about whether it should exist at all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAGE, EDWIN ''PETER''
description: GAGE-Edwin ''Peter'', realtor, passed away at Mary Manning Walsh Home in New York City on April 7, 1997 after a long illness. Husband of Suzanne Reade Gage. Father of Linda O'Connor (Timothy) and Thomas Gage (Teri) and beloved ''Pop'' of Andrew, Jessica, Peter and Laura, brother of Alan Gage. Contributions may be made to Monmouth Medical Center. Funeral services private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDA, WILLIAM R.
description: LANDA-William R., 77, of Culpeper, died on Tuesday, April 8, 1997 at Culpeper Memorial Hospital. A memorial service will be held at 11 AM on Monday, April 14, at Found & Sons Chapel, Culpeper, VA, with Dr. R. Wayne Bernardo officiating. Interment will follow in Fairview Cemtery. Memorial contributions may be made in his name to the Culpeper Rescue Squad, P.O. Box 731, Culpeper, VA. 22701.

title: The People's Verse
description: Should poetry be on the Internet? Should it have a month, like cheese or Vaccination Awareness? No, say critics like the sage and distinguished poet Richard Howard, citing the inner, personal nature of the art. This is a sympathetic position, but I differ. Poetry is part of our shared, communal life, as surely as is the Internet.

title: The Bolshoi, After Some Painful Changes, Is Striving to Become Great Again
description: Anna Antonicheva looks as if her endless, elegant legs are about to buckle beneath the feathery weight of her body. In a few hours she and her young partner from the Bolshoi Ballet, Dmitri Belogolovstsev, will leave for Canada, where they have been invited to perform in an evening of dance devoted to the ballet stars of the 21st century.

title: The Fox Hunt Is Hounded, but Won't Turn Tail
description: Advocates of fox hunting, feeling their traditional sport endangered by the likelihood of a change in government after the national election on May 1, have taken a step cunningly appropriate to fighting a party called Labor. They have formed a union.

title: It's Not A Secret, But Still Exciting
description: ONE morning last month, just before a filming of the ABC television show ''Ellen,'' Tracy Newman, a consulting producer, asked the show's star, Ellen DeGeneres, to autograph her copy of the script. It was the script for the heavily anticipated and highly publicized April 30 episode in which the sitcom's lead character, Ellen Morgan, announces she is a lesbian.

title: Indictment Traces Gifts of Drug Money
description: Almost $30,000 laundered from illegal narcotics transactions was donated to the Democratic National Committee and to President Clinton's 1992 inauguration, according to an indictment returned today against an Arkansas lawyer.

title: Tele-Communications Abandons Plan to Spin Off 3 Units
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, said late yesterday that it would not spin off three businesses because it could not obtain a favorable tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Fame Splits the De La Hoya Family
description: He is champion and he is corporate not necessarily in that order. His hat says, ''www.oscardelahoya.com,'' his long lost cousins want a piece of the pie, and he lives in a log cabin for privacy's sake. He wishes his mother could see this, or maybe not, because the De La Hoyas are no longer traveling in the same station wagon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, GABE
description: WIENER-Gabe. On April 9, 1997. Beloved son of Michael and Zena Wiener, cherished brother of Jenny, suddenly taken away at the tender age of 27. His wonderful, indomitable spirit and gift for life made this world a better place. His passions have deeply touched our lives and his talent and vision will always surround us. He will serve as an inspiration for all who knew and loved him. Gabe will always be with us. Funeral services will be held at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55th Street, on Friday, April 11th at 10 A.M.

title: Tensions Grow as Europe Moves to a Unified Market
description: Europe's progress toward political and economic unity, glacial though it may be, is opening the Continent to a level of worldwide competition that is unprecedented in its traditionally insular markets. Radical change is shaking some of Europe's biggest industries, leading to widespread job losses.

title: Tax-Exempt Groups Receive Subpoenas on G.O.P. Gifts
description: Congressional investigators issued subpoenas today to a group of conservative tax-exempt groups as part of an inquiry into whether campaign contributions were funneled from conservative donors to Republican candidates in ways that may have evaded Federal election laws.

title: Quality Where It Counts
description: IT was a typical scene in Alphabet City, on Ninth Street between Avenues C and D: squatters sat playing guitars on the steps of an abandoned tenement house, and some teen-agers with a ball headed off to a basketball court.

description: CIRKER-Sol. April 10, 1950. In loving memory of a dear father, grandfather & great-grandfather. Children

title: Rubin's Dominant Victory Proves Williams Still Has a Way to Go
description: Venus Williams has made no secret of her designs on the No. 1 ranking owned by the fellow teen-ager Martina Hingis, who is not at the Bausch & Lomb Championships. But today the 102d-ranked Williams received a second-round tennis lesson from a player ranked a mere 30th, Chanda Rubin.

title: Asians Are Alarmed as Beijing Objects to U.S. Forces in Region : China Tries to Be King of the Hill
description: SINGAPORE  China has alarmed many Asian countries by saying publicly for the first time that it opposes the stationing of U.S. forces in the region.

title: FLORES & RUCKS SAID TO PLAN JOINT OIL VENTURE
description: Flores & Rucks Inc. said yesterday that it expected to disclose a joint venture with ''a major oil company'' to explore for oil in the Gulf of Mexico. The company, based in Baton Rouge, La., would announce the venture in 60 to 90 days, the company's chief executive, James Flores, said. He declined to name the partner, saying only that it was a major integrated oil company with ''significant deep-water production, technical capability and rig availability.'' Shares of Flores & Rucks rose $4.125, to $43.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said the joint venture would allow Flores & Rucks to reinvest its rapidly growing cash flow.

title: Fictional Foreign Crisis For Real Players to Mull
description: Unable, presumably, to sign up Bill Clinton or at least George Bush, the producers of ''Constant Combatants: The President and Congress'' settled for Joseph A. Califano, a former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, to play the President of the United States.

title: Russian Talks of a Possible NATO Pact
description: All but conceding defeat in its long battle against NATO's expansion, Russia agreed conditionally today to put its relations with the alliance on a new footing at a meeting in May with President Clinton and other allied leaders.

title: 300 Jobs to Greenburgh
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is to formally announce corporate moves expected to take 300 jobs to the former Ciba-Geigy headquarters in Greenburgh when he appears in the Westchester County community today to accept an award for leadership in the county's economic revival.

title: Dole Takes Position With a Washington Law Firm
description: Bob Dole will become special counsel at a Washington law firm -- Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand -- whose partners include many prominent Democrats, the firm announced today.

title: France Telecom Price Plan Approved
description: France's telecommunications regulators have approved a modified plan by France Telecom S.A. for the prices the current monopoly can charge future rivals to use its network. The Authorite de Regulation des Telecommunications said yesterday that it had approved average interconnection charges of 6.09 centimes, or about 1 cent, a minute for local calls; 12.8 centimes a minute for regional calls, and 17.57 centimes a minute for longer-distance calls. The charges are to take effect Jan. 1.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEIGEL, GRETA
description: BEIGEL-Greta. Of New York City, April 5, 1997. Survived by daughter Uli Monaco, grandchildren Nicholas, Jessica and Lucas, and greatgrandchildren Raphael, Gabriel & Noah. Visiting Sunday 3-6 P.M., at 315 Riverside Drive, Apt 19B.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRITTON, A. DUDLEY. JR.
description: BRITTON-A. Dudley. Jr., 92. On April 1, 1997 of complications from a tennis court broken hip. Devoted husband of the late Carroll Scarborough Britton and the late Helen Ingram Britton, he is survived by his sister, Edna, of New York and son, Peter of Pleasantville, New York. He was a former New York Times reporter and General Motors speech writer. A memorial open house will be held at his home in Pleasantville, on April 12 from 2-5 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to the National Osteoporsis Foundation, Washington, D.C. 20036 are appreciated.

title: At Augusta, a Peek at the Future and the Past
description: In the city where time stands still, at the golf course where the giants past and present walk in one another's footprints, another Masters tournament will begin on Thursday. This is the signal golf event that annually serves as both reminder and portent: as towering as the history of the Masters is, something even bigger might be riding the wind.

title: NBC TO OFFER INTERNET SITE GEARED TO LOCAL STATIONS
description: NBC said it would offer its 215 television stations an Internet site that features telephone directories, restaurant and real estate listings and other services geared to local areas. NBC, a unit of the General Electric Company, said it expected NBC Interactive Neighborhood to build a service that can generate advertising revenue while linking viewers to its local affiliates. Infoseek Inc., which signed an exclusive agreement to provide a directory service for NBC Interactive Neighborhood, would sell advertising for the site. The services that NBC has signed up include the Microsoft Corporation's Sidewalk, which provides arts and entertainment coverage in cities, and Realtor.com, the site of the National Association of Realtors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARSTEN, CHARLES CHRISTOPHER
description: KARSTEN-Charles Christopher. Suddenly at his home in Williamson, NY on Apr. 5. Survived by his wife, Laila Farevaag; his children, Rebecca and Charles Karsten; his parents, Rev. and Mrs. Charles Karsten of ME., and his sister, Wendy Karsten Beck of VA. Chris was born on Apr. 9, 1952. He grew up in Gardner, ME., and graduated from St. Paul's School and Hobart College '74 and received his MBA from the University of Rochester. Served since 1983 as Executive Director of the Wayne County Association for Retarded Citizens. The untimely loss of this much loved man is an unbearable blow to his family, friends and co-workers. Services 11AM, Apr. 10, Church of the Good Shepherd, Webster, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Wayne ARC or Church of the Good Shepherd.

description: CHERRY-Herman. 4/10/92. Always in my thoughts. Regina

description: Two recent decisions by the nation's antitrust officials appear contradictory, even anomalous. In fact, both are well crafted to protect consumers from high prices.

title: Corrections
