The apartment has one bedroom and rents for $749 a month, including garage fees; it is not a two-bedroom apartment costing $1,200 a month.

title: Japan Stocks a Bit of a Bust for U.S. Investors
description: From the viewpoint of an American investor, the Japanese stock market has plunged to a four-year low.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VITULLI, CAROLE JAN (NEE POLLACK)
description: VITULLI-Carole Jan (nee Pollack). Age 42. On March 30, 1997 in Coral Springs, FL. Formerly of Teaneck, NJ. Beloved mother of Angela. Daughter of Dorothy Belle and Sidney Pollack. Sister of Joy Montgomery, Bill and Alison Pollack. Memorial service on Saturday, April 12th, 2:00 P.M., at First Church of Religious Science, 331 Mt. Kemble Avenue (Rte. 202), Morristown, NJ. In her memory, donations may be made to National Kidney Foundation, 30 East 33rd St., New York, New York 10016.

title: No Headline
description: ''These are really mind-blowing pictures. How often is an ocean discovered? The last one was the Pacific by Balboa, and that was 500 years ago.''

title: Canadian Cable TV Operators In Internet Deal With @Home
description: @Home Network, the high-profile provider of Internet service via cable networks, got a much-needed lift today when the two largest Canadian cable television companies said they would offer the service as well as acquire 5 percent of the two-year-old company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Seal Is Recuperating
description: A female seal rescued from the beach in Lower Township is slowly recuperating at the Marine Mammal Stranding Center, but it is not totally out of danger, officials said yesterday.

title: Jerusalem Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Redefining German Citizenship
description: The key to German identity is found in the blood. A German is not someone born in Germany, but someone born to ethnic German parents anywhere in the world. Many other nations define citizenship the same way, but Germany's Nazi past gives the concept a different resonance. Now a remarkable new debate in Germany may change the German concept of citizenship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, JUDGE HARRY W.
description: DAVIS-Judge Harry W. The Spiegel family, Charlotte, Jill, Maura, Arthur, Little Sam and Kate, mourn the loss of dear friend, ''Uncle Henry,'' and classmate, law partner and colleague of the late Surrogate Samuel A. Spiegel. Our heartfelt condolences to Teresa, and to Michael, always a part of our extended family, our thoughts are with you. We share your pain.

title: Fugitive Eludes Police Detection for 5 Years by Hiding in a State Forest
description: Over the years, high winds and small brush fires have left countless piles of brush strewn about Shindagin Hollow State Forest in upstate Tompkins County, N.Y. And from a distance, there appeared to be nothing unusual about a particular earthen clump rising gently from the forest floor.

title: Alejo Peralta Diaz, 80, Is Dead; One of Mexico's Wealthiest Men
description: Alejo Peralta Diaz, a pioneering figure in Mexico's industrial development who became a confidant of presidents and one of the country's wealthiest entrepreneurs, died here on Tuesday of heart failure. He was 80.

title: Hazardous Waste Is Left
description: In August 1995, when Joseph Maykish walked away from his electroplating company in Newark, he also walked away from vats of hazardous materials, state officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about First Deputy Prime Minister Boris Nemtsov of Russia incorrectly described the officials whom he forced to sign an anti-corruption decree. They work for the Government of Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, not the Russian Parliament.

title: 12-Run Burst Over 2 Innings Buries Angels
description: Call it baseball bliss. For one awesome second inning and one amazing third inning at Anaheim Stadium, everything felt terrific for the Yankees. Every swing was sweet, every pitch was precise and every run was theirs.

title: Panel Upset by New Delay In Russian Space Module
description: After years of delay and cost overruns on the proposed international space station, the Clinton Administration came into office four years ago vowing to put the project on a strict schedule and keep it there, no matter what.

title: Tickets to Ride
description: So everyone wants to go to Camp David, now. Yup, skip all those pesky interim steps in the Arab-Israeli peace process and just cut right to the bottom line. I like that idea -- on just one condition: Everybody who wants to come to Camp David has to buy a ticket. And it won't be cheap.

title: McCourt Tells Students the Storytelling Power of a Life
description: A stretch limousine stopped in front of a Manhattan apartment building this morning to pick up a retired schoolteacher named Frank McCourt. It was a means of travel not to his taste, but such are the burdens of luxury for someone who has just won the Pulitzer Prize for biography.

title: Surgery for Gooden Is Set for Next Week
description: After two days of conversations and cajoling, the Yankees finally convinced Dwight Gooden today that it would make sense for him to undergo surgery immediately to repair a small hernia in his left groin. Gooden will have surgery Monday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Tampa, Fla., and the Yankees said he could be pitching in five or six weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CERTNER, JOEL
description: CERTNER-Joel. In loving memory of our beloved Joel, killed 31 years ago today. Mother, Naomi and Jerry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICEMAN, OLIVER M.
description: PRICEMAN-Oliver M. Beloved son of Mark & Alla of Larchmont, NY. Brother of Eric, brother-in-law of Kathleen and uncle of Zachary, Mark and Kristina, all of Oak Park, IL., & nephew of Hedda Prejsman of Tel Aviv, Israel. Died tragically in Larchmont, New York, on April 6. He carried a burden too crushing for him to bear. He did not know how many loved the noble human being that he was. Funeral arrangements will be private. A memorial reunion will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to NARSAD Research Fund (National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression) 60 Cutter Mill Road, Great Neck, New York 11021.

title: The Met markets 'Glory of Byzantium' exhibition to those whose ancestors helped make it glorious.
description: ETHNIC marketing'' has become a familiar phrase in the advertising lexicon. All too often, though, ''ethnic'' is used to mean Asian, black or Hispanic.

title: Iraq Defies U.N. Ban With Pilgrimage Flight to Arabia
description: An Iraqi aircraft flew more than 100 passengers to Saudi Arabia today in the first open defiance of the United Nations air embargo that has been enforced against Iraq since the Persian Gulf war six years ago.

title: A Time Capsule of the Pre-Legend Rat Pack
description: They come onstage snapping their fingers, smoking cigarettes, joking about being happy drunks. ''Fly Me to the Moon'' is arranged with a steady laid-back rhythm rarely heard outside malls and elevators these days. In ''The Rat Pack Captured,'' a recently rediscovered tape of a live television performance from June 1965, Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and Sammy Davis Jr. are frozen in time (or as they might have put it, swingin' through time). The show, the only complete performance of these three known to exist, will be screened at the Museum of Television and Radio beginning tomorrow and running through June 12.

title: Right to Protest In Hong Kong To Be Cut Back
description: In a severe blow to civil liberties here, the man appointed by China to run Hong Kong after July 1 announced plans today to impose more stringent controls on public protest and free association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINDENBAUM, RUTH J. NEE KRAUSKOPF
description: LINDENBAUM - Ruth J. nee Krauskopf. Beloved wife of Sidney. Mother and grandmother. Our lives will never be the same. You made everybody and every day feel special around you. You set wonderful examples for us to follow. Your legacy of loving kindness and caring will be with us forever. With love, Sidney, Marcy, Randy, Jessie, Amy, Sandy, Leslie, Dara and David. Funeral service at 1 P.M., Thursday, Community Synagogue, Sands Point, N.Y.

title: P.& G. Plans To Acquire Tambrands
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would acquire Tambrands Inc. for $1.85 billion in what would be its largest acquisition ever and establish the consumer product giant as the leader in the feminine protection business.

title: Devils Have a Reason to Root for Rangers
description: The Devils have won 39 games this season when they have scored the first goal. Conversely, the Florida Panthers came into tonight's game without a victory when trailing after two periods.

title: Woman Held in Attempt To Strangle Daughter, 8
description: A South Bronx mother was charged yesterday with trying to strangle her 8-year-old daughter while another woman tried to shield them from view, the police said.

title: Target's campaign sells Midwestern 'nice' to New Yorkers.
description: WHEN a retail company from the Midwest where shoppers are called ''guests'' and everyone who answers the telephone sounds like Frances McDormand in ''Fargo'' comes to New York, how should its arrival be advertised?

title: 2 Members of Palestinian Group Get U.S. Legal Resident Status
description: In a move that could be a turning point in a 10-year effort by the Federal Government to deport eight advocates of Palestinian sovereignty, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has granted legal resident status to two of the defendants known as the L.A. Eight, lawyers in the case said today.

title: LUCENT DEAL WITH BELL ATLANTIC WORTH UP TO $1 BILLION
description: Lucent Technologies Inc., the former equipment unit of the AT&T Corporation, said yesterday that the Bell Atlantic Corporation had agreed to buy as much as $1 billion of phone equipment over five years as part of a lawsuit settlement. On March 13, Bell Atlantic agreed to buy more Lucent equipment in exchange for dropping a suit that accused AT&T of blocking transmission of caller-identification information over its phone network. Bell also contended that Lucent impeded competition by refusing to build equipment that was easily compatible with equipment and software made by other companies. Under the settlement, Lucent dropped countersuits it had filed against Bell Atlantic and the DSC Communications Corporation.

title: An Era Still Driven to Abstraction
description: YOU wouldn't know it from this year's Whitney Biennial, or from ''Abstraction in the 20th Century: Total Risk, Freedom, Discipline'' at the Guggenheim last spring, but abstract painting in America is alive and in guarded but stable condition.

title: 'I'm Tight Because I Care'
description: TIGER WOODS thought he was ready for his first Masters as a pro after two as an amateur. He considered himself ''tournament tough.'' He had been putting ''really well.'' His game, he told friends, had ''clicked in.''

title: Yanks Back at Stadium, With Steinbrenner on Deck
description: Six months after the Yankees captured the hearts of New Yorkers with their World Series victory, they return to the stadium this afternoon, charging higher ticket prices and with a big unresolved question: How long will they remain in the Bronx?

title: A Record for Futures Seat
description: A membership on the Chicago Board of Trade sold this week for a record $775,001, surpassing the previous high of $750,000 set last month. A full member has the right to trade any contract on the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's largest futures market. Buyers are now offering $775,000 for a seat, sellers are seeking $875,000, the exchange said.

title: Compaq Computer Agrees to Buy Maker of Networking Products
description: In the latest move in the rapid consolidation of the computer networking industry, the Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Microcom Inc. for $280 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MC GRATH, MARIE, NEE SPEIRS
description: MC GRATH-Marie, nee Speirs, 1933-April 1, '97 after a four month battle with cancer. Beloved wife for 35 years of Timothy. Resident of Stuyvesant Town, Long Beach and Boynton Beach. Graduate of Fordham University. Congresstional secretary and longtime member of Local 153-OPEIU. Predeceased by parents James and Mary Speirs and sister Joan Wolf. Survived by sisters Anne Malone and Sister Gilmary, IHM, and two nephews, six nieces, one grandnephew and 2 grand-nieces.

title: A Self-Serving Portrait of Woods
description: The infomercial preceding the fourth round of the Masters on Sunday at 3 P.M. on CBS will not hawk abdomenizers, hair-in-a-can, Captain Video decoder rings or Richard Simmons's deal-a-meal plans. This one crassly sells Tiger Woods as a supernatural golfing deity, an inspiration to children and old black golfers and the man predestined to globalize golf, maybe take it to the Jupiter moon where life may exist. If lesser lights like Albert Schweitzer, Ralph Bunche and Mahatma Gandhi were available, this portrayal of Woods would have them utter the mantra scripted of the future saint: ''I'm Tiger Woods.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIPNES, ELLEN
description: KIPNES-Ellen. The Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of the Muttontown Club mourn the passing of our beloved member Ellen Kipnes, and extend our deepest sympathy to her husband Robert, her son Stuart and daughter Staci. Joel Simon, President Thea Capazzi President Womens Group

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Roman Catholic Church's practice of annulment has become a cause celebre in Massachusetts.

title: Triarc to Cut 50 Jobs
description: The Triarc Company said today that it would eliminate 50 jobs in the sale of all 355-company owned Arby's Restaurants to RTM Restaurant Group. Triarc said that after the reorganization, about 150 employees would continue to work at its Restaurant Group's headquarters and field offices, with about 110 in Fort Lauderdale. Triarc, a holding company with interests including beverages, propane and chemicals, agreed to sell the restaurants to RTM, which is based in Atlanta, for $71 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

description: SINGER-Herbert, on April 9, 1997. Beloved husband of Leona, loving father of Ellen and Gordon, Connie and Richard, most loving grandfather of Rod, Cliff, Brad, Pam and Keith. Loving brother of Charlotte Rose. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Av at 81 St, Thursday April 10, 79PM, funeral service, Frank E Campbell Friday, April 11, 12:30pm

title: 2 Standards About Words On Farrakhan
description: BEFORE the mayoral candidates find something new to argue about, there are a few questions still reverberating from the set-to between Ruth W. Messinger and the Rev. Al Sharpton over Louis Farrakhan's anti-Semitic rants. They have far less to do with the battle for City Hall than with race relations in this ethnic stew of a city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIENER, DAVID
description: DIENER-David. Age 78 of New York and Fire Island on April 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Esther. Loving father of Jonathan, Bart, and Mick. Dear brother of Edward and Marcia.

title: Four A's Presents A+ Creative Awards
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies, also known as the Four A's, yesterday named two agencies to share its A+ Creative Award for the first time in its seven-year history.

title: Evidence Backs Theory Linking Origins of Life to Volcanoes
description: The theory that life on earth began around a volcano, perhaps at the deep-sea vents where molten lava boils through the ocean floor, has been bolstered by the chemical reconstruction of an essential step in the metabolism of living cells.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENENDEZ, ALVARO
description: MENENDEZ-Alvaro. On April 9, 1997, of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved husband of Delores. Loving father of Alvaro, Antonio and Manuel Menendez; Delores Vilgertshofer, Victoria Moskowitz and Teresa Menendez. Also survived by five grandchildren. Visiting at Fox Funeral Home, Ascan Ave, corner Metropolitan Ave, Forest Hills, Friday, 7-9. Funeral Saturday private.

title: The Decline and Fall of the Monoliths
Girl, 15, Is Found Slain In Vacant Bronx Hallway
description: A 15-year-old honor student who friends said would go straight home from school every day to study was found strangled Wednesday night in a hallway of a Bronx apartment building, the police said yesterday.

title: Police Levy Fine On Russian Bus
description: While the State Department and the New York City administration battled yesterday over a plan to force diplomats to pay parking tickets, four Russian diplomats and a city highway patrol officer had an hourlong face-off over a summons for a double-parked bus on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the police said.

title: Glaxo Shares Climb On News of Drug Trials
description: Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C.'s shares climbed yesterday after it reported ''extremely encouraging'' results from tests of a new hepatitis B drug that analysts said could generate annual sales of about $:300 million ($486 million). Glaxo Wellcome shares closed at 1,108.5 pence, up 20, after it announced that the preliminary results of late-stage trials showed the drug improved liver functioning in 67 percent of patients and reduced viral replication in 16 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An opera review on Tuesday about Verdi's ''Ernani'' by the Opera Orchestra of New York at Carnegie Hall on Sunday misidentified a supporting singer. He was Steven Harrison, not Martin Dillon.

title: Prices Steady To Lower on Treasuries
description: Prices of Treasury securities were slightly lower to unchanged yesterday, as investors sold on the fear that forthcoming data would point to stronger inflation and keep the Fed in a restrictive mode.

title: Calling for Indictment of Officer, Marchers Protest Fatal Shooting
description: Calling for an indictment of a police officer in the fatal shooting of a teen-ager on Sunday, about 600 people marched a nine-block stretch of Washington Heights yesterday evening in a peaceful protest that included the lighting of candles outside the 33d Precinct station house.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARMIKE CINEMAS INC., Columbus, Ga., and Wal-Mart Stores Inc., Bentonville, Ark., have formed a joint venture to operate a chain of family entertainment centers.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Is Third Democrat to Join New Jersey Gubernatorial Race
description: The field of Democratic candidates who will compete for the chance to unseat Gov. Christine Todd Whitman was completed today, as Michael Murphy, the former Morris County Prosecutor, officially announced that he would seek the nomination in the party's June 3 primary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANNET, SEYMOUR
description: GANNET-Seymour, on Wednesday, April 9, 1997. Seymour Gannet of Florham Park, formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. Beloved husband of Gladys (Nee Wenderoff). Devoted father of Todd and Dean Gannet, dear brother of Herbert Gannet and Mitzie Landsberg, loving grandfather of 7 grandchildren. He was a very much loved family leader and friend and we will miss him. Funeral services conducted from the Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, N.J. On Friday, April 11, 1997 at 1:00 PM. Interment Beth Israel Cemetery, Cedar Knolls, N.J. In lieu of flowers donations in his memory may be made to the American Cancer Society, Northfield Ave., West Orange, N.J. 07052

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, DR. JOSEPH D.
description: LIEBERMAN-Dr. Joseph D. The Hebrew University and American Friends of the Hebrew University are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend. A Benefactor of The Hebrew University, Dr. Lieberman and his late wife, Natalie, established a fund to support the Dental Clinic for Handicapped Children, which bears their name, and for graduate students in the life sciences. A man of compassion and conviction, Joe was devoted to Israel and The Hebrew University. He will be buried on the Mount of Olive in Jerusalem. We extend our sincere condolences to his daughter, Irene, and the entire family. Professor Adam Stabholz, Dean, The Faculty of Dental Medicine American Friends of the Hebrew University Keith L. Sachs, President Lawrence Newman, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: JUDGE VOIDS LAW GIVING PRESIDENT LINE-ITEM VETOES
description: A Federal judge today struck down a new law that gave the President the power to cancel individual appropriations and tax benefits in legislation already enacted.

title: Publisher Branches Out
description: Kadokawa Shoten Publishing, one of Japan's biggest publishing companies, has opened an office in New York City, hoping to attract more opportunities to work with the growing number of multimedia businesses.

title: Eating Fish Cited Anew As Good For Heart
description: A large long-term study has found that men who eat seven ounces or more of fish a week are less likely than those who rarely eat fish to die of heart attacks. The new finding, published yesterday in The New England Journal of Medicine, joins eight other studies that have associated a heart-protective effect with regular fish consumption.

title: Stage Is Set for Act II of Fight Over Arts
description: Soon after Speaker Newt Gingrich called today for eliminating Federal subsidies to the arts, a bipartisan coalition followed him to the microphones to announce a counteroffensive.

title: Gingrich Continues to Reach Out to G.O.P. Conservatives
description: Continuing his courtship of House conservatives, Speaker Newt Gingrich recommitted himself today to wiping out Federal money for the arts.

description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Software Has Problems in California
description: Less than one week before the filing deadline, thousands of California taxpayers who used Turbotax software to calculate their state taxes are finding that they may have overpaid and that they will have to refile their returns because of a error in the software.

title: Backtracking on Ballot Reform
description: New Yorkers won an overdue reinstatement of their democratic rights last July when the State Legislature voted to eliminate many of the election law technicalities that have made it hard for insurgent candidates to get on the ballot. Unfortunately, that same reform spirit is missing in the regulations just proposed by the State Board of Elections to institute the new law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGATY, NINA
description: BOGATY-Nina. The entire community of the New York University Postdoctoral Program in Psychotherapy and Psychoanalysis is deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed colleague, Dr. Nina Bogaty, a candidate in our program. We express our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends. Alvin Atkins, PhD Robert Fiore, PhD Michael Varga, PhD David Wolitzky, PhD Co-Directors NYU Postdoctoral Program

title: Housing Chief Says U.S. Waiver Won't Mean Rent Rises
description: The chairman of the New York City Housing Authority said yesterday that if the authority were given much wider latitude by Federal officials to manage its properties, it would ''absolutely'' not use that new power to increase rents, evict tenants or demolish buildings.

title: Tuition at Rowan to Rise
description: Only few weeks after their school was upgraded from a college to a university, students at Rowan University are learning that they are likely to receive a tuition increase to match the new status. Tuition is expected to rise 14 percent next fall, officials said yesterday. A five-year budget plan, now in its second year, had included a tuition increase of 10 percent a year, but more is needed because of cutbacks in state aid, said Joe Cardona, director of university relations.

title: Stock Investor Enthusiasm Seen Ebbing
description: After helping the stock market get off to one of its fastest starts in history this year, mutual fund investors have apparently grown weary of an increasingly volatile marketplace.

title: Art in Review
description: Lois Connor

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the welterweight title fight between Pernell Whitaker and Oscar De La Hoya tomorrow night in Las Vegas misidentified the site. It is the Thomas and Mack Center, not the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino.

title: Morgan Reports 3.4% Drop in Earnings
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that earnings fell 3.4 percent in the first quarter, with March's sharp decline in stock and bond prices hurting the bank's securities trading business.

title: Proud but Cornered, Mobutu Can Only Hope
description: By the time President Mobutu Sese Seko named a general this week to rule Zaire under a state of emergency, people here seemed to have lost count of the aging dictator's proliferating Governments. After all, the new Prime Minister, Gen. Likulia Bolongo, who was named late Wednesday to manage Mr. Mobutu's declining hold on power, is Zaire's third head of Government in less than a week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAGE, EDWIN ''PETER.''
description: GAGE-Edwin ''Peter.'' The Board of Trustees and members of the Ocean Beach Club note with sadness the passing of long time friend and member, Edwin Peter Gage. He was a friend to the community and will be missed. Andrew Arno, President Laurie Lowenstein, Secretary

title: Inside Photography
description: ''I've always been around architectural spaces of significance,'' says the British-born photographer Richard Pare. When he was 7, for instance, and living in Canterbury, England, school was a stone's throw from the cathedral. ''For minor infractions,'' he recalled, ''punishment was a walk around the railings that surrounded these beautiful Norman columns of the old refectory. So I had a lot of time to study the Norman architecture.''

title: Hong Kong Residents Protest China's Plans to Limit Civil Rights
description: On call-in radio shows, in newspapers and on the streets of Hong Kong, people voiced outrage and apprehension today over plans announced Wednesday to roll back a series of civil liberties when China takes control on July 1.

title: Parking Ticket Uproar at U.N.: For Now, Peace Has No Chance
description: Faced with a storm of protest from United Nations diplomats over a plan to force them to pay their parking tickets, the State Department backed away from an agreement to remove the license plates of diplomatic scofflaws yesterday, igniting a verbal battle with the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the value of the United Nations to New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TCHERTKOFF, VICTOR, MD.
description: TCHERTKOFF-Victor, MD. The Medical Board and members of the medical staff of Metropolitan Hospital Center express their deep sorrow on the death of our devoted and beloved colleague, Victor Techertkoff, MD, Chief of Service, Department of Pathology at Metropolitan Hospital and Professor and Vice-Chairman of the Department at New York Medical College. Dr. Tchertkoff provided medical scholarship and leadership to the medical staff for over fifty years. We will deeply miss him. Our sincere condolences are offered to his family. Medical Board Officers Phyllis Harrison Ross, MD President Barbara Koppell, MD, Vice-President Clifford Gevirtz, MD, Treasurer Barbara Bess, MD, Secretary Richard Stone, MD, Senior Associate Dean

title: Low Sales Figures in March Disappoint Many Retailers
description: Winter markdowns and new spring merchandise were apparently not enough to lure many shoppers into the malls last month.

title: Suspicious Fire Burns Sharpton's Harlem Office
description: A suspicious fire tore through a three-story building that houses the Harlem headquarters of the Rev. Al Sharpton's mayoral campaign early yesterday, but investigators said they believed that the intended target of the fire was a beauty parlor one floor below the campaign office.

title: US Airways Chief Warns Of Cutbacks
description: If US Airways is unable to reach a cost-cutting agreement with its labor unions, it may start dropping unprofitable routes between the East and West coasts, as well as routes in Florida and at its Baltimore hub.

title: Roaring for the 1996 World Champion Yankees One Final Time
description: For one sparkling afternoon in a baseball stadium in the Bronx, the Yankees will actually have grander expectations than their demanding fans. The Yankees expect today to be a day they will long cherish as a new World Series flag joins 22 others over Yankee Stadium. They expect more than 57,000 sets of vocal cords to make the day feel like a Nine Inch Nails concert inside a garage. They expect to feel like champions. Again.

title: A Bad Deal Is Worse Than None
description: Congressional and White House negotiators will meet again today to prepare for possible budget talks next week involving President Clinton. These talks are likely to determine not only what a future budget might look like, but even whether any budget deal at all will be struck this year. The pressure is on both sides to reach agreement and prove they know how to govern. But unless the concessions made by each side are right, the better outcome would be no deal at all.

description: SCHWARTZ-Aaron I., died April 11, 1989. Alive in our hearts and minds. Love from, Betty, Carole, Ted, Lisa and Leta

title: I.R.A. Gunman in Londonderry Wounds Ulster Policewoman
description: A policewoman of the Royal Ulster Constabulary was shot in the chest and seriously wounded in Londonderry today.

title: Aging A-Plant In New Jersey May Be Closed
description: Owners of the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant, one of the nation's oldest, said today that they were exploring options to sell or close it by 2000.

title: Toshiro Mayuzumi, 68, Eclectic Composer
description: Toshiro Mayuzumi, an eclectic Japanese composer who combined traditional Japanese music, neo-Romantic orchestration and electronic and avant-garde techniques in his ballet, film scores, theater works and symphonic pieces, died yesterday at a hospital in Kawasaki, near Tokyo. He was 68 and lived in Tokyo.

title: For Rostropovich at 70, New Works as Well as Old
description: Conventional wisdom -- or perhaps it is a combination of rationalization and lazy thinking -- holds that new music is a young person's pursuit, and that older musicians' efforts are best spent exploring the classics. Mstislav Rostropovich, who celebrated his 70th birthday on March 27, clearly rejects that view. Having given premieres of works by Prokofiev, Shostakovich and Britten that are now part of the standard cello repertory, he maintains his link to the creative side of musical life, and is one of the few musicians of his stature to do so.

title: 1996 Earnings Rose 30% at Dresdner Bank
description: Dresdner Bank A.G., Germany's second-largest bank, said yesteday that its 1996 profit rose 30.7 percent as it took in fees from Deutsche Telekom A.G.'s mammoth share offering. Net income rose to 1.58 billion marks ($921 million), from 1.21 billion marks in 1995.

title: G.E. Posts 10.5% Profit Gain, In Line With Analyst Forecasts
description: The General Electric Company said today that earnings rose 10.5 percent in the first quarter, lifted by double-digit profit growth at six divisions, including aircraft engines, power systems and GE Capital Services.

title: Police Chief Post to Remain
description: In a slap against Mayor James Whelan, the Atlantic City Council voted on Wednesday to restore the position of police chief.

title: German Group to Investigate Claims of Nazi Victims
description: One of Europe's largest insurance companies promised today to investigate claims from the families of thousands of European Jews whose insurance policies were confiscated by the Nazis in World War II.

description: Governor Whitman is not as popular with registered voters as she was two months ago, but she could easily beat any of her Democratic challeners.

description: A lawyer for Raul Salinas de Gortari, the elder brother of the former President of Mexico, today sharply disputed assertions by Swiss prosecutors that his client accepted millions of dollars to protect the shipments of narcotics traffickers.

title: Dollar Falters Against Yen After Reaching 4 1/2-Year High
description: The dollar fell yesterday for the first time in a week, tumbling from a four-and-a-half-year high against the Japanese yen, after three senior Japanese officials suggested that Japan might sell dollars to halt its rally.

title: Finding Comfort, Confidence and Stardom
description: American shows have often seemed like a warmed-over mush of European ideas, taking place as they do in the shadow of the British, French and Italian collections that precede them. In many seasons, the identity of fashion has come down to three proper nouns: Donna, Ralph and Calvin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPARI, VICTOR
description: LIPARI-Victor. Executive Director of Dance Films Association. The Board of Directors of Dance Films Association announce with deep sorrow the passing of their Executive Director on April 8, 1997, and wish to express their heartfelt condolences to his family and friends. The dance and film world will miss his vast knowledge and dedication.

title: Gotti's Son Accused of Obstructing Police
description: John Gotti Jr., the 33-year-old son of the convicted boss of the Gambino crime family, was arrested by police narcotics officers in Brooklyn last night and charged with obstructing governmental administration after he and a friend apparently tailed the undercover officers, who were driving an unmarked police car, the police said.

title: Plans Set to Honor Robinson
description: Jackie Robinson's daughter, Sharon, and a former teammate, Ralph Branca, were at Shea Stadium yesterday to help the Mets pitch plans for Jackie Robinson Day next Tuesday night, the 50-year anniversary of Robinson's breaking into the major leagues with the Brooklyn Dodgers.

title: Plan to Name Parkway For Jackie Robinson
description: As the city prepares gala celebrations for the 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's breaking of the baseball color barrier, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed renaming the Interboro Parkway that winds through Brooklyn and Queens in honor of the ex-Brooklyn Dodger.

title: Palmer Saluted In Round of 89
description: He walked slowly up the hill at the 18th green today, doffing his visor to the swelling applause from the gallery that rose as one to salute him. Most eyes were averted from the scoreboard that held his score -- ''A. Palmer +15'' -- and instead focused on Arnold Palmer as he waved and smiled. It didn't matter when he double-bogeyed 18 for an 89.

title: Parties Inch Toward Budget Compromise
description: Budget negotiators from the White House and Congress met today to lay out their differences on taxes, with Republicans pushing the Clinton Administration to accept bigger tax cuts and abandon some of its proposals for raising money to pay for them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMERMAN, KENNETH M.
description: KAMERMAN-Kenneth M., 65 of Albuquerque, New Mexico passed away April 7, 1997. Beloved husband of Merilee Dannemann, son of Judith and the late Irving Kamerman, brother of Ruth and Joseph Giden, uncle of Michael & Deborah of Los Angeles and nephew of Matty Kamerman of Forest Hills, Teresa Kamerman, & Eleanor and Jules Coen of Fla.

title: Jury Selection in Oklahoma Bomb Trial Is at Halfway Point
description: As jury selection in the Oklahoma City bombing trial neared the halfway point today, a shy young widow told the court she was a witch, did not believe in violence and would find it extremely difficult to impose the death penalty.

title: Jackson's Big Triple: 24-11-10
description: It did not seem like it at times, but there was a point to this Nets game, after all. It just did not come in the form of Sam Cassell.

title: Old Bell Regains Its Voice, And a Community Resounds
description: IT sometimes seems that there are as many different ways to experience New York as there are people experiencing it. Layered, whorled, encyclopedic, the city's treasures -- and some of its troubles -- are often arranged like those cunning Russian boxes, one within another within another. There's the New York you see, the New York you move through, the New York you smell, the New York you remember being prettier, cleaner, cheaper, more civilized, or lately (who would have thought it?) grittier and more dangerous. Always, of course, there's the New York you hear: this city has to be more richly, if cantankerously, aural than any other in the hemisphere.

title: QUAKER SAYS QUARTERLY PROFITS WILL EXCEED ESTIMATES
description: The Quaker Oats Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would beat Wall Street's expectations, excluding a $1.4 billion pretax charge from the sale of its Snapple beverages unit. Quaker said the charge, taken in the quarter that ended March 31, would amount to $8.40 a share. In the quarter a year ago, Quaker earned $32.2 million, or 23 cents a share. Quaker, which is based in Chicago, said it expected operating profits for the first quarter of 1997 to be at least 22 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had predicted earnings of 18 cents a share. Quaker's stock slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $38.50.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEASLEY, BARBARA LAVES, M.D.
description: BEASLEY-Barbara Laves, M.D., of New Rochelle, NY, on March 30, 1997. Loving mother of Eliza Bunnell and Julie Beasley; caring grandmother of Dylan Bunnell. Devoted daughter of Maxine Laves and the late Gerhardt Laves. Beloved sister of Edward, Elizabeth and Jean. Neurologist for over 30 years in Philadelphia and New York. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Barbara Beasley Memorial Fund, Medical College of Pennsylvania, 3300 Henry Avenue, Philadelphia, PA. 19129.

title: Royal and Sun Alliance Acquiring Italian Insurer
description: Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group, a British insurer, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Prudential Corporation's Vita Group, an Italian life insurer, for 125 billion lire, or about $73.5 million. Prudential Vita Group consists of Prudential Vita S.p.A., a life company; Prudential SIM S.p.A., a distribution company offering a range of financial products, and Prudential Fondi S.p.A., a fund manager. The Milan-based business had premium income of $:52 million ($84 million)in 1996.

title: Spin Employee Was Harassed, Jury Says
description: Spin magazine may represent a certain edge when it comes to covering the music scene. But a Federal jury has found that, along the way, the office environment involved a certain hostility to women that constituted sexual harassment.

title: INSIDE
description: Suspected Terrorists Seized

title: President Says the Government Will Hire 10,000 Off Welfare
description: President Clinton said today that the Federal Government would hire at least 10,000 welfare recipients over the next four years -- including 6 at the White House -- to do his share in moving people from welfare to work.

title: One of These Teams Looked Like a Champ
description: Michael Jordan sensed it. Scottie Pippen sensed it. And now the entire league can sense it.

title: House Banking Chief Wants Freddie Mac Bond Inquiry
description: The chairman of the House Banking Committee called today for an investigation into the investment practices of Freddie Mac, the Congressional-chartered, shareholder-owned mortgage finance company, saying it had abused the preferential borrowing terms it enjoys through its ties to the Government.

title: Restaurants
description: Sitting in the silly, theatrical splendor of Torre di Pisa, I watch the man across from me take a sip of his martini. He closes his eyes, leans back and slides slowly down in the silky sofa. Soon he is snoozing at his seat.

title: Art in Review
description: Prudencio Irazabal

title: First Steps on the Journey From Prodigy to Picasso
description: IF Picasso had died at 25 in 1906, when the last works in the show of his early years at the National Gallery of Art here were made, how highly would we regard him today?

title: John K. Armstrong, 62, Health Law Expert
description: John Kremer Armstrong, a New York lawyer specializing in health and intellectual-property law, died on Saturday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 62.

title: Opera Fans And Rule Breakers
description: Struggling to be heard amid the rowdy sentimentality of ''Cosi,'' an Australian film with a heart as sticky as molasses, is a potentially incisive comedy of manners comparing modern-day romance to the duplicitous sexual shenanigans in the Mozart opera ''Cosi Fan Tutte.'' But the film, adapted by Louis Nowra from his play, which was a hit in Australia, only halfheartedly develops the notion that passionately committed lovers are as susceptible to infidelity today as they ever were. Because the movie wants everyone to feel good about everyone else, it actually tries to show that true love 1990's-style is truer than it was in 1790. But don't you believe it.

title: First Lady Denies a Scheme On Hubbell and Whitewater
description: With a note of weary exasperation, Hillary Rodham Clinton today dismissed Whitewater as a ''never-ending fictional conspiracy that honest-to-goodness reminds me of some people's obsession with U.F.O.'s and the Hale-Bopp comet some days.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, JUDGE HARRY W.
description: DAVIS-Judge Harry W. The Spiegel family, Charlotte, Jill, Maura, Arthur, Little Sam and Kate, mourn the loss of dear friend, ''Uncle Harry,'' and classmate, law partner and colleague of the late Surrogate Samuel A. Spiegel. Our heartfelt condolences to Theresa, and to Michael, always a part of our extended family, our thoughts are with you. We share your pain.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Cooperate to Seize 4 Terrorist Suspects
description: The Israeli authorities announced today that they had uncovered an underground cell of the militant Islamic group Hamas that bombed a Tel Aviv cafe last month and kidnapped and killed an Israeli soldier who has been missing since September.

title: Hot Dogs Are Resized For School Cafeterias
description: The Board of Education has reshaped the hot dogs served in public school cafeterias after a third grader choked to death on one last year.

title: Evsey D. Domar, 82, Professor And Economic-Growth Theorist
description: Evsey D. Domar, a leading theorist of economic growth and expert on comparative economic systems, died April 1 at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass., where he had lived for many years. He was 82.

description: No-Win Situation

title: Quick & Reilly To Publicis/Bloom
description: Quick & Reilly Inc., the discount brokerage firm in New York, named Publicis/Bloom in New York to handle its account, which had been handled by Grey Direct in New York since October 1994. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million. Publicis/Bloom, a unit of Publicis S.A., was awarded the account after a two-month review that included Grey Direct, a unit of Grey Advertising, and other undisclosed agencies.

title: No Headline
description: ''If they'd like to leave New York over parking tickets, then we can find another use for that area of town.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, MAX
description: ELKIN-Max. Kind and gentle soul. Beloved husband of Anna, devoted father of Leo Paul. Graveside service 11:30 on Friday at The Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a bombing in Myanmar misstated the year the Burmese opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, was placed under house arrest. It was 1989, not 1990.

title: Three Fools Gear Up for A Letdown
description: Where better to set a wild goose chase than in the land of the wild goose?

title: How Cold Villainy Adds Warmth
description: Say hello, if you dare, to Uta, fashion plate, murderer and heroine for our times. She looks like Ivana Trump, sounds like Marlene Dietrich and has the hard, hard heart of Barbara Stanwyck in ''Double Indemnity.'' A mistress by profession, she cheerfully notes that ''selfishness is part of our job description.'' Told she is the subject of very compromising blackmail photographs, she immediately zooms in on what's important: ''But you say I looked thin?''

title: Coal Furnaces at 18 Schools to Be Replaced
description: The antiquated coal-fired boilers used to heat 18 New York City schools will be replaced with cleaner-burning natural gas furnaces, thanks to money from the state environmental bond act, state officials said today.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Remember when Le Madri opened in Chelsea with a group of Italian women running the kitchen? If you've been wondering where they went, you'll be happy to hear that one, Bruna Alessandria, is cooking near Sutton Place.

title: Lowe Direct Picks Creative Unit Chief
description: Lowe Direct, the direct marketing division of Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, named Doug Speidel to head the agency's creative department as executive vice president and executive creative director. He succeeds Sonny Farese, who was one of five Lowe Direct executives who abruptly left in October and formed their own breakaway shop, called Lieber, Levett, Koenig, Farese & Babcock in New York. Mr. Speidel, 42, joins Lowe Direct, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, from Wunderman Cato Johnson in New York, the direct marketing unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., where he was previously vice president and group creative director. He reports to Lynn Fantom, chief executive.

title: It Takes a Saint to Keep a Prison Camp Humming
description: With the possible exceptions of Vanessa Redgrave and Meryl Streep, no actress is better at projecting an empathetic, high-minded nobility than Glenn Close. And in ''Paradise Road,'' Bruce Beresford's grandly messy World War II epic, she has the saintliest role yet in a gallery of screen characters notable for their angelic (''The Natural'') and demonic (''Fatal Attraction,'' ''Dangerous Liaisons'') extremes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARMSTRONG, JOHN K
description: ARMSTRONG - John K. The Governors, medical staff and administration of Lawrence Hospital are deeply saddened by the death of our Legal Counsel, John K. Armstrong. He was a trusted advisor and friend of the Hospital. His sound guidance and intelligence, combined with his understanding and concern for the health care in our community were deeply valued and he will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Mieke and his entire family. Roger G. Dvorak, President George E. Austin, Chairman, Board of Governors

title: Accounts
description: * McCann-Erickson Washington, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was awarded an account and becomes the first agency to handle advertising for The Newseum, an interactive museum devoted to news, Rosslyn, Va. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: Modern Narrows Architects
description: The Museum of Modern Art has selected the three architectural firms that will compete to design the expansion of its midtown complex. The museum said yesterday that the finalists were Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron of Basel, Switzerland; Yoshio Taniguchi of Tokyo and Bernard Tschumi of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, RUTH
description: ROSEN-Ruth. 83. Loving mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister and aunt. She was loved by all and loved all. She set wonderful examples for us to follow. Her legacy of loving kindness and caring will be with us forever.

description: Nelly and Monsieur Arnaud

title: EVERGREEN MEDIA TO BUY 5 RADIO STATIONS AND SELL 3
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation said yesterday that it would buy five radio stations from the Gannett Company for $340 million and sell three radio stations to the Bonneville International Corporation for $205 million. The sale is to satisfy antitrust concerns stemming from its planned $2.58 billion acquisition of the Chancellor Broadcasting Company. In yesterday's transaction, Evergreen would acquire WGCI-AM and WGCI-FM in Chicago, KHKS-FM in Dallas and KKBQ-AM and KKBQ-FM in Houston. It is selling WPNT-FM and WLUP-FM in Chicago and KDFC-FM in San Francisco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, ANNE MARIE (MURRAY)
description: RYAN-Anne Marie (Murray). On April 10, 1997. Beloved wife of James V. Ryan, of Fairfield, CT. Mother of Deirdre, Kevin, Emmett, Maureen, James and the late Marybeth. Grandmother of six grandchildren. Sister of James and John Murray. Born April 3, 1926 in New York City. Service, Saturday, April 12, at Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich, CT, 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations to New York Hospital.

title: First-Quarter Profit Rose at Volkswagen
description: Earnings at Volkswagen A.G. were higher in the first quarter of 1997 than in the corresponding period a year earlier, company officials said yesterday. The chairman, Ferdinand Piech, said profit figures for the first quarter were not available yet but were up from a year earlier. In the first three months of 1996, Volkswagen posted a profit of 116 million marks, or about $67 million. But Mr. Piech said the Spanish truckers' strike in February 1997 cost the company 64 million marks.

title: At Trade Center Deck, Views Are Lofty, as Are the Prices
description: On a clear day you can see not quite forever from the observation deck of the World Trade Center, but visibility was 50 miles recently, and one small child, pointing in the general direction of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, excitedly told his mother, ''Look, Mommy, I can see up to Heaven.''

title: The Captain Won't Sail If the Skies Are Stormy
description: The threat of rain injected one kernel of intrigue into the draw for the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct yesterday, when 10 horses were entered but the owner of Captain Bodgit said that he would not run his horse if the track became ''a sea of slop.''

title: Helene Hanff, Wry Epistler Of '84 Charing,' Dies at 80
description: Helene Hanff, whose wittily acerbic 20-year correspondence with a London bookseller she never met won her a passionate following after it was published as the epistolary memoir ''84, Charing Cross Road,'' died on Wednesday at the De Witt Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 80.

title: A Sculptor Who Made Everything Look Easy
description: IT is quite some time since the New York public had a chance to reassess the achievement of the sculptor and sometime painter Aristide Maillol (1861-1944). Ranging in date from 1899 to 1940, the sculptures, drawings and one late painting at C. & M. Arts make up an exhibition that is nicely tailored for that purpose.

title: A Prophet's Gospel: Faith, Hope and Seed Money
description: The Hale-Bopp comet glowed in the sky above Manila Bay, but the 50,000 ecstatic Christian followers of Brother Mike paid it no heed. Flying saucers were the last thing on their minds. Their reward was here and now: good jobs, good health, good marriages and, best of all, money.

title: A Time to Negotiate, A Time for Courtship
description: Congressional budget negotiators pressed the White House yesterday to accept bigger tax cuts and to abandon some of its proposals for raising revenues as the two sides met for a third day.

Gleason Funeral Home, 149-20 Northern Blvd., Flushing. Friends may visit Friday evening, 7-10PM. Funeral services Saturday, 10AM. Entombment, Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to the Julia and Ned R. Arnold Center for Radiation Oncology, New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, 56-45 Main Street, Flushing, NY 11355 would be appreciated.

title: Lawyers Ask for Tests on Rifle in Killing of Dr. King
description: A bullet recovered from the body of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on April 4, 1968, just after his death and a Remington hunting rifle that James Earl Ray had bought days earlier in Birmingham, Ala., have never conclusively been linked.

title: A Midseason Addition: Tales of the Coroner
description: First you have to get by the cloying title and a premise that can best be described as icky. ''Leaving L.A.'' is set in the Los Angeles coroner's office, and the title refers to that final trip out of town taken by the customers. But it doesn't take long to move past those obstacles and realize that this off-kilter, energetic show is one of the better mid-season replacements. It's ''Quincy'' (the old show with Jack Klugman as a medical examiner) meets ''E.R.'' (a racing pace, hand-held cameras, multiple stories that flow smoothly). That turns out to be a surprisingly good combination.

title: Police Overkill
description: Roma Cedeno, with tears leaking down her ashen face, stood near the windy intersection of 159th Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Washington Heights on Tuesday and urged her neighbors to react peacefully to what they felt was the cold-blooded killing of her 16-year-old son Kevin.

title: Bill to Aid Local School Debt
description: Local officials have counted on state aid to help pay off bonds used to build a new school, add portable classrooms or construct a swimming pool. But for the last few years, the number of school construction projects has increased, yet the state has drastically reduced its contribution toward repaying local debt service.

title: Warning on Religious Right
description: With the local school board elections approaching on Tuesday, a liberal advocacy group known as the Coalition for Democracy is urging voters to help unmask candidates who may be hiding their participation in the Christian Coalition or other conservative religious groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, MARTIN B.
description: KAYE-Martin B., 77, of Lauderhill, FL, formerly of Merrick, NY, died on Tuesday, April 8, 1997. Beloved husband, brother, father and grandfather, he is survived by his wife Dorothy Rubens Kaye; his sons and daughters-in-law, Larry & Joan Kaye of N.Y.C. and Danny Kaye and Roseanne Patrissi of Los Angeles, CA; his sister Beverly Hornreich & her husband Arthur; and his grandchildren Michael, Emily and Sophie. Dedicated administrator and educator, he was for many years the Principal of Flushing High School in Flushing, New York. He will be missed. The family will be sitting Shiva in Manhattan at the home of Larry and Joan Kaye, 515 East 89th Street, Apt. 6-A, on Monday, April 14, from 4-10 PM.

title: Bulls, With One-Two Punch, Floor Knicks Again
description: Michael Jordan equated his and Scottie Pippen's performances to two brothers engaging in a backyard scrap with the neighborhood bully.

title: In God They Trust
description: Every day now Western politicians, diplomats and journalists, some well-meaning, some not very, announce that the only way to achieve Israeli-Palestinian peace is for both sides to learn to trust each other. If that's true, forget peace, because they won't.

title: Casio Computer To Fresh Carats
description: Casio Inc., the consumer electronics company owned by the Casio Computer Company, said yesterday that it had named Fresh Carats Ltd. in New York to handle its account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The account had been handled for 23 years by the Merkley Newman Harty unit of Omnicom Group in New York, and its predecessor shop, Doremus & Company, until Casio and Merkley Newman parted ways three weeks ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALTZMAN, MANUEL
description: SALTZMAN-Manuel. We mourn the loss of our beloved colleague, Rabbi Emeritus of Congregation Kehillat Israel in Brookline, MA, where he served for over 30 years. We extend our condolences to his wife Esther, his children Ora (Richard), Sarina (Elliot) and Ruth Saltzmann and to all who were touched by his rabbinate. Rabbi David L. Lieber, Pres. Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec. V.P. The Rabbinical Assembly

title: Auto Makers Draw a Yawn On Wall Street
description: The Big Three auto makers have been showing signs of renewed strength this month, but to Wall Street the industry seems to have reached a plateau. Even two bullish announcements today -- that the Chrysler Corporation had better-than-expected profits in the first quarter and that the Ford Motor Company would increase its dividend -- left analysts talking about auto stocks mostly as a safe bet if the stock market nose dives.

title: The Spoken Word
description: PETER BOGDANOVICH, Barnes & Noble, 1972 Broadway, at 66th Street. The director and author will discuss his new book, ''Who the Devil Made It'' (Knopf, 1997). Tonight at 7. Free. Information: (212) 595-6859.

title: Going Straight To Video Stores
description: LAST summer, months before Juliette Binoche won her Academy Award and years after William Hurt won his, I saw them in a quirky new film with much wry charm. In ''A Couch in New York,'' she is a dancer fleeing a romantic mess in Paris and he is a harried Manhattan psychoanalyst. They trade apartments; she cures his patients, and eventually their love lines cross. The film's charm was a major shock, because ''A Couch in New York'' was having its premiere on a plane and I expected it would make me want to jump out the window. The film's sad reputation had preceded it. An unlikely romantic comedy by the avant-garde Belgian director Chantal Akerman, this film had not found anyone willing to release it in American theaters. It was one of those pathetic orphans headed straight to video.

description: LIBERTY FINANCIAL COS., Boston, said it had hired Andy Hilbert as senior vice president and its first chief financial officer.

title: Time Running Out
description: Dr. Eyad Sarraj is a Palestinian psychiatrist in Gaza and a campaigner for human rights. I wrote about him last year when he criticized the Palestinian Authority for mistreatment of prisoners and was then himself imprisoned for 25 days.

title: Mets Back Home at 3-6 As Hope Springs Eternal
description: A pessimist would find satisfaction in the nine-game road trip the Mets completed here Wednesday night with a 3-2, 14-inning loss to the Dodgers. The Mets lost six of nine games, hitting a lowly .194, and the erratic bullpen was charged with all six defeats.

title: Ballet Theater Gala With Alicia Alonso
description: Alicia Alonso is to be the host of the American Ballet Theater opening-night gala on May 12 at 7 P.M. at the Metropolitan Opera House. The program will include previews of the season's new works, a 50th-anniversary celebration of George Balanchine's ''Theme and Variations'' and surprise dances.

description: HOPKINS-Anna. April 9, 1997. Former prominent NYC social work executive director and consultant. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, 81st St., Friday, 7-9 and Saturday, 3-6PM. Funeral service Saturday, 7:30P.M. Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West 57 Street, NYC.

title: Experimental Price Index Offers Glimpse of a Lower-Cost Future
description: Labor Department statisticians introduced an experimental version of the Consumer Price Index today that could shrink inflation readings and thus save the Government billions of dollars a year in payments to Social Security recipients and beneficiaries of other programs.

title: A Jet's Conspiracy Theory About Faking an Injury
description: In a book coming out this month that will continue to make Jets receiver Keyshawn Johnson a controversial figure, he suggests that Neil O'Donnell conspired with the coaches Rich Kotite and Ron Erhardt to fake a pre-game injury so that the ''coaches could keep their jobs.''

So far ''Fargo'' stands alone on tape, with delivery of Mike Leigh's ''Secrets and Lies'' scheduled for April 29. After that, arrivals of ''The English Patient,'' ''Shine,'' ''Jerry Maguire'' and others drag on into early summer.
