description: To the Editor:

title: House Republicans Back Away From Wide Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: The Republican-led House committee investigating campaign fund-raising today approved procedural rules that restrict the influence of Democrats on the panel and increase the likelihood that the inquiry will focus on the Clinton White House and the Democratic National Committee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, GABE
description: WIENER-Gabe. New York City Opera is deeply saddened by the sudden passing of the son and brother of our very good friends, Mike Zena and Jenny Wiener. We extend our friendship and profound sympathy to the entire family on their tragic loss. May the knowledge of the support of their many friends help to sustain them at this time. Irwin Schneiderman Co Chairman Paul Kellogg General Director Sherwin M. Goldman Executive Producer

title: Democrats Vote to Restore Connecticut Budget Cuts
description: Democrats on the Legislature's budget-writing committee today restored $400 million in cuts proposed by Gov. John G. Rowland and added several new welfare programs to soften the blow that is expected this fall when thousands of people begin to lose their welfare benefits.

title: Lilco Merger Receives Conditional Support
description: Long Island's leading business group said today that it would endorse the state's proposed partial takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, but only if the plan was revised to permit competition in the electricity market by 1999.

title: LEND LEASE AGREES TO BUY REAL ESTATE UNIT OF EQUITABLE
description: The Lend Lease Corporation, an Australian property development and financial services company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the real estate unit of the Equitable Companies, an insurance company based in New York, for $400 million. The deal would give Lend Lease, based in Sydney, Australia, about $35 billion in real estate assets under management. AXA Group of France owns 60.4 percent of Equitable. The unit that Lend Lease agreed to buy, Equitable Real Estate Investment Management Inc., has $25 billion in office and commercial property under management in the United States.

title: Welfare Cases Fall
description: New Jersey's welfare caseload fell more than 27 percent, to 256,000 from 350,000, in the last four years, according to a survey released yesterday.

title: Bennett Funding Executive in Guilty Plea
description: Kenneth P. Kasarjian was house proud -- so much so that his lavish home in Mahwah, N.J., was in a feature in Architectural Digest.

title: Wages May Be Heading Up, But Prices Hold Their Own
description: The people who work at the Wal-Marts, J. C. Penneys and Nordstroms of America are doing better lately. They received pay increases over the last year averaging more than 4 percent -- the sort of raises that have Wall Street ablaze with talk of coming inflation. But rather than increase prices, the nation's big retailers are finding other ways to get the money for those wage gains.

title: BERLIN COURT SAYS TOP IRAN LEADERS ORDERED KILLINGS
description: A court concluded here today that the highest levels of Iran's ''political leadership'' ordered the September 1992 killing of exiled Iranian Kurdish dissidents in Berlin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBBONS, PATRICK JOSEPH, JR.
description: GIBBONS-Patrick Joseph, Jr. Age 79, of Summit, NJ. Suddenly on April 8, 1997, in Captiva, Florida. Beloved husband of 50 years of Marie C. Gibbons. Loving father of Christine G. McKay and Patrick Joseph Gibbons III and father-inlaw of Joseph Kevin McKay and Jessica R. Gibbons. Devoted grandfather of Andrew and John McKay. Dear brother of Mary Louise Mullen, Margaret Young, Virginia Welsh and Barbara Wilson. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1940 and was a decorated paratrooper in the 82nd Airborne Division during WWII. He also served as Aide to General Douglas MacArthur from 1951 to 1952 and retired as a Lt. Col. USAR. He was for many years an officer and director of Despard & Co, insurance brokers, and retired as Senior VP of Fred S. James & Co. A mass will be held on Monday, April 14, 1997, at 10:30 AM, St. Theresa's R.C. Church, 306 Morris Avenue, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania, C/O Rememberance Program, 601 Franklin Bldg, 3451 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19104-6285.

title: Harlem Man Is Arrested In Beating Death of Child
description: A Harlem man was arrested yesterday in the beating death of his girlfriend's 3-year-old son in Brooklyn.

title: Longtime Councilman Won't Seek Re-election
description: Enoch H. Williams, one of the City Council's most senior members and the chairman of its Health Committee, said yesterday that he would not seek re-election this year.

title: Celebrity Visits Show What's Missing in City Schools
description: For his first act as Principal for a Day at Public School 70 in the Bronx, Donald J. Trump -- the Trump of the high-rolling hotels and chandelier-encrusted casinos -- gave a speech to an auditorium full of fifth graders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALE, REV. JAMES E.
description: DALE-Rev. James E. On April 9, 1997. Retired Priest. Dear uncle of Rosemary Hubbell, James E. Dale, Margaret Gildow and Catherine D'Agostino. Beloved brother-in-law of Mary E. Dale. Reposing Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM at Riverdale - on - Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave (W. 261 St, Bronx). Mass Christian Burial Saturday, 11AM at Saint Margaret of Cortona Church, 6000 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Marshall's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: It will be a quiet but sentimental celebration when ISABELLE STEVENSON, the president of the American Theater Wing, which presents the Tony Awards, and her husband, JOHN STEVENSON, a retired publisher, toast their 60th anniversary tonight.

title: Health Care Investment
description: Transworld Home Healthcare Inc. said today that Hyperion Partners II L.P. and its affiliate, Hyperion TW Fund L.P., had agreed to invest an additional $52.8 million in the company. The two firms bought a total of 5.4 million shares at $9.875 a share, the price of its stock the day the agreement was reached. Transworld shares rose 56.25 cents today, to $10.75. Transworld, based here, provides alternative-site health care services and products.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Silences of the Palace

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Parcells Won't Part Easily With Top Draft Pick
description: Bill Parcells had a warning today for any teams casting an eye toward the Jets' overall top draft choice. ''I'm not saying I'll do anything with this pick,'' Parcells said, ''but if I do, you'd better do what's right.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ARTHUR LUCE
description: KLEIN-Arthur Luce. Temple Israel of New Rochelle mourns the passing of its generous and participating member, Arthur Luce Klein, whose constant presence at our events, keen sense of social justice, and spirit of benevolence for our congregation and its work will always be remembered. May Luce and the family know that Arthur's reward will be great in the world to come. Jeffrey Stier, President Amiel Wohl, Senior Rabbi

title: Grumman Cuts Jobs In Long Island Office
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation, which employed 25,000 people on Long Island in the mid-1980's, continued its inexorable retreat from the regional economy yesterday, with the announcement that 445 workers -- all of them at the company's former headquarters in Bethpage -- would be laid off or relocated. The latest round of job cuts, when completed by 1999, will bring Grumman's job total down to only 2,700 people in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Store Sales Lack Luster, Though Discounters Thrive

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLOANE, HOWARD G.
description: SLOANE-Howard G. It is with deep regret and a profound sense of loss that the Officers, Board of Trustees, and staff of Old Sturbridge Village in Sturbridge, MA, mark the passing of Howard G. Sloane. As a past-Chairman of our Board, Howard played a crucial and important role for Old Sturbridge Village. Howard will be remembered as an exemplary volunteer leader for his vision, dedication, and philanthropic support. He made a difference in this world. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Virginia and the family. Alberta Sebolt George, Pres. Old Sturbridge Village

title: To Everything There Is a Season, and a Time for Every Fashion
description: AMONG the factors that cause fashions to change and develop, probably the least capricious is the weather. Year in and year out, the seasons ring in changes of attire, while climate has always had a great deal to say about sartorial style and invention. After all, the world doesn't have saris, boiled-wool jackets or cotton dusters because some fashion editor decided it should be so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, CAROLYN
description: MURPHY-Carolyn. On April 10th, 1997, of Bayside, NY. Devoted aunt of Joan Stoehr, Barbara Bankey, Frederick and Neil Murphy. Funeral Mass Sacred Heart Church, 38th Ave. at 216th Street, Bayside, Saturday, 9:45 AM. For further information, call Lloyd Funeral Home: 718-229-2420.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on March 24 about a new magazine on philanthropy, The American Benefactor, referred incorrectly to an article about Bette Midler in the magazine's first issue. It was a profile; she did not give the magazine an interview.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Steven Millhauser, winner of this year's Pulitzer Prize for fiction, misstated the surname of another finalist and misspelled her book's title. She is Joanna Scott, not Holt, and the book is ''The Manikin.''

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: 101 Dalmatians

title: Mann as Sounding Board
description: So many words, so much music. How do we fit them all together? ''The Musical World of Thomas Mann,'' presented by Da Camera of Houston at the Walter Reade Theater on Monday night, offered enlightened suggestions. Maybe solutions are not to be had.

title: Judge Rules Chicago Man Took Part in Nazi Crimes
description: A Federal judge today stripped United States citizenship from a retired machinist, saying that the man ''unquestionably participated in the massacre'' of hundreds of Jews at a Nazi labor camp in World War II.

title: $25 and Under
description: The demands of marriage can be unpredictable, particularly where restaurants are concerned. Take Adela and Jack Talanga, for instance.

title: Huston Puts Wild Finish on a Wild Day
description: It began with wailing and ended with laughter, this madcap, upside-down, two-days-in-one first round of the Masters. In the cold breeze of the morning there were chip shots sliding into water; in the fading light of afternoon there was a 5-iron shot holed for eagle on No. 18.

title: Hong Kong Democratic Party Faces Huge Question Mark: Its Future
description: As China signals its new vision for Hong Kong a society of shriveled civil liberties and an anemic political culture -- the opposition politicians who have most relentlessly opposed Beijing's plans for the territory now face their greatest challenge.

title: When Agents Change, Keeping Track of Records
description: When the operations of one Upper East Side co-op were turned over to a new managing agent a few years ago, the transfer was, according to Jim O'Connor, an executive at the new management company, ''chaotic beyond belief.'' The only records given to the new managers were a pile of invoices -- in a shopping bag.

title: When Techies Play Publisher
description: The trend seems ominous. American Cybercast, the producer of the Web soap opera site The Spot, has filed for bankruptcy protection. Out.com, the on-line version of Out magazine, has shut down for lack of advertising revenue. Politics Now, a joint venture of ABC News, National Journal and The Washington Post, which was one of the Net's busiest sites during the 1996 campaign, no longer exists. And late last month Netguide Live, an on-line Web directory that had nearly 200 employees at its peak, announced it is pulling the plug.

title: After Blockade, Rangers Find an Easy Path to the Goal
description: Trying to get even with the Rangers for delaying their practice early this week, the Flyers retaliated at New York's workout this morning with a Zamboni blockade. One of the ice-making machines stood, like a Sherman tank, in one of the goal creases.

title: Deep in the Primal Dunes
description: When Hiroshi Teshigahara's film ''Woman in the Dunes'' was first shown in 1964, cinematic modernism had reached high tide, and this richly metaphoric film was hailed as a bleak but compelling masterpiece. Those were the days when Samuel Beckett loomed over the artistic landscape as an austere, granite-faced father of atomic-age visions of a world reduced to a desert. And this black-and-white Japanese film, which opens a two-week run today at the Film Forum, is Beckettian to the core in its unblinking portrayal of human endeavor as so much scratching in the sand. Breathtakingly photographed, it is being presented in a newly subtitled, 35-millimeter print made directly from the original camera negative.

title: Don't Risk Okefenokee
description: To the Editor:

title: Intelligence Incompetence
description: It was an admission of breathtaking incompetence from the nation's top spy organization. On Wednesday the Central Intelligence Agency acknowledged that it had received information more than a decade ago, some of it quite solid, indicating that chemical weapons were being stored at an Iraqi depot later destroyed by American soldiers who were unaware of the dangers they faced. The tangle of errors and misjudgments that led the agency to ignore or downplay the evidence further erodes the C.I.A.'s reputation for professional expertise -- and raises the troubling question of whether the agency has been trying for some time to keep these miscues hidden from the public.

title: The Hit of the Reunion Is Just That: A Hit Man
description: ''Grosse Pointe Blank'' has the good idea to send a professional hit man to his high school reunion and the even better notion to make this high-concept story human. As played irresistibly by John Cusack, Martin Q. Blank is just one more overworked, stressed-out careerist who is forced to do some soul-searching when he re-encounters old friends. Simple premise, but Martin's line of work is good for funny idiosyncrasies. ''Don't tease me,'' he warns his wisecracking secretary, Marcella (Joan Cusack), as she goads him into going home. ''You know what I do for a living.''

title: Cirillo Leaving Garden Post
description: John Cirillo will leave as the senior vice president of communications at Madison Square Garden in two weeks.

title: No Break in Ties Expected Despite Policy Shift : EU Recalls Envoys as Iran Is Found Guilty of Terror
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union decided on a mass recall of ambassadors from Tehran on Thursday and suspended its so-called critical dialogue with Iran after a German court ruled that the Islamic regime had ordered the assassinations of four people in Berlin in 1992.

title: U.S. Program Helps Return Industry to Depressed Area
description: For three generations, an enormous Cadillac factory stretched across eight blocks on the southwest side of the Motor City, providing a path to the middle class for tens of thousands of workers. It closed a decade ago, becoming a vast, derelict monument to the decay of a great manufacturing center. The surrounding neighborhood deteriorated almost as fast as the weeds grew up around the factory. The only high-paying job nearby was drug dealing.

title: People Who Make Treadmills Go Nowhere
description: The 20-something blue-collar malcontents who rumble through Chris Kentis's film ''Grind'' are characters who could have sprung full-blown from a Bruce Springsteen ballad like ''Factory'' or ''Racing in the Street.'' Like those songs' brooding narrators, they are smart and sensitive enough to want something more out of life than a grueling factory job assembling treadmills. At the same time, they are trapped by family responsibilities and by a fatalistic sense that it is already too late to change life patterns that seem to have been set in stone.

title: Scared of Snakes, and Rightly So
description: From deep inside the scaly white throat of a voracious 40-foot snake, you can see the head of its human prey being inexorably sucked into the hot gaping mouth. This inside-the-beast view from the recesses of a monster's devouring gullet is the niftiest shot in Luis Llosa's ''Anaconda,'' a trashily entertaining reptilian version of ''Jaws'' set in the steaming heart of the Amazon rain forest.

title: KAYDON TO BUY MAKER OF CYLINDERS FOR $22 MILLION
description: The Kaydon Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Great Bend Industries, a subsidiary of the Hein-Werner Corporation, for $22 million. Kaydon said the subsidiary, which is based in Great Bend, Kan., makes hydraulic cylinders and had 1996 sales of about $20 million. Kaydon, which had 1996 sales of $290.1 million, said Great Bend Industries would be part of its Fluid Power group. Kaydon, of Clearwater, Fla., makes custom engineered products.

title: A Warning to Thieves: Right Key Is Needed
description: Car thieves, beware: increasingly concerned by high theft rates and escalating insurance premiums on their cars, auto makers are putting new and more potent weapons in their defensive arsenal. Realizing the futility of car alarms that are often ignored, the companies are installing devices that immobilize the car unless the correct key is used.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, HENRY
description: HOROWITZ-Henry. April 11, 1994. TO MY FATHER A giant pine, magnificent and old,/Stood staunch against the sky and all around/Shed beauty, grace, and power. Within its fold,/Birds safely reared their young. The velvet ground/Beneath was gently, and the cooling shade/Gave cheer to passers-by. Its towering arms /A landmark stood, erect and unafraid, /As if to say, ''Fear naught from life's alarms.''/It fell one day. Where it had dauntless stood/Was lonliness and void. But men who passed/Paid tribute-said, ''To know this life was good,/It left its mark on me. Its work stands fast.''/And so it lives. Such life no bonds can hold-/This giant pine, magnificent and old. In loving memory-always Linda and Family

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan gallery shows:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a decision to restrict civil liberties in Hong Kong misstated the date and authors of the so-called Basic Law that is to govern the territory after it reverts to Chinese control on July 1. The law was drafted in 1990 after discussions between Hong Kong groups and the Chinese Government -- not in 1984 after negotiations between China and Britain, the colonial power.

title: Ending Standoff, Giuliani Agrees to Allow Audits
description: Ending a rancorous two-week standoff, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed yesterday to allow auditors for State Comptroller H. Carl McCall back into New York City agencies. Mr. McCall in turn said he would change the guidelines for four audits that the Mayor had complained were politically motivated.

title: The Sun Over Hong Kong Sets on the British Navy
description: In crisp tropical whites, an officer stepped forward. ''The parade will retire!'' he shouted. ''Sound eight bells!''

title: G.O.P. Fights Bill to Offer A Health Plan For Children
description: Senate leaders are urging Republicans not to back a children's health insurance bill sponsored by Senators Orrin G. Hatch of Utah and Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, and one of the bill's original eight Republican supporters dropped off today.

title: Bruno, Threatened, Attacks Rent Groups
description: After two suspicious fires near one of his offices and a series of death threats, the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the leading proponent of abolishing rent regulations in New York, accused tenant organizers and Democrats today of creating an emotionally charged atmosphere that has placed him, his staff and his family in danger.

title: An Opening Without A Closing
description: THE World Series trophy was on display on the ground-floor level of Yankee Stadium yesterday, as was destiny's stepchild, Don Mattingly, to help raise the championship flag in Monument Park. Joe DiMaggio threw out the ceremonial first pitch that Joe Girardi did not drop. The sun was out, the air was crisp, Yankee Stadium was packed and David Cone was predictably pumped.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAHN, BERNARD
description: KAHN-Bernard. April 12, 1977. In loving memory. You are always in our hearts. Roberta, Nancy and Victor

title: Clinton Urges an Expanded U.S. Role in International Affairs
description: In the first wide-ranging foreign policy address of his second term, President Clinton today called on the United States to play a more active role in the world. He urged Congress to approve a treaty banning chemical weapons and to give him enhanced authority to reach a trade agreement with Chile.

title: Sharpton's Omission
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mob and the Markets
description: The dramatic decline in street crime has been applauded throughout New York City. No less impressive, however, has been the city's progress in combating organized crime in the Fulton Fish Market, the commercial garbage-collection industry and other mob-influenced places of business. The next step is for the City Council to adopt legislation to expand the city's ability to remove corrupt businesses and unions from all the big produce, meat and fish markets where kickbacks and extortion are endemic. Unfortunately, some labor leaders are opposing the legislation or trying to water it down. Council members should resist those efforts and pass the bill.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Plunges 148 Points; Market Loses Year's Gains

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, EVELYN
description: LEVY-Evelyn. Beloved and devoted mother of Adele Zimmerman and Howard Levy. Loving grandmother of Michael, Bobby, Joseph, Susan, Stewart and Carol. Beloved great grandmother of 13. Services Sunday, 12 noon, ''Parkside'' Chapels, Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: A Suburban Barrier Falls
description: The Mount Laurel Township Planning Board approved a rental complex of 140 town houses for low- and moderate-income families early yesterday. It was the latest step in a 26-year legal battle that turned the prosperous community into a national symbol of suburbs that used their zoning laws to exclude the poor.

title: AON SET TO PURCHASE LONDON-BASED MINET GROUP
description: The Aon Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the London-based Minet Group from the St. Paul Companies as it expands in the insurance brokerage business. For St. Paul, the agreement ends an almost six-month effort to sell the money-losing Minet, which specializes in arranging insurance coverage for accountants and other professionals. The undisclosed purchase price, which analysts estimate may be less than $100 million, is expected to have no ''material'' impact on Aon or St. Paul, Aon said. While Minet is unprofitable, buying it will give Chicago-based Aon access to key customers and allow for some cost cuts.

title: Army Trial Raises Questions Of Sex, Power and Discipline
description: In a small military courtroom, with lawyers and jurors dressed in crisp uniforms, an explosive court-martial is exposing the tension between sex and power that has come with the sexual integration of the American military.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARNER, PEARL
description: WARNER-Pearl, on April 11, 1997 in Needham, MA. Formerly of Westbury, Long Island. Beloved wife of the late David. Devoted mother of Robert and the late Joseph. Loving mother-in-law of Linda. Cherished grandmother of Sarah. Services Sunday 10 A.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island. In lieu of flowers or other gifts kindly direct all contributions to Stanley R. Tippett House, 920 South Street, Needham, MA. 02192.

title: Let Public Housing Encourage Hard Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRASSO, MARY
description: GRASSO-Mary. Its been a long eleven years; and we miss you and love you. Linda, Donald, Tommy, Patrick

title: Guardians of the Green Cards
description: Item: In cities with large immigrant populations, couples flooded municipal offices for marriage licenses. Experts believed that this trend was driven by concern about changes to the Federal immigration law, which took effect on April 1.

title: Of Tosh, and Tally-Ho!
description: Advocates of fox hunting in Britain have given a novel twist to an old dispute about blood sports. Faced with a May 1 election that the Labor Party is favored to win, they have formed a Union of Country Sports Workers to represent as many as 90,000 people, from grooms to gamekeepers, who stand to lose if the Laborites push for a vote to ban fox hunting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIENER, GABE
description: WIENER-Gabe. Class of '84 at The Day School. Gabe exemplified all that we hold important. He was raised to pursue excellence in all things, by parents who nurtured his love of ideas, and delighted in his enthusiasm for the intellect. His warm heartedness, the encouragement and support he gave to others and his creative spirit will always be cherished by us. The Wiener family and their love and respect for each other have served as a model to all of us. You have good reason to be proud, Mike and Zena, and our hearts ache with you and Jenny. Jack Dexter, Head of School Alexandra Peters, President, Board of Trustees

title: Devils Can Turn Their Attention to Flyers
description: The Devils could not be blamed tonight for looking ahead to Sunday's regular-season finale with the Philadelphia Flyers, which could determine first place in the Eastern Conference playoff standing. At times they played down to the level of the Boston Bruins, who will not be in the Stanley Cup playoffs for the first time since 1967. Still, the result was not surprising.

title: TV News Violence Harms Children, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Moves To Assume Control Of Hartford Schools
description: Gov. John G. Rowland and state lawmakers have agreed to take over this city's troubled school system, dissolving a local school board for the first time in state history and replacing it with a panel of state-appointed trustees.

title: Dollar Gains Against Mark And Yen, but Falls vs. Pound
description: The dollar generally rose yesterday, after a Japanese official said efforts to bolster the yen by selling dollars would have little effect and a Bank of France council member raised concern that Europe's proposed single currency would be weaker than the mark.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Basketball

title: Cold Spares Most Crops
description: The near-record cold temperatures of the last few nights may have caused slight damage to southern New Jersey's peach trees, which are in full bloom, but other crops appear to have been spared, agricultural officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about retailers' results for March referred incorrectly to Saks Fifth Avenue's sales at stores open at least a year. The 1.5 percent change was an increase, not a decline.

title: Truck Tests Planned
description: New Jersey has about 270,000 trucks weighing more than 26,000 pounds, and almost all of them use diesel fuel. Starting this summer, these trucks and any buses that run on diesel fuel will have to undergo annual emissions tests.

title: Knicks Pay Riley a Visit In Search of Confidence
description: The Knicks flew to Miami tonight to play a final regular-season game against their former coach on Saturday. Two years removed from the New York landscape, Pat Riley will see familiar faces and familiar themes on the opposing bench.

title: Aaron Kramer, Poet And Translator, 75
description: Aaron Kramer, a poet and translator, died on Monday at his Long Island home. He was 75.

title: John F. Walsh Is Dead at 93; Top Police Commander in 60's
description: John Francis Walsh, who served through turbulent times and four New York City police commissioners as the department's top uniformed commander in the 1960's, died on Thursday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. A longtime resident of Whitestone, Queens, he was 93 and and had recently moved to Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Ambulance Hits and Kills Woman, 63, in the Bronx
description: An ambulance struck and killed a 63-year-old woman yesterday evening when she stepped out into a Bronx street from between two parked cars, apparently without noticing the flashing lights and the sirens, the emergency medical service said.

title: Easier, Fairer Taxes
description: Tax season is upon us, and the President and the Republicans are talking about child tax credits, education tax credits, expanded I.R.A.'s and capital gains tax cuts. We've come a long way from last year's calls for a flat tax and other radical simplifications.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: NO SYMPATHY -- At the Parking Violations Bureau, there was a chorus of boos for diplomats fighting to keep their immunity from parking violations. Page 23.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JANET C.
description: GREENE-Janet C. Mrs. Stephen (Janet) Greene died peacefully April 10 at home. Writer, editor, co-owner of Stephen Greene Publishing. She leaves her daughters Jennifer Greene and Stephanie Greene Brooks, grandchildren Isaac & Graham Brooks. Funeral April 14 at St. Mary's In The Mountains Episcopal Church, Wilmington, VT, 2PM. Memorials to West Dover or East Dover Ladies Aid Society in care of Covey & Allen Funeral Home, 44 East Main Street, Wilmington, VT. 05363.

title: Back on the Bus for Whitman
description: Four years ago, with the gubernatorial election only two weeks away, Christine Todd Whitman was trailing her opponent, Gov. Jim Florio, when she embarked on a bus tour around the state.

title: SARA LEE TO ACQUIRE BAKERY BUSINESS IN EUROPE
description: Entering the bakery business in continental Europe, the Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the European baker Brossard from Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. The companies did not disclose the purchase price. People close to the negotiations said Sara Lee would pay $:20 million to $:30 million, or $32.5 million to $48.7 million. British newspapers reported the figure might be as much as $113.6 million, but that figure was later described as too high.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIBBONS, PATRICK JOSEPH, JR.
description: GIBBONS-Patrick Joseph, Jr. Age 79, of Summit, NJ. Suddenly on April 8, 1997, in Captiva, Florida. Beloved husband of 50 years of Marie C. Gibbons. Loving father of Christine G. McKay and Patrick Joseph Gibbons III and father-inlaw of Joseph Kevin McKay and Jessica R. Gibbons. Devoted grandfather of Andrew and John McKay. Dear brother of Mary Louise Mullen, Margaret Young, Virginia Welsh and Barbara Wilson. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, Class of 1940 and was a decorated paratrooper in the 82nd Airborne Division during WWII. He also served as Aide to General Douglas MacArthur from 1951 to 1952 and retired as a Lt. Col. USAR. He was for many years an officer and director of Despard & Co, insurance brokers, and retired as Senior VP of Fred S. James & Co. A mass will be held on Monday, April 14, 1997, at 10:30 AM, St. Theresa's R.C. Church, 306 Morris Avenue, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania, C/O Rememberance Program, 601 Franklin Bldg, 3451 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA. 19104-6285.

title: EXPANSION INTO VARIOUS AVIATION SERVICES SOUGHT
description: The Boeing Company, traditionally just an aircraft manufacturer, is more aggressively seeking work in airline maintenance and other aviation services. In January, the plane maker created a unit, Boeing Enterprises, to pursue new opportunities in aviation-related businesses. The move comes as major airlines like British Airways consider spinning off their maintenance units to outside investors. The business could be worth billions of dollars in revenue over five years to the Seattle-based plane maker, according to The Wall Street Journal, which reported yesterday on the unit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVIGNA, DINA
description: LaVIGNA-Dina. Age 33, Thursday, April 10, 1997. Adored bride of Jeff Schmitt. Loving mother of Zachary. Cherished daughter of Gary and Brenda. Precious sister to Bill, David, Ayndrea and Grant. Beloved granddaughter of Carlota Pires & Betty Jossen. A big jewel in a little package, you lived life to the fullest; bringing love, beauty, candor and laughter to all our lives. Gutsy and feisty, vibrant, caring and motivated, you are an inspiration who will be terribly missed but never forgotten by your family and ever reaching circle of friends. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to: The Jeffrey Modell Foundation, The Dina LaVigna Breath of Life Fund, 43 W. 47 St. NY 10036, or The Gift of Life Transplant Donor Program of Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, in memory of Dina LaVigna, 622 West 168 St, NY, NY 10023. Services, Memorial Mass Saturday, April 12, 1997, at the Holy Name of Jesus R.C. Church, 1 P.M. West 96 St. and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Du Pont Delays Its Plans To Mine Near a Refuge
description: If government officials and environmental groups remain opposed, the Du Pont Company ''will not go forward'' with plans to mine titanium just outside the Okefenokee National Wildlife Refuge in southeast Georgia, a company official said today.

title: VW Shares Up Again On Earnings Report
description: The shares of Volkswagen A.G. reached record highs again yesterday as details on 1996 earnings published on Thursday showed that the company was more profitable than investors had thought. VW's earnings climbed to 55 marks ($32) a share in 1996 from 22 marks, much higher than analysts' forecasts.

title: Prosecutor Dismisses Charge Against Reporter at Procession
description: At the request of the Police Department, the Brooklyn District Attorney yesterday dismissed a disorderly conduct charge against a freelance reporter who was arrested last month while covering the funeral procession of the slain rapper Christopher G. Wallace for The New York Times.

title: The Latest Coming Attraction: Movie House in East New York
description: Residents of East New York, Brooklyn, who are still waiting for a major supermarket to take root in their poor neighborhood, may at least be able to walk to the movies by the end of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASSER, EVELINE
description: NASSER-Eveline. The officers and members of the Board of Directors of Harvard-Radcliffe Hillel note with sadness the passing of Eveline Nasser, sister of Edmond (and Lily) Safra, and Moise (and Chella) Safra. Our deepest condolences to the entire Safra, Nasser and Kassin families. Carl Sloane, Chairman Prudence L. Steiner, President Bernard Steinberg, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, SHELDON WOLF
description: BERGER-Sheldon Wolf. Passed away Kiriat Gat, Israel. Formerly of New York City and Wingdale, NY. Artist, tinkerer, teacher, friend. Beloved son of the late Fannie and Isidor Berger. Beloved brother of Bessie Kosstrin and the late Archie Kosstrin. Cherished uncle of Emily Mann (Sam), Herbert Kosstrin (Judy), Jane Kosstrin-Yurick (Charles). Graveside service Sunday April 13 11am Mt Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENICK, SYLVIA
description: RENICK-Sylvia. We mourn the loss of our esteemed member and extend heartfelt condolences to her family. Temple Israel of Great Neck Eileen Putterman, President

title: France to Halve Its Stake in Bull
description: France said yesterday that it would sell 18 million shares of Compagnie des Machines Bull beginning on Monday, nearly halving its stake in Bull, France's biggest computer maker, to 17 percent. The state currently holds 47.7 million shares in Bull, or 30.5 percent of its equity, the largest shareholding. After the sale, it will no longer be the largest shareholder in Bull, which it took over in 1982. Motorola Inc., the NEC Corporation of Japan and France Telecom each have 18.7 percent.

title: Pilot Grew Up on Long Island With a Flier's Dream
description: The pilot of the Air Force warplane that vanished in the Colorado Rockies 10 days ago is, by his Long Island family's account, a straight arrow: passionate for flying, dedicated to his career, preparing for an assignment in Europe next summer, a stable man who did not appear to be under any unusual stress.

title: Party-Crashing A's Show Yanks It's a New Season
description: The gorgeous afternoon at Yankee Stadium started with a surprise guest, Don Mattingly, helping to hoist a championship flag. It continued with the always surprising David Cone pitching an amazing seven innings and holding a 1-0 lead, then it took a surprising detour when Mariano Rivera mishandled another save chance and allowed a monstrous 464-foot homer to Mark McGwire in the ninth. It concluded with catcher Joe Girardi surprisingly botching a throw home that helped the Oakland Athletics pilfer a 3-1 triumph in 12 aggravating innings.

title: Bullets Get Boost From Nets
description: The Bullets needed to win tonight. The Nets needed just to show up, but even that gave them trouble.

title: Woods, in Front, Recalls Images of Old
description: His father sat underneath the big oak tree outside the manor clubhouse today when Tiger Woods strolled past, on his way out for the second round of the Masters. Earl Woods waved to his son and told him, ''Just do what you do.''

title: An Old Tingler With a New Tone of Its Own
description: ''It's no use, is it?'' the sinister housekeeper Mrs. Danvers whispers to the naive, second Mrs. de Winter, warning this famously unnamed heroine that she will never usurp the place of the dead Rebecca as mistress of Manderley. ''She'll always be the real Mrs. de Winter,'' Mrs. Danvers hisses.

title: The Masters in Their Element
description: There is a sort of fashion Mount Olympus where designers who survived the onslaught of wave after wave of iconoclastic demigods can quietly reign supreme over their true believers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, VINCENT
description: LYNCH-Vincent. A leader in political and humanitarian work for NYC School Employees Local 372. Died April 8, at age 66. Mr. Lynch was born into a prominent political family in Jamaica, W.I., on Christmas Day, 1930. His father Leopold was a leader in the Labor Party, a member of Parliament for 36 years and Minister of local government. Vincent was an outstanding student at Oliver Park School and Titchfield High in Port Antonio. He started as a School Aide for the NYC Board of Ed. in 1974 and worked at IS 195 in Harlem for two decades. In addition to his job at the school store, he served as an advisor and ''father figure'' for thousands of students. His co-workers elected him Shop Steward, and his dedicated union work led to key assignments in the 23,000-member Local 372, which is part of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County & Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO. Mr. Lynch chaired the Political Action Committee of the Local which operates computerized telephone and puts hundreds of volunteers into the field in election campaigns and is well known as a powerhouse in city politics. He served as 2nd Vice President of Local 372 for many years, and represented the Union on disaster relief missions and at conferences in Africa, Israel and throughout the Caribbean region and the U.S. Beyond his official duties, he was a close friend and advisor to Local President Charles Hughes. ''He gave me and the entire Union the benefit of his insight and judgement without fear or favor,'' said Hughes ''more than an officer, more than a friend, Vincent was like a brother to me. The Union will never be able to replace his strength of character, his warmth and wit and his loving sparkling smile.'' As an immigrant himself, Lynch was particularly proud that he was named to chair DC 37's Citizenship Committee which set up the Union's Citizenship Program with the unanimous backing of the DC 37 Executive Board. In 1996, its first year, the program helped more than 1000 union members exchange their green cards for full citizenship in the U.S.A. Mr. Lynch is survived by his wife Audrey and children Sadia, Dominic, Yvonne and Amy. Interment will be in Jamaica, W.I. A memorial service will be held Monday, April 14, at 6:00 PM at The Cathedral Church of St. John The Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Ave., at 112 St. in NYC. Charles Hughes, President Local 372

title: Expert Panels
description: Deborah Berke is the godmother of the everyday and the ''dumb,'' as she loves to say, in architecture today. Not surprisingly, the clientele for her ascetic brand of elegance has a downtown New York air. The list includes artists -- Peter Halley and William Wegman -- the creative director Fabien Baron and the boutiques for Calvin Klein's CK line. Berke was therefore surprised when Frederick Kantor, an accountant, and Barbara Kaplan, a retail advertising executive, asked her to renovate their apartment in a prewar Central Park West building in Manhattan. Berke describes it as one of her ''fancier'' jobs, mainly because there are traditional rooms, wall-to-wall carpeting and painted plywood as opposed to the open-loft spaces, bare floors and exposed plywood of some of her other projects. But even the painted plywood in this apartment has Berke's esthetic written all over it. Her clients wanted a paneled study, but traditional wood paneling was not in the budget. Berke's ingenious solution was to take standard 4-by-8-foot plywood sheets, cut them into narrow widths to elongate their proportions and paint the panels a warm shade of ''not white,''' as she calls it. The result is the kind of chic that knows no price. P.V.

title: BLAST PAST
description: 1. April 16 will be the 50th anniversary of the nation's worst industrial disaster, when 2,300 tons of ammonium nitrate exploded aboard the ship Grandcamp, docked at Texas City, Tex. 2. The toll was ghastly: nearly 600 people died, 3,000 were injured and 1,000 buildings were destroyed. 3. Meriworth Mabry, a retired Texas City teacher, has collected hundreds of first-person tales from survivors. 4. Not all are grisly. J. J. Trotter, a longshoreman, says he heard a crack and a roar, and then ''I was flying end over end.'' 5. But most are. One family was able to identify its father, six weeks later, only by his work pants. 6. I myself was about to exit when Gass shamed me into staying by shouting from the stage, ''For culture, you must suffer!'' A few of us actually dropped back into our seats; suffer we did.

title: Netanyahu Pays a Visit

title: The One and Only
description: What book could do justice to Cary Grant, the movie star who personified romance, sophistication and gentlemanly grace? In most ways, Graham McCann's well-researched CARY GRANT: A Class Apart (Columbia University, $24.95) does, and gratifyingly well. Grant's 72 movies illuminate the delectable, self-made style that was his and his alone. ''Nobody talked like that,'' Mr. McCann writes, ''not even Archie Leach in earlier years.'' Archibald Alexander Leach, born in Bristol, England, on Jan. 18, 1904, was a child for whom the good times ended early: one day the 9-year-old boy came home to find his beloved mother gone. His alcoholic father, a tailor's presser, had secretly committed her to a local asylum. Elsie Leach languished in the filthy, negligibly supervised asylum for nearly 25 years. It wasn't until her husband died that her son, by then 32 years old and a movie star, was alerted to her existence. Grant, a reserved, hard-working perfectionist who easily won the love and respect of friends and colleagues, lived by his own credo that ''it takes 500 small details to add up to one favorable impression,'' and was apparently no picnic for wives and lovers, who ultimately discovered the devil in his details. But at least three women in his life found him just perfect: his mother, to whom Grant was devoted after their reunion until she died in 1973, shortly before her 96th birthday; Jennifer Grant, his daughter; and his fifth wife, Barbara Harris. For the rest of the world, as the critic Pauline Kael noted, ''It makes us happy just to look at him.'' There are pictures galore in Geoffrey Wansell's CARY GRANT: Dark Angel (Arcade, $29.95), but the text is superficial. Mr. Wansell faults his 1984 biography of Grant, ''Haunted Idol,'' because ''it brought the dark side of his character to life, certainly, but did not quite balance it with proper tribute to his incandescent screen presence.'' Perhaps a third one will be the charm. Andrea Higbie

title: CURTAIN UP
description: After designing several traditional houses in that epitome of neo-traditional towns -- Seaside, Fla. -- the architect Alexander Gorlin designed a house there for himself and his wife, Debra Solomon, a cartoonist and film maker. But Gorlin's own house is a modernist, cubelike structure, and, as he says, ''the modernist's dream is a wall of glass.'' Alas, the dream began to pall slightly. ''I felt the room looked a little bare,'' Gorlin explains, ''and my wife thought it was too cold.'' So Gorlin decided that curtains were the answer, but it was Carl D'Aquino, who had originally decorated the house, who suggested white parachute cloth as the fabric. Its light weight was a key, since the windows are nearly 20 feet tall. And its relative sheerness gives the curtains a diaphanous quality that changes the room without compromising its clean lines. For those architects who cringe at the idea of curtains, Gorlin is quick to note that the modernist deity Le Corbusier used them in many of his houses. Case -- or should we say curtain -- closed.

title: A One-Price Jaunt To Jamaica
description: JUST east of Ocho Rios, about a half dozen resorts line the north shore of Jamaica like beached cruise ships. Each has its own manicured grounds, activity board, perfect scallop of sand, guarded front gate and perfumy name -- Ciboney, Sandals, Sans Souci. Many sprang up after Hurricane Gilbert ravaged Jamaica's gold coast in 1988, and specialize in a kind of Caribbean vacation I've long wanted to try: the all-inclusive package, providing round-trip plane tickets, van transfers from the airport in Montego Bay to Ocho Rios (taking about two hours each way), accommodations, meals, drinks from the bar, water sports, tips and tax. At some, you can even get a free wedding if you bring the right person and check in for at least five days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYNCH, VINCENT
description: LYNCH-Vincent. A leader in political and humanitarian work for NYC School Employees Local 372. Died April 8, at age 66. Mr. Lynch was born into a prominent political family in Jamaica, W.I., on Christmas Day, 1930. His father Leopold was a leader in the Labor Party, a member of Parliament for 36 years and Minister of local government. Vincent was an outstanding student at Oliver Park School and Titchfield High in Port Antonio. He started as a School Aide for the NYC Board of Ed. in 1974 and worked at IS 195 in Harlem for two decades. In addition to his job at the school store, he served as an advisor and ''father figure'' for thousands of students. His co-workers elected him Shop Steward, and his dedicated union work led to key assignments in the 23,000-member Local 372, which is part of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County & Municipal Employees, AFL-CIO. Mr. Lynch chaired the Political Action Committee of the Local which operates computerized telephone and puts hundreds of volunteers into the field in election campaigns and is well known as a powerhouse in city politics. He served as 2nd Vice President of Local 372 for many years, and represented the Union on disaster relief missions and at conferences in Africa, Israel and throughout the Caribbean region and the U.S. Beyond his official duties, he was a close friend and advisor to Local President Charles Hughes. ''He gave me and the entire Union the benefit of his insight and judgement without fear or favor,'' said Hughes ''more than an officer, more than a friend, Vincent was like a brother to me. The Union will never be able to replace his strength of character, his warmth and wit and his loving sparkling smile.'' As an immigrant himself, Lynch was particularly proud that he was named to chair DC 37's Citizenship Committee which set up the Union's Citizenship Program with the unanimous backing of the DC 37 Executive Board. In 1996, its first year, the program helped more than 1000 union members exchange their green cards for full citizenship in the U.S.A. Mr. Lynch is survived by his wife Audrey and children Sadia, Dominic, Yvonne and Amy. Interment will be in Jamaica, W.I. A memorial service will be held Monday, April 14, at 6:00 PM at The Cathedral Church of St. John The Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Ave., at 112 St. in NYC. Charles Hughes, President Local 372
