description: In the most tasteless remark of her First Ladyship, Hillary Clinton asserted that the investigation into hush money purportedly paid her former partner Webster Hubbell ''reminds me of some people's obsession with U.F.O.'s and the Hale-Bopp comet.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVIGNA, DINA
description: LaVIGNA-Dina. The Jeffrey Modell Foundation expresses its profound sorrow at the loss of our dear and precious friend, Dina. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband Jeffrey, son Zachary, parents and family. Vicki and Fred Modell Co-Founders The Jeffrey Modell Foundation

title: ACCORD TO COMBAT SWEATSHOP LABOR FACES OBSTACLES
description: With President Clinton and leaders of the apparel industry set to announce a code of conduct on Monday to combat sweatshops worldwide, members of the Administration's anti-sweatshop task force say the success of the effort could turn on issues like what the minimum level of factory pay should be and how much consumers should be told when factories violate the code.

title: A Hotel Revival on the Coast of New Hampshire
description: HOTEL construction, long dormant in New Hampshire, is beginning to revive on the seacoast.

title: Turkey's Passionate Interpreter to the World
description: THIS IS THE TURKEY OF THE photographer Ara Guler: A confused child peers from behind decaying tombstones inscribed with ornate Arabic script. Laborers unload hulking freighters. Couples walk down foggy streets lined with old wooden houses. Men gaze out over their drinks or contemplate rugged landscapes. Autos jam broad avenues. Horses pull carts up snowy hillsides. And Muslim worshipers bow in prayer by the hundreds.

title: Elen Ivorian-Jones, Arthur Rogers 3d
description: Elen Ivorian-Jones and Arthur Merriam Rogers 3d, lawyers in Boston, were married on Tuesday in Harare, Zimbabwe. The Rev. Nicholas Crawley performed the ceremony at the Anglican Church of St. Mary Magdalene.

title: More About Moving Used Nuclear Fuel
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Hardy, Brenton Carey
description: Elizabeth Hickok Hardy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodney D. Hardy of Edina, Minn., was married yesterday to Brenton Henderson Carey, the son of Phyllis Henderson Carey of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Frank L. Carey Jr. The Rev. Dean Wolfe performed the Episcopal ceremony at Trinity Church in Boston.

title: A Victory, Perhaps Brief, On Garbage
description: It may be a fleeting moment, but for now northern Brooklyn's fear that it was destined to become the city's garbage Dumpster has been eased a bit.

title: De La Hoya Beats Whitaker by Decision to Capture Title
description: Oscar De La Hoya's latest infomercial was not suitable for all audiences. He walked into the ring wearing mousse, but left it with a mouse under his right cheek, not to mention a left nostril that trickled blood. He had just had his first visit from a moving target, Pernell Whitaker, and he found out that moving targets hit back.

title: The Look of New York's Gilded Age
description: The concourse of the vanished Pennsylvania Station reminds David Garrard Lowe of ''an airy, traditional design with memories of Greece, Rome and Paris.''

title: Program Helped Westighouse Finalist
description: ONE way to measure improved scientific training in the classroom is seeing how students fare in national competitions like the Westinghouse Science Talent Search. Although such contests are not the only measure of students' scientific prowess, they reflect the opportunities schools offer for performing scientific research.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ENCHANTRESS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, CHARLES H.
description: HARRISON-Charles H. on April 7, 1997, of Manhasset, NY. Former executive with IBM Corporate Headquarters in NYC from 1929-1971. Beloved husband of Helen. Loving father of Charles, Jean and James. Cherished grandfather of Kimberly, Karin, and Jessica.

title: Singing a Zoo's Praises
description: ''THE ANIMALS OF POPCORN ZOO PARK,'' a musical recording produced by the Associated Human Societies. The songs tell the stories of animals who ended up at the zoo, at Forked River in Ocean County, which is a sanctuary for abused, exploited and unwanted wildlife, exotic pets and farm animals. Grace Davis wrote the lyrics, David Dowalski wrote the music and Beth Lawrence sings the songs on the recording. Cassettes cost $9.95 and CD's are $13.95; the price includes two passes to the zoo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUNLAEVY, EDGAR PARKER
description: DUNLAEVY-Edgar Parker. Retired President of Phelps Dodge Industries and avid sailor. Of Mill Neck, L.I. On April 11, 1997. Age 95. Beloved husband of the late Marie. Father of Erik, Anne Glenn & Michael. Grandfather of Larry, D'Arcy, Henrik, Allison, Kirsten and Courtney. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Gertrude R.C. Church Bayville, Monday, April 14, 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, a donation may be made to Oyster Bay Sailing Foundation, POB 720, Oyster Bay, New York 11771.

title: Shootings and Harsh Weather Take a Toll
description: As spring unfolds across Yellowstone National Park, biologists calculate that less than half of the park's bison population survived the winter, the herd's worst since 1902, the year that Congress ordered Yellowstone to rescue bison from extinction.

title: The Supper Club
description: Entertainment angst: it came on in the 90's like a contagion. People who had been giving dinner parties and formal lunches for decades -- those who had mastered minceur and nouvelle and even Tex-Mex and Thai, who knew what to do with infused oils and lemongrass -- all these people realized like a bolt that for them the joy had gone out of cooking for company.

title: Residents Want to Trade Methadone Clinics for More Business
description: For nearly 30 years, the methadone clinics run by Beth Israel Hospital on 125th Street near Park Avenue have served tens of thousands of addicts. But almost since the day the clinics opened, residents have viewed them as a source of trouble and have fought to have them relocated.

title: A Maritime Mystery That Never Rests
description: THE Titanic in its day was the largest and most luxurious ship afloat, a glittering icon of the good life rich in crystal and mahogany, champagne and foie gras, pearls and black ties. The story of her inaugural voyage in 1912 is deservedly famous. Carrying about 2,220 people (including a number of prominent socialites and industrialists), the giant ship steamed westward across the cold Atlantic and near midnight on Sunday, April 14th, off Newfoundland, struck a mountain of ice while moving at a speed of more than 20 knots. A little more than two and a half hours later, the monument to opulence sank beneath the waves. More than 1,500 lives were lost. At the time, it was history's greatest disaster at sea.

title: Betsy Rosenblum, R.D. Buchband
description: Betsy D. Rosenblum, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Rosenblum of Tucson, Ariz., was married there last evening to Richard D. Buchband, a son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Peter Buchband of Glen Head, L.I. Rabbi Tom Loucheim officiated at the Lodge at Ventana Canyon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUCHKOFF, THEODORE HERTZL
description: PUCHKOFF - Theodore Hertzl. Age 89. With saddened hearts, his family, son David and daughter-inlaw Eileen, son Jerome, grandchildren Carrie, Adam and granddaughter-in-law Paola, their mother Anne, granddaughter Maya, nieces Sylvia and June, sister and brother-in-law Pearl and Jack, companion and friend Lillian, all mourn their loss and will always remember his unique, distinguished character, his unfailing humor and sensitive personalityrest in peace with Toby. Services Sunday, April 13th, 11AM, Eternal Light Memorial Gardens, Boynton Beach, FL. 800-772-5983.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLENDER, STANLEY B.
description: HOLLENDER-Stanley B., died April 10th, in St. Louis, MO. Beloved husband of Paula of Boynton Beach, FL. Father of Erika Harder and Andrea Schwartz of Chesterfield, MO. Brother of Eddie of New Brunswick, NJ. Memorial services April 16, at Riverside Gordon, Delray Chapel, Delray, FL.

title: Corrections
description: A book review on March 16 about ''Inside the Kaisha: Demystifying Japanese Business Behavior,'' by Noboru Yoshimura and Philip Anderson, included the book's misstatement of the ''slogan of the year'' of Shiseido, a cosmetics maker. The actual slogan is ''Celebrate the past. But embrace the future with change,'' not ''For beautiful human life.''

title: 'Literature' Bores Me
description: James Atlas certainly has earned his standing as one of the leading figures in the mass market lit-crit business. So at first I thought his article 'Literature' Bores Me'' (March 16) was written at a level of irony too advanced and subtle for this reader. Or is he serious? Was it a joke to describe his shelved books waiting for ''their moment in the sun of my attention,'' or simply an inflated sense of his own importance?

title: Torre Has Kind Words For Rivera
description: If the current shuffling in the Yankee bullpen eventually achieves the same success this year as the Yankees had last season, the words of reassurance Mariano Rivera heard yesterday may soon have the feel of a marketing campaign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARREAU, MARGARET E.
description: CARREAU-Margaret E., of Oxford, MD. A musician and composer of nine published songs, was associated with Irving Berlin's Music Box Revue and later accompanied John Charles Thomas and Grace Moore. Died peacefully at 98 on April 4, 1997 in Easton. Beloved wife of Robert, caring mother of Patricia and Jane, and touchstone to all who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIPELES, PAULINE
description: LIPELES-Pauline, April 11, 1997. Beloved widow of David Lipeles, mother of Maxine, Ramie and Bonnie, grandmother of Rachel, Evan, Joshua, Lexi, Benjamin and Noah, sister of Marvin Cooper, and fiancee of Allen Post. Services Sunday, April 13, 12 noon, Sunset Chapel, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, 516-482-3600.

title: A Good Word for a Bad Thing
description: IT won't be so bad . . . O.K., maybe it will. But when the stock market takes a serious, sustained tumble -- which it has been threatening to do -- there will be some benefits.

title: Some Advice on Building Homes in the Pine Barrens
description: The Pine Barrens cover more than a million acres of land in seven southern New Jersey counties. It is ''the largest tract of open space on the mid-Atlantic coast,'' according to a booklet recently published by the Pinelands Commission.

title: Inconspicuous Consumption
description: IN ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN TODAY, less is more again. Houses, rooms and furnishings are less ornate, less complicated and less ostentatious than they were 10 years ago. Rather than putting their money on display, people seem to be investing in a quieter brand of luxury, based on comfort and quality.

title: Painful Memories
description: To the Editor: Lawrence Block's excellent storytelling in ''The Bumpy Road to Inspiration'' (March 9) evoked a painful memory, but for reasons unrelated to the subject matter of the article.

title: New Stairwells for Renovated Subway Station Have Tempers Climbing
description: Cutting back on the congestion at the subway station at 14th Street and Eighth Avenue, where the busy A, C, E and L lines intersect, was never going to be easy. But two years into the four-year project, store owners and residents charge that the renovation is hurting business and encouraging crime.

title: Talkative Young Man, An Elderly Couple
description: A CURIOUS play, ''The Size of the World,'' made its first appearance in 1991, near the end of the Yale Repertory Winterfest series of plays in progress.

title: Oval Offices, by Way of Hollywood
description: NEED A 747 AIRPLANE INTERIOR, a roadside diner, a New York street scene? No problem. Most studios keep such generic sets on hand. But what if a director needs something more specific, say, a semicircular room with a big desk in front of three large windows, a rug with the Presidential seal, a Frederic Remington reproduction of a man on a horse, bookshelf alcoves with fancy woodwork and a big American flag -- in other words, an Oval Office?

title: Music Reconceived as Acoustical Sculpture
description: Correction Appended

title: A Seamy Side of Augusta's Big Event
description: STRESS at the Masters has always seemed confined to the golfers. Hitting their drive in the fairway. Lofting an approach shot near the hole. Trying to make a putt.

title: The Stealth Governor Gets His Way
description: I suppose I should be relieved to learn that the Governor of New York State isn't a bumbling doofus who can't string two articulate sentences together. Instead, as your article clarifies, he's a calculating and relentless political shark with a fiercely conservative political agenda, little regard for society's vulnerable and poor and aspirations for the White House.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer entry error, the performance tables in the Mutual Funds Quarterly section last Sunday carried incorrect listings for several fund categories. An updated Weekly Performance table and a corrected Quarterly Performance table appear today on page 13.

title: Standing By With Answers To Those Last-Minute Questions
description: Last-minute questions about your Homestead Rebate? Still trying to figure out if you qualify for the new property tax deduction? The state has extended the hours of its tax hot line and its seven walk-in taxpayer assistance offices for the last two days of the season. The hot line and the offices will be staffed from 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday and 8:30 A.M. to 7 P.M. Tuesday, April 15.

title: At Meeting, G.O.P. Chiefs Vow to Move On Agenda
description: Like the cavalry riding to the rescue, Congressional Republicans descended on a meeting of state party officials here today and Friday to reassure them that they are more organized and energetic than they may appear.

title: One of Merrick's Most Loyal Daughters
description: ON the cement sidewalk in front of a high-ranch house in Merrick lies a pyramid of green squares with the Nos. 8 and 7 clearly visible. It is what is left of a hopscotch board. That anything is left says a great deal about its creator.

title: Everest, 1997: There They Go Again
description: A year ago next month, 11 people died on Mount Everest, a tragedy that prompted national debate over whether anyone but experienced mountaineers belongs up there. And what was learned? ''Lessons?'' asks Todd Burleson, a 1996 Everest guide who is returning this year. ''Climbing is like riding airplanes. You feel bad when disaster strikes, but you get back on. Others must agree: professional mountain guides have done almost nothing about ''reform.'' Meanwhile, Everest is red hot, as a goal, a media property, a style thing. Here's a look.

title: A Burst of New Office Space Foreseen in Fairfield
description: BROKERS here say that some 2 million square feet of office space could rise within two and a half years on five prime sites that are either near development or under negotiation for development.

title: That Sinking Feeling
description: Tomorrow night, exactly 85 years after 2,200 or so passengers and crew did the same, some 100 diners will pay $79 each to eat ''the last dinner on the Titanic,'' as scrupulously recreated by the Halcyon restaurant in New York. Titanic buffs are flying in from all over for the feast, which sold out so quickly there will be a repeat repast on Tuesday -- though by then, if authenticity is to prevail, the Consomme Olga will have to be watered down.

title: It's All in the Family and Keeps Growing
description: BRYANT and Cooper in Roslyn is arguably the best steakhouse on Long Island. Riverbay Seafood Bar and Grill in Williston Park could well be Nassau-Suffolk's No. 1 seafood restaurant. The three Poll brothers -- Dean, Gillis and George -- own both of these upscale, successful spots.

title: Office Complaints: Voices in the Wilderness
description: Sometimes it seems that any resemblance between the workplace and Utopia is strictly coincidental. Some offices are too cold; some are too hot. Some are too strictly governed. Even Goldilocks would have a hard time finding one that was just right. But complaints, whether from staff or management, have a way of going unheeded. Change, like a raise, falls into the category of things that are easier to ask for than to achieve.

title: Spanning the Globe: 60 Years With Lomax
description: STARTING THIS MONTH, Rounder Records is making the folk-song collector Alan Lomax's life work available. Working with the Lomax Archive, a few rooms at Hunter College stuffed with thousands of hours of tape and hundreds of record albums as well as Mr. Lomax's notebooks and photographs, Rounder will issue more than 100 hourlong compact disks in the next five years, drawing from Lomax recordings that date to 1933. The suggested price for each CD is $14.98.

title: In Paris, Chauffeurs On Two Wheels
description: People in a hurry now have a fast, expensive way to get around traffic jams in Paris: 10 hefty BMW 1100 RT motorcycles, whose drivers will pick you up in the city or suburbs and whisk you to your next appointment. The service, offered by a company called Cie SP2, is available 24 hours a day, by reservation only, and it is not cheap: A 20-minute ride to the Charles de Gaulle Airport at Roissy from central Paris costs $110. Reservations should be made a day in advance. A motorcycle and driver can be hired for 24 hours for $500 with insurance.

title: The Real Boys of Summer
description: FIRST problem. The first baseman persists in wanting to use a fielder's glove.

title: Harnisch Confides He Is Still Puzzled by His Condition
description: Pete Harnisch, currently on the disabled list because of exhaustion and heightened anxiety, told a friend in recent days that he still doesn't know what's wrong with him. Harnisch also told the same friend that while he is sleeping a little bit better, he still isn't eating regularly and that over all, he has lost 17 pounds.

title: Co-op Profits, Not Free Market, Are Behind Rent Deregulation
description: To the Editor:

title: Hide the Money!
description: Has the simple life ever been so chic? Nearly a decade since free-flowing Cristal lost its fizz, prosperity no longer equals posh. To be sure, people who have money still spend it. But nowadays wealth tries to look unambitious and inevitable -- at least among the upwardly mobile fortysomething set. Rather than living large, people are paring down and playing it cool.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Macy's Origins

title: Hubbell Trouble
description: As far as Hillary Rodham Clinton is concerned, all the talk about hush money for Webster Hubbell is just so much rubbish. She calls it part of the ''never-ending fictional conspiracy'' of Whitewater and likens it to an obsession with U.F.O.'s and the Hale-Bopp comet. It would be a relief if that were so, but unfortunately the Hubbell matter cannot be so easily dismissed.

title: Out of Africa: Sayville Artist's Photographs Compiled on CD
description: WHEN Esther Lidstrom was a child in Nassau County, she would creep through the bushes of the Whitney estate on Post Road in Old Westbury and climb on the split-rail fence to pet Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney's horses. She would then go home and with pencils and crayons paint the magnificent creatures she had just seen.

title: Combining Apartments On Central Park West
description: BECAUSE of a mistake made by a real estate agent -- understating the maintenance by $50 -- Gerry Madigan was able to get out of one deal and into a much better one.

title: Lots of Ice, And Even More Spin
description: THE iceman cometh. He also carveth. Guests arriving at the Cotton Club in Harlem on Wednesday for a Fashion Week party given for Donatella Versace by Absolut vodka made their way past a giant bottle-shaped Popsicle into a tent that had been lined, igloo style, with ice bricks. Joe O'Donoghue, otherwise known as Joe Ice, used a 15-man team with three forklifts and six chain saws to carve the 15 tons of ice.

title: Crime
description: Robert B. Parker is a tough act to follow -- especially for Robert B. Parker. Now that he's written more than 20 crime novels that pretty much set the standard for the private eye mystery, what's left? How far can he take the Boston-based gumshoe he calls Spenser, and will this muscle-bound man of honor ever show his age? For all his periodic declarations of feeling past his prime, Spenser has stayed an eternally young and virile strongman who sticks to his principles and shrugs off the body blows of time -- until now. In SMALL VICES (Putnam, $21.95), Mr. Parker not only brings his hero to the point of death but challenges him to confront his own mortality in a way that he hasn't since ''Valediction'' (1984).

title: Tying a String To the Wind, To the Universe
description: WHEN most people fly a kite they're relaxing, feeling the fresh grass under their feet and the wind tousling their hair as they hold on to the string that connects them with the paper, plastic or cloth soaring high above their heads. Andrea D. Skwarek makes a lot of trips to the beach to fly kites as well, but for her it's serious stuff: market research. As president of Go Fly a Kite in East Haddam, she wants to know how the product performs, how the colors look against a blue sky, whether it can sail higher than the competition or if any defects show up in a 25-mile-an-hour wind.

title: A Plodding Ma Bell and Her Precocious Child
description: IT was not supposed to play out this way.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: SINGLES

title: Splitsville For Hartford And the Whalers
description: TWENTY-THREE years after the New England Whalers of the old World Hockey Association relocated, name and all, to Hartford -- a city renown for insurance but not for seafaring -- the team is leaving.

title: In the Early Returns, American League Hitters Have the Upper Hand
description: Just when it didn't seem possible, players are crossing home plate in greater numbers in the early days of the season, but only in the American League. National League pitchers are exercising much greater control over their hitting colleagues.

title: Fresh Funds for Theater, Radio, Painting, Poetry
description: The National Endowment for the Arts announced grants last week totaling almost $1 million to New Jersey arts organizations and artists. So far this fiscal year, the endowment has distributed $1.4 million in the state. But under severe Congressional pressure, awards nationally have been cut drastically, and New Jersey's share, too, has continued to dwindle. Just two years ago, the state received 74 grants totaling almost $3 million two years ago, according to the endowment.

title: Teen-Ager Shot to Death In Burglary, Police Say
description: A man returning home on Friday shot and killed a teen-ager he found burglarizing his apartment in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Aiming to Improve Math and Science Skills
description: EDUCATORS and other experts periodically complain about the poor performance of American students in international mathematics and science competitions. Last year, in the Third International Mathematics and Science Study, which tested a half-million students in 41 countries, American eighth graders scored below average compared with their counterparts in Asia and Western Europe.

title: Editor Complains of Assault at Yale Protest
description: A rally by an Asian-American organization at Yale University escalated on Thursday night, when the editor of National Review says he was pushed and punched by protesters who charged that a recent cover of the conservative magazine was racist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONATY, ARTHUR
description: CONATY-Arthur. The President of Montefiore Medical Center and its Board of Trustees are profoundly saddened by the passing of Arthur Conaty, dear father of our esteemed colleague, Mr. Robert B. Conaty, executive vicepresident of operations. A giving man, devoted to his family and deeply committed to his community, he will be missed by all who had the privilege to know him. We extend our deep and heartfelt sympathy to his loving wife of 59 years, Marguerite; his daughters, Gayle Connolly, Joyce Conaty and Lynn McCabe; his son Robert; his ten grandchildren and six greatgrandchildren. Spencer Foreman, MD, President Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Jazz Concert Series Enlivens Mount Vernon Scene on Sundays
description: ON Sundays through the end of the month, this city is being filled with the haunting sounds of saxophones and piano riffs in ''Jazz Around the City,'' a concert series taking place in various supper clubs, restaurants and nightclubs.

title: Tuskegee's Long Arm Still Touches a Nerve
description: LAST week, as four of the eight remaining survivors of the Tuskegee syphilis experiments gathered at the Shiloh Baptist Church in Notasulga, Ala., a White House spokeswoman promised that President Clinton would soon formally apologize for the Federal Government's sponsorship of that infamous medical study.

title: Widening Arenas In Top County Race
description: ONE contender has already started a television advertising blitz; another has an elaborate Web page, and others vow to follow soon. News releases are circulating, money is being solicited and behind-the-scenes jockeying is going on in Westchester's cities, town and villages. And just about everyone is promising to reduce taxes.

title: Facing Psychic Hurt With a Quip
description: EVEN though rehearsals for the Wordplay II production of Neil Simon's ''I Ought to Be in Pictures'' had already begun at the Schoolhouse here, another play, A. R. Gurney's ''Sylvia,'' was rushed in, ready to go. All that the postponement meant at the time was the replacement of the leading actor in Mr. Simon's play. It happens.

title: J. Wister Meigs, 82, an Epidemiologist
description: J. Wister Meigs, an epidemiologist and researcher in occupational medicine, public health and the environmental causes of cancer, died on March 25 at the Evergreen Woods Health Center in North Branford, Conn. He was 82 and lived in Hamden, Conn.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article last Sunday about Atlantic City development and real estate misidentified the chairman of the MGM Grand. He is J. Terrence Lanni, not Al Luciani.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Jingle Jangle

title: Asking Viewers Not to Avert Their Eyes
description: THE PICTURES WOULD SEEM to have nothing in common: a composite image of Hollywood leading ladies, a Rembrandtesque photograph of an androgynous man, a Polaroid portrait of a facially disfigured subject, an F.B.I.-commissioned image, which appeared in The New York Post in 1985, of what a child in a kidnapping case might look like as a teen-ager. But they are all variations on themes central to the work of Nancy Burson: difference and similarity, normality and abnormality.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARUCKI, CHARLES (SZAJA)
description: ZARUCKI-Charles (Szaja). On April 12, 1997. Holocaust survivor. Beloved husband of Rose. Devoted father of Betsy and Judy. Adored grandfather of Sheri, Michael, Jennifer and Corey. Funeral service Monday, 10 AM, at ''Plaza Memorial Chapel,'' 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Noise and Fumes of 'Backyard' Buses Frustrate Neighbors
description: Ann Kuhlman may be a homeowner, but she looked more like a prisoner as she peered out her daughter's bedroom window last week at the Transit Authority express buses maneuvering around a parking lot behind her house.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Quotable Einstein

title: Hong Kong Gets A Signal From Beijing
description: In his first major act in preparation to be China's new leader for Hong Kong, a post he will assume July 1 when Beijing resumes sovereignty over the territory, Tung Chee-hwa announced plans to sharply restrict the rights of protest and assembly there.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ROCKING ZYDECO

title: Four Painters Who Absorb Photography
description: IT has been said that the invention of photography rendered representational painting obsolete, thus clearing the way for the possibility of abstraction, and sometimes even that photography has outstripped painting altogether.

title: Frequent-Flier Plans: New and Different
description: Several established frequent-flier plans are making changes, and one program has recently made its debut.

title: Five 'Forgotten Funds' on a Remember List
description: WITH so many stocks rallying over the last year and the coffers of mutual funds filling, it took digging by the Morningstar Mutual Funds newsletter to come up with its eighth annual list of ''forgotten funds.'' But the editors managed to do it, unearthing five of what they call ''appealing funds that investors had overlooked.''

title: Time for Lawn Mower Maintenance
description: MOST homeowners use a power mower, either gas-powered or electric, to cut their lawns. Preseason tuneup for these mowers starts with a thorough cleaning to remove all accumulations of dirt and grass from the underside of the mower deck. Next inspect the wheel nuts and other fasteners and tighten them if necessary.

title: Don't Forget The Real Trolleys
description: It was strange to see the article (''Ding, Ding, Ding . . . The Trolley Goes Again,'' March 16) lionize a phony trolley replica in Danbury, while failing to inform readers that operating genuine trolleys and streetcars of true historical importance exist near Hartford and New Haven. In fact, a Connecticut native, Frank J. Sprague, was the father of the electric trolley. This remarkable man became the Bill Gates of his era by electrifying streetcars, and went on to invent the railroad air brake system used today, and the modern elevator.

title: A Palatial Setting for Art in Rome
description: One of Italy's best private art collections, housed in the Galleria Doria Pamphilj in Rome, has been restored to its former splendor in a Baroque palace and expanded to include four rooms long closed to public view. Thanks to the discovery of a detailed architectural plan from the period that showed the exact location of works, the restoration project, completed at the end of last year, included rehanging paintings where they hung in the 18th century. Thus, today's visitors will see the artworks arranged just as 18th-century travelers saw them while making the Grand Tour. The collection encompasses 600 paintings and sculptures and includes Velazquez's ''Portrait of Innocent X,'' Titian's ''Salome,'' Caravaggio's ''Flight Into Egypt'' and Bernini's marble bust of Pope Innocent X.

title: A Message That's Diminished by the Buildup
description: NEARLY BURIED IN THE avalanche of hype surrounding ''Ellen,'' the ABC sitcom in which the lead character is about to come out as a lesbian, is one especially revealing factoid. In a poll taken recently for TV Guide, 63 percent of viewers who were aware of ''Ellen'' said they had little or no interest in watching the supposedly special coming-out episode.

title: Embattled Pizza Restaurant Is True Neighborhood Place
description: To the Editor:

title: America the Valuable
description: Passionate collectors of American furniture -- the kind who spend upwards of $1 million for a Chippendale chest or about half that amount for a pair of Queen-Anne-style side chairs -- also think nothing of eating pizza off an equally expensive table. ''Buyers today like living with their furniture,'' says John Hays, who heads the American furniture department at Christie's. ''Their insurance companies may not like it, but no one's putting up any red ropes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOLODENK, BERTHA (NEE SHIMKIN)
description: CHOLODENK-Bertha (nee Shimkin). On September 4, 1996 at home. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Jack Cholodenk, sister of the late Dr. Irving Shimkin, Leon Shimkin, Mary Kunitz, Rose Danziger and Nathan Shimkin. She is survived by several nieces and nephews. Interment was at New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI.

title: Why Men Find 'Casual Fridays' Suitable
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BRIEN, FRANK, SR.
description: O'BRIEN-Frank, Sr. Colleagues and friends at the NYU School of Medicine mourn the loss of Frank O' Brien, Sr., father of our highly respected clinician and teacher, Dr. Francis O'Brien. Mr. O'Brien was a distinguished maritime lawyer who endowed his four sons with a legacy of professional accomplishment and strong family values. Francis, Jr., our colleague in the Cardiology Section, Department of Medicine, has earned the respect of his peers, the deep appreciation of his patients and the warm regard of his students. A caring and thoughtful physician, he embodies the noble attributes of his late father. Throughout the generations, children have sought to model their lives on the accomplishments of their parents. Our colleague, Dr. Francis O'Brien has been true to his heritage. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Mrs. Ellin O'Brien, her sons and the O'Brien family. Arthur C. Fox, M.D. Chief, Cardiology Section Richard I. Levin, M.D. Department of Medicine NYU Medical Center and School of Medicine

title: Saying Goodbye to an Old Friend
description: GOOD local bookstores really aren't like other places of business. I'm a fairly friendly guy, but I don't go to my local Edward's supermarket to chat it up with the manager about the current state of meat packing. Talk about books is another matter: Almost every time in the last 12 years that I've dropped by Nancy Mullen's Corner Bookshop in Setauket, I've ended up chatting about books and authors and current events. She shares her latest clippings from the local press of inept bits of English, or inappropriate sales letters or we just gossip a while to pass the time of day. Part of the ritual of buying books at this venerable entrepot of the written word was that more than cash would pass between us.

title: Ever So Sinkable

The moment she took the stage, resplendent in blue silk brocade with every hair of her shimmering ash-blond coif in place, they gave her a welcome as hearty as the one belted out by ''Hello, Dolly's'' singing waiters, and Prime Minister John Major, not always known for having the right lines, beamed at her and said, ''Welcome back here where you belong.''

title: DROP THAT DUCK
description: The State of Tennessee recently declared that rubber-duck races must be classified, like bingo games and raffles, as illegal lotteries. State charities have used the races, which aren't illegal anywhere else, for years. Participants pay $5 or so to ''adopt'' a numbered duck; a flock is released on a river; you win a prize if your duck outpaces the rest, and profits go to charity. The ''quackdown'' means bad news for outfits like the Boys and Girls Clubs of Greater Knoxville, which raised $117,000 with its duck race last year. Despite the setback, the 1997 event is still tentatively scheduled for April 19 -- Knox County may seek a restraining order against the state on the clubs' behalf, as part of a larger legal challenge. ''The duck ain't dead,'' says John Lee, the clubs' president. ''He may be winged, but he ain't dead.''

title: Wilder and the Marvels of the Heart
description: A friend of mine, now a distinguished author and scholar, remembers that as a teen-ager in California she would wander in the stacks of the Berkeley Public Library. One day, with a random curiosity, she picked a novel off the shelf and turned to the opening paragraph. ''The earth sighed as it turned in its course; the shadow of night crept gradually along the Mediterranean, and Asia was left in darkness. The great cliff that would one day be called Gibraltar held for a long time a gleam of red and orange . . . at the mouth of the Nile the water lay like a wet pavement.'' She was enthralled. She decided right there to become a writer, and hoped sometime, somehow to write sentences as ravishing as these. The novel was ''The Woman of Andros,'' by Thornton Wilder.

title: Whacked But Not Forgotten
description: Yekaterinburg, the hometown of President Boris Yeltsin, is also the setting for some of Russia's bloodiest gang wars. For six years, members of Centralny (the center) and Uralmash (named for an enormous machinery plant outside the city) have fought a fierce battle in the streets. At stake is control of the major local business -- the export of rare metals like iridium and platinum and precious stones like emeralds and rubies, all of which are mined in the nearby Ural Mountains. It's a prize worth a total of several billion dollars, and so far 12 gang chieftains have died fighting for it.

He had no wish to turn the house into a mini Mar-a-Lago. Instead, he called Steven Harris, a New York architect and fellow Floridian who designed a house near Daytona Beach for Root. ''Chapman and I both grew up in north Florida,'' notes Harris, ''and this house has some of that vernacular. He knows that old floors are supposed to slope, and screen doors are supposed to slap when you close them.''

''The architecture is about as spare as it can be,'' says Ted Flato, who established the firm in 1984 with David Lake. title: Could a Little Fenugreek Hurt?
description: The charming idea of Chitra Banerjee Divakaruni's lyrical first novel, THE MISTRESS OF SPICES (Anchor, $22.95), is that there is an appropriate spice to cure every human ill -- and we learn about them in a procession of chapters with names like ''Turmeric,'' ''Fenugreek'' and ''Ginger.'' Our narrator is the Mistress of Spices herself, an old woman named Tilottama whose past is the stuff of legend. Born in India with the gift of prophecy, she is captured by pirates, rescued by sea snakes and transported to a remote island where a woman called the Old One instructs her in the special powers of spices. When her instruction is completed, Tilo can choose among various exotic locales in which to exercise her skills. She picks -- of all places -- Oakland, Calif., where she materializes as an old woman who runs a store called the Spice Bazaar. Since this is a novel about feminine insight and healing, Tilo can see what spices people need even before they speak. But the problems she encounters are disappointingly shopworn. Her only really interesting customer is a man she thinks of as ''the lonely American,'' who can see the true beauty beneath her wrinkled exterior. Naturally, he has a fascinating story of his own to tell. Tilo's magic is not without its drawbacks; she can bring on disaster if she is unskillful, especially if she lets her own wishes come into the picture. And so ''The Mistress of Spices'' becomes a novel about choosing between a life of special powers and one of ordinary love and compassion. If Tilo's choice is rather predictable, the way Ms. Divakaruni gets us there is anything but. David Guy

title: Faster Than Jackie Robinson: Branch Rickey's Sermons on the Mound

The 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's debut with the Brooklyn Dodgers will be commemorated by President Clinton at Shea Stadium Tuesday, but what of the man who hired Robinson? title: Hair-Raising
description: At the Paul Mitchell platform, the smoke machine was emitting clouds of gray haze in the tradition of Las Vegas magic shows and overwrought Broadway musicals; the speakers were throbbing with an insistent techno-beat. It was 2 in the afternoon on a recent Sunday, and the International Beauty Show was in full swing at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York, where hairdressers from all over the country were wandering the aisles, lingering to take in the live proceedings sponsored by manufacturers. The Paul Mitchell team of stylists was putting the finishing touches on hairdos intended to demonstrate its creativity, working on a handful of models who sat meekly, oblivious to what was happening on top of their heads. In the end, it was the upsweep topped by a cascade of chain links, each wrapped in hair, that received the most enthusiastic applause. And then the throng moved on to inspect the merchandise on display: the scissors, timers, turbans, leopard-print robes, butterfly clips, salon chairs and -- among the more ingenious devices -- giant combs with a level embedded in the center, for cutting flattops.

title: OVER-THE-TOP GUN
description: ''We'll go supersonic in supercruise without afterburners,'' boasts Jeff Rhodes, a spokesman for Lockheed Martin Aeronautical Systems, the prime contractor for the Air Force's just-rolled-out F-22 fighter jet. The craft will cruise at more than 1,500 miles per hour and is supposed to be so stealthy and smart that enemy targets won't know they're under attack until they're blown away, a capability the Air Force briskly calls ''first look, first shot, first kill.'' Of course, it's all very expensive -- $70 billion for 438 F-22's, which will be built until 2013 -- and the jet was originally designed to pierce the air defenses of an enemy that no longer exists, the Soviet Union. Among the not-so-thrilled are Chuck Spinney, a Pentagon analyst who thinks the money would be better spent on the upgrading of existing jets. ''By 2013 we'll have a few new planes and a lot that are old,'' he says. ''But the Air Force wanted the F-22. It's that simple.''

title: Carol Palumbo Waits for Her Heart
description: On a friday evening in late January, Carol Palumbo sat up in bed on the sixth floor of the Milstein Hospital Building at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in upper Manhattan, waiting for the most important phone call of her life. Carol, a 46-year-old hairdresser and divorced mother of one, had been on a waiting list for a heart transplant for nearly two and a half years, and had spent the last month and a half in the hospital because her heart had become too weak to sustain her without the help of intravenous medication.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORNICK, EUGENE
description: HORNICK-Eugene, age 72, of Woodbridge, NJ, died Saturday at Newark Beth Israel M.C. Mr. Hornick was born in New York City. He was for ten years an oil chemist for Shell Oil in Sewaren. Later from 1960 until 1985 he was an owner of the EBCO Electrical Supply Co. in Middlesex, NJ. He was a navigator in the Army during World War II, flying 25 missions over Europe with the 43rd Bomber Group of the 8th Air Force. He was discharged as a 1st Lieutenant. He was a member of the Jewish War Veterans. Mr. Hornick graduated from City College in 1947 with a BS in Chemistry and was a member of the Baron House at City College. Mr. Hornick was a member of Congregation Adath Israel in Woodbridge, where he served as President of the Congregation from 1964 to 1967. He served on the Woodbridge Board of Education in 1967 and for many years on the Woodbridge Township Juvenile Conference Committee. Mr. Hornick's sister Betty Wasserman died in 1993. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, Harriet Roitman Hornick, two sons, Andrew of Moorpark, UK, Richard of Newtonville, MA, and three granddaughters, Lisa, Jessica, and Sophia, and a sister-in-law, Selma Mandell. The funeral will be Tuesday, 11 AM, at Congregation Adath Israel in Woodbridge. Interment will follow in Beth Olam Cemetery in Lakewood. Shiva will be observed at the family residence through Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, DR. ARTHUR LUCE
description: KLEIN-Dr. Arthur Luce, born March 31, 1916, to Joseph Klein and Jennie Kallish, in Carbondale, PA, died of a heart attack on April 7, 1997, in New Rochelle. Dr. Klein was an actor, director, and consumate raconteur. He founded Spoken Arts Inc., the distinguished recording company which was among the earliest ventures devoted to the preservation of the voices of contemporary poets and novelists, as well as to literary and educational recordings. Dr. Klein earned his bachelor's, master's, and doctoral degrees at the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor. He was a captain in the Army Signal Corps during WWII. Among the beneficiaries of Dr Klein's generous philanthropy were the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester, the New Rochelle Boys' Club, and the police and fire departments of New Rochelle, NY. He is survived by his wife Luce; his children, Judith E. Klein of Manhattan, Florence Klein of Santa Barbara, CA, Joel Klein of Baltimore, MD, and Rosine Klein of New Rochelle, NY; seven grandchildren; and his sister Sylvia Meil of Scranton, PA. Services were held at Temple Israel of New Rochelle on Thursday, April 10th. He was a unique personality who touched many with his creative fire, his love, and his courageous insistence to always live to the fullest despite obstacles life offers. We will miss him and we pray that he finds peace and comfort with the Most High.

description: ZARUCKI-Charles. We mourn the loss of our beloved friend, our business partner, and confidant, who brought forth great strength, wisdom, and courage to all those who were privileged to have shared in his life. We are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of such an inspiration and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Rose, his daughters, his son-in-laws, and his grandchildren. As a Holocaust survivor who endured the unimaginable hardship of losing his entire family during the darkest of times, he came to the United States determined to create a new life. Never once forgetting his roots, he strove endlessly towards his commitment to the community and his beloved State of Israel. His charitable contributions to the needy, to the remembrance of the Holocaust, and to Israel are very well-known and his legacy for such kindness and caring will be with us forever. May the knowledge of the support of so many friends help to sustain the family at this time. Mr. and Mrs. Henry Baigelman and family Mr. and Mrs. Simon Baigelman and family Mr. and Mrs. Jack Glazer and family Mrs. Miriam Oster, Mr. Daniel Oster Mr. and Mrs. Abe Oster and family

title: Fewer Tickets, But More Revenue

In the fiscal year that ended last June, the Department of Finance collected $351.5 million in fines from parking tickets, compared with $282 million in 1995 and $250 million in 1994, even though slightly fewer tickets were issued -- 9.3 million in fiscal year 1996, compared with 9.9 million in 1995.

title: Newt Gingrich's Medley

First, he told the Chinese a thing or two about human rights and the sanctity of Taiwan. Then last week he called for eliminating capital-gains and estate taxes -- hardly likely to happen but awfully pleasing to the hard core that has grown disenchanted with his leadership lately. Now he seems sorry that he ever hobnobbed with Alec Baldwin and suggested that the National Endowment for the Arts was less than the den of snakes the right wing makes it out to be. The endowment, he now says, will indeed have to go.

title: On a Web tour of the world, you can skip tourist traps and sample the local flavor.

I have glanced at the heavily touristed birthplace of Kim Il Sung and read about the ''fascist cliques'' and ''puppet courts'' south of the border. A new epic poem praising the late President's luminous wisdom was hailed, as was the ''victory of socialism'' in Hafez al-Assad's Syria. The Korean Central News Agency of the Democratic People's Republic (http://www.kcna.co.jp) makes this forbidding political culture quaintly accessible. No need to change currency, carry a visa or wear a good pair of walking shoes. World Wide Web travel has its virtues.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GARILLI, ANNE
description: GARILLI-Anne. To celebrate the life of Anne Garilli, who passed away on March 27, 1997, a memorial gathering will be held at The New York Design Center, 200 Lexington Avenue, NY at 5PM on Wednesday, April 16th. Her professional career began in 1960 at Mademoiselle magazine as mail order editor. She rose to the position of associate promotion director and joined Knapp Communications in 1981 as promotion manager. In 1983 she was promoted to promotion director for Architectural Digest. She kept that title when the magazine was acquired by Conde Nast Publications, Inc., in 1993. Know as ''Aggie'' to all who worked with her, she will be as much missed in death as she was loved in life. Friends who wish to honor her memory should make contributions to The American Cancer Society or The Make a Wish Foundation.

title: A Bay Is Sick. Will the Cure Make It Worse?
description: IN more than 20 years as a fishing guide on Florida Bay, Mike Collins has experienced many a classic sunny day prospecting for shy bonefish and high-leaping tarpon in beds of turtle grass waving in the clear water.

title: MCCAWS, EXERCISING OPTION, TO RAISE NEXTEL HOLDING
description: Nextel Communications Inc., the digital-communications concern backed by the cellular-phone pioneer Craig O. McCaw, said yesterday that the McCaw family would exercise an option to buy 15 million Nextel common shares on July 28 at $15.50 apiece, or $232.5 million. The McCaws also paid $25 million for options to buy an additional 15 million shares at $16 a share and 10 million shares at $18 a share, or $420 million in new equity. Those options expire in July 1998. The family also agreed to provide Nextel with $50 million in financing. Nextel shares rose 37.5 cents, to $15.125.

title: NCR SET TO INTRODUCE SERIES OF PRODUCTS FOR INTERNET
description: The NCR Corporation is planning to introduce a series of new Internet-related products on April 28, the company said yesterday. NCR, which was spun off from the AT&T Corporation earlier this year and is based in Dayton, Ohio, has been slow to embrace the Internet because it has been trying to reverse years of losses under AT&T. Scott Swain, an NCR executive, said the new products would extend existing NCR technology to the World Wide Web. For example, NCR's cluster technology will enable large businesses to operate Web sites 24 hours a day. Other products will enable banks to offer customers home banking using simple Web browsers and let telephone companies offer customers access to their bills on line.

title: Countdown Ends at Shea
description: The golden anniversary of Jackie Robinson's breaking of the color line will be celebrated during the Mets-Dodgers game at Shea Stadium tonight with the kind of pomp and circumstance usually reserved for a World Series or the breaking of a hallowed baseball record.

title: Norwegian Bank Seeks Acquisition
description: Sparebankgruppen, a regional Norwegian savings bank, said yesterday that it wanted to take over Fokus Bank, Norway's third-largest commercial lender. Sparebankgruppen said its bid was valued at 4.795 billion kroner (about $689 million), or 73 kroner for each Fokus share.

title: Strong Quarterly Earnings Reported by Several Banks
description: The Nationsbank Corporation, the First Chicago NBD Corporation and several other big banks reported higher profits yesterday for the first quarter, buoyed more by service charges and other fees than by income from lending.

title: Wheat Prices Surge the Limit As Freeze Hits Sprouting Crop
description: Wheat futures prices surged the daily trading limit yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reaching a six-month high after reports that a weekend freeze in the Midwest had damaged the sprouting winter wheat crop.

title: CHRONICLE
description: HAROLD E. STASSEN, whose name epitomizes losing Presidential campaigns, celebrated his 90th birthday yesterday. More than 900 people showed up for a party in St. Paul, including former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, both of whom also sought the Presidency, Reuters reported.

description: LEIBOWITZ-Nehama. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun & Ramaz School mourn the passing in Jerusalem of the peerless Bible teacher of our generation. Through her words and teachings she will live eternally. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Fred Distenfeld, President Kehilath Jeshurun Steven R. Gross Chairman, Board of Trustees Ramaz School

title: As Markets Shift, a Technology Pioneer Harvests the Fruits of Innovation
description: Over the years, the promises to become more than a copier company have seemed as repetitive as, well, Xerox copies. Sure, the strategy looked clean and crisp. But some new products notwithstanding, the tactics were fuzzy at best.

title: Novellus Stock Slumps on Patent Decision
description: Shares of Novellus Systems Inc. plunged 29.6 percent yesterday after the company announced that a jury had decided against it in a patent infringement lawsuit brought by Applied Materials Inc.

title: Rangers See Opposites in Panthers
description: If nothing else, the Rangers-Panthers series in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs will provide a contrast of personalities and styles.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS : Should I Eat a Peach?Fine, But First Pay Your Taxes
description: Thousands of last-minute U.S. income tax filers will find that, as many of them have long suspected, procrastination can pay.

title: Lexmark Gives Grey Additional Duties
description: Lexmark International in Lexington, Ky., which markets computer-related equipment, has further expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising in New York by selecting it to handle advertising for its personal printers account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The account has been handled by Goldberg Moser O'Neill in San Francisco since July. Grey Advertising and its Grey Direct unit in New York have worked for Lexmark since June 1995 handling Lexmark assignments, including corporate branding. Grey received the account without a review.

title: RENO REJECTS CALL TO NAME A COUNSEL OVER FUND-RAISING
description: Attorney General Janet Reno today rejected Republican demands for an independent prosecutor to investigate the financing of President Clinton's re-election campaign, telling Congress that career prosecutors at the Justice Department were capable of carrying out the inquiry.

title: Ex-Clinton Ally Gets 3 Years; Starr Says Inquiry Is Revived
description: A Federal judge today imposed a three-year prison sentence on James B. McDougal, the Whitewater business partner of Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, for illegally obtaining millions of dollars in Federally backed loans in the 1980's.

title: Modest Gains Are Reported In Budget Talks
description: Working under a Republican-imposed deadline of a week, Congressional and White House budget negotiators said today that they had made progress in their talks but that they were still political miles apart on some core issues.

title: Yankees Strike Out in Poll
description: New Yorkers may fret about the Yankees' possible defection to New Jersey, but as far as New Jerseyans are concerned, New York can keep its world champions. A poll released yesterday by Quinnipiac College of Hamden, Conn., found that only 36 percent of New Jersey residents would like the Yankees to move across the river after their lease at Yankee Stadium expires in 2002, while 44 percent said the team should stay in the Bronx. The other 20 percent were not sure or had no opinion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TREPEL, BEATRICE
description: TREPEL-Beatrice. Age 97. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother, grandmother and great grandmother. Graveside service Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, L.I. today, 10:30AM. Shiva will be held at the home of Seymour Trepel, 100 Fulton Street, Lawrence, L.I., on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday.

title: Young Art Helps Give Immigrants A New Face
description: Congress has not treated legal immigrants kindly in the last year, slashing their public benefits and toughening deportation rules.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 1 about the author Arthur C. Clarke misstated the distance traveled so far by radio beams transmitted from earth into space starting 50 years ago. It is 50 light years, not 50 billion.

title: Clintons Earned $1 Million in 1996, Including Royalties
description: A look at their tax returns shows that 1996 was a pretty good year for the people living at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. President Clinton and his wife, Hillary Rodham Clinton, made more than $1 million last year.

title: De Mortuis Nil Nisi Denial
description: Mafia killers, if we can believe ''The Godfather,'' notify the higher-ups that someone has been bumped off by saying, ''He sleeps with the fishes.'' This reveals Americans' fastidious distaste, even among our more uncouth citizens, for forthright talk about death and murder.

title: John Landry, 73, Marlboro Marketing Expert
description: John Thomas Landry, whose knack for marketing helped turn Marlboro into the world's largest-selling cigarette and whose love of horse racing inspired the Marlboro Cup, died on Sunday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 73.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCPHETERS, WILLIAM HUNTER
description: McPHETERS-William Hunter, on April 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Beatrice A. Loving father of William Hunter McPheters, Jr. and Martha Nell McPheters Ealy. Devoted grandfather of Julie Claire McPheters, Alexander George Gounares and Peter Hunter Gounares. Funeral service 11AM Thursday, April 17, at Calvary Episcopal Church, 61 Gramercy Park North (at 21st Street and Park Avenue), N.Y.C. In lieu of flowers donations to the Boy Scouts of America in his name would be appreciated.

title: Variations in Stride
description: RANDOM irregularities in a person's stride may be symptoms of a susceptibility to falling down, but variations in stride that display subtle, long-range patterns appear to be normal for healthy people who are steady on their feet. That is the conclusion of scientists at the Beth Israel Hospital in Boston, the Harvard University Medical School and their collaborators.

title: Venture to Put Generation X On Line
description: Pathfinder, Time Warner Inc.'s on-line arm, has signed an agreement with Alt.Culture, a New York-based content provider, to update an advanced, on-line encyclopedia of Generation X culture.

title: In Shift, U.S. Tells Texas It Can't Ignore Court Ruling Barring Bias in College Admissions
description: A month after warning Texas that it could lose Federal financing if it ended affirmative-action programs in its university system, the Department of Education has reversed itself and now says that Texas and two neighboring states must comply with a year-old Federal court decision banning the use of race as a factor in admissions and scholarships.

title: Foreign Monsters, False Alarms
description: ''America does not go abroad in search of monsters to destroy,'' said John Quincy Adams in 1821, and Americans have tended to obey that dictum. They declared war on Britain in 1812 only after 15 years of grievances, on Mexico in 1846 after a decade of strife over Texas, and on Spain in 1898 after years of slaughter in Cuba. They were late entrants in both world wars and reluctant cold warriors. Perhaps the United States should have identified some of its foes as ''monsters'' much sooner. But that is not the American style.

title: Student Paper Brings Arrests
description: A 17-year-old student at Wall Township High School turned himself in to the police yesterday for his role in creating an underground newsletter that prosecutors described as vulgar and slanderous. The police did not identify him or the three other students who were arrested last weekend.

title: Japanese to Continue Policy of Low Rates
description: The Bank of Japan's governor, Yasuo Matsushita, said yesterday that the central bank would maintain its low interest rate policy. To help the economy, the central bank has kept its discount rate at a low of five-tenths of 1 percent. Expectations for higher rates in the United States and no change in Japan have led the dollar higher.

title: Hatchets Seem Buried In Jets' Weight Room
description: Perhaps Neil O'Donnell will feel differently on Tuesday, when Keyshawn Johnson's book hits the stores.

title: Bonds Lower In Advance Of Price Data
description: With investors defensive in fear of a strong consumer price number, Treasury securities were flat yesterday, with prices caught in a tight range in thin volume.

title: DeShields Embraces Black Players' Legacy
description: On a conference call for tonight's celebration at Shea Stadium on the 50th anniversary of the integration of major league baseball, Don Newcombe was asked to compare the exploits of Jackie Robinson and Rosa Parks.

title: Stocks Bounce Back After a Big Selloff
description: The Dow Jones industrial average flirted yesterday with a 10 percent decline from its recent peak before roaring back to close up about 60 points for the day.

title: Isringhausen Hurts His Hand
description: Jason Isringhausen, who is attempting to work his way back to the Mets after arm surgery, will probably be scratched from his start tomorrow for Class AAA Norfolk after injuring his pitching hand while punching a plastic trash can. Isringhausen's right hand and wrist are swollen and he is wearing an Ace bandage, but an X-ray showed no serious damage. ''I might pitch Wednesday,'' Isringhausen said last night. ''We haven't ruled that out.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMERS, BERNARD N.
description: SAMERS-Bernard N. The Officers, Board and Staff of the Weizmann Institute of Science and its American Committee are immensely grieved by the death of a luminous figure in all of our lives. As Executive Vice President from 1986 to 1995 and later as Executive Vice President Emeritus, he inspired ACWIS to record-setting achievements in support of the Institute. His fervor was contagious, his commitment total. With stubborn determination, he never allowed serious illness to slacken his pace. Eloquent and knowledgeable in support of basic scientific research as a vehicle of progress for the benefit of humankind, immensely proud of the role of Weizmann scientists in stimulating the economic strength of Israel, he set a personal example of total devotion, admired throughout the United States and the entire worldwide Wiezmann Family. He was an exceptionally effective bridge builder to the Institute community in Rehovot, sharing insights and wisdom with its leaders and scientists. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife of 38 years, Edith, to his daughter Audrey, sons Michael and William and the entire family. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Bernard and Edith Samers Scholarship Fund in Cancer Research at the Weizmann Institute of Science. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President S. Donald Sussman, Chairman American Committee Robert G. Begam, President Fran Ginsburg, Exec. Director

title: U.S. Court Bars Hearing In a 'Megan' Challenge
description: A Federal appeals court refused yesterday to allow a secret court hearing for a new and potentially far-reaching legal challenge to New Jersey's ''Megan's Law.''

title: Success May Be Bad for Jews As Old Russian Bias Surfaces
description: At a recent rally near Red Square to protest the Russian Government's delays in paying salaries and pensions, people's rage quickly focused on a different culprit.

title: G.M. Quarterly Profit Soars, Eclipsing All Forecasts
description: Exceeding even the most optimistic predictions of Wall Street analysts, the General Motors Corporation said today that its earnings more than doubled in the first quarter as the troubled North American division reported its strongest profit in a decade.

title: Finding the Right Words for the Father of Poetry
description: When Robert Fagles translates Homer, legions of earlier translators are looking over his shoulder, along with Homer himself, a lively presence from 2,700 years ago. Then there is what he refers to as ''the translation police,'' that cadre of keepers of the Homeric flame who will allow no divergence from the original.

title: A Challenge to the Line-Item Veto
description: Mindful of the dangers of vesting too much power in either the President or Congress, the Constitution's framers devised a balanced governmental structure that has stood the test of time. Article I of the Constitution gives Congress the sole power to legislate, while giving the President authority to either approve or disapprove in their entirety the bills Congress passes.

description: He was 14 and considered himself puny at 5 feet 5 inches and 150-something pounds. Marcellus Wiley wanted to be ''diesel'' -- he wanted muscles like rocks. So he and his pal, Jabari, back in South Central Los Angeles decided they would do something about it.

description: Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden smiled from ear to ear as he listened to the song, sung in a nice harmony by a choir of about 40.

title: Chess

The disparity in their recent results is thought to be the reason sponsors are hard to find. If they are going to come up with a prize fund running into millions of dollars, they would at least like to know that the title contenders are Nos. 1 and 2 in the world.

A memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: New Cast in an Old American Game
description: Sorting out all the shadowy characters with Asian names, features and connections who discovered they could serve their own interests by serving the interests of the Clinton Presidential campaign is a little like watching a movie serial of the 1930's in which Oriental became a synonym for sinister. Even the Buddhists are now among the suspect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRYAN, KATHERINE

title: CHRONICLE
description: When ANDRE PREVIN divorced DORY PREVIN in 1969 to marry Mia Farrow, their partnership as musical collaborators ended as well.

title: Pasta Factory Will Close
description: The 82-year-old Mueller's pasta factory in Jersey City will squeeze out its last noodle at the end of the year, Mueller's parent company announced yesterday, and 364 workers will lose their jobs.

title: Needing More Than a Dodger Over the Door
description: IT goes without saying that they will remember Jack Roosevelt Robinson today at Middle School 320 in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. It is, after all, also called the Jackie Robinson School, daytime home to 1,400 students, grades six to eight. The entrance on McKeever Place is only yards from what used to be the third base foul line at Ebbets Field.

title: New Habits in El Salvador
description: The most extraordinary thing about El Salvador's elections last month was not their results, which were startling, but how routinely they proceeded. One of the parties of former left-wing guerrillas, known as the F.M.L.N., doubled its parliamentary seats and won many important mayoralties. The right-wing Arena party, which now has only a one-vote margin in Parliament, respected the results. The army stayed in its barracks.

title: Maker of Cancer Drugs to Oversee Prescriptions at 11 Cancer Clinics
description: A big British pharmaceutical manufacturer has taken over the management of 11 cancer centers it owns in United States hospitals, in what analysts say is the first case of a maker of drugs actually overseeing their prescription.

description: To the Editor:

title: It's Literary Double Dutch, and Americans Jump In
description: In a handsome mansion here, almost four centuries ago, a group of Dutch merchants and politicians examined a crude map and made their fateful decision: they would buy the faraway island of Manhattan and build a fort there that they would call New Amsterdam.

title: Senate Takes A First Step To Restoring Aid for Aliens
description: Several thousand people rallied on Capitol Hill today, urging Congress to restore welfare and disability benefits for legal immigrants who have not become citizens. And the Senate took a first step to address the concerns that prompted the rally.

title: Barney's Expects Agreement With Investor
description: Barney's Inc. said yesterday that it expected to select an investor to rescue it from bankruptcy proceedings by May 28.

title: High-Technology Search For Attack Plane Goes On
description: From the flight deck of a C-130 circling the snow-swept flanks of New York Mountain, it is clear how the Rocky Mountains can still stymie the latest in human technology, swallowing a $9 million attack plane without a trace.

Entombment Ferncliff Mausoleum Shrine of Memories. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Academy of Mount St. Ursula, Bronx, NY. or St. Joseph's Medical Center, Yonkers, New York.

title: MARRIOTT SELLS 5 NURSING HOMES FOR $79 MILLION
description: Marriott International Inc. said yesterday that it had sold five Brighton Gardens nursing homes to Prime Care One L.L.C., a private investment company, for $79 million. Under the agreement, Marriott will continue to manage the homes, which provide more skilled medical attention than is usually available in retirement homes. The five nursing homes are in Venice, Fla.; Mountainside, N.J.; Friendship Heights, Md.; Houston, and Charlotte, N.C. Marriott, based in Bethesda, Md., manages more than 1,000 hotels worldwide and has annual sales of $10.2 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOKEL, ROBB B.
description: YOKEL-Robb B., on April 13, 1997, after a valiant battle with a fatal disease, Parkinson's, is finally at peace. Revered brother of Monty, uncle of Dindy, David and Ken. Service and interment private. In compliance with Rob's wishes, donations to American Parkinson Disease Association or Parkinson Disease Foundation will be appreciated.

title: Paul Henson, 71, Pioneer In Fiber Optic Phones at Sprint
description: Paul Henson, the telephone executive who built the first major fiber optic network, which improved sound quality so much that Sprint advertised you could hear a pin drop at the other end of the line, died in Palm Springs, Calif., on Saturday. He was 71.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the salvage of a 17th-century Spanish galleon in Ecuadorean waters misidentified the two men shown. The man holding two coins from the wreck was John deBry, an archeologist, not Robert McClung, the lead diver on the project. The man with him was Cesar Toapanta, an Ecuadorean Government archeologist, not Jorge Viccaino of the Ecuadorean Navy.

title: Secretary Cohen's Call
description: It will be interesting to see if Defense Secretary William Cohen has the moxie to hold the Air Force accountable for security failures in Saudi Arabia last year. So far the Pentagon's handling of the terrorist bombing in Dhahran that killed 19 American airmen and wounded 500 has followed a dismally familiar script. The Air Force high command has sloughed off responsibility, betting that top civilians will once again bow to the shopworn argument that punishing individual commanders is unfair and would damage morale.

title: WILLIAMS SCOTSMAN SALE SET FOR $675 MILLION
description: Two financial companies, the Cypress Group and Keystone Inc., said yesterday that they would jointly acquire Williams Scotsman Inc. for $675 million from Odyssey Partners L.P. The Baltimore-based Williams Scotsman is a mobile-office leasing company with estimated annual revenue of $200 million. The announcement by Cypress, a closely held investment company specializing in leveraged buyouts, and Keystone, the investment arm of the Fort Worth investor Robert Bass, confirmed a report yesterday in The Wall Street Journal. In January, Odyssey, based in New York, said it would liquidate itself. Keystone and Cypress will own 45 percent of Williams Scotsman each, with the company's management and Odyssey retaining small stakes.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSS, DR. BENJAMIN
description: ROSS-Dr. Benjamin. 4/15/95. The very best. We love you and miss you. Elsie and Girls

title: Standing For More Than a Logo
description: THE inevitably futile questions were asked time and again during the weeks leading into tonight, the 50th anniversary celebration at Shea Stadium of Jackie Robinson's breaking major league baseball's color line. What would Robinson think of the modern game and its multimillionaire stars? What would he say about a generation of kids who view sports as their only chance to escape cycles of poverty and worse?

title: Embracing The World Of a Song, But Briefly
description: Hakan Hagegard's strength as a singer has always been his ability to walk into the world a composer and a poet create in an art song, give listeners a sense of its essence, whether comic or painful, and then move easily into the world of the next song. His comic timing is exemplary, and when the music is dramatic or has a tragic tinge, he is thoroughly persuasive.

title: Philadelphia Mayor Joins Farrakhan to Calm Ethnic Tensions
description: In a long church rally today, called to promote racial reconciliation after several recent high-profile crimes, Mayor Edward G. Rendell joined Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader, in challenging residents of Philadelphia and the nation to put aside ethnic differences.

title: European Chip Maker Says Earnings Fell
description: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V., Europe's biggest chip maker, said yesterday that its income dropped a greater-than-expected 48 percent in the first quarter, as chip prices fell. SGS, a French-Italian company, earned $90.5 million in the period, down from $175 million a year earlier.

title: Premieres and Curiosities, From 90 Years Ago to Now
description: For 20 years, the American Composers Orchestra has done essential work that too many major orchestras disregard: championing contemporary music by American and Latin American composers. Along the way there have been over 100 world premieres.

title: GREAT UNIVERSAL BUYS SECOND U.S. DIRECT MARKETER
description: Great Universal Stores P.L.C., the British retailer that owns the Burberry chain, said yesterday that it had bought Direct Marketing Technology Inc. for up to $298.7 million in cash and assumed debt, its second recent acquisition in the United States information-marketing industry. Great Universal, Britain's largest catalogue retailer, said Direct Technology, which develops lists of potential customers for its clients, would complement last year's $1.7 billion purchase of the Experian Corporation. Direct Technology, based in Schaumburg, Ill., is privately held.

title: Predators Get More Than They Bargained For: Tuberculosis
description: THE age-old story of the hunter and the hunted -- the lion and the buffalo -- seems so predictable. But in a twist with overtones of poetic justice, the latest chapter in the great struggle of nature is being rewritten here: the prey are bringing down the predators by infecting them with tuberculosis.

title: Under Pressure, Knicks Fall Short
description: Patrick Ewing lost his poise and was ejected over a controversial foul call. Larry Johnson faded away from the basket instead of driving to it on the Knicks' final possession. Chris Childs's defining moment came when he turned the ball over with less than two minutes remaining.

title: Woods Pumps Up CBS Rating
description: Even in a 12-stroke runaway, Tiger Woods's scintillating victory in the Masters on Sunday produced one of the highest rated rounds of golf in television history.

title: New Netscape Web Browser To Offer Push Technology
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation plans to incorporate so-called push technology, which automates the delivery of content, into the latest version of its Internet browser.

title: House Republican Plans Child Insurance Proposal
description: Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, said today that she would sponsor the House version of a bill intended to provide health coverage for about half the nation's uninsured children by raising the cigarette tax.

The company said, however, that it would file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection if it did not receive approval of all the holders. The filing would involve only the parent company and would not affect vendor, customer or employee relations of the company's subsidiaries, Merisel Americas Inc. and Merisel Canada Inc., through which most of Merisel's business is conducted. Merisel, based in El Segundo, Calif., distributes computer hardware and software products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MATTHEWS, MARK S.
description: MATTHEWS-Mark S., age 90, died Saturday April 12, 1997 at his home in Delray Beach, Florida. He was born in Chicago, Illinois in 1906. Mr. Matthews lived in Greenwich, CT and Delray Beach, FL for the past 40 years. He graduated from Columbia Law School in 1930. Mr. Matthews was appointed by Mayor Laguardia in 1936 to serve as assistant corporation council for New York City. He was elected National President of the Junior Chamber of Commerce in 1940 and was selected as one of ''Americas Ten Outstanding Young Men''. Mr. Matthews served as Vice-President of the National Municipal League representing New York City in the State Legislature. In Greenwich, he was a member of the General Assembly of Conn., Chairman of the Greenwich Legislature Council and was president of the Town Republican Club of Greenwich. Mr. Matthews was the author of ''Guide to Community Action'' as well as hundreds of magazine articles. He joined the Army in 1943 and served overseas on the staff of General Eisenhower. Mr. Matthews was discharged in 1946 as a major. He also owned and operated three camera stores in Delray Beach, FL. Mr. Matthews is survived by his wife, Betty. He was previously married to the late Jean Flagler Matthews of Palm Beach, FL, a daughter; Judith Hodge of El Paso, TX; Six grandchildren and one great granddaughter. Contributions may be made to the First Presbyterian Church or Hospice. A memorial service will be held at the First Presbyterian Church, 33 Gleason St. Delray Beach, FL, on Thursday, April 17, 1997 at 11:00 A.M.
