We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, Phyllis (and Michael) Hammer and Max (and Sandra) Thurm, grandchildren, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORMAN, DOROTHY
description: NORMAN-Dorothy. The School of American Ballet notes with sadness the death of Dorothy Norman, who committed her considerable talents to 20th Century arts and social activism with great ardor and aplomb. Chairman Albert Bellas, Facility Chairman Peter Martins, and President Curtis Harnack join the SAB Board, Facility and Staff in sending deepest condolences to our devoted friend, her daughter Nancy Lassalle, and to the entire family.

title: Cubs' Record Falls to 0-11, National League's Worst Start This Century
description: The Chicago Cubs, a team that has not won a World Series in nearly 90 years and has not been in one for 52 years, broke new ground in futility today.

title: Killing Casts Focus on Abuse in Chile's Military
description: Inspired by a military recruitment campaign that promised education and housing benefits for young men who complete a year of military service, Pedro Soto eagerly enlisted for duty at the Yungay de San Felipe Regiment when his draft number came up last April.

title: Chief Sees Port Authority Gains for New York
description: Six weeks after becoming the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Robert E. Boyle said yesterday that the authority had for too long favored investing in New Jersey at the expense of New York.

title: Speech Fees and Book Contract Raised Patakis' Income, Tax Returns Show
description: In what appears to have been their best financial year ever, Gov. George E. Pataki and his wife, Libby, saw their total income increase by nearly a third to $267,483 in 1996, mainly due to fees from the Governor's speechmaking and a book contract, according to tax returns that the couple made available today.

title: Big-Party Sponsors Sought
description: Anyone want to sponsor the biggest New Year's Eve party New York City has seen since, well, the last millennium?

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Watson Not Invited to Party
description: Bob Watson was the first African-American to be named a general manager of a major league baseball team when the Houston Astros hired him in 1993. Three years later, Watson became the first African-American general manager for a team that won the World Series when the Yankees captured the championship.

title: What would Lazard be like without Felix Rohatyn?
description: FELIX G. ROHATYN, a star at Lazard Freres for nearly 40 years and a 1970's savior of New York City's tangled finances, may really be leaving town this time.

title: No Rent Regulation, No Middle Class
description: As a lawyer who has long represented tenants, I am alarmed at efforts to jettison New York City's rent laws. The leader of this effort, Joseph Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, claims that the poor, elderly and disabled would be protected. But middle- and low-income tenants also need protection. Without rent regulation, most of my clients would have been evicted long ago. Not only would tenants' rents go up; they would lose other protections as well.

title: Executive Dies and 3 Are Hurt in an East River Copter Crash
description: A corporate executive was killed and three other people were injured when their helicopter crashed into the East River moments after lifting off from the heliport at 60th Street in Manhattan.

title: Drug Firm, Relenting, Allows Unflattering Study to Appear
description: Concluding a dispute that raised questions of academic integrity, a pharmaceutical company has permitted publication of a long-suppressed study that showed its widely used thyroid drug was no more effective than less expensive generic versions of the drug.

title: Sales Increase 18% At Roche Holding
description: Roche Holding A.G. said yesterday that its sales rose a lower-than-expected 18 percent in the first quarter as one of its leading drugs faced growing competition from generic products. Sales of the Swiss-based company rose to 4.45 billion francs ($3.02 billion), from 3.79 billion a year earlier. In local currencies, revenue rose 3 percent.

title: Doctors Say Defibrillators Save Lives, but Laws Slow Wider Use
description: When Tony Cox's heart stopped beating, he was working out on a treadmill at the Reebok Club on the Upper West Side.

title: Little Inflation Seen, And Markets Rally
description: Fears that inflation is building up were eased somewhat after the Government reported that consumer prices rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in March.

title: ADVANTA MAY ABANDON MARKETING OF REWARDS CARD
description: The Advanta Corporation will probably stop marketing a credit card that gives customers rewards in an American Express Company program and settle pending lawsuits involving Visa International Inc. and Mastercard International Inc., people involved in the decision-making said yesterday. Advanta, of Horsham, Pa., has suspended marketing of the Rewards Accelerator card since November, when the suits were begun. The program allowed users of Advanta's Visa cards and Mastercards to earn bonuses in an American Express program. Visa and Mastercard objected, saying that their trademarks were being infringed. The possibility that Advanta would abandon the program was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal.

title: Personal Health
description: CHARLIE HAMM, the 59-year-old president and chief executive of the Independence Savings Bank in Brooklyn, is not the retiring type. He is an irrepressible leader, a champion of his borough and the people who live there. He has also been a lifelong squash and tennis player, but his hips gradually became so stiff and painful he could hardly walk. So in January, Mr. Hamm joined about 125,000 Americans who will undergo hip replacement surgery this year. With two new titanium joints and daily physical therapy, he will soon be ready to engage in all kinds of activities that he has been watching from the sidelines for years.

title: China Defeats U.N. Resolution Critical of Its Record on Rights
description: After a vigorous lobbying campaign that divided European members of a United Nations commission, China today defeated a resolution condemning its human rights record, preventing even debate on the issue.

title: Living Off the Land, and Sea, on an Island in the Bahamas
description: WHO hasn't dreamed of going to a tropical island and never coming back? Or of replacing supermarket specials with fresh fruit and vegetables from your own garden and living off the sea and the land?

title: From Le Bec Fin, A New Brasserie
description: Even though he now has two restaurants, Georges Perrier said he doesn't work any more than he did with just one. He still puts in his customary 19 to 21 hours a day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLATT, SOL
description: PLATT-Sol. On behalf of the Officers, Board of Governors and Members of Fresh Meadow Country CLub, we extend our heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family on the passing of our esteemed member, Sol Platt. He will be missed by all of us. Richard Reitman, President Allen Kaplan, Secretary

title: Insurer to Cover Some Who Are H.I.V. Positive
description: A small Midwestern insurance company said yesterday that it was beginning to offer life insurance to some people who were H.I.V. positive, a first commercial step toward recognizing that contracting the AIDS virus may no longer be an automatic death sentence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPAPORT, HARRIET, NEE FLANDERS
description: RAPAPORT-Harriet, nee Flanders, 4/15/97. Wife of Frank H.; mother of William J. (Mary) Rapaport; grandmother of Michael I. Rapaport. Services were held at Delaware Park Memorial Chapel, Inc., Buffalo, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENCRANS, FLORENCE (SIKORA)
description: ROSENCRANS-Florence (Sikora). Loving mother of Estelle Spindel and Lawrence Sikora. Cherished grandmother of Glenn, Meryl, Allison and Adam. Devoted sister of Lillian Weiner. Services Thursday, April 17, 12 Noon, at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Avenue J).

title: CHRONICLE
description: Why, one might ask, did EILEEN FULTON, who has played the scheming Lisa on the CBS soap opera ''As the World Turns'' for 37 years, take her bichon frise puppy to lunch with ANGELICA TORN, who joined the show a month ago?

title: A Modest Start on Sweatshops
description: A newly proposed code of conduct for domestic and overseas sweatshops makes useful pledges to improve the appalling working conditions of apparel workers around the world. But the code is so littered with loopholes its impact will probably be limited unless public and press attention remains fixed on the problems of sweatshop workers.

title: MERITAGE HOSPITALITY OFFERS TO BUY SKYLINE CHILI
description: Meritage Hospitality Group Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to buy Skyline Chili Inc. for as much as $34 million. The restaurant and hotel operator said that under one option, the majority of Skyline shareholders would receive $7.50 for each Skyline share, with the remaining holders getting shares in the new company valued at $9.50 each, in a deal valued at $34 million. Under the second option, Meritage, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., would buy new Skyline shares equal to a majority of shares outstanding for $9.50 cash each in a deal valued at $32.3 million. Skyline, based in Fairfield, Ohio, owns and franchises about 95 Skyline Chili restaurants in Florida, Indiana, Kentucky and Ohio. Its shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $7.375.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, MOE
description: GOLDBERG-Moe. March 26, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Tanya Krutchkoff. Loving father of Judy Valdez. He will be missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANET, LEO
description: BANET-Leo, of Ann Arbor, Michigan, on April 12th, 1997. Physicist at the U.S. Naval Applied Science Laboratory in Brooklyn 1943-1968 and resident of Sunnyside, Queens for fifty years. Beloved husband of Sarah, father of Bernard (Barbara), grandfather of Jeff (Shelly) and great grandfather of Lee Callender and Jay.

title: Jewish Recipes Of the Inquisition
description: IT was a few days before Passover in 1503 in northern Spain. Angelina de Leon was kneading a dough of white flour, eggs and olive oil, flavored with pepper and honey. She formed walnut-size balls, flattening them into round cakes and pricking them with a fork.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOMAR, EVSEY D.
description: DOMAR-Evsey D. In Concord, MA., on April 1. Husband of Carola R. Domar. Father of Erica D. Banderob and her husband John of Milton, MA. and Alice D. Domar and her husband David Ostrow of Sudbury, MA. Grandfather of Rachel Domar Banderob and Jessica Banderob, both of Milton and Sarah Domar Ostrow of Sudbury. Memorial service Wednesday, April 23 at 1:30PM in the M.I.T. Chapel, Cambridge, Massa chusetts. Contributions in his memory may be made to Economics Fellowship Fund, C/O Department of Economics, M.I.T., 77 Mass. Ave., Cambridge, MA. 02139 or to Concord Free Public Library, 129 Main Street, Concord, MA. 01742.

title: Comptroller Issues Subpoenas As Battle Over Audits Continues
description: A day after the collapse of his truce with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall took the offensive yesterday, issuing several subpoenas in an effort to force the Mayor to cooperate with state audits of city programs.

title: Albright to Go to Hong Kong For Transfer of Rule to China
description: Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced tonight that she would go to Hong Kong to represent the United States in the ceremonies marking the return of the British colony to Chinese rule on July 1.

title: Roseanne Looks Back, Laughing And Angry
description: Nine years after the birth of her benchmark television series, Roseanne is exhausted. The pop culture star who created ''Roseanne'' sat slumped on a sofa in her manager's office the other day, saying she hoped to take a year off when the show ended in May, except for a three-week engagement in New York City as, of all things, the Wicked Witch in ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Test Struck Down

title: Plays on 2000 and All That
description: ABC has commissioned a roster of the most famous playwrights in the United States, including Neil Simon, Arthur Miller, David Mamet, Wendy Wasserstein and August Wilson, to create original plays that will draw on the theme of the coming millennium, the network announced yesterday.

title: Manning May Have Been Waiting for Sign From the Jets
description: The Jets apparently might have been able to pique Peyton Manning's interest in turning pro -- but they would have had to stretch the league rules.

title: China Trade Surplus Up Sharply in Quarter
description: China's trade surplus ballooned to $6.7 billion in the first quarter of the year -- equal to half of the $12.24 billion total for all of 1996 -- suggesting that Chinese consumers are reluctant to spend even as the country's exports boom. Exports surged 25 percent, to $35.5 billion, as China closed a trade deficit from the first three months of 1996, the Customs Administration reported yesterday. The trade surplus exceeded many forecasts.

title: 12 Men and Women, Some Angry or Bored
description: ''CBS Reports'' goes tonight where Court TV has yet to venture. With the permission of the Arizona Supreme Court and the consent of all the involved parties, the network placed remote-control cameras in a jury room. The videotaped deliberations, to use a word that does not begin to describe what actually happens, make up most of the engrossing two hours of ''Enter the Jury Room.''

title: Corrections
description: A fashion review on Saturday about the collections of Russell Bennett and three other designers at the New York shows misstated his position at Moschino. He is a consulting designer, not the head designer.

title: And Cheers to You, Mrs. Robinson, Elegantly
description: They celebrated the 50th anniversary of the integration of baseball at Shea Stadium last night, meaning they honored Jackie Robinson for smashing baseball's repulsive color barrier in 1947. Let's hear it, too, for Rachel Robinson, who broke the wives' color barrier.

title: Merrill Beats Income Forecast; Earnings at Salomon Off 37%
description: Two big Wall Street firms, Merrill Lynch & Company and Paine Webber Inc., posted first-quarter earnings that were stronger than expected yesterday, while a third, Salomon Inc., said earnings fell 37 percent.

title: Fire Kills Pilgrims at Tent Camp in Mecca
description: Fire swept through a crowded encampment yesterday outside Mecca, Saudi Arabia, where some two million Muslim pilgrims had gathered for one of Islam's holiest rituals. As many as 300 people were killed, witnesses said.

title: For the Widow Of Brad Davis, Time Cannot Heal All the Wounds
description: AS love stories go, this one seemed predictable.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARRAMERICA REALTY CORP., Washington, a real estate developer, bought three office properties and land in suburban Atlanta for $58.6 million. It did not disclose the sellers.

title: Stronger Commissioner
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Falls as Price Report Eases Outlook for Rate Rise
description: The dollar fell against other major currencies yesterday as a smaller-than-expected rise in consumer prices dampened expectations for another Federal Reserve interest-rate increase next month.

title: Retracing Jewish Steps, Through Haroseth
description: AS a child in Bombay, India, Mozelle Sofaer watched her mother prepare Passover halek, a form of haroseth made from dates that have been cooked for hours in massive copper pots. Today, she uses the same recipe when she makes the dish in her San Rafael, Calif., home.

title: No More Moonlighting
description: Since October, 51 off-duty Jersey City police officers, sergeants and lieutenants have been paid as much as $54 an hour to patrol Jersey City's 10 business districts. But on Friday, the police union issued a memo urging members to stop their moonlighting, which is subsidized by sales tax revenues. In response, Michael Yun, president of the Jersey City Merchants Council, accused the union of penalizing businesses because of a contract dispute with Mayor Bret Schundler. The police have been without a contract since Dec. 31.

title: Drawing a Line on Drug Tests
description: The Supreme Court, often too quick to dilute the Fourth Amendment's protection against unreasonable searches in the name of fighting drugs, sent a welcome message yesterday that there are some searches the war on drugs cannot justify. By an impressive 8-to-1 margin, the justices struck down as unconstitutional a Georgia statute that required candidates for most state offices to submit to a urine test for illegal drugs as a condition of appearing on the ballot.

title: Could It Have Been Something They Ate?
description: ''Corn'' is the dumbest musical in town.

title: Celebration Stirs Up Memories in Stands
description: It was a trifle surreal, the ball game halting just after the Mets had rallied to take a 2-0 lead in the bottom of the fifth last night at Shea Stadium. But this was not baseball; it was ceremony. It was history. A singer named Tevin Campbell sang ''The Impossible Dream'' from a microphone behind home plate, and then came the announcement.

title: Stock Option Trading To Start in Japan
description: Two Japanese stock exchanges said yesterday that they would start trading options on listed stocks on July 18, as part of the country's plan to revive itself as a leading world financial center. Trading in depositor receipts -- similar to the American depository receipts (A.D.R.'s) of foreign companies traded in the United States -- will probably also be allowed in Tokyo after June 1.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANARY, GRACE J.
description: CANARY-Grace J. (Retired Associate Deputy District Superintendent, NYC Board of Education) of Staten Island on April 14, 1997. Dear niece of Lillian Keating. Beloved friend of Christine C. Christie. Also survived by 15 first cousins and many dear friends. Reposing Harmon Funeral Home. 571 Forest Ave, Staten Island, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-4 PM, 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Saint Peter's Church, Staten Island, Friday, 10 A.M. Interment, Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Military Women Are Vulnerable to Abuse, Psychiatrist Says
description: An Army psychiatrist took the stand today in the court-martial of a former drill sergeant accused of raping six women and testified that women in the military found it more difficult to resist and report sexual advances and forcible rape by their superiors than did women in civilian life.

title: Higher Price Cements Samsung's Deal With AST
description: The Samsung Electronics Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the 51 percent of AST Research Inc. that it does not already own for $5.40 a share. Samsung, which had offered $5.10 a share for the AST stake in January, raised its offer after shareholders sued, contending that the initial bid was too low.

title: Older Expatriates Relish the Good Life
description: At first, American writers came to Paris as much to escape Prohibition, censorship and discrimination in the United States as to enjoy a bohemian life style. Later, a stint in Paris in pursuit of the ghosts of Ernest Hemingway or Henry Miller or James Baldwin became part of the rite of passage for a good many aspiring American novelists.

title: New AIDS Test Is Offered
description: In an effort to encourage more people to be screened for H.I.V., Camden County will start offering a new AIDS test next month that is conducted without a blood sample. If the three-month trial proves successful, the test will then be adopted by the 14 other AIDS testing sites in the state that are run by county and state health departments, Debra Sellitto, a spokeswoman for the Camden County freeholders, said yesterday.

title: Caterpillar Profit Rose 33% in First Quarter
description: Caterpillar Inc.'s first-quarter net income rose 33 percent, easily topping forecasts, on strong North American demand for its heavy machinery.

title: Palestinian Hasn't Passed the Test of Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Money Is Just Part of Woes Facing Washington Schools
description: As parents and school officials in the District of Columbia wrangle over the emotional issue of which schools will be closed to save money in a city struggling to balance its budget, a series of troubling incidents is drawing attention to other problems plaguing the public schools.

title: Forced to Open, Branches Profit and Refute Stereotype
description: Two years ago, Felipe Guzman brimmed with ambition. After working for United Parcel Service and a thriving grocery store, the 27-year-old Dominican immigrant wanted to break out on his own and open a bodega in the South Bronx.

title: TCI Cable Concern Plans Six Divisions
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable-television operator, said today that it would restructure its domestic operations into six regional divisions: Northwest, West, Central, Great Lakes, Northeast and Southeast. Each will be responsible for two million to three million cable customers and will be headed by a vice president, the company said.

title: At Monastery In Brooklyn, An Era Ends
description: THE Mother Superior stood in the chapel at the Monastery of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, where a damp chill stuck to the cloister's thick marble walls and sparkling mosaics. In this sanctuary, the sounds of the Brooklyn streets are shut out as firmly as the light that once shone through the stained-glass window over the altar.

title: CVS Starts Review Of Broadcast Account
description: The CVS Corporation in Woonsocket, R.I., which owns and operates drugstores, said yesterday that it had placed in review the broadcast creative portion of its account, with billings estimated at more than $15 million. The account has been handled by Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson in Boston since July 1989.

title: Mets' Own Melting Pot Provides Victory Blend
description: The Mets offered a lasting tribute to Jackie Robinson in their fifth-inning rally last night, the same tribute offered every day in the major leagues. Butch Huskey, Carlos Baerga and Alex Ochoa -- in order, an African-American, a native of Puerto Rico and a Cuban-American -- loaded the bases with a couple of singles and a hard smash that was ruled an error.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASLEY, VIRGINIA
description: EASLEY-Virginia. We will never forget how this grand lady welcomed our sister Constance into her heart and family. Our deepest sympathies to her husband Ed and wonderful sons Bob and Tom. We will miss her and never forget her. Louise Lynch Galleshaw and Eileen Lynch Hawkins & families

title: Writer Who Committed Suicide Faced Sex-Abuse Complaint
description: Michael Dorris, a National Book Award winner who suffocated himself with a plastic bag at a New Hampshire motel on Friday, had been under investigation in Minneapolis after a complaint of sexual abuse involving ''one or more children,'' law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: A Republican, Sort Of
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARCHIOLO, FRANK
description: CARCHIOLO-Frank. May God carress you into eternity. Rest in peace. Anne

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLINS, EDWARD MATTHEW (MOON)
description: MULLINS - Edward Matthew (Moon). Retired I.L.A. Beloved husband of Carmen (nee Lopez). Loving father of Marlene Sager, Edward, Jr., (NYPD), James (NYPD/FDNY) & the late Carmen. Cherished grandfather of Brian, Lauren, Christopher, Jimmy, Michael and Matthew. Dear brother of Timothy, Kathleen Dominguez, James, and Agnes Barreiro. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, New York, New York, Wednesday and Thursday 25 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian burial Friday 9:30 A.M., St. Veronica's R.C. Church. Entombment Nassau Knolls Memorial Park.

title: Brazos Sportswear Deal
description: Brazos Sportswear Inc. said today that it intended to acquire Morning Sun Inc., a privately held apparel maker, for $30 million plus $12 million in assumed debt. Morning Sun, of Seattle, has annual revenues of about $55 million. The company designs embroidered and screen-printed fleece wear, T-shirts and other women's tops. Brazos Sportswear, of Kent, Wash., makes decorated sportswear and has annual revenues of about $250 million. The company expects to close the deal by May 31.

title: LERNOUT & HAUSPIE TO BUY KURZWEIL APPLIED INTELLIGENCE
description: Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products N.V. of Belgium said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Kurzweil Applied Intelligence Inc., a computer software developer based in Waltham, Mass., for $53 million in cash and stock. Shares of Kurzweil rose more than 39 percent yesterday, or $1.1875, to $4.1875. Lernout will pay 80 percent of the purchase price in cash and 20 percent in newly issued shares. The president and chief executive of Kurzweil, Thomas Brew, is expected to leave the company after the deal closes in a few months.

title: The Armani Sulk
description: Women who live the lush life in Hollywood can sometimes seem a bit out of touch.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dole Promotes His Wife as a Candidate
description: Bob Dole stepped back into public view today to promote his wife, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, as a contender for the White House and to polish his legacy after his own failed bid last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUSZECKI, MATIAS
description: GRUSZECKI-Matias. Beloved husband of Fanny. Devoted father of Mary and Bruce Rabiner, Harry and Gladys Gruszecki and Abraham and Mali Gruszecki. Adored grandfather of Danielle, Shauna, Rita, Tobi, Bonnie, Perry, Lennert and Sylvia. Adored great-grandfather of Sarah Rose, Ian, Mason, Marisa, Jaycee, Jaret, Jamie and Rachel. Services Wednesday 1:15 at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck opposite LIRR.

title: FORTRESS GROUP IN DEAL FOR WOODSIDE HOMES
description: Fortress Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to acquire the closely held Woodside Homes Corporation for $126.5 million in cash, stock and assumed debt to expand its home-building operations in Arizona, Nevada and Utah. Under the deal, Fortress would pay $67.5 million in cash, $2.5 million in notes, $2.5 million in common stock options and $54 million in assumed debt for Woodside, a builder based in Salt Lake City. Woodside had revenue of about $137.9 million in 1996, Fortress said in a statement. Shares of Fortress, which is based in Vienna, Va., slipped 12.5 cents yesterday, to $5.25.

title: No Headline
description: ''You can easily fit into Paris, particularly if you like long lunches and even longer dinners.''

title: Hoping the Age of Fizzy Water Will End
description: CRABBY bosses, stupid rules, labyrinthine office politics: the corporate world is not for sissies anymore. Why? The conventional wisdom blames downsizing. But maybe, just maybe, the problems of the corporate world were caused by a single pernicious custom: the consumption of fizzy water at lunch.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: 2 NEW INTRANET PRODUCTS JOINING I.B.M. SOFTWARE ROSTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced new entry-level software yesterday aimed at helping small businesses or corporate departments establish internal computer networks, or intranets. The two new products will be sold by I.B.M.'s Lotus Development unit and will be available later this year. They are part of a new framework integrating all of I.B.M.'s Internet software. The first product, code-named Lotus Go, is Web-server software, which is the foundation of an intranet. It will compete with products from the Microsoft Corporation and the Netscape Communications Corporation as well as with software available free on the Internet. The second new offering, called Domino Mail, adds E-mail, on-line discussion and scheduling features to a web server.

title: Wine Talk
description: NO one seems to know why it happened; it just did. One day, everyone was drinking cabernet; the next day they were not. Out of nowhere, or so it appeared, ''A glass of merlot, please,'' could be heard throughout the land.

title: New World's Spanish Speakers Declare Independence
description: Behind the decorous colonial facades of this city an epic battle of words has been under way to determine who is the master of the Spanish language -- and whether it should, or can, have any master at all.

title: Ah, Springtime by the Lake: Snow, Scandals and the Cubs in the Basement
description: It is not for nothing that comedy has always flourished in Chicago.

title: Food Notes
description: The Up and Down Price of Matzoh

title: 81 Police Recruits Charge Age Discrimination
description: A week after the city decided to enforce a maximum age for new police recruits, 81 candidates who had already passed the test to become police officers were turned away from the Police Academy's swearing-in ceremony yesterday morning because they were over 34.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHL, JOSEPHINE T.
description: KAHL-Josephine T., age 101, on April 9, in Meadow Lakes, Hightstown, NJ. Widow of the late Charles A. Kahl, born in Brooklyn, long time employee of Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn, NY. Committal of cremains on Friday, April 18, 1 PM, in Greenwood Cemetery, 5th Avenue at 25th street, Brooklyn, NY. For more information contact the Glackin/Saul Funeral Home, 136 Morrison Avenue, Hightstown, N.J. 08520.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHACHTER, SIDNEY
description: SCHACHTER-Sidney. The unveiling, Sunday, April 20, 2:30 PM, Mount Moriah Cemetery, 685 Fairview Avenue, Fairview, NJ.

title: New Jersey Voters Approve Extra Local School Spending
description: Voters in a range of suburban communities approved new school budgets today even though they exceeded new state guidelines for school spending.

title: ALPINE GROUP ACQUIRES HEPWORTH REFRACTORIES BUSINESS
description: Alpine Group Inc. bought Hepworth Refractories Ltd. yesterday from Hepworth P.L.C. for $100 million in cash. Alpine, based in New York, said the deal would broaden its refractories product line and expand its customer base. Hepworth Refractories, based in England, is a manufacturer and distributor. It had revenues of $260 million in 1996, according to Alpine, which makes and supplies telecommunications wire and cable products as well as refractory products and services. Shares of Alpine rose 25 cents yesterday, to $8.25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSCH, LILLIAN S.
description: FORSCH-Lillian S. Of New York City. April 11, 1997. Widow of Frederick D. Forsch. Sister of William S. Sagar, Jr. and the late Margaret S. Pierpoint. There will be a gathering in her memory at 5PM on May 7th at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66 Street, N.Y. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Vassar College, Pougkeepsie, N.Y. would be appreciated.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Auto Racing

title: At This V.F.W. Post, Salute the Polenta
description: At most veterans' clubs, getting a hot dog and a beer might be considered a culinary experience. But at the Tabor-Franci V.F.W. Post, an inconspicuous brick building just past the police station in Cranston, R.I., the bar is not the draw; the restaurant is. People come to Mike's Kitchen for the salt cod salad, the stuffed artichokes, and the polenta with sausages.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the designation of Brooklyn as a ''peace blossom'' site by followers of the spiritual leader Sri Chinmoy misstated a word in his explanation of his move to Brooklyn from India in the 1960's. He said, ''Dire poverty compelled me to live in Brooklyn,'' not ''Bad poverty.''

title: A Hero's Flaws
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Dana L. Fields, vice president and group publisher for Rolling Stone and US magazines, New York, owned by Wenner Media Inc., was named to the new post of group publisher for all Wenner Media titles, assuming added responsibility for Men's Journal magazine. Kevin C. O'Malley, vice president and associate publisher at Rolling Stone, was named publisher of Men's Journal, succeeding Mark E. MacDonald, who left. Jeffrey S. Ahl, advertising director at Rolling Stone, succeeds Mr. O'Malley as associate publisher; Jack Rotherham, Eastern advertising director, succeeds Mr. Ahl as advertising director.

title: Making Room for More Antipasto
description: Fiorello's, 1900 Broadway (63d Street), has expanded into adjacent space. The move has enabled the restaurant to double the size of its antipasto bar, which is now in the middle of the restaurant and can seat 25 instead of 12. Customers at the bar, as well as at tables, can select from dozens of vegetable and seafood dishes displayed on large platters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGOFF, SHIRLEY
description: ROGOFF-Shirley. In her 95th year, died April 12, 1997 at her residence in Virginia Beach, VA. A native of NY, she was the widow of Martin Rogoff. Devoted mother of twins, Jerry and wife Rena of Virginia Beach, VA, and Marvin and wife June, of Boca Raton, FL, and Roslyn Heights, NY. Cherished grandmother of Robin and husband Michael Star of Rockville, MD, Maury and husband David Gostfrand of NY, NY. Martin and wife Ellen of Merion Station, PA, and Bruce and wife Janice of Wellesley, MA. Loving great grandmother of Matthew, Drew, Harrison, Tess, Andrea, Corey, Kyle, Jenna, and Leah. Services at Mount Zion Cemetery, Maurice Avenue, Maspeth, Queens, NY today at 1:30PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: The Latest Misfortune For Rivera? It's Leyritz
description: Mariano Rivera sat by himself at a buffet table in the clubhouse, looking exactly like a closer who had just failed at his job. Rivera jabbed at his food, stared at a can of soda and looked perplexed. He should be. Another ninth inning turned into a fiasco for the Yankees last night and Rivera was to blame.

title: 6 Copters Have Crashed in East River Since '85
description: The East River has been the site of six helicopter accidents in the last 12 years. And while the cause of yesterday's crash remains under investigation, in most such helicopter accidents around the city the culprit was mechanical failure, rather than pilot error.

title: Architecture Students Resist the Emotional, and End Up Falling in Love
description: Sue Ferguson Gussow is a 61-year-old woman of cheerful countenance who wears hats. Most of them are large, have wide brims and are made of felt. At first glance she looks like the sort of vaguely Bohemian suburban matron who rejected fashion but couldn't quite escape it. What she does not look like is anyone else at Cooper Union, the college of art, architecture and engineering off Astor Place in lower Manhattan where she has taught figurative drawing for 26 years and is treated with something close to reverence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANTSERIS, FAY
description: HANTSERIS-Fay on April 15, 1997. Cherished longtime companion of Ros Lipps. Much loved friend of many. She was the bravest and strongest person we ever knew. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Wednesday, April 16, 2-4, & 7-9PM with service Thurs., 9:45AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Fay's name to Cabrini Hospice or SHARE.

description: AT the World Travel and Tourism Council meeting in Washington today and tomorrow, I.B.M. will demonstrate an automated system for speeding passengers through immigration checkpoints at airports. Called Fastgate, the system will undergo testing beginning next month at Bermuda International Airport; by fall it is expected to be in North America, Europe and Asia.

title: Trade Center Defendants Encouraged
description: As they began poring through the Justice Department's report yesterday on problems in the F.B.I. crime laboratories, lawyers for four Muslim fundamentalists convicted in the 1993 World Trade Center bombing and for two defendants to be tried this summer could scarcely contain their delight.

description: Instead of being drained by a crisis that would seem to offer him no happy ending, President Mobutu Sese Seko appears to have drawn energy from being thrust back onto the world stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAYES, AGNES B.
description: HAYES-Agnes B. Age 92. On April 15, 1997. Beloved wife of the late James V. Devoted mother of Mary-Ann Mumma, James B. and John. Adored grandmother of ten. Dearest great-grandmother of four. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Wednesday, 6-8PM. Funeral Mass on Thursday, St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89th St., 10AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to Interfaith Neighbors, Inc., 247 E. 82nd St., NY NY 10028.

title: Inflation Data Bring Surge In Bond Prices
description: Bond yields fell yesterday to their levels of a week ago as a smaller-than-expected rise in the Consumer Price Index sent relieved investors back into the market.

title: Loew's Paradise Facade Is Designated a Landmark
description: Loew's Paradise, the ornate Bronx theater remembered as one of the palaces of the golden age of moviegoing, edged toward a new lease on life yesterday when the Landmarks Preservation Commission voted unanimously to designate its exterior an official New York City Landmark.

title: Board's Hunt for Rumormonger on Campus Sets Off Furor on Privacy Rights
description: When an anonymous flier accusing the local junior college president of being a racist first appeared on the college's bulletin boards 18 months ago, most students and faculty members here dismissed it as mean-spirited prank.

title: Irabu Decision Expected
description: The Padres may trade the Japanese pitcher Hideki Irabu before this weekend, two highly placed baseball executives said, or they may decide once and for all to retain his rights in the hope that he will sign with San Diego.

title: Money for Casino Tunnel
description: The state's Casino Reinvestment Development Authority approved a measure yesterday to spend $120 million on a highway and tunnel to carry gamblers from the Atlantic City Expressway to casinos in the marina district, said James Kennedy, the authority's executive director. Under an agreement between Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Stephen A. Wynn, the casino magnate, the rest of the $330 million cost of the project would be paid for by the state and Mirage Resorts International, Mr. Wynn's company. Mirage plans to build 7,000 hotel rooms and three casinos in the marina district.

title: Republicans Attack Reno Decision on Fund-Raising Inquiry
description: Republican lawmakers took turns furiously assailing Attorney General Janet Reno today for her decision not to request the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate whether any crimes were committed by the Democratic Party in its fund-raising efforts.

title: European Nations Are Told They Need Tough Budget Cuts
description: Efforts by European countries to narrow budget deficits have been unsatisfactory, and governments must be prepared to make painful spending cuts, the European Monetary Institute said today.

title: Most Efforts to Stop Crime Fall Far Short, Study Finds
description: The most comprehensive study ever of crime prevention shows that some of the most popular programs, including boot camps, midnight basketball, neighborhood watches and drug education classes in schools, have little impact. The study also questions the effectiveness of the nation's huge prison construction program in the past two decades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANKEL, BARRY
description: TANKEL-Barry. Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted father of Marc, and Lawrence and Barbara. Dear son of Minnie Tankel. Loving brother of Marilyn Kamchi. Services today, 11:30 A.M., at ''Boulevard - Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: The Incredible Shrinking Meal
description: ONCE there was the lunch hour. Now there is the lunch squeeze: the midday mealtime interlude that has been rushed, scaled down and even eliminated as workers like Susan Julbe juggle the demands of office and home.

title: Fighting Intolerance
description: With yesterday being the 50th anniversary of Jackie Robinson's first game in major league baseball, television tributes to him have abounded. So it seemed timely, even if not directly tied to the Robinson anniversary, that the USA Network's ''Erase the Hate'' campaign took a step forward yesterday, too.

title: Surgery's Chill Can Be Risky
description: ANYONE who has ever lain naked and shivering on an operating table, or come to in a recovery room with teeth chattering, knows that having surgery is not just a lonely experience, but also a cold one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PANKEN, IRVING
description: PANKEN-Irving, 78, Director of Organization, Professional Staff Congress-CUNY and lifetime Social Democrat, died on April 13 after a lengthy illness. Beloved husband of Shirley Panken, devoted father of Ted Panken, doting grandfather of Angelina, loving brother of Mildred Diller. Irving began life as a legendary soapbox orator in the Bronx; he brought clarity, vision and sweet spirit to the many worlds he intersected with and enriched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, CYNTHIA PIERCE
description: CHASE-Cynthia Pierce on April 13, 1997 of post polio syndrome. A scientist successful in spite of severe polio myelitis with a PhD in Microbiology from Yale University. She worked at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research from 1946 through 1964 in tuberculosis research. She is survived by her husband Merrill W. Chase, a sister, two nephews and two nieces. A memorial service to be announced at a later date.

title: Sykora and Elias Auditioning to Fill In for Andreychuk
description: Dave Andreychuk's replacement in the Devils' lineup for the opening playoff game against the Montreal Canadiens on Thursday will be either Petr Sykora or Patrik Elias. Both were promoted from the minor leagues today.

title: Supreme Court Strikes Down Drug Testing of Candidates
description: The Supreme Court for the first time struck down a Government drug-testing program today, voting that a Georgia law requiring political candidates to submit to urine tests for illegal drugs as a condition for appearing on the ballot was unconstitutional.

title: A Hawk's 3-Pointers Drain Nets
description: The disbelief of Nets Coach John Calipari was registered in the pale-faced stare he shot toward an amazed Omni crowd near the end. The disgust of Kendall Gill was uncorked the moment he put his fist into a clipboard with 49 seconds left.

title: Principal for a Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Trip Home From Plant Ends in Tragedy for Executive
description: Craig B. Tate, the executive who died yesterday in the crash of a Colgate-Palmolive Company helicopter, was a driven corporate man who climbed the company ladder and an equally driven family man who enjoyed barbecues and pool parties with his family, neighbors in Connecticut said last night.

title: Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Is to Acquire a Unit of Total
description: In a continuing consolidation of the oil refining and marketing industry, the Ultramar Diamond Shamrock Corporation said yesterday that it was acquiring Total Petroleum (North America) Ltd. for about $400 million in stock and the assumption of $414 million in debt.

title: A Window on Recovery
description: ''Niche networks'' in cable television are those that cater to specialized tastes -- the Golf Network, the Home & Garden Network or the Travel Network, and so on. And now the latest: the Recovery Network.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by The Associated Press on Monday about a Ukrainian woman with diplomatic immunity who was cited for drinking and driving misstated her name and position. She is Olesya Yarotska, not Olesy Yarotskiy; she is the wife of a diplomat, not a counselor at the Ukrainian Embassy.

title: Belgian Panel Faults Police in Murders
description: BRUSSELS  A parliamentary committee investigating a pedophile scandal said Tuesday that five young girls might be alive today if not for gross blunders and rivalries on the part of the police and magistrates investigating the known child rapists charged in the killings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASELLI, ALBERT V.
description: CASELLI-Albert V. On April 12, 1997, in Houston, Texas. Services in Houston, on April 18, burial in Westerly, R.I. Husband of Elizabeth, brother of Elizabeth Uccellani. Graduate of Columbia College and Columbia University School of Engineering '36. Career with Shell Oil spanned 45 years in U.S. and overseas. Fellow of AICHE, founding member of its Netherlands Section, liaison to 1976 World Congress of Chemical Engineers, member of American Chemical Society, CMRA, Sigma Xi. Contributions may be made to Parkinson's Foundation of Harris County, Houston, TX 77056.

title: Turks Fight Gold Mine, Saying Prospect Is Poison
description: Built by the ancient Greeks, conquered by Alexander the Great and denounced by St. John as ''the devil's throne'' because of the number of early Christians tortured here, this town has been the scene of battles and confrontations for more than 3,000 years.

title: Pepsico says a new campaign for Diet Pepsi isn't a war with Sprite, and isn't brain surgery either.
description: WHILE makers of soft drinks play down talk of a soda war, the battle for market share is clearly intensifying.

title: House Panel Subpoenas Wrong Person by Confusing Asian Names
description: The House committee investigating questionable campaign fund-raising practices confused two people with similar Asian surnames, and mistakenly subpoenaed the bank records of the wrong person earlier this month.

title: Stitching Grunge From Borrowed Riffs
description: Nirvana is gone, Pearl Jam is unsure of its direction, Soundgarden has just disbanded, Alice in Chains is between albums. That leaves grunge in the hands of mopers-come-lately like Bush, the English band that headlined at Madison Square Garden on Monday night for an audience filled with squealing high school girls.

title: Evelyn Sharp, 94, a Philanthropist and an Owner of the Stanhope and Other Hotels
description: Evelyn Sharp, a New York businesswoman, investor and philanthropist and the head of a hotelier family that owned and managed some of the country's best-known properties, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 94 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

description: For their combined $60 million, Nike and Titleist may have got a bargain in Tiger Woods, the youngest Masters champion.

description: ARNOLD SCAASI is used to seeing his fashions on the runway, at gala parties, in magazines. This evening he will watch as 104 of his couture designs are auctioned at Sotheby's to benefit the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, which was established in 1993 by Evelyn Lauder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRENNER, BENJAMIN
description: BRENNER-Benjamin. On April 13 in Walnut Creek, CA., at age 85. A native of New York, lived in Walnut Creek for two years and Lafayette and Concord, CA. prior to that. Predeceased by wife Tess Brenner in 1983. Survived by daughters Susan Freeman and Marion Brenner of CA., brother Sydney (and Thelma) Brenner of New York, Sister-in-law Ruth Wassell of New York and grandchildren, Sara, Rachel, Elana, Eve, Galia, Sasha and Max. Services were held in California.

title: U.S. Giving North Korea More Food
description: On the eve of a new set of meetings with the North Koreans, the State Department announced today that the United States would provide $15 million worth of corn to North Korea, answering an international appeal for aid to avert a growing famine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASSER, EVELYNE
description: NASSER-Evelyne. The Officers and Board of Trustees of Magen David Yeshiva (Isaac Shalom Elementary School) and the Magen David Yeshiva (Celia Esses High School) are deeply saddened by the loss of Evelyne Nasser, beloved wife of Dr. Rahmo Nasser and sister of our esteemed friends and supporters, Edmond, Joseph and Moise Safra. Our heartfelt condolences to the Nasser, Safra and Kassin families. Steve Shamah, Joseph Harary Co-Presidents

title: March Shows Little Inflation and the Markets Stage a Rally
description: Consumer prices edged up a mere one-tenth of 1 percent in March, the Government said today in a report that eased inflation fears and ignited a Wall Street rally that was also fueled by some strong corporate earnings reports.

description: Dow Surges by 135 Points Though Nasdaq Ends Lower

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZAMIR, SHMUEL
description: ZAMIR-Shmuel. The Workmen's Circle Jewish School of Bergen County records with sorrow the death of its cherished member and extends its heartfelt sympathy to the family.

title: LVMH Reports a Surge In Luxury Goods Sales
description: LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French retailer of luxury goods, said yesterday that its first-quarter sales rose 68 percent, to 10.87 billion francs ($1.86 billion). Wine and Champagne sales rose 14 percent, to 1.05 billion francs ($180 million). Sales of cognac and spirits were up 9 percent, to 1.25 billion francs ($213 million), on a 7 percent rise in volume sales. Excluding acquisitions and divestitures, sales for the entire company rose 10 percent.

title: Workers in Accord With Supermarkets
description: After a marathon bargaining session that began on Monday night, a labor union representing 28,000 supermarket employees reached a contract agreement yesterday with the management of five supermarket chains that operate 288 stores throughout New York, New Jersey and northeastern Pennsylvania.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: OUTRAGE AT FUNERAL -- Mourners called Kevin Cedeno, who was shot by a police officer, a victim of police brutality. B3.

title: Two Accused of Fraud
description: Two former executives of the Brooklyn company that makes Sweet 'n Low were charged yesterday with tax fraud, accused of diverting company funds to pay personal expenses.

title: See No Evil
description: ''. . . there is an inherent conflict whenever senior executive branch officials are to be investigated by the Department $(of Justice$) and its appointed head, the Attorney General.'' Thus spoke Attorney General Janet Reno in 1993, when Congress was considering re-enactment of the Federal law providing for an independent counsel in sensitive cases. Had Ms. Reno continued to adhere to the spirit of those words, she would have sought the appointment of an independent counsel in the White House fund-raising scandals. Instead, Republicans and many Democrats are furious at her decision not to take such a step. Under normal circumstances, House Speaker Newt Gingrich's threat to call Ms. Reno to Capitol Hill to explain her dereliction would sound extreme. But forceful Congressional intervention may be the only response when the Attorney General of the United States is afflicted with legal myopia.

title: Neighbor Vs. Neighbor
description: As the adage has it, a conservative is a liberal mugged by reality. Add to that adage: A conservative is an erstwhile liberal tenant who is now a co-op owner in an apartment building put at financial risk by tenants who pay rents below -- often far below -- the building's per unit maintenance costs.

title: Flush With Cash, Hotels Renovate
description: New York's hotel business is booming and many hotel operators are using the cash produced by heavily occupied rooms and rising room rates to improve their properties with renovations. According to the Hotel Association of New York, 33 different operators are spending a total of $400 million to refurbish guest rooms and meeting areas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, DAVID ABRAM
description: EISENBERG-David Abram. Suddenly on April 3, 1997 in Los Angeles. Deeply loved by family, Melvin, Helen and sister Bronwyn Bonnie, Grandmother Laura, and many friends. Practiced law for five and one half years in L.A. Graduate of U.C.L.A. Film School and University of California, Berkeley Law School, Boalt Hall. Widely travelled throughout the world, he had interests in electronics, film, and music. He was an accomplished writer. He will be sorely missed and long remembered by all who knew him. Burial was on April 11, 1997. Home of Eternity, Oakland, CA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, WILLIAM L.
description: WILLIAMS-William L., of Hilton Head Island, S.C., a long time resident of Bronxville, New York, and a retired senior partner of the international law firm of White & Case, died on Saturday, April 12th at his home. He was 83 and had retired in 1980. He is survived by his wife, the former Margaret Morrill; by five children: Centes C. Williams of Bronxville, N.Y., William L. Williams, Jr. of Franklin, TN, David M. Williams of New York, NY, Margaret W. Loftus of Scarsdale, NY and Abbe W. Winn of Atlanta, GA; by his brother, Charles R. Williams of West Point, GA; and by six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, April 17th at 2:00 PM at Christ Church, Bronxville, New York. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be made to St. Albans School, Mount St. Alban, Washington, D.C. 20016.

title: Mayor's Family Income at All-Time High
description: Propelled by a 60 percent increase in Donna Hanover's income and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's 27 percent raise, the joint income of New York's first couple soared to $442,778 before deductions last year, the most they have ever earned together, according to tax returns released yesterday. In 1995, they reported $303,889 in income.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTWELL, DENNIS, M.D.
description: CANTWELL-Dennis, M.D. The faculty and staff of the Child Study Center of the New York University Medical Center and New York University School of Medicine mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague, Dennis Cantwell, M.D., the Joseph Campbell Professor of Child Psychiatry at UCLA. Denny was the quintessential child and adolescent psychiatrist, a clinician extraordinaire, a gifted teacher, a productive researcher and a caring and generous colleague. He will be missed by his patients and their families and by all of his colleagues who benefited from his mentorship and wisdom. We extend our condolences to his wife Susan and their children. Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D. Professor of Clinical Psychiatry, Director, Child Study Center, New York University School of Medicine Howard Abikoff, Ph.D., Professor of Clinical Psychiatry, Director of Research, Child Study Center, New York University School of Medicine

title: Knicks Trying to Go Over the Hump
description: Jeff Van Gundy is aware of their history when things are going bad, how they find a way to change their fortunes in 48 minutes. But like any courtside observer, he, too, is unsure of anything anymore.

title: Kodak Profits Fall 45.6%, But Investors Bid up Stock
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which upset investors last month by reporting that revenue thus far in the year was lower than expected, said today that earnings fell in the first quarter, in line with expectations.

title: A Role Model For the Ages Is Honored
description: HE was the first man of color to be allowed -- allowed! -- into the traditional American sport in this century. What a singular achievement.

title: RESULTS PLUS

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC ADDS LOCKHEED MARTIN MEDICAL UNIT
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had bought the Lockheed Martin Corporation's medical imaging business for an undisclosed price to expand its ability to store and transmit X-ray and other images electronically. The business, Medical Imaging Systems, makes equipment that stores and sends pictures from X-rays, magnetic resonance and computed tomography. G.E.'s medical systems business has annual revenue of about $4 billion and more than 15,000 employees. Shares of G.E. rose $2.875 yesterday, to $102.875; Lockheed Martin rose 87.5 cents, to $83.125.

title: Tiger Is No Jackie
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Look Anew at a Landmark Church-State School Case
description: There is no doubt that a majority of the Supreme Court no longer supports a significant church-state precedent that for the last 12 years has barred public schools from sending teachers into parochial schools to teach federally financed remedial classes.

title: Senate Approves Temporary Site in Nevada for Nuclear Waste
description: With the Government many years behind schedule in building a permanent underground repository for nuclear waste in the desert near Las Vegas, Nev., the Senate voted today to build a temporary one there by 2002.

title: Ruling in Real Estate Case
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a real-estate company can be held liable for misleading homebuyers about poor-quality homes. Weichert Company Realtors, the sales agent for the Squire's Runne development in Lawrence Township, must bear some responsibility for the inaccurate statements made by its agents about the quality of work done by Timberline Property Development, the court ruled.

title: New Hurdles To Trade Deals With China
description: Just as the Clinton Administration heads into critical months of negotiations over China's willingness to make some far-reaching economic changes, the talks with Beijing have hit several potentially major roadblocks that make an agreement this year increasingly doubtful, Administration officials said today.

title: COLEMAN TO CLOSE 4 PLANTS AND CUT WORK FORCE
description: The Coleman Company said yesterday that it would close three United States and one international factory, trim its 7,000-member work force by 10 percent and eliminate about a third of its product line as it strives to become profitable. The camping gear maker also plans to close its year-old corporate headquarters in Golden, Colo., and its regional headquarters in Geneva, transferring administrative personnel to other facilities, and sell its pressure-washer business. The moves were announced by Jerry W. Levin, Coleman's new chairman and chief executive, who pledged quick action to begin a turnaround when he returned to Coleman in February.

title: Lincoln Center Festival To Present 100 Events
description: More than 100 music, dance, theater and performance-art events by some 1,000 artists from around the world will be presented by Lincoln Center Festival 97, details of which were announced yesterday. The festival's second season, which runs from July 8 through July 27 and includes 11 premieres, will be held in all the Lincoln Center theaters as well as Damrosch Park, the John Jay College Theater and the LaGuardia High School Theater.

title: Questions and Anger at Funeral of Youth Shot by Police
description: Kevin Cedeno's white coffin rested an arm's length away from his closest relatives at the front of the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday morning, but the men and women, ministers and politicians who rose to speak fixed their eyes far beyond it.

title: Columbia/HCA Makes New, Cash Offer for Value Health
description: Compensating for a sharp decline in its stock price, the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it would pay $1.12 billion in cash, or $20.50 a share, to buy Value Health Inc., instead of using Columbia stock as it had originally announced in January.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARAND, DR. NORMAN D.
