Entombment Gate of Heaven Mausoleum. Visitation Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: State Cites Mismanagement
description: The beach community of Seaside Heights has only 2,500 residents, but it is rife with fiscal mismanagement, a state agency concluded yesterday after a three-year investigation. Officials doled out more than $1 million to a handful of retiring employees, the State Commission of Investigation found. Purchase orders were often signed by Santa Claus or Olive Oyl and approved for payment anyway, the report said. The borough collected more than $367,000 from the Federal Emergency Management Administration and the borough's insurance carrier after a December 1992 storm, but many of those claims were not legitimate, Lee C. Seglem, the commission's executive assistant, said.

title: Gold Prices Near 4-Year Lows On Report of Weak Inflation
description: Gold prices fell to nearly their lowest point of the last four years yesterday after a Government report showing that inflation is in check reduced the metal's attraction to investors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORNFELD, SHIRLEY
description: KORNFELD - Shirley. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Paula Sennet and Allan. Loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services Thursday, April 17, 1997, 2 P.M., at the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, N.Y.

title: First Troops In Peace Force Get a Fanfare From Albania
description: With much fanfare and some uncertainty, the first contingent of a modest international force, to be made up of 6,000 soldiers from eight European countries under Italian command, arrived in Albania today, a month after the Balkan country collapsed into near anarchy.

title: N.H.L. PLAYOFF MATCHUPS
description: EASTERN CONFERENCE

title: NATIONAL SERVICE IN TALKS OVER PARTIAL SALE OF LINEN UNIT
description: National Service Industries said yesterday that it was in talks to sell parts of its $500-million-a-year textile rental unit, National Linen Service. The Atlanta-based company, which also makes lighting equipment, specialty chemicals and envelopes, is seeking to sell about $100 million of assets in its National Linen business. The unit rents napkins and linens to hotels, hospitals and other businesses. The company said it was in discussions with several buyers and that no agreements had been reached. Shares of National Service advanced $1.75 yesterday, to $41.50. National Linen previously said it was reviewing a number of its businesses to increase its profitability.

title: Bill Gives City New Powers To Fight Crime at Markets
description: With the hard-won blessing of labor leaders, the Giuliani administration and the City Council agreed yesterday on a bill to give the city sweeping new powers to combat organized crime at the city's five major wholesale food markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STROKA, MICHAEL G.
description: STROKA-Michael G., actor, died after a long and valiant battle with cancer at his home in West Hollywood, CA, April 14th, 1997. Survived by his beloved wife Karen and his mother Helen. Contributions may be made to the Bes Kimberly Scholarship Fund at Carnegie Mellon University.

title: Technology Company Profit Reports Show Selective Strength
description: Several major technology companies reported earnings that met or surpassed expectations today, showing strength in some computer and semiconductor areas even as investors' selloff of Intel betrayed fears about the personal computer market.

title: 50 Years Later, Texas Town Recalls Horrors of Deadly Blast
description: This Gulf of Mexico port was bustling on a fine spring morning 50 years ago, when longshoremen saw wisps of smoke in the hold of the Grandcamp, a French freighter loaded with as much as 2,300 tons of ammonium nitrate. At 9:12 A.M., the ship exploded.

title: Mustafa Amin, Liberal Editor Jailed by Nasser, Dies at 83
description: Mustafa Amin, a pioneer of Arab journalism and an advocate of Western-style democracy who was imprisoned under President Gamal Abdel Nasser, died at his home in Cairo on Sunday. He was 83.

title: Bora! Bora! Bora!
description: Four months after he nearly abdicated, Bora Milutinovic returned to the throne of Mexican soccer on Sunday. His team scored a breathtaking 6-0 victory over Jamaica in a World Cup qualifying match before 110,000 spectators, who jubilantly waved flags and threw confetti and blew horns that made Azteca Stadium sound like a throbbing hive.

title: Guest With the Philadelphia Takes a Baton to the Russians
description: Now that Wolfgang Sawallisch has announced his desire to relinquish the podium of the Philadelphia Orchestra at an undefined time in the near future, guest conductors are likely to come under close scrutiny. Riccardo Chailly, who conducted the Philadelphians at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening, would seem to be a long shot: he is ensconced at the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, and although there were some fine moments in their collaboration on Monday, the chemistry between Mr. Chailly and the orchestra was not the kind that produces sparks, let alone fireworks.

title: Workers Back at Belgian Renault Plant
description: Workers in Belgium's Renault S.A. plant in Vilvoorde resumed work today in both morning and afternoon shifts, Martin Baert, the plant spokesman, said.

title: Records Show Favors for Nominee's Friend
description: In the last four years, Alexis M. Herman, President Clinton's nominee to be Secretary of Labor, and her aides at the White House have done several personal and business favors for a close friend of Ms. Herman who bought her management-consulting firm in 1993, interviews and Government records show.

title: In Brooklyn, Clinton Moves From School To Fund-Raiser
description: With the legacy of Jackie Robinson on his mind and several of New York's Democratic office-holders at his heels, President Clinton came to Brooklyn yesterday to urge junior high school students to seize life's opportunities and Democratic donors to seize political ones.

title: On the Path of History, and a Moment Out of Time
description: How nice it was to forget about history for a moment or two on Monday night. The six young members of the New Millennium Ensemble played Pierre Boulez's ''Derive'' at Alice Tully Hall and after it, the Schoenberg Kammersymphonie, Op. 9.

title: Newer Drugs Increase Sales Of 2 Makers
description: Both Johnson & Johnson and Pfizer Inc. reported first-quarter earnings gains of more than 10 percent yesterday, paced by strong sales of their newer medications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOTWIN, CAROL
description: BOTWIN-Carol. Greatly loved and loving mother of son William and daughter Alexandra, sister of Lillian Katell and companion of Bill Koplowitz on April 15, of cancer. Educated at New York & Columbia Universities, she was a recognized authority on sexuality and male-female relationships. During her forty year career as journalist and author, Carol Botwin's articles appeared in leading magazines and newspapers, her six critically acclaimed books published in 12 or more languages. She was a frequent guest expert on popular television programs. A woman of keen intelligence and insight, she wrote and spoke with exceptional clarity and emphathy about the frustrations and gratifications of marriage, sex & related topics. Carol loved this City and the Hamptons where she had a home. She was a steadfast and valued friend. Funeral services at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 St. at 12:00 noon, Thursday, April 17. Friends are invited to call on family the same day after 5:00 PM at 1026A Third Ave. Donations may be sent to SHARE, 1501 Broadway, Suite 1720, New York City 10036.

title: Carol Botwin, 68, Writer on Sex and Infidelity
description: Carol Botwin, the author and social critic whose lively and exhaustive writings on sex and infidelity made her one of the leading sexologists of her generation, died yesterday at her apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 68.

title: More Plans For Bouley's Expansion
description: Some restaurateurs are opening places all over the country or all over the city. David Bouley has honed in on a couple of blocks in TriBeCa, where his food empire keeps growing.

title: Volkswagen Stays With DDB Needham
description: Volkswagen A.G. in Wolfsburg, Germany, said yesterday that it had retained DDB Needham Germany in Dusseldorf to handle its account in Germany, which has been at that agency for 30 years. Billings were estimated at $80 million. DDB Needham Germany, a unit of Omnicom Group, was awarded the account after a five-month review that also included Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in Frankfurt, which is part of Cordiant P.L.C.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES SCIENTIFIC TESTING AT F.B.I. CRIME LAB
description: The Justice Department's inspector general said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's renowned crime laboratory was riddled with flawed scientific practices that had potentially tainted dozens of criminal cases, including the bombings of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City and the World Trade Center in New York.

title: Strike Shuts Zaire's Capital for Second Day
description: This sprawling capital city struggled to function today as a strike called by opposition forces closed stores and impeded travel for a second day.

title: BBDO West Wins An MGM Account
description: The MGM Distribution Company, which handles marketing, publicity and distribution of films for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in Santa Monica, Calif., said yesterday that it had named BBDO West in Los Angeles to handle the media planning and buying portions of its account, with billings estimated at $100 million. The account had been handled for three years by Saatchi & Saatchi Pacific in Torrance, Calif., a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., until that agency withdrew from a review.

title: Watch Out, Ninjas, The Superturtle's Back
description: Gamera: he's not your father's 200-foot flying turtle any more. Starting today at the Film Forum, he celebrates his 30th birthday with a big promotion -- from Guardian of the Earth to Guardian of the Universe -- and a zippy new adventure to delight fans of campy Japanese horror.

title: After a Modest Entrance, One Dodger's Leap Into History
description: There was no sellout that day, just 25,623 fans. Somewhere near half were said to be black. On that chilly day in Ebbets Field 50 years ago yesterday, Jack Roosevelt Robinson made social and baseball history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATMAN, JEFFREY T.
description: LATMAN-Jeffrey T. The Partners of Goldstein Golub Kessler & Company, P.C. are saddened by the passing of our Partner and leader of our Healthcare Services Group. Jeffrey T. Latman, 54, died of heart failure while hospitalized on April 15. Beloved husband of Judy, devoted father of Neil, Marc and Allyson, cherished brother of Maureen. Funeral service Thursday, April 17th, commencing at 10AM at the Gutterman Funeral Home (8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, Long Island). In lieu of flowers, gifts in his memory can be made to the American Heart Association or the American Cancer Society. The Partners and staff of Goldstein Golub Kessler & Company extend our deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Jeff was a fine gentleman, a true professional, and a visionary leader. He will be missed by all of us.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYERS, INA S. (NEE SZABAD)
description: MEYERS-Ina S. (nee Szabad). On April 14, 1997, of Haverford, PA, formerly of Mamaroneck, New York. Beloved wife of Harold H. Meyers. Mother of Michael Meyers-Jouan, Paul Meyers and Kim Meyers. Sister of George M. Szabad. Also survived by six grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to a celebration of her life, Sunday, 1 PM the Quadrangle Manor House, 3300 Darby Rd., Haverford, PA. For further information, contact the Quadrangle Concierge 610-642-3000.

title: Dow Continues Its Bounce, Surging 135.26
description: The bull lives.

title: Phone Companies' Earnings Meet Forecasts
description: Ameritech, GTE and Sprint reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that matched or exceeded Wall Street's expectations. The gains came on strength in the companies' core telephone businesses as well as in enhanced services like caller identification.

title: Accounts
description: * Personal Care Group, Montvale, N.J., a unit of J. W. Childs Associates, to the Lord Group, New York, a joint venture of Young & Rubicam Inc. and Dentsu Inc., to handle advertising for the marketer of products like Wet Ones and Binaca breath spray. The account had been handled by Jordan McGrath Case & Taylor and Warwick Baker O'Neill, both of New York. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANTOINETTE D'AMATO never has much notice when her son ALFONSE M. D'AMATO, the Republican Senator from New York, decides to come home for dinner.

title: Zucchini Penne, Via Shortcuts
description: In a perfect world, people who cook family meals like zucchini with penne would have time to make everything from scratch, including pepper basil sauce. They would manage to roast peppers instead of buying them already roasted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWELL, JOEL L.
description: POWELL-Joel L. Age 56, suddenly on April 15, 1997 at Freehold, N.J. Loving husband of Diane (nee Weiss). Son of Mrs. Betty Powell. Father of Richard and Alysa Slifkin. Also survived by son-in-law Richard Slifkin, his mother and father-in-law Harry and Lee Weiss, sister-in-law Iris, brother-inlaw Steve and niece Rhonda Handler. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral service today, 11 AM, at Bloomfield Cooper Jewish Chapels, 44 Wilson Ave, Manalapan, N.J. Interment to follow at Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, N.J. Shiva will be observed at his late residence, 32 Canadian Woods Road, Marlboro, N.J. through Monday afternoon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAPPAPORT, SIDNEY
description: RAPPAPORT-Sidney. On April 15, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Sadie. Adored father of Martin, Bernard (Marilyn) and Joel. Cherished brother of Frances, Sarah, Evelyn, and the late Nettie. Devoted grandfather of Susan, Alyssa, Jessica, Samantha and Jake. Services Thursday 11 a.m., graveside, at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi NJ.

title: From Irish Fable Into Reality
description: In this village in northwestern County Donegal, not far from where Balar the giant created the Poisoned Glen, there is a natural echo. Macalla, they call it in Irish Gaelic. And Macalla is the name that Grace O Maolagain and her husband, Sean, chose for the bed-and-breakfast they ran in their house for three years.

title: Dead Missile Ignites a Bout Of Scurrying
description: As it turned out, the old Navy missile was right where it belonged. Before someone became nervous and called the bomb squad, before the bomb squad officers, who are paid to be nervous, hustled it off to the Police Department firing range at Rodmans Neck, the 16-inch artillery shell was lying in a heap of other junk at a scrap metal yard in the Bronx.

title: Towers Financial Figures Charged
description: Two former top executives of the Towers Financial Corporation will be arraigned today in the United States District Court in Manhattan on charges of conspiring to commit perjury, obstruct justice and violate securities laws during their tenure at the failed bill-collection company, the flagship of the convicted swindler Steven Hoffenberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTWELL, DENNIS, M.D.
description: CANTWELL-Dennis, M.D. The faculty and staff of the Child Study Center of the New York University Medical Center and New York University School of Medicine mourn the loss of their esteemed colleague, Dennis Cantwell, M.D., the Joseph Campbell Professor of Child Psychiatry at UCLA. Denny was the quintessential child and adolescent psychiatrist, a clinician extraordinaire, a gifted teacher, a productive researcher and a caring and generous colleague. He will be missed by his patients and their families and by all of his colleagues who benefited from his mentorship and wisdom. We extend our condolences to his wife Susan and their children. Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D. Professor of Clinical Psychiatry, Director, Child Study Center, New York University School of Medicine Howard Abikoff, Ph.D., Professor of Clinical Psychiatry, Director of Research, Child Study Center, New York University School of Medicine

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Id al-Adha, the Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today, tomorrow and Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Chrysler Seeks to Spur Neon Sales in Japan
description: The Chrysler Corporation will start a cash-back program in Japan that will cut the sticker price of its Neon by as much as 15 percent to bolster sales, a company spokeswoman said yesterday. Under the program, the first 500 customers to buy a Neon will not have to make payments for the rest of 1997, the spokeswoman, Kaori Kato, said.

title: Ordway Will Skip the Derby
description: The Kentucky Derby lost one of its stronger New York candidates yesterday when Ordway, winner of the Champagne Stakes last fall, was declared ''two jumps behind'' in his preparations and more likely to run instead in the Preakness two weeks later.

title: Winning at Home A Must for Knicks
description: Even if the Knicks capture home-court advantage for the first round of the playoffs, it will help them only if they perform the way they did last night.

title: Dutch Say Effort To Save Fokker Is Over
description: The Dutch Government said yesterday that the effort to rescue the plane maker Fokker N.V. from bankruptcy was over. ''This is a bitter conclusion, especially for the Fokker employees who have dedicated themselves until the end,'' said Economics Minister Hans Wijers. The Dutch Government decided to withdraw funds to keep the 80-year-old company going until a restart could be negotiated, he said.

title: Web Site Offers Breakdown of Tax Spending
description: Taxes may be the last thing one wants to think about after April 15. But now, people can find out where their money goes in greater detail than ever before. To the penny. And free.

title: Off to a Slow Start, Legislature Takes a Recess
description: With no budget in place, no progress to report on rent laws that could expire in two months, and no agreements on issues from welfare to prison construction, the State Legislature gaveled out of session this afternoon to begin a two-week recess.

title: New Amoco Canada Plant
description: The Amoco Canada Petroleum Company said today that it wouldbuild a $178.9 million olefins plant on the NOVA Chemicals Ltd. Joffre site near Red Deer, Alberta. Amoco Canada, a unit of the Amoco Corporation of Chicago, said the plant's linear alpha olefins were used in the production of a wide range of consumer and industrial products. Amoco plans to sell up to 40 percent of the alpha olefins to Alberta polyethylene producers, which are currently importing the product from the United States. The plant, to be designed with a production capacity of 550 million pounds a year, is expected to start operating in 2000 and will employ about 120 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINOKUR, SAMUEL
description: WINOKUR-Samuel, 91, a business executive and community leader. He raduated from The Hotchkiss School, Yale College and Yale Law School, where he was Editorin-Chi ef of the Yale Law Journal. Selected as clerk to U.S. Supreme Court Chief Justice William Howard Taft. He was an attorney at Sullivan and Cromwell, an executive at Grand Union Company and Seeman Brothers, Director of The Air Wick Company and Circuit City Stores, and until his retirement at age 86, developed several Culligan water treatment franchises. Active as well in community activities, his love and advice will be missed by all. He is survived by his wife, Catherine, four sons, Dr. Jay, Richard, Dr. Andrew and Matthew, a stepdaughter Frances Ellen McSherry, ten grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on June 8th, time and place to be announced.

title: Gerald Piaget, 79, Maker of Luxury Watches
description: Gerald Piaget, whose name became synonymous with women's ultrathin watches that sold for as much as $3 million, died on Saturday in his native Switzerland. He was 79.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARAKASHIAN, ANGELA
description: KARAKASHIAN-Angela. Lovingly remembered forever. Alice, Thomas and Richard

title: People
description: * Don White, president, and Judy Cohen, senior vice president of Clarion Direct, Greenwich, Conn., a division of the Clarion Marketing and Communications unit of the MacManus Group, left to join Hill, Holliday Direct, Boston, a unit of Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, in the new posts of executive vice president and senior vice president, respectively.

title: New Acquisition For Leap Group
description: The Leap Group in Chicago, which owns agencies including the Leap Partnership, said yesterday that it had acquired YAR Communications in New York, an agency specializing in multicultural marketing, for $20 million in cash.

title: Officer Charged In Mason Case
description: A New York City police officer who arrested Anthony Mason last summer faces departmental charges that he tried to shake down the Charlotte Hornets forward for $100,000.

title: U.N. Ignores U.S. Call to Rule That Iraqi Flight Broke Sanctions
description: In a setback for the United States, the Security Council issued a statement today that did not condemn Iraq for violating sanctions by flying a group of Muslims to Saudi Arabia last week without United Nations permission so they could make the pilgrimage to Mecca.

title: The Retro And the Restless: Two Milans
description: With the same upstart exuberance displayed at this year's Academy Awards, independent furniture designers won the day at the 36th Milan International Furniture Fair, the world's premier annual furniture showcase. And even though the macrame chairs, inflatable room dividers and snowboard divans may never see the light of a mass market furniture store, these conceptually daring, intentionally raw furnishings -- the brainchildren of Dutch, English and Finnish designers mostly in their early and mid-20's -- came to stand for the way this nomadic generation will be living and designing into the next century.

title: She's a Politician. He Avoided Attention. Not Anymore.
description: When people in Westchester talk of powerful couples, the first pair that usually comes to mind are the Pirros, Jeanine and Al.

title: Students End Sit-In
description: Dozens of students protesting possible 9.3 percent tuition increases at Montclair State University yesterday left the campus building they had occupied since Tuesday afternoon.

title: America's trade gap is (1) a disaster (2) a sign of success.
description: IT'S 1985 all over again. America's trade deficit is ballooning, thanks mostly to the huge imbalance with Asia. Only this time the ''culprit'' is authoritarian China rather than Japan, our democratic ally. And even Newt Gingrich, a stalwart free-trader, is warning the Chinese to shape up or sell their teddy bears and running shoes somewhere else.

title: A Sexy Balance of Brains and Brawn, With Moves Invented as Needed
description: Angelin Preljocaj's time has come. More precisely, the time has come for Mr. Preljocaj, one of France's leading experimental choreographers, to have the showcase he deserves in New York.

title: Housing Sign Cut Down
description: Who sawed down the 4-by-8-foot sign at the site of Mount Laurel's newly approved low- and moderate-income housing project?

title: Coffee Prices Surge as Report Shows Lower U.S. Inventories
description: Coffee prices surged yesterday on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after a report showed United States coffee inventories were lower than expected.

title: Final Accord on Sale of Garden Stake
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its 50 percent stake in New York's Madison Square Garden and the Knicks and Rangers sports teams to the Cablevision Systems Corporation for $650 million.

title: Keycorp to Sell 6 Branches
description: Keycorp plans to sell six bank branches in Ohio to LNB Bancorp and Lebanon Citizens National Bank, for an undisclosed amount. Keycorp, which is selling three offices to each bank, has sold 77 branches since November. The six branches have a total of $108 million in deposits, $29 million in loans and 39 employees, all of whom have been offered jobs, the bank said.

title: Ellis Benjamin Gardner Jr., 77; Helped Update U.S. Shipbuilding
description: Ellis Benjamin Gardner Jr., a retired transportation executive who helped modernize American shipbuilding in the 1960's, died on April 4 at Stamford Hospital. He was 77 and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Space Shuttle vs. F-22
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Morris Earnings Climb 13.3% in First Quarter Report
description: The Philip Morris Companies announced strong first-quarter earnings yesterday, following the news that it and the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation were negotiating a tobacco liability settlement. Shares of Philip Morris rose 10.6 percent and other tobacco stocks were sharply higher, too.

title: Declining Birthrates Irk Grandparents and Other Experts
description: Despite the gallery of charts and graphs on display tomorrow night, Ben Wattenberg, the host of ''Think Tank,'' is not running for the Ross Perot Tony of 1997. He's out to demonstrate that birthrates are going down everywhere, with momentous social and economic consequences. Along the way, he demonstrates that a significant subject does not necessarily make for an enthralling hour of television.

title: Young Must Wait to See Who Is Left
description: This is one of the more important drafts that General Manager George Young of the Giants has had in years. Unfortunately for the Giants and the other 29 teams, this is also one of the more muddled.

title: Cubs Red and Blue as They Set N.L. Record for Losing
description: The misery and suffering continue for the Chicago Cubs, who broke another record on another excruciating day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NASSER, EVELYNE
description: NASSER-Evelyne. The Jerusalem Foundation mourns the passing of Evelyne Nasser, beloved sister of Edmond Safra, devoted benefactor and friend of Jerusalem. We offer our condolences to the Nasser, Safra and Kassin families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and of Jerusalem. Teddy Kollek, Honorary Chairman Ruth Cheshin, Int'l President Mendel Kaplan, Int'l Chrman Alvin H. Einbender, Nat'l Chrman Michael Neiditch, Nat'l President

title: AMERICAN GENERAL COMPLETES $665 MILLION ACQUISITION
description: The American General Corporation said yesterday that it had completed its $665 million acquisition of the Home Beneficial Corporation, the holding company of Home Beneficial Life Insurance Company. American General, a financial services company based in Houston, said Home Beneficial shareholders had elected to receive $287 million of cash and 9.4 million American General common shares. In connection with the closing of the transaction, Home Beneficial, of Richmond, paid a special dividend of $300 million to American General representing excess capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, SAMUEL
description: BLOCK-Samuel. Beloved husband of the late Teresa Wigdor and Miriam Kresch. Devoted father of Abraham and Iris Block, Rita and Richard Seclow. Loving grandfather of 6 grandchildren and 11 great grandchildren. Services Thursday, 1 PM, Temple Emanuel, Bayonne, N.J. For information ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: 4 Arrested Over Pamphlets
description: Four high school seniors are facing charges of juvenile delinquency after distributing offensive pamphlets to other students, the authorities said.

title: Critics Say New Jersey Phone Plan Shuns Poor
description: In the five years since Bell Atlantic promised to wire every home and business in New Jersey with fiber optic cable, the company has hooked up suburban business parks and large corporations and set a schedule for suburban neighborhoods, but has not yet made specific plans for the thousands of poor people who live in the state's largest cities.

title: Muppets a la Chippendale
description: THE new reception desk created for the headquarters of Jim Henson Productions Inc., on East 69th Street, inventors of the Muppets, provokes instantaneous delight and cognitive dissonance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOEHME, GEORGE A.
description: BOEHME-George A., on April 15, 1997, of Massapequa. Beloved husband of Catherine. Devoted father of Bob and Barbara Holmes. Fond grandfather of Krystin, Alyson, Katie and Shane. Reposing at James Funeral Home, Inc., 540 Broadway, Massapequa. Funeral Mass Friday, 9:45 AM, at Maria Regina R.C. Church. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Visiting 2-4:30 and 7-9:30 PM Thurs.

title: Germany Arrests Suspect Linked to Basque Group
description: A German citizen suspected of having links to Basque terrorists has surrendered to the police in Wiesbaden, Germany, ending a manhunt that began in Madrid on Saturday, Spanish officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAZIER, JOHN B. (JACK)
description: BRAZIER-John B. (Jack), age 51, died on April 16, 1997 in Meriden, CT, after a long battle with cancer. He was the beloved husband of Leslie Clauson Brazier, and was a sales rep for World of Golf, NYC. He was born in Bridgeport, CT., and was a resident most of his life. Services will take place on Friday at 11:00 AM in St. Thomas Church, Fairfield, CT. Burial will be in Lakeview Cemetery, Bridgeport. Donations may be made to the William S. Brazier Fund or the Sarah E. Brazier Fund, C/O Lafayette American Bank, 1643 Post Road, Fairfield, CT, 06430, Attn: Dee Wust-Forman, Community Banking Officer.

title: When Money Counts
description: INTELLIGENTLY designed tools may not make cleaning fun, but they should make it less painful. These buckets, mops, brushes, brooms and dustpans have been redesigned to be kind to backs, knees and hands. They are even kind to one another: note the rectangular bucket made to fit a rectangular sponge mop. What took so long?

title: Miscellany
description: * MRM World Group, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson Worldwide unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., agreed to acquire Scherer Team, Starnberg, Germany. Terms were not disclosed. Monika Scherer, 46, who founded Scherer in 1981, will continue to head the agency as general manager. MRM is devoted to direct and relationship marketing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, BURTON S.
description: COOPER-Burton S. On April 15, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Douglas and Terry Cooper & Lisa and Stanley Brettschneider, dear brother of Jerome & Iylene Cooper, adoring grandfather of Andrew, Joshua, Allison and Abigail. Service today 12:30 PM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Westchester, 11 Skyline Drive, Hawthorne, New York 10532.

title: New Center for Pace
description: Pace University will open a new center today in Manhattan offering customized training and education programs for corporate employees.

title: Thomas May Turn Pro
description: Speculation has intensified that TIM THOMAS, the Big East rookie of the year, will be leaving Villanova to enter the National Basketball Association draft in June. Although the university would neither confirm nor deny reports that Thomas had already informed Villanova of his decision, KAREN FRASCONA, a spokeswoman for Villanova, said a news conference would be held next week.

title: With Every Loss, the Yankees Look Less Like Champions
description: The frigid weather was more suitable for the Green Bay Packers. The sluggish play was more appropriate for a minor league game. The attendance was worthy of a high school game. But the result was what the spiraling Yankees are becoming accustomed to: a frustrating loss.

title: Apartment Dwellers Prepare for a Strike By 30,000 Workers
description: Tens of thousands of anxious apartment dwellers in New York City are stocking up on garbage bags, hiring security guards and otherwise gearing up for a possible strike on Monday by more than 30,000 doormen, elevator operators, handymen and janitors.

title: Bell Atlantic Says Approval Near for Merger With Nynex
description: In a step that could remove the last big hurdle to their $22 billion deal, the Justice Department has told Bell Atlantic that it is unlikely to block its merger with Nynex.

title: No to 'Lily-White'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 27 about a plea of no contest to charges of fraud and money laundering by John G. Bennett Jr., who heads the Foundation for New Era Philanthropy, misstated the relationship between the foundation and Princeton and Harvard Universities. While the universities were named as beneficiaries by people who made gifts through New Era, neither Princeton nor Harvard invested money with the foundation.

title: Drug Courts Added to Family-Courts System
description: Noting that three of every four people charged with child abuse have drug or alcohol problems, New York's Chief Judge, Judith S. Kaye, announced the establishment of special drug treatment courts yesterday as well as several other changes in the state Family Court system.

title: Institutional Pharmacy Companies to Combine in Stock Swap
description: Capstone Pharmacy Services Inc., a provider of institutional pharmacy services, agreed yesterday to buy the pharmacy unit of Beverly Enterprises Inc. for about $475 million million in stock.

title: Sound Bites on Gingrich From Congressman With Oratorical Flair
description: Amid the general sense of capital drift, the House Republican conference today turned out to be one of the most heavily attended of the three-month-old session, but not for members' great expectations about the national agenda.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIVNER, SOLOMON
description: GIVNER-Solomon. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member Solomon Givner. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Yankee Bullpen Woes Come as Eye-Openers
description: John Wetteland is usually so wired after pitching the ninth inning that he cannot even eat a cracker for hours. He is usually so intense that he continues to perspire even as he does post-game interviews. He is usually so hazardous that he dances with danger before escaping.

title: 10 Months Late, a Budget
description: The Camden City Council approved a budget yesterday, 10 months into the fiscal year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Heaven's Gate-gate
description: The media alimentary canal now digests events so quickly that yesterday's tragedy is not only instantly replayed as farce by Leno and Letterman but then goes directly to video (a made-for-TV movie), all within the Warholian 15 minutes. Thus is the Heaven's Gate mass suicide already sliding toward its final reward, as a future answer on ''Jeopardy.''

title: New York's Hot Property
description: It's easy for New Yorkers to be irritated with the United Nations, and not just because of geopolitics. They see high-ranking diplomats who live in the city's fanciest neighborhoods dine out on expense accounts and -- most annoying of all -- park anywhere without worrying about rules or tickets.

title: AMERICAN EAGLE ORDERS 12 ATR PLANES FOR $200 MILLION
description: The AMR Corporation's American Eagle subsidiary ordered 12 ATR72-210A turbo-propeller aircraft yesterday from Aero International Regional, which said the order was worth more than $200 million. Alain Brodin, senior vice president for sales, said the order represented a turning point for Aero International Regional since it is the first order placed by American Eagle since the crash of an American Eagle-operated ATR72 plane in October 1994 that killed all 68 people aboard. American Eagle is the biggest customer for ATR planes, which are built jointly by Aerospatiale of France and Italy's Alenia Aerospazio, a subsidiary of Finmeccanica. Aero International Regional was formed by Aerospatiale, Alenia Aerospazio and British Aerospace to market the planes built by those companies.

title: Pataki Faults Limit on Bond Firm Donations
description: On the eve of his largest fund-raiser of the year, Gov. George E. Pataki today criticized a Federal rule that places strict limits on campaign contributions from executives of bond firms to officials -- including himself -- who have the power to grant bond-underwriting contracts.

title: Clinton Serves as Dinner Host to Woo Congress on Foreign Policy
description: Facing a series of legislative roadblocks to his foreign policy, President Clinton held a dinner tonight for more than three dozen Democratic and Republican members of Congress at Blair House, pressing them to support his goals in Europe, with China and at the United Nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSTERWEIL, JOYCE (NEE SKARBNIK)
description: OSTERWEIL-Joyce (nee Skarbnik), 63, of River Vale, New Jersey, on April 15, 1997. Beloved mother of Marla and mother-inlaw of Geoff Hewitt. Cherished Nana of Brent and Eric of Westfield, New Jersey. Loving sister of Florence Kent, Jack Skarbnik and the late Howard Skarbnik, and adored by her nieces & nephews. She will always be remembered and deeply missed by her many friends, colleagues and her family. While she faced much adversity, she never lost her ability to look forward to a new day. She was an accomplished poet and a gifted writer. Funeral service on Friday, April 18, at 1PM at Louis Chapel, Fairlawn, NJ, (800-525-3834).

title: Accounting for Child Abuse
description: Unflattering attention was focused, once again, on New York City's child welfare agency with the recent death of 5-year-old Daytwon Bennett and the abuse of 7-year-old Cassandra White. Nicholas Scoppetta, who heads the agency, has defended its actions in one case and criticized it in the other. By his own admission, the agency's performance remains uneven.

title: Accounts
description: * Pro Player Inc., Hudson, N.H., a unit of Fruit of the Loom, to Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to handle national advertising for the sports apparel manufacturer, which had been at Bates U.S.A., New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHARIN, BARNEY
description: SHARIN-Barney, 4/17/87. Add ''f'' to heart, for father. Still my favorite man of letters. Carole

title: Dismantle Japan Inc.
description: Japan finds itself at a crossroads. After World War II, our country devoted itself to catching up with the West. But the social and economic systems that enabled success in that endeavor are now obsolete, incapable of coping with the competition we face internationally and the rapid aging of our population at home. These changes require us to reform our existing systems drastically.

title: Olivetti Shares Fall After a Large Loss
description: Olivetti S.p.A. shares fell as much as 13 percent yesterday on Tuesday's news of a greater-than-expected 1996 loss and announcement that the office equipment and computer systems company would write down its capital. Shares fell as much as 75 lire, to 480 lire (28 cents), their lowest since Nov. 11.

title: BRIGGS & STRATTON TO BUY 5.87 MILLION SHARES
description: The Briggs & Stratton Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back about 5.87 million shares, or about 20 percent of its stock, at $43 to $51 a share to improve its capital structure. The stock gained $5.25, closing at $48. The Milwaukee-based company, which makes gasoline engines for outdoor power equipment, said it planned to get a new line of credit from the BankAmerica Corporation to finance both the buyback and its seasonal working capital needs.

title: Want to Be Rich? Here's How
description: Would you like to be as rich as George Soros? Well, thanks to Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, you may have the chance. Listen up.

Friends are invited to call at Park Abbey Funeral Chapel, 1430 Unionport Rd, Bronx, NY 10462, Friday, 2-5PM and 79PM. Funeral Mass, Saturday, 9:45AM, St. Raymonds Church, Bronx, New York. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHARP, EVELYN
description: SHARP-Evelyn. It is with great sadness that the Board and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc., mourn the passing of Evelyn Sharp. Along with her son Peter Jay Sharp, she was a thoughtful and dedicated supporter of this institution. We extend our deepest sympathy to her daughter Mary Cronson, and to her family. Beverly Sills, Chairman Nathan Leventhal, Pres. Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Bear Stearns Income Up 28%
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that income rose 28.4 percent in its third quarter, another in a series of largely positive recent earnings reports from Wall Street firms.

title: Ford Reports Its Quarterly Profit Jumped
description: The Ford Motor Company delighted Wall Street today by reporting first-quarter profits far higher than analysts thought possible.

title: Sony retools its electronics brand for the digital age.
description: SONY ELECTRONICS is beginning a new print advertising campaign that it hopes will humanize and popularize its brand and products in the hotly competitive digital era, just as a landmark campaign by Doyle Dane Bernbach did for its miniature Trinitron TV's in the late 1960's.

title: New Line, an Outsider, Plays Inside With the Big Boys and Stumbles
description: Thirty years ago Robert Shaye, living in a fifth-floor walk-up apartment in Greenwich Village, started a movie company named New Line by distributing ''Reefer Madness,'' a 1930's anti-drug tract that became a cult classic on the college circuit.

title: Round Table of Experts As Specks in the Cosmos
description: In ''Sympathetic Magic,'' that fine American playwright Lanford Wilson considers nothing less than the universe (''What else is there?'' as one character notes) and concludes that it is unknowable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORSCH, LILLIAN S.

In lieu of flowers, contributions to Vassar College, Pougkeepsie, N.Y. would be appreciated.

title: Knicks Revive Their Game and Their Expectations
description: The ball dropped through cleanly with 6.9 seconds to play, nothing but net from 11 feet away on the left wing, as the shot clock sounded. It was neither the winning basket nor the most crucial shot of the game, but as Patrick Ewing lifted his arms in triumph and everyone in the building stood and roared, its importance was twofold: the Knicks had come to life, as had Madison Square Garden.

title: Hospital Chief To Take Over Merged Center
description: Dr. Robert G. Newman, who as president of Beth Israel Medical Center for the last 18 years guided its expansion into one of the largest health care networks in the city, is stepping down from that post to concentrate his efforts full time on the joint corporation that Beth Israel formed in December with the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ELI
description: DAVIS-Eli. Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the passing of Professor Eli Davis, beloved Director-General Emeritus of the Hadassah Medical Organization from 1948-51, who died yesterday in Israel at the age of 89. Renowned as a man of both science and letters, Dr. Davis was a pioneer of Israeli medicine and research, a gifted teacher, visionary leader, art collector and published novelist. After the loss of Hadassh Hospital on Mt. Scopus and the murder of 78 medical personnel in 1948, Dr. Davis led Hadassah in rebuilding and maintaining its medical operations. During his decades with Hadassah Medical Organization, he published numerous articles and books on contemporary and biblical medicine, led cutting-edge microcirculation research, and paved the way for Hadassah to become the leading medical center in Israel and the Mideast. He will be greatly missed by all whose lives he touched. Our deepest condolences to daughter Naomi Frenkel, son Haim Divon, and their family. May his memory be for a blessing, and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marlene E. Post National President Beth Wohlgelernter National Executive Director

description: For a rough idea of what has happened in the former East Germany, imagine someone wrote a check worth $1 trillion to a state with an economy the size of North Carolina's.

description: The season about to end has been fraught with labor unrest, budget crunches and hand-wringing about the state of the music world. These worries are nothing new: similar crises arise every few decades, and solutions that may seem painful at the time often prove workable in the long run. The remarkable performance by the Virginia Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening was a reminder that consolidation can have its benefits.

description: In a widening of the American inquiry into possible money-laundering by the brother of Mexico's former President, Federal investigators are examining the movement of millions of dollars through Texas Commerce Bank, people familiar with the matter said yesterday.

description: Craig B. He was 51 and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

description: NOW that I have turned 40 and have no children, people ask me why I have chosen not to become a mother.

title: Corrections

When Ms. Tucker said to the poet Gregory Corso, ''Such a lover,'' she was referring to what she regarded as Ginsberg's ''kind and generous nature.'' She was not suggesting that she and Mr. Ginsberg had been lovers.

title: Caution Urged Over Switch In Thyroid Drug
description: Experts in thyroid disease expressed caution yesterday about whether patients with underactive thyroids who take a drug known as Synthroid as a daily hormone replacement should switch to a less expensive generic substitute.

description: * Mary Lou Quinlan, president and chief executive of N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York, a unit of the MacManus Group, was among eight women named to receive the 27th annual Matrix Awards, sponsored by New York Women in Communications.

description: FINKELSTEIN-Bernard. Pappy Dearest, remembering your birthday with love. All of Us

title: Parcells Sets Deadline
description: An increasingly frustrated BILL PARCELLS has turned up the heat on teams interested in making offers for the Jets' overall No. 1 pick. Several people within the National Football League said that Parcells told those clubs they had to make an offer by today. If Parcells cannot make a deal, he is expected to take Southern California's defensive tackle DARRELL RUSSELL on Saturday.

title: In Merged Identities, Chaos Becomes Counterpoint
description: Among Mark Morris's most engaging qualities are his passion and the ways he wears it on his sleeve. What other choreographer would think to suggest the singularity of a favorite composer by naming a new work ''Rhymes With Silver,'' alluding to that composer's unrhymable middle name?

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAULA ZAHN, the CBS News anchor and correspondent, was injured in a traffic accident in Dallas on Tuesday, but that did not keep her from going on to an interview she had scheduled with Herbert Kelleher, the founder and chief executive of Southwest Airlines.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CAPSTAR BROADCASTING Austin, Tex., a radio company, said that it had agreed to buy Patterson Broadcasting Inc. for $215 million and that it planned to raise about $90 million through an initial public offering.

title: Studies Show Talking With Infants Shapes Basis of Ability to Think
description: When a White House conference on early child development convenes today, one of the findings Hillary Rodham Clinton will hear from scientists is that the neurological foundations for rational thinking, problem solving and general reasoning appear to be largely established by age 1 -- long before babies show any signs of knowing an abstraction from a pacifier.

title: More of Largest U.S. Banks Post Income Rise in Quarter
description: Some of the largest banks, including the BankAmerica Corporation and the Fleet Financial Group Inc., reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings had risen, as they held down costs and raised revenue from other businesses like trading.

title: Ferrer Calls Youth's Death An 'Execution'
description: Fernando Ferrer, a Democratic candidate for Mayor, yesterday described the fatal police shooting of a Manhattan teen-ager last week as ''an execution,'' and attacked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani for initially embracing the police account of the killing. The Police Department condemned Mr. Ferrer's remarks as ''irresponsible and very prejudgmental.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOUGH, HUGH
description: GOUGH-Hugh, of New York, maker of harpsichords, clavichords, and fortepianos. Died April 14, 1997. The funeral service will be held at The Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, on Saturday April 19, at 11 A.M.

title: As Kleptocracy Teeters, Charges Fly
description: Two immutable laws seem to have governed the behavior of public officials throughout Mobutu Sese Seko's 31-year hold on power here: First, those who make their fortunes in high office shall not condemn others who do likewise, and second, ill-gotten gains must be generously shared -- especially with the chief.

title: Knight-Ridder Repurchase
description: Knight-Ridder Inc., the Miami-based newspaper publisher, plans to repurchase up to 10 million shares on the open market. Knight-Ridder said on Tuesday that its board had approved the plan. Combined with an existing program to buy five million shares, the new authorization will allow it to repurchase up to 15 million common shares, it said. Knight-Ridder had about 93.3 million shares outstanding at the end of 1996. The stock rose 50 cents today, to $38 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Test for Pension Bond Deal
description: Legislative leaders scrambled yesterday to win support for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's plan to borrow $2.9 billion to help eliminate a shortfall in the state's two largest pension plans.

title: Brooklyn Boy Threatens Clinton and Is Arrested
description: Hours before the high drama of a Presidential tribute to Jackie Robinson before 54,000 fans at Shea Stadium, a teen-age Brooklyn boy threatened Mr. Clinton with death and said a bomb had been planted in the ballpark in Queens, the police said yesterday.

title: Legged Snakes? First Reliable Evidence Is In
description: Paleontologists say they have found the first compelling fossil evidence that long ago, snakes grew legs.

title: With Parcells Gone, the Patriots' Grier Calls the Shots
description: On draft day last year, the New England Patriots were slotted at No. 7 in the first round and the Patriots hoped for a lucky 7. Just before the selection, the Patriots' owner, Robert K. Kraft, called a meeting in a small room near the Patriots' large draft room here at the team's offices at Foxboro Stadium. Present were Bill Parcells, then the head coach, and Bobby Grier, then the director of player personnel.

title: NETANYAHU FACES A SERIOUS CHARGE OVER APPOINTMENT
description: Police officers investigating allegations of influence-peddling in the Israeli Government have recommended bringing charges against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, the Police Minister said today, thrusting the troubled administration into an acute new political crisis.

title: Council Seeks Delay in Sale Of Building In Midtown
description: Trying to insure that it has a voice in a major redevelopment plan, the City Council yesterday pressed the Giuliani administration to delay its proposal to sell 2 Columbus Circle in Manhattan, one of the linchpins in the effort to revitalize the circle.

title: New York Stakes Claim On Mobster's Book Money
description: In a legal action to prevent Salvatore Gravano, a mob informer, from profiting any more from his Mafia days, New York State officials moved yesterday to confiscate payments he could obtain from a book describing his underworld career and his reasons for becoming a turncoat.

title: Voters Reject Budget Limits On Education In New Jersey
description: Voters in nearly 70 percent of New Jersey school districts that faced new state limits on their spending rejected the restrictions on Tuesday and approved the higher budgets sought by local school officials.

title: France Telecom Value Is Put at $31 Billion
description: France Telecom S.A.'s initial public offering, France's biggest ever, will value the company at 180 billion French francs ($31 billion), analysts and investors said yesterday. The Government is likely to value the company at 12.5 times 1996 earnings from operations. France Telecom's 1996 earnings totaled 14.5 billion francs. The company's profit growth may be limited by labor laws that make it difficult for companies based in France to cut jobs.

title: Zaire Rebels Attract The Fat Checkbooks
description: Mining executives are swarming around Shaba province a week after the mineral-rich region fell to Laurent Kabila and his rebel troops, signing lucrative deals despite Zaire's uncertain future.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: G.O.P. Blithely Seeks Big Donors
description: Undeterred by the furor over campaign fund-raising, Republicans are planning a black-tie dinner next month featuring Congressional leaders in hopes of attracting contributors who will give or raise as much as $250,000 apiece.

title: Dow Rallies For a 3d Day, Gaining 92.71
description: The stock market rose sharply yesterday for its third consecutive gain, as the Dow Jones industrial average extended a rally, helping it recover nearly half the losses it had suffered in the last month.

title: Safeguards Urged for Researchers
description: A group of researchers has called for stronger protection for scientists who make discoveries that threaten vested interests, saying that some have paid a high price.

title: Tobacco Gets Smoked
description: Big tobacco is desperate for peace. Yesterday's revelation that Philip Morris and RJR Nabisco are holding secret settlement talks with tobacco plaintiffs marks a momentous development in the struggle to curb the nation's smoking addiction. There could be no more promising sign that the tobacco barons have finally abandoned their galling hubris and are scrambling to cut the best deal possible before the combined weight of legal, regulatory and public pressures beats them into submission.

title: INVESTORS PAY $48 MILLION FOR 4.5% OF AT HOME NETWORK
description: At Home Network said yesterday that a group of investors including Sun Microsystems and Motorola had paid $48 million for about 4.5 percent of the closely held high-speed Internet-access service, giving the company an implied market capitalization of about $1.1 billion. Other investors were Bay Networks and the Canadian cable companies Rogers Communications and Shaw Communications. At Home, of Mountain View, Calif., said it would continue to expand its network.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE TO PUT $350 MILLION IN MISSOURI PLANT
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it would invest $350 million to add a tissue and towel plant to its diaper factory in Cape Girardeau, Mo. The company, which makes Bounty paper towels and Charmin tissue, said it expected the plant to employ 350 workers in addition to 1,770 workers now there. It said it increased tissue and towel volume by 45 percent in the last five years as demand grew. It has built new paper machines at plants in Albany, Ga., and Oxford, Calif., and is rebuilding machines at other sites to run at higher speeds. With each machine adding 65,000 tons of capacity, production capacity will increase by more than 30 percent over four years, it said. Its shares rose $2.50, to $123.875.

title: In Florida, Referee Can Smell a Rat
description: Because Florida fans delayed games by celebrating goals with showers of plastic rats during the Stanley Cup playoffs last spring, the National Hockey League added Rule 68 (c) Note 1 for this season.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about an effort to create an international code of conduct to combat sweatshops misstated the ownership of the Hathaway Shirt Company, and the error was repeated yesterday in an editorial. Hathaway has been privately held since Nov. 13, 1996, and is no longer a subsidiary of Warnaco.

title: Adjusting Their Dream Downward
description: PATRICK EWING followed through with the right arm on a jump shot from the left side, about 15 feet out, and followed the flight of the ball as it dropped cleanly through the bottom of the net. The arm stayed up as he drifted toward midcourt, but only the index finger remained upright. The dream was alive. The dream for third. Ewing's salute to himself was two fingers short.

title: PHYSICIAN CORPORATION IS IN TALKS ON 'A TRANSACTION'
description: Physician Corporation of America said yesterday that it was in talks that could lead to a capital infusion or the sale of the company. ''In recent weeks several parties have expressed an interest in a transaction with PCA,'' the chairman and chief executive, E. Stanley Kardatzke, said in a statement. The company did not elaborate. On March 18 Sierra Health Services ended an agreement to buy Physician Corporation after disclosure of losses at its workers' compensation unit cut its market value in half. The canceled transaction also left Physician in default of $102 million in bank debt. Shares of the Miami-based company rose 31.25 cents, to $4.75.

title: Germany Charges Compuserve Manager
description: Prosecutors in Germany have indicted the head of Compuserve's on-line computer service here on charges of trafficking in pornography, attempting to hold the company responsible for material that its customers could obtain from sites on the Internet.

title: Let Arafat Deliver Concrete Gesture, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Gingrich to Pay Ethics Fine With Own Money and Loan
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich has decided to take out a loan to pay the $300,000 fine imposed for ethics violations in January, senior aides said tonight.

title: Laws to Protect Patients
description: Governor Whitman signed five bills yesterday that are intended to protect patients and increase security at the state's psychiatric hospitals.

title: The Unscientific F.B.I. Lab
description: When accounts of incredible sloppiness and possible dishonesty at the Federal Bureau of Investigation's high-tech crime laboratory surfaced in January, Director Louis Freeh acknowledged ''serious problems.'' Just how serious those problems are has now been revealed in a new report from his inspector general, Michael Bromwich. The report says that much of the vaunted laboratory's work was amateurish, and, worse, that lab officials who appeared at trials were overly eager to help the prosecution.

title: Reno Air Suing Northwest Over Fare Cuts
description: Reno Air Inc. has sued the Northwest Airlines Corporation for reportedly cutting air fares to force Reno Air out of the Minneapolis-St. Paul market four years ago.

title: A Shore City Tries to Shed A Faded Image
description: THE boardwalk was empty. It was sunny, warm, slightly breezy, the kind of day that could turn an up-tight working stiff into Huck Finn. Yet not a soul was visible as far as the eye could see.

title: Executive Changes
description: CHARLES SCHWAB & CO., New York, named James McMillen as a managing director in its capital markets and trading group and as head of Nasdaq sales trading.

title: Con Edison Stresses Century of Service
description: Consolidated Edison has started an advertising campaign in New York City to encourage its customers to continue using the utility as the effects of deregulation become apparent in the next few years.

description: Garden Antiques

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLICK, OLIVE KATHLEEN (NEE BOOTH)
description: MULLICK-Olive Kathleen (nee Booth), 83, of Monmouth Beach, NJ, formerly of Pelham Manor, NY, on April 14. Daughter of Harmon and Mary Jane (Musgrave) Booth, wife of Louis Frederick Mullick, she is survived by her daughter, Kristin Booth Glen of New York, her son and daughterin-law Kurt and Anna Mullick of Dallas, her grandchildren, Alicia and Samuel Glen and Kurt Mullick, Jr. and her great granddaughter Olivia Glen-Rayner. She was generous, funny, kind and brave, and she touched the lives of many. A memorial service will be held at Saint James Episcopal Church, Long Branch, New Jersey at 3 P.M. on May 3. title: Political Convulsions in Israel
description: Israel, already shaken by a breakdown of the Mideast peace effort, now faces a political crisis. A long-awaited report by Israel's national police has recommended to prosecutors that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu be indicted for fraud and breach of trust in a political appointments scandal. This is a recommendation only, one that prosecutors may ultimately reject. The report also recommends charges against other Netanyahu allies.

title: Strong Data On Output Hurt Bonds
description: Treasury securities were little changed yesterday, a day after prices surged on a report of lower-than-expected inflation. Still, some investors sold after a new report, showing strong manufacturing activity, revived fears of inflation and of a more aggressive stance by the Federal Reserve against it.

title: BALTIMORE GAS-POTOMAC ELECTRIC MERGER CLEARS HURDLE
description: A plan by the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company to buy the Potomac Electric Power Company in a $3.1 billion stock swap was approved yesterday by the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. The merged company, Constellation Energy, will have 4.5 million customers in Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia. The transaction still needs approval from the Maryland and District of Columbia public service commissions, and possibly from Congress. The District commission, in addition to weighing the merger's implications, is also deciding whether to apply a 1913 law restricting outside ownership of its utilities. ''We do see calls for concern at the retail level,'' said Elizabeth A. Moler, chairwoman of the Federal agency. ''However, the commission decided to leave that to the District of Columbia and Maryland public service commissions.''

title: Apple Computer Posts Loss; Sale Advice May Be Sought
description: As expected, Apple Computer Inc. reported a big loss yesterday for its second fiscal quarter. Sales fell from the previous quarter and from the corresponding one a year earlier, but Apple executives said demand had picked up and that the company now had a significant backlog of orders.

description: Investors are increasingly using state courts to bring fraud lawsuits against companies in an apparent attempt to circumvent a new Federal law, a Securities and Exchange Commission study found.

title: A HARCOURT GENERAL BID FOR NATIONAL EDUCATION
description: Harcourt General Inc. said yesterday that it was making a $740 million cash offer for the National Education Corporation, a provider of educational and training services. The offer tops a friendly bid from Sylvan Learning Systems by 15 percent. Harcourt General, a big publisher and the owner of the Neiman Marcus retail chain, said that it would make a tender offer of $19.50 a share. The bid by Sylvan, a provider of education services, is in stock worth about $602 million, or $16.89 a share. The shares of National Education rose $4.375, to $19.375; those of Harcourt General rose $2.125, to $45. Sylvan shares rose $1, to $30.125. National Education would be another channel for distributing Harcourt's educational books.

title: Bid Is Raised for Speedway

It said this offer was a 72 percent premium over the latest offer from Penske Motorsports Inc. Penske, which operates Michigan Speedway and a track in Nazareth, Pa., offered $18.61 a share in cash, or 0.62 Penske common share for each share of the track.

Still another illustration is found in ''Blue Note: A Story of Modern Jazz.'' This two-part essay, with the bassist Ron Carter as host, can be seen on Bravo tonight and next Thursday night. The Julian Benedikt film, initiated in Germany, is a Euro-Arts Production made with support from, among others, Lufthansa Airlines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMERS, BERNARD
description: SAMERS-Bernard. The officers, Board of Directors and staff of the American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology (ATS) mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Bernie Samers. Bernie succumbed after a long and gallant battle with cancer but he faced his illness with courage, grace and dignity and worked creatively until the very end. He fought his disease and pursued his career with the tenacity and sense of humor that were so much a part of his character. He ably filled the position of vice president for administration and vice president for campaign with ATS from 1983 to 1986, when he became the executive vice president of the American Committee for the Weizmann Institute. In making a transition from volunteer to professional in the field of Jewish communal service, he displayed exemplary leadership ability, intelligence, wisdom and dedication to Jewish values. He had a significant impact on both organizations he served and made a major contribution to the American Jewish community and to Israel. Bernie brought out the best in people and he will remain in our hearts. We, his colleagues, extend deepest sympathy to his wife, Edith, and his children, Bill, Michael and Audrey. Irving A. Shepard, President Ben Z. Sosewitz, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Paul Rovinsky, Senior Vice President/Finance Stephen D. Schreier, Senior Vice President/Campaign Beth Wilner, Vice President/Development

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, JOHN N.
description: COOPER-John N. A former president of the New York Intellectual Property Association and longtime senior partner of the law firm of Cooper & Dunham of New York City, died on April 15, 1997, in Stamford, Connecticut. Born in New Brunswick, New Jersey, on November 30, 1910, Mr. Cooper attended Mercersburg Academy and graduated from Brown University in 1932 and from Yale University Law School in 1935. From 1946 until 1986, he was a partner of Cooper & Dunham & its predecessor firms. A litigator in Federal trial and appellate courts, he counseled and represented major corporations in intellectual property matters. In the 1950's he became managing partner of the firm. Mr. Cooper was an officer of the New York Intellectual Property Association (formerly the New York Patent Law Association) in the early 1960's, and served as president of the Association in 1965-66. His other memberships included the Association of the Bar of New York, the New York County Lawyers Association, the New York State and American Bar Associations, and the American Intellectual Property Law Association. A resident of Stamford for more than thirty-five years, Mr. Cooper was a longtime Senior Warden and Honorary Warden of St. Francis Episcopal Church, Stamford, Connecticut. An avid sportsman, he belonged to the Woodway Gun Club, the Indian River Trap Club, the Moorings Club of Vero Beach, Florida and the Atlantic Indians. He is survived by his wife, Jocelyn W., three sons: Jacob H., Peter W., and Nicholas D., two daughters, Cary A. and Nina H., two brothers, Theodore W. Cooper of Houston, Texas, and R. Lawlor Cooper of Woodbury, Vermont; and a number of grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. A memorial service will be held 11 AM Saturday, April 19th at St Francis' Episcopal Church, 503 Old Long Ridge Road, Stamford, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to St. Francis' Church Memorial Fund, 2810 Long Ridge Road, Stamford, CT. 06903.

description: The Governor of Arizona said yesterday that he would sign a bill to neutralize a state ballot initiative that allows doctors to prescribe marijuana, heroin and other generally illegal drugs to sick or dying patients.

description: A conscript in the Chilean Army reserves committed suicide on Tuesday, the ninth such death in the armed forces in the last year, increasing calls by legislators and human rights groups for an end to compulsory military service.

So what better way to celebrate the 100th anniversary of his birth than with ''A Wilder Evening,'' to benefit the colony? Or so the writer's nephew and literary executor, TAPPAN WILDER, reasoned.

title: Marietta Age Suit Pact
description: A Federal judge has approved a settlement valued at about $183 million in a five-year-old age discrimination lawsuit against the Lockheed Martin Corporation's predecessor, the Martin Marietta Corporation, newspapers reported. The agreement between the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and the company, approved by Federal District Judge Wiley Daniel in Denver, provides for $13 million in cash payments to 3,459 former workers who were over 40 when they were dismissed from the company's astronautics division between 1990 and 1995. The rest of the settlement is attributed to salaries over five years to be paid to 450 workers who have been, or will be, rehired at the company's plant in suburban Denver. It does not affect 167 workers whose suits are set for trial in October.

title: HILTON ENDS TALKS TO BUY CLARIDGE HOTEL AND CASINO
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation has ended talks to buy the Claridge Hotel and Casino Corporation of Atlantic City. Claridge did not say why the talks ended. Claridge said in January that it was in talks to be acquired by Hilton, which owns about 40 percent of Claridge's $85 million of outstanding 11 3/4 percent first-mortgage notes. Claridge would have given Hilton 500 more hotel rooms for its Bally's Park Place casino, which is on the Boardwalk in Atlantic City in front of Claridge. Claridge said in December that it was on the verge of filing for bankruptcy because of losses from a costly marketing war. Since then, Claridge made a $5 million interest payment on its bonds.

title: Design Problems Found In Korean Train Project
description: A $12 billion bullet-train line being built in South Korea has been found to be riddled with design flaws and shoddy work. The Korea High-Speed Rail Construction Authority said yesterday that a study it commissioned found that a fifth of a 38-mile section of the line was defective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUGHLIN, RICHARD L., PH.D.
description: LOUGHLIN-Richard L., Ph.D., 89, Bradenton, FL, died April 14, 1997. Former Queens resident. Professor Emeritus, Bronx Community College of the City College of NY, Dr. Loughlin authored/co-authored volumes of poetry, secondary English textbooks and study guides, and hundreds of articles on humor and education. First Lieutenant in the U.S. Army during World War II, served in the Pentagon as historical editor under the Surgeon General. His research and papers on restoring injured/ traumatized soldiers led to increased focus on both physical and psychological rehabilitation methods which today benefit both military and civilian patients. Survivors include wife, Laura; and daughter, Laurie, Nashville, TN. Visitation will be on Sunday April 20 2:00-4:00 PM and 6:00 -8:00 PM at Brown and Sons Funeral Home, 5624 26th Street West, Bradenton, FL 34207. A funeral Mass will be said Monday at 10:00 AM, at Saints Peter and Paul The Apostles Catholic Church in Bradenton.

title: Taiwan Lifts Ban On Exports of Pork
description: Taiwan has lifted a ban on exports of pork and pork-related products, which was imposed after the outbreak last month of an epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease, Board of Foreign Trade officials said yesterday. The end of the ban does not necessarily open the door for pork exports to Japan and other countries, as importing countries will make their own decisions on the purchase of pork products from Taiwan.

title: Sears, Roebuck Profits Up
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that earnings rose in the first quarter as clothing sales increased. Net income, reflecting a gain of $38 million for an accounting change and a loss of $36 million from the sale of the company's interest in Sears Mexico, rose 21 percent, to $182 million, or 46 cents a share, from $151 million, or 36 cents a share, a year earlier. Profit from operations increased 19 percent, to $180 million, or 45 cents a share, from a year earlier, when operating profit and net income were the same. Analysts had expected, on average, a per-share operating result of 43 cents a share. Sears fell $2 on the New York Stock Exchange, to $46.75. Sears said sales rose 9.4 percent, to $7.56 billion from $6.91 billion. Sales at American stores open at least a year, a key barometer of a retailer's business, rose 2.5 percent.

title: Tiger's Best Shot
description: Tiger Woods had just finished winning the Masters. He had handled the course with the grace and sophistication of a Duke Ellington guiding his orchestra through the intricacies of his finest compositions. Now, with the gallery at Augusta watching, and with an enormous television audience also looking on, Tiger Woods walked straight toward his father. The two men embraced, held each other tightly, and as the CBS camera moved ever closer you could see the tremendous emotion on Tiger's face, his eyes squeezed tightly as the tears formed. And still they held each other. Father and child. Father and son.

title: Elf and Total Consider Buybacks of Stock
description: Elf Aquitaine S.A. and Total S.A. said yesterday that they were considering buying back chunks of their own stock in the next few years in a move intended to increase returns to shareholders. The companies, France's two biggest oil refiners, said that they would ask shareholders to approve plans allowing them to buy back stock worth a combined 29.7 billion francs, or $5.11 billion. Elf wants to buy 15 percent of its stock by June 2002. Total wants to buy 6.2 percent by the end of 1998.

title: State Dept. Set For Reshaping, Pleasing Helms
description: President Clinton today approved a plan to reorganize the State Department, senior Administration officials said, a decision that responds to a longstanding demand by Senator Jesse Helms that has snarled foreign policy decisions.

title: Dow's Rally Ends With a Decline of 21.27
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average snapped a streak of three consecutive days of impressive gains.

title: Voucher Program in Danger
description: Lincoln Park's school voucher program may be in danger now that three opponents of the plan have been elected to the Board of Education. Tuesday's districtwide election gave the plan's critics a 5-to-4 majority on the board. Robert Hosley, one of two incumbents who oppose the move to provide vouchers for parents who want to send their children to private or parochial schools, said he would introduce a motion to kill the program on Tuesday when the new members are seated.

title: The Speaker Chooses the Buddy Plan
description: In a speech to the House of Representatives this afternoon, Speaker Newt Gingrich said he had decided to pay his debt to the House by taking out a loan from Bob Dole because that was ''what was best, what was right, morally and spiritually.''

Mr. Manilow wasn't looking for pity: his show was full of his usual good-natured self-chiding about his treacly pop image. He was thanking the audience for sticking with him so long.

title: The Governor's Distorted Prison Plan
description: Gov. George Pataki's latest budget for New York State calls for 7,000 new prison beds, mainly to house violent offenders. But this warmed-over proposal makes no more sense this year than it did last year when Democrats in the State Assembly refused to accept it, calling it an excessive expense. Mr. Pataki should try harder to keep existing prison space from being clogged by nonviolent criminals, thereby freeing cells for those who really need incarceration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERSON, ROBERT L.
description: PIERSON-Robert L. Of Columbiaville, NY. On April 13, 1997. Received master of Divinity degree from Nashota House. He was ordained a priest in 1954. In addition to other parishes he was rector of St. Paul's, Bronx, NY, St. Barnabas, Newark, N.J. and did supply work at St. Paul's Church, Tivoli, N.Y. An active defender of civil rights. Arrested as a participant of the Freedom Rides in Jackson, Miss. in 1963. A war protester and an advocate of women's equality in and out of the Episcopal Church. Worked with migrant apple pickers in Columbiaville, N.Y. Formerly married to Ann R. Roberts, daughter of the late Nelson A. Rockefeller. Beloved father of Clare, Joseph, Mary Louise and Rachel. Loving grandfather to Alta, Jeremiah, Clark, Phebe, Sebastian, Raven, Helen, Barrett, Marnie & Griffin. Beloved brother to Jean Hirst of Milwaukee and friend to many. Services to be held at St. John the Evangelist, Stockport, N.Y., Monday, April 21. Viewing at 10 A.M. Services at 12 Noon. Please make contributions to St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 489 St. Paul's Place, Bronx, New York 10456 in lieu of flowers. His good heart will be missed by all.

title: TRADING IN UNION CARBIDE GROWS ON SALE SPECULATION
description: The trading volume on the Union Carbide Corporation's options increased yesterday with speculation that the company might be for sale. ''Rumors that the company is for sale or that it will have some other positive development are driving the options activity,'' said Jeffrey Spetalnick, an Oppenheimer & Company chemical industry analyst. Options to buy Union Carbide at $47.50 by May 16 rose 21 percent, to $1.8125 in trading of 1,502 contracts. In total, 2,121 of the May $47.50 contracts have traded this week. Union Carbide shares rose $1, to $47.625. A Union Carbide spokesman, David Kernis, declined to comment on whether the company was for sale.
