While independent films flourish, they have nearly eradicated the scrappy B movie, of which this is an agile, enjoyable example.

title: Spanish Company Is Expected To Drop Alliance With AT&T
description: In a major blow to the AT&T Corporation's overseas ambitions, Telefonica de Espana S.A., Spain's telecommunications carrier and the largest communications provider in Latin America, will leave AT&T's global alliance today, people close to the situation said yesterday.

title: People
description: * Andrew Spinelli was named to the new position of advertising manager at Individual Investor magazine, New York, which is published by Individual Investor Group.

title: Art in Review
description: Jason Rhoades

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, CHAIM
description: HERZOG - Chaim. Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the passing of Chaim Herzog, the sixth President of Israel. His memory will be forever cherished by all fellow Zionists for his courageous stand as Israel's ambassador to the UN against the reprehensible 1975 UN resolution equating Zionism with racism. A devoted friend of Hadassah, he had been designated to receive this organization's treasured Henrietta Szold Award this summer at the Hadassah's National Convention. In his varied roles as head of Israeli military intelligence, Israel's ambassador to the UN, Knesset member and then, for 10 years, Israel's president, he brought great honor to the Jewish state and to the Jewish people. Our deepest condolences to his wife Aura and his entire family. May his memory be for a blessing and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marlene E. Post National President Beth Wohlgelernter National Executive Director

title: Rodin and Michelangelo, Together at Last
description: MICHELANGELO BUONARROTI (1475-1564) and Auguste Rodin (1840-1917), two of the most sacred cows of European sculpture, are starring for the first time together, in ''Rodin and Michelangelo: A Study in Artistic Inspiration,'' at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Although there are those who feel that the Florentine and the Frenchman ought not to be mentioned in the same breath, the two have a lot in common aside from their fame, particularly their mutual admiration for Michelangelo's art.

title: The Torture of a Child, The Defense of a Beast
description: Rigid and wide-eyed with terror, 9-year-old Oliver Wyatt (Sam Bould) steals into the recesses of his mother's garage, where he cowers in the darkness like a frightened animal, clutching his injured hand, and waits for his mother to return home from work. Oliver has just been brutally punished by Frank Donally (Jason Flemyng), his mother's architect boyfriend, for some imaginary infraction. It's not the first serious injury Oliver has suffered at Frank's hands, but the boy is scared to tell his mother that the man who has made her so happy is responsible.

title: Israeli Linked To Iran Arms Ordered Jailed
description: Under a cloak of secrecy, an Israeli businessman living in Switzerland was jailed after arriving in Israel last month, apparently on suspicion of arms sales to Iran.

title: Stumbles and Grumbles as Yankees Tumble
description: David Weathers tossed the critical 3-0 fastball and every pair of eyes behind him and every pair of eyes in the Yankee dugout watched Umpire Terry Craft's right arm. It never budged. Craft did not call the close pitch a strike, so John Jaha walked and Fernando Vina walked home with the decisive run in a shocking 5-4 victory by Milwaukee yesterday.

title: A Pliant New Anna Treats The King Like an Equal
description: ''I HATE Anna,'' Christopher Isherwood wrote in his diary in 1956 in a most heretical statement for the Eisenhower years. Isherwood was talking about the plucky, beloved schoolteacher of Rodgers and Hammerstein's ''King and I,'' whom he went on to revile as ''that sweetly smiling, gently snooty apostle of democracy and 'our' way of doing things.''

title: Microsoft Network Loses E-Mail Service
description: Investors in the Microsoft Corporation may have been buoyed by the company's quarterly financial results yesterday, but they could not spread the word via Microsoft's electronic mail service.

title: It's Definitely Ivanhoe, But Robin Hood, Too?
description: Given ''Braveheart,'' ''Rob Roy'' and television's ''Highlander,'' a revival of Sir Walter Scott, the man who virtually invented historical pulp fiction, could hardly be far behind. Behold, sire and fair maid, the BBC and A&E co-production of ''Ivanhoe,'' a six-hour drama being shown on A&E over three consecutive nights, beginning Sunday.

title: Police Close Pizza Shops
description: The police and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents said they shut down a drug ring run by the Sicilian Mafia from two pizzerias in Mount Laurel and Palmyra yesterday when they arrested and charged 12 people, the authorities said. Among those arrested was the leader of the operation, Giacomo Gallina, 32, of Mount Laurel. For at least 18 months, Mr. Gallina, the owner of Stefano's Pizzeria, and his staff used their restaurant as a front for selling hundreds of thousands of dollars of cocaine and heroin a week to dealers and wholesalers across the state, Federal agents said.

title: High Earners Paying No U.S. Income Tax Rose to Nearly 2,400 in 1993
description: Nearly 2,400 of the Americans with the highest incomes paid no Federal income taxes in 1993, up from just 85 individuals and couples in 1977, the latest available information from the Internal Revenue Service shows.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows; Mistake Found in Report

title: ADVANTA TO STOP OFFERING SPECIAL CREDIT CARD
description: The Advanta Corporation said today that it had agreed to stop marketing a credit card that gave customers rewards in an American Express Company program after settling lawsuits with Visa U.S.A. and Mastercard International. Advanta had not marketed the Rewards Accelerator card since the lawsuits first arose in November. The program gave users of Advanta's Visa and Mastercards the opportunity to earn bonuses in ''Membership Rewards,'' an American Express bonus incentive program. Visa and Mastercard objected on the ground that their trademarks were being infringed. Advanta, based in Horsham, Pa., said that none of the companies received any money as part of the settlement.

title: 'The Greatest Thing to Me, Personally'
description: AS the Devils opened their Stanley Cup quest with a 5-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens last night, their left wing with 503 career goals, Dave Andreychuk, was on crutches instead of skates, his fractured left ankle in a cast.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, ANNA
description: BLASER-Anna. April 18, 1989. Cherished mother, we will never forget you. Love, Blaser Family.

title: Antitrust Pact With Australia
description: The United States and Australia reached an agreement today to help each other uncover evidence of antitrust violations, a move intended to strengthen worldwide enforcement of price fixing and other anticompetitive activity.

description: FISCHER-Helen. Beloved wife of the late Harold, devoted mother of James Fischer and Louise Cozzi. Loving grandmother and dear sister. Services at BoulevardRiverside Chapels, 312 Coney Island Avenue at Prospect Park, Brooklyn today at 11:30 A.M.

title: The MGA Roadster: Cool, but No Cup-Holder
description: The three largest investments you are ever likely to make are in a house, a college education and an automobile. A house is expected to increase in value, while the payback on higher education has been well documented.

description: SERCHUK-Janis. It is with deep sorrow that we record the untimely passing of Janis Serchuk, and we extend our deepest sympathy to her husband David and her children Leon and Richard. Old Westbury Golf & Country Club Jeffrey Sands, President Barry Swidler, Secretary

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on the Health page on April 16, about a study of patients who undergo bypass surgery or angioplasty to clear blocked arteries, misstated a major result. The study found that the patients treated only with drugs were six times as likely to die in the next two years as those who received angioplasty -- not that those who received angioplasty were six times as likely to survive.

title: INSIDE
description: SCHUMER TO SEEK D'AMATO SEAT -- Representative Charles Schumer plans to quit his job to run for the Senate. B2.

title: Nordic Study Links Dementia To Drivers in Fatal Crashes
description: A study of the brains of elderly drivers killed in automobile accidents in Sweden and Finland has found that an unusually high percentage, as many as half, showed signs of early Alzheimer's disease, researchers said today. But the condition had not been diagnosed before their deaths, which led the scientists to suggest that even in its preliminary stages, Alzheimer's can cause enough mental impairment to make driving dangerous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SANCHEZ, MARIA DEL PILAR CASTRO
description: SANCHEZ-Maria del Pilar Castro. Beloved wife of Joseph R. Loving sister of Jose Manuel Castro Rodriguez. Sister-in-law of Isabel Probaos de Castro. Godmother of Manuel Castro Probaos. Niece of Francisca Sanchez, Toribio Castro Muniz and Enrique Castro Muniz. Also survived by many loving cousins and a host of friends. Reposing Peter R. Angerame Funeral Home, Inc., 27-12 23 Avenue, Astoria, N.Y. on Friday 2-5 & 7-9. Mass of the resurrection Immaculate Conception R.C. Church, Astoria, Saturday 9:45AM. Medical Center, Office of Development, 550 First Avenue, New York, New York 10016.

title: Midwives Deliver Healthy Babies With Fewer Interventions
description: Women with low-risk pregnancies who choose midwives to deliver their babies have healthy births with fewer medical interventions than those who go either to obstetricians or family-practice doctors, according to a new study of obstetric care.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Considering the fashion sensibilities in the social circle of SAMANTHA KLUGE, it is hardly surprising that a number of the guests at her wedding to ADAM CAHAN in Virginia on Sunday and at the festivities preceding it will be dressed by MARIE-ANNE OUDEJANS, whose Tocca line is a favorite of models and young social leaders.

title: Domestic Violence Help Lines Often Fail Callers, Study Says
description: New York City's system for helping victims of domestic violence is so poorly managed that many women receive no assistance from telephone lines that are supposed to direct them to counseling and shelters, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani agreed, and said he would spend $7 million to try to fix the system.

description: BRUDER-Mark. The Board of Directors and staff of Lawyers for Children, Inc. mourn the untimely death of our friend and colleague, Mark Bruder. His dedication and compassion will be as great a loss to his friends and family as to the thousands of children he tirelessly served. We extend our deepest sympathy to his loving family.

title: Trading of Supercuts Ex-Chief Is Cited
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the former chairman and chief executive of Supercuts Inc. today with saving $621,000 by trading on inside information.

title: Justice Dept. Calls F.B.I. Derelict in Its Pursuit of Most Damaging Spy in C.I.A. History
description: A two-year-long, highly classified internal inquiry at the Justice Department has concluded that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was derelict in failing to aggressively pursue the case that ultimately led to Aldrich H. Ames, the most damaging spy in the history of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: The Great Gold Rush in Zaire
description: Even before the leader of Zaire's rebellion can finish off the dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko and seize this country's capital, a series of major business deals may enable him to resist Western pressures for economic change and democracy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAEBURN, BEN
description: RAEBURN-Ben. 1911-1997. Founder, president, editor, Horizon Press, NYC. Renowned for integrity and quality. Published dozens of pre-eminent writers and creative thinkers, including his close friends Frank Lloyd Wright, Irving Howe, Harold Rosenberg, B.H. Haggin, James Hanley. Admired for his idealism, ethics, high standards, & brilliant, independent intellect. Loved for his graciousness, generosity and wit. Family requests donations to Alzheimer's associations or research.

title: ASHLAND MAY SELL UNIT INSTEAD OF SPINNING IT OFF
description: After originally planning to spin off its oil and natural gas unit, Ashland Inc. is now considering a sale to another company in the face of sliding energy stock prices. In early March, the company filed for an initial offering of roughly 18 percent of the exploration and production business, which it has named Blazer Energy. The idea was to let the market set the unit's value, then spin off the remaining stock to Ashland shareholders. But Ashland officials said yesterday that they would allow third parties to examine the financial and operating information of Blazer Energy. The filing for Blazer estimated an offering price of $24 a share for 17.5 million shares. With debt, that valued the company at roughly $530 million.

title: Chaim Herzog, Former Israeli President, Dies at 78
description: Chaim Herzog, Israel's outspoken President from 1983 to 1993, died yesterday at Tel Hashomer Hospital in Tel Aviv. He was 78 and lived in Herzliya Pituach, a suburb of Tel Aviv.

title: Lower East Side Councilman Is 4th Candidate for Manhattan Borough Chief
description: Striking the most combative tone yet in the race for Manhattan borough president, City Councilman Antonio Pagan officially announced his candidacy yesterday, declaring himself ''the most independent candidate'' and hurling pointed jabs at his rivals and the official he hopes to succeed.

title: Tour Ready to Cash In on Woods
description: On April 28, the PGA Tour will start to discover how valuable its events are, and perhaps whether Tiger Woods will make it substantially richer.

title: Rate Plan Is Opposed
description: By a 71 percent to 14 percent margin, New Yorkers want the freedom to choose their electricity provider and to do so as soon as possible. And 2 to 1, they oppose a Consolidated Edison plan that would give large corporate customers a bigger reduction in energy rates than individual households, according to a statewide survey.

title: Art in Review
description: Ken Price

title: GINGRICH WILL GET A LOAN FROM DOLE TO PAY HOUSE FINE
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich announced today that he would pay his $300,000 fine to the House by borrowing the money from Bob Dole, who called his action ''not only an opportunity to support a friend, but a long-term investment in the future of our party.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NORWEST CORP., Minneapolis, a financial service company, will acquire International Bancorp., Golden Valley, Minn., a bank holding company with 17 sites. Financial terms were not disclosed.

Archaeologist, Architect, Sculptor. Memorial service Sat. 4PM, Round Hill Community Church, Greenwich, Ct. Memorial contributions to the Church.

title: U.S. Denies Request For Funds in Air Crash
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency has denied a request by New York State for the reimbursement of about $12.4 million in expenses related to the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 off the Long Island coast last July, saying it has authority to declare national emergencies only in the case of natural disasters, the State Emergency Management Office said last night.

title: COLUMBIA/HCA TO ACQUIRE HOSPITAL IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a hospital in West Virginia, its first planned acquisition since a Federal investigation of the company began last month. Columbia, the largest United States hospital chain, said that it would pay an undisclosed price for Beckley Hospital in Beckley, W.Va., a private, for-profit hospital with a capacity of 135 patients. On Tuesday, Columbia revised its bid for Value Health Inc. of Avon, Conn., to $1.12 billion in cash from an earlier offer of stock. Columbia shares rose 75 cents, to $35.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: President Clinton has all but settled on Edward M. Gramlich, an economist at the University of Michigan, to fill one of two vacancies on the Federal Reserve Board, an Administration official said tonight.

title: Bell Atlantic Earnings Climbed 11% in the First Quarter
description: Propelled by demand for second phone lines, earnings of the Bell Atlantic Corporation rose sharply in the first quarter. The company, which offers local phone service in six mid-Atlantic states and the District of Columbia, said yesterday that its income rose 11 percent from the comparable period last year, to $515.6 million on revenues of $3.4 billion.

title: Writer's Death Brings Plea For Respect, Not Sensation
description: Louise Erdrich got the word that Michael Dorris, her estranged husband and fellow author, had suffocated himself last Friday in a New Hampshire motel room when a mutual friend called from the scene. She was not surprised.

title: TECHNITROL TO SELL MEASUREMENT DEVICE UNIT TO AMETEK
description: Ametek Inc. said yesterday that it planned to acquire Technitrol Inc.'s test and measurement products business for $34 million in cash. Technitrol's products, sold under the brand names Chatillon and Lloyd, are used to make measurement and test devices to test physical properties like strength and breaking point. Shares of Ametek, based in Paoli, Pa., rose 12.5 cents, to $21.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Technitrol, based in Trevose, Pa., rose 75 cents, to $20.625.

title: More Money, Less Tax
description: The number of Americans who make more than $200,000 but pay no Federal income tax has grown twice as fast as the number who earn more than $200,000.

description: One-month-old 85 Down is not like many restaurants in the East Village. No loud music bombards you. The spare dining room with its pale walls is brighter than expected. In fact, the only objects of decor in this minimalist scheme are the light fixtures. Nothing is fancy or outrageous. This is simply a restaurant for grown-ups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DURAND, HARRISON F.
description: DURAND-Harrison F., one of the nation's leading experts in estate and trust law, died on April 16, 1997, at Martha's Vineyard, Massachusetts, at the age of 93. Prior to moving to Martha's Vineyard in 1995, Mr. Durand and his family resided in Short Hills, New Jersey for over 60 years. From 1973 to 1974, Mr. Durand was President of the American College of Probate Counsel, and from 1964 to 1965 he was Chairman of the Section of Real Property Probate and Trust Law of the American Bar Association. He was active in the reform of the law of probate, wills, trusts, and estate taxation, serving as a member of the Consultative Group for the American Law Institute Study of Federal Estate and Gift Tax Reform in the 1960's. For many years, he was a member of the Joint Editorial Board for the Uniform Probate Code which reformed and updated the probate laws of the various states. He is survived by two granddaughters, Carolyn Durand and Julia Durand, and by a daughter-in-law, Edna Durand. His wife, Anne S. Durand, died on April 1st, 1987, and his two sons, James H. Durand and Murray S. Durand, also predeceased him. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, 66 Highland Avenue, Short Hills, New Jersey, on April 26, 1997 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers, the family would welcome contributions to the American Heart Association, New Jersey Affiliate, 2550 Route 1, North Brunswick, New Jersey 08902-4301, or Legal Services of New Jersey, P.O. Box 1357, Edison, N.J. 08818.

title: Toolbox to Handle New York Account
description: The New York State Department of Economic Development said yesterday that it had named Toolbox Communications in New York as the lead creative agency to handle its spring and summer travel and tourism assignment, known as the ''I New York'' campaign.

Survived also by son, Peter Kolins, a lawyer of Glenhead, NY and beloved daughter, Lisa Stern, a teacher of Bradenton, Fla. and their mother, Mrs. Katherine K. He is Matt Haimovitz, not Arthur Fiacco.

title: NETANYAHU FIGHTS REPORT BY POLICE
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu went on the counteroffensive today against police recommendations that he be indicted for breach of the public trust, defiantly vowing to a gathering of political allies that ''this Government is not going anywhere.''

title: Interpublic Acquires Promotional Agency
description: Draft Direct Worldwide, the direct marketing unit of Interpublic Group of Companies in Chicago, said that it had acquired D. L. Blair Inc., a sales promotion agency in Garden City, L.I. Terms were not disclosed. Blair, which will operate as a separate unit of Draft Direct, has offices in Blair, Neb., and Paris, with a total of 185 employees and billings estimated at $143 million from clients like the Coca-Cola Company, the Walt Disney Company and the Miller Brewing Company, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies Tom Conlon, 61, president of Blair, will continue to head the agency.

title: How Was Your Date Last Night? Dead
description: When Sandra Larson (Molly Parker), a beautiful young woman with hooded blue eyes, a fragile quivering mouth and an erotic attraction to dead bodies, describes making love to a corpse, her language takes on an ecstatic metaphysical lilt.

title: CAPSTAR TO BUY 8 STATIONS AND SWAP 3 OTHERS WITH SFX
description: Capstar Broadcasting Partners Inc., a unit of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., said yesterday that it would buy eight radio stations in Mississippi for $60 million in cash and swap three others with SFX Broadcasting Inc. In addition, Capstar, based in Austin, Tex., said it would pay $70 million to buy closely held Knight Quality Stations, which operates eight radio stations in New England. Capstar is developing clusters of stations in mid-sized markets. Capstar will buy six stations in Jackson and two in Biloxi, Miss., from SFX. It will also trade three stations in Greenville, S.C., for an SFX station in Daytona Beach, Fla., and two in Wichita, Kan.

title: Wheat Prices Surge as Cold And Flooding Hit the Plains
description: Wheat prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after a report showed exports advanced at a time when poor weather is hampering this year's crops.

title: Facing a Fateful Test, Pencils in Hand, Butterflies in Stomach
description: For weeks, Shanee Medley, age 8, trained like an Olympic gymnast for the moment that finally arrived just after 9 yesterday morning: the start of the standardized, city-wide reading examination.

title: 43-Story Hotel Planned Over Shuttered Biltmore Theater
description: A Manhattan developer plans to erect a 43-story hotel over the Biltmore Theater, the shuttered Broadway landmark at 261 West 47th Street where shows like ''Barefoot in the Park'' and ''Hair'' were staged during its long history.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOODBRIDGE, KATHARINE
description: WOODBRIDGE - Katharine, on April 15, 1997 in Raleigh, NC. Wife of George Woodbridge, deceased, and mother of David, Kate and Jane.

title: Democrats Tell White House To Stop Giving on the Budget
description: Senate Democrats angrily told the Clinton Administration today that it had been too quick to make concessions in the bipartisan negotiations to balance the budget, suggesting that the White House should stop rushing to clinch a deal and instead force Republicans to put out a budget proposal of their own and defend it.

title: On Becoming a Dog By Acting Like One
description: UNTIL April 26, Oleg Kulik, a 36-year-old Russian performance artist from Moscow, is living his life as a dog, and a pretty unfriendly one at that. Pit bull is the breed brought to mind by the sound of Mr. Kulik's ferocious growls and barks bouncing off the walls of his cagelike room at Deitch Projects in SoHo; likewise, by the sight of his square, close-cropped head and muscular body as he roams about on all fours, craning at barred windows, growling at onlookers, pausing at water and food bowls and finally curling up on his pallet, all the while wearing nothing but a thick studded collar.
