title: Dole to the Rescue, as a Party Loyalist
description: In classic deus ex machina fashion, Bob Dole, the 73-year-old Republican veteran, materialized unexpectedly in the gloaming on Tuesday and offered Speaker Newt Gingrich a way out of his $300,000 dilemma.

title: Cigarette Ads May Disappear, but Marketing Will Live On
description: If wide-ranging bans on cigarette advertising are eventually enacted as part of a deal with tobacco companies, it will by no means be the end of cigarette marketing, advertising and tobacco industry experts say. Instead, they predict, consumers will simply be confronted with a whole new set of marketing initiatives.

title: McCaughey Ross Says She'll Stay On
description: Lieut. Gov. Elizabeth McCaughey Ross said she had not spoken more than a few formal hellos to Gov. George E. Pataki in nearly a year until shortly after 4 P.M. yesterday, when Mr. Pataki called her.

title: Yeltsin Now Seems Ready to Accept NATO at His Borders
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia today gave his firmest public commitment yet that he would sign an agreement with Western leaders in Paris next month to permit the eastward expansion of NATO to nations that were once part of the Warsaw Pact.

title: No News Is Good News
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Can Bust Be Far Behind the Boom?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, BURT
description: COOPER-Burt. We mourn the loss of our beloved colleague and friend. You were the shining example of what an honest businessman and a good family man should be. Our condolences to your entire family. Bus Association of NY State Russ Ferdinand, President Mark Boungard, Secretary

title: Art in Review
description: Nathan Gluck

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIMMERMAN, RITA
description: ZIMMERMAN-Rita. The Board of Directors, Administration and staff of Peninsula Hospital Center are saddened by the loss of Rita Zimmerman, member of The Board of Directors and President of The East End Auxiliary. Deepest sympathy is extended to the family. Robert V. Levine, President and Chief Executive Officer Joel A. Miele, Sr, P.E., Chairman, Board of Directors

title: BAKER HUGHES TO ACQUIRE DRILEX INTERNATIONAL
description: Baker Hughes Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Drilex International Inc., a provider of drilling products and services, for as much as $109 million in stock. Baker Hughes said that it would pay either $15 or $16 for each outstanding share of Drilex, based in Houston, depending on Drilex's financial performance in the coming months. Drilex stock gained 75 cents, to $14.125 a share in Nasdaq trading. Baker Hughes shares slipped 50 cents, to $35.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. In 1996, Drilex International earned $3 million, or 53 cents a share, on revenue of $76 million. Baker Hughes is also an oil services company based in Houston.

title: Profit at Digital Equipment Fell 59% in Third Quarter
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday reported a 59 percent drop in profits for its third quarter as sales of its flagship computers declined. But the struggling computer manufacturer managed to surpass the low expectations of analysts and sparked a rally in its battered stock.

title: S.&P. May Cut Tobacco Ratings
description: Standard & Poor's Ratings Services said yesterday that it might cut its ratings on debt issued by tobacco companies or their units amid concern the costs of lawsuits against the industry could hurt the companies' ability to pay back bondholders.

title: No Headline
description: ''The Governor called me this afternoon with a short statement that he would be choosing someone else as his running mate in 1998. It was the first time he had talked to me in months. I actually thought he was returning my calls.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORLITZ, FRIEDEL T.
description: HORLITZ-Friedel T., Nee Basler, age 75, of East Hampton formerly of Queens Village, April 16, 1997. Beloved wife of Karl W. Loving mother of Susan Vujnovich, K. Steven, and Janice Stanley. Dear sister of Paula Whitebay. Also survived by five grandchildren. Reposing at Yardley & Pino Funeral Home, Rte. 114, Sag Harbor. Religious services Monday, April 21, 10:00 am at Incarnation Lutheran Church, Montauk Highway, Bridgehampton. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Knicks, With Two to Play, Can't Afford to Lose One
description: Two games remain on the Knicks' regular-season schedule, and with victories in both, they would guarantee themselves the No. 3 spot in the Eastern Conference playoffs and home-court advantage for the first round. But even one loss could drop the Knicks to No. 5, leaving them to open the playoffs on the road.

title: Strike Looms, but Until Then, Victor Ortiz Keeps Busy
description: Being a doorman, Victor Ortiz knows, is not just opening the door and tipping your cap or else anybody could be a doorman. It's not just buzzing people's apartments to advise them that someone is downstairs. It's not just minding packages and dry cleaning. Done right, Mr. Ortiz insists, being a doorman is an art form.

title: A Cleaner City Depends on Teamwork
description: To the Editor:

title: NATO Club Practices Bias in Its Membership
description: To the Editor:

title: Dead Blonde. The President. Uh-Oh.
description: ''Sixteen hundred what?'' asks the stunned Washington homicide detective Harlan Regis (Wesley Snipes) as he receives the fateful call. Yes, it's a lurid crime on Pennsylvania Avenue and another case of First Libel, with the President of the United States implicated in the murder of a beautiful young babe.

title: Settlement Appears Closer On U.N. Diplomats' Tickets
description: After a high-level meeting over the diplomatic parking issue yesterday, both New York City and United States officials said they seemed to be getting closer to a new method of forcing diplomats to pay their parking tickets, an issue that has roiled the previously friendly relationship between Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the United Nations.

title: Bribery Investigation Dropped
description: A South African prosecutor announced yesterday that he would not bring bribery charges against Solomon Kerzner, a step that is likely to smooth the way for the gambling magnate to get a license to operate a casino in Atlantic City.

title: Emilio Azcarraga Milmo, Billionaire Who Ruled Mexican Broadcasting, Is Dead at 66
description: Emilio Azcarraga Milmo, a hard-driving billionaire who built his family's television and radio network into the largest media empire in the Spanish-speaking world, died of cancer Wednesday at a residence he maintained in Miami, a company spokesman said. He was 66.

title: 58% Gain in Quarterly Profit Is Reported by Times Company
description: Citing higher advertising revenues and declining newsprint prices, The New York Times Company reported yesterday that net income for the first quarter rose more than 58 percent.

title: Score One For Goalie As Brodeur Hits Spot
description: Martin Brodeur had been waiting for this moment all his life.

title: If Whites Can Be Silly ...
description: The subject of ''Black and White TV,'' a brief documentary on MTV, is the ghettoization of television. Ratings lists of what whites watch bear little resemblance to what blacks watch. And now that the new networks, WB and UPN, are intentionally revving up the competition with black-theme shows, the divide seems even more daunting. This program, to be broadcast tomorrow night at 10:30, pushes all the familiar buttons but with some interesting variations.

title: Lack of Intensity Worries Campbell
description: At the conclusion of the Rangers' practice today, Wayne Gretzky and Coach Colin Campbell talked seriously for seven minutes near a side wall in a suburban rink.

title: Whitman Plans Late Push For Her Plan on Borrowing
description: With Senate passage of her plan to borrow billions of dollars for the state pension system far from assured, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that she would call Republican lawmakers this weekend before the scheduled vote on Monday.

title: Down Under, Tourism As the Growth Industry
description: It's 4 P.M.: pelican-feeding time. Mitsuru and Noriko Inawashiro, Nikons at the ready, look down from rocks above the golden and indigo bay as a bearded man in waders flings fish heads and tails at the squawking, hovering birds.

title: Dead but Not Forgotten: Body Art
description: From countless paintings of the Crucifixion to 19th-century battle scenes, from Rembrandt's depictions of anatomy lessons to Andres Serrano's photographs taken in morgues, dead bodies have long been present in art. Now, by making molds of heads, torsos and limbs of cadavers, a London sculptor has gone a step further -- perhaps a step too far.

title: WITH SALE IN QUESTION, POTOMAC ELECTRIC SHARES FALL
description: Shares of the Potomac Electric Power Company fell to a 52-week low yesterday after the Baltimore Gas and Electric Company said it might scuttle its planned $3.04 billion acquisition of the utility, based in Washington. Potomac's shares fell $1.75, to $22.25, on the New York Stock Exchange after touching $21.125 earlier. Baltimore Gas and Electric's shares rose 75 cents, to $25.75. Maryland has asked Baltimore Gas and Electric to cut prices $56 million if it acquires Potomac. Baltimore said on Thursday that it would not buy the neighboring utility unless Maryland changed its terms. Baltimore Gas and Electric officials would not comment on whether the utility would consider changing the terms of its agreement with Potomac.

title: Argentina Dispersing the Nazi Cloud
description: Long criticized for harboring Nazi war criminals, Argentina is now winning praise from some Jewish groups for its efforts to track down Nazis who came here after World War II and to locate stolen assets they may have brought with them.

title: Hong Kong's Freedoms
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Is Ordering Dependents Of Embassy to Leave Zaire
description: The State Department today ordered all dependents of American Embassy personnel to leave Zaire because of the ''uncertain political and security situation and the potential for unrest throughout the country.''

title: The No. 13-Seeded Nets Hand Heat a Surprise
description: The Miami Heat played with the tentativeness and caution of someone trying to walk and balance a book on his head. With the Atlantic Division title secured and a 60-victory season, too, the Heat failed the delicate challenge of trying to protect its health and incentive clauses while playing a basketball game at the same time.

title: Polish Virtuoso Braves The Standards for Piano
description: On paper, the program the Polish pianist Krystian Zimerman brought to Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night did not look adventurous. Haydn's stately Sonata No. 44 in E flat is not so often heard. But Beethoven's late Sonata No. 30 and Schubert's sprawling Sonata in A Major, written in the last year of that composer's life, are repertory staples.

title: This Dehydrated Isle, Demi-Desert, This England
description: There hasn't been a rainy day, much less a foggy one, in London this spring, but the extended spell of cloudless blue skies and warmth hasn't stopped the English from complaining about their weather.

title: Court Urged to Bar Protesters
description: Citing a Federal law that forbids preventing patients from entering abortion clinics, the Justice Department filed a civil complaint yesterday against 30 protesters who had repeatedly blockaded the entrance to an Englewood women's clinic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STERN, MARVIN
description: STERN-Marvin. Labor organizer, died on April 17, devoted father of Joan and Dan, cherished grandfather, companion of Bea. Memorial will be announced.

title: MGM Owner Said to Offer $300 Million to Buy Orion
description: Kirk Kerkorian just cannot stop buying. Mr. Kerkorian, the reclusive billionaire who acquired MGM for the third time last year, is now in talks to acquire Orion Pictures from John W. Kluge for about $300 million, a person close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: Bell Atlantic Suit Rejected
description: Starting May 5, New Jersey telephone customers will be able to choose their local toll-call carrier just as they choose their long-distance company, a Federal judge ruled yesterday. United States District Judge Nicholas H. Politan rejected a bid from Bell Atlantic-New Jersey to delay the starting date imposed by state regulators.

title: Pork Traders
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tense Israel Waits: Will Netanyahu Be Charged?
description: Israel's chief prosecutor said today that she had concluded her review of the police investigation of the influence-peddling scandal and would announce the results on Sunday. Israeli television said it appeared that neither Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu nor two senior members of his Government would be indicted.

title: What's the Moral of a Story on Plagiarism?
description: To the Editor:

title: Telefonica de Espana Ends AT&T Alliance
description: Telefonica de Espana S.A. said yesterday that it had chosen the MCI Communications Corporation and its British partner, British Telecommunications P.L.C., to join in its lucrative Latin American operations, a venture that could redraw the map of global telecommunications alliances. The announcement had been expected. By moving to pull out of its alliance with the AT&T Corporation, Telefonica is dealing a major setback to the AT&T's global ambitions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about a turnaround at the Bankers Trust New York Corporation misstated the given name of the company's chief executive. He is Frank N. Newman, not Fred.

title: A Debut With Resonance, A Family With a Problem
description: Let's get one thing out of the way right away about ''In the Gloaming,'' the hourlong drama on HBO tomorrow. A man in his late 20's must use a wheelchair and is dying of AIDS. The director is Christopher Reeve, who, as is widely known, must use a wheelchair after a horse-jumping accident. Subliminal anxieties? Freudian undertones? Who cares? The fact is, Mr. Reeve makes an enormously impressive directorial debut.

title: Amex to Settle With Investors
description: The American Stock Exchange will reimburse investors who sold shares of the Castle Convertible Fund below $21.50 on Tuesday, when the stock fell 32 percent in 22 minutes, the fund's manager said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKEFELLER, MARY FRENCH (MRS. LAURANCE S.)
description: ROCKEFELLER-Mary French (Mrs. Laurance S.) It is with the deepest sense of loss that The Boards of Overseers and Managers of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center mourn the death of the beloved Mary French Rockefeller, wife of our honorary chairman & benefactor, Laurance S. Rockefeller and the mother of our colleague Dr. Lucy R. Waletzky. She was a leader in our society, a dear friend, mentor and model of commitment and dedication to the goals of our Center. Above all else, she was a gentle spirit whose belief in tending to the intangible needs of the human heart bettered our lives and the lives of our patients. Mrs. Rockefeller's commitment to Memorial Sloan-Kettering over the last 30 years has left a legacy that is everywhere visible at our Center for she focused on the aesthetic and spiritual environment for patients and staff. Mrs. Rockefeller said it best herself: ''For the patients, we hope that having something beautiful to look at brings them peace or strength or respite. That's our main concern.'' She brought us all that and much, much more. On behalf of The Boards, our staff and patients, we extend our condolences to the entire Rockefeller family. We are grateful to have been able to share in her unique qualities. Benno C. Schmidt, Honorary Co-Chairman James D. Robinson III, Chairman, Board of Overseers Douglas A. Warner III, Chairman, Board of Managers H. Virgil Sherrill, Vice-Chairman Richard L. Gelb, Vice-Chairman Paul A. Marks, M.D., President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the Muslim holiday Id al-Adha, the Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Winners of the Rome Prize For Work and Study Abroad
description: The winners of the annual Rome Prize Competition have been announced by the American Academy in Rome, a center for independent study, research and creative work in the arts and humanities. The prizes are administered by the academy at its headquarters in New York City and include travel benefits, stipends and living and working accommodations on the academy's Rome campus for six months to two years.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: A HOUSE DIVIDED -- With a possible strike looming, service workers and residents at one apartment building on the Upper West Side are making preparations. Page 23.

title: Honda to Raise Exports to U.S.
description: The Honda Motor Company plans to increase its United States-bound auto exports from Japan by roughly one-third this year to meet strong demand for some of its models.

title: State Jobless Rate Drops
description: New Jersey gained more than 4,000 new jobs last month, pushing the unemployment rate down to 5.5 percent, from 5.6 percent, the State Department of Labor reported yesterday. An estimated 21,400 jobs were created in the first quarter of this year, an 18 percent increase over the same period in 1996, a department spokesman said. The national unemployment rate is 5.2 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBS, NATHAN
description: JACOBS-Nathan. Your legend grows-incredible courage, honesty, principle and total commitment. I love you-Julia

title: Dow Surges To End One Of Best Weeks
description: Stock prices rose yesterday, helping the Dow Jones industrial average cap its best week in more than five years.

title: Scientists Find A Key Weapon Used by H.I.V.
description: Scientists have discovered the precise mechanism by which H.I.V., the AIDS virus, penetrates the membrane of the cells it infects.

title: NIAGARA ACQUIRES LASALLE STEEL FROM QUANEX
description: The Niagara Corporation bought the LaSalle Steel Company yesterday from the Quanex Corporation for $65.5 million in cash plus closing adjustments. The acquisition, combined with a Niagara unit, the Niagara Cold Drawn Corporation, forms the largest maker of cold-finished steel bar products in the United States, with yearly production of more than 300,000 tons. Niagara, a metals maker based in New York, said the purchase would give the company the widest geographic coverage and product range in the industry. Quanex, based in Houston, makes specialized metal products. LaSalle Steel makes cold-finished and chrome-plated bars.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Mary Rockefeller, Women's Advocate, Dies at 86
description: Mary French Rockefeller, the wife of Laurance S. Rockefeller and for more than four decades active in promoting leadership opportunities for women, died at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center on Thursday from injuries she suffered in a fall in her Manhattan apartment. She was 86, and a family spokesman said she had been in failing health for several years.

title: Argentina's Stance on Nazi Past Has Changed
description: To the Editor:

title: I.N.S. Doing Little To Bar Criminals
description: Safeguards issued last year to prevent immigrants with criminal records from becoming citizens have largely been ignored by the agency that was supposed to carry them out, auditors said.

title: A Precisely Timed Divorce
description: That which Alfonse D'Amato joined together has now been torn asunder. It was Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross's own consummately weird behavior that got her kicked off New York State's prospective G.O.P. ticket for 1998. One does not have to agree with Gov. George Pataki's policies to accept the premise that every governor has a right to expect a No. 2 who either supports his administration or airs any differences in private. It is the same suffer-in-silence rule that applies to Vice Presidents and deputy mayors.

title: Beliefs
description: John Erickson moved deliberately through ''The Glory of Byzantium'' exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, taking in the full array of illuminated manuscripts, processional crosses, small and large mosaics, fragments of frescoes, painted icons, gold and enameled medallions and ivory carvings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATMAN, JEFFREY T.
description: LATMAN-Jeffrey T. The Chinatown Health Clinic and The Asian Health Center of Flushing deeply regret the loss of Jeffrey T. Latman. Jeff was a mentor, valued advisor and true friend of the Clinic. He guided us in our growth and development. To Neal and the entire Latman family, we send our heartfelt sympathy. Jane T. Eng Marie Lam Pyser Edelsack Sandra Lee Kawano Lynn Sherman Board of Directors and Staff of the Chinatown Health Clinic

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the partial reopening of cod fisheries off Newfoundland misstated the authority responsible for lifting the ban. It was the Canadian Government, not the Newfoundland provincial government.

title: Dissing the Dalai Lama
description: The Dalai Lama is coming to Washington next week and would like to talk to President Clinton about what the United States can do to help ease China's tightening stranglehold on his country, Tibet. But, fearful of annoying China, President Clinton is reluctant to have a formal meeting with this worldwide symbol of peace and reconciliation.

title: INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY LIVE ENTERTAINMENT
description: Live Entertainment Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by the closely held investment group Richland, Gordon & Company for at least $150 million in cash and assumed debt. Holders of the film and video distributor's series B preferred stock will receive $10 a share in cash plus accrued dividends. Holders of its common shares will receive $6 in cash. The companies declined to give a value for the transaction or say how much holders of Live's series C preferred shares would receive. Live, based in Los Angeles, said the transaction would recapitalize it and put it on firmer financial ground. Shares of Live rose 12.5 cents, to $5.75, in Nasdaq trading. The shares rose $1.25 a week ago yesterday as speculation grew that a transaction was near.

title: Gun Program to End
description: For the last two weeks, the Montclair Police Department has been paying gun owners to turn in their weapons. The program will have to end today because of a lack of funds, officials said yesterday.

title: Chicago Trading to Extend
description: The Chicago Board of Trade, the nation's largest exchange for trading futures contracts, plans to lengthen its standard trading day by one hour and change the hours of other parts of its operation. Its board voted Thursday to extend the closing time of the open outcry session to 3 P.M. from 2 P.M., central time. The opening of the open outcry session remains 7:20 A.M. The changes are scheduled to take effect April 2, 1998.

title: NEC to Spend Heavily On Production of Chips
description: The NEC Corporation, one of the world's largest makers of computer chips, said yesterday that it would spend 400 billion yen ($3.17 billion) on its production of semiconductors in the next three years. That is more than its planned capital spending on electronics or telecommunications in the same period, the company said yesterday on the opening of a semiconductor plant in Hiroshima.

title: Lacking Space, N.Y.U. Seeks Governors Island Expansion
description: New York University has approached the city about buying part of Governors Island for use as athletic fields, student housing or classroom space, officials said yesterday.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Show Slight Gains
description: Treasury prices edged higher in a quiet session yesterday.

title: Helicopter Crash Inquiry Focuses on Broken Parts
description: Federal investigators said yesterday that it could take more than a week to determine the cause of a fatal crash of a corporate helicopter in the East River on Tuesday. They said they had narrowed the search for an explanation to the helicopter's tail rotor and drive shaft.

title: A Big Game Already for MetroStars
description: The Major League Soccer season is hardly a month old and already the MetroStars are faced with a game they simply cannot afford to lose.

title: Central Americans Feel Sting Of New U.S. Immigration Law
description: At the height of the civil war here, as the United States was spending billions of dollars to prop up El Salvador's military, hundreds of people from this small town fled the violence that engulfed their country and made their way to Washington. They took jobs at hotels and construction sites or as household help for members of the United States Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, CHAIM
description: HERZOG-Chaim. The American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science notes with sorrow the passing of a dynamic diplomat and statesman, who served his country and his people with unsurpassed devotion. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire Herzog family. Gershon Kekst, Chairman Weizmann Institute of Science Haim Harari, President S. Donald Sussman, Chairman American Committee Robert G. Begam, President Fran Ginsburg, Executive Director

title: U.S. and Russia Toe to Toe Over Treasures of the Czars
description: Outside the Corcoran Art Gallery near the White House this evening, cars from the Russian Embassy were blocking a truck that was supposed to have left for Houston three days ago with the Romanov jewels, along with costumes and portraits from imperial Russia.

title: Fire Near Station Disrupts Train Service
description: Train service on Amtrak, New Jersey Transit and the Long Island Rail Road was disrupted yesterday evening when fire broke out aboard an Amtrak engine heading into Pennsylvania Station after being serviced at the Sunnyside Yards in Queens.

title: On Aspects of Love After 40
description: Mark Morris received the Capezio Dance Award onstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Thursday night, just before the New York premiere of ''I Don't Want to Love,'' a work he has set to seven Monteverdi madrigals.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SONN, CARL ROBINSON
description: SONN-Carl Robinson. August 1, 1929 to April 19, 1995

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a performance by the New York New Music Ensemble at the Kaye Playhouse on Monday night misstated the age of Aaron Einbond, a composer whose work was performed. He is 18, not 19.

title: Tiger's Double Bogey
description: There have been other disses of historic proportion.

title: Labor Leader Investigated For Remarks
description: Secret Service officials said yesterday that they were investigating comments about assassinating presidents that were made this week by Gus Bevona, the president of the union representing the more than 30,000 New York City apartment building workers who might go on strike this Monday.

title: For Basie, Red Hot Blues
description: The blues settled into Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night with the arrival of the singer Dennis Rowland. Mr. Rowland was there to play the role of Jimmy Rushing and Joe Williams for Jazz at Lincoln Center's show, ''Swingin' the Blues for Count Basie.'' He's a spectacular blues singer, pleading, hollering with joy, opening his eyes to the sky to emphasize the words, holding out his heart in his hands. And he perfectly captured the music's emotional complexity: in ''Goin' to Chicago,'' taken at a euphoric dance tempo, he sang some sweet lines of revenge to a lying lover, then finished up by addressing the mean and evil woman with, ''But you got my brand of honey, so I'll put up with you.'' It was at once honest and liberating; what Mr. Rowland dispenses should be sold at drugstores.

title: VORNADO REALTY BUYS SHOPPING CENTER IN PUERTO RICO
description: Vornado Realty Trust said yesterday that it had acquired a shopping center in San Juan, P. R., from the Kmart Corporation for $74 million. The Montehiedra Town Center has 525,000 square feet, including a 135,000-square-foot Kmart store. Vornado, based in Saddle Brook, N.J., said $63 million of the purchase price was in newly issued 10-year debt securities. Vornado, a real estate investment trust, also agreed to acquire Kmart's 50 percent interest in the Caguas Centrum Shopping Center, which is under construction in Caguas, P. R., but financial terms were not disclosed.

title: No Headline
description: ''I was thinking about calling Senator Dole this afternoon. You know, Chelsea is about to go to college. . . .''

title: When Electronic Echoes Take Over for Melody
description: Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's Making Music series at Weill Recital Hall offers a ground-floor introduction to contemporary composers and their work. It is not quite a matter of spoon-feeding: each concert focuses on a single composer, who is interviewed by Ms. Zwilich between performances. The discussions are informal and nontechnical, but they offer occasional glimpses into the composer's process and personality.

title: Edgy Denver Is Bracing For Chance Of a Threat
description: While waiting every weekday for the No. 44 bus, Brian Mohr, a 31-year-old freight forwarder, has watched his bus stop gradually become part of the most heavily guarded city block in the United States.

title: The U.N.'s Deadbeat Dads
description: Mention the United Nations, and many New Yorkers immediately think resentfully of unpaid parking tickets. But consider that the same treaties that protect diplomats from criminal, civil and administrative prosecution also shelter them and other U.N. staff members from court orders to pay child support.

title: When Women Make Music
description: As a music director and conductor of a regional symphony orchestra, I not only rehearse and conduct the concerts, but also serve as an administrator and organizer. In effect, I am the C.E.O. of a company whose product is music.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLSTED, MARTIN
description: WILLSTED-Martin. Beloved husband of the late Rose Willsted. Beloved father and father-in-law of Alice and Arnold Schultze. Cherished grandfather of Melissa and Joseph Lonski, Wendy Schultze and fiance Robert Ziegler, and great grandfather of Joseph Tyler. We love you Dad and Grandpa. Service Sunday 11 AM, Follett & Werner 516-288-1231. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: A.A.R.P. Dropping Plans for Royalties In a Health Program
description: The American Association of Retired Persons said yesterday that it had revised a sharply criticized plan to endorse selected health maintenance organizations, dropping a proposal to collect royalty payments for each of its members who joined an H.M.O.

title: S.E.C. Inquiry at the Philadelphia Stock Exchange
description: In another sign that America's oldest stock exchange is also its most troubled, Federal regulators are investigating whether units of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange shortchanged some investors and violated securities laws.

title: John Major Runs Against Europe
description: Surrendering to a revolt by the isolationist, anti-Europe wing of his Conservative Party, Prime Minister John Major of Britain seems prepared to turn the remaining two weeks of his faltering re-election campaign into a Europe-bashing crusade. That is regrettable. Mr. Major's centrist leadership on Europe and other issues was one of the Conservatives' strongest selling points.

title: Extension Expected for Whitewater Panel
description: The life of the Federal grand jury investigating a variety of Whitewater matters in Little Rock, Ark., will probably be extended an additional six months, Government officials said today.

title: Simplifying Spanish Won't Be So Simple
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBER, ALAN RICHARD
description: GRUBER-Alan Richard. Age 69. On April 17, 1997. Beloved husband of Harriet (Mandel), loving father of James (Janet Elgar), Marian (Walter Montgomery) and Steven (Elizabeth Strauss) and delighted grandfather of Caleb, Kirsten, Abigail, Samuel, Matthew, Lucas, David, Rebecca, Emily, Johanna and Jonathan. Former Chairman and CEO of Orion Capital Corporation. Also survived by his mother Esther Gruber and sister Althea Landau. Service Sunday, April 20, 12pm at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations maybe made to the M.I.T. Gruber Family Fund.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Citicorp Official to Retire; String of Departures Grows

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 25 about Vice President Al Gore's appearance in Beijing at the signing of two business deals with China, including the sale of five Boeing 777-200 jetliners, misidentified the airline that would use them. It is Air China, the national airline, not China Air.

title: Bruins Dismiss Kasper as Coach
description: The Boston Bruins fired Coach STEVE KASPER yesterday after the team failed to make the playoffs for the first time in 30 years. Kasper had just completed his second season as coach.

title: PRESIDENT PRESSES FOR BUDGET DEAL AND ARMS TREATY
description: President Clinton today appealed for Congressional support on two crucial tests of his leadership: a bipartisan agreement on the Federal budget and a vote, scheduled for Thursday, to ratify a treaty banning chemical weapons.

title: L. Brent Bozell, 71, a Champion of Conservatism
description: L. Brent Bozell, a writer and longtime champion of conservative political causes, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md. He was 71 and lived in Washington.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter published April 15 from Harris L. Present on rent regulation rendered a sentence incorrectly. It should have read: ''First, all residential buildings in the city built at the present time without government subsidy are entirely free of regulation and can be rented at the market rate.''

title: Immigration Procedures Are Criticized
description: A set of sweeping safeguards issued late last year to prevent some immigrants with criminal records from becoming citizens have been largely ignored by the agency that was supposed to carry them out, auditors hired by the Government said today.

title: Pataki Battles His No. 2, But by Proxy
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday designated the State Parks Commissioner, a woman, to answer the flurry of questions about his decision this week to dump another woman from his re-election team, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross. It was the second act in an outsized drama over what is in fact the state's least influential elective position.

title: Harnisch Is Told To Take His Time
description: Pete Harnisch considered returning to the Mets yesterday for his first workout since leaving the team on April 6. However, club officials discouraged that idea and asked him to see another psychologist on Monday, before he comes back.

title: Stocks Roar Back
description: No sooner had the stock market rattled investors by slumping sharply and surrendering nearly all its gains for the year than the Dow turned around and posted its strongest week since 1993. Business Day, page 33.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIRTH, GUNTHER
description: WIRTH-Gunther. The Officers, Directors and Members of the Club Managers of the City of New York sadly announce the death of our friend and colleague. For many years, Gunther devoted himself, unselfishly, to the interests of club management. To all of us in the industry, he was and always will be an idol. The example he set will long continue to influence and inspire us. It is difficult indeed to find the words to express our regret at the death of this splendid man. To the family of Gunther Wirth, please accept for yourself, and all who mourn with you, our assurance of heartfelt sympathy.

title: Federal Judge Refuses to Grant Another Delay in Gigante Trial Without a Doctor's Note
description: An angry Federal judge declared yesterday that the trial of Vincent Gigante, the suspected Mafia boss, would proceed as scheduled, voicing strong doubt about his lawyers' claims that the defendant is too sick from a heart ailment to prepare for the case.

title: A Bad Face, Even if It's On Plagues
description: For those who like blood and gore, for those who enjoy shivering over scary diseases ready to strike without notice, ''The Coming Plague,'' a two-part series on TBS, is actually kind of enjoyable. The series includes film clips of plagues past, like polio, complete with a toddler fitted with crutches and struggling to drag himself across a lawn. It also includes a truly creepy close-up of a face that starts with a few pimples and morphs into a decaying, pustule-ridden visage of a smallpox victim.

title: The F.B.I.'s Limited Cleanup
description: By punishing the whistle-blower who finally forced the Federal Bureau of Investigation to begin to address the lack of professionalism and honesty in its legendary crime lab, Director Louis Freeh has sent a chilling message sure to deter future critics from coming forward. This makes one wonder how genuine the bureau's commitment is to cleaning up its lab. The whistle-blower, Frederic Whitehurst, has been put on indefinite paid administrative leave and barred from the lab.

title: House Campaign Inquiry May Include Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Eagle to Call Jets Games
description: IAN EAGLE, the television voice of the Nets for SportsChannel, will call Jets games this season for WFAN Radio, alongside DAVE JENNINGS. Eagle replaces PAUL OLDEN, who had succeeded MARTY GLICKMAN. ''We felt we wanted to make a change,'' said JOEL HOLLANDER, WFAN's general manager. Eagle is a veteran of WFAN as a talk-show host and as host of the Jets' pre- and post-game radio shows.

title: Wheat Prices Up as Estimates Of Freeze Damage Are Raised
description: Wheat prices surged yesterday on exchanges in the Midwest as some crop forecasters said last weekend's freeze in the Plains had done more damage than had been previously thought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERT, FLORENCE
description: LIEBERT-Florence. Beloved and devoted mother of Robert and Michelle, loving grandmother of Jason and Sara. Was a well-loved teacher and best friend to all. Services 11:30AM, Sunday, at ''Parkside Chapel'', Queens Boulevard and 66th Avenue, Forest Hills.

title: Power-Broker at Center of Scandal
description: The man in the middle of the influence-peddling scandal threatening Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Government, Aryeh Deri, is no stranger to police investigations and criminal indictments.

title: Wannabe Tells All
description: I'd like to be Martha Stewart. Then I would never have to interrupt my cooking to go shopping for the hand-woven Malaysian cheesecloth without which it is impossible to bake a brace of mallards to perfection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHNER, LOUISE CELENKO
description: KUSHNER-Louise Celenko. Wife of Bernard. Mother of Ann, David, Peter and Pinky. Nana to Rachel, Jake and Jennifer. Great-grandnana to Mara. Many fond nieces, nephews, great and grand; and numerous friends.

title: Bridge
description: There are no cash prizes at team events in the New York area this year, but three give a cash equivalent: the Grand National Teams, Flights A, B, and C, divided by master-point holding. The winners get a free trip to the national playoffs in Albuquerque, N.M., in July.

title: Dorothy Frooks, Lawyer and Suffragist, Dies
description: Dorothy Frooks, who stumped for women's suffrage as a child, recruited thousands of men to World War I service as a teen-ager, and then spent most of the century as a lawyer and political gadfly, died on Sunday at Veterans Hospital in Manhattan. She was about 100 and lived in Manhattan and Peekskill, N.Y.

title: In Peru, Shell Listens to the Community
description: To the Editor:

title: A Navy Base Takes a Dive
description: There's the scene of a panic-stricken David Alan Grier turned into a squishy human cannonball when the inflated wet suit he is wearing is punctured by a cigar, and there's the scene in which a sailor pops open a beer bottle with his eye. But that's it for the jokes that land in ''McHale's Navy,'' the leaky PT boat of a comedy, descended from the television series, that sloshed into theaters yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOUGH, HUGH
description: GOUGH-Hugh, of New York, maker of harpsichords, clavichords, and fortepianos. Died April 14, 1997. Beloved husband of Christabel, dear uncle of Nick Lera of London and dear great-uncle of Justine Lera of Sydney, Australia. The funeral service will be held at The Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, on Saturday April 19, at 11 A.M.

title: Remedies for Piracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a meeting between President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany referred imprecisely to Mr. Yeltsin's policy on the eastward expansion of NATO. While he has indicated a willingness to allow the admission of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to the Western alliance, he has never hinted that NATO would be welcome throughout the territory of the former Warsaw Pact.

title: Worries Over the Euro Elbow Other Issues Aside
description: The increasing likelihood that the European Union will go ahead on schedule with a bold plan to start a common currency in 1999 has made it the defining issue of domestic politics across the 15-nation group.

title: Internet Access Puts Burden of Control on Schools
description: More than half the nation's public schools have access to the Internet and hundreds more could join them in the coming weeks, as volunteers lay the wiring through a monthlong project known as Net Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DESANCTIS, MARY C.
description: DeSANCTIS-Mary C.. on April 16, 1997. Funeral Mass Monday, 10AM at St. Thomas More Church. Interment Most Holy Trinity Cemetery, East Hampton, New York.

title: Grumbling, Giuliani Accepts Truce in U.N. Parking War
description: The melodramatic struggle over how to make diplomats pay their parking tickets in New York City drew to an uneasy close yesterday when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani reluctantly settled for a weakened version of the enforcement plan he originally wanted.

title: Echostar and G.M. Unit Lose Court Battle
description: The Echostar Communications Corporation and the General Motors Corporation's DirecTV lost a court battle over how to divide direct broadcasting channels once controlled by the Advanced Communications Corporation.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COS., St. Louis, agreed to take an undisclosed minority stake in the closely held Widmer Brothers Brewing Co., Portland, Ore., and distribute its beer, gaining a bigger piece of the growing United States specialty beer market.

title: Lack of Marquee Stars Puts Top Draft Choices on Trading Block
description: The spotlight in today's National Football League college draft is squarely focused on Orlando Pace, the splendid offensive tackle from Ohio State.

title: Steinbrenner Will Waste No Time With Changes
description: After less than three weeks of sluggish baseball, George Steinbrenner has seen enough of the bumbling Yankees masquerading as defending World Series champions. The antsy owner told Manager Joe Torre and General Manager Bob Watson during a telephone conference call today that he will make alterations to a team that had lost five straight games before tonight's 10-4 victory over the White Sox and that is still stuck in last place in the American League East.

title: Ravens and Giants May Deal
description: Art Modell, the Baltimore Ravens' owner, said an agreement has been reached with the Giants that if certain players were not available to them at No. 4, the Ravens would trade the pick to the Giants for their No. 7 pick and a third-round choice.

title: A Pianist Pacing the Tides
description: Jazz innovations have traditionally come from soloists; big bands organize that work and make it orchestral. McCoy Tyner, the pianist who changed the sound of jazz in the 1960's as a member of John Coltrane's quartet, occasionally breaks out his big band, and on Tuesday night at the Blue Note, the orchestrations were woolly, exuberant and open-ended.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PLASTIK, CLAIRE
description: PLASTIK-Claire. Beloved wife of the late Ted. Loving mother of Richard and David. Devoted sister. Cherished friend. Services 9:45AM, Sunday at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: INSIDE
description: Europe Girds for Change

title: Hudson Battle Heats Up Over Standard & Poor's
description: In an escalating border war, state and city officials in New York are assembling a package of tax breaks and other incentives to keep Standard & Poor's from accepting a lucrative offer to move its headquarters and 2,000 employees to New Jersey.

title: Freddie Mac Sells Criticized Bonds
description: Under pressure from the House Banking Committee chairman, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today that it had sold its holdings of Philip Morris bonds.

title: CHIEF OF WMX WOULD GIVE UP DUTIES FOR RIGHT SUCCESSOR
description: WMX Technologies Inc.'s chairman and chief executive, Dean Buntrock, would ''forfeit all management duties'' to attract a first-rate successor, a company spokesman said yesterday, confirming a report in The Wall Street Journal. Mr. Buntrock, 65, has been acting chief executive of the waste-hauling company since February, when Phillip Rooney resigned under pressure from shareholders, including a group led by the investor George Soros. WMX, of Oak Brook, Ill., has been searching for Mr. Rooney's replacement.

title: The Loser In This Game Is Irabu
description: HIDEKI IRABU has been called the Japanese Nolan Ryan, but the longer baseball fumbles what should have been a small-time dispute, he begins to look a little more like an international version of the late Curt Flood. Rebel with a cause, resisting rules that allow him no say in where he works, from one side of the world to the other.

title: At One Building, Both Sides Dread Strike
description: Jaan E. Vaino, president of the board of his Upper West Side apartment building, and Eduardo George, who mops the building's halls and takes out the trash, have little in common aside from a growing sense of dread that Mr. George's union will go on strike on Monday.

title: TODD-AO TO ACQUIRE HOLLYWOOD DIGITAL FOR $31 MILLION
description: The Todd-AO Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the closely held Hollywood Digital for $31 million in cash and debt, expanding its movie and television post-production and editing business. The acquisition will add Hollywood Digital's video, audio and film post-production operations, and its Hollywood facility, to Todd-AO's operations in New York, Los Angeles, Atlanta and London. Hollywood Digital, which will operate as an independent division, had revenue of $20 million in 1996, according to Todd-AO, based in San Francisco.

title: Overcoming Life's Slings and Arrows With a Song
description: Pop-rock songwriting is a nerd's paradise: a private retreat where the slights and setbacks of human contact can be avenged through craftsmanship. At Irving Plaza on Wednesday night, Fountains of Wayne, from New York City, sang about staring at a desirable girl on the arm of a tattooed, scar-faced biker and wondering ''if he ever has cried 'cause he couldn't get a date for the prom.'' And Sloan, a band from Nova Scotia, sang, ''You have done me wrong, I wrote these songs about it.''

title: Parcells Leaves Plenty Of Draft Options Open
description: Bill Parcells presides today over his first Jets draft in his effort to revive a franchise whose greatest moment is a Super Bowl memory from 1969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONDSHEIN, ESTHER BELLE
description: MONDSHEIN-Esther Belle. 98-1/2 years young. Beloved wife of the late Frank. Loving mother of Marian Edson, Harriet Dicker and son-in-law Arnold Edson. Adored grandmother of Andrea, Richard, Steven, Jennifer, Donna and Debbie and seven great grandchildren. Former Manager of the Consulate of Afghanistan for thirty years, Belle was an outstanding and unusual human being. We love her and we will all miss her greatly. Funeral service at Zion Memorial Home, 767 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, New York, Sunday, April 20th, at 12 Noon.

title: 1947:Tiso Executed : IN OUR PAGES:100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
description: PRAGUE  Reaction to the execution of Father Jozef Tiso in Bratislava ranged from satisfaction to dismay, but no disturbances were reported among the followers of the parish priest who rose to political power preaching autonomy for Slovak regions. Czech and Slovak authorities were prepared to prevent any incident, which might take the form of anti-Semitic excesses. Tiso's trial emphasized anti-Semitism as a characteristic of his followers among the outlawed Hlinka Guard.

title: VIACOM TO RAISE STAKE IN SPELLING ENTERTAINMENT TO 80%
description: Viacom Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy an additional 5 percent of Spelling Entertainment Group Inc. in a deal valued at $27.6 million. That would increase its stake in the company, which produces the television show ''Melrose Place,'' to 80 percent. Viacom, which is based in New York and owns MTV Networks and Blockbuster Entertainment Group, said the move would allow it to combine Spelling's financial results with its own for tax purposes. Spelling has reported losses in the last four quarters. Viacom would benefit because Spelling's losses would lower Viacom's overall earnings subject to taxes, said Richard Read, an analyst at Arnhold & S. Bleichroeder in New York. Viacom's class B shares gained 37.5 cents, to $32.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: School Board Member Is Suspended by Crew
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday suspended a Bronx school board member who the Federal Justice Department says profited from more than a hundred tampered ballots in the board race last May.

title: Another Top Executive Departs at Citicorp
description: In another in a string of high-level executive departures at Citicorp, Roberta J. Arena, the head of its huge but beleaguered credit card business in North America and Europe, announced that she intended to retire by the end of this year, a Citicorp spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: Legislators Visit Arsenal
description: Republican members of New Jersey's delegation to Congress traveled to Picatinny Arsenal yesterday to meet with workers who have watched nearly 1,400 jobs disappear since the Cold War ended. About 3,700 people are still employed there.

title: Creosote Tests Planned
description: Until it closed in 1959, the Federal Creosote Plant produced a tar-like substance used to preserve wooden rail road ties and utility poles. The plant was replaced by 137 homes and a strip mall. After creosote was discovered in a sinkhole in January, soil tests found traces of benzene, a carcinogen, officials said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Unpaid Tickets? In Other Countries, They're More Blase About It
description: World capitals take a far more laissez-faire view of foreign diplomats' using diplomatic immunity to violate parking rules than New York City does. Parisians expect it. Romans do it themselves, under try-to-stop-me immunity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HASSETT, THOMAS P
description: HASSETT-Thomas P. On April 18, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Florence A. (Brennan). Devoted father and father-in-law of Patricia and Michael Ribaudo and Suzanne and Vito Soffioti. Loving grandfather of Thomas, Kerry, Benjamin and Peter. Dear cousin of Theresa Ryan and Marie McGovern. Reposing at Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home, 6140 Woodhaven Boulevard, Rego Park. Funeral Mass at Our Lady of Hope Church, on Monday, at 12:30 P.M. Interment in Pinelawn Memorial Park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, DINA
description: GOLDBERG-Dina. Beloved wife of the late Irving and the late Frederick Grayenson. Dear mother of Guy, Anne and Eric. Adored sister of Beatrice and Murray. Devoted grandmother of Frederick, Carrie and Elizabeth. Loving aunt of Robert, Marilyn, Mara and Linda. Services Sunday 1PM at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard (76th Road), Forest Hills, New York.

title: Clinton Meets a Thorn in China's Side
description: President Clinton met today with a prominent Hong Kong democratic politician and warned Chinese leaders that they should ''live up to their agreement'' to protect Hong Kong's economic, political and civil liberties after the British colony returns to Beijing's sovereignty on July 1.

title: Two Views of Bombing Trial: 'Closure' or Painful Reminder
description: Martin Cash needs to get into the Denver courtroom. ''I'll look right at McVeigh with my one eye,'' said Mr. Cash, whose other eye was blown out of its socket on April 19, 1995. ''I'm going to let him know I'm there.''

title: After a Killing, a Surge in Fear of Florida Alligators
description: Driving along the shoreline of a six-acre lake in a popular city park, Todd Hardwick kept a watch through binoculars on a dark, elongated shadow that every 10 minutes or so would come up for air, then slip back underwater.

title: Richard Stockton, Playwright, 65
description: Richard Stockton, a playwright, died on April 5 at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 65.

title: Officer, Shot 3 Times, Is Saved by His Flak Jacket
description: A police officer was shot three times in the chest but was saved by his heavy flak jacket at a housing project in Queens yesterday morning as he and other officers tried to arrest a suspect in a February double stabbing, the police said.

title: McGaughey Back in Derby
description: Accelerator, who ran second to Captain Bodgit in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct last week, will be shipped to Churchill Downs today to run in the Kentucky Derby two weeks later as Shug McGaughey's first Derby starter since Easy Goer and Awe Inspiring eight years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLEIN, ALEXANDER
description: KLEIN-Alexander. On April 18, 1997. Beloved husband of Bea. Devoted father of Rachel, Corey, Ann, Ruvi and Vanessa. Services Sunday, 10:45AM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUDLER, MICHAEL DAVID
description: DUDLER-Michael David, 58, of Manasquan, New Jersey, 4/17/97. Beloved brother of Frank Dudlar, Walnut Lake, MI., and Barbara Ginsberg, Chester, NJ. Uncle of Gunnar Gray Dudlar, Ann Arbor, MI, Gannon Thor Dudlar, Walnut Lake, MI, Kevin Michael Ginsberg and Brian Lee Ginsberg both of Chester, NJ. Funeral Service will be held at St. Uriel the Archangel Episcopal Church, Sea Girt on Sat 4/19 at 2PM. Interment is private. Call Neary-Quinn Funeral Home, 39 South St, Manasquan, N.J., at (908) 223-0003. Memorial Donations in his memory can be made to Kidney Foundation of New York/New Jersey, 1250 Broadway, 20th Fl, New York, NY 10001 or The Sharing Network, 150 Morris Avenue, Springfield, NJ 07081.

title: Airtouch to Get Cellular Units From U S West In Stock Deal
description: In a deal that expands one telecommunications company and simplifies another, Airtouch Communications said yesterday that it would acquire the domestic cellular properties of the U S West Media Group for $2.8 billion in stock and $2.2 billion in assumed debt.

title: Sharpton Says No to Backing Ferrer
description: Democratic efforts to present a united front in their campaign to unseat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have suffered another setback, as a second Democratic candidate says he will not necessarily pledge to support the winner of his party's mayoral primary.

title: Line Item Veto Is Constitutional Balancing Act
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Creating Pride From an Insult In El Barrio
description: IN 1962, before any real-estate speculator dared to call East Harlem Upper Yorkville, Maria Lopez came to El Barrio looking for a community where she could feel at home. It had been good enough for her grandmother in the 1940's, when El Barrio was the epicenter of Latin New York -- a neighborhood of familiar foods and phrases and the cradle of activism in labor and politics.

title: Plague Ravages Taiwan Pigs and Many Blame China
description: If truth is the first casualty of war, trust must be the second, especially between old enemies like mainland China and Taiwan. To prove it, plenty of Taiwanese apparently suspect that the epidemic of hoof-and-mouth disease now ravaging their pork industry could have been an act of economic sabotage by China.

title: Les Cason, 43, High School Basketball Star
description: Les Cason, whose overwhelmingly successful basketball career at East Rutherford High School in New Jersey signaled a promise he never came close to achieving, died on Wednesday. He was 43.

title: OFFSHORE ENERGY DEVELOPMENT CONSIDERING SALE
description: The Offshore Energy Development Corporation said yesterday that it was suffering from several recent drilling and development failures and was exploring a possible sale of the company. Investors drove the company's stock down 54 percent, or $4.25 a share, to close at $3.625 in Nasdaq trading, reducing the company's market capitalization to $29.2 million. Offshore Energy, a natural gas company based in Woodlands, Tex., said it had hired a financial adviser to find partners for a sale, merger or other combination.

title: China Growth Slows a Bit, To 9.4% Pace
description: China's economic growth rate slowed to 9.4 percent in the first quarter from 9.9 percent in the previous three months as companies reduced bloated inventories built up in 1996, the Government reported today.

title: Banque Hervet Likely To Try to Privatize
description: France's state-controlled Banque Hervet is expected to announce within days that it will make a second attempt at privatization, the financial daily L'Agefi reported yesterday. The first attempt at privatization failed in 1993 after the bank was hurt by a crisis in the real estate sector and Credit Commercial de France pulled out of the deal. At the time, the bank's market value was estimated at 830 million French francs.

title: United, the West Can Handle Iran
description: At first glance, the ruling by a German court last week implicating top Iranian leaders in the assassinations of four Kurdish dissidents in Berlin in 1992 seems to vindicate America's hard-line policy toward Iran. Until now, the European Union, led by Germany, had maintained a ''critical dialogue'' with Iran, hoping to persuade its leaders to stop promoting terrorism in exchange for lucrative trade. The German court ruling seems to indicate that this conciliatory approach has been no more successful in forcing Iran to change its ways than the tougher policy of economic sanctions imposed by the United States.

title: Knicks Gain Home Court but Are Far From Home Free
description: On nights when the Knicks move the ball with precision and hit crucial shots, Madison Square Garden is a special place. That has not always been the case this season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERSON, ROBERT L.
description: PIERSON-Robert L. Of Columbiaville, NY. On April 13, 1997. Received master of Divinity degree from Nashota House. He was ordained a priest in 1954. In addition to other parishes he was rector of St. Paul's, Bronx, NY, St. Barnabas, Newark, N.J. and did supply work at St. Paul's Church, Tivoli, N.Y. An active defender of civil rights. Arrested as a participant of the Freedom Rides in Jackson, Miss. in 1963. A war protester and an advocate of women's equality in and out of the Episcopal Church. Worked with migrant apple pickers in Columbiaville, N.Y. Formerly married to Ann R. Roberts, daughter of the late Nelson A. Rockefeller. Beloved father of Clare, Joseph, Mary Louise and Rachel. Loving grandfather to Alta, Jeremiah, Clark, Phebe, Sebastian, Raven, Helen, Barrett, Marnie & Griffin. Beloved brother to Jean Hirst of Milwaukee and friend to many. Services to be held at St. John the Evangelist, Stockport, N.Y., Monday, April 21. Viewing at 10 A.M. Services at 12 Noon. Please make contributions to St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 489 St. Paul's Place, Bronx, New York 10456 in lieu of flowers. His good heart will be missed by all.

title: 'Good Looks' Questions Barred at Rape Trial
description: Lawyers argued about Alex Kelly's preppy good looks today during jury selection for his second trial on charges that he choked, raped and threatened a teen-age girl more than a decade ago.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about measurements suggesting that the universe has an ''up'' and a ''down'' misstated the distance in which radio waves from 160 distant galaxies appear to make a complete corkscrew turn as they travel through space. It is one billion light-years, not one billion miles.

title: Court Upholds Construction of Planetarium
description: An appellate panel yesterday upheld a lower court's decision to allow construction of a new planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History and to dismiss lawsuits from groups opposed to the plan.

title: Man Knowingly Exposed 62 Women to AIDS Virus
description: His world knew him as Boss Man, the slender possessor of a kind of devilish charm. He cruised this bedraggled riverside slum in fancy cars, dazzled impressionable girls with roller-skating pyrotechnics, and mysteriously flitted back and forth across the Mississippi River to St. Louis.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-6

title: Offering by Essex
description: Essex International Inc. said yesterday that it had raised $97.5 million in an initial public offering. Essex, a maker of electrical wire and cable products, said the 5.75 million shares were sold for $17 each, at the low end of the expected range of $17 to $20 a share. The stock closed at $17 yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, which is based in Fort Wayne, Ind., said the proceeds of the offering would be used to repay debts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONARD, IDA
description: LEONARD-Ida. Age 97, Of Rockville Centre, Long Island. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Devoted mother of Bernard and the late Loretta. Loving grandmother and great-grandmother.

title: With More Dog Waste on Streets, Crackdown Vowed
description: There she was, a Carolyn Bessette- Kennedy look-alike, sauntering down West 82d Street in Manhattan one evening, one hand holding a Louis Vuitton purse, the other clutching the leather leash of a golden retriever. Surreptitiously, she glanced over her shoulder, as if she were going to commit a crime. Which she was.

title: Cycling: Going Around Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Ovitz Puts On A Show
description: THERE'S no business like show business, except maybe publishing. As Paul Newman walked over to greet Michael Ovitz, who was posing for a photo opportunity with his former Disney colleague, Harvey Weinstein of Miramax, an innocent bystander could be forgiven for thinking that the New York State Theater had been taken over by Hollywood. In a sense, it had.

title: A Schism Among Jews?
description: Judaism, like any other religion, has a history of passionately argued theological disputes. But the argument between some Orthodox Jewish groups and non-Orthodox Jews over the role of the chief rabbinate in Israel and what constitutes Judaism itself is unusually corrosive. It is also dismaying to anyone concerned about Israel and the well-being of the Jewish community. History shows that an absolutist approach by religious groups in a pluralistic country endangers the common bonds holding society together. Israel is the last country in the world that can afford an internal religious schism.

title: Songs Blue at Heart, but Not Quite the Blues
description: WHEN CHRIS WHITLEY picks his bottleneck slide guitar and bends blue notes on his third album, ''Terra Incognita,'' the sound is both familiar and incongruous. He's not playing the blues in their standard late-1990's form: a thumping, predictable 12-bar verse that makes way for showy guitar solos. While the songs borrow blues techniques, they aren't exactly blues tunes. Instead, Whitley infuses them with a spirit of the blues: a clear-eyed, fatalistic tone that accepts both exaltation and despair. He sounds like he's consorting with ghosts, and in a way he is.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SHARIN, BARNEY
description: SHARIN-Barney, 4/17/87. Add ''f'' to heart, for father. Still my favorite man of letters. Carole

title: New Dealers Reflect on Roosevelt, and Flesh-and-Blood Liberalism
description: Mary A. Bain, the last of the original New Dealers still in Government, sparkled with amusement at the very idea of her President, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, ever resorting to the focus-group testing devices of modern politicians before approaching the nation with a fresh idea.

title: Friendly Little City Split on Big Issue
description: It started here as a local zoning dispute, then mushroomed into a battle before the United States Supreme Court that some legal scholars are describing as one of the most important in years involving the separation of church and state.

title: Mets Do Empathize, But Still Beat Cubs
description: Sure, the Mets understand what the Cubs are going through. Catcher Todd Hundley empathized with some of the Chicago hitters as they stood in the batter's box yesterday, one professional ballplayer understanding the plight of another.

title: A Necessary End
description: RICHARD BRADLEY gets a little teary-eyed as he recalls the funeral of his great friend, the Rev. Dale Forsman, associate pastor of the Chatham United Methodist Church, who died last year at age 52. It was a huge affair, befitting a beloved community leader who died young. Thousands attended and representatives of one organization after another spoke about the difference the pastor had made. Mr. Forsman's church had celebrated every Easter Eve with a jazz vigil, and so, appropriately, he was honored with a Dixieland send-off himself. At graveside, a sole trumpeter played ''Just a Closer Walk With Thee.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Education Life section on April 6, about senior military colleges, referred incorrectly to North Georgia College and State University. It is state-run, not private.

title: Tenured Teachers Still Fight Banishment
description: From where he sits at the Westchester Community College Library here, John Goetschius can watch the seasons change and observe the comings and goings of campus life.

title: Everybody Else's College Education
description: For most people not currently attending one, the word college is likely to summon up a particular mental picture. Floating around somewhere in it is the figure $20,000, which represents the popular notion of the cost of a year's tuition. (This doesn't include room and board.) ''How Colleges Are Gouging: A Special Investigation Into Why Tuition Has Soared'' was the headline on the cover of a recent issue of Time magazine, evidently composed to heighten the annual anxiety about college acceptances. The story inside led off with the news that tuition and fees at the University of Pennsylvania next year will be $21,130 and went on to accuse universities of hoarding endowment income and squeezing parents willing to pay anything to buy their children a B.A. An accompanying article questioned whether President Clinton's proposal to allow tax deductions for tuition won't ''encourage colleges to raise tuition even higher.''

title: Tobacco Settlement Doesn't Solve the Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Anchor' for Neglected Area

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HERZOG, CHAIM
description: HERZOG-Chaim. The entire Boys Town Jerusalem family joins with the family of Israel in mourning the passing of Chaim Herzog, the sixth President of Israel. We remain inspired by the remarks he made after his visit to Boys Town. ''The things I saw here today convince me that Boys Town Jerusalem is truly unique. This outstanding institution of Torah and technology gives its students not only a comprehensive education but a sense of respect and love for the People and the State of Israel. Behind the name of Boys Town Jerusalem rests an exalted conceptone which brings together the youths of all tribes of Israel and unites them in the spirit of the Torah, 'whose ways are ways of pleasantness and whose paths are all of peace.' Here, one learns not to shut oneself in, not to be isolated from the community of Israel, but rather to be an involved, creative and responsible citizen of Israel as it takes the first steps on the road to redemption. If there is any development that should give us cause for concern, it is the splintering of the Jewish People into sects and groups of all kinds. At Boys Town Jerusalem, I have found a source of hope I have found a source of hope for unity and love between the different parts of the Jewish People. The students of Boys Town Jerusalem leave here strengthened in their Torah and in their faith, able to identify heart and soul with the building of the State of Israel, and appreciative of the contributions of all segments of our nation, without exception, to Israel's redemption. Boys Town Jerusalem's graduates are spread throughout the land. They have fought in the ranks of the Israel Defense Forces, shoulder to shoulder with their brothers from cities, villages and kibbutzim. Many have fallen in battle, and their names are inscribed forever in the hearts of our People. In the weekly portion of the Prophets, we read: 'And the people shall all be righteous and they shall inherit the land forever; they are the offshoots of My plantings, the glorious works of My hands. The small shall grow into thousands, and the young shall become a mighty nation. These wonderful verses are fitting to be said of Boys Town Jerusalem. May there indeed be more of you.'' May there be many more like Chaim Herzog. May the Almighty comfort his family among the mourners of Zion and Jersualem. Josh S. Weston, Chairman Alexander S. Linchner, V. Chmn Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Rabbi Ronald L. Gray, Exec VP

title: The Bataan Death Hike
description: Starting at dawn today, some 1,500 racers will speed-march across 26 miles of desolation in southern New Mexico's White Sands Missile Range. The little-known event, called the Bataan Memorial Death March, commemorates the April 1942 Bataan death march, in which thousands of starving American and Filipino troops, captured by the Japanese, died during a 65-mile forced trudge through Philippine jungles. This march is only sport, but it still sounds pretty tough. Entrants are warned to expect wild animals, poisonous snakes, dangerous tunnels and unexploded munitions.

Viewers of this offbeat tale of crime and pursuit can only wonder how many such cases never came to light in the Nazi era. title: In Suburbia, More Barriers to Hurdle
description: THERE they were, two of the most famous black athletes of all time, Jackie Robinson and Joe Louis, playing golf at a predominantly Jewish country club not far from Robinson's spacious home in Stamford. The year was 1956, Robinson's last season as a Brooklyn Dodger and five years after Louis's last fight. It was also the last year Robinson, an ardent golfer, would play at the High Ridge Country club, which straddled the border of Stamford and Pound Ridge, N.Y. and was, as he himself once put it, ''a few good wood shots from my home.'' The reason? Racial barriers. Just two years earlier, Robinson and his wife, Rachel, had surmounted one racial hurdle by acquiring a home on a six-acre tract of land in a previously all-white section of North Stamford. ''We had outgrown the house we owned in a racially mixed neighborhood in St. Albans, Queens, and decided to look in Stamford because it was close enough for Jack to commute to Brooklyn,'' Mrs. Robinson recalled. ''But we had trouble finding suitable property.''

title: Surprises and Consolation Prizes
description: At the beginning of one story in Kim Edwards's accomplished first collection, THE SECRETS OF A FIRE KING (Norton, $23), a troupe of circus performers arrives in a new town. ''No matter how many stares they drew as oddly dressed strangers,'' Ms. Edwards tells us, ''they knew that soon they'd hold an audience of these same people breathless, spellbound.'' Ms. Edwards's stories are every bit as confident as her trapeze artists and just as skilled at evoking wonder. In ''Spring, Mountain, Sea,'' a soldier takes his Asian bride to upstate New York. Neighbors teach Jade Moon the finer points of macaroni and cheese, for which she thanks them with a carefully prepared fish. When the Americans gag, Jade Moon turns away from her husband's culture -- but she also plants a message of love that he'll find decades later, ''three small strokes of language that reconstructed their shared past.'' Ms. Edwards captures the sweep of those decades in a single story, and an impressive swath of the world in the book as a whole. One hero, Mohammed Muda Nor, must choose between duty and hope when gold is discovered in his Malaysian village. Half a world away, Marie Bonvin recalls dusting the laboratories of Marie Curie and tells with awe of touching Madame's ''jars, lined up on the rough boards, glowing softly in the dusk.'' Even in stories that stay close to home, characters find new wonder -- and terror -- in the familiar. ''The Secrets of a Fire King'' gives eloquence to their astonishing range of discoveries, and leaves the reader entranced. Nina Sonenberg

Molloy -- it might have been expected that the community would rally behind the officer, who contended that the wound was self-inflicted. Instead, some are calling him a killer, and the case has divided the community.

title: Criticism Either Way
description: Janet Reno is not the first Attorney General to find herself in an uncomfortable squeeze between partisan politics and criminal law. ''I'm damned if I do and damned if I don't,'' the somewhat exasperated Attorney General said last week after she rejected Republican demands to appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate how Democrats raised millions of dollars to re-elect President Clinton. Her decision infuriated Republicans like Speaker Newt Gingrich who compared her to John N. Mitchell, President Nixon's Attorney General during Watergate, who went to prison for obstructing the Watergate investigation. Her refusal to seek an outside prosecutor represented a change for Ms. Reno, who in the past has been criticized by Democrats for being too quick to refer cases to outside prosecutors. DAVID JOHNSTON

title: The Dispossessed
description: From the arid northeast to the fertile south, tens of thousands of Brazilians are claiming their right to settle vast tracts of unused land in their country. Hundreds of millions of acres of rich soil lie untouched -- the legacy of land grants awarded to the ruling class 400 years ago by the Portuguese kings. Leading families and business groups keep their estates as a hedge against inflation or as an investment that may one day pay off. At the same time, rural workers toil in near-feudal conditions, while others, cast off when jobs run out, wander the countryside.

With such a formidable testosterone support network already in place, why Icon? Getson's answer boils down to that second word: Thoughtstyle. Which is what? description: PIANA-Mary T., M.D. In Providence, RI, on April 17, 1997. Formerly of Queens and Fort Salonga, NY. Wife of the late G. Emil Piana, M.D. Mother of Monica J. Schaberg, M.D. (Providence, RI) and Diana M. Mariton, M.D. (Paris, France). Mother-in-law of Frank J. Schaberg, Jr., M.D. and Bernard A. Mariton. Grandmother of Adrienne, Madeleine, and Marianne Schaberg and Cassandre, Celine and Emilien Mariton. Born in Milan, Italy, in 1915. She was a daughter of the late Erminia (Poletti) and Cipriano Facchinetti (prominent in the anti-fascist resistance while in exile in Paris from 1925 to 1945, and late Senator and Defense Minister of the Italian Republic until his death in 1952). A 1940 graduate of the Faculte de Medecine, Paris, she emigrated to the United States in 1941. She was a psychiatrist and acting director of Creedmoor State Hospital, Queens Village, NY, until retirement in 1975, and child psychiatrist at the Kennedy Child Study Center, Manhattan. She was cognizant of the privilege of having known many interesting people during her life and grateful to have lived an interesting and good life in this century. Interment will be in Milan, Italy. Expressions of sympathy may be sent to the family, c/o Monica Schaberg at 58 Irving Avenue, Providence, RI 02906. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations in her name may be made to the Kennedy Child Study Center, 151 E. 67th Street, NYC 10021, attention Ann Williams.

She often seems to have more energy and drive than I as she works, travels, sees friends of many years and meets new ones and cares passionately about what goes on in the world. I marvel at the variety and texture of her life and the gusto she has always had for it.

title: The First Round of Gin Rummy

What seems at first like a simple, two-character parable of unhappy old age turns out to be a savage demonstration ''of how life kills itself,'' said Richard Eder in his review in The New York Times. Ms. Tandy would go on to win a Tony Award for best actress in the role of Fonsia Dorsey, and Mr. Coburn the Pulitzer Prize for best play. The director was Mike Nichols.

This usually means that within a couple of weeks he is back out in the potato patch, heaping on straw mulch to protect his sprouting spuds from late freezes. title: Penmaenmawr! You Can Say That Again!
description: Alice Thomas Ellis was brought up on the north coast of Wales in a town called Penmaenmawr, a place with ''a slightly schizoid air'' where, even by midcentury, the hotels and villas built by wealthy Edwardian vacationers had never quite conquered the old hill farms -- not to mention the granite quarries -- of the local people. Small wonder, then, that her memoir, A WELSH CHILDHOOD (Moyer Bell, $34.95), seems gleefully intent on ruffling the genteel surfaces of Patrick Sutherland's accompanying photographs. At times, the Sutherland-Ellis team seems distinctly schizoid itself. Ms. Ellis (a novelist best known for her trilogy, ''The Summer House'') makes it plain early on that she has ''never much cared for panoramic views and vast sights unless something unusual or interesting is happening to them.'' Which is why, as her text rambles past a handsome photograph of mist-shrouded Holyhead Mountain, there is no cloyingly rapturous hymn to nature -- just a satisfying rant about the bad press the Romans gave the Druids, accompanied by a deft story featuring a local tradesman called Uncle Roberts, who took young Alice on his rounds ''as cover'' for what ''must have been smuggling forays.'' Part reminiscence, part grab bag of historical and social curiosities, part meditation on such difficult subjects as death and happiness (with detours into the evils of tourism and suburbia), Ms. Ellis's book is not cozy and not for children. It's for grown-ups with a taste for the bracingly idiosyncratic, for a writer who bristles with sardonic charm. Alida Becker
