title: FIGHT BACK!
description: 1. When the University of Wisconsin denied tenure last year to Denis Collins, an assistant professor of business ethics, he retaliated with gusto. 2. In February, alleging ethical violations at the Madison campus, he announced a 40-day campaign to gather dirt on university-related misdeeds. He even rented off-campus space, where he met with whistle-blowers. 3. The yield -- 35 allegations covering everything from photocopying abuses to sexual harassment -- has been forwarded to the state Attorney General. 4. Next he undertook a ''liquids only'' fast (juice and broth), which lasted from March 7 to March 17. 5. At the same time, he ran for mayor. On April 1, he got 462 votes of the 51,000 cast. 6. Has he had enough? ''I've taken a beating,'' Collins sighed. ''I'm going to reflect on my experiences -- I'm entering a Trappist-monk cycle.''

Hanging on to her victimhood as a battered woman, she drags down those of us who have learned that we played a hefty role of our own in sticking around for hideous treatment. The best thing for her at this point is not waterproof mascara, but a plaque on her wall saying, ''I killed Lisa, too.''

She had won the best contemporary folk Grammy for her 1989 debut album, ''Steady On,'' and her two other records had also received nominations. But her competition this year -- Celine Dion, Toni Braxton, Tracy Chapman and Sting -- were all million-selling artists while none of Ms. Colvin's albums had sold half that. Not unexpectedly, Ms. Dion won the prize.

The dancers knelt or stood, their feet quite still, their upper bodies rocking and twisting, their arms arcing in air. They were celebrating the abundant harvests and hunts of the past and expressing hope for more in the future.

title: In Tokyo's Ryotei, The Art of Service
description: THE Japanese call it omotenashi: a service concept for which no simple translation exists. Thoughtfulness, dedication to customers' needs and meticulous attention to detail are key elements of such service. In relation to restaurants, the notion of omotenashi also demands the consistent use of top-quality ingredients, prepared with skill and integrity. These lofty goals are the standards by which ryotei, the magnificent and often exclusive Japanese restaurants that resemble dining clubs, judge themselves. I recently visited five of Tokyo's fine traditional restaurants that take pride in both food and service.

At worst, it's as good as stamping ''out of towner'' on your forehead. These considerations seem to matter little, however, to the thousands who buy these T-shirts, and even less to the restaurant owners. Macy was acting and building sets for the fledgling St. Nicholas Theater Company in Chicago, and his mentor and pal and partner in the company, David Mamet, was working on his play ''American Buffalo,'' the writer walked into the actor's apartment. He was hungry, literally. They were both hungry in the sense of ambition; they were not yet overly successful, and they were working hard -- starving artists, as it were.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MORIN, PAULINE
description: MORIN-Pauline, 83, Longboat Key, Florida died on April 11, 1997. Beloved wife and mother. In her youth, she was a ballroom dancer. During W.W. II, she was a civilian truck driver. She married Robert Morin, who survives her, and together they operated the Walk, Trot, and Canter Club in Briarcliff Manor, NY. They then operated their own real estate agency for a quarter century. After a short retirement in Sarasota, she joined Michael Saunders & Co. Realty and became a vice president. More recently, she was president of the Winding Oaks Condominium Association and the Longboat Key Democratic Club. Her loss is mourned by her husband and sons, Barron and David, as well as all who knew her as a woman of extraordinary character and intellect. No immediate memorial. Her sons will notify the appropriate parties about a future gathering.

title: The New Office Shoe
description: The only certainty in the fashion world is its unpredictability. Just when the minimalist look of all-black, no accessories and severely masculine clothes is dominating fashion and replacing the woman-as-a-decorative-object approach, some very stylish business women are softening the impact of functional clothes by wearing glamorous stiletto-heeled shoes more associated with evening than with day. The trendsetters are wearing them with pants suits, leather trousers, Burberrys raincoats and military-style officer's coats. This contrast of the masculine and feminine worn together first appeared last fall and continued through the winter, with the open-strapped shoes worn over dark stockings. Now, the dark stockings are off and the sexy shoe has emerged to counterbalance the masculine attitude in women's wear.

Once the well-clad, well-to-do had gathered for tea and cucumber sandwiches at the Mayfair. But the hotel is going to be turned into 70 luxury condominiums, and now, the same people were joining a feeding frenzy for furnishings.

title: KIDNEY BEANS
description: A hoary urban myth about kidney theft has, says a very concerned Wendy Brown of the National Kidney Foundation, ''gotten out of control'' thanks to the Internet. The tale: A man meets a woman at a party, goes home with her, drinks, passes out. He wakes up in a tub of ice, with slits in his back and both kidneys missing -- they've been stolen for the black market in organs. The story has been blazing recently on college campuses; at the University of Texas at Austin, the school newspaper printed a disclaimer to quell rumors that it had happened there. Meanwhile, the Kidney Foundation, which has battled this myth for years, is asking any certifiable snatchees to step forward. ''No one has called,'' Brown says.

Moviegoers, needing something to occupy them before the nightly screening, can idle in the cafe, also new, or wander into the gallery. Real Art's visual arts program may be getting its large audience by default, but, once inside, the crowd has a chance of being genuinely stimulated by the goings-on.

title: Spike Lee's 30 Seconds
description: One afternoon in early February, a news conference to announce the Mike Tyson-Evander Holyfield rematch was held in a ballroom of the Equitable building in midtown Manhattan, and Spike Lee was there to sell and be sold. The Tyson-Holyfield fight, which is now scheduled to take place on June 28, and will be carried by Showtime's pay-per-view division, is the first project of Spike DDB, an advertising agency Lee founded last fall with DDB Needham Worldwide. Lee has been directing ads since his first movie, ''She's Gotta Have It,'' struck a chord nine years ago with Jim Riswold at Wieden & Kennedy, the Portland, Ore., agency whose biggest client is Nike. Wieden & Kennedy hired Lee to direct a spot and star in it as the fast-talking, basketball-obsessed, love-struck ''Gotta Have It'' lead, Mars Blackmon. The ads helped shape Michael Jordan's image -- and helped establish Lee's reputation. Those first Jordan/Blackmon spots were witty, quick, vivid and effective: the best of Spike Lee.

title: International Style
description: Izhar patkin approaches the design of a room in the same way he paints a painting. He uses color, texture and scale to construct a narrative assembled from an international smorgasbord of cultural imagery. A few years ago, he made a 14-foot-tall, blown-glass sculpture of a dancer, which combines features of the Hindu god Shiva, Carmen Miranda and Josephine Baker. Now he's at work on a series of 101 paintings using Oriental rug motifs called, aptly enough, ''Gardens for the Global City.'' So it's no surprise that the interiors of his nearly 20,000-square-foot home and studio vibrate with the same world beat. The seemingly endless series of spaces -- part of a former vocational school in the East Village that Patkin and some friends bought and divided up -- is designed so that the areas open directly one onto another, creating long vistas that Patkin terms ''visual escapes.'' These doorways offer glimpses of brilliant, saturated wall colors, fabrics from India and North Africa and furnishings that evoke tales of faraway lands -- even if they come from no place more exotic than an upstate yard sale. Patkin's eye for color and pattern and his talent for recycling mundane materials into idiosyncratic objects render the ordinary extraordinary. These rooms are a tribute to the consistency of his vision, which transcends stylistic boundaries. ''It's not about a style,'' he says of both his home and his work. ''It's about the privilege of traveling and being able to be impressed by all the amazing things going on out there.''

title: The Film Makers And the Abuser
description: The premise of Ted Conover's article ''The Film Makers and the Abuser'' (March 30) -- that Brian Treglio was somehow exploited by the filming of ''It Ain't Love'' -- overlooks the real victim in this story, Irene Torres, the woman who was beaten by Treglio. Throughout history, excuses have been made for domestic abuse and rape. (The article on Hedda Nussbaum, in the same issue, reminds us that the victim of abuse is typically vilified.) Conover's article follows in this tradition, suggesting that had the film makers not manipulated reality, Treglio's actions could be seen in a better light, one that might excuse his behavior.

description: LISCO-Alfred. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alfred Lisco, associated with the Times from 1965, until retiring in 1995.

title: We, the Very Angry People
description: You might expect burning crosses and gun-carrying militiamen. But no, ''Angry White Men,'' a new exhibit at New York's SABA Gallery through May, largely skips the standard imagery of hate in its depiction of the radical right. Instead, the pictures are disturbing precisely because for the most part they look like snapshots of mainstream America. Michael Bray, a convicted abortion-clinic bomber, stares benignly from his living- room couch. Timothy McVeigh relaxes in his socks as he flashes a goofy adolescent smirk.

title: When 'Celebrity' Consultants Sort Out the Dirty Laundry
description: WHEN companies are criticized about their labor practices, they have good reason to worry about how consumers will react. If enough consumers care, sales as well as stock prices can be affected. A sensible response would be just to correct what's wrong and let the public know.

description: SHARP-Evelyn. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation mourn the loss of Evelyn Sharp. She brought a keen eye and discriminating intelligence to the appreciation of art, as demonstrated by her oustanding collection of modern masters. We extend our sympathy to her daughter, Mary Sharp Cronson, Trustee of The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, and to her family. Peter Lawson-Johnston Chairman The Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation

description: ''Many drug smugglers try to entice our officers to cooperate with them. But very few officers ever do, because it goes against the interests of our nation. Plus, if you get caught you'll be executed.''

title: Black Culture Surveyed In Detroit Museum
description: The history of blacks in America is surveyed in the relocated Museum of African American History, which opened April 12 in Detroit. Founded in 1965 as the International Afro-American Museum of Detroit by Charles Wright, a physician, the museum aims to document, preserve and educate the public on the history, life and culture of African-Americans.

title: Landmark Status Is Proposed For Eclectic NoHo
description: As a neighborhood, the trapezoid between the West and East Villages above Houston Street, known as NoHo, has long suffered from low self-esteem. ''In the late 70's and early 80's, we had to fight for what other neighborhoods take for granted, like sanitation services,'' said Keith Crandell of the NoHo Neighborhood Association. ''There has always been the sense that we have not been properly recognized.''

title: Bad Science Mars The F.B.I. Crime Lab
description: Recent events at the Federal Bureau of Investigation suggest that the image of stalwart G-men could be in danger of being replaced by the comic cops in the ''Naked Gun'' movies. The latest embarrassment was an inquiry by the Justice Department's Inspector General that found the F.B.I.'s high-tech crime lab riddled with bad science.

description: The player every team wanted wasn't selected yesterday in the National Football League draft. And it was by his own choice.

description: WHEN Victoria Cerami chose to become a mechanical engineer, she recalled that it was generally assumed that it was another engineer, her father, Vito Cerami, who encouraged her to follow in his footsteps.

title: Renewing Tocqueville's American Tour
description: FOR about 10 days this summer, the public affairs cable station C-Span will be in Westchester, part of nine months of programming aimed at re-creating the 1831-32 journey to America of the Frenchman Alexis de Tocqueville, the author of ''Democracy in America.''

title: School Districts Are Getting Tougher on Illegal Students Who Come From Other Places
description: It's crackdown time in Morrisville, Pa.: this summer, in an effort to stop students from trickling across the state line from New Jersey, the school board will require all students in the district to re-enroll and prove their residency.

Richard Channing Weymouth, a cousin of the bridegroom who is also an Episcopal priest, took part in the service.

description: Wanted: Job in Major League Baseball, front office (in area of responsibility, title unimportant) or field (manager, bench coach, hitting coach, third base coach).

description: Florida State running back Warrick Dunn wasn't expected to go very high in the first round. Many people thought his size (5 feet 8 inches, 176 pounds) might be a problem for him in the draft and that he wouldn't make a durable back in the National Football League.

title: Entering Extinction: The Hardware Store
description: ''THERE'S this thing under the basin in the bathroom, like a sort of prong that goes up and down, and it fell off and the plug won't work.'' This is typical hardware store conversation, a cry for help from the heart of suburbia. Fortunately, the hardware store is staffed by competent men, like the heroic surgeons of ''Chicago Hope,'' who will calm our fears and save us from the horrors of domestic decay. Of course this screen door can be saved. Certainly the old cistern can be nursed back to life. And no, the laundry machine doesn't need a quadruple bypass, just this small plastic washer. The hardware store is an H.M.O. for aging suburban homes.

title: . . . But for Some, 'All You Can Eat' Is Only a Dream
description: One way to to feed New Jersey's hungry is to tap the generous side of busy people, says the Rev. Stephen M. Rozzelle, who is organizing a statewide drive to collect canned food. The aim is to reach the nurturing qualities in everybody, from elementary-school students to commuters and factory workers.

title: Pace Is Top Choice In the N.F.L. Draft
description: After days of maneuvering, Orlando Pace emerged as the No. 1 choice in yesterday's National Football League draft. The issue was quantity or quality, and the St. Louis Rams went for quality, trading four picks to the Jets for the right to choose Pace, an offensive tackle from Ohio State.

title: The Kindest Month
description: Parties for cancer research, AIDS housing, public TV, the arts, education, and for fun.

title: Redeeming the Humanism in Portraiture
description: THERE has always been a ''humanist'' strain within the photographic tradition, concerned with documenting the universal dignity and worth of what one famous exhibition dubbed ''the family of man.'' But for many, the products of that concern have been mostly sentimental cliches and condescension, founded on a disregard for what the photographer Dawoud Bey describes as the ''implicit power relationships acted out in the process of photographing people, particularly those on the margins of society.''

title: A Ranger Team Divided Can't Stand in Playoffs
description: The Rangers' 1997 playoff guide, thick and thorough, has a cover photograph that is interesting and unintentionally appropriate. It is a posed team picture showing some players in their white home uniform shirts and some in their road blues. Others, including the highly paid veteran stars, wear their third jerseys, the spiffy new ones showing the head of the Statue of Liberty.

title: Rooting for What Really Mattered
description: What a month, this April seems to be. Like heavenly bodies aligning themselves to produce celestial spectaculars, the confluence of history-making events has been stunning.

title: Trattoria Food That Is Worth the Wait
description: THESE days there is much to recommend Mona's, but it might be a good idea to mention a few caveats up front. This is no place for a quick dinner. On a weekend, plan to spend three and a half hours; on a weeknight, two. In addition, the kitchen's efforts are markedly uneven: most dishes are either superb or a disaster. It would seem that the chef is either inspired or careless.

title: The Power of Baby Talk
description: The number of words a baby hears in the first year of life and the tone in which they are spoken affect fundamental circuits in the human brain, researchers have found. A child's ability to think rationally, solve problems and reason abstractly appear to be established in infancy -- long before babies understand what is being said to them.

title: From Turn of the Century, a Block of Former Stables
description: THE landmark block on 73d Street from Lexington to Third Avenues is one of the most distinctive in New York, and little seems to have changed since its rank of two- and three-story private stables went up a century ago to serve the grand houses west of Park Avenue. But despite the sunny block's landmark status, something fundamental has been happening, as these buildings have become primary residences of their own.

title: A New Navy Destroyer Honors Victims of a Wartime Tragedy at Sea
description: On Nov. 13, 1942, the American light cruiser Juneau, limping away from one of the fiercest naval battles of World War II, was hit by a Japanese torpedo off Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands and went down with most of her crew of 700. But about 100 men, most of them badly wounded, some missing limbs, helped one another into three life rafts, hoping for rescue by other ships in convoy.

title: Elizabeth Tyler, John Kennedy 3d

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CHUSID, DR. EMANUEL
description: CHUSID-Dr. Emanuel, of Neversink, NY, a 39 year resident of Mt. Vernon, NY, died Thurdsay, April 17 at Arden Hill Nursing Center in Goshen, NY. The son of the late Sonia and Nathan Chusid, he was born March 25, 1920 in NYC. He graduated from City College of New York, and Chicago Medical School. He was in private practice as a pediatrician in Mt. Vernon, NY from 1955 through 1970. He was former Chairman of the Metropolitan Chapter of the American Academy of Pediatrics. The rest of his professional career was spent at the Mental Retardation Institute of the New York Medical College in Valhalla, NY, where he served as Director, retiring in 1985. He studied and loved music in all of its forms all his life. He was active in efforts to bring peace and justice to the world. He is survived by his wife Alta Butkus Chusid, a resident of Arden Hill Life Care Center, Goshen, NY; his son Michael Chusid, of Vilnius, Lithuania, and two daughters, Nancy Chusid Ruscoe, of Neversink, NY, and Barbara Chusid, of Madison, WI; a son-in-law, Tim Ruscoe; two grandchildren, Emily and Sonia Ruscoe; and many other loving relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by his parents, his brother, Moses Chusid, and twin grandsons, Max and Eli ChusidJacklitz. A private memorial will be held. In recognition of Emanuel Chusid's active interest in the welfare and happiness of all the world's children, memorials in his name may be made to U.S. Committee for Unicef, 333 East 38th Street, NY, NY 10016. His love for his family, friends, music and humanity, was boundless and he will be remembered with great love.

title: The Faces of Hedda Nussbaum
description: It cheapens and demeans the plight of those who truly are victims of domestic violence to compare Hedda Nussbaum to Patty Hearst, who was kidnapped and terrorized by a fanatical group, or to Nicole Simpson, who was by all accounts a loving and attentive mother. Nussbaum was a crack cocaine addict, and getting the drug at all costs was the driving issue in her life. Her excuse that the monstrous Joel Steinberg ''demanded'' that she smoke cocaine with him after he beat little Lisa is typical. Addicts never accept responsibility for their actions.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HUDSON, JOHN
description: HUDSON-John. Family and friends mourn John's passing on April 12, 1997, in Portland, Oregon. John was a labor union and human rights activist his entire life. Born February 26, 1949, in Danville, Illinois, he completed undergraduate studies in economics at the University of Illiniois, Urbana in 1971, and graduate studies in community and social psychology at Goddard College. He then lived and worked in New York City for over 20 years. His abstract oil paintings were included in a number of gallery exhibits in New York. He married Patricia Westwater in New York, in November 1995. They moved to Portland in January 1996. His parents, John and Helen, and his brother Joseph and his family live in Seattle. Disposition was by cremation. John requested that in lieu of flowers, contributions go to the Leukemia Society of America, 600 3rd Ave, New York, 10016. A memorial service will be held on May 10, at 1:00PM, Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, 85 South Oxford Street, Brooklyn.

They limited the Canadiens to just two shots in a span of 23 minutes, setting the tone for a 4-1 triumph at Continental Arena that gave New Jersey a two-games-to-none lead in this first-round matchup.

When she was 13, her family moved to New Haven, and she would help out every weekend at St. Anthony's Orphanage. ''I just wanted to be there, hold those babies,'' Mrs. Sabetta said. ''It just seemed like an orphanage is not where you want to children to grow up. They need to be in a family.''

title: A Look Back And Ahead At Oklahoma City Site
description: The grass-covered spot where the Murrah Federal Building once stood was empty today at 9:02 A.M. It remained so as Oklahoma City paused to observe 168 seconds of silence, one for each person killed in the bombing here on this date and at this time two years ago, and for a few moments more as the pealing of church bells broke the quiet.

This reader lives in Sag Harbor, is not a member of the Sag Harbor Golf Course, but states there is ''never a problem playing there on weekends.''

title: Museums That Tell What to Think
description: THERE are some chilling objects on display at the Museum of African-American History in Detroit, which opened in a new $38.4 million building last week and is now clearly the nation's biggest and most important black history museum. There are rusted shackles used to hold slaves on a plantation in Virginia, a tin case in which a freed black man kept the document proving he was nobody's property, a diagram showing how to tightly pack African slaves on a British ship.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  IRITANI, CHIKA A.

title: When Death Begins
description: THERE was a time when no one worried much about pinpointing the exact moment of death. After all, it was pretty clear when a dying person took a final breath and lay still. You could put your ear to the chest and discern no heartbeat. Hold a mirror under the nose and see no sign of moist breath.

Contact L. L. Bean, Casco Street, Freeport, Maine 04033; (800) 809-7057.

I was perplexed, however, that there was not a single advertisement for clothes for mature men and women. Someday, someone will realize that we constitute a real market. I wear a size 10. I go to parties and church; I entertain, travel and even wear a bathing suit.

Under a plan approved in February, parents from Lincoln Park, which has no high school, would have received vouchers to send their children to the school of their choice. Some opponents of the vouchers say a better approach would be to address dissatisfaction with Boonton High School, where students now go.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDMAN, JEANNETTE
description: FRIEDMAN-Jeannette. Died April 16, 1997, at age 86, of cancer. Social activist and social worker. Uncompromising fighter for racial equality, peace, freedom and justice. The bravest, kindest person we know. Teacher, confidante, leaving a legacy of love and joy to three generations. She was committed to living life fully and daily expressed her radical/humanist values with passion and integrity. Widow of her beloved Harry D. Katz-great soul (died 1965). Survived by husband David, daughter Ruth, son Joel, grandsons Cassidy and Harry Ming, sisters Rebecca and Nettie, son-in-law Ernie and daughter - in - law Helen. She touched the lives of so many. We will love her forever. Shivah will be held at the home of the family. Memorial service at Ethical Culture Society, 2 West 64th Street, Manhattan, at 2 PM, on Saturday, April 26. Donations in her memory may be made to National Emergency Civil Liberties Union or Jewish Currents.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bias on the Books
description: NEW JERSEY'S last vestige of official discrimination is enshrined in a 70-year-old statute that allows municipalities to regulate and license junkyards, used car dealerships and ''roving bands of nomads, commonly called gypsies.'' The Assembly and Senate should immediately repeal this law, a law whose existence represents an embarrassment and affront to each resident of our state.

title: Broken Bone in Leg Puts Acceptable Out
description: Two weeks before the Kentucky Derby, the road to Louisville claimed yet another prominent horse yesterday when George Steinbrenner's Acceptable broke a bone in his left foreleg while working out on a muddy track at Keeneland.

title: Elizabeth Levine, Roland Samieske
description: Elizabeth Ann Levine, who administers an H.I.V. program, was married last evening to Roland Samieske, a librarian. Rabbi Mark E. Blazer performed the ceremony in the Rodin sculpture court at the Brooklyn Museum of Art.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: A Question of Commitment, A Question of Tact
description: Enormous political might, like the type often realized by newly elected officials, must be as intoxicating as a stiff cocktail -- erasing inhibitions, clouding the senses, and distorting one's judgment. As evidence of this unproved theory, take Robert G. Torricelli, the freshman Senator who found himself in a close race last fall but still won by 10 percentage points because of a strong turnout among minority voters.

title: Converting the Dollar into a Bludgeon
description: Afew weeks ago, President Clinton decided not to punish Mexico for losing its war on drugs, partly out of concern that the punishment -- economic sanctions -- would have hurt Mexico's economy and America's too. This month Mr. Clinton said he'd moderate his sanctions on Cuba to avert a trade fight with the European Union that could, in turn, backfire on businesses at home. The President also seems reluctant to impose tough sanctions on Myanmar for abusing human rights because a few American companies might lose out on business.

title: Pedal Pushers
description: Stretchy halters, below-the-knee pants and at-the-knee shorts for breezing through spring and summer. From left: Toddler's halter from Les Tout Petits.

title: Exit Laughing
description: LAUGHTER'S GENTLE SOUL

title: U.S. Challenges Courts on Disabilities
description: In a move that could delay or deny benefits for tens of thousands of people, the Social Security Administration has told its judges that they should, in most cases, disregard Federal court precedents if those rulings conflict with agency policies.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 199.52 points, or 1.09 percent, at 18,551.66. On Friday, the Nikkei index gained 258.73 points, or 1.43 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLAX, MARY M.
description: FLAX-Mary M. Of White Plains, NY. Wife of the late Dr. Milton E. Flax. Survived by one son, one daughter, two grandsons. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. Bernard's R.C. Church, White Plains, NY. Reposing at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Avenue, White Plains, NY, Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Exodus
description: At sundown tonight Jews around the world will gather to celebrate Passover and to retell the story of the Exodus from Egypt. Exodus, of course, wasn't just about leaving Egypt. It was about coming to Israel and building a Jewish homeland. More than at any time in its modern history the meaning of Israel as a Jewish homeland is up for grabs. For friends of Israel, this is no time for a phony unity. This is a time for taking sides. This is a time for using your money, or your pen, or your political clout or your body to make sure you are helping to build an Israel you'd want your own children to live in.

title: The once-stable talent agency business joins the Hollywood shuffle.
description: FOR years, the talent agency business has been relatively stable in the unstable world of entertainment. Film studio executives moved through a revolving door of jobs. The careers of actors and directors ebbed and flowed. But for the most part, talent agents seemed impervious to change.

title: The Congressional Spin
description: To the Editor:

title: Fassel and Brown Get What They Want
description: How is this for an endorsement of Ike Hilliard, the Giants' top pick in the National Football League draft. Dallas quarterback Troy Aikman worked him out recently and told Cowboys scouts that Hilliard has a chance to be in the next 10 Pro Bowls.

title: Trees Obstruct Fire Lookout
description: Observers in a fire lookout in the Pine Barrens literally can't see the forest for the trees, and that has led to a dispute about whether it might be necessary to destroy part of the forest in order to save it.

title: Treasury to Sell Notes and Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and auctions of two- and five-year notes tomorrow and Wednesday, respectively.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKEFELLER, MARY FRENCH
description: ROCKEFELLER-Mary French. The Trustees and staff of the Wildlife Conservation Society are deeply saddened by the passing of Mary French Rockefeller, long time friend of the Society, its zoos and aquarium, and beloved wife of the Society's Honorary Trustee and past Chairman, Laurance S. Rockefeller. Her gentleness, compassion and kindness will long be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to her family. She will be missed by all. David T. Schiff, Chairman Howard Phipps, Jr., Chairman Emeritus William Conway, President

title: New Jersey State Workers Worry About Pension Plan
description: Few people in New Jersey may be more concerned about Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's proposal to borrow billions of dollars for the public employee pension system than the hundreds of state workers who live in this town just outside of Trenton.

title: McCall Fears Governor's Race Too Costly
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, widely considered the leading Democratic contender for governor, has begun openly asking whether he will be able to raise enough money to challenge Gov. George E. Pataki in 1998, fueling longstanding doubts about his willingness to run.

title: Recipes, Advice and Ideas for Cooks
description: Bewildered by boiling water? Flummoxed by flan? There is a place where aspiring cooks can get help whenever it is needed. Just fire up the browser and head out to the World Wide Web, where your favorite chefs are standing by.

title: New Chance For D'Amato To Deliver
description: APPARENTLY, fate still has a soft spot for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Devils Can Now Afford Cautious Optimism
description: Having won the first two games of their series with the Canadiens rather easily, the Devils left for Montreal this afternoon trying not to look ahead to Round 2 of the playoffs before they get finished with Round 1.

title: Airport Traffic Increases
description: Rebounding from an off year, traffic at Newark International Airport increased to 29.1 million passengers last year, a jump of 9.3 percent over 1995, according to figures released by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey last week. The growth at Newark helped the region's three major airports post their busiest year ever last year, serving 81 million travelers. Traffic increased by 2.6 percent at Kennedy International Airport and by 0.5 percent at La Guardia Airport.

title: Clinton Pushes Pact Covering Chemical Arms
description: With the Chemical Weapons Convention and a large chunk of his political credibility -- hanging in the balance, President Clinton dispatched his Secretaries of State and Defense to make a rare joint television appearance today, where they tried to persuade wavering senators to back the treaty.

As a doctor, artist, traveler and adventurer, he lived each day fully and touched the lives of all he met. A memorial service will be held Monday, April 21, 1997, 2-5 PM, at Austin F. Knowles, Inc, Funeral Home, 128 Main St, Port Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to GMHC, 129 West 20th St, New York, NY 10011, would be greatly appreciated.

description: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

title: To One Building's Tenants, Cost Is Under $1 a Month
description: For residents of one Upper West Side apartment building, yesterday's settlement between landlords and building workers will cost the building an average of only 86 cents a month more for each apartment.

description: The International Data Group sees itself as the Procter & Gamble of the technology media marketplace.

title: Trouble From the Start: Knicks Get the Hornets
description: Just when the Knicks thought they were through dealing with the guy who shaves post-season messages into his scalp, Anthony Mason and his barber were added to the Madison Square Garden playoff roster late last night.

title: Accounts
description: * The Mining Co., New York, to Frierson & Mee Inc., New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the Web site network. Cone Communications, New York, was named to handle public relations. Billings were estimated at $3 million to $5 million.

title: Arthur Klein, 81; Made Literary Recordings
description: Arthur Luce Klein, the founder and president of Spoken Arts, a pioneering company in the field of recorded literature, died on April 7 at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 81.

title: In With New, Out With Old
description: Two well-known college quarterbacks joined the National Football League yesterday, selected on the second day of the draft. At the same time, a well-known veteran quarterback said goodbye to the N.F.L. after 12 seasons.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHEINKOPF, ALLEN
description: SHEINKOPF-Allen. Survived by his wife Mollie, his son Solomon and his daughter Freida and six grandchildren. He was past Master of E.G.G. Lodge, number 889 F.&A.M., also past Grand Sword Bearer, Grand Lodge, NYS Masons. He will be dearly missed.

title: Politician With an Urge to Befriend Pakistan
description: As a young man, in 1947, I. K. Gujral, who was sworn in as India's Prime Minister today, joined the vast throngs of Hindu and Muslim migrants who left their homes when Britain's colonial rulers partitioned the subcontinent into the two new nations of India and Pakistan.

title: Experiment Leaves Legacy of Distrust Of New AIDS Drugs
description: Walter Williams, a 49-year-old Vietnam veteran in Harlem, tested positive for the AIDS virus eight years ago, but he has rejected his doctor's urging that he try the new drugs that have shown such promise in reversing the progress of the deadly disease.

title: At Last Giuliani Fund-Raiser, Arias Say It All
description: One of the great pleasures of being Mayor of New York City is the opportunity to fully indulge one's personal passions, and last night's fund-raiser at Lincoln Center for Rudolph W. Giuliani -- his last and most extravagant -- was a complete reflection of his own musical tastes.

title: Pippig and Roba Are Preparing to Settle an Olympic Grudge in Boston
description: A mile into the 1996 Olympic marathon, Uta Pippig of Germany made a bold move to the front, but it was Fatuma Roba of Ethiopia who crossed the finish line first, running relaxed and effortlessly while the injured Pippig dropped out, unable to run at all.

title: In-Laws at Odds in Battle of Two Books
description: When the authors of the best-selling ''Sisters'' choose the theme for their next portrait of tender family relationships, this much is certain: It will not be a dreamy paean to the brother-in-law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEICHTER, MAURICE
description: LEICHTER-Maurice. On April 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Minna, loving brother of Frances Golub, dear uncle of Rita Golub. Services Monday, 12 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: For Some, Work May Not Mean Self-Sufficiency
description: When welfare benefits end, will recipients find work and will work bring self-sufficiency?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FREEMAN, DOROTHY
description: FREEMAN-Dorothy. On April 20, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Nathan Freeman. Loving mother of Gordon, Gerald and the late Martin. Dear sister of Emily Nagler and Oscar Epstein. Cherished grandmother of Ivan, Jill, Heidi, Nadine, Noel, Iris, Scott and Alison. Also survived by five great-grandchildren. Services Monday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: New Plan for Rescuing the Salmon
description: Every spring in the Pacific Northwest, just as sure as the grass turns green, salmon begin their annual migration from the mountains to the sea.

title: Searchers See Wreckage Likely to Be From Plane
description: Apparently ending a military mystery that bedeviled the Air Force for almost three weeks, searchers today spotted what they believe is the metal wreckage of a warplane that vanished into the thin air of the Colorado Rockies on April 2.

title: Diversity Makes a Debut at a High-Society Party
description: Thirty-seven years ago, it took student sit-ins in Nashville to integrate the lunch counters at F. W. Woolworth and Harvey's Department Store. But integrating the Swan Ball? That took patience.

title: 2 Dead After Car Chase
description: Two men fleeing the police after a shooting died yesterday and two others were critically injured when the car they were in crashed and burst into flames, the Newark police said. A man and a woman had been shot but not seriously wounded outside a Jersey City bar by one of the occupants of the car around 3 A.M., the Jersey City police said.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: WILL McCALL RUN? State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, considered the leading Democratic contender for governor, has begun asking whether he can raise enough money to challenge Governor Pataki, suggesting he may be shying away from the race. B7.

title: Watkins Matthews, Rancher From Bygone Era, Dies at 98
description: Watkins Reynolds Matthews, a wiry wrangler who spent more than half a century presiding over his family's showcase Texas cattle spread, died on April 13 at the historic Lambshead Ranch, 140 miles west of Fort Worth. He was 98 and the last of his generation in one of the state's oldest and most prominent cattle families.

title: Thomas Connor, Last of Dillinger Detail, 91
description: Thomas J. Connor, who had such a brief but decidedly eventful career with the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he dined out on it for six decades -- including 18 cold war years with the Central Intelligence Agency, died on April 14 at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 91 and the last surving member of the F.B.I. detail that gunned down John Dillinger outside the Biograph Theater in Chicago in 1934.

title: Be Creative When Seeking College Leadership
description: To the Editor:

title: No Deal
description: The tobacco companies kill me. Suddenly they want to atone for their sins. They are going to stop their lying and stop trying to lure whole new generations of children into the deadly smoking habit. They are going to pull most of their advertising. They are going to fold their litigious tents and, like good citizens, obey the laws of the land. Most of all, they are willing to reach into their deep, deep pockets and pull out many billions of dollars to be used as compensation for the decades of grotesque suffering they have wrought.

title: 'Irrational Exuberance'
description: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, seemed to signal to many Americans with one unnerving rhetorical question last December that the boom in the stock market was coming to an end. Now four months later, Mr. Greenspan is gradually providing his own answer: the speculative frenzy that could bring a prolonged market decline is not here yet.

title: Again, Yanks Lose to Own Bullpen
description: A new day with new hope deteriorated into a day fraught with big deficits, big comebacks and then the same villains and annoying results that have hampered the Yankees all season. Ponder why the Yankees have usually faltered and then guess what failed them today. It should take one second to respond. The bullpen did it again, and in bizarre fashion.

title: Computers May Soon Use Your Voice to Say Anything
description: Move over, Rich Little. Researchers are developing electronic impersonators -- computer systems that can speak in a particular person's voice.

title: Heroes Now Tend to Be More Hard Edged, Urban and Pop Oriented
description: The author Michael Dorris, who committed suicide last week, was best known for ''The Broken Cord,'' a book about fetal alcoholism syndrome, and as the collaborator of his wife, the best-selling novelist Louise Erdrich. The facts of Mr. Dorris's background are still being sorted out, but he claimed Modoc Indian descent. Whatever his background, he was a tireless promoter of a range of young American Indian talent, both as a reviewer and behind the scenes.

title: A new magazine reviewing commercial Internet sites may prove to be ahead of the curve.
description: POSSIBLY before its time, a new magazine has appeared in which seasoned-sounding surfers review Internet sites peddling everything from imported olive oil to domestic flight reservations.

title: Mets Raise The Price Of Beer In Chicago
description: Harry Caray, legendary baseball announcer and owner of a Chicago bar, promised patrons that he would sell beers for 45 cents as long as the Cubs' record losing streak continued.

title: Defector Says North Korea Seems Intent on a War
description: A high-level North Korean defector arrived here today, saying that people in the North have already ''lost hope'' and that he wants to prevent a war that the desperate Communist Government seems intent on waging.

title: Drug Maker Doesn't Influence Medical Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: The Cure for Growth
description: While most countries are striving hard these days to generate growth in their economies, the United States is fortunate enough to be pondering the opposite problem: how not to have too much of it. As a result, the stock market and indeed the entire nation hang on every word uttered by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman. People worry about the effect of higher interest rates -- the Fed's strategy for slowing growth -- on their personal investments.

title: Religion and Welfare Shape Economics for the Hasidim
description: The job interviews take place with practical, unspoken calculation in Southside's dozens of Hasidic schools. The schoolteacher is desperate for work; the school administrator, short of funds, can offer only the most minimal of wages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZIPPIN, GEORGE J., M.D.
description: ZIPPIN-George J., M.D. Age 82, of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Schenectady, NY. Loving husband of Ruth Zippin, devoted father of Robert S. Zippin of Lauderhill, FL, and Carol Z. Gipstein of Englewood, CO. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan and David Zippin, and Steven and Richard Gipstein. Funeral services to be held in Schenectady.

title: A Story of Notes and Men Told by Brendel's Fingers
description: One can't resist attaching a story to Alfred Brendel's program at Carnegie Hall on Friday even if it isn't the one the pianist intended. Liszt wrapped in Busoni was the first half of the evening, then Schumann's C Major Fantasy, perhaps the most successful ''big'' piece he ever wrote, and finally, curiously, unexpectedly, the Allegro innocente and Presto (equally innocent) that make up Haydn's G Major Sonata (Hob. XVI/ 40).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNAMARA, JOHN M.
description: McNAMARA-John M. Of Venice, FL, on April 15, 1997. Former teacher at the Staten Island Academy and The Buckley School. Husband of the late Katherine Y., devoted stepfather of Janet Phillips, Elizabeth Retan and William B. Wood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, LESLIE G.
description: KATZ-Leslie G. Ballet Society notes with great sadness the death of Leslie Katz, founder and guiding spirit of the extraordinary Eakins Press Foundation. He leaves a rich and elegant legacy. It was our particular honor to collaborate with him on projects commemorating the work of George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein. Sincerest condolences to his family, and most especially to Jane Mayhall. Nancy Lassalle, President Thomas Schoff, Treasurer

title: Go Forrest Gump one better. Have your image inserted at, say, Ebbets Field in the late 1940's.
description: AT the movies, Forrest Gump stands sheepishly in the Oval Office and greets President John F. Kennedy. We know it's really Tom Hanks, and we marvel at the powerful computer technology that so seamlessly places him in the 1962 White House. Wouldn't it be fun to create a home video with the same special effects, showing, say, Uncle Norman tagging out Jackie Robinson. Certainly it's possible, except for the fact that the editing process used for feature films is an exorbitantly expensive, specialized undertaking.

title: CHRONICLE
description: While four helicopters filled with paparazzi hovered outside, BROOKE SHIELDS, 31, the model and actress, married ANDRE AGASSI, 26, the tennis star, on Saturday evening in Monterey, Calif.

title: Chirac Is Expected to Call Parliamentary Elections One Year Early
description: President Jacques Chirac, who had long resisted calling early elections, is now widely expected to reverse himself in a speech Monday night and announce a dissolution of the French Parliament, a year before the expiration of its five-year term.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DORAN, EAMONN
description: DORAN-Eamonn. A Memorial mass for Eamonn Doran will be held on Thursday, April 24, at 6:30 P.M., at Our Saviour Church, 59 Park Avenue at 38th Street. At Eamonn's request, memorials to the New York Foundling Home would be appreciated.

title: Hollywood Braces for Likely Delay Of 'Titanic'
description: The likelihood that ''Titanic,'' the costliest film ever made, will delay its opening, previously set for the July 4 weekend, is sending ripples across Hollywood and turning the summer season into turmoil.

title: Ex-Nets Coach Has Last Laugh
description: AS it turned out, the Knicks did not need the Nets to help them with playoff seeding here last night. And thus, as the Nets bid farewell to another season without seeing the light of May, the pertinent issue was how the Nets and their jumpy young coach, John Calipari, might in the future assist themselves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIALLER, FLORENCE (NEE SLUTZKY)
description: BIALLER-Florence (nee Slutzky). Of Teaneck, NJ, on April 19, 1997. Beloved wife of Joseph, devoted mother of Leslie and Nancy. Services Monday, 1 PM, at ''GuttermanMusicant,'' 402 Park St, Hackensack. The period of mourning will be observed at the family home.

title: A Card Game as Metaphor for the Emotional Battle of Aging
description: You can step into a certain restaurant and instantly know you are in good hands. The lighting, the flowers, the table: everything just feels right. No sooner do you sit than a waiter, solicitous but not intrusive, arrives with a basket of crusty bread and a glass of rare Burgundy. You scan the menu. Among the specials: your favorite dish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOW, LAURA
description: RUDOW-Laura. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, devoted mother of Gilbert Rudow and the late Ruth Saffer, cherished grandmother and great-grandmother. Graveside services today, 10:45 AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York

title: Bridge
description: To get the full flavor of the diagramed deal, you must cover the East and South hands and consider West's defensive problem. You have raised your partner's three-diamond opening to five, and the opponents have settled in six hearts. You lead the ace of diamonds, and to your astonishment this wins the trick. Dummy discards a spade, and your partner plays the diamond three and South the diamond eight.

title: 1,000th Victory Is a Shutout
description: Jan Hutchinson reached a milestone yesterday when her Bloomsburg University softball team beat Dowling College of Long Island, 6-0, for the 1,000th victory of her coaching career. Hutchinson is believed to be the first female college coach to hit that landmark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORE, BARBARA
description: SCHORE-Barbara. On April 19. Beloved wife of George for 57 years. Mother of Allan (Judith) and Cari (Jon) Markell. Grandmother of Beth Schore, David (Suzy) Schore, and Joshua Markell. An adventurous and loving woman. Her devotion and deep concern for family and friends was an inspiration to us all.

title: Cambodia's Blinding Genocide
description: The faces linger in the visitor's memory, rows and rows of mug shots taken on entry to the prison, men, women and even small children. The women wear their hair chopped at the neck and are dressed in dark pajamas. Many of the men are bare-chested and draped in a Khmer scarf. Their faces show they know what is to come. Sixteen thousand of these people entered Tuol Sleng, the Khmer Rouge's secret police prison, between 1975 and 1979. Perhaps seven of them emerged alive.

title: Richter Repays Panthers In Shutout
description: As teammates on the Rangers in the early 1990's, Mike Richter and John Vanbiesbrouck were two goalies battling for one first-string job. Richter won the competition and validated his victory by earning a Stanley Cup ring in 1994. Vanbiesbrouck also did well after Florida chose him in the expansion draft; he led his team to the cup finals last season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSLIGHT, GRACE R.
description: GROSSLIGHT-Grace R. Of Englewood, NJ. Beloved mother of Lorraine and sister of Marilyn C. Wasserman. Loving friend of Robert Katz and Mary Lambert, sister-inlaw. Services are 11 AM, Wednesday, Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City tomorrow and Wednesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: 3 Killed and 16 Are Injured In Blaze in Queens Apartment
description: A fire engulfed a three-story wood-frame apartment house in Maspeth, Queens last night, trapping and killing three men in the basement and injuring 16 other people, including two parents and a child who jumped from the second floor, terrified of the fast-approaching flames.

title: Tentative Accord Averts Strike By Doormen in New York City
description: Staving off a strike in nearly 3,000 New York City apartment buildings, the union representing more than 30,000 residential building workers agreed yesterday to a tentative three-year contract that includes a lower wage for new employees and an 8.3 percent pay increase for current workers.

title: Glanville Williams, 86, Teacher And Authority on Criminal Law
description: Glanville Williams, a British authority on criminal law who taught at Cambridge and also was a visiting professor at Columbia and New York University, died on April 10. He was 86 and a longtime resident of Cambridge, England.

title: This Goal Will Rebound Into the Blooper Highlights
description: THERE is a market for the first Mexico goal yesterday. It may not be a flourishing market here in the United States, but around the world they take their soccer goals seriously, particularly the freakish ones, like the ball that bounced over Kasey Keller's head yesterday.

title: Parcells Focuses Heavily On Defense
description: The Jets selected eight more collegians in just four rounds today, concluding an intense draft weekend that left Coach Bill Parcells reasonably satisfied and just about everyone else dizzy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRER, JOHN GEORGE
description: FUHRER-John George, April 14, 1997. Survived by wife Tillie, daughter Ellen and son-in-law Roger Salomon. Loving niece and newphews. The Fuhrer Family

title: Drawing Rave Reviews After Years Out of Sight
description: We've heard enough about the race card so deftly played by smooth Johnnie L. Cochran Jr. in that Los Angeles trial most of us would rather forget. Less obvious, though just as entrenched and sometimes at least as insidious, is what might by called the gay card.

description: AFTER THE MADNESS

description: HERZOG-Chaim. The Jewish National Fund mourns the passing of former President of the State of Israel Chaim Herzog. We have lost a true champion of the Jewish people and the Zionist cause. An outstanding statesman, President Herzog guided Israel's people through the hardships of war and expressed their deepest yearnings for peace. May his family and the people of Israel be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Jewish National Fund Moshe Rivlin World Chairman, KKL Ronald S. Lauder President, J & F Milton S. Shapiro Immediate Past President, J & F Dr. Samuel I. Cohen Senior Executive Vice President, J & F

title: City Fears Miseries of Flood May Last for Weeks
description: As most of the last die-hards fled today from this unlivable city, struck by both flood and fire, residents began coming to grips with the knowledge that it may be weeks before they can return.

title: When Doctors Own Hospitals
description: The Government investigation of Columbia/ HCA Healthcare, the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain, raises profound questions beyond possible financial impropriety. The larger question is whether Columbia/HCA's practice of inviting local physicians to buy shares in its hospital complexes is appropriate. Critics say the arrangement encourages doctors to steer patients to a hospital they own rather than to possibly superior facilities that they do not own. The hospital chain says that ownership motivates doctors to work hard for the hospital on behalf of their patients.

title: Gretzky's Skill Leads To Breakthrough Goal
description: Rangers goalie Mike Richter is convinced that Wayne Gretzky does not determine where he will aim a shot until his stick is in the downswing. ''He very much reads the goalie's language,'' Richter said, meaning his body language.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One way or another, GAIL COOPER-HECHT, a theatrical-costume designer, was determined to use a black mink coat she saw several months ago at the Ritz Thrift Shop, a second-hand fur store on West 57th Street, in a play.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GATCH, MARY CURRY.
description: GATCH-Mary Curry. On April 17, 1997. Wife of the late Milton M. Gatch. Mother of Milton McC. Gatch, Philip C. Gatch and Thomas H. Gatch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOWARD, HY
description: HOWARD-Hy. Passed away April 19, 1997. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Cherished father of Elaine (George) Kahn and Jay Howard. oving grandfather of Jill (Richard), Eric, Brett, Justin and Spencer. Great-grandfather of Rachel and Lauren. You will be in our hearts forever.

title: People
description: * Anthony Wainwright was named to the new position of vice chairman and business development director at McKinney & Silver, Raleigh, N.C. He was previously chairman at Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Thousands Go on Strike at Goodyear Plants
description: More than 12,000 union workers at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company went on strike shortly after midnight Saturday at nine plants, after failing to reach an agreement on job security and wage and benefit issues.

title: Hartford Mulls An Overhaul Of Drug Laws
description: Connecticut's State Legislature is considering a major overhaul of its drug laws that would shift the emphasis from punishment toward treatment of drug abuse as a public health problem, in part as an attempt to reduce the costs of imprisonment.

title: Who uses the Internet and how? We'll get back to you on that if someone figures it out.
description: THE World Wide Web has been hailed as the king of all interactive media, where publishers can learn everything there is to know about their audiences because surfers vote with every mouse click. But more than two years after the Web burst into the limelight as the next great commercial medium, it is remarkable how little is still known about who is using it and how.

title: Follow That Precedent!
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Tales of Soured Affairs of the Heart Intersect in a Courtroom in Queens
description: Almost four decades ago, Burton Pugach, a well-known personal injury lawyer in the Bronx, was convicted of a sensational crime of passion. Mr. Pugach, who was married, paid three men $2,000 to throw lye in the face of a girlfriend who had threatened to leave him. The girlfriend, Linda Riss, was blinded.

title: Frank Talk on Dying: Examining the Choices
description: How should a doctor tell a patient that her cancer cannot be effectively treated? Will her managed-care insurer let her spend her last days or weeks in a hospital? If she asks for a speedy death, should the doctor oblige? If she goes into a coma, at what point should a doctor disconnect the devices that are keeping her alive? Suppose there is family disagreement about that final pulling of the plug?

title: Municipal Bond Abuses Return
description: Until a few years ago, the municipal bond industry was one of the most corrupt in the United States. The abuses consisted of politicians brazenly soliciting campaign donations from municipal bond firms in return for granting business on the underwriting of billions of dollars in public debt. In 1994, the Securities and Exchange Commission sought to correct these shady dealings by outlawing political donations by individuals and firms handling government bonds. But as The Times reported last week, leading bond underwriters have now found ways of circumventing the law and contributing the money anyway. The practice remains as corrupt as it ever was, and the S.E.C. should again shut it down.

title: Smith Corona Picks Partners & Shevack
description: The Smith Corona Corporation in Cortland, N.Y., which manufactures office products like typewriters, named Partners & Shevack in New York, to handle its worldwide account, with billings estimated at $10 million. The account was previously handled on a project basis by Ryan Drossman & Partners in New York.

title: Software Confusion
description: To the Editor:

title: High Quality, Higher Price
description: The newest competitor in the race for high-quality big-screen televisions has entered the market in New York City.

description: HUANG-Simon Kuo-Lun. Of Mount Kisco, NY. Beloved son of Jen-Chi and Shyh-Fen Ni Huang. Brother of Thomas Kuo-Fong Huang. For further information, call Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Inc, (1-800-244-6634).

description: To the Editor:

title: Tangled Web of Factors Led to Tobacco Talks
description: On Dec. 23, as President Clinton made a Christmas visit to the Marine Corps base at Camp Lejeune, N.C., that state's Governor, Jim Hunt, had a peace message for the President: the time might be ripe for the White House to help bring together cigarette makers and their adversaries in settlement talks.

title: Both Sides Are Shaky In a Draw
description: The largest crowd to ever watch a World Cup qualifying match in the United States was treated to a thrillingly bizarre game against Mexico today, one that produced two freakish goals and was wildly entertaining, but ultimately unfulfilling for the Americans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, SALLY
description: ISRAEL-Sally. On April 19, 1997. Ceramic artist and teacher. Beloved wife of Lawrence, loving sister of Rene Samuels, devoted aunt of Anne and Michael Samuels. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Monday and Tuesday, 5-8 PM, with service Wednesday, 1 PM.

title: From a Scouting Assignment at Age 10, Van Gundy Has Risen to the Top
description: In 1981, a freshman at Yale named Jeff Van Gundy decided that the esteemed Ivy League institution wasn't for him. Well, not exactly the school, but the basketball team. As a 5-foot-9-inch guard, he had been recommended to play there by an assistant coach who then left after Van Gundy's arrival on the New Haven campus, and Van Gundy was cut from the squad before the season began.

title: Biju Patnaik, 81, Daring Pilot-Patriot of India
description: Biju Patnaik, one of the most prominent survivors of the generation of Indian leaders who took part in the independence struggle against Britain, died here on Thursday. He was 81.

title: Indentured to Tobacco
description: To the Editor:

title: Architects Chosen For Arts Center
description: A New York City firm, Rafael Vinoly Architects, has been selected to design the Regional Performing Arts Center, a complex being planned as the future home of the Philadelphia Orchestra and other performing arts companies.

title: Who Is Tony Blair?
description: With 10 days to go in the British election campaign, it is a near certainty that Tony Blair will be the next Prime Minister. That leaves one question to be answered: Who is Tony Blair?

title: NETANYAHU AVOIDS CRIMINAL CHARGES IN SCANDAL INQUIRY
description: Israel's top state prosecutors announced today that they did not have enough evidence to press charges against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in a scandal over the appointment of an Attorney General, but said they had a ''tangible suspicion'' about the propriety of his role in the affair.

description: Wreckage Possibly Found
