description: GOLF

title: New Guidelines on Net Ads for Children
description: Responding to growing concerns about familiar cartoon characters prancing around World Wide Web sites and inviting children to enter contests, buy products or provide information about themselves, an advertising industry group will release new voluntary guidelines today for ''responsible marketing to children'' on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARRETT, JOHN D.
description: GARRETT-John D. The Officers, Trustees and Members of Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to his wife, Diana, and to the family our heartfelt sympathy. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Alan Levine, Ch. of the Bd. Robert P. Antler, President

title: New Measures To Separate Foreign Policy From Politics
description: Faced with criticism of the National Security Council in several campaign finance controversies, Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, is instituting new rules to limit the Democratic National Committee's access to his staff and to screen foreign visitors to the White House.

title: Charge in Baby Beating
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with attempted murder for beating his girlfriend's 14-month-old son while caring for the child on Saturday afternoon, the police said.

title: Gingrich's Loan From Dole Wasn't Unethical
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORE, CHESTER A.
description: GORE-Chester A. On April 19, 1997, at age 78. Beloved husband of Gerie, adored father of Eloise and treasured friend to many. President of Chester Gore Co., advertising. Chet did it all with charm, humor, brilliance and irrepressible optimism. Services Wednesday, April 23, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Lenox Hill Hospital Chairman's Fund for Medical Excellence.

title: After Setback, AT&T Pursues Global Reach And Partners
description: The AT&T Corporation's loose-knit strategy for extending its global reach appears to be unraveling, even as the international partnership of the MCI Communications Corporation and British Telecommunications P.L.C. is gaining strength.

title: Coaches Who Pick In Their Own Image
description: More than a third of the 30 National Football League teams entered last weekend's college draft with new generals at the helm. It was a chance for Bill Parcells, Jim Fassel, Dick Vermeil, Bobby Ross, Joe Bugel, Steve Mariucci, Dan Reeves, Mike Ditka, Pete Carroll, Kevin Gilbride and Bruce Coslet to put their personal imprints on their new teams.

title: The Evolution of Remote Controls
description: When Stephen Wozniak left Apple Computer in 1985, he formed a company to build the universal remote control, one that would work with every electronic device. He failed. The company, CL9 or Cloud 9, was sold to two of its engineers who altered the remotes to run hospitals' M.R.I. machines - a far less complex task than controlling TV's with hundreds of cable and satellite channels, VCR's, laser disks and stereos, not to mention today's digital video disks and Web TV. here is a recap of the remote's development and its struggle to end the confusion and the clutter on coffee tables.

title: Needed for an Impossible Role: Unimaginable Stamina
description: What could Wagner have been thinking when he composed the title role in ''Siegfried,'' the third installment of the ''Ring'' cycle, which came to the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night?

title: Final Day: Charlotte Slips, Washington Soars, O'Neal Misses
description: This was the situation facing the Charlotte Hornets in Milwaukee last night. Win and finish fifth in the Eastern Conference playoff seedings and play Atlanta in Round 1. Lose and finish sixth and play the Knicks. Final score: Milwaukee 120, Charlotte 100. The Hornets are headed to New York to take on a team they beat three out of four times during the regular season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A More Reassuring Tone From the Fed Chairman

title: Foreign Troops Protect Albania, but From What?
description: About half of the 6,000 foreign soldiers being sent here with United Nations backing are setting up camp and beginning patrols, but there is confusion about what else they are to do.

title: Light Rail Project Starting
description: After 11 years of plans and studies, workers are scheduled to break ground today on a light rail system for Hudson and Bergen Counties. When the $1.26 billion first phase of the project is completed, trains will stop at 17 stations along a 10.6-mile route paralleling the Hudson River from Bayonne to the Hoboken PATH and train terminal. Officials hope to have the trains running by late 1999.

title: Clinton Is Said to Fill Federal Reserve Post
description: President Clinton has decided to name Roger Ferguson, a financial consultant, to the last vacancy on the Federal Reserve Board, a White House official said tonight.

title: No Headline
description: ''This error was inflated totally out of proportion by our political rivals for political reasons.''

title: Key to City Hall Opens Door to National Power
description: Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, an early favorite in Mexico City's first-ever mayoral election, heard people at one campaign stop in a remote suburb complain the other day of Government indifference to the pollution of local water.

title: Richard Tousey, 88; Solar Physicist
description: Richard Tousey, a solar physicist who used a captured World War II V-2 rocket to take the first photographs of the Sun's ultraviolet spectrum from beyond the atmosphere, died on Tuesday at Prince Georges Hospital Center in Maryland. He was 88 and had lived in Mitchellville, Md.

title: Stopping Drunken Drivers
description: Those who choose to drive drunk may want to steer clear of the town of Pennsauken altogether. In what local officials say is a first for the state, the Pennsauken police have begun sending letters to police departments in the hometowns of motorists whose licenses are suspended because of drunken driving in Pennsauken, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The idea is to stop drivers with suspended licenses from flouting the law.

title: Nets Take The Hawks' Giveaway
description: The dance music thumped. The beer tabs popped. A farewell party of sorts was under way in the Nets' locker room tonight, with many of those drifting out of the Meadowlands knowing they may not be back.

title: Montague Selects A Chief Executive
description: Brian Martin, executive vice president and business development director at Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, is leaving that agency after a year and a half to join Montague &, a communications consulting company in Westport, Conn., in the new position of chief executive. At Montague, Mr. Martin, 37, will work with Ty Montague, the chief creative officer. At Kirshenbaum Bond, Benson Hausman, 28, vice president for new business development, will succeed Mr. Martin.

title: Charges Test Mettle of Tough New Election Rules in Kentucky
description: Two months after Paul E. Patton, a Democrat, won election as Governor of Kentucky in 1995, the state Republican Party filed a series of complaints, charging his campaign with violating state election and campaign finance laws.

title: Advertising Giant Likely To Break Up
description: Cordiant P.L.C., the advertising agency company descended from the Saatchi brothers' empire, is expected to announce today that it will dissolve itself, spinning off to shareholders its main holdings, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Bates Worldwide, executives with knowledge of the proposed transaction said last night.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: EXPONENTIAL SAYS DEFECT TO DELAY CHIP PRODUCTION
description: Exponential Technology Inc., a closely held computer chip maker partly owned by Apple Computer Inc. and UMAX Data Systems, said yesterday that a design defect would delay production of its highest-speed chips. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., had planned to ship the chips by July. They run at speeds of 500 megahertz, about twice the speed of current processors. Richard Bergman, Exponential's vice president of marketing, said, ''We're really pushing the edge and sometimes you break things.'' Apple played down the delay. ''We haven't announced any specific products'' using Exponential chips, said Russell Brady, a spokesman for Apple.

title: Patterns
description: Von Furstenberg's Return

title: Insurance Fraud Admitted
description: Two Bergen County chiropractors agreed to settle charges that they bilked state-run auto insurance pools of more than $12 million by performing meaningless tests and procedures, the Attorney General's office said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LINZER, LENA
description: LINZER-Lena. On April 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Abraham. Devoted mother of Morton, Claire Shapiro, Burnette Groveman and Lawrence. Cherished grandmother of seven and great grandmother of seven. Loving sister of Yetta Penzel. A remarkable woman. Services Wednesday, 10 A.M., at ''Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapel,'' Queens Boulevard and 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Joe Louis Was There Earlier
description: TIGER WOODS brings up the aspects of legacy -- of the golfers, and athletes, of color who had preceded him, and who struggled against discrimination. Immediately after winning the Masters, and in an interview while at the Bulls-Knicks game on Saturday, he spoke of Charlie Sifford and Lee Elder and Ted Rhodes in golf, and of Jackie Robinson in baseball.

title: Bad News Bears
description: By human standards, real-life Poppa Bears do not measure up as good fathers. For one thing, male bears in some species have a habit of killing the existing offspring of any female taken as a new mate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINTRAUB, MILDRED
description: WEINTRAUB-Mildred. Of Long Island, Yonkers and The Bronx. We deeply mourn the passing of our beloved mother. Her indomitable spirit, strength and love of family has been an inspiration to all who knew and loved her. A memorial service will be held at the Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, New York, at 12 Noon, Thursday, April 24th. From her loving children: Dr. Michael I. Weintraub, Karen Weintraub Novins and Sanford Weintraub.

title: CLINTON APPROVES NEW U.S. SANCTIONS AGAINST BURMESE
description: After weeks of internal debate, President Clinton has approved a ban on new American investment in Myanmar because of human-rights abuses by the Burmese military Government, a senior Administration official said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the philanthropist Brooke Astor misstated the purpose of the Astor Foundation's $500,000 grant to benefit the Astor Row houses on West 130th Street in Harlem. The grant, to the New York Landmarks Conservancy, is to restore historic porches on Astor Row; it is not for low-income housing.

title: Boston Proves a Rough Road for Champions
description: While the 101st running of the Boston Marathon lacked speed and passion today, at least the top racers in the women's wheelchair division were willing to attack. Jean Driscoll of Champaign, Ill., and Louise Sauvage of Australia played a game of cat and mouse for 22 miles until the unthinkable happened.

title: AT&T Profit Down; Weak 2d Quarter Seen, Too
description: A month after warning that it faced a gloomy financial future, AT&T delivered the first bitter spoonful yesterday. The company said that net income from continuing operations dropped 24 percent in the first quarter and that the next quarter would also fall short of earlier estimates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOBLER, GERTRUDE
description: TOBLER-Gertrude. On April 19, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin. Devoted mother of Carol Miller, Marilyn Wise and motherin-law of Lester Wise. Loving sister of Lottie Aplebaum. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother. Private services were held at ''Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When JULES FEIFFER was a teen-ager, he got a job working for WILL EISNER, the cartoonist and writer, and promptly offered him a few words of advice. ''I was at an age when you think that anyone you admire can be anything you want him to be,'' Mr. Feiffer recalled yesterday. ''I told him I thought his prewar cartoons were better than his postwar ones, and he said, 'If you think so, why don't you write one then?' ''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, BELLE (HECHT)
description: GORDON-Belle (Hecht). Peacefully, as she lived, on 4/19/97, in her 97th year. Beloved wife of the late Ben, loving mother of Richard. Survived by dear sisters Ray Cherr, Ethel Gerstin and Anne Nagourney. Services were held.

title: TRANS WORLD AIRLINES (TWA,A)
description: Trans World Airlines reported a widened first-quarter loss yesterday because of higher maintenance and training costs and a decline in passenger traffic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTINI, LOIS COWAN
description: MARTINI-Lois Cowan, of NYC. Age 89. Died at home April 18, 1997. She was the beloved wife of Roland Martini, Vice President of Gardner Advertising who died in 1966. Born and raised in Sioux Falls, S.D., she received a scholarship and graduated from St. Joseph's College, Emmitsburg, MD in 1928. She taught high school on Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in SD, and English at Washington H.S. in Sioux Falls. At the begining of World War II, she moved to Washington D.C. and then to NYC to work for the FBI as a translator of French and Italian. After W.W. II, she went to work at Gardner Advertising where she met and married her late husband. In her retirement, after his death, she made frequent trips to Italy and London, England and attended the Church of St. John the Evangelist in NYC. She is survived by sisterin-law Mrs. Robert Cowan (Margaret) of Hemet, CA; niece Mrs. Roger K. Allan (Nance) of Spearfish, SD and brother-in-law Edward A. Wojcoski of Arlington VA, and many longtime close friends. Services, including viewing at 9:30AM today. Funeral Mass at 10:30AM will be held at the Church of St. John the Evangelist (1st Avenue and 55 Street). Interment will be at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne NY immediately following the services. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Church of St. John the Evangelist, 348 East 55 Street, NY 10022 or VNSNY Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, N.Y., N.Y. 10001.

title: A Stage for All the World of Asian-Americans
description: When Tisa Chang's father, Ping-Hsun Chang, was a young man in China, he and Chou En-lai went to Nankai University in Tianjin and acted together in school plays. Often they did Ibsen, Ms. Chang said in an interview. Her father played male roles while the future Communist leader specialized in female roles. This favorite family story may have been the start of Ms. Chang's fascination with theater and with her campaign to end stereotypical casting.

title: Turner to Build Laboratory
description: The Turner Corporation said yesterday that it had received a $35.7 million contract from the University of Connecticut Health Center in Storrs, Conn., to construct an academic research building. Turner, of New York, said that the 11-story building would house the health center's biomedical research, molecular biology programs and 128 laboratory modules.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARY LOU RETTON, the 1984 Olympic gold-medal gymnast, and her husband, SHANNON KELLEY, an investment broker, have a second daughter, born on April 15, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, SALLY
description: ISRAEL-Sally. On April 19, 1997. Ceramic artist and teacher. Beloved wife of Lawrence, loving sister of Rene Samuels, devoted aunt of Anne and Michael Samuels. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Monday and Tuesday, from 5-8 P.M., with service Wednesday, at 1 P.M.

title: Reckless Salesmanship on Arms
description: In the name of advancing American commercial interests overseas, the Clinton Administration has all but turned its policy on arms sales abroad over to the Pentagon and the corporations that make the weapons. Their lobbying is hard to stop even when it unsettles a regional balance of power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HABER, LEONARD
description: HABER-Leonard. Beloved husband of Janet. Devoted father of David, Jeffrey, Michael and Robert. Cherished father-in-law of Dana, Nancy and Lori and adored grandfather of William, Jessica, Eric, Briana, Joshua and Lindsay. Len was a wonderful, caring person always exhibiting his intelligence and knowledge of life. He will be remembered forever by his family and many friends and sadly mourned by all. It was an honor to know him. We will always love him. Expressions of sympathy can be made by donations to your favorite charity in Len's memory. Services on Wednesday 2PM, Bernheim Apter, Maplewood, NJ (201) 763-3505.

title: Going against the trend, Cordiant seeks better results by getting smaller, not bigger.
description: THE world's sixth-largest advertising agency holding company, Cordiant P.L.C., is undertaking a radical and unusual reorganization, splitting into two companies to improve the business performance of both.

title: Profitable Knowledge
description: When James O'Hagan discovered that his law partners were helping a client prepare a takeover bid for Pillsbury Company, he bought Pillsbury stock before the public announcement and racked up an effortless $4.3 million profit. His behavior was shameless and unprofessional. But did Mr. O'Hagan act illegally? That question will be answered by the Supreme Court when, on the basis of arguments heard last week, it draws a line between trades that are merely distasteful and trades that are illegal.

title: HUGHES WINS $100 MILLION CONTRACT FROM F.A.A.
description: Hughes Information Technology Systems has won a Federal Aviation Administration contract that could be worth as much as $100 million to integrate air traffic computer systems, the agency said yesterday. The contract consists of a three-year, $40 million base contract and two two-year, $30 million options. Over a 10- to 15-year period, Hughes will provide the technical support needed to merge with existing computer systems that make up the National Airspace Infrastructure Management System. The company is a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation.

title: New Stuff: Let the Buyer Be Aware
description: COMPUTER prices are dropping. Dog bites man. Computer prices are always dropping. Wait a bit and you get more power for less money. But what if you need a Windows 95 machine today?

title: Court Won't Reconsider Tax Ruling in Favor Of Texaco
description: The Supreme Court yesterday left standing a lower court ruling that Texaco Inc. did not owe about $1 billion in taxes. As a result, the oil company said it expected to get a refund of $700 million from the Internal Revenue Service this year.

title: Chairman To Leave Humanities Endowment
description: Sheldon Hackney, who has led the National Endowment for the Humanities during a period of reduced budgets, told the White House today that he would not seek another term as chairman and would return to the University of Pennsylvania to teach history.

description: To the Editor:

title: A Monitor for Broker Ads
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers, which runs the Nasdaq stock market, said today that it was creating a unit to investigate complaints about the advertising and marketing materials of brokerage firms. The unit is to be part of the advertising regulation department of N.A.S.D. Regulation, and it will be led by an N.A.S.D. Regulation official, Amy Sochard.

title: Sergeant's Lawyers Start Case By Accusing 2 of His Accusers
description: Lawyers for a drill sergeant charged with rape and sexual harassment set out today to demonstrate that his accusers are habitual liars who openly yearned to have intimate relations with him.

title: 'Adapted' Theaters
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPELBAUM, MAREANER S.
description: APPELBAUM-Mareaner S. Born May 9, 1905. Passed away April 18, 1997. Beloved wife and mother. Graveside services 11:30 Wednesday, Mt. Lebanon Cemetery.

title: The Pink of Conditions
description: If the makeup mood for winter was Deep Purple, for spring it's Pretty in Pink. The pinks come in different shades with hints of lavender, brown or coral to achieve a natural look on any skin tone.

title: Mexican Steel Venture Set
description: Grupo Acerero del Norte S.A. said today that it had formed a $30 million joint venture with Eisenwerk Sulzau-Werfen R.& E. Weinberger A.G. of Austria. The venture, based in Mexico, will make rollers, which are used in the production of steel plate. GAN, as the Mexican company is better known, will hold a 51 percent interest in the new company, while the rest will be owned by the Austrian company. GAN, the parent company of the steelmaker Altos Hornos de Mexico S.A., said it planned to export 45 percent of the new company's production. The rest will be sold to Mexican steel companies.

title: Irish Merchant Tells Inquiry Of Cash Gifts to Ex-Premier
description: In a scandal that has thrown Irish politics into turmoil, the former chief executive and part-owner of Ireland's largest department store chain told a Government tribunal today that he had provided about $1.1 million for the use of former Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FYLSTRA, WILLIAM T.
description: FYLSTRA-William T. on Sunday, April 20, 1997 of Kinnelon. President and CEO of Passaic County Newspapers, Paterson and past president of the publishing industry's twenty-five year club. Beloved husband of JoAnn (nee Lucas) Fylstra; loving father of six. Funeral services were held Monday at the Vander May Wayne Colonial Funeral Home, 567 Ratzer Road, Wayne. In lieu of flowers memorial donations to TwentyFive Year Club, c/o Playboy Enterprises, 730 5th Ave, NY, NY 10019 would be appreciated.

title: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AGREES TO ACQUIRE NHP
description: The Apartment Investment and Management Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy NHP Inc. in a transaction valued at about $279 million. The agreement to purchase the second-largest United States apartment property manager is valued at $21.50 a share. It called for Apartment Investment to buy from NHP's two largest shareholders their 53 percent stake for about $145 million in stock and cash. Other shareholders of NHP, based in Vienna, Va., would receive about $134 million, payable in either a cash and stock combination or all stock. With this and other pending transactions, Apartment Investment, an investment trust based in Denver, would own or have a stake in 34,842 apartment units and manage another 176,000 units.

title: Washington Mayor Supports Some Executions
description: The Mayor of the nation's capital, long an opponent of the death penalty, said today that he now favored executing killers of police officers.

title: Corrections
description: A list of credits yesterday with a television review of ''Fred Friendly Seminar: Before I Die,'' a WNET program being shown tonight on PBS stations, referred imprecisely to two executive producers. Richard Kilberg is the program's executive producer; Barry Levine is the executive producer of WNET's Internet Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDOFF, ROBERT
description: DAVIDOFF-Robert, on April 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Lore. Devoted father of Roger and Linda. Loving father-in-law of Patrina. Loving grandfather to Andrew, David and Daniel. Visitation Tuesday 7:30-9:30 PM. Services Wednesday 11:30 AM at Schwartz Bros, Forest Hills.

title: HEXCEL TO ACQUIRE U.S. OPERATIONS OF FIBERITE
description: The Hexcel Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire most of the United States operations of Fiberite Inc. for about $300 million. Hexcel, based in Stamford, Conn., said that the operations to be acquired produce composite materials for the aerospace industry and had sales of about $200 million for 1996. Fiberite, based in Tempe, Ariz., will retain operations in Orange, Calif., and Ostringen, Germany. Hexcel, which makes materials for commercial aircraft, said that the acquisition expanded its product line into new areas. Hexcel's 1996 revenues totaled $695 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: Malone (and Guardians) Feel the Time Is Now
description: The last power forward on earth is building a dream house in his favorite city, wherever that may be. Construction is only two-thirds done, but he can already visualize the ride home on his Harley: up the mountain, past the boss's house, into the driveway, through an eight-foot log door, straight to the den, past the mounted grizzly, touch the trophy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AZCARRAGA MILMO, EMILIO. I
description: AZCARRAGA MILMO-Emilio. I join the people of Mexico in mouring the death of Emilio Azcarraga Milmo. He most certainly did fulfill his mandate to broadcast entertainment to the world. Saint Francis, your friend is now home. Jose E. R. Maldonado, II

title: Lease Space Popular In Grand Central
description: The restoration of Grand Central Terminal is more than a year away from completion. But already, prospective stores and restaurants are lining up to secure the 180,000 square feet -- twice the space available before the make-over -- in the Beaux Arts landmark.

title: Trenton Tells Bell Atlantic to Speed Up Urban Cable Connections
description: New Jersey's Board of Public Utilities ordered Bell Atlantic today to speed up its plans for connecting schools, libraries and the state's biggest cities to its high-speed communications network -- a system now available almost exclusively to suburban business parks and large corporations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIRANY, LESLIE
description: VIRANY-Leslie, on April 20th, 1997. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Cherished father of Susan and Steven. Dear father-in-law of Jerry. Adored ''Papa'' of Rachel and Nicole. Services Thursday, April 24th, 1:30 PM, at BoulevardRiverside, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York.

title: Grocery Chain's Bank Has 100,000 Patrons

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEDER, HENRY
description: FEDER-Henry, who owned and ran Joel's dress shop on Church Street in West Chester, Pennsylvania for more than 40 years, died on April 20, 1997 after a long and painful illness, at the home of his brother, Samuel L. Feder, M.D.,in Lenox, Massachusetts. He was 85. Joel's was a successful family business established more than 60 years ago by Joel and Anna Weiss, Feder's sister. After Feder's service in the military during World War II, he joined his sister in the store in 1947. He quickly fit in. His personal charm and exquisite taste won him a loyal following among fashion-conscious women of West Chester and neighboring communities. Feder was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, the ninth of the 11 children of Max and Fanny Feder. After attending high school in Philadelphia, he went to Northwestern University in Evanston, Illinois. Early on he cultivated a taste in literature and particularly the theater, and he numbered many leading stage and screen figures among his close friends, frequently entertaining them at his West Chester home. Feder was among the first young men inducted into the Army in 1940 and he spent the next six years in the Pacific Theater, where he rose through the ranks to become a major. The friendships he forged in the Army stayed with him throughout his life. In 1956 he married Frances Rains (nee Propper) and embarked on the bon vivant style of life that became his hallmark. The couple traveled to all parts of the world year after year spending weeks exploring London or Paris, Venice or Madrid, Jerusalem or Cairo. On one of the trips they retraced the battlefield route he followed in the Pacific. Feder is survived by his wife, Frances, his stepdaughter, Jessica Rains, a granddaughter, Abigail Lentz, his sisters Sylvia Kohn and Mathilda Brailove and brothers Daniel and Samuel Feder.

title: U.S. JUDGE RULES ITT CAN'T BE FORCED TO HAVE MAY MEETING

Although the company has traditionally met in May, U.S. District Court Judge Philip Pro said yesterday that ''neither Nevada law nor ITT's bylaws require that the 1997 annual meeting be conducted in May.'' Hilton sought a quick meeting to complete its $10.5 billion hostile takeover bid for ITT. ITT, which owns the Caesars World casinos and the Sheraton hotel chain, said that it could hold its annual meeting as late as November under Nevada law, but had not set a date. Analysts said that a delay would give ITT time to pursue a reorganization plan and regain shareholders' confidence. Reynolds has been selling businesses, dismissing workers and cutting costs to bolster profit and pare debt after earnings tumbled amid a downturn in aluminum prices in 1996. description: President Jacques Chirac took a major step today toward a difficult French rendezvous with a common European currency in 1999, announcing the dissolution of the national legislature tonight and calling an election for May 25, a year early.

title: Rookie Season Served As a Primer for Calipari
description: The dark circles that slowly surfaced beneath John Calipari's eyes this season appeared like rings in a tree trunk. Each represented an uneasy passage for the New Jersey Nets' rookie coach. Each revealed another stressful step in his development.

title: Evolutionary Necessity Or Glorious Accident? Biologists Ponder the Self
description: THE self is like an irritating television jingle: you cannot get it out of your head. Whatever you do on this blue planet with your allotted three score and ten, whatever you taste, embrace, learn or create, all will be filtered through the self. Even sleep offers no escape, for who is it that struts through the center of every dream but you, yourself and id?

title: Ex-Official At Office For Aliens Is Sentenced
description: A Federal judge sent the former third-ranking Immigration and Naturalization Service official in the agency's Newark office to jail for three and a half years today for accepting cash and gifts in exchange for helping people enter the country illegally.

title: Private Colleges Juggle Aid Formulas To Fill Seats With the Top Freshmen
description: ''I loved Tulane,'' recalled Hillery Martin, a freshman from Los Angeles, about her search for just the right school. ''But if I hadn't gotten the scholarship, I probably would have gone to the College of William and Mary.''

title: Flooding Crests in Ravaged City; Residents Face Weeks of Anxiety
description: Sitting in the emergency shelter, knowing that everything back home might be lost to the Red River flood, Deb Storey looked at her hand, gasped and began to cry.

title: Iraq Plans Flights to Saudi Border Despite Ban
description: In a new sign of defiance, Iraq said today that it would send helicopters to the Saudi border to pick up returning Muslim pilgrims despite a ban on flights in the area. The United States, which with its allies enforces the ban, urged Iraq to reconsider, but said American warplanes would not shoot down civilian helicopters.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARTIN CRUZ SMITH has been named the winner of the prestigious Hammett Prize by the North American branch of the International Association of Crime Writers. Thanks to a lucky raffle ticket, he will come from San Francisco to New York to accept the honor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUSE, SANFORD WILLIAM, CPA
description: HOUSE-Sanford William, CPA, died on April 20, 1997. Devoted husband of the late Esther. Loving friend to Molly Bronstein. Beloved father of Susan Eisman (Arthur); cherished grandfather of Leslie and Michael Wiener, and Fred and Jennifer Eisman; adoring greatgrandfather of Lillian, Rachel and Douglas. Funeral services at 10 am on Wed, April 23, Temple Israel in New Rochelle. Interment Sharon Garden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. For more information call George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle, NY.

title: POP
description: A Family Band With Roots

title: Lost Cause: Isringhausen Is Sidelined 6 to 8 Weeks
description: Jason Isringhausen, seen as a part of the Mets' foundation for the future, was found to have a compression fracture of his pitching wrist yesterday. The injury was the result of a recent assault on a trash can.

title: Dance in Review
description: Dancers Whose Physicality Makes One Rethink Their Art

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Passover, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations are suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Amateur Shakes Up Ideas on Recipe for Life
description: SCIENTIFIC research is so specialized, and its hot fields so crowded, that it is highly unusual for an amateur to make a significant contribution. So it is surprising that a patent lawyer from Munich, Germany, has managed to elbow his way to the forefront of attention with a striking theory about the origin of life.

title: Knicks Look at Quality, Not (Playoff) Quantity
description: For the last six seasons, the Knicks have arrived here with a bus-load of playoff-hardened veterans. But this year Coach Jeff Van Gundy is no longer dealing exclusively with decorated post-season warriors.

title: 2 Held in Thrill-Killings of Pizza Men
description: Two small-town New Jersey teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with what officials called the brutal, senseless and elaborately plotted murders of two pizza deliverymen, who were lured to an abandoned house in a remote area of Sussex County Saturday night and shot to death in their car.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYDA, JOSEPH
description: BEYDA-Joseph. Once in a generation, the Almighty gives us a gift and puts on this earth a person whose purpose is to lead, and make a difference. In his 57 short years, Joseph has touched thousands of souls from children to senior citizens. His humanity, his kindness, and his caring inspires us all. His impact on our community and on the lives of those he touched will last forever. We miss you, Joseph, but you will never be gone. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Barbara, his daughter Shirley, sons David and Jeffrey, his mother Shirley and the whole family. May he continue to look after us all from above.

title: 2 Executives Get New Posts At Fidelity
description: Fidelity Investments announced yesterday that Robert Pozen, its general counsel, had been named to succeed J. Gary Burkhead as president and chief executive of the Fidelity Management and Research Company, which oversees its $472 billion family of Fidelity mutual funds.

title: The Hard Times of a Coal Town, Ignored in Booming Britain's Vote
description: The turnoff for this South Yorkshire mining town with the Dickensian name comes up shortly after an election billboard on the main road saying, ''Britain is booming.''

title: After Four Centuries, Still Gaining Devotees
description: Tomorrow is the 433d anniversary of Shakespeare's birth and, from box office grosses to book sales to a survey by the Modern Language Association, the evidence suggests that more people are watching him, reading him and studying him than ever before.

title: British Inflation Threat Seen in Bank Offerings
description: The sharp rise in the price of shares of Alliance & Leicester P.L.C., the first British building society to convert to a bank this year, shows that the inflationary effect of such conversions might be more severe than expected. Some 91 million Alliance & Leicester shares, or 16 percent of the total, were traded yesterday, and the shares closed at 566.5 pence ($9.23), significantly higher than the 460 to 512 pence that analysts had signaled as targets.

title: Pop Culture's Role in Nuclear Fears
description: Tonight's ''Frontline'' takes on the anti-nuclear-power industry. Richard Rhodes, the author of ''The Making of the Atom Bomb,'' brings in scientists and engineers to make a provocative case that nuclear energy, now being abandoned by the United States, is safer, cleaner and more efficient than the coal, oil and natural gas on which the nation continues to rely.

title: Head Games in Vogue As Devils Visit Montreal
description: Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire wanted no part of the many distractions that seem to lurk in every nook and cranny of this hockey-crazed city, where Lemaire played for a dozen seasons and where he coached for two more.

title: The Season Is Gone, And So Are the Coaches
description: For many coaches, the end of the regular season will mean the end of a job.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NABATOFF, RICHARD
description: NABATOFF-Richard. Age 39. Beloved son of Robert and Joan. Devoted brother of Ross and Diane. Loving uncle to Andrew, Nathan and Alison. Cherished grandson of Jean Herman. Services Thursday, April 24, 11AM at Temple EmanuEl Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Contributions may be made to the Wharton School, Philadelphia Pa.

title: Trying to Unite Fractured Tribe While Fighting State Over Taxes
description: Until six months ago, Michael W. Schindler was an ironworker who could balance on a rail in the sky.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  THOMAS, TREVOR A.
description: THOMAS-Trevor A. In loving memory of our beloved son who left us three years ago today. A son who will never be forgotten. Mother and stepfather

title: The Big Cash Register
description: Is there anything left but money, the market, the bottom line and more money, plus money, money, money?

title: Defendant Cross-Examines Ex-Lover Who Accuses Him
description: The unfaithful husband, accused of threatening to kill a former lover when she tried to leave him, stared at the woman on the witness stand. He was acting as his own lawyer, he had said, in the hope that she would soften under his cross-examination.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ALPER, JAMES B.
description: ALPER-James B. Artist/Engineer/Inventor/ Secular Humanist/Visionary. In eternal remembrance of James B. Alper who died on Earth Day, April 22, 1990: ''T'en aux etoiles''From you to the stars. Forever, Rita

title: Alan Gruber, 69, Retired Insurance Executive
description: Alan R. Gruber, who took charge of the Equity Funding Corporation after it collapsed in the 1970's in a big financial scandal and rebuilt it into the Orion Capital Corporation, a thriving insurance holding company, died Friday, the company announced. He was 69.

title: Mr. Netanyahu Survives
description: Israel's top prosecutors spared Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu the embarrassment of a criminal trial and the instant collapse of his Government Sunday. They found insufficient evidence to sustain a police recommendation to indict him for fraud and breach of trust in a political corruption scandal.

title: Blizzard Delays Recovery of Likely Jet Wreckage
description: As a spring blizzard swirled around the New York Mountain range near here, the military suspended recovery operations of aircraft wreckage today, confident that the missing warplane had been found and that the pilot had not survived.

title: 'Provoking' China
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Nation's Politicians, Big Tobacco No Longer Bites
description: When Attorney General Michael C. Moore of Mississippi filed the first lawsuit by a state against the tobacco industry, in May 1994, it was considered an act of supreme political courage, if not self-immolation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, SIDNEY
description: SMITH-Sidney. The Officers and Trustees of Jewish Child Care Association convey their deepest sympathy to the family fo Sidney Smith. In his many years as director of Business affairs at JCCA, Mr. Smith's superior professional skills enabled him to make a real difference in the lives of clients and colleagues. Irwin U. Goldberg, President Stephen Sokoloff, Chairman Paul Gitelson, DSW, Executive Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SESSLER, DORIS
description: SESSLER-Doris, on April 20th, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Sigmund. Devoted mother of Paul Sessler & Isabel Zupan, daughterin-law Bonnie Sessler and son-inlaw Jeffrey Zupan. Loving sister of Sadie Glassman, Pauline Jawitz, Anna Crystal, the late Sol and Herman Markoff and the late Elsie Schreiber. Cherished grandmother of Ira and Cheryl Sessler, Deborah and Geoffrey Howell, Jennifer Sessler, Julie Zupan, and Erica and Gabriel Anthony. Friends may call at the home of Paul Sessler on Wednesday after 7 P.M., then at the home of Isabel Zupan on Thursday after 7 P.M. and on Sunday from 2-5 P.M.

title: Stella McCartney: Ready for Chloe
description: When Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH Moet Hennessy-Louis Vuitton, chose two young British designers to head up Christian Dior and Givenchy, the French Establishment could be a bit blithe. Mr. Arnault is press hungry, shows off his power, thrives on doing the unthinkable.

title: New Jersey Celebrates Start of Work on $1.1 Billion Light Rail Line on Hudson
description: New Jersey today officially started construction of the first segment of a light rail system to run along the Hudson River, a $1.1 billion project that officials called the state's biggest public works job ever and one that will put this city in a better position to draw jobs from New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILMAN, FREDERIC
description: HEILMAN-Frederic. Suddenly, in Longboat Key, Florida. Beloved husband of Kathryn, adored father of Craig and Tracy, devoted son of the late Rosalind and Samuel, loving brother of Dr. Kenneth Heilman. Will be sorely missed by his family and many friends. Services Thursday, April 24, 1997 at noon at the Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, New York.

title: A $600 Million Order for Bombardier Jets
description: Bombardier Inc. said today that it had received a $600 million order from Atlantic Southeast Airlines for 30 Canadair regional jet aircraft, the biggest single order to date for the 50-passenger plane.

title: Popularity of Interactive Theater Is Changing the Face of Off Broadway
description: The strains of ''Volare'' pierced the West Village catering hall festooned with garish statues and strings of blinking lights. ''Someone just shook my hand just like my Uncle Phil does!'' Toni Marie Vaccarino, a recent law school graduate from Wayne, N.J., said as she demonstrated the backhanded grasp. Then she pulled her chair closer to the banquet table to avoid the elbows of a klutzy wedding guest on the dance floor who was busy mangling the fox trot.

title: Norsk Hydro Shares Up As Profit Beats Forecast
description: Shares of Norsk Hydro A.S. surged yesterday after first-quarter profits fell a less-than-expected 4 percent, reflecting higher taxes on its petroleum production and lower prices for its aluminum and fertilizers. The company, Norway's biggest industrial concern, said pretax profit fell to 3.202 billion kroner ($456 million) from 3.327 billion a year earlier.

title: Independence, a Mutual Bank In Brooklyn, Plans to Go Public
description: Independence Savings Bank, a $3.7 billion Brooklyn-based thrift institution that is one of the few remaining mutually owned banks in New York City, will sell shares to the public to raise money for acquisitions and expansion, the bank's chairman said yesterday.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: SETBACK FOR WHITMAN BOND PLAN -- The New Jersey Senate delayed action on Governor Whitman's plan to borrow $2.75 billion for the state's pension system. B6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WADMOND, ELITA CASON
description: WADMOND-Elita Cason, 93, of Palm Beach, Florida, and formerly of New York City, died at her home in Palm Beach on April 18, 1997. She was predeceased by her husband, Lowell Wadmond, a long time senior partner of White and Case. Mrs. Wadmond was born in Lakeland, Florida and attended Southern Seminary in Virginia. While living in New York City, Mrs. Wadmond served on the Boards of Grosvenor Neighborhood House, The Presbyterian Home, The American Bible Society and during World War II on the Board of the Morgan Officers Club. Mrs. Wadmond was a member of Brick Presbyterian Church and the Colony Club in New York City and the Everglades Club and the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach, Florida. She is survived by several cousins. Her services will be private. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to The First United Methodist Church, 72 Lake Morton Drive, Lakeland, Florida 33801. The Heath Funeral Chapel in Lakeland, Florida and Quattlebaum-Holeman Burse Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Taiwan's Money Gifts Influence U.S. Policy
description: Your April 14 editorial ''The Taiwan Factor'' says Taiwan played a central role in the White House fund-raising abuses. It is well known that Taiwan has the second-largest lobby in America, and it is hard to imagine that Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, could have gotten a visa to visit the United States without giving political donations to his alma mater, Cornell University.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about plans to open a gold mine in Turkey misidentified one sea that borders a broad band of Turkish territory that officials of a French-based company, Eurogold, believe may be rich with gold. The band stretches to the Black Sea from the Aegean, not the Adriatic.

title: Questioning of Potential Jurors in Oklahoma Bomb Trial Is Ended
description: The questioning of potential jurors in the Oklahoma City bombing trial ended today. On Tuesday morning, prosecutors and lawyers for the defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, will begin using peremptory challenges to winnow the panelists until a jury is seated.

title: 60 Years After Disaster, A Zeppelin Is Set to Fly
description: IT has been almost exactly 60 years since the giant Hindenburg zeppelin exploded in a spectacular fireball over Lakehurst, N.J., killing 37 crew members and passengers who had just completed a leisurely flight across the Atlantic. Though the world has since seen scores of much bigger aviation catastrophes, the Hindenburg became forever synonymous with disaster in the popular mind and abruptly ended the era of zeppelins.

title: State Senate Deals Setback To Pension Borrowing Plan
description: In a setback for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the New Jersey Senate delayed a scheduled vote today on the Governor's proposal to borrow $2.75 billion for the state pension system after Republican legislative leaders said that they did not have the 21 votes needed to approve the plan.

title: Rigorous Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, IRVING L.
description: STONE-Irving L., on 4/21/'97, 86 years. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving father of Judith and Irving Kaufman. Devoted grandfather of Carole A. Bloom. Service 1:15 PM Thursday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Arson Caused Lodi Fire
description: Arson caused the raging fire that gutted two big discount stores last Thursday, Bergen County prosecutors said yesterday. They declined to discuss details of the case or whether there were suspects. Ralph Lilore, the assistant county prosecutor who heads the arson squad, said only that the fire started in the automotive section of National Wholesale Liquidators, which shared the 200,000-square-foot brick building along Route 17 with an International Food Warehouse store. The building's owners, Vornado Corporation in Saddle Brook, did not return phone messages yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEIS, MARJORIE
description: WEIS-Marjorie. The Members of Rockrimmon Country Club are saddened by the passing of their long time good friend and extend sincere sympathy to her husband and family. Leonard Danon, President

title: Sharpton Ally Opposes Brooklyn Councilwoman
description: In a City Council race that is bound to have broad implications, Charles Barron, a Brooklyn civic advocate with close ties to the Rev. Al Sharpton, announced his candidacy yesterday to oppose Priscilla A. Wooten, a 15-year incumbent, in the Democratic primary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZECKHAUSEN, ELIZABETH MC MILLAN
description: ZECKHAUSEN-Elizabeth Mc Millan of Manhasset, Long Island, NY. A combined memorial service for Elizabeth and Paul Zeckhasuen, Sr. is Saturday, April 26, 1997 at 12 noon at the Chapel of Manhasset Congregational Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Wilbraham United Church, 500 Main St., Wilbraham, MA. 01095

title: The Netanyahu Verdict: Political Probation
description: A few minutes after the Attorney General finished announcing that he did not intend to indict the Prime Minister, a jaunty Benjamin Netanyahu came on the air to declare that another challenge by his political enemies had been firmly rebuffed, and so he could continue on his chosen path.

description: In a Desolate World

title: Goodwill Venues Shifted
description: Boxing at the 1998 Goodwill Games in New York City has been switched from the Theater at Madison Square Garden to a 3,300-seat structure to be built on the U.S.S. Intrepid, and figure skating has been moved from the Garden to Nassau Coliseum on Long Island, Mike Plant, the Goodwill Games president, said yesterday. The Intrepid is docked on the Hudson River at West 46th Street.

title: 4th Body Found in Fire; City Says House Had Illegal Units
description: The death toll in the fire that destroyed a house in Queens climbed to four yesterday, and city officials said the building had been illegally converted to provide cheap sleeping quarters to struggling immigrants.

title: Hale-Bopp Has 3d Tail
description: COMET HALE-BOPP, the bright comet that has delighted even the most casual stargazers in the last month, has surprised astronomers by sprouting a type of tail never detected in any previous comet.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: DANA CORP., Toledo, Ohio, an auto parts supplier, agreed to sell four hydraulic cylinder manufacturing plants to Empire Financial Corp., Dallas, a merchant bank and investment firm, for an undisclosed amount.

title: McCaughey Ross Retreats on Seeking Re-election
description: After saying earlier that she might run in the Republican primary next year to keep her job, despite Gov. George E. Pataki's efforts to be rid of her, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross said today that she probably would not make such a run.

title: The Pop Life
description: War on Bootleg Records

title: Take Daughters to Work? Union Offers Another Idea
description: Upset that so many New York garment factories still use child labor, the nation's largest clothing union has come up with a novel approach to combat this longstanding problem -- it is called Don't Bring Our Daughters to Work Day.

title: Cabdriver's Melancholy Resists the Liquid Cure
description: Add to the pantheon of August Wilson's indelible characters a drunk named Fielding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEARN, CHARLES
description: STEARN-Charles, 96, on Monday April 21, 1997 at Princeton, New Jersey. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: Product Shift Is Credited as Earnings Rise 14% at Xerox
description: The Xerox Corporation said today that earnings rose 14 percent in the first quarter, lifted by increased revenue from its printing services and higher sales of its computer-compatible printers and copiers.

title: Hoboken Rail Route Altered
description: In an announcement that cheered Hoboken officials, Governor Whitman said yesterday that the 20.5-mile light rail system planned from Bayonne to Ridgefield would run along Hoboken's western edge, not on the waterfront.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELMAN, NORMAN, M.D.
description: KELMAN-Norman, M.D. The Association for the Advancement of Psychoanalysis, Inc of the Karen Horney Psychoanalytic Institute and Center, the executive council, and membership are greatly saddened by the passing of our dear friend, colleague, and mentor. Dr. Kelman, was a man of inspiring qualities, direct and committed to his words. His genuine human concern as well as his intellectual and moral integrity was a model for all. We deeply miss him and wish to express our profound sympathy and condolences to his dear family and friends. Nicole Dintenfass, Ph.D., President

title: Emerging Bond Markets Suffering Reversal
description: Emerging bond markets in nations from Mexico and Brazil to Poland and Russia, which have provided nice returns for many risk-taking investors, are suffering their worst reversal in a year. And analysts say the downturn could get worse because they expect the Federal Reserve to push interest rates higher later this year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Celebrity and perquisites go hand-in-hand, even during bomb scares in London.

title: Students' Class Work Available on Line
description: Teachers in the Kent School District, just south of Seattle, used to post excellent student work on hallway bulletin boards. Now they post the work on the district's Web page for all the world -- and especially parents and grandparents -- to see.

title: Alarms in Abusive Homes
description: Toms River has become the state's first community to test an alarm system for children in abusive homes.

title: With a Simple Handshake, Civility and Game Resume
description: No spit, no runs, no errors.

title: Whitewater Counsel Says He Has Evidence Of Obstructing Justice
description: The Whitewater prosecutor, Kenneth W. Starr, said in papers filed today in Federal court that he had found ''extensive evidence'' of obstruction of justice and that he needed more time to complete his investigation, which has centered on the political and personal affairs of President Clinton and his wife, Hillary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCKEFELLER, MARY FRENCH
description: ROCKEFELLER-Mary French. The Board of Trustees and staff of the New York Blood Center extend profound sympathy to our long time Trustee and founder, Laurance S. Rockefeller on the passing of his beloved wife, Mary French Rockefeller. We offer our sincere condolences to the entire family. Howard Sloan, Chairman Board of Trustees John W. Adamson, M.D., President

title: Discovering a Family's Heritage, Mustard Seeds and All
description: AS a child, Maya Kaimal MacMillan watched her father carry out a peculiar immigrant rite of passage. Chandran Kaimal, who arrived in the United States from India in 1955, spent evenings nurturing the memory of his mother's cooking, trying to replicate with a scientist's precision the fish curries and tart lentil soups of his hometown in Kerala, the lush coastal province on the southwestern tip of the subcontinent.

title: Gingrich Attacks Press as Out of Touch
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich, who has faced heavy criticism in the press of his ethics record and his method of paying a $300,000 fine, leveled a brief but blistering attack on the news media today and suggested that advertisers should use their financial clout to demand change.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BALBERA, VIRGINIA
description: BALBERA-Virginia. 5 years gone, but always in our hearts. We love and miss you very much. Irwin, Gregg, Stefanie and family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JOHNSON, SHERMAN
description: JOHNSON-Sherman. 11/9/47-4/23/87. Your company was like warm, spring sunshine. The memory warms me still. Bob Eberhard

title: Algeria Says Rebels Killed 93, Many Women, in Village Raid
description: Algeria's authoritarian Government said today that Islamic radicals had hacked to death 93 people, 43 of them women and girls, in an overnight raid on a village near Algiers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRIS, ARTHUR E.
description: HARRIS-Arthur E. On April 20, 1997. Dear husband of Faith Harris, beloved father of Matthew, Timothy and Benjamin, adoring grandfather of Katherine and Spencer, esteemed brother of Gerald. An award-winning art director at Young & Rubicam for 42 years, he was also a popular teacher at Pratt and School of Visual Arts. His family and friends miss him deeply. Memorial service to be announced.

title: Herbert Zipper, 92, Founder Of Secret Orchestra at Dachau
description: Herbert Zipper, who as an inmate at Dachau started a secret orchestra and with a friend composed a song that became an anthem of the death camps, died on Monday at St. John's Medical Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 92, said his niece, Lucy Horowitz.

title: Whitman Puts Hold on Plan For Insurance
description: One day before a rally planned by drivers demanding lower insurance rates, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced today that she would temporarily abandon her proposal to offer motorists less coverage for lower rates and move ahead with other parts of her plan certain to win quick approval in the Legislature.

title: Chess Team Bolstered After Visit by Trump
description: Two weeks after Donald J. Trump gave a fake million-dollar bill to the chess team at a Bronx elementary school where he was Principal for a Day, other people have chipped in with real money.

title: One More Requirement
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCAFFREY, RAYMOND A., DR.
description: McCAFFREY-Raymond A., Dr. on April 20, 1997. Beloved husband of Virginia (nee Forster). Loving father of Donna and Rosanne O'Donnell. Cherished grandfather of Denise, Lisa, Michael and Ginger. Reposing at Moritz Funeral Home, Route 303, Tappan, New York. Mass of Christian Burial, Thursday, 11 A.M., St. Catherine Church, Blauvelt, NY. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Reverend Cornelius Forster Scholarship Fund, Providence College, Rhode Island.

title: Swiss Army Brands uses astronauts, Navy Seals and name recognition to sell its new sunglasses.
description: AS temperatures heat up, so does competition in the highly competitive sunglasses industry, with each manufacturer trying to convince consumers that its brand is best at blocking out ultraviolet rays, while offering the newest colors and latest styles.

title: Bronx Landlord Is Charged With Evicting Hospitalized AIDS Patient
description: A Bronx landlord who ordered a building superintendent to destroy the belongings of a tenant who was in the hospital being treated for AIDS was arrested yesterday for illegally evicting the resident.

title: McVeigh Jury Is Selected After 3 Weeks
description: Shortly after 3:30 P.M. today, their faces hidden by a wall and their names concealed by random numbers, the 18 men and women who will judge the evidence in the Oklahoma City bombing case took their assigned seats in the jury box.

title: First Brother-in-Law Has Tobacco Talks Role
description: At a recent round of the landmark tobacco settlement talks, Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut Attorney General, met a member of President Clinton's family whom he had not encountered as a classmate of Bill and Hillary Clinton at Yale Law School: Hugh E. Rodham Jr.

title: For the Knicks to Stand, Ewing's Legs Must, Too
description: Patrick Ewing is beginning to resemble the annoying guy at the health club who steps on the Stairmaster and mocks the 20-minute rule. Six weeks later, he is still on the machine. If only his tender, 34-year-old knees worked as well as his cardiovascular system.

title: CMS-LED GROUP IN AUSTRALIAN POWER PLANT DEAL
description: A group led by the CMS Energy Corporation said yesterday that it would pay $3.81 billion for a 75 percent interest in the Australian Loy Yang A power station. CMS, based in Dearborn, Mich., will take a 50 percent stake in the 2,000-megawatt power station and an associated brown coal mine in the state of Victoria. NRG Energy Inc., a unit of the Northern States Power Company of Minneapolis will take 25 percent. Horizon Energy Australia Investments, which is held by Infrastructure Trust of Australia Ltd., ANZ Securities, Macquarie Bank and Unisuper, holds the remaining 25 percent. Victoria is the first Australian state to privatize its utilities and to introduce competition into its electricity market.

title: 732 Were Found and Flown to England, and They've Kept in Touch
description: On Aug. 14, 1945, 300 Jewish orphans recently liberated from Nazi concentration camps sat huddled on the floor of 12 Lancaster bombers on their way to the British Isles. ''The precious cargo,'' their social workers called them.

title: Invigorating Western Palates With Eastern Influences
description: FOR centuries, cooks have been borrowing ingredients from other cultures. This was the case even before the first French chef put lemon grass in his soup (20 years ago) and way before the first American put mascarpone in pumpkin cheese cake. But only in the last few years have chefs felt compelled to give this practice a name: fusion cooking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRUEMAN, EILEEN
description: TRUEMAN-Eileen, on April 20th, 1997. Wife of Jerry, mother of Amy and Jolie, ''Bramma'' of Cody and Tyler, grandmother of Erin, sister of Celeste and Sy. Adored, cherished and respected by all who knew her. Condolences may be offered at the family home Wednesday through Saturday.

title: British Vote Shaping Up as the Battle of Europe
description: Fearing that the wavering he sensed in the traditional Conservative vote was endangering his re-election to Parliament, John Horam began calling around to find out what was troubling the Tory faithful in his district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITON, KATHLEEN O'BRIEN
description: WHITON-Kathleen O'Brien. On April 20. Wife of the late Herman F. Whiton. Sister of Francis L. O'Brien. Step-mother of Charles L. Whiton, Herman F. Whiton, Jr., Romalda W. The company, formerly known as Infomed Holdings Inc., expects the offering, at a projected per-share price of $13 following a 2-for-1 reverse split, to raise $22.9 million after expenses. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JABLONSKY, ADELAIDE
description: JABLONSKY-Adelaide, educator, psychologist and artist, died April 16 at North Ridge Medical Center from a cerebral hemorrhage suffered in a fall in her apartment in Pompano Beach, FL. She was five days shy of her 85th birthday. Dr. Jablonsky, Prof. Emeritus at Yeshiva Univ. was Dean of the Graduate School of Educ. and Stern College. Her love of teaching began at 14 when she taught at a Hebrew school in the Bronx. A graduate of Evander Childs HS and Hunter College, she received her Ed.D. from Teachers College at Columbia Univ. Her 26-year teaching career began at Pratt Inst. and Brooklyn College. From 1945 to 1972, she and her husband of 53 years, Benjamin, who died in 1988, were the owners/directors of Lake Bryn Mawr Camp in Honesdale, PA. After retiring from Yeshiva Univ., Dr. Jablonsky was an active volunteer in the Fort Lauderdale area tutoring kids in the Senior Mentors for Creative Students program and adults in the Senior Volunteer Literacy program. For 17 years, up to the day she died, she ran SRO classes for seniors in water painting, stained glass, lapidary, sewing, computers, and meditation. She served for many years on the Broward County Advisory Council in the Area Agency on the Aging and for 10 years was a volunteer psychologist at the Gold Coast Hospice. She was elected to the Broward County Senior Hall of Fame in 1986. She is survived by two sons, Stephen of Easton, CT., and Fred of Hazleton, PA., and two sisters, Sandy Vorspan of Los Angeles and Terry Cohen of Margaretville, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FENTON, JOHN L.
description: FENTON-John L. A retired Bankers Trust executive, Mr. Fenton died Sunday, April 20 after a long illness, in Key West, FL, where he had a winter home. He also maintained homes in New York City and East Hampton, NY. He was 83 years old. Mr. Fenton whose distinguished military career included long service in the Pacific, was the son of an Army General and was born at Ft. Totten on Staten Island. He attended Storm King School in Cornwall, New York, and was a 1936 graduate of Yale. He served as an aide to General Douglas MacArthur from 1940 to 1946 and rose to the rank of colonel. His entire business career was at Bankers Trust, where he was a full vicepresident, eventually heading a principal office at 5th Avenue and 44th Street in New York. Mr. Fenton, a member of the Huguenot Society, the Sons of the American Revolution and the Yale and Century Clubs, is survived by a sister, Katherine Greene, of San Antonio, Texas, and a brother, Donald C. Fenton, of Sterling, Virginia. Burial will be in the military cemetery at West Point, New York.

title: NEWPORT NEWS SHIPBUILDING WINS $72 MILLION CONTRACT
description: Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. said yesterday that it had received a $72 million, one-year contract with four successive one-year renewal options from the United States Navy. Newport News said it would provide continuing design and engineering support for the Los Angeles and Seawolf class submarines. Newport News Shipbuilding, of Newport News, Va., is a ship design and construction company. The company's shares rose 25 cents, to $14.125.

title: Clinton Promises Flood Victims a 'Marshall Plan'
description: President Clinton and several members of his Cabinet came here today to tour the devastation of flood and fire and to promise he calls a Marshall Plan approach to rebuilding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN LEER, PIET

Mr. Van Leer is survived by a son and three daughters. Remembrances: Older Adult Services at Mt. Hood Community Mental Health Center, 400 NE 7th Street, Gresham, Oregon 97030. For further information contact Bateman Carroll Funeral Chapel, Gresham, OR. (503-665-2128).

title: POINTCAST AND EXCITE SET TO DISCLOSE PARTNERSHIP
description: Pointcast Inc., a privately held company that broadcasts news and information to about one million desktop computers through its Pointcast Network, plans to announce today that it has formed a partnership with Excite Inc., an Internet search company based in Mountain View, Calif. Excite will create a directory for a new Pointcast channel, called Connections, that will give Pointcast's customers access to information from more than 1,000 World Wide Web sites. In addition, Excite will become the search service Pointcast customers first see when they venture onto the Web from the network. Pointcast, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., also said it would embrace the Recreational Software Advisory Council's system to rate the content of Web sites.

title: Defector Stirs North Korea Nuclear Scare
description: The high-ranking North Korean defector who arrived in Seoul on Sunday has implied that North Korea has nuclear weapons and the ability to use them to annihilate South Korea, according to a newspaper report here.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the planned common European currency misstated the campaign position of the British Labor Party. The party has said it is unlikely that Britain would be among the first countries to join but should reserve the right to do so later.

title: PRUDENTIAL SECURITIES NAMES EQUITIES RESEARCH HEAD
description: Prudential Securities Inc. said yesterday that it had named Michael Shea director of equity research. Mr. Shea, 41, replaces Michael Culp, who left the fifth-biggest United States securities firm, a unit of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, to join Paine Webber Inc., a unit of the Paine Webber Group of New York Mr. Shea was most recently Prudential's head of institutional equity sales. Timothy Landers, 38, will assume Mr. Shea's responsibilities overseeing institutional equity sales. Prudential also named Greg Smith, its chief investment strategist, chairman of a newly formed investment policy committee.

title: RJR Nabisco's First-Quarter Net Up 7.5%, But Sales Fell
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation yesterday reported disappointing international tobacco volumes, a continuing erosion of its domestic cigarette business and a decline in sales for its first quarter.

title: PERU TROOPS RESCUE HOSTAGES; REBELS SLAIN AS STANDOFF ENDS
description: Peruvian Army soldiers stormed the occupied residence of the Japanese Ambassador in Lima, Peru, yesterday, ending a four-month hostage stalemate in an eruption of smoke and gunfire. All but one of the 72 hostages were rescued, and 14 Marxist guerrillas who had held them died in the assault, as did one hostage and two military officers, according to Peru's President.

title: Minnesota Mining's Earnings Up 13% on Strong U.S. Sales
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its earnings rose 13.3 percent in the first quarter, aided by economic strength in the United States.

title: Officials Say China Illegally Sent U.S. Equipment to Military Plant
description: A Federal criminal inquiry has uncovered new evidence, including American satellite photos, suggesting that a state-owned Chinese company had all along intended to divert American machine equipment to a military plant that builds missiles and fighter aircraft, intelligence officials say.

title: Change at Top Of Time Inc.
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that Reginald K. Brack Jr., chairman of Time Inc., would step down in July after three years as head of the unit that publishes Time, Fortune, People, Sports Illustrated and other magazines.

title: The Perfect Setting Isn't For Electric Car Boom
description: Much earlier than most, islanders here have tasted the future of the car, and in some ways it is as sweet as the boosters of electric vehicles promised.

title: Safir Names Panel to Look At Bias Claims
description: Responding to complaints that the department is too quick to discipline its minority officers, Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced yesterday the formation of a 13-member task force to look into the matter.

title: The Right Move on Myanmar
description: Nine months after Congress passed a law banning new American investment in Myanmar if the regime there staged a crackdown on democratic rights, President Clinton has finally, and rightly, invoked the law's provisions. With hundreds of democracy activists in jail and their leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, under effective house arrest, conditions for sanctions were more than met. Now the challenge for the Administration is to get European and Asian nations to isolate Myanmar as well.

title: More hotels are offering guests boxed lunches as an alternative to fast food and airline fare.
description: HELP may be on the way for travelers tired of passing by the greasy fare in the food courts lining airport terminals, only to find their taste buds bored by bland meals served at cruising altitude. More and more hotels are offering boxed means to go for their guests, including delights like smoked duck salad, pan-seared chicken with shiitake mushrooms, and angel hair pasta salad in a peanut-ginger vinaigrette.

title: Safeskin to Expand
description: The Safeskin Corporation, a maker of latex gloves, said today that it would spend $40 million to expand its manufacturing operations in Thailand. The San Diego-based company will spend $20 million this year and another $20 million in 1998 to increase its annual production by more than a billion gloves. The investment will also finance an additional building, expected to be operating by 1999. A second factory will be built in southern Thailand starting late this year. Since 1992, medical personnel have been required to wear protection against hepatitis and H.I.V.

title: Older Suspect in Pizza Killings Was the Mastermind, Officials Say
description: The authorities say they believe that the older of the two suspects in the ambush and murder of two pizza deliverymen on a desolate country road here Saturday night was the mastermind of the killings.

title: Benching Doesn't Sit Well With Baerga
description: Carlos Baerga became one of baseball's most expensive part-time players yesterday when Mets Manager Bobby Valentine decided to bench him. Temporarily, anyway, until Baerga's swing shows signs of producing more than weak grounders and pop-ups.

title: Captain's Testimony Shows Failure in Handling Sex Charges
description: The former superior of a drill sergeant accused of raping six women acknowledged today that widespread allegations of sexual abuses never reached his level, despite an elaborate counseling system set up at the Army base here.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK ACQUIRES A BOATMEN'S TRUST UNIT
description: The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the corporate trust business of the former Boatmen's Bancshares from the Nationsbank Corporation of Charlotte, N.C. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Nationsbank had acquired Boatmen's Bancshares in January. Corporate trust operations handle payments of dividends and interest distributions to bondholders and notify investors of meetings and other formalities. The transaction is expected to be completed in the third quarter. Shares of the Bank of New York rose 72.5 cents, to $36.625, while Nationsbank shares gained $1.50, to $56.875.

title: German Software Maker Posts 54% Jump in Profit
description: The shares of SAP A.G., a German software maker, rose to a record yesterday after the company said first-quarter pretax profit was up a better-than-expected 54 percent. The gain in profit was attributed to favorable currency rates and big contracts in the United States and other international markets. Sales rose 49 percent, though SAP said it did not expect to maintain that pace for the full year. The shares rose as much as 17.4 marks, or 6 percent, to 308.5 marks, in the first minutes of trading but closed with a gain of 5.5 marks, at 295.5 marks ($174.04).

title: Koppel in Hong Kong
description: Ted Koppel has become so indelibly associated with ''Nightline,'' which he has been anchoring for 17 years, that viewers may forget he was a foreign correspondent for ABC News for many years. That period included a stint in Hong Kong from 1969 to 1971, and this week Mr. Koppel returns there, to report for three programs on the city as it prepares for its transfer from British to Chinese control. The programs will be broadcast on ABC on Friday night and next Monday and Tuesday, getting a jump on others waiting until the transfer date of July 1 nears.

description: After settling more than 200 accident injury suits, and with new Federal automobile roll-over standards possible, the Suzuki car company yesterday produced what it said was evidence that Consumers Union deliberately set out in 1988 to prove that the Suzuki Samurai was prone to tipping over in certain circumstances.

title: Eating Well
description: THE fallout from the 1994 Dietary Supplement and Health Education Act continues. That law, passed despite objections from the Food and Drug Administration, gave dietary supplement manufacturers carte blanche to make claims that would once have brought the products under the agency's supervision -- as drugs. Now, as long as the manufacturer adds a disclaimer that the products ''have not been evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration,'' just about anything goes.

title: GERRY BABY PRODUCTS SOLD TO EVENFLO FOR $73 MILLION
description: The Huffy Corporation said yesterday that it had completed the sale of its Gerry Baby Products Company unit to the Evenflo Juvenile Furniture Company for $73 million in cash. Huffy, a maker of bicycles and basketball backboards based in Miamisburg, Ohio, said it had sold Gerry rather than make the investment necessary to build the unit into one of the top two companies in the baby and juvenile products industry. Evenflo, owned by the closely held E & S Holdings Corporation of Tampa, Fla., said the acquisition of Denver-based Gerry would bolster its position as a market leader for baby products.

title: Tracing Path Of Artworks Smuggled Out of Asia
description: Of the hundreds of thousands of people who visit the Southeast Asian galleries at the Metropolitan Museum each year, no one ever questioned the origins of a 10th-century head of Shiva that was displayed among the buddhas, bodhisattvas and other deities. Neither the scores of world-renowned experts familiar with the galleries nor the Asian dignitaries who made special visits to tour them expressed concern or curiosity about how the head, or any of the other rare objects on display, got to the museum.

title: Personal Health
description: THE attacks can be terrifying, mimicking the severe anaphylactic reaction that can occur in people allergic to peanuts, shellfish or bee venom. In addition to widespread hives, itching and facial swelling, there are often dizziness and loss of consciousness and life-threatening symptoms like swelling of the mouth and throat, difficulty breathing and plummeting blood pressure. Other symptoms may include sneezing, a runny nose, flushing of the skin, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and abdominal pain.
