title: MOORE IN DEAL FOR PEAK TECHNOLOGIES
description: The Moore Corporation of Toronto said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Peak Technologies Group Inc., a bar-code data collection concern based in Columbia, Md., and New York, for $210 million. News of the deal drove up shares of Peak Technologies nearly 35 percent, or $4.50, to $17.50, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Moore rose 50 cents, to $20.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Moore, a business-forms maker with 1996 sales of $2.5 billion, said it would make an offer of $18 a share directly to Peak Technologies shareholders. Peak Technologies had 1996 revenue of $216 million.

title: Sony Raises Ticket Price At Some Theaters
description: Just in time for Hollywood's summer blockbusters, ticket prices at Sony-Loews theaters in Manhattan suddenly jumped to $9 from $8.50 at Sony Lincoln Square's multiplex and to $8.75 at the chain's 10 other houses. The change took effect last Friday as moviegoers were going in to see ''Liar Liar,'' ''The Devil's Own'' and other films at those theaters.

title: Hats Off To Hockey's True Star
description: THE Great One still is.

title: Hundley Lets It Go, And Belts 2 Homers
description: Todd Hundley found an isolation booth this week. It is the dank tunnel that leads from the Mets dugout, a quiet place he can go to during a game to seek refuge from the burden that has been weighing on him.

title: Jessye Norman in New Songs
description: Jessye Norman could get by on a tiny repertory. Indeed, she could probably get by without singing at all: enough for her to come out onto the platform, stand there and slowly rotate her smile for half an hour. But she's an inquisitive and intelligent artist, and she evidently likes to do new things. On Sunday at Carnegie Hall, amid the Brahms, Schubert and Poulenc that made up the bulk of her program for the Chase Recital Series, she gave the first performance of a song cycle created for her by Richard Danielpour and Toni Morrison: ''Sweet Talk.''

title: Swapping Family Tedium for Ruthless Narcissism
description: MY LIFE, STARRING DARA FALCON

title: Experts Clash Over Need for Changing Census Data by Race
description: For the first time in 20 years, the Federal Government may change the way it measures race and ethnicity, standards critical in enforcing voting rights laws, studying disease patterns and collecting school registration statistics.

title: KMART INTRODUCES PROTOTYPE FOR NEW STORE LAYOUT
description: The Kmart Corporation, aiming to draw more customers into its stores, disclosed today a new store layout that places highly sought items near the front of the store and expands the selection of food and household goods. Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., said 297 stores had already been converted to the new design. It disclosed the prototype for Big Kmart, as the revamping is called, at the Chicago Brickyard Mall. By 1999 it plans to have remodeled 1,600 of its 2,200 stores to offer cleaner surroundings, better lighting, smarter layouts and updated merchandise.

title: Tokyo Fears Nonviolence Is Invitation to Terrorists
description: Japanese welcomed the release of hostages in Peru today with joy, relief and a bit of dread.

title: Chevron and Mobil Earnings Exceed Experts' Predictions
description: The Chevron Corporation and the Mobil Corporation both posted first-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded analysts' expectations, continuing a string of strong industry profit reports brought on by higher oil and natural gas prices.

title: Chester A. Gore, 78, President Of Ad and Marketing Agency
description: Chester A. Gore, the founder, president and creative director of the Chester Gore Company, an advertising and marketing agency in Manhattan, died on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 78 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: GIANT INDUSTRIES TO BUY OR LEASE THRIFTWAY BUSINESSES
description: Giant Industries said yesterday that it had agreed to buy or lease 96 gas stations and convenience stores from the closely held Thriftway Marketing Corporation of Farmington, N.M., more than tripling the number of stations and stores it controls. Giant, of Scottsdale, Ariz., said the retail outlets and Thriftway's transportation business, which it also plans to acquire, should contribute about $13 million in earnings before taxes, interest and depreciation in their first full year. Giant had net income of $17 million on sales of about $499 million last year. The company said it would buy a still-to-be determined number of stations and stores and the petroleum products transportation business for $16 million. It will lease the remaining stations for 10 years, with options to buy them during that period for a total of $23 million.

title: Isn't Perjury Criminal?
description: To the Editor:

title: A diverse political group backs choice for auto insurance.
description: WHAT do Rod Grams, the right-wing Senator from Minnesota who never graduated from college; Mitch McConnell, the Kentucky Republican known for his fire-breathing partisanship; Slade Gorton, the pragmatic, tend-to-the-constituents conservative from the State of Washington; Joseph I. Lieberman, the new-fashioned Democrat from Connecticut, and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the Senate's ranking liberal intellectual, have in common? They are co-sponsors of the Auto Choice Reform Act, a bill introduced this week that would allow motorists to give up their right to collect legal damages for ''pain and suffering'' in auto accidents.

title: Stepping Up Recycling
description: Ten years after New Jersey passed a mandatory recycling law, the state has reached its goal of recycling 60 percent of all solid waste and plans to improve its recycling rate by 5 percent before the year 2000, officials said yesterday.

title: At the Moment of Truth, Rebels' Resolve Failed
description: Moments after a thundering explosion signaled the beginning of the military raid to rescue the 72 hostages in the residence of the Japanese Ambassador, a young guerrilla burst into the second-floor bedroom where several high-level Government officials were held.

title: New Rules Imposed For Refrigerators: Efficiency, at a Cost
description: Refrigerators sold in 2001 will have to use 30 percent less electricity than those now on the market, the Energy Department said today, ordering a change meant to cut electric bills by more than $1 billion a year by 2010 and reduce air pollution from power plants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOMS, JOHN L.
description: TOMS-John L., 72, passed away April 19, 1997 after a brief battle with cancer. Born February 9, 1925 in Bronx, New York, he served with the U.S. Army during WWII in the Pacific Theater. He attended Iona College and worked for the NY Central R.R. For the last 36 years he worked for Everlast Sporting Goods in the Bronx and known as ''Mr. Everlast'' in the boxing arena, he was Vice President of Sales at Everlast for 25 years where he was involved in every major event in the industry. During all of this, he managed to raise and support two families of three children and support several charities in his hometown. He was an avid Yankee fan and also Notre Dame's Fighting Irish. He is survived by his devoted wife, Jean Toms of Houston and his loving children: Linda Lea D'Onofrio, of West Creek, NJ; John Toms, Jr. of Huntington, NY; Christina Levi of Hicksville, NY; Jeff Schmidt of East Patchogue, NY; Dean Schmidt of Monterey, CA; Michael Schmidt of Houston, TX.; and seven grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Pinelawn National Cemetery, Melville, New York, on Monday, April 28, 1997 at 10:45 AM, (516) 249-6100. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Cancer Society.

title: Nynex Operating Net Rises on Output Gain
description: The Nynex Corporation yesterday reported robust earnings before one-time charges in the first quarter, helped by increased demand and improved productivity.

title: Russia-China Theme: Contain the West
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and President Jiang Zemin of China pledged today to work together to limit American power and influence in the world.

title: Raid Stuck to the Rules, With a Few Twists
description: Counterterrorism specialists in the United States said today that the Peruvian military managed to pull off their daring rescue of 71 hostages in Lima by applying lessons learned from recent hostage situations elsewhere in the world but with notable innovations that included the use of a network of tunnels beneath the compound.

title: A Record and Big Questions As Woman Gives Birth at 63
description: In a feat that has raised questions about the uses of medical science, a woman 63 years and 9 months old recently gave birth to a healthy baby girl. Her doctors say that as far as they know, she is the oldest woman ever to give birth.

title: No Ordinary Disaster
description: People living along the Red River in North Dakota began bracing for a flood as early as last winter. It was then that a cannonade of blizzards dumped more than three years' worth of snow in a period of just three months, the heaviest snowfalls in modern memory. Two months ago Gov. Edward Schafer declared a flood alert, and the Army Corps of Engineers joined residents to build dikes in preparation for the snowmelt. Their efforts proved futile and the Red River still had its way, inundating Grand Forks in one of the most spectacular disasters of recent years.

title: Dundee and Foreman, a Ring Odd Couple, Are Reunited
description: You think George Foreman is old for a boxer at 48? His senior adviser, Angelo Dundee, is 75 years old and will work in his corner Saturday night.

title: Bitter Sephardic Jews Rally for Central Figure in Israeli Scandal
description: Borne on the shoulders of his followers to the roar of thousands who chanted his name in a packed stadium under a baking sun, Aryeh Deri rode a victory lap here today.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  OBER, ANITA ROSENBLUM
description: OBER-Anita Rosenblum. June 26, 1919-April 24, 1990. I beg you appear, you're near. Seek your words, they're here. In my heart you remain so dear. Norman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERALDS, ROBERT ATKINS ROMMEL
description: GERALDS-Robert Atkins Rommel. Suddenly in Paris, France on Tuesday, April 22, 1997. Born March 19, 1957. Devoted son of Dr. and Mrs. Hagan Peters and Mr. and Mrs. William T. Geralds, beloved companion of Eric Coursin. Interment in Louisville, Kentucky. Memorial Services in Paris, New York and Memphis to be announced.

title: Mastercard Sets Review Lineup
description: Mastercard International said yesterday that it had invited six agencies to compete in a review for the creative part of its domestic account, with billings estimated at $90 million. Those duties had been handled for five years by Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which declined to participate when the review was announced Feb. 28.

title: Money for Buses Is Sought
description: During last-minute budget deliberations last year, the State Legislature eliminated $700,000 from a $22.2 million bus and van program serving the elderly and disabled, cutting service throughout the state, several lawmakers said.

title: 2 Big European Producers Of Electronics Lift Earnings
description: Two of the world's biggest electronics companies reported earnings gains yesterday, with Philips Electronics N.V. of the Netherlands posting a 22 percent increase for the first quarter and Siemens A.G. of Germany up 3.7 percent in its fiscal second quarter.

title: Swedbank Says Profits Increased by 9%
description: Swedbank A.B., Sweden's second-largest bank by assets, said yesterday that first-quarter operating profit rose 9 percent as bad debt charges fell and income from provisions rose. Swedbank's operating profit rose to 1.315 billion kronor ($171 million), from 1.202 billion in the first quarter of 1996. That is below average expectations of 1.404 billion kronor.

title: Guerin Is in a Cast, But Devils Are Deep
description: The Devils suffered their first loss of the playoffs on Tuesday night. But it wasn't to the Montreal Canadiens.

title: Boeing, Challenging Airbus, Seeks to Sell Planes to China
description: The Boeing Company, matching a proposal from its rival, Airbus Industrie, is seeking to sell China 100 aircraft valued at about $4 billion.

title: Appeal Heard In Convictions Of 3 Athletes In Sex Assault
description: Four years after three former high school football players from Glen Ridge, N.J., were convicted of sexually assaulting a mildly retarded girl in front of several schoolmates, they have yet to serve any time behind bars for the crime, and their lawyers argued today that they never should.

title: Software Maker Optimistic on Earnings
description: Computer Associates International Inc. announced yesterday that it expected its earnings for its most recent quarter to be higher than Wall Street analysts have predicted.

title: U.S. Drafting Policy to Widen Trade With Africa
description: The Administration said today that it would support promoting more trade with African nations as part of a broader initiative to encourage free-market reforms among the continent's more promising economies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINE, NORMAN L.
description: LEVINE-Norman L. died March 2. A devoted friend, husband and father. He will always be remembered in those glowing terms. Norman Robbins, Louis Kaminsky

title: A Justifiable Rescue
description: Peru's commando raid on the Japanese Ambassador's residence on Tuesday was an astonishing feat. Only one hostage among 72 died in the three-pronged attack, timed to start while the guerrillas were distracted playing soccer. Given the risks, it is a great relief that President Alberto Fujimori could count on excellent intelligence, coordination and no small measure of luck.

title: People
description: * John McNamara was named to the new post of vice president for client services and managing director of the New York office at Western Direct, the direct response media-buying group of Western International Media, owned by the Interpublic Group. He had been senior vice president and group media director at Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam.

title: Marketers from Ford to La-Z-Boy are hit by a computer-aided outbreak of anthropomorphism.
description: EVER since Babe the pig started talking in August 1995, animals all over seem to have something to say.

title: Connecticut's Sensible War on Drugs
description: While New York continues to stuff its prisons with drug offenders, the Connecticut Legislature is considering a more sensible approach that emphasizes treatment rather than punishment. Gov. John Rowland has yet to embrace a package of reforms to the state's drug laws, but the Legislature is pushing him in the right direction.

title: Japanese Women
description: To The Home Section:

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Tuesday about the political aftermath of the decision against indicting Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel misidentified a columnist for the newspaper Maariv who commented on the events. He is Hemi Shalev, not Ham Shell.

title: Mandarins Gather, Confidence Rules
description: ''I'D get that chandelier done and get it over with,'' Tom Britt told Mario Buatta in his trademark rasp, as he watched Mr. Buatta direct the installation of a five-foot-wide 18th-century English amethyst glass chandelier in the neo-classical style hallway of the Park Avenue town house.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KOSLOFF, JUDY
description: KOSLOFF-Judy. Always in our thoughts. We miss you very much. Love, Mike, Janie, Chuck, Andrea and Andrew

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELMAN, NORMAN, M.D.
description: KELMAN-Norman, M.D. The Board of Directors and staff of the Karen Horney Clinic note with deep sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. Dr. Kelman was a bright light, an esteemed clinician and one of the revered academicians. He will be sorely missed by all. Henry Paul, M.D., Exec Dir

title: Knicks Welcome Clean Slate With Hornets
description: Like many observers, Buck Williams was curious when he heard that Milwaukee had blown out Charlotte in the final game of the season on Sunday, a loss that insured that the Hornets would meet the Knicks in the first round of the Eastern Conference playoffs.

title: Real Estate Merger
description: LaSalle Partners and The Galbreath Company, two Midwestern real estate management and services companies with significant operations in New York, announced yesterday that they would merge, with LaSalle as the surviving entity.

title: Copper Prices Rise a 5th Day As Chile Strike Slows Output
description: Copper prices rose yesterday for a fifth day on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange as a strike at the Escondida copper mine in Chile, the world's largest, slowed copper output at a time of dwindling inventories.

title: School Choice Program Gets 17,000 Applications
description: Caroline Toner has long hoped to send her four young children to a Catholic school. She says she likes the values such schools instill, and she thinks the classrooms in her neighborhood elementary school in Woodside, Queens, are too crowded.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Tuesday and in some editions yesterday about the killing of two men who were delivering pizzas in Franklin, N.J., misspelled the given name of one victim. He was Giorgio Gallara, not Georgio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAEBURN, BEN
description: RAEBURN-Ben. We mourn the death of Ben Raeburn, great publisher, superb editor and friend. Ruth Benjamin Arthur Rosenblatt

title: Public Housing to Be Razed
description: Another large complex in Newark's North Ward will be destroyed, starting today, as part of the Federal drive to change the face of public housing, city officials said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Chancellor HELMUT KOHL of Germany has filed suit against the German edition of Penthouse magazine for publishing a cartoon of his wife wearing nothing but gloves and pearls.

title: Zoeller Learns Race Remarks Carry a Price
description: The controversy over Fuzzy Zoeller's racial remarks about Tiger Woods, which resulted in Kmart's dropping Zoeller as its golf spokesman on Tuesday, escalated yesterday when the golfer pulled out of the Greater Greensboro Classic.

title: Sybase Narrows Account Review
description: Sybase Inc., a software company in Concord, Mass., said yesterday that it had narrowed a review on its account to three agencies from six. The account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million, had been handled by Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White in Salt Lake City, a unit of Havas Advertising.

title: Charges in Loan Case
description: A Las Vegas man working from an office in Cherry Hill was indicted in Federal court in Camden yesterday on charges that he posed as a loan broker and cheated his clients out of more than $100,000 in advance fees on nearly $4 billion in loans that were never made, prosecutors said.

title: Hingis Has Knee Surgery
description: Bad bounces do not happen often to the 16-year-old Martina Hingis on the tennis court, where she is the youngest player ever to hold the No. 1 ranking. But her other favorite sport, horseback riding, dealt the teen-ager a bad bounce on Monday when she injured ligaments in her left knee after she was thrown from a friend's horse near her hometown of Trubbach, Switzerland.

title: In the Irabu Game, the Victory Goes to the Losers
description: The Mets may be living life in relative obscurity these days, but there is no doubt which New York baseball team proved to be a winner yesterday, and not because they outdrew the Yankees by a cool 13,500 fans in another day of dueling interborough baseball games.

title: Senate Bills to Extend Medicaid to Children
description: Senators John H. Chafee and John D. Rockefeller 4th said today that they were introducing bipartisan legislation that would expand Medicaid to cover five million additional children.

title: Ralph Reed Resigns
description: Ralph Reed is resigning as executive director of the Christian Coalition, a group he helped transform into a powerful force in Republican politics. He is becoming a consultant.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAGAZZINI, GENE
description: MAGAZZINI-Gene. 11/5/14-7/14/94. Happy 60th Anniversary, My Love. Thanks for the memories. I embrace you, Gino, forte, forte. Yolanda

title: Profit Is Flat At I.B.M., but Revenue Rises
description: I.B.M. reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that were essentially flat, but revenue was stronger than expected and per-share earnings exceeded Wall Street estimates.

title: Mt. Sinai in Health Alliance With Network in New Jersey
description: Fresh from the failure of its attempt to merge with the New York University Medical Center, Mount Sinai Medical Center is set to announce today that it has agreed to affiliate its entire health care network with the Saint Barnabas Health Care System, the largest network in New Jersey.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Dow Industrials Slip, But Technology Stocks Rise

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINSIDLER, JUNE
description: EINSIDLER-June. On April 23, 1997. Beloved wife of Joseph, loving mother of Gary Einsidler and Lisa Borg, cherished grandmother of Mori, Max, Cole and Devin. Services Friday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76 St, Amsterdam Ave.

title: Yes, His New Book Is Biblical, but Don't Call Him God
description: There is an old joke Norman Mailer is particularly fond of about a man who is complaining to God. The man whines: ''You're not treating me fairly, God. Why not? Why don't you treat me fairly?''

title: Quaker Chief, Tied to Losses From Snapple, To Step Down
description: The Quaker Oats Company said today that William D. Smithburg, who led the company in its disastrous acquisition of the Snapple drinks business, would resign as chairman and chief executive as soon as a successor could be chosen.

title: Agency to Vote on La Guardia Ferry Plan
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey is expected to award a contract today to NY Waterway, the region's largest private ferryboat operator, for service to La Guardia Airport from several docks in Manhattan, beginning in 1998.

title: 3% Deficit Limit Is Not Expected To Be Attained : Italy Won't Make Euro By 1999, EU Forecasts
description: BRUSSELS  Italy's hopes of joining the European single currency at the start in 1999 suffered a major setback Wednesday when the European Union's executive commission forecast that the country would exceed the deficit ceiling for monetary union this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, HOWARD I.
description: SCHNEIDER-Howard I. On April 20, 1997 at the age of 75. Beloved husband of Selma. Devoted father of Les and Michael. Cherished brother of Doris. Adored grandfather of Ben, Philip and Ross. Admired and loving uncle, cousin, nephew, inlaw and cherished friend to all whose life he touched. His passing saddens us all and yet we will remember his charm, humor, grace, honesty, integrity, directness and zest for life. Services Friday, 1 PM, at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, New York.

title: 6 Minutes Is Plenty To Humble Panthers
description: To a man, they hung their heads and blamed their predicament -- one game from playoff extinction -- on one man.

title: China Cheats (What a Surprise!)
description: Satellite photos now reveal that a state-owned Chinese company deliberately deceived Washington officials in 1994 when it claimed it was importing American machine tools for civilian purposes. Instead, it diverted them illegally to a missile factory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBIN, BEATRICE
description: DUBIN-Beatrice, 76. Of Lake George, New York and Hollywood Florida. Died April 23. Devoted wife of the late Jimmy; beloved mother to Scott and Jane; loving mother-in-law; adoring grandmother to Emily and Julia; dearest sister to Charlotte, Helen and the late Hadassah. NYU Master's, CUNY Professor and Department Chair. She brought us together and gave us love. She was our strength. Services Friday 12:30PM, Parkside Chapels, 718-896-9000.

title: A Joint U.S.-Mexican Drug Plan, Born in Hope, Is Hobbled by Disputes
description: After struggling for years to find small groups of honest officers in what they describe as a morass of Mexican police corruption, American law-enforcement agencies have begun training small groups of Mexican agents that they hope will some day transform the two countries' campaign against illegal drugs.

title: New Brooklyn Museum Chief
description: To the 4-year-old boy, the Brooklyn Museum was a house of magic, a seemingly endless trove of huge and beautiful pictures, wondrously recreated period rooms and stunning art objects culled from civilizations from Mesopotamia to Mexico.

title: New President For Spelman Is Announced
description: Dr. Audrey F. Manley, the Acting Surgeon General, has been named the next president of Spelman College here. She will succeed Johnnetta B. Cole, who has been president for the past 10 years.

title: Trained Caseworkers Can Detect Child Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole No Senator, but Might as Well Be
description: The Senate debate over the chemical weapons treaty was in its second hour, waxing slow and grave as only the Senate treaty process can, when the scene was suddenly interrupted by Senator John McCain, looking wide-eyed as a newsboy about to shout, ''Extra!'' He rushed in, grabbed a microphone and took the floor with a deep breath.

title: Intel Set to Expand Networking Business
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it would invest more in networking products, as they are an important area for the company's sales growth.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., said its shareholders approved a 2-for-1 stock split at the company's annual meeting.

description: Frostbitten Magnolia

title: Health Groups Criticize Tobacco Proposal
description: Major public health organizations today stepped up their criticism of proposals that could give cigarette makers immunity from liability suits. They demanded a greater role in negotiations to end tobacco-related litigation, further complicating the prospects for any such deal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NABATOFF, RICHARD
description: NABATOFF-Richard. Age 39. Beloved son of Robert and Joan. Devoted brother of Ross and Diane. Loving uncle to Andrew, Nathan and Alison. Cherished grandson of Jean Herman. Services Thursday, April 24, 11AM at Temple EmanuEl Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. Contributions may be made to the Wharton School, Philadelphia Pa.

title: Sixth Man Award for Starks
description: When Don Nelson sent him to the bench a year ago in favor of Hubert Davis, John Starks went kicking and screaming. When Coach Jeff Van Gundy asked him before the season how he would feel about being the Knicks' sixth man, Starks thought long and hard about the proposition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITON, KATHLEEN O'BRIEN
description: WHITON-Kathleen O'Brien. On April 20. Wife of the late Herman F. Whiton. Sister of Francis L. O'Brien. Step-mother of Charles L. Whiton, Herman F. Whiton, Jr., Romalda W. Clark and Emelyn W. Patterson. Service private. Contributions may be sent to Recording For The Blind, Inc., 545 Fifth Ave., New York, New York 10017.

title: Hewlett in $1.15 Billion Deal For Maker of Credit Card Devices
description: Broadening its reach in electronic commerce, the Hewlett-Packard Company said today that it had agreed to acquire Verifone Inc., the leading maker of credit card authorization devices, in a stock swap valued at $1.15 billion.

title: Adult Trial Sought for 17-Year-Old in Killings
description: The Sussex County Prosecutor said today that he would seek to have a 17-year-old tried as an adult in the killings of two pizza deliverymen on Saturday night.

title: Military Confirms Wreckage Is Missing Jet
description: Aircraft wreckage found on a snowswept mountainside in Colorado came from the Air Force plane carrying four bombs that disappeared on a training mission on April 2, the Air Force said today.

title: When Money Counts
description: BE prepared for some history on this shopping spree. Each lamp comes with a story, and each has to do with preserving the past, be it preservation of an artifact or a style. And some of the results are endearingly quirky.

title: Off on Their Horizon, North Dakota Farmers See Little but Disaster
description: In a normal year, this is when most North Dakota farmers are planting the wheat, soybeans, potatoes and sugar beets that make agriculture by far the state's leading industry.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: ANXIOUS PARENTS -- More than 17,000 public-school children have applied for 1,300 private school scholarships. Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew acknowledged that the response shows that ''parents want schools that work.'' B3.

title: Protecting Infant Nutrition
description: The WIC program, which provides nutritional counseling and food to poor pregnant women, new mothers and infants, ranks among the Federal Government's best health and nutrition programs. Dozens of studies show that it reduces infant mortality and other medical problems of childbirth. Yet a House subcommittee controlled by Republicans recently approved crippling reductions in funding, and the Senate will soon consider equally destructive cuts.

title: Amid the Whirlwind of Jet Moves, Haley Is Staying Put
description: The breathtaking Jets era of Bill Parcells -- in which so much of the recent past has been swept aside in an effort to remake the team -- paused yesterday to keep a bit of history.

title: Surgeon's New Best Friend
description: Whether tonight's edition of ''48 Hours'' strikes you as moving or funny or off-putting or just odd may depend on whether you have a pet around the house. ''Animal E.R.'' is a quizzical look at the pains that American pet owners take on behalf of the physical and emotional well-being of their dogs, cats and birds. Susan Spencer, one of the program's reporters, asks whether there is something untoward about spending a lot of money on animals when medical care for the human species is wanting.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKER, HELEN
description: BECKER-Helen. You are always in my thoughts and forever in my heart. Rusty

title: Three Times as Great: Gretzky Lifts the Rangers
description: In a sports environment filled with exaggeration, understatement sometimes refreshes, even in discussions of someone known as the Great One.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, CHAIM
description: HERZOG-Chaim. The American Friends of Bar-Ilan University mourn with world Jewry the passing of one of the greatest coreligionists of the century, the sixth president of the State of Israel, Chaim Herzog. From his parents and his paternal and maternal grandparents he was blessed with a wealth of gifts that he dedicated to the people and the State of Israel in war and in peace. Fortunately for us, he completed and published his autobiography before he breathed his last, and that is a testament to his greatness and legacy for all of us to emulate. To his beloved wife Aura and all the family we extend sincerest condolences. His memory is eternal as is our people. Rabbi Emanuel Rackman, Chancellor Jane Stern Lebell Pres., American Friends Gen. (Res.) Yehuda Halevy Executive Vice President Bar-Ilan University

title: Bausch & Lomb Will Trim 1,900 Jobs in Revamping
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,900 jobs, or about 14 percent of its work force, as part of a revamping that the eyewear manufacturer said would result in more than $100 million in annual savings by 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, NONA
description: MILLER-Nona. Beloved wife of Roger. Memorial service Unitarian Universalist Center, 48 Shelter Rock Rd., Manhasset, Sunday 2:30 pm, April 27, 1997

title: Mother of Four Charged With Endangerment
description: A mother of four young girls was arrested last night and charged with endangering the welfare of her children after leaving them alone without food in the family's unsanitary apartment in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Strikes Against Automakers Threaten Car-Sales Season
description: Strikes at automobile factories are crimping the output of popular cars and trucks just as the spring selling season is getting under way at dealerships across the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLLINS, ROBERT C.
description: COLLINS-Robert C., of New York, NY, died on April 21, 1997; born on October 21, 1910 in Rock Island, Illinois; raised in New Kensington, PA.; and graduated from Cornell University in 1931. In World War II he was a captain in the Army Air Corps and served as Group Ordinance Officer for the 47th Bomb Group in the campaigns of North Africa, Italy and Southern France. He worked as an engineer for U.S. Steel in Birmingham, Alabama, Koppers Company in Venezuela and for General Cable in New York City where he retired. He is survived by his wife, Patricia L. Collins; his daughters Catherine Hillenbrand of Seattle, WA., and Dorothy C. Collins of Ashville, NC; his grandchildren Nathaniel Hudson and Simon Hudson of Seattle, WA.; and his brothers Donald J. Collins of Nashville, TN and Philip C. Collins of Wilmington, DE. Services will be private. Contributions to Cancer Care Inc., 1180 Avenue of the Americas, New York, N.Y. 10036, would be appreciated.

title: Fantasy of Killing Is Seen as a Path to Murder

description: Fearing that forthcoming economic data will be strong, prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates further, traders bid down prices of Treasury securities yesterday, despite decent demand at a note auction.

title: PHARMACIA & UPJOHN SHARES FALL ON EARNINGS FORECAST
description: The stock of Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. dropped more than 13 percent yesterday after the American-Swedish drug company said first-quarter earnings per share would fall 16 percent from the level a year earlier. The company also said it expects to report a 6 percent drop in sales for the quarter ended March 31. Analysts had predicted a strong quarter for Pharmacia & Upjohn, but the company said exchange rates and weak European sales, as well as competition from cheaper copycat drugs in the United States, hurt profits. Its shares fell $4.75 yesterday, to $30.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Woman Killed As Man Chases A Stolen Van
description: A driver chasing a van stolen from his workplace in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon crashed his car into a third vehicle, killing a woman and injuring three other people, the police said.

title: Hiding Behind the Moon
description: During the 1963 debate over whether the U.S. should sign the Limited Test-Ban Treaty, which prohibited all aboveground nuclear testing, right-wing opponents of the treaty came up with a novel argument for rejecting it. They said the treaty was unverifiable because the Russians could always send a nuclear missile to the other side of the moon and detonate it there without us seeing it. I'm not makin' this up. Fortunately, such looney arguments were rejected by the Senate, the Test-Ban Treaty was ratified and all U.S. and Soviet atmospheric nuclear testing ended -- even on the dark side of the moon.

title: Repairs at Nuclear Plant
description: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station will be shut down for a few days to two weeks while repairs are made to control rods that failed to operate quickly enough during a regular weekend test, officials said yesterday.

title: Bank of Scotland Reports Profit Increase
description: The Bank of Scotland, Britain's eighth-largest bank, said yesterday that fiscal year 1996 pretax profit rose at the high end of expectations because of a strong increase in lending income. The Edinburgh-based bank said profit before tax for the year to Feb. 28 was $:664.1 million ($1.05 billion), up from a profit before tax and one-time items of $:491.3 million a year earlier.

title: PHOENIX NETWORK TO MERGE WITH US ONE COMMUNICATIONS
description: Phoenix Network Inc. said yesterday that it would merge with the closely held US ONE Communications Corporation of Dallas in a $94 million deal. Under the agreement, Phoenix Network, a reseller of long-distance telephone service, will issue about 37.5 million common shares to US ONE shareholders. Phoenix Network stock rose 31.25 cents a share yesterday, to $2.50. The company, which is based in Golden, Colo., and will be the surviving entity, will use US ONE's national network of telecommunications switching equipment for its own long-distance telephone service.

title: CHARTER ONE IN STOCK DEAL FOR ANOTHER CLEVELAND BANK
description: Charter One Financial Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Haverfield Corporation for $53.7 million in stock. Both companies are based in Cleveland. Charter One Financial is the holding company of Charter One Bank, which has about $14 billion in total assets. Haverfield is the holding company of Home Bank, which has about $342 million in assets. The deal values Haverfield's stock at $27 a share. Shares of Haverfield rose 75 cents yesterday, to $24.25. Charter One stock was unchanged at $42.50 a share.

title: Genovese Family Counselor Is Convicted of Racketeering
description: The counselor and third-highest-ranking member of the powerful Genovese crime family was convicted yesterday in Manhattan Federal court on racketeering and murder conspiracy charges, as well as charges of defrauding the city and various charities of money from the annual Feast of San Gennaro, a popular street festival in Little Italy.

title: Martinez Makes It Look Easy For Yanks
description: The gray afternoon that the Yankees were finding gorgeous with a 5-0 lead on the scoreboard had deteriorated into a grayer day after their imposing advantage had shriveled to 6-5 in the sixth inning yesterday. That was when Tino Martinez, looking as comfortable as Tiger Woods's accountant, batted with the bases loaded. That was when the day turned brighter and the scoreboard turned beautiful again for the resurgent Yankees.

title: Anheuser-Busch Sees Gain
description: Anheuser-Busch is expecting its United States beer shipments to rise about 1 percent in 1997. The maker of Budweiser and Bud Light beers, which reported today that first-quarter shipments rose three-tenths of 1 percent, expects shipments for the overall domestic beer industry to be little changed or slightly higher for the year, said Anheuser-Busch's chief financial officer, Randolph Baker. Anheuser-Busch, based here, is the world's largest brewer.

title: MERCURY FINANCE TO RESTATE 1996 EARNINGS TO A LOSS
description: The Mercury Finance Company estimated yesterday that it would restate last year's earnings to a loss of $48 million to $55 million, and said its outside auditors questioned its ability to survive. Mercury, a lending service based in Lake Forest, Ill., originally reported a $120.7 million profit for 1996. Yesterday it estimated its net worth at $138 million to $145 million, or less than $1 a share. Mercury's stock fell to $1.375 a share, an eight-year low, after a delayed opening this morning. It closed down 25 cents, to $1.75. There are 172.5 million shares outstanding. Mercury said it expected its outside auditor, Arthur Andersen L.L.P., to express ''doubts about the company's ability to continue as a going concern.'' The New York Stock Exchange said if Andersen took that position, the exchange would review Mercury's eligibility for continued listing.

title: Bridge
description: A quarter-century ago, at a world championship in Taiwan, two French experts who were not regular partners had an unusual misfortune. One of them, holding no aces, responded five clubs to a Blackwood inquiry. As he had bid strongly, his partner assumed that this meant four aces and bid a grand slam. The result was down four, doubled, and it is a world record -- at worst a tie -- for acelessness in a grand slam contract.

The 65-foot yacht's sleek white hull displayed a large graphic of a computer keyboard in keeping with the boat's name and sponsor, Toshiba. Conner, 54, has hired CHRIS DICKSON of New Zealand to skipper Toshiba in the 1997-98 competition. The nine-month event is scheduled to begin Sept. 21 in England.

title: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES ACQUIRING SPIRIT RENT-A-CAR
description: Republic Industries agreed yesterday to buy Spirit Rent-A-Car Inc. of Solon, Ohio, for about $80 million in stock. It would be the third recent purchase of a rental car company by Republic, which is based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Spirit is active in the insurance replacement market, providing rental cars to customers whose vehicles are being repaired or replaced. In February, Republic completed its acquisition of National Car Rental System Inc. for $832.7 million in stock and the assumption of debt, following the $625 million purchase of Alamo Rent-a-Car late last year. Republic said it would form a rental car unit that would include National, Alamo and Spirit. Republic rose 43.75 cents yesterday, to $26.50.

title: New Date, A Dentist And Yada Yada Yada
description: ''Frasier'' and ''Third Rock From the Sun'' come mighty close at times, but ''Seinfeld'' remains the most inventive, utterly delicious sitcom on network prime time. The NBC series about four quintessential New Yorkers has had an occasional dry stretch, but then, taking a deep comedic breath, it goes on a roll of what have come to be known as instant classics, episodes like ''The Soup Nazi'' and the ''Master of My Domain'' riff on masturbation. Even with this season's departure of Larry David, the producer who was Jerry Seinfeld's closest collaborator, the show continues its extraordinary momentum.

title: The Camera Smiled on the Rangers
description: The camera -- now a celebrity -- is no bigger than a lipstick tube. It is wrapped in foam, then encased in a Home Depot plumbing pipe worth $5, the type you would find beneath your kitchen sink. The most expensive part of the casing is a $25 clamp that attaches the well-protected camera to the rear of a goal. A wire from the pipe connects at the bottom of the net to a transmitter that emits television signals.

title: Creditors in South Korea Disagree on a Bailout
description: Creditors of the Jinro Group of South Korea, a debt-ridden conglomerate, failed yesterday to agree on a plan to speed a bailout. In a meeting, commercial banks rejected a bid to exempt smaller merchant banks from having to make additional loans to prevent Jinro from becoming the country's third multibillion-dollar bankruptcy this year.

title: Touring Gardens, Homes and Estates
description: HOUSE tours, show houses and garden tours -- each a fund-raiser for a social-service organization, school or historic preservation group -- have started at country estates, urban apartments and backyard gardens from Boston to Delaware.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for Orthodox Holy Thursday and tomorrow for Orthodox Good Friday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: STANHOME ANNOUNCES SALE OF UNIT AND JOB CUTS
description: Shares of Stanhome Inc. rose 22 percent yesterday after the company said it would sell a collectibles unit, dismiss workers and sell its Westfield, Mass., headquarters to focus on its giftware business. The stock advanced $5.50 a share, to $30.50. Stanhome said it would sell Hamilton Direct Response, which sells dolls, plates and figurines, to the closely held Bradford Group for $46 million, including debt. Hamilton had $145 million in sales last year. Stanhome also said it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to study options for its Worldwide Direct Selling Group, a maker of personal care and cosmetics products, with 1996 sales of $187 million.

title: Plaid and Other Familiar Styles From Portugal
description: As the Chinese proverb goes, ''Do not climb a tree to look for fish.'' The Ballet Gulbenkian from Lisbon is one of Europe's best-known modern-dance troupes, has marvelous dancers and apparently has nothing new to tell us.

title: Judge Faults Giuliani's Policy On Releasing Public Records
description: Criticizing the Giuliani administration's policy on providing access to public records, a state judge said yesterday he would appoint a special referee to decide whether the city must give The Daily News reports of investigations into allegations of wrongdoing against city officials.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WATERBURY, AMY WALDHORN
description: WATERBURY-Amy Waldhorn. 4/24/54-6/23/96. Diva of talk, singer in the rain. Sublimely funny. Deftly smart. Never lost her touch. Memorial service 5/17/97. Call Bank St. College of Education: 875-4607

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTMAN, NATHAN
description: ALTMAN-Nathan. Our deepest sympathy to our brother and friend Howard, on the passing of his father Nathan. Our prayers are with him and his family. The Brothers of Pi Kappa Alpha Emory University

title: A Signal, and Peru Hostages Opened Door to Raid
description: The spectacular rescue of 71 hostages from the Japanese Ambassador's residence here on Tuesday was a meticulously executed plan in which military commandos blasted into the compound through underground tunnels and hostages who had received advance warning of the raid furtively opened a sealed door for the soldiers to enter.

title: California State Term Limits Overturned by Federal Judge
description: In the nation's first court ruling against term limits for state legislators, a Federal judge today overturned the limits approved by California voters in 1990, declaring that the measure's lifetime limits of six years in the State Assembly and eight in the State Senate were unconstitutional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLIKOFF, BENET, JR.
description: POLIKOFF-Benet, Jr., April 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Florence Davis Polikoff. Adored father of Elisabeth Polikoff Doyle and her husband Peter, Benet Steven Polikoff and his wife Cynthia, Louise Polikoff Belsky and her husband Paul, Andrew Charles Frank and his wife Atsuko, and Thomas Leon Frank. Cherished grandfather of Kylee, Chloe, Natasha, Sarah and Briggs. Beloved brother of Peggy Polikoff Bradt and her husband Bud, and treasured uncle of George and Richard Bradt. Was counsel to the law firm of Rosenman & Colin. He was a long time member of the Board of Trustees of the Lexington School for the Deaf and former chair of the Real Property Committee of the Bar Association of the City of New York. He was an active member of the American College of Real Estate Lawyers and a trustee of the Victor D'Amico Institute of Art. Family receiving at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street between 7-9PM on Wednesday, April 23. Service at Campbell's at 10 AM, on Thursday, April 24. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday, about Bear Stearns Companies' relationship with a small brokerage firm that failed, omitted four words in a quotation from a Bear Stearns advertisement. As shown in the adjoining picture, the ad reads, ''We clear just about everything for just about everybody.''

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BERGER, STANLEY
description: BERGER-Stanley. April 24, 1977. Inspiration-illumination-integrity.

title: Cat Hair Finds Way Into Courtroom in Canadian Murder Trial
description: It was a trial to remember on Prince Edward Island, Canada. A young woman was murdered, her estranged boyfriend was accused of the crime, and the main evidence against him came from the DNA of a cat.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Friendship Bent by Gender
description: ''All Over Me,'' a confident first feature directed by Alex Sichel and written by her sister Sylvia, observes the teen-age angst of best girlfriends being driven apart by stirrings of sexual identity. Big, ungainly Claude (Alison Folland) must deal with the attraction she feels for Ellen (Tara Subkoff), a druggy flirt who also has a boyfriend vying for her affections.

title: Art in Review
description: Oscar Bluemner

title: The Spoken Word
description: ''CHRISTO AND JEANNE-CLAUDE: WORKS IN PROGRESS,'' Harlem School of the Arts, 645 St. Nicholas Avenue, near 141st Street. The artists will talk about their current works in progress, including ''The Gates'' project for Central Park. Tomorrow at noon. Free. Information: (212) 926-4100.

title: Fiat's Earnings Increased 10.4% Last Year
description: Fiat S.p.A., Italy's largest company, said today that its profits rose 10.4 percent in 1996, which was larger than expected, because of one-time gains. It said, however, that profitability did not pick up much in the first quarter of 1997.

title: RHONE-POULENC RORER INC. (RPR,N)
description: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that earnings fell 23.4 percent in the first quarter, reflecting production delays at its Centeon plasma joint venture and increased competition for its asthma and cancer drugs.

title: Businesses Buying More PC's, Survey Shows
description: Personal computer purchases are on the rise among United States companies, jumping 20 percent in March from the month a year earlier, according to a survey by the market researchers Computer Intelligence.

title: A Flood of Fire and Ice
description: Dawn was still hours away on Sunday as I closed the car trunk and returned to the house to finish off my hoard of drinking water: one gallon for the orchids, a second to take with me. Since Christmas I had kept a few containers stashed away, seemingly without reason. I walked into the back garden for a final look at the creeping river, and said a silent goodbye to the house. The neighborhood was still; no people, no movement, only rising water. I was the last to leave.

title: Pregnant At 63? Why Not?
description: To any middle-aged mother, having a baby at age 63 probably seems like a colossally bad idea. Imagine the constant backache at that age, the 2 A.M. feedings and the endless diaper changes. Didn't nature arrange for us to stop doing this sort of thing after our mid-40's?

title: On Video, It's 'No Problem'
description: The videotape's quality is not good. It is black and white and jerky, and never really frames the main character's face. But the drama is captured in a twice-repeated motion: two envelopes, containing what prosecutors say is more than $500 in cash, find their way into the right rear pocket of a large man behind a desk, whose favorite line appears to be, ''No problem.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINSTEIN, DR. SHERMAN C.
description: FEINSTEIN-Dr. Sherman C. On Tuesday, April 22, 1997. The American Society for Adolescent Psychiatry mourns the loss of its Past President Dr. Sherman C. Feinstein of Highlands Park, IL. Dr. Feinstein served for many years as Editor in Chief of the annual volume: Adolescent Psychiatry. More recently, he was President of the International Society of Adolescent Psychiatry. Our condolences are extended to his family. Contributions may be made to the ISAP Feinstein Memorial Fund C/O Rosalie Landy, 730 Soundview Avenue, Bronx, New York 10473.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, MAX, M.D.
description: FRIEDMAN-Max, M.D. 91, on April 18, 1997, in Tamarac, FL. Director Emeritus OBS-GYN Wyckoff Hts Hospital. Born near Tarnopol, Austria. Attended Columbia University and L.I. Medical College, Brooklyn. Past President, Queens Gynecological Society; Life Fellow, Brooklyn Gyn. Society; Fellow, American College of Ob/ Gyn. Survived by his wife, Elaine; sons Sheldon B. and Alan W.; sisters Ethel Wagner and Leah Kaiser; brother Julius; six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Kushner

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BABSON, DONALD P.
description: BABSON-Donald P., of Wellesley, Massachusetts; on April 21, 1997. He was 73. Husband of the late Susan (Averill) Babson. He is survived by 5 children: Averill Babson & her husband Gregory E. Sohns of Darien, CT; Paul Talbot Babson, II of Needham, MA; James A. Babson and his wife Asoka Bandarage of South Hadley, MA; Deborah Babson of Jaffrey, N.H. & Richard Babson of Boston, MA; three granddaughters: Olivia Louise Sohns, Antonia Averill Sohns and Juliet Susan Babson of Darien, CT; and one grandson, Maithri Bandarage Babson of South Hadley, MA. The family request that no flowers be sent. Contributions in his name may be made to the institution or charity that best represents your affiliation with Donald P. Babson. A memorial service in celebration of his life will commence at 7:30PM on Friday, May 30, in Knight Auditorium on the Babson College Campus. Mr. Babson was Chairman of Babson-United Investment Advisors, Inc. as well as Chairman and President of United Business Service. For information call J.S. Waterman and Sons-Waring Funeral Home, Wellesley, Massachusetts (617-235-4110).

title: White House Backs Off Urging Ban on Big Unregulated Gifts
description: The White House has put on hold its plan to petition the Federal Election Commission to ban large, unregulated campaign donations, because of resistance from a surprising source: some of the most prominent Congressional supporters of tighter campaign finance laws.

title: A Twist On Songs With a Twist
description: Karen Akers, the most regal of cabaret singers, is not known for her ebullience. But her new show, ''Time for a Love Song,'' at Rainbow and Stars through May 10, includes an inspired seam of deadpan humor. Punctuating her program of serious ballads performed in English, French and Italian are comic torch songs by Dick Gallagher and Mark Waldrop from the musical ''Howard Crabtree's When Pigs Fly'' addressed to Speaker Newt Gingrich, Senator Strom Thurmond and Rush Limbaugh.

title: Two Very Hot Hands: For One Night Only?
description: The Charlotte Hornets were supposed to be the better shooting team in their first-round playoff series against the Knicks.

title: People
description: * Nik Mainthia was named senior vice president and media director at the Fitzgerald Cos., Atlanta, succeeding Rich Simms, who left to join the Media Partnership Corp., Norwalk, Conn., as president. Mr. Mainthia had been vice president and planning director at BBDO South, Atlanta, a unit of Omnicom Group.

title: Mets Hope Alfonzo Will Move In at Third
description: The youngest Met would like to settle down and maybe raise a batting average. Now is his chance.

title: Stock Trades: A Better Deal For Investors Isn't Simple
description: Wall Street is buzzing about ''best execution'' -- regulators are requiring it, academics are analyzing it, brokerage firms are boasting about it. And some of the nation's stock exchanges are wielding it as a weapon in their long-running war over trading volume, power and profits.

title: Accounts
description: * Newspaper Association of America, Vienna, Va., to Jerry & Ketchum, New York, owned by Jerry Della Femina and the Omnicom Group, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: Costs Of the C.I.A.
description: What responsibility should Americans feel when our Government, for policy reasons, imposes on another country a regime that reduces it to misery?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DAVIS, HARRY W.
description: DAVIS-Harry W. A memorial to the late Hon. Harry W. David, Acting Justice of the New York State Supreme Court, will be held at The Association of the Bar, Evarts Room, 42 West 44th Street, April 29, 1997 at 4 P.M.

title: Democracy in Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: KENNETH COLE PLANS AGREEMENT WITH HONG KONG RETAILER
description: Kenneth Cole Productions Inc. said yesterday that it would enter a licensing agreement with Dickson Licensing Ltd. of Hong Kong for the Kenneth Cole New York and Kenneth Cole Reaction trademarks. Financial terms were not disclosed. Kenneth Cole, a New York-based designer of shoes, handbags and apparel, said Dickson planned to develop a network of Kenneth Cole retail stores in Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan, China, Indonesia and Malaysia. Stores in all six countries are to open by the end of 1999. Dickson Licensing Ltd. is a unit of Dickson Concepts Ltd., a Hong Kong retailer.

title: Bribery Charges Brought
description: A Palisades Park auxiliary police officer was charged yesterday with trying to bribe a regular police officer into dismissing a drunken driving charge against a local businessman. The auxiliary officer, Matthew Testino, 26, who worked as a part-time bouncer for several nightclubs in the area, offered a $1,000 payment on behalf of Sok M. Kang, a businessman, said David Nathanson, an assistant Bergen County prosecutor. A friend of Mr. Kang, Hyong J. Choe, contacted Mr. Testino, asking him to persuade the arresting officer in the case to drop the charges. The officer refused. Mr. Testino, Mr. Kang and Mr. Choe were charged with bribery; Mr. Testino was also charged with official misconduct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOUSMER, PERRY
description: ZOUSMER-Perry. You were the best friend a man could have. Honorable, decent, dependable, wise. Goodby, my lifelong partner. Manny and Jean Zisser

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAIL, LILY
description: VAIL-Lily, 84. Beloved mother, grandmother, great grandmother, sister and aunt. Adored widow of the late William Vail. Peacefully at her home in Stamford. Services Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, CT, 9:30AM, Friday, April 25th. Shiva will be observed Friday afternoon, Saturday night, Sunday and Monday. She has gone where she will be happiest, back to Bill.

title: Lights! Camera! Action! But No Smoking!
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Positions on Nasdaq Rose 6.3% in Latest Month
description: Staples has been sliding for weeks, first on fears that antitrust regulators would oppose its acquisition of Office Depot, and then on the reality that they were doing so. Staples closed yesterday at $18.75 a share, down from a peak of $26.375 in early March. So the short positions have been profitable.

title: Johnson and Erhardt Talk, And the Topic Is Literature
description: Neither Bill Parcells nor his assistants are currently giving interviews, but Keyshawn Johnson says he has patched up his differences with Ron Erhardt, the Jets' offensive coordinator last season.

title: MAZDA SAYS ITS SALES IN THE UNITED STATES FELL 16.6%
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation's sales in the United States fell 16.6 percent, to 226,000 vehicles, in the year ended March 31, the company said. Mazda, the smallest of Japan's top five auto makers, expects sales to rise in the year through March 1998. The company said in February that it would reorganize its money-losing North American operation and named Richard Beattie, a Ford Motor Company executive, to run it. Ford took effective control of Mazda last April by raising its stake to a controlling 33.3 percent. Mazda said its share of the United States market for cars and trucks was 1.6 percent in 1996, down from 1.9 percent in 1995.

title: Graduate Gives $30 Million To Swarthmore
description: Emphasizing the idea that a commitment to social service is a vital part of a liberal arts education, the philanthropist Eugene M. Lang donated $30 million to Swarthmore College, the institution announced yesterday. It is one of the largest gifts ever received by a small liberal arts college.

title: UNISYS SHAREHOLDERS REJECT PLAN TO SPLIT OFF A UNIT
description: The Unisys Corporation said yesterday that its shareholders had rejected a proposal to sell or split off the company's computer hardware unit. About 37 percent of the Unisys shares voted were cast in favor, while about 60 percent were against the proposal backed by the company's largest shareholder, Greenway Partners L.P., a New York investment firm that owns a 4.6 percent stake. Unisys, a computer maker based in Blue Bell, Pa., said its management opposed the plan. Shareholders, approved a second Greenway-backed proposal to end the staggered terms on its board. The shareholder vote is nonbinding, but management said it would consider having all directors elected at one time.

title: Eurotunnel Reports Loss of $1.1 Billion
description: Eurotunnel, the debt-burdened operator of the Channel Tunnel, said yesterday that it lost $:685 million, or $1.1 billion, last year as the costs of servicing its debt overwhelmed a 71 percent rise in revenue.

title: Cut! A Fielder Movie Without Any Action
description: Cecil Fielder digs a small hole in the batter's box to plant his right foot, lowers himself into his usual crouch, waves the massive bat once or twice behind his head, eases his 270-pound body back and then swings. The routine produces another pop-out. Cut, try it all over again. Fielder is uncomfortable.

title: Blinded Wife Testifies in a Twisting Trial
description: Thirty-five years after delivering testimony that helped send Burton N. Pugach to prison for 14 years, Linda Pugach, now married to him, defended her husband in a Queens courtroom yesterday against charges that he threatened to kill his mistress of five years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLIKOFF, BENET, JR.
description: POLIKOFF-Benet, Jr. The Lexington School for the Deaf and Center for Deafness is deeply saddened by the passing of Benet Polikoff, Jr. as a longterm member of the Board of Trustees. He offered wisdom and guidance to all associated with the Lexington Community. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. Oscar Cohen, Chief Exec Officer

title: The Fans Face Off In New York's Great Doughnut Debate
description: New York City, a town long wedded to the bagel, is having a wild fling these days with the doughnut.

title: The Double Crime
description: ''The suffering or death of any human being of any or no religion is as offensive to God and as demeaning to us as is the suffering and death of Christians. However, to act is to act on something particular -- and the persecution of Christians worldwide is massive, underreported, largely unknown and when known is often passed by in silence.''

title: Art in Review
description: June Leaf

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BAKER, FLORENCE
description: BAKER-Florence. 4/25/94. Miss you, Mother. Our thoughts and hearts embrace you always. Cherish you. Paula, Beau and Bobby

title: In Lyrical, Dilapidated Saxony, Castles for a Song
description: The Gaussig Castle has everything that an up-and-coming duke or count might want: a ballroom, a fully stocked library, a hunting room complete with hundreds of deer antlers mounted on the wall. It even comes with a Gothic chapel.

description: Rackstraw Downes

title: Standard & Poor's, Given Subsidies, Is to Stay in New York
description: Rejecting a more lucrative bid from officials in New Jersey, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a fixture of New York City's financial industry since 1860, agreed yesterday to keep its 2,057 employees in Manhattan through the year 2019 in exchange for a package of tax incentives and energy discounts worth at least $23.7 million.

title: Heat Crushes Magic Early
description: Pat Williams, the Orlando Magic's executive vice president, brought the Magic here in a cocky mood for tonight's Eastern Conference quarterfinal playoff opener with the Miami Heat.

title: Motorola Raises Stake in Czech Chip Maker
description: Motorola Inc., the electronics maker, increased its stake in the Czech computer chip producer Tesla Sezam A.S. to 57 percent, company officials said today.

title: Very Mean Streets: They're Full of Lava
description: BIBLICAL calamity is hotter than usual this week, thanks to the explosions, flames, ash and, in the words of one quick-witted newscaster, ''what can only be described as . . . lava!'' that level Los Angeles in the happily malicious ''Volcano.'' Come on, admit it: you might enjoy watching this happen. Another perfect day dawns on cabana men, sun worshipers and roller skaters during this film's opening credits. There's comfort in knowing that the La Brea tar pits will be shooting off flaming meteors before that day is over.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SNYDER, JACOB M.
description: SNYDER-Jacob M. The Directors and Staff of the Board of Jewish Education of Greater New York records with sorrow the death of Jack Snyder, Honorary Trustee and former Administrator of the BJE. May Faigel and his entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Philip Schatten, President David Mann, Executive VP Stephen A. Kramer, Chairman of the Board

title: Kidder to Pay $14.1 Million To Settle Suit By Investors
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company, which has not operated as a brokerage firm for two years, agreed yesterday to pay $14.1 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that accused 35 firms of fixing prices on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: New York City Sued by U.S. On Water Filtration Plant
description: The Federal Government sued New York City yesterday for failing to build a $600 million filtration plant to clean drinking water from its most polluted reservoirs, those east of the Hudson River.

title: Burmese Sanctions Get Little Backing in Asia
description: Not long ago a senior American diplomat in Myanmar who desperately wished for that country's pro-democracy movement to prevail conceded that economic sanctions would at most amount to ''a moral shot across the bow.''

title: SENATE APPROVES PACT ON CHEMICAL WEAPONS AFTER LOTT OPENS WAY
description: The Senate approved the Chemical Weapons Convention tonight after Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, threw his support behind it. The treaty prohibits the production, storage and use of poison gas.

title: Reworked by Stephen King, 'Shining' Is a Shriek
description: More often than not, when television decides to remake a well-known movie, especially one from a distinguished film director, the result is distressing. But that is hardly the case this weekend. The best-selling author Stephen King never hid the fact that he was unhappy with the director Stanley Kubrick's 1980 version of his novel ''The Shining.'' Mr. King's solution: adapt the book himself for a six-hour mini-series. ''Stephen King's 'The Shining' '' will be shown on ABC Sunday, Monday and, running up against NBC's big guns (''Seinfeld'' and ''E. R.''), Thursday. This television production leaves the movie in the dust.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, CHAIM
description: HERZOG-Chaim. We mourn the passing of our dear friend, Chaim Herzog, sixth President of the State of Israel, Ambassador to the United Nations, head of the Israeli Military Intelligence and General in the Israel Army, who not only lived through a historic period in world history-but helped to create it. As the son of Isaac Halevy Herzog, first Ashkenazi Chief Rabbi of the State of Israel, he received a thorough religious and secular education starting with the Hebron Yeshiva through the Wesley College in Dublin, the Government of Palestine Law School in Jerusalem and London and Cambridge Universities. Although he received many awards as co-author of more than six books, liberator of the victims of Nazi concentration camps while serving as officer in the British Armed Forces and honored by both branches of the U.S. Congress-In recent years he was most proud of the establishment of the Chaim Herzog Center for Middle East Studies & Diplomacy at the Ben Gurion University in the Negev-he served as a distinguished member on the Board of Directors of our Slim Fast Foods Companies for many years as a colleague of the greatest reliability, a loyal associate and an important factor in the success of a number of our business decisions. President Chaim Herzog brought a great sense of dignity and respect to the Jews throughout the world in general, and the citizens in Israel in particular because of his intellect, warmth, and his profound feeling of love and understanding for all members of the human race throughout the world. May the ''Almighty'' comfort his wife, Aura, his children and grandchildren among the bereaved people of Zion and Jerusalem and may his memory serve as a beacon of light to guide them all in the years ahead. S. Daniel Abraham, Chairman of the Board Dr. Edward L. Steinberg, Vice Chairman of the Board Slim Fast Foods Company

description: You May Already Be a Winner

description: In percent

title: MERGER OF NYNEX AND BELL ATLANTIC CLEARS U.S. HURDLE
description: After an intensive nine-month investigation, the Justice Department announced yesterday that it would not try to block the $22 billion merger of Bell Atlantic and Nynex. The decision removes the last major hurdle to a deal that would create a communications colossus, offering local telephone service in an unbroken line from Maine to Virginia.

title: Listless? Flamenco May Help
description: ''Flamenco'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Here are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29. The film opens today at Lincoln Plaza, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: Political Spotlight Shines on Voluntarism Conference
description: The Presidents' Summit for America's Future, which opens a three-day run in Philadelphia on Sunday, is the offspring of the dominant reality of contemporary American politics -- the shortage of money for government programs.

title: Life in This Man's World Can Rattle a Superwoman
description: Eve Stephens (Tilda Swinton), the excruciatingly conflicted central character in ''Female Perversions,'' is a high-powered trial lawyer so obsessed with appearances and competition that when she runs into another woman wearing the same trendy shade of lipstick (it's called ''Red Pussycat'') she flies into a rage and furiously tosses her tube of the stuff into the trash.

title: Lloyd's Wins Ruling Against Investors
description: Lloyd's of London has won another round in the battle to get investors who have refused to pay their bills, contending the insurance market defrauded them, to pay up.

title: Officials Say Suspect Knew Pizza Worker
description: One of the two teen-agers accused of killing two pizza deliverymen in Franklin, N.J., knew one of the victims and asked if his food would be delivered by that deliveryman when he called to make the order, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Prices for Winter Wheat Ease As Fears of Freeze Loss Fade
description: Wheat prices fell yesterday after the largest United States farmers' cooperative estimated that a freeze in the Plains this month had caused less damage to the winter crop than earlier estimated.

title: Thomas Ricketts, 66, Savings and Loan Executive
description: Thomas R. Ricketts, the longtime chairman and chief executive of the Standard Federal Bancorporation Inc. of Troy, Mich., the nation's 10th-largest savings and loan association, died on Tuesday. He was 66.

title: Sensuous Contradictions On a Passage to India
description: INDIA has an image problem in the West. Depending on who's looking, it might be seen as the home of reverberant sitars and yogic rapture, a kind of paradisiacal picnic ground between this world and the next. Or it's a place of leprous slums and civil strife, with a fathomless gulf between privilege and poverty.

title: Bogues's Injury Puts Weight on Delk
description: Muggsy Bogues did not have a crutch, but he had the table that divided the Hornets' locker room. And that was just as good.

title: Yesterday's Stars Lobby for Writers
description: In the basement of the Hart Senate Office Building, in the artificial light and clatter of the cafeteria, Fay Wray, 89, was preparing for her next scene. The legendary actress, the luminescent object of King Kong's desire, took out a mirror from her purse. She uncorked her lipstick, ''Really Red,'' and swiped her lips. Beaming, she was ready for her close-up with Senator Spence Abraham.

title: Laura Ashley Falls 28%; It Won't Meet Forecasts
description: Shares of Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C. plunged 28 percent yesterday after the retailer warned that current-year profit would fail to meet expectations. ''Overly aggressive'' sales targets and delays in opening stores in the United States caused an inventory buildup that will force it to cut prices, Laura Ashley said. The markdowns will cut first-half earnings, meaning full-year profit, ''although ahead of last year, will fall below current market expectations,'' the company said.

Paert's Stabat Mater) will be presented at the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse, 68th Street between Park and Lexington, at 8 P.M., May 1, 2 and 3.

title: Toyota Plans Another Buyback
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said yesterday it would buy back another 100 billion yen, or $793 million, of its shares and raise its dividend. Under that program, Toyota has bought back 25.83 million shares at a cost of 75 billion yen. The number of Toyota shares outstanding at the end of 1996 was 3.774 billion.

title: Using Cellular Phones May Add to Road Risks
description: The 1992 Ford Explorer was headed west on Route 25 in Suffolk County, N.Y., one day in October 1993, when the driver, according to a lawsuit filed later, tried to use the cellular phone installed on the transmission hump.

title: Diner's Journal
description: When Pino Luongo opened Coco Pazzo on the Upper East Side in 1990, who would have predicted that the restaurant would expand into a chain?

title: France Signals Its Displeasure At U.S. Over Cuba Trade Policy
description: France's conservative Government may be facing elections May 25 and June 1, but today it left no one in doubt about what it thought of American legislative attempts to discourage investments in Cuba.

title: MCI Says Earnings Were Flat Despite Long-Distance Gains

title: Publisher Shuts Down

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALINT, GEORGE, M.D.
description: BALINT-George, M.D. 72., Physician, internist and anesthesiologist for 47 years, died at New York Hospital April 24, 1997. Dr. Balint devotedly cared for his more than eighty-thousand patients during his lifetime. As a young doctor he worked at the Peterffy Hospital in Budapest, Hungary and at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Attendorn, Germany. In New York City he served at New York University and V.A. Hospital, The Hospital for Special Surgery-Cornell Medical College and at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. Dr. Balint was a charitable human being, a cultured man with great integrity and dignity. He enjoyed music, the fine arts and appreciated the company of his loyal colleagues and friends. He trusted and was grateful to his own caring physicians and medical associates, nurses, throughout his illness until the end of his life. Maria, beloved wife of 37 years, is mourning him. He is survived by his aunt, Nelly Szasz, Budapest, Hungary, his late brother's widow and her daughter Eva Balint of Los Angeles, and Agnes Liebhardt of California. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in the memory of Dr. Balint to Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Department of Anesthesiology and/ or Department of Surgery, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, New York 10029-6574.

title: The Misty Mood of the Tonalists
description: AMONG the many isms of American art, the amorphous one known as Tonalism has a rather low profile. Almost a kind of anti-Impressionism, substituting muted hues and misty effects for the Impressionists' exuberant here-and-nowness of color and light, Tonalism expressed itself mainly in landscape. Not really a movement, but a mix of tendencies that began to drift together around 1870, it remained a style without a name until the mid-1890's. It peaked in the first decade of the 1900's and faded out by the time of the 1913 Armory Show.

description: The Government said today that the Medicare trust fund that pays hospital bills for elderly people would run out of money in just four years if Congress took no action to slow spending or raise taxes.

description: A woman jumped to her death from the roof of an 18-story apartment building in East Harlem yesterday, moments after the police arrested a man for trespassing on the rooftop, the police said.

title: A Lesson From Milwaukee
description: Desperate to find a remedy for failing schools, several states are considering voucher experiments that would offer low-income students private-school scholarships at public expense. The point would be to determine if students who fail in public schools would do better in private settings. The teachers' union opposes the idea, arguing that vouchers would bankrupt public schools while offering little in the way of educational benefit. But a study of the longest-running experiment in Milwaukee suggests that vouchers can improve the prospects of the poorest and least prepared students.

title: A Channel-Surfing Experience With Beanbag Chairs and Gym
description: IN ''Rooms With a View: Environments for Video'' at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo, three of the season's most visible trends -- video art, curatorial experimentation and the rising interest among artists in design -- are thrown into the deep end of the pool. They don't exactly swim, but they certainly don't sink either. Rather they cling together, each alternately pushing the others under in order to stay afloat, in a competitive survival-of-the-fittest blur of ideas and images that is both exciting and irritating.

title: Theory About the Universe Has Its Own Ups and Downs
description: Just last week two scientists reported that the universe appeared to have an ''up'' and a ''down,'' a startling piece of news for cosmologists because it challenged their fundamental belief that the universe is the same in all directions.

title: Officer Cleared in Shooting
description: A white Camden police officer who fatally shot a black teen-ager while on a drug stakeout has been cleared of any criminal wrongdoing, prosecutors announced yesterday. On Wednesday, a grand jury declined to indict the officer, John Sosinavage, the Acting Camden County Prosecutor, Lee A. Solomon, told the Associated Press. The shooting last November sparked a furor in the South Camden neighborhood where Kevin Spencer, 19, was shot in the chest after he went to urinate in an abandoned row house, where police officers were on a drug stakeout.

title: FILENET TO TAKE $6 MILLION CHARGE TO CLOSE OFFICE
description: The Filenet Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $6 million pretax charge in the second quarter to dismiss 10 percent of its workers and close its office in Burlington, Mass. About 150 employees will lose their jobs, the software developer said. Filenet announced plans on April 1 to close the Massachusetts office because of weaker-than-expected new orders. Filenet said the order shortfall led to a first-quarter loss of $9.4 million, or 63 cents a share, about 3 cents more than it had estimated earlier this month. The company's shares dropped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $11.375.

The lawsuit, which seeks $20 million in damages, comes two weeks after Providence Capital Inc. and Wyser-Pratte Inc. said they would wage a proxy fight to replace Comsat's directors because the stock has fallen 27 percent the past year. Shares of Comsat, a satellite communications company based in Bethesda, Md., fell $2 yesterday, to $20.375.
