title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERST, RICHARD NEVIN
description: KERST-Richard Nevin, age 83, of Katonah, N.Y., passed away on April 22, 1997. He was a graduate of the University of Wisconsin. Mr. Kerst served as a Lieutenant in the Navy aboard the USS Phoenix in the Pacific Theatre during World War II. He was associated with the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in NYC for 34 years until retiring in 1979 as Vice Chairman of the Board of Trustees. Mr. Kerst began his career in 1945 as the Assistant Comptroller, and was promoted to Comptroller, Assistant SecretaryTreasurer, Vice President of Administration, and then President from 1975-1977. He was a member of the Board of the Hecksher Foundation for Children for many years and was a member of the Board of Trustees for the Katonah Museum of Art. Beloved husband of Barbara Clark Kerst. Father of R. Duncan Kerst of Portland, OR, and Katrena K. Engstrom of Woodbridge, CT. Brother of Kenneth Kerst of Heathville, VA. Grandfather of Nicholas Engstrom, Cameron Kerst, and Allison Kerst. He was predeceased by his first wife, Annie Lee Duncan. Friends are invited to attend a memorial service on Monday, June 2, 1997, at 11 A.M. in the South Salem Presbyterian Church, South Salem, NY. Committal will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 at Jay Street, Katonah, New York 10536.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISS, RUTH MARGARET
description: REISS-Ruth Margaret, 37, of Boston, MA., died on April 22, 1997. Cause was complications from a bone marrow transplant for leukemia. Education included Miss Porter's School, Farmington, CT, Amherst College, Amherst, MA, '82, Masters in Education and English, Harvard University. Upon graduation from Amherst College, Ruth joined Morgan Guarantee Bank, NYC, where she was elected Vice President. In 1989, Ruth changed careers and after obtaining the Master's Degrees from Harvard she joined The Boston Foundation and became Director of Development. Pre-deceased by her brother Theodore Kranz Reiss. Ruth is survived by her parents Beverly B. and Theodore J. Reiss of Rumson, NJ, a sister Heidi M. Reiss, also of Rumson, a brother Carl A. Reiss, NYC and her maternal grandmother Lucille A. Blanchet, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to Miss Porter's School, Ruth M. Reiss Fund, 60 Main Street, Farmington, CT. 06032. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, NYC, Thursday 7-9 PM and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, April 26th, 10 AM, St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street, New York City.

title: Dredging Plans Move Ahead
description: The Port Authority yesterday approved spending $48.9 million to dig a 65-foot deep pit in Newark Bay to allow for some dredging of silt-clogged shipping channels. The buildup of sediment has made channels in Newark and Elizabeth too shallow for larger cargo ships to pass. But a debate over how to dispose of the dredged material, which contains toxins such as PCB's and dioxin, has stalled progress on dredging. The pit is to be used for one to three years while the authority explores other alternatives, including on-land dumping and construction of a containment island, officials said.

title: Press Seeks an End to Trial's Secrecy
description: As opening statements began yesterday in the trial of Timothy J. McVeigh, one of two men charged in the Oklahoma City bombing, lawyers for news organizations sought to persuade Judge Richard P. Matsch of Federal District Court to lift an order barring participants from talking about the case.

title: Technology Rally Fails To Lift Market
description: Investors allowed worries over rising interest rates to overpower a strong rally in technology stocks yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average down following a morning rally.

title: Softbank Profit Nearly Doubles
description: Profit at the Softbank Corporation, the big Japanese software distributor, nearly doubled last fiscal year, but analysts said that the jump was largely a result of a spectacular series of acquisitions and that growth would slow somewhat this year. Softbank reported yesterday that group pretax profit soared 94 percent in the year ending March 31, to 27.88 billion yen, or $221 million, on a 110 percent sales increase, to 359.74 billion yen, or $2.85 billion.

title: EASTMAN KODAK TO BUY MAJORITY STAKE IN CHINON
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a majority stake in Chinon Industries, a maker of digital cameras, for 1.9 billion yen ($15 million). Kodak, which makes photographic and imaging products, already owns 12.2 percent of Chinon and will buy 9.91 million more shares, giving it a 50.1 percent stake. The two companies have jointly developed and produced several Kodak digital cameras, and Chinon, which is based in Japan, produces Kodak's IL-500 scanner. Shares in Kodak, which is based in Rochester, fell $1, to $80.125.

title: Tens of Thousands of Refugees Abandon Zaire Camp
description: United Nations officials said today that tens of thousands of Rwandan refugees have abandoned a camp along a jungle road south of Kisangani after three days of confused fighting and are apparently moving south.

title: Corrections
description: A capsule summary on page B1 on Monday for the article about the trial of a Queens man, Burton N. Pugach, on charges of aggravated harassment and sexual abuse referred incorrectly to an earlier attack, on the woman who later became his wife. In that case, Mr. Pugach hired three men to throw lye in the woman's face; he did not do it himself.

The film is set in 1975, in the midst of bloody conflict, and it opens with the magisterial doomsaying of William Butler Yeats. That should offer some idea of its powerful foreboding.

description: The Procter & Gamble Company, benefiting from its efforts to cut costs, said today that earnings rose 16 percent in the fiscal third quarter.

title: CADMUS TO CLOSE PLANTS AND DISMISS 225 WORKERS
description: The Cadmus Communications Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss about 225 people, or 7.4 percent of its 3,050 employees, close plants and buy back 9 percent of its stock to bolster earnings. Cadmus, a printer of magazines and journals, also said that fiscal third-quarter results were $2 million, or 25 cents a share, on revenue of $97 million, less than analysts' expectations of 36 cents. Cadmus shares rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $13.375.

title: Weapons Expert Tells of Possible Iraqi Gas Attacks in Gulf War
description: A respected chemical-weapons researcher who had been mysteriously dismissed from a special White House panel said today that he believed that Iraq might have attacked American troops with chemical weapons during the 1991 Persian Gulf war, contrary to repeated denials by the Pentagon.

title: Ah, Those Nuances of Sugar and Grease
description: I like doughnuts as much as the next person, but eating eight or nine in a row is not my idea of a good time.

title: Airport Runway Closing
description: One of Newark International Airport's two main runways will close tomorrow and remain closed for 15 days for repaving, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey announced yesterday. To accommodate the $8.5 million project, airlines serving Newark agreed to reduce operations during the construction period, Port Authority officials said, cutting back on the number of flights that were scheduled through May 15 -- about 60 flights daily. Those flights were canceled several months ago, and officials said they did not expect the construction to cause any delays.

title: Lawmaker Questions Plans Of Mortgage Enterprises
description: Representative Jim Leach, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, called on the Clinton Administration today to review the investments and expansion plans of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, Fannie Mae and the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

title: Sam Moskowitz, 76, Learned Devotee of Science Fiction, Dies
description: Sam Moskowitz, an unlikely scholar widely regarded as the world's foremost authority on science fiction and by far its most devoted fan, died on April 15 at a hospital near his home in Newark. He was 76 and the author or editor of 62 books.

title: Computer Associates Shift
description: Computer Associates International Inc. said today that it had reorganized its Japanese operations and formed a new subsidiary, CA-Japan. Computer Associates, a software developer based in Islandia, said that its Cheyenne Japan division operations had been merged with those of CA-Japan. The A.C.A. Company, its venture with K. K. Ashisuto of Tokyo, was dissolved, with Ashisuto becoming the exclusive distributor of CA software in Japan, a Computer Associates spokesman said. CA-Japan will provide software and support directly to end-users and market its software through Cheyenne's reseller network, the company said.

title: The Carrot Connection
description: Perhaps the jury is still out. It's easy enough to demonize cigarettes and to think of the tobacco industry as the savviest promoter of agonizing death on the planet. But, hey, tobacco executives have the right to be heard. And after listening to them closely, one has to ask, in all fairness: Is applesauce dangerous to your health? Is the ordinary carrot addictive?

title: VESTA INSURANCE BUYS TWO SUBSIDIARIES FROM ANTHEM
description: Vesta Insurance Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the two main operating subsidiaries of Anthem Casualty Insurance Group Inc. for $238.8 million. Anthem Casualty, of Shelby, Ohio, sells insurance through about 1,500 independent agents in the Midwest and Middle Atlantic states. Anthem Casualty's business consists mostly of auto and homeowners' insurance sold in small towns and suburbs. Under the deal, Vesta, an insurance holding company based in Birmingham, Ala., will buy the Anthem Casualty Insurance Company and the Shelby Insurance Company, which have a combined $275 million in annualized premiums. Anthem Casualty is owned by Anthem Inc., an Indianapolis-based health management company.

title: Iomega Expands Ties To Euro RSCG Unit
description: The Iomega Corporation, a personal computer storage company, said yesterday that it had further expanded its relationship with the Euro RSCG unit of Havas Advertising by awarding that agency responsibilities for the European and Asian-Pacific markets.

title: Banks Putting Out Welcome Mat for Developers of Rental Buildings
description: With rental prices soaring and the sales market steady, banks in recent months have begun writing loans for new residential projects, a practice they had all but given up during the recession in the early 1990's.

title: Elevator Inspectors Indicted in Bribery
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday announced the indictment of 11 New York City elevator inspectors, including three top supervisors, who officials said extorted bribes in a pattern of ''pervasive corruption'' that infected all levels of the department for at least 15 years.

title: Suspicious Package Prompts 8-Hour Vigil at B'nai B'rith
description: The Fire Department sealed off the world headquarters of B'nai B'rith for eight hours today, with 108 people inside, after a mail room employee noticed a foul odor emanating from an envelope marked ''anthrachs,'' a misspelling apparently referring to an often fatal bacterium.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about sponsorship of a bill to extend Medicaid for children misstated the given name of Senator Kennedy of Massachusetts. He is Edward, not Theodore.

description: Ernest Hemingway's ''Spanish Earth'' is among 13 films to be shown in ''For Whom the Bell Tolls: Reverberations From the Spanish Civil War,'' a weeklong series that opens today at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center. The series, which honors survivors of the Spanish Civil War and observes the 60th anniversary of the war's beginning, will also include films by Carlos Saura, Ken Loach, Alain Resnais and Andre Malraux. Information: (212) 875-5600.

title: A Mistreated Dog and a Boy With a Mission
description: It's not immediately clear why an 11-year-old boy who is practically an animal-rights activist is carrying a hunting rifle when he meets a little runaway beagle on a bridge, but there he is. The bridge, in timeless small-town West Virginia, looks as if Andy and Opie might be crossing it any second now, fishing poles in tow. The beagle, who has fled because his hunter-owner kicked and hit him, is the title character of Dale Rosenbloom's new film, ''Shiloh.''

title: Restaurants
description: When Seryna opened 13 years ago, Japanese food still seemed exotic to many New Yorkers, and the idea of cooking steak on hot rocks at the table was something of a thrill. These days, however, sushi seems like a perfectly ordinary introduction to a plate of filet mignon, and the staid Japanese restaurant on East 53d Street seems like little more than an upscale ethnic steakhouse.

title: In China, a Spectacular Trove Of Dinosaur Fossils Is Found
description: An international team of paleontologists announced today that a fabulous trove of dinosaur fossils had been discovered in a remote region of northeast China. Hundreds of major finds at the site include the first fossilized internal organs of dinosaurs ever seen, and the first fossil of a dinosaur containing a mammal it had just eaten.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the reunion of Dante Cordova, a former hostage in Peru, with his relatives misstated the day of the picture. It was taken late Tuesday, the day he was rescued, not on Wednesday.

description: The American Express Company said yesterday that earnings rose about 15 percent in the first quarter from increased business in its charge and credit cards and record sales in mutual funds.

title: Fed Official's Speech Raises Anxiety as Bond Prices Fall
description: The prices of Government securities fell yesterday as worrisome economic data hinted that a blizzard of key reports next week might encourage the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.

title: Being Smart Isn't, Like, Everything
description: Romy (Mira Sorvino) and Michele (Lisa Kudrow) are the bimbo Bill and Ted, two lovable dimwits gliding hilariously backward in time. They travel only 10 years and just do it in their daydreams, but that's still enough to turn the candy-colored ''Romy and Michele's High School Reunion'' into cheerful, giddy fun. The film never lets its audience forget that it's possible to be as dopey as these sweetly bird-brained heroines without also being pretty smart.

title: Book Burning That Worked
description: Chances are excellent that not one person in a thousand could identify the second-most-quoted writer in English, after Shakespeare. He is William Tyndale (1494-1536), and there is good reason for his obscurity. Not only were the books he published burned, but so was Tyndale, for the offense of rendering the Bible into English from its original Greek and Hebrew. Nearly all the oft-quoted phrases from the King James Authorized Version of the Scriptures in 1611 were first translated by Tyndale, for which he received scant credit, then or now.

title: Far Out in Front in British Polls, Labor Party Still Runs Scared
description: The Labor Party's campaign to end 18 years of Conservative rule in Britain entered its final week today with party leaders determined to prevent a replay of five years ago, when Labor'scommanding lead in the polls evaporated in just a few days.

title: Trial Begins in the Oklahoma City Bombing Case
description: Two years after the bombing of the Federal Building in Oklahoma City and the killing of 168 people there, the Government opened its case against Timothy J. McVeigh today by portraying him as a man who wanted to use violence to incite a second American Revolution.

title: Prosecutors Find Irregularities but No Crimes in City Contracts With Private Agency
description: Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they would not bring criminal charges against city officials who oversaw the bidding on $43 million in welfare contracts in 1995, but they also said that they had uncovered evidence of irregularities in the city's contracting process.

title: HUD Suspends Lax Landlord Of Thousands
description: A California businessman described by Federal housing officials as one of the country's worst landlords of properties for low-income residents was suspended today from doing business with the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Troubling Portents in Zaire
description: Laurent Kabila, the rebel leader who may soon be Zaire's new master, promises to end the manipulation of ethnic hatreds by President Mobutu Sese Seko for the past three decades. But a campaign of starvation and violence against Hutu refugees in the area of Zaire now under Mr. Kabila's control runs counter to that promise.

title: In a Trice, Orchestra Transmutes
description: If Hans Vonk and the members of the St. Louis Symphony are not yet celebrating their mutual good fortune, they should start. The Dutch conductor and new music director in St. Louis has long been busy with Europe's orchestras, but one doubts he has ever had firmly in his hands a group of this accomplishment.

title: A Rough Life in Harlem Made Rougher in Central Park
description: There's a scene early in Seth Zvi Rosenfeld's film ''A Brother's Kiss'' that captures the cramped desperation of inner-city life with an acuity that is all the more remarkable for its quietness and attention to every squalid coffee-stained detail. In an East Harlem tenement apartment, two young boys coax their mother into repeating a cherished family ritual, a game of Scrabble that requires elaborate preparation. While their mother makes herself up and dresses as though she were going on a date, her sons excitedly fix the evening's party drinks, a martini for Mom, and Kool-Aid for themselves. Once the game begins on a battered old Scrabble set, the boy who goes first puts out the letters for ''rhythm,'' which his competitors insist couldn't be spelled that way.

title: Vaccine Offers Hopec For Infections Of the Bladder
description: A vaccine to prevent urinary tract infections has proved successful in mice and holds promise for people, researchers are reporting today in the journal Science. The advance is also expected to lead to vaccines for other common infections.

title: Review Narrowed At Ameritech
description: The Ameritech Corporation has narrowed a review on its consumer, corporate and small-business accounts, with billings estimated at more than $100 million, to 5 agencies from 10.

title: CORRECTIONS CORPORATION TO SELL 9 PRISONS
description: The Corrections Corporation of America said yesterday that it had agreed to sell nine of its correctional and detention centers to CCA Prison Realty Trust for $308 million. Corrections Corporation manages prisons and detention centers for governmental agencies. CCA Prison Realty Trust is a newly formed real estate investment trust. The companies are based in Nashville. Under the agreement, CCA Prison Realty Trust will receive the right to buy five more properties from Corrections Corporation for $193 million. Corrections Corporation will continue to manage the properties. CCA plans an offering of 17 million common shares to pay for the purchase. Shares of Corrections Corporation climbed $1.25, to to $30.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Queens Man Accused Of Raping Stepdaughter
description: A Queens man has been charged with repeatedly raping his 14-year-old stepdaughter over the last three years, and law enforcement officials said yesterday that he may be the father of her 14-month old child.

title: Peru Hears Report Some Rebels Were Slain Trying to Surrender
description: As accusations mounted that some rebels may have been killed trying to surrender during Tuesday's successful hostage rescue, the Government refused to allow relatives of the 14 slain guerrillas to hold funerals for their dead and said most of the bodies would be buried in unmarked graves.

title: Good Guys Are a Feast, Bad Guys A Famine
description: At an extravagant outdoor banquet in a Georgian vineyard, a man and woman dangling bunches of luscious grapes in each other's faces exchange a lingering kiss that the harvest they're holding in their hands discreetly conceals from view. Love, wine and acres of scrumptious food: Nana Djordjadze's film ''A Chef in Love'' is a voluptuous celebration of abundance set in the former Soviet republic of Georgia, mostly during the early 1920's. If you haven't eaten dinner before seeing the film, be sure you have a reservation at a favorite restaurant afterward, because the procession of dishes is mouth-watering.

title: Disney Combines Video Divisions
description: The Walt Disney Company said today that it had combined its American home video division, Buena Vista Home Video, and its international counterpart into a single business unit.

title: Tension Rising, Attorneys General Are to Meet on Tobacco Suit
description: As friction grows among some state attorneys general who are suing cigarette companies, top law-enforcement officials from states involved in the landmark settlement talks are expected to gather on Monday in Chicago to plot strategy and iron out differences.

title: U.S. Officials Link Klan Faction to 1 of 4 People Held in Texas Bomb Plot
description: At least one of the four people arrested on Tuesday in a plot to blow up a gas plant in North Texas had ties to a branch of the Ku Klux Klan, Federal officials and the local sheriff said today.

title: Restaurant Faces Bias Suit For Barring Man in Turban
description: El Quijote Restaurant is the kind of place where the stiff leather booths are as red as the shrimp diablo, cocktails are served with tiny paper umbrellas and male patrons are required to remove their hats before dining. That is the way it has been since the restaurant opened in 1930, but now that policy on hats has embroiled El Quijote in a Federal discrimination lawsuit.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: CIRQUE CORP., Salt Lake City, named Thomas B. Quarton president and chief operating officer.

title: Congressional Leaders Are More Optimistic About Budget Talks
description: Congressional leaders said today that they were increasingly optimistic about reaching a deal in the next few weeks to balance the Federal budget, as they moved toward concrete give and take on their competing tax and spending proposals.

title: New Yorker's 800 in Relay Leads Villanova to Victory
description: At the 1996 Penn Relays, Villanova failed to win a single women's relay race for the first time in a decade. ''Don't worry,'' Tamieka Grizzle told her future teammates after they had lost last year's distance medley. ''We'll win next year.''

title: Top French AIDS Specialist Will Move to Queens College
description: Professor Luc Montagnier, co-discoverer of the AIDS virus and one of Europe's most eminent scientists, has announced that he intends to move the home base for much of his research from the Pasteur Institute in Paris to Queens College, part of the City University of New York.

title: No Evidence of Abuse Is Found At City-Run Shelter for Women
description: Two months after the entire staff of a city-run shelter for battered women was removed amid allegations of sexual misconduct, child abuse and other wrongdoing, investigators have found no evidence so far to support the most serious charges, the head of New York City's social service agency said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's support among Hispanic New Yorkers misstated the scope of a recent poll conducted by The Times about the mayoral election and misstated the margin of sampling error for the 323 Hispanic respondents. The chart reflected the feelings of all Hispanic respondents, not just likely voters; the margin was plus or minus 5 percentage points, not 3.

title: INSIDE METRO
description: BIAS LAWSUIT -- A Princeton University professor is suing a Manhattan restaurant for refusing to serve him last spring because he would not take off his turban. B2.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALINT, GEORGE, M.D.
description: BALINT-George, M.D. 72., Physician, internist and anesthesiologist for 47 years, died at New York Hospital April 24, 1997. Dr. Balint devotedly cared for his more than eighty-thousand patients during his lifetime. As a young doctor he worked at the Peterffy Hospital in Budapest, Hungary and at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Attendorn, Germany. In New York City he served at New York University and V.A. Hospital, The Hospital for Special Surgery-Cornell Medical College and at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. Dr. Balint was a charitable human being, a cultured man with great integrity and dignity. He enjoyed music, the fine arts and appreciated the company of his loyal colleagues and friends. He trusted and was grateful to his own caring physicians and medical associates, nurses, throughout his illness until the end of his life. Maria, beloved wife of 37 years, is mourning him. He is survived by his aunt, Nelly Szasz, Budapest, Hungary, his late brother's widow and her daughter Eva Balint of Los Angeles, and Agnes Liebhardt of California. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in the memory of Dr. Balint to Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Department of Anesthesiology and/ or Department of Surgery, 1 Gustave L. Levy Place, New York, New York 10029-6574.

title: The High Cost of Justice for All
description: I recently presided over a long and complex trial in Queens that reflects how high the cost of justice for illegal immigrants has become. Three individuals, all here illegally, were found guilty of kidnapping and of more than a dozen rapes of one victim who was held hostage, blindfolded and in leg shackles for 10 days. This trial, which cost more than $1 million, was an enormous drain on public funds and court personnel.

title: How Peruvian Hostage Crisis Became Trip Into the Surreal
description: Minutes after explosions and gunfire erupted at the Japanese Ambassador's residence in December, the cream of Peruvian society cowered under pianos and coffee tables. From the bathrooms came a chorus of flushing toilets as diplomats, military and government officials flushed away their identity papers.

title: XEROX TO BUY REMAINING STAKE IN DELPHAX SYSTEMS
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the rest of Delphax Systems for an undisclosed price to gain access to its high-speed electronic printing technology. Xerox, which owns one-third of Delphax, of Canton, Mass., said it would buy the remaining stake from the Avery Dennison Corporation of Pasadena, Calif., and the Olympus Corporation of America, a unit of the Olympus Optical Company Ltd. of Tokyo. Delphax, which has annual revenue of about $60 million compared with Xerox's $17.4 billion, will be operated as a Xerox unit. No cuts in its 335-member work force are expected, the companies said. Xerox shares fell 87.5 cents, to $58.50, while Avery Dennison lost 50 cents a share, to $35.125.

title: Pataki Hits the California Trail
description: Gov. George E. Pataki will spend the weekend in California attending private events to raise money for next year's gubernatorial campaign, but his aides refused today to disclose any details about the events.

title: Japanese Take Back Mansion, Ending Hostage Saga
description: President Alberto K. Fujimori turned over the burned-out residence of the Japanese Ambassador to Japan's Foreign Minister today, bringing a formal close to the saga that began when Marxist guerrillas seized the mansion on Dec. 17. The last hostages were freed on Tuesday when Peruvian commandos stormed the building.

title: Volunteers: Pro and Con
description: When the last of the limousines leaves Independence Hall in Philadelphia next week, after a three-day ''summit'' that will bring together President Clinton, three former Presidents, 30 governors and dozens of corporate executives to praise and promote volunteer work, one impudent question may remain:

title: A More Intimate Volunteerism
description: The Presidential conference on volunteerism that starts tomorrow in Philadelphia does not need to instill a charitable spirit in Americans. They already possess it. Come a catastrophe, like the recent floods in North Dakota, and Americans turn out in droves to place sandbags and help victims. Millions of Americans routinely supervise recess at their local schools or clear trash from their local parks. Over 90 million of them contribute a startling 20 billion hours a year of voluntary service.

title: Messier Finishes Off What Gretzky Started
description: The Panthers, last year's Stanley Cup finalists, were backed into a corner in the very first round this year. They had their teeth bared and their hackles raised tonight at Miami Arena.

description: GOODMAN-Charles. 4/26/92. Dear Dad, five years have gone like a day. We think about you always. Love, Leon, Joan, Andrew, and Leslie

title: Abe Feder, Master of Lighting in All Its Forms, Dies at 87
description: Abe Feder, who in a lifetime devoted to the art of illumination virtually created the field of theatrical lighting design and was also a seminal figure in architectural lighting, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Accused of Posing as Bishop
description: A man posing as a bishop sold bogus diplomas and fake marriage annulments, sometimes doing business right out of his car, the authorities told The Associated Press. The man, Paul Stoms, 47, of Pemberton, was arrested this week and charged with theft by deception and falsely identifying himself as a representative of the church, said Michael E. Riley, the first assistant Burlington County prosecutor. He faces up to five years in prison if convicted. At least 40 people were duped during the three-year scheme, and some paid as much as $500 for false documents, Mr. Riley said.

title: A Healthy Apology
description: There were some unexpected positive lessons in the self-inflicted humiliation of Fuzzy Zoeller. First, Kmart acted swiftly and effectively in canceling Mr. Zoeller's promotional contract following the veteran golfer's racial remarks about Tiger Woods, the first minority golfer to win the Masters tournament in Augusta.

title: WESTERN WIRELESS IN A $202 MILLION CELLULAR DEAL
description: The Western Wireless Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Triad Cellular Corporation for $202.6 million. Western Wireless, based in Issaquah, Wash., would pay $184.8 million in cash and 1.6 million common shares valued at $17.8 million. It would acquire 12 rural service area licenses in Texas, Oklahoma, Utah and Minnesota, serving nearly 51,000 subscribers. The venture capital group Media/Communications Partners, of Boston, owns a majority interest in Triad, which is based in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Russia's New Capitalist Tool
description: A recent uproar over editorial meddling by a major stockholder at the newspaper Izvestia is just the latest example of conflicts in Russia between the media and the corporate conglomerates that are buying them up.

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's oldest bridge organizations is in New York City. Few players have ever heard of it.

title: A 2nd Pipeline, This One for Gas, Gains Support
description: Not so long back in Alaskan history, there was a golden period known as ''the pipeline.''

The performers are to include Eiko and Koma, Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane and Company and Susan Marshall and Company. Tickets range in price from $150 to $2,500. Information: (212) 674-8112.

title: 163 Workers Let Go After Loss at Casino
description: The Casino Magic Corporation said today that it had dismissed 163 people at its recently opened casino in Bossier City after posting a loss of $700,000 in the first quarter.

title: South Korea Leader's Son Admits No Wrong but Expresses Regret
description: A corruption scandal encircling President Kim Young Sam tightened a bit on Friday when his son testified before Parliament, firmly denying allegations of influence-peddling but breaking into tears at claims that his behavior had helped ruin his father's reputation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFEO, PHILIP L.

Respected and beloved uncle, friend and benefactor to Teresa M. McTague and Philip Stahlman and their family and Thomas J. McTague. Served proudly in the U.S. Navy in WWII. Salesman extraordinaire for twenty-seven years for American Bank Note Company. Phil was a mentor to the younger salesmen who worked with him and was respected by his colleagues. He was a handsome, charming and intelligent man who was admired by all who knew him. He endured his long illness with grace, dignity and humor. It was a pleasure and honor to know him. He will be missed but not forgotten. Visiting Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, McLaughlin & Sons, Third Avenue at 97 Street, Brooklyn. Interment Monday, 10:30AM, Maple Grove Cemetery.

title: Drug Suspect Is Extradited
description: After four years as a fugitive and three more fighting extradition from Jamaica, a man accused of leading a Jamaican drug-trafficking gang has been returned to the United States to stand trial on Federal drug and murder charges, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Promoting Puerto Rico Trade
description: In an effort to increase exports to Puerto Rico, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday announced the formation of a joint committee to promote trade between New Jersey and the island commonwealth, where she was visiting. New Jersey exports about $230 million in goods annually to Puerto Rico, the state's largest trading partner in the Caribbean. Still, the state imports more from the island than it exports, and Governor Whitman, speaking from San Juan, called the trade relationship ''a little bit unbalanced.''

title: Woman Led Police to Suspect in Pizza Murders, Court Papers Say
description: A tip from a woman led detectives to one of the two teen-agers accused of ambushing and murdering two pizza deliverymen outside an abandoned house on a desolate country road on Saturday night, court papers filed today said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP., Houston, named Robert M. Devlin, chief executive, to the additional post of chairman. Mr. Devlin will give up the post of president, which will be assumed by James S. D'Agostino Jr., now chairman of one of the insurance units.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERESEY, CORNELIA FRANCES
description: KERESEY-Cornelia Frances, of Houston, passed away, Wednesday, April 23, 1997. She was born November 20, 1928 in New York, New York, to Henry D. and Mary F. Keresey. She was a graduate of Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, NY and a member of the Vassar Club, and also a faithful member of Christ Church Cathedral in Houston and Church of the Epiphany in New York. She gave unstintingly of her time and energy in Ministry to the homeless of New York City. She is survived by her four sons: Richard Kellogg and wife Jan, Montgomery Kellogg and wife Jeanette, Donn Kellogg and Michael Kellogg; one sister, Mary Edmonson; two brothers, Donn Keresey and Michael Keresey; six grandchildren, Clark, Winnie, Taylor, Tristin, Catherine and Elizabeth; she is the granddaughter of Cornelius F. Kelly; a number of nieces and nephews and other loving relatives. Family will be present to receive friends on Tuesday evening, April 29, 1997 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, NY from 6PM until 8PM. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, April 30, 1997 at 11:00AM at the Church of the Epiphany, 1393 York Avenue, NY with the Rev. Dorsey McConnell officiating. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Valhalla, New York. A memorial service in Houston is pending.

title: One Appointee Is Considered For Health Jobs
description: The director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. David Satcher, is the leading candidate to be appointed both Surgeon General and Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services, Clinton Administration officials said today.

title: Hundreds Protest in Harlem, Saying a Death Wasn't Suicide
description: A day after the police said a woman jumped 18 stories to her death in East Harlem, several hundred people gathered for a protest yesterday, saying that they did not believe the death was a suicide.

title: Big Hits Can't Stop Hilliard's Big Plays
description: So much has been made of Ike Hilliard's good hands. His speed. His ability to zing a defense after he makes a big catch. What has been left out is that he has the toughness of concrete.

title: The English Impatient
description: John Major peered at leather swatches in teal, oatmeal, cream, coffee and warm charcoal.

title: Accelerator to Miss Derby After Breaking His Ankle
description: The Kentucky Derby lost another contender today when Ogden Mills Phipps's colt Accelerator suffered a fractured bone in his left front ankle while working out at Churchill Downs and was withdrawn from training for two months.

title: Train Service Is Disrupted
description: A section of electrical wires powering trains between Newark and New York City collapsed Friday afternoon, disrupting rush-hour service for 21,000 commuters, officials said. The wires for two tracks used by New Jersey Transit and Amtrak collapsed near Secaucus shortly after noon and were repaired at 4:30 P.M., but delays of 30 minutes to an hour continued into the evening because of reduced train speeds, officials said. Construction on an access road near the tracks in Secaucus shook a foundation that holds a pole supporting the electrical wires, and caused the wires to come down onto the tracks, an Amtrak spokeswoman said.

title: From Militias To 'Dragnet' To Prevention
description: Tomorrow brings a short course on America's police forces, with attention to corruption, brutality, inefficiency and, lately, sense and sensibility.

title: Understaffed Mets Struggle
description: Passing by the lineup card in the Mets' clubhouse this afternoon, Rey Ordonez stopped and did a double-take. No Lance Johnson. No Todd Hundley. No Bernard Gilkey.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN TO SELL A FABRICS UNIT FOR $310 MILLION
description: The Collins & Aikman Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its flat-woven upholstery fabrics unit, Mastercraft Group, to the Joan Fabrics Corporation for $310 million. Collins & Aikman, of Charlotte, N.C., said it was selling the unit to focus on manufacturing automotive supplies and would use proceeds from the sale to reduce debt. Mastercraft had $264 million in revenues for the 11 months ended Dec. 28. Joan Fabrics, a privately held business, makes automobile interiors, contract systems and home furnishings, with factories in Massachusetts and North Carolina.

title: Starks Finds That Less Means More
description: JOHN STARKS'S epiphany occurred one day last summer after the Knicks had signed Allan Houston to be their starting shooting guard. Starks got into his car and drove to Dave Checketts's house.

title: At Bomb Trial, Tearful Stories Of Terrible Day
description: A few minutes before 9 A.M. on April 19, 1995, Capt. Michael Norfleet of the Marines drove up to the Federal Building in Oklahoma City. ''This is my lucky day,'' Captain Norfleet said to himself. ''All the parking spaces are open.'' He parked his pickup in front of a Ryder truck by the front door and walked inside. Moments later, a giant blast tore through the building and changed his life forever.

title: F.D.R.'s Progressive Spirit Is Vote for Wheelchair
description: To the Editor:

title: North Dakota Flood Blights Senior Year's Precious Times
description: During one of the eight blizzards that punished North Dakota this winter and spring, Katie Stinar, 18, shivered on her way from church one Sunday morning to an icy car.

title: Books and Company on East Side to Close Down
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art, acting as landlord, yesterday rejected a last-minute effort to save Books and Company, sealing the fate of the Upper East Side bookstore that some New York intellectuals consider the city's best because of its eclectic offerings and home-away-from-home atmosphere.

title: Ignoring U.S., France Signs Accord Protecting Cuba Ties
description: France signed an agreement today protecting the interests of French companies that invest in Cuba, brushing off mild American criticism of the accord.

title: HFS Ends Deal for Value Rent-A-Car
description: HFS Inc. said today that it had canceled its agreement to buy Value Rent-A-Car from Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America Inc. for $175 million in cash.

title: MetroStars Short-Handed
description: The MetroStars have lost four of their first five Major League Soccer games this season, but that is not their only problem. Getting all their stars onto the same field at the same time has been quite a challenge, too.

description: When Women Onstage

description: FREEMAN-Dorothy. Mrs. Freeman was a most generous supporter of the Institute in very difficult times. We will miss her. Joann Gerardi, Ph.D., President Jeffrey Rubin, M.D., Dean

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KREIZVOGEL, FRANCES
description: KREIZVOGEL-Frances. Devoted wife of the late Henry. Loving mother of Joyce Weil and Martin Kreston. Grandmother of Elise, Edward, Mark and Rebecca. Great-grandmother of Andrew, Stephanie, Samantha, Ryan and Connor. Service 11AM at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

title: In Pursuit Of a Definition Of Justice
description: THREE women recently strolled along 125th Street searching for justice. The pulsing, screeching beats of Public Enemy's raps provided an urgent soundtrack from a passing car. The beaten-down looks of some buildings on the side streets offered little encouragement. Nor did the sight of one man's cardboard-box home tucked into the entrance of an abandoned office building.

title: New Yorkers, Ever Critical, Say City Is Cleaner
description: To the Editor:

description: ROFFE-Hyman. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Also survived by his sisters, Gladys and Belle. Funeral services on Sunday, at 11:30, at Temple Israel of New Rochelle.

title: U.S. Pressing To Deport Man Tied to I.R.A.
description: Immigration officials said yesterday that they would appeal a judge's verdict allowing a former member of the Irish Republican Army who now lives in Rockland County to remain in the United States despite his role in a 1975 attack on a police barracks in Northern Ireland.

title: Pat Paulsen, 69, a Parodist Of Presidential Doubletalk
description: Pat Paulsen, the mournful-looking comedian who ran five tongue-in-cheek races for the Presidency, died yesterday in Tijuana, Mexico. He was 69 and lived in Tujunga, Calif.

title: 'Oedipus,' With Tears And Chimes
description: Harry Partch's vision of total musical theater surely did not include singer-actors reading from the book and decorous wafts of ritual. He wanted vividness. He wanted intoxication. His one-man dispute with Western culture was rooted in a dismissal of anything learned or abstract. He looked to the musical cultures of ancient China and Greece, in which sound, display, word and gesture were welded and magically potent. He spoke of the ''emotional saturation, or transcendence, that it is the particular province of dramatic music to achieve.'' He was a hobo Antonin Artaud.

title: Harnisch Says He Is Being Treated for Depression
description: Speaking publicly for the first time since leaving the Mets on April 6, Pete Harnisch revealed tonight what ails him: ''I'd just like to let everybody know I've been diagnosed with depression.''

title: $122 MILLION VENTURE FORMED FOR SALVESEN WAREHOUSES
description: The Hunt Financial Corporation said yesterday that it and Security Capital Industrial Trust of Denver had formed a new corporation, CS Integrated LLC, to acquire the North American refrigerated operations of Christian Salvesen Inc., the British food distributor, for $122.4 million. Hunt Financial, a private company based in Dallas, said the deal included 17 warehouses throughout the United States.

title: CUNY President Is Re-elected in Heavy Vote
description: In the first contested election in 20 years, the faculty and staff union of the City University of New York re-elected Irwin Polishook, the 62-year-old president, and his Unity Caucus.

title: The Knicks, to Prevail, Must Play Their Game
description: It seemed as if Coach Jeff Van Gundy were stripping the shine off Thursday night's victory in Game 1 of the playoffs, all but popping the party balloons with this sharp reality: The Knicks cannot continue to beat the Charlotte Hornets with fancy perimeter shooting.

title: Reno Names 2 to Shape Up Citizenship Process
description: Exasperated with the Immigration and Naturalization Service's handling of the nation's citizenship process, the Justice Department today assigned one of its top troubleshooters and a former Comptroller General to straighten out the program.

title: Tail Flaw Is Found In More Helicopters
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the grounding of all 132 helicopters of the model that crashed into the East River last week, killing a passenger.

title: With 'Smaller' Proposals, Clinton Basks in Friendly Press Coverage
description: Some of Bill Clinton's little proposals have big significance after all, judging from the attention news organizations are now paying to the same ideas they played down and even dismissed as bite-size in the 1996 campaign.

title: JUDGE RULES F.D.A. HAS RIGHT TO CURB TOBACCO AS DRUG
description: A Federal district judge in North Carolina today upheld the Food and Drug Administration's power to regulate tobacco as a drug, but he said the agency lacked the authority to control advertising intended for youths.

title: No Investigation of Trump
description: The State Division of Gaming Enforcement will not investigate whether Donald J. Trump's efforts to block construction of a $330 million tunnel in Atlantic City are illegal, the Attorney General's office said this week. Mr. Trump filed a lawsuit in February to stop the tunnel, which would connect the Atlantic City Expressway with the marina district, where Stephen A. Wynn, a Trump competitor, plans to build 7,000 hotel rooms and three casinos. Jeffrey J. Miller, an assistant attorney general, said that state officials had directed the agency not to pursue an investigation of Mr. Trump, because Mr. Trump's lawsuit is still pending in Federal court. On Tuesday, the Casino Redevelopment Authority charged that Mr. Trump's suit violated a state law intended to preserve competition among casinos.

title: New Factory Resets Sights Of Chrysler on South America
description: The Chrysler Corporation today opened its first new assembly plant in an emerging market since 1965, one of a series of steps Chrysler is taking to return to international markets that it abandoned in its brush with bankruptcy in the late 1970's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLEYER, MARJORIE B.
description: BLEYER-Marjorie B. The Women's Auxiliary of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sadness the death of our esteemed Honorary Board Member, Marjorie B. Bleyer, and express deep sympathy to her family. Eve Haberman, President Sivia Brodsky, Rec. Secretary

title: COLUMBIA/HCA BUYS STAKE IN A HOSPITAL IN BARCELONA
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that it had bought a 54 percent stake in Instituto Dexeus, a 110-bed hospital in Barcelona, Spain. Terms were not disclosed. Columbia, based in Nashville, said Instituto Dexeus is one of two private hospitals affiliated with Universidad Autonoma de Barcelona and is recognized for its research and teaching. Columbia said it would seek other opportunities to develop a network in Spain. It operates 344 hospitals, 147 surgery centers and 560 home health care centers in the United States, Britain and Switzerland. Its shares fell 87.5 cents, to $34.125.

description: To the Editor:

title: Aces and Duffers Alike Dream of U.S. Open on a Course in Bethpage
description: With only a year of golf experience under his belt, Jeffrey Brooks shrugged off the sign on the first tee of the Black Course at Bethpage State Park warning all but the most advanced golfers to stay away.

title: Military Pilot Went Down With Plane, Air Force Says
description: The pilot of the A-10 Thunderbolt that crashed in the Colorado Rockies three weeks ago apparently went down with the plane, Air Force officials said today.

title: Rutgers Gets Greer
description: In his first successful recruiting effort as the new head coach at Rutgers, KEVIN BANNON announced yesterday that JEFF GREER of Cardinal Hayes High School in the Bronx would attend the New Jersey college.

Loving step-mother of Jill Rick and caring mother-in-law of Jill. Adored grandmother of Michael, James and Valerie Hepner and Zachary and Kiva Iscol. Loving sister of Ethel Harr, Burt Weston and the late Chester Weinstein.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the Zeppelin company's plans to make its first zeppelin since the Hindenburg crash of 1937 referred incorrectly to its founder, Count Ferdinand von Zeppelin. He died in 1917, long before the crash, and was thus not involved in the company's later diversification.

title: Trade Data Confirmed: $10.4 Billion February Gap
description: Corrected figures released by the Commerce Department today confirmed that the trade deficit declined to $10.4 billion in February, narrower than initially estimated.

title: Man Shot on Empire State Walks Back Toward Life
description: Walking without assistance out of the same emergency room doors he entered two months earlier, Matthew Gross, the young musician who was shot in the head and critically injured atop the Empire State Building, was discharged from Bellevue Hospital Center in Manhattan yesterday and admitted to a rehabilitation center in New Jersey.

title: GTE Leaving Prime Space In Stamford
description: GTE Corporation, one of the first Fortune 500 companies to move its headquarters to downtown Stamford in the early 1970's and remake the city into a corporate center, announced today that it would move its headquarters to Dallas.

title: Higher Rates and Bad Weather Hurt Housing Resales in March
description: Home resales fell 2.8 percent in March as higher borrowing costs began to bite, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Yanks Deny Reported Offer
description: Stressing that the Yankees have not yet been given permission to negotiate with Hideki Irabu, the team's owner, George Steinbrenner, last night denied a report in The Daily News yesterday that the team had made a three-year, $12 million offer to the Japanese pitcher.

title: Shelters Investigated on Possible Mob Link
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani halted referrals of homeless people to a shelter in Brooklyn and another on Staten Island late yesterday amid mounting allegations that the shelters are connected to organized crime.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Whitewater counsel's request for an extension of the grand jury investigating the financial dealings of President Clinton and his wife omitted a word in paraphrasing the stated reason. The prosecutor, Kenneth Starr, said he needed more time to investigate evidence of ''possible obstruction of the administration of justice.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLON, FREDERICK E.M.
description: BALLON-Frederick E.M. Prominent attorney. On April 25, 1997. Beloved husband of Sydell (Swergin). Loving brother of Rhita Behrman. Devoted father of Lois Ballon and Geraldine Lipshie. Adoring grandfather and great grandfather. Servivces to be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Sunday, April 27 at 1:30 P.M. At the family's request contributions in his honor may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERESMAN, HELEN CHAFETS
description: MERESMAN-Helen Chafets. On April 25, 1997. Beloved wife of Harry Meresman for 60 years; devoted and cherished mother of Helaine Meresman Barnett and Victor Barnett and Janice Meresman Goldman and Michael Goldman; adored grandmother of Craig and Jennifer Barnett, Roger Barnett, Melissa Goldman, and Lori Goldman; loving sister of Henrietta and Alan Leiner, Selma and Bill Rafsky, and Emanuel Chafets; and loving aunt and great aunt to many nieces and nephews. A woman known for her remarkable beauty, grace, and intellect, she also had a special gift of language that turned conversations into poetry. Her devotion, guidance, and unconditional love helped to define every member of her family and everyone she touched. She remains uniquely loved and irreplaceable. Funeral services April 27, 1997, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 1:15 P.M.

title: Texaco Jazz Festival Announces 300 Events
description: The World Saxophone Quartet, the violinist Jean-Luc Ponty, Cyrus Chestnut and John Zorn are among the artists who are to take part in this year's Texaco New York Jazz Festival. Presented by the Knitting Factory, which announced the schedule yesterday, the festival is to run from June 16 to 30, featuring over 300 events, some in association with other arts presenters.

title: Letter Prompts Charges Against School Guard
description: The Board of Education is to file administrative charges on Monday seeking to dismiss a school safety officer for trying to initiate a romantic relationship with an 18-year-old female student, a board spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: SUPERVALU TO END ITS INVESTMENT IN SHOPKO STORES
description: Supervalu Inc., a food distributor in Minneapolis, said that it would sell its remaining 46 percent stake in Shopko Stores Inc., ending a 26-year investment in the discount retailer in a deal valued at about $270.3 million. Shopko, of Green Bay, Wis., agreed to buy back 8.17 million of its shares from Supervalu at $18.35 apiece. Then, Supervalu will sell its 6.56 million Shopko shares to the public if it can get at least $18.35 each. Shopko stock lost 25 cents a share, to $19.25; Supervalu also fell 25 cents, closing at $29.50. Supervalu, which began selling its Shopko shares in 1991, sought to sell its 46 percent stake in the planned merger of Shopko and Phar-Mor Inc., the drugstore chain. The deal fell through this month.

title: Leave A Little Unchiseled
description: Should the Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial include a sculpture of F.D.R. sitting in his wheelchair? Of course not. There should be no statue of Roosevelt in any position.

title: Hostile $631 Million Bid for Machine-Tool Maker
description: Harnischfeger Industries announced late yesterday that it was making a hostile $631 million bid for Giddings & Lewis Inc., a big maker of machine tools.

title: Driver Is Accused Of Chasing Youths
description: The leader of a Hasidic neighborhood patrol group in Crown Heights was arrested on charges of reckless endangerment, the police said yesterday, after he drove his car onto a sidewalk to chase a group of West Indian teen-agers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the use of DNA from a cat to gain a conviction in the murder of a Prince Edward Island woman, Shirley A. Duguay, misidentified her hometown. It was Summerside, not Sunnyside.

title: Blue Cross Merger Dropped
description: The planned merger of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield health insurance companies in New Jersey and Delaware collapsed this week because the firms could not complete the deal by a May 20 deadline, company executives said yesterday. The two arms of the giant nonprofit health insurer were supposed to have joined forces to create a $3 billion company with more than two million members under an agreement announced last May, but the plan faced legal and regulatory obstacles, said Fred Hillmann, a spokesman for New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield.

title: Hornets Not Panicking Yet
description: As the Charlotte Hornets prepared for this afternoon's playoff game, there were several things Coach Dave Cowens did not like.

title: Mitsubishi to Write Off American Auto Losses
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would write off 43.1 billion yen ($342 million) in losses from its American sales subsidiary, the latest blow to the company's troubled United States operations. The yen's strength in 1995 hurt sales overseas, forcing the company to become overly dependent on the less profitable leasing business, the auto maker said.

title: Magazine Settles Compuserve Suit
description: The Compuserve Corporation and Time Warner Inc.'s Time magazine settled a $3.5 million lawsuit filed against Compuserve after it dropped the magazine's on-line version from its service.

title: Leery Planners Slow Coliseum Competition
description: Wary of making the same mistakes that derailed earlier plans, state officials are markedly slowing the process of choosing a developer to build on the site of the New York Coliseum in Manhattan, a project that is intended to anchor a revived Columbus Circle.

Loving sister of Linda Clarke, Madeline Weinrich, Richard Owens III, and Connie Mavrogeanas. Dear aunt of five nieces and nephews. Family will receive friends Saturday 7-9PM, Sunday 24PM and 7-9PM at the William H. Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, New York. Mass Mon. 10am at The Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY.

title: Whiten Error Keeps Yankees Short of .500
description: The high-priced slugger finally blasted his first homer, the quirky player snapped at the umpires over balls and strikes and the left-handed pitcher was dominant when the Yankees and the White Sox clashed last night. Can you determine the winner from these hints?

title: In This Circus Ring, Six Fierce Pianos
description: The pianists who comprise the innovative contemporary music ensemble Piano Circus work as a collective, with no one in charge. But whoever came up with the name for the ensemble deserves some special status, because it perfectly describes what they do.

title: Bonds Lower Ahead of Next Week's Data
description: Prices in the Treasury market were depressed yesterday as a combination of factors led investors to sell -- fear that next week's economic statistics will be strong, a heavy supply of corporate and municipal debt and light volume.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, ESTHER
description: FOX - Esther. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Jack B. Levitt, President

title: Corrections
description: An art review yesterday about three Manhattan exhibitions of Indian works omitted the opening date for ''Gods, Kings and Tigers: The Art of Kotah,'' at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue (70th Street). It opens today.

title: Cuban Music Infiltrates Miami Exiles' Defenses
description: For one short month, listeners here who tuned in to WRTO-FM, known across South Florida as Tropical 98.3, had to pause for a reality check. The contagious rhythm coming from the radio sounded Cuban. Shockingly, it was: the station was playing Los Van Van, Cuba's most famous dance band.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-7

title: New Family Services Director
description: In a move aimed at stabilizing the state's troubled child welfare agency, the Commissioner of the State Department of Human Services yesterday named his deputy, Michele K. Guhl, to head the Division of Youth and Family Services. Commissioner William Waldman said that he was putting the department's second-highest-ranking official in charge of the agency until working conditions and morale improved for the agency's 1,113 caseworkers.

title: Down Obscure Corridors, In No Particular Direction
description: Directionless is an insult often applied to uninspired music. But at the sold-out double bill of Richard Buckner and Son Volt on Thursday night at Irving Plaza, directionlessness was a compliment and a goal, a feeling to be captured in the music. Both acts are alternative-minded traditionalists, mixing folk, country and rock and delivering lyrics from life's dark and confusing corridors in an opiated drawl. And both have also just released stark, meandering albums: Mr. Buckner, a San Francisco songwriter, came out with ''Devotion and Doubt'' (MCA). And Son Volt, one of two bands formed from the ashes of the important roots-rock outfit Uncle Tupelo (the other is Wilco), released ''Straightaways'' (Warner Brothers).

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALSEY, BETTY
description: WALSEY-Betty. We miss you and will always remember your tolerance and gentle spirit. Love, Milton, Elliot and Joan, Steven

title: Daiwa and Nikko Both Post Losses
description: The Daiwa Securities Company and the Nikko Securities Company of Japan both posted net losses yesterday for the fiscal year ended March 31 as a result of providing aid to financially troubled affiliated companies. Daiwa reported that its parent company loss totaled 84.02 billion yen ($666 million) in the fiscal year while its revenues were 3.3 percent lower at 291.8 billion yen and pretax profit was down 29 percent at 44.26 billion yen. The company took a charge of 120 billion yen to rescue its real estate loan subsidiary.

description: ROFFE-Hal. The Board of Governors and membership of Ridgeway Country Club offer their deepest condolences to Ruth Roffe and family upon the passing of Hal Roffe. Stanley Goldberg, President

title: Aide Denies Mayoral Politics Led to Ouster of Shelter Staff
description: A senior Giuliani administration official denied yesterday that politics had played a role in a decision by the administration in February to remove the entire staff at a city shelter for battered women where workers had been accused of misconduct.

title: British Airport Plan Results in BAA Charge
description: BAA P.L.C. the British airport operator, said yesterday that it would take a $:40 million ($65 million) charge in fiscal year 1997 because of accumulated interest from the costs of developing a fifth terminal at Heathrow Airport. BAA cited delays in approvals for the project, which has drawn fire from some residents.

title: Harrah's and Union at Odds Over Poison-Pill Vote Tally
description: A hotel workers' union said yesterday that it had won a shareholder vote removing an anti-takeover device at Harrah's Entertainment. But the casino company said that the resolution had failed, although it would not release the results.

title: No Headline
description: ''It seems like when people get older, and talk about their high school memories, they mostly remember the big things at the end of senior year. We won't have that. Our last days together were spent sandbagging.''

title: Young Miler Is Closing on 4 Minutes
description: It has been nearly 30 years since June 23, 1967, when Jim Ryun set a world record of 3 minutes 51.1 seconds in the mile on a dirt track in Bakersfield, Calif. The eighth-place finisher provided an impressive footnote to the race: Marty Liquori, a schoolboy from Cedar Grove, N.J., also limboed under four minutes, finishing in 3:59.8.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MADDEN, MATTHEW J.
description: MADDEN-Matthew J. Age 78, on April 24, 1997. Former Vice President and Treasurer of First Boston Corp, New York, NY. title: After the Draft, Jets Recruit Another 19 College Players
description: In a recruiting program as aggressive and bold as that of any college football power, the Jets have been courting dozens of players who were not selected in last weekend's National Football League draft.

title: Foreman Back In the Ring
description: George Foreman has fought just twice since he knocked out Michael Moorer in 1994. In his last fight, he waltzed around the ring for 12 rounds with Crawford Grimsley in Chiba, Japan, last Nov. 3 and won on a decision.

title: Lemaire Annoyed By Devils' Defeat
description: Only a smattering of Devils showed up for practice here today, less than 14 hours after their marathon in Montreal. Their teammates, still recovering from Thursday night's triple-overtime loss to the Canadiens, were home or at the team hotel, resting their aching bodies.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the main front-page article yesterday about the approval of the Chemical Weapons Convention referred incorrectly in some editions to the nation that used poison gas against its Kurdish citizens. It was Iraq, not Iran.

title: CBS-TV Drags Down Westinghouse Results
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it had a net loss in the first quarter and a wider loss from continuing operations as a poor performance at its CBS television unit more than offset strong results at its radio network.

title: Adding a Contemporary Ring to an Ancient Story
description: The Passover seder, the festive meal at which Jews tell again the story of the biblical Israelites' liberation from Egyptian bondage, provides ample space for both reflection and celebration. But while the particular story, drawn from the biblical book of Exodus, is fundamental to Jewish history, its themes of exile, slavery and freedom lend it a currency that allow groups and individuals to discover in it new levels of personal meaning.

title: Colombia's Subtle Censorship
description: In Colombia a state commission now rates television programs for objectivity, accuracy and social responsibility, and low ratings can mean the end of a TV license. Colombia's Constitutional Court is studying challenges to the law, which was passed in December. It should overturn this blatant act of censorship.

title: HERTZ STOCK RISES 15% ON FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: Shares of the Hertz Corporation, the car rental unit of the Ford Motor Company, rose 15 percent above their offering price in their first day of trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts credited the performance to Hertz's name recognition and the quality of the investment firm that managed the offering, J. P. Morgan Securities. More than $480 million was raised on the sale of 20.01 million shares late Thursday at $24 apiece, at the high end of the expected price range. The stock closed yesterday at $27.625. The sale of 20 million shares by Ford represented a 19 percent stake. Ford became sole owner of Hertz in 1994 after having bought a stake in the company in 1987.

title: Under the Probing Gaze Of the Egyptian Dead
description: The exhibition is called ''Ancient Faces,'' but it is easy to forget that the extraordinary mummy portraits currently on display at the British Museum were painted in Roman Egypt 1,900 years ago. They look so modern that some art historians have even compared them with Impressionist works of the late 19th century, which happens to coincide with their discovery by European explorers.

title: Clinton Looks to Republican As Ambassador to Mexico
description: In a gesture of bipartisanship, President Clinton is expected to nominate William F. Weld, the Governor of Massachusetts, to be Ambassador to Mexico, White House officials said today.

title: Indication of Buying by China Drives Up Prices of Soybeans
description: Soybean prices rose sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday on speculation that China had bought or was seeking to buy United States supplies this week.

title: Split Decision on Protecting Salmon in Oregon
description: In a divided Federal decision, coastal coho salmon that spawn in northern California and southern Oregon were designated today a threatened species under the Federal Endangered Species Act, while coastal coho in central and northern Oregon will receive state, but not Federal, protection.

title: Rebels Force 80,000 Hutu to Flee to Jungle
description: United Nations officials today accused Zairian rebels of trying to drive Hutu refugees to a slow death in the jungle. Aid workers who flew over refugee camps south of the Zairian city of Kisangani discovered that the number of people who had lived in the camps just days ago and had disappeared, presumably fleeing into the surrounding forest, had risen to more than 80,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELER, ANN DAY
description: WHEELER-Ann Day. On April 25th, 1997 at her home in Brookline, MA at age 45. Survived by her father Ira B. Wheeler, sister Dorothy W. Bacon, brother Timothy M. Wheeler, friend Michael J. Byrnes, nieces Katharine D. and Sarah H. Bacon, stepmother Mary T. Wheeler and stepbrothers Fletcher H., W. Walker and Clymer D. Bardsley. Also survived by too many friends to count. Ann was educated at Northfield Mt. Hermon School, Connecticut College, the University of Rochester and Yale University School of Management. She led a full life of service to the community, most recently as Director of the Center for Youth Development and Education at Bay State Skills Corp. Ann will be sorely missed. Burial will be held on Block Island, RI, where Ann summered for many years, on Sunday, April 27th. A memorial service will be held in Boston on May 3rd.

title: Clinton Warns Japan Leader On Trade Gap
description: President Clinton warned Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan today that a sudden resurgence of his country's trade surplus with the United States threatened to raise political tensions again over the slow pace at which Japan was opening its markets and deregulating its economy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FABER, DORA ''TOBY''
description: FABER-Dora ''Toby''. Born November 22, 1910, died April 25, 1997. Beloved wife of David. Mother of Stephen and Marilyn. Grandmother of Michelle, Rachel, Alyssa and Jeremy. Sister of Sylvia. An honor student, Toby worked for United Cerebral Palsy and, for many years, the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. She was possessed of an indomitable spirit and was a passionate lover of education, music and literature. She leaves a legacy of laughter and compassion for all humanity. Her memory is honored by all who loved her.

title: BOARD OF REGENTS IS URGED TO TEST IN FIVE LANGUAGES

title: OUTBOARD MARINE OMITS DIVIDEND AFTER $7.3 MILLION LOSS
description: The Outboard Marine Corporation said yesterday that it had omitted its dividend for the current quarter and hired Salomon Brothers for assistance after the loss of $7.3 million, or 36 cents a share, for its fiscal second quarter ended March 31. The loss by Outboard Marine, a maker of leisure boats and engines based in Waukegan, Ill., compared with earnings of $1.1 million, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue fell 17 percent, to $237 million from $285.5 million. The company said it had hired Salomon, the investment banker, to help ''explore strategic alternatives as a means of maximizing shareholder value'' and strengthening the capital base of the company. The company paid a dividend of 10 cents a share last quarter. Yesterday, its shares fell 25 cents, to $12.

description: Judge Upholds Drug Agency On Tobacco Regulation

title: Don Quixote Rides Again, With Retinue of Readers

That feisty, invaluable dance space was in danger of closing but was saved by the Joyce Theater, which bought it last year. Happily, the only major changes seem to be more comfortable seating and easier access for the disabled.

title: Missing Training Missiles Found Abandoned in Texas
description: After three days of searching, the Air Force said today that it had found four training missiles, all abandoned at a building supply store in a small West Texas town by the civilian tractor-trailer driver who had been hired to drive them from Georgia to New Mexico. The driver was arrested more than 300 miles away as he slept at a truck stop near the Louisiana state line.

description: Some people say nostalgia is the wave of the future. Others say it isn't what it used to be. title: Flaw Cited in Fatal Crash Had Been Found in 3 Other Copters
description: Three helicopters of the type that crashed in Manhattan last week, killing a passenger, had earlier been found to have cracks in their tails, the same flaw blamed in the accident. But the Federal Aviation Administration said it had not learned of those cracks until after last week's crash.

title: KELLOGG CO. (K,N)
description: The Kellogg Company said yesterday that earnings fell 22 percent in the first quarter, sharper than expected, as steep price cuts on breakfast cereals ate into revenue for the fourth consecutive quarter.

description: Whitbread P.L.C., the British hotel, food retailing and brewing group, said yesterday that it would sell 13 hotels to the Regal Hotel Group for $:64.5 million ($104.8 million).

description: In the 1950's, Burton N. Pugach was viewed by many as one of the most successful lawyers in the Bronx. Yesterday morning, Mr. Pugach -- six days past 70, his eyes looking tired behind thick orange-tinted glasses -- told six Queens jurors the most intimate details of what he last week called his ''stupid life.''

title: Swiss Union Bank Says Profits Gained
description: The Union Bank of Switzerland said yesterday that first-quarter earnings were ''considerably'' higher than a year earlier, bolstered by commission and trading income. The bank, which does not report quarterly figures, said ''practically no new provisions'' were necessary after last year's charge of 3 billion Swiss francs ($2 billion) to cover future loan losses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RABIN, WILLIAM M.
description: RABIN-William M. On Friday, April 25, 1997. Cherished husband of Frances Rabin. Devoted father of two, grandfather of seven, and great-grandfather of 3. Inventor of the modern ice cream sandwich, he was credited with inventing the first ice cream sandwich machine, which led to the popularization of the ice cream sandwich. He was the founder of Wafer Sales and spent over 50 years in the ice cream business. Services will be held Sunday at 12 noon, Wein & Wein Memorial Chapels, 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey.

title: Giving Birth at 63
description: The news that a 63-year-old California woman gave birth late last year has prompted calls to set a maximum age limit for women who receive treatment at fertility centers to get pregnant. While individual fertility centers can, and already do, set age limits, this is not an area that requires regulation or other government intervention. The decision on whether to undergo pregnancy after menopause should remain a private choice between a woman and her doctor, based on individual circumstances.

description: To understand some of what lies behind President Jacques Chirac's decision to risk his conservative Government's political future on early national elections, it helps to talk with Bernard Jorant, a 46-year-old long-distance truck driver who lives in Le Mans, in the heart of France.

title: Art and Science, the Yin and Yang of Culture
description: ART AND SCIENCE MAY BE THE original odd couple, but they have gone together for a very long time. During the Renaissance, when both were newly and heavily dependent on direct visual observation, a few men made real contributions in both realms. Brunelleschi invented linear, or one-point, perspective and engineered the huge dome that crowns the Cathedral of Florence. Leonardo da Vinci's scientific observations and engineering proposals still strike us as marvels.

title: A Bridgeport Neighborhood Beginning the Road Back1
description: ON a recent midweek evening, St. Charles Borromeo Church on the East Side of Bridgeport was the site of an Interfaith Service for Public Safety, a call by local clergy for action against violence, drugs and community decay. Indeed, in recent months a coalition of neighborhood groups and city agencies has made some gains in taking back control of the streets.

title: Remembering Jackie Robinson, the Golfer
description: THERE they were, two of the most famous black athletes of all time, Jackie Robinson and Joe Louis playing golf at a predominantly Jewish country club not far from Robinson's spacious home in Stamford. The year was 1956, Robinson's last season as a Brooklyn Dodger and five years after Louis's last fight.

title: As a River Rises, So Does a Small Town's Determination
description: It has left Grand Forks a befouled urban swamp. It has washed so inexorably over the small towns nearby that officials are proclaiming a 500-year flood. But here, among the stubborn inhabitants of the oldest town in North Dakota, population 642, the Red River may have met its match.

title: Stores
description: Paul Goldberger's ''The Store Strikes Back'' reminded me of the farm that Macy's had in its Herald Square building in the early 1940's. I stopped on the floor (I believe it was the seventh) where the farm was one day and watched, transfixed: inside a tall wire fence were chickens, cows, horses and goats, with men to care for them and keep the place clean. I believe Macy's ran this farm to encourage those who could to grow their own food because many products were rationed or in short supply in World War II. Years later, when I moved to Martha's Vineyard, I met a young man who told me that his mother had bought a cow in Macy's for her farm in Edgartown.

title: Moving Day Nears For Getty Collection
description: The J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., will close July 6, with most of its collection of art and antiquities moving to a new museum with twice the amount of gallery space opening in December at the Getty Center in Los Angeles. The center will bring together the J. Paul Getty Trust's museum, institutes and grant program in six buildings on 110 acres in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles.

title: Soaking Where Lumberjacks Once Bathed
description: A RED-TAIL hawk glided above our car and swooped into a valley of flaxen hills decorated with laurels, oaks and cherry-colored madrones. We were driving on a narrow two-lane road in Mendocino County that wound down to a hot-springs retreat a half-hour's drive west of Ukiah, Calif. When we left the Bay Area three hours earlier, the fog hugged the land like a fluffy blanket. After an hour on the road, the sun and a fall breeze began streaming through our open car windows. Passing a cluster of mailboxes near the side of the road, we came to a wall of blackberries 60 feet long and pulled over to fill the bottom of a paper bag with the sweet taste of summer in late September.

title: For the Young, Hong Kong Is the Home of Opportunity
description: AS we approach July 1, that fateful day when Hong Kong will be placed back in the hands of motherland China, my grandfather in Toronto is increasingly talking politics -- even at the dinner table, where it had always been a forbidden topic. Relatives tell me that when the stock market falls here, he blames it on Deng's ghost, curses the island state's colonial rulers as wimpy, and swears he will never return to this homeland he left five years ago. He doesn't understand how Hong Kong could have gotten itself into this fix -- or why my two cousins and I have chosen to stake our futures here.
