title: New Air-Quality Rule In Effect Inside Planes
description: Although the Department of Transportation has issued a new regulation on the quality of air in plane cabins, it will not help travelers who blame airline trips for their upper respiratory infections. The new rule reduces the level of carbon dioxide -- the stuff humans breathe out -- permitted in the cabins of new planes while in flight. The old rule allows a maximum of 3 percent carbon dioxide in cabins; the new rule, which took effect Jan. 2 for planes going into service from that date, sets a ceiling of 0.5 percent. This compares with a level of 0.03 that the Federal Aviation Administration said is found in outdoor air. But most planes, the agency said, already meet the new rule.

title: Sorry, the Professional Class Is Full
description: Work is work, and I am afraid I can muster very little sympathy for a college-educated man who has had the best of what America has to offer, yet whines about having to work with his hands and this supposed step down in status. It is an insult to all of us who work outside the ivory tower of automatic entitlement. It is snobbery, and it is unacceptable.

title: Crime

Estleman's NEVER STREET (Mysterious Press/Warner, $23) -- just in time to smack a little sense into a genre that's getting dumber by the minute. Although the Detroit gumshoe cynically refers to himself as ''a redundancy,'' he's really the dependable, wide-bodied model in a classic line.

title: For Stylish Orthodox Women, Wigs That Aren't Wiggy
description: TO express joy on a festive Jewish holiday, it is traditional to wear something new. Last week, for a Passover seder at her parents' home in Borough Park, Brooklyn, Suzy Berkowitz, 50, upheld tradition from head to toe. Exemplifying the Diana Vreeland dictum that elegance is restraint, she wore new Gucci pumps and a new Armani suit, hemmed discreetly just below the knee. She also wore a custom-made wig bought for the occasion.

title: For the President's Defender, a Task That Never Ends: Keeping 'The Beast' at Bay
description: It was 7:30 in the morning and Lanny J. Davis, the designated public defender of President Clinton in the scandal hunts of Whitewater and campaign finance, had no clue yet about the day's rovings and ravings of The Beast.

title: BIG TOM
description: 1. Wednesday is the release date for ''Mason & Dixon,'' the closely guarded new novel by Thomas Pynchon. 2. Bookstores are forbidden to display it until then, but the novel's 119-word opening sentence has been on the Internet for weeks. 3. It begins: ''Snow-Balls have flown their Arcs, starr'd the Sides of Outbuildings.'' ... 4. The publisher, Henry Holt, says this story of Mason and Dixon, the 18th-century British surveyors, features ''ripped bodices, naval warfare, conspiracies erotic and political, major caffeine abuse.'' 5. Pynchon-ophiles are celebrating their recluse's bewitching prose at events like the ''Open Mike Thomas Pynchon Imitator Contest,'' tonight at KGB in New York. ''We're hoping he'll show,'' says Denis Woychuk, KGB's principal owner. ''Maybe with a few drinks in him, he'd tip his hand.''

title: In Baltimore, a Whirl of Sites Old, New and Delicious
description: TOWARD the beginning of ''An Accidental Tourist,'' by the Baltimore novelist Anne Tyler, there is a moment when hope whispers in the ear of the protagonist, Macon Leary -- a depressed travel writer who hates to travel. About to embark on another joyless research trip from Pennsylvania Station in Baltimore to New York, he looks around and realizes that the dilapidated old building has been renovated. Its marble walls gleam and light pours in through the ceiling's freshly cleaned stained glass. Suddenly, Macon wonders whether he's got it all wrong; maybe travel isn't so bad after all.

title: Downtown, A Seder With Riffs
description: THE Passover seder at the Knitting Factory on Tuesday night was like a cross between a Jewish summer camp in the Catskills and a progressive jazz concert. About 275 people jammed into the main room to dip bitter herbs, break matzoh, hide the afikomen and remember their Jewish heritage. The atmosphere was warm, fuzzy and alternative, not unlike the club itself.

title: Hoff-Barthelson Celebrates 20th-Century Music
description: FOR more than three decades, the Hoff-Barthelson School has presented an annual Baroque Festival. Further to its credit, the school has also been greeting spring with a Festival of 20th Century Music, the eighth one due next weekend. Opening night is Friday at 8 at Hitchcock Presbyterian Church in Scarsdale.The highlight will be the world premiere of Robert Starer's ''Five Miniatures for String Quartet and Piano,'' a work commissioned for the festival. Also on the program are works by Barber, Ives, Faure, Schoenberg, Bernstein, Reich and others. Mark Mandarano will lead the Festival Chorus and Orchestra, and Ruth Alperson will lead the school's Junior Chorus and will play the piano in the Poulenc Sextet, joining the Amber Woodwind Quintet.

title: Secrets of the Sawdust Templt
description: Bruce Walstad has seen a lot of lead-weighted milk bottles. ''I've seen darts that are bent, darts you can crochet with,'' he says. ''I've actually seen darts bounce off balloons.'' A detective in the Franklin Park, Ill., Police Department, Walstad is a nationally recognized expert on the rigging of carnival games, a multimillion-dollar business. Right now, some 700 carnivals are beginning their impish seasonal migrations in North America, and Walstad wants players to have, at least, a prayer.''Often there's not a chance you're going to win -- even by accident,'' he says.''They're there to take your money, period.'' Here are some current scams to watch out for.

title: Honors for the Millers, Daughter and Father
description: Lennox and Inger Miller are the only father and daughter to win Olympic medals in track and field. With Inger Miller's first appearance at the Penn Relays today, reprising her role on the 1996 Olympic champion 4x100-meter relay team, the careers of sprinting's First Family came full circle.

title: Retraining for a Job, But What Kind of a Job?
description: At the end of the year, 364 workers at Mueller's noodle factory in Jersey City will be grappling with a problem as common as it is traumatic. The factory is moving to Columbia, S.C., where labor is cheaper and unions are rare. Workers here will be laid off. To get another good job, they will probably have to go back to school. People in their 40's and 50's, people who have bought houses and supported children with good union wages, must face the job interviewers as shaky, inexperienced novices, competing with young people fresh out of college.

title: River Cleanup Plan Is Adrift

title: YOU GO, DIVA!
description: When Deborah Voigt takes to the Metropolitan Opera's stage tomorrow night as the woeful Sieglinde in Wagner's ''Die Walkure,'' her biggest fans will be clutching the latest issue of Parterre Box: The Queer Opera Zine -- which has her picture on the cover. ''She's the real thing,'' gushes James Jorden, Parterre's editor. ''She gives you that extra something in a performance so you can't sleep afterward.'' Jorden, 42, edits the bimonthly zine and Web site, a raucous celebration of the longstanding subculture of opera queens, gay men whose passion for the art borders on obsessive. Parterre Box approves of divas who work hard, sing hard and believe in what they're doing -- no matter how outrageous their performances on and off the stage. It loathes ''phonies who are all P. R. and no action.'' Jorden's love of opera isn't always reciprocated. He claims he was once shown the door at the Met by a homophobic guard who tore up copies of the zine. The Met denies it and refuses to apologize, leaving Jorden a tad steamed. ''They're democratic at the Met,'' he snipes. ''They're equally rude to everyone.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYDA, JOSEPH D.
description: BEYDA-Joseph D. Of all that we deem valuable accumulated over a lifetime, one of the most precious is a true friend. Joseph D. Beyda (A''H) was a friend, mentor, problem-solver and benefactor to all who knew him. His vision, wisdom and generosity were far reaching within and beyond our organization and community. He helped Jewish communities, institutions and individuals throughout the world. As President of Sephardic Bikur Holim from 1991 to 1995, he was a beacon of guiding light. Always growing, he became an instrument of growth for all of us. In his quest for excellence, he inspired us to excel. His profound kindness inspired passion. His boundless energy inspired enthusiasm. His generosity opened our hearts and his creativity opened our minds. His unique vision inspired us to dream. Carried by his greatness, we rose like the foam on an ocean wave. As President of Sephardic Bikur Holim, no hurt, problem or project was too small to address, no difficulty, crisis or project was too big for his insurrmountable determination and drive. He successfully lead Sephardic Bikur Holim in the re-settlement of over 2500 Jews from Syria. He instilled in our youth the importance of doing and giving to those less fortunate. Knowing that we are put on this earth to give, he used his resources, wide range of talents, unique gifts and abundant blessings to better the lives of all he touched. Although our lives are darkened by his passing, his light is not extinguished and continues to guide us. Cut down himself at an early age, his eternal vineyard of good deeds will bear fruit for generations to come. Our condolences to Barbara and all the children. From the Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of Sephardic Bikur Holim

description: A 15-year-old girl who peered out her apartment window in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, when she heard gunfire was hit in the neck by a stray bullet yesterday, the police said.

title: Adults Behaving Badly
description: Karin Cook's first novel, WHAT GIRLS LEARN (Pantheon, $23), is a good argument for always keeping a box of tissues on your night table. What at first seems to be a well-written but not unpredictable coming-of-age story -- about two sisters approaching adolescence and facing the fact that their divorced mother has fallen in love -- develops into a much darker and more disturbing tale. Tilden, the 12-year-old narrator, is less confident and outgoing than Elizabeth, 11, and she worries about adjusting when they move with their mother, Frances, to the Long Island home of Frances' new boyfriend, Nick. The time is 1980 and Ms. Cook gets all the pre-teen iconography right: watermelon lip gloss, television's ''Brady Bunch'' and purloined copies of that bible for the pubescent, ''Our Bodies, Ourselves.'' But these humorous details are overshadowed by Frances' sudden hospitalization for breast cancer and by the arrival of her brother, Rand, an alcoholic drifter who is by turns protective and predatory toward the girls. One of the novel's themes is the fraying that truth undergoes in the hands of family members, and Ms. Cook sensitively describes Tilden's efforts to understand the oblique codes of the adults. Unfortunately, readers must cope with just as many secrets: we never learn any more about the girls' biological father or the reasons for Rand's weaknesses than they do, and Nick emerges as little more than a kind man with bad taste in music. Ms. Cook triumphs completely, however, in her achingly nuanced depiction of a young girl's fierce love for her brave mother. She also succeeds in capturing the essential bond between siblings, who fight here ''the way only sisters can fight -- with the luxury of forever and forgiveness at hand.'' Laurel Graeber

title: Fleeing South, Crying War

Arriving in Seoul last Sunday, 67 days after he first sought asylum at the South Korean consulate in Beijing, Hwang Jang Yop said North Korea had lost hope and its leaders saw war as the only way out.

title: The Promise Keepettes
description: Ike Turner had the Ikettes. Now the Promise Keepers -- those take-charge Christian men who fill stadiums and hug and weep over their devotion to God and family -- have attracted female backup groups. And they may be coming to a town near you. Here's a who's-who guide.

title: Giving Credit to Head Of Burial Ground Study
description: Regarding the ''African Burial Ground Is Documented in Film'' $(March 16$), the W. Montague Cobb Human Skeletal Collection in the department of sociology and anthropology at Howard University is under the direction of Dr. Michael Blakey, curator and scientific director of the African Burial Ground Project. Dr. Blakey directs the study of the nearly 400 human remains and artifacts excavated from the 18th-century African Burial Ground in Lower Manhattan. Therefore, I feel his name merits inclusion whenever his lab is mentioned.

title: Contemporary Art Showcased in Chicago
description: Two events in Chicago this spring, an international art fair and an outdoor exhibition of large sculpture, will focus on contemporary art.

title: 'Dear Cousin Julius, We Trust on Our God and on You...'

''There are a lot more, if you're interested,'' she said, handing them to me in a thin purple folder, letters that were more than half a century old and had been locked away in a suitcase, forgotten for years.

title: Of Towering Concern: The Cellulars' Antennas

title: Life Down on Earth for Everybody's Darling

Just 15, she was adorable, with doll features, a bold, maidenly air and what one critic called ''her honey amber hair of remarkable texture.'' But it was her assured and joyful mastery of the classical idiom, even in a student performance, that won her the admiration of audiences and critics and the support of George Balanchine, the New York City Ballet's ballet master in chief. Balanchine chose her from his company's academy, the School of American Ballet, made her a company member at 16, worked closely with her and cast her in great roles.

title: Munch the Printmaker
description: ''Munch is our contemporary, as he will be the contemporary of our children's children, because his subject is life in the present tense, which may pass in and out of intellectual vogue but will not become obsolete.'' So Peter Schjeldahl, art critic for The Village Voice, writes in THE SYMBOLIST PRINTS OF EDVARD MUNCH: The Vivian and David Campbell Collection (Art Gallery of Ontario/Yale University, $50). Certainly the prints reproduced in this revelatory book support Mr. Schjeldahl's claims -- and then some. But as Michael Parke-Taylor, associate curator of European art at the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto, writes in an informative essay, despite Munch's lifetime reputation in Norway and Germany (where he is considered one of the greatest European modern artists), a similar level of appreciation and awareness of Munch's work did not reach this country until 1950, when a retrospective exhibit first appeared. Elizabeth Prelinger, chairwoman of the department of art, music and theater at Georgetown University, writes that it was through his prints that Munch (1863-1944) achieved the Symbolist ideal of fusion between the meaning of the image and the technique used to give it form. She also provides valuable background information on his technique. But Mr. Schjeldahl's essay best captures Munch's achievement. Commenting on the timeless appeal of Munch's best-known work, ''The Scream,'' he writes, ''It is a template of creativity that discovers a way to say the unsayable by giving over to an internal logic of saying.'' Robin Lippincott

title: Street Singer
description: It seems cruelly inappropriate that Allen Ginsberg should have died during National Poetry Month -- an occasion that he, as much as anyone, helped to create. He was the champion of that plain-spoken, full-throated tradition of American verse going back to Williams, Pound and Whitman, and even more than they did, he liberated poetry from the library and took it boldly into the cafes and onto the street corner. He believed in poetry of the people, not the professoriate. But though he would have been amused by the comparison, there was also something Wordsworthian about Ginsberg: he wrote his best, most impassioned poetry as a young man and then settled into a long middle age as a twinkling, gray-bearded laureate, turning out lyrics and reams of what amounted to occasional verse -- some of it memorable, more of it not. He was a cultural busybody -- an inspired yenta -- turning up at protests, rallies, rock concerts, love-ins; but he brought to these occasions not rage or dogma so much as a kind of avuncular concern. In the end, his most enduring contribution to our culture may be less such works as ''Howl'' and ''Kaddish'' than the way that, humming and chanting and clicking away on his finger cymbals, he transformed the American avant-garde, and the angry alienation of the Beats, into something altogether more cheerful and benign. Some of his later poems take radical pleasure in the deeply ordinary and in a form of transcendence that seems almost middle-class: getting high, making love, raiding the icebox. ''Gone Gone Gone,'' part of an unfinished collection, was written last year. Charles McGrath

Dave was the President of Advanced Publishing Systems which he began some 25 years ago to bring innovative computerized techniques to the marketing of college textbooks, a skill he learned first in sales for the T.Y. title: Moviegoer's Return to Another Era

They sought green lawns, new schools and tranquillity. The parade continued into Suffolk County, where lawns were larger and schools were newer. With our children on their own and the opportunity of a new business, my husband and I made the last leap -- to the North Fork, now known as Wine Country.

title: Son of Darien
description: I'm drinking bottled water at the bar of Jimmy's Seaside in Stamford. Old fishing boats are upended in the parking lot, and in the back room photocollages of people partying hang above the pool tables. This is where Alex Kelly struck up a conversation with three women last summer. Kelly, who was wearing his electronic ankle monitor and was under a court-ordered curfew, confided in the women that he wasn't guilty of either of the rapes he was charged with back in February 1986. Then he wandered off to the bar. When he returned 20 minutes later he stuck his tongue out at one of the women and made an obscene suggestion involving the pool cue. When the police came, Kelly taunted them with more obscenities and accusations, the police report says. ''Kelly was thoroughly uncooperative and appeared to be alcohol-impaired.''

title: Putting Out Word on Picking Up Trash
description: When a small group of men wearing royal blue uniforms began sweeping Broadway from 71st to 96th Streets two weeks ago, some residents and officials were puzzled. Honorable, dependable and loving, he will forever be cherished in our memories.

description: LEPSON-Leah (nee Smith). Beloved wife of the late Israel. Devoted mother of Lawrence and Marion Lepson. Dear sister of Ethel Lubin. Loving grandmother of Alan and Iris. Great grandmother of Sam and Aimee. Services on Sunday, at 12 Noon, ''Gramercy Chapel'', 152 2nd Avenue, NYC.

title: MO' BETTER MILTON
description: There are niche publications, and then there's Milton: The Luxury Gaming Magazine, a new quarterly that celebrates the credo ''We Drink, We Smoke, We Gamble.'' Aimed at''the Milton man and woman'' -- upscale 25-to-39-year-olds who share Milton Berle's ''taste for adventure and luxury'' -- Milton is heavy on hard-hitting, um, journalism (''From Vice to Virtue: Using Real Numbers to Defend Gambling'') and creaky sex humor. The cover features a younger Berle, whose jokerlike visage appears endlessly inside. Why so much Milton? Why so much vice? ''If the magazine was named Humperdinck, who do you think they'd put on the cover?'' says Berle, 88. As for the naughtiness, no apologies: ''We're talking about pleasure and enjoyment, which have always been hot.''

title: Solo Effort That Led to Worldwide Relief
description: IT is the eyes that get to Robert C. Macauley, founder and chairman of Americares Foundation. It was the eyes of children that prompted him in 1975 to mortgage his house to lease a 747 jet to get Vietnamese children out of Saigon when the city fell to the Communists. It was the eyes of Pope John Paul II that propelled Mr. Macauley's efforts to find medicine to help Poland during its time of martial law.

title: Anne Noble, Harry Ervine Jr.
description: Anne Rowell Noble, a lawyer, was married last evening to Dr. Harry Fillmore Ervine Jr., an obstetrician and gynecologist. The Rev. Anthony Hollis performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Anglican Church in St. George, Bermuda.

description: WHAT'S the difference between a sadist and a dentist?'' my dentist asked me the other day.

description: A bold effort by Coldwell Banker agents in Westchester County to buck local custom by preparing real estate contracts for clients came to a halt last week after the county bar association made good on its threat to take the brokers to court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, JOSEPH
description: JACOBSON-Joseph. Age 56, died suddenly at home. Loving son of the late Sidney and Leona Jacobson, cherished brother of Reeva Kimble, devoted uncle of Matthew, Evan and Sara Kimble. Good friend to many. Private memorial services.

title: Lincoln Home
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Joseph Siano's article ''Since 1811, a Cozy Vermont Inn'' (March 23) describing the beautiful area of Manchester, Vt. I visited Manchester last summer and particularly enjoyed visiting its primary tourist attraction, Hildene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEJOY, GARY
description: DeJOY-Gary. Born June 1, 1958. Died of complications from AIDS, April 25, 1997, in Miami, FL. Beloved life partner of Paul Kevin Cline. Beloved son of Joseph C. and the late Edna White DeJoy. Beloved brother and friend to Michael J., Joanne and Robert C. DeJoy. Beloved of friends in New York, Florida and Bucks County, PA. He enriched their lives with a spirit of kindness and generosity they will always treasure. Good night, sweet prince.

title: Shows Feature Coils of Braids And Portraits Done in Beads
description: BEADED Presidents and braided hair under the same roof: it is a once-in-a-lifetime juxtaposition for which the Hudson River Museum here is responsible -- and which may or may not be accidental. Either way, the shows, both small, make diverting appetizers for the museum's main course, a folk art extravaganza, which requires a separate review.

title: Tiger Woods Also Needs to Apologize for Distasteful Jokes
description: TIGER WOODS has accepted Fuzzy Zoeller's apology for what the 21-year-old Masters winner described as an ''attempt at humor that was out of bounds,'' but Woods's apology to African-Americans for his own out-of-bounds jokes in GQ magazine has yet to be heard.

title: Stores
description: My fiancee and I pored over Richard Panek's ''Superstore Inflation'' (April 6) with interest. Her parents are fond of regaling us with a story from their days as newlyweds, when, shopping in a small furniture store in Cornwall, Conn., they were torn between buying a small love seat and a coffee table. They were unable to afford both. The store owner, sensing their predicament, gave them the table as a ''post-wedding gift, with blessings.'' They still have it today.

title: Percolating
description: COFFEE AND POWER

title: Demystifying a 19th-Century Kitchen
description: SARAH EDMOND BOOTH inscribed her favorite recipes in a small notebook more than 150 years ago, a record of teatime sweets in terse prose. Now in print, it is helping to support the Cornelius H. Booth Library in Newtown, built in honor of Mrs. Booth's husband by her granddaughter, Mary Elizabeth Hawley.

title: New Computer Systems Help Improve Efficiency
description: IF making deals is the glamorous side of the commercial real-estate business, then property management is the solid, supporting side that makes the deals possible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARON, IRVING
description: MARON-Irving. Beloved husband of Jeanne; loving father of Judy and Jeffrey; loving father-in-law of Willa and Harold; adored grandfather of Karen, Gabriel and Asa. A graduate of Cornell and Columbia Law School, he was an attorney for 67 years. In past years, he was counsel for Mosbacher Properties. A bon vivant, he loved his friends, good food and travel. Services April 30, 11am at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: Buffy Is Sweet, 16 and Slaying Vampires
description: DON'T mess with Buffy. The perky, preternaturally wise high school girl may seem like a pushover at first, but she's a uniquely talented 16-year-old. As she sheds her girlish interests and assumes the job of protecting her hometown, Buffy Summers becomes a heroine who'd make both Joseph Campbell and Judy Blume proud. When the going gets rough, she starts kick boxing and staking vampires through the heart.

title: LaJoyce Hunter, Gus Brookshire Jr.
description: LaJoyce Celeste Hunter, a record company publicity director, was married yesterday to Gus William Brookshire Jr., a travel agent. Sam L. Williams, a Pentecostal minister, performed the ceremony at the Reaching Out for Jesus Christian Center in Stroudsburg, Pa. The Rev. Kenneth L. Pearman, a Baptist minister, took part in the service.

title: How to Fight Bugs That Bite
description: AN IMPORTANT part of travelers' health is warding off insect and parasite bites. Health experts at the conference of the International Society of Travel Medicine in Geneva last month emphasized that the only sure way to avoid malaria in the tropics was to avoid getting bitten. Protection against bites is also the major defense against illnesses not confined to the tropics, such as Lyme tick disease, for which there is now no vaccine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUER, JAY ROBERT
description: LAUER-Jay Robert, 74, died 4/23/ 97; Beloved husband of Betty, Loving father of April, Matt, Fred, Jim, Andy; Grandfather of Samantha, Jennifer, Rachel, Daniel, Michelle, Allyssa; Brother of Lynne (Hal) Dietz and Fred Picker. A gentle gentleman loved by all. Donations may be sent to 52 Association, Suite 3304, 350 5th Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10118.

title: Planting Coneflowers for Beauty and a Tonic
description: I have a whole stand of purple coneflowers, Echinacea purpurea, growing on my family's farm in Maryland, and this fall, I'm going to dig up some roots and soak them in vodka to make a tincture.

description: BARBARA TORINA, 57, does not have time to get old. The New Rochelle resident is too busy teaching music, playing tennis, bowling, singing in a choir, playing guitar, doing organic gardening and making habits for a monastery in the South Bronx. And she traveled to Florida on spring break with her two college-age children.

description: Meredith Lynn Nieves, the daughter of Lore and Richard Nieves of New York, was married yesterday to Steven Swift Millington, a son of Didi Kelley of Westhampton Beach, N.Y., and John A. Millington of Washington Depot, Conn. The Rev. Sally E. Norris, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Riverside Church in New York.

title: Color Still Reigns Where Birren Walked
description: OUT of its slender and recently refurbished row house, the durable Stamford Art Association belatedly observes its 25th anniversary (which occurred last year) with a show in its upstairs gallery: paintings, sculptures and photographs by its early members.

title: Homeless Pressed at Terminal
description: Over the last six months, the Staten Island ferry terminal has been the nighttime resting place for a growing number of homeless people. On cold nights it was not uncommon to find as many as 70 people sleeping on the floor around the benches.

title: The Pizza Murders
description: The utter senselessness of it was stunning. In a world of easy violence, people have become familiar with teen-agers killing over sneakers and necklaces and lost love. But who kills just to kill?

title: Twilight of a Subscriber
description: YOU'VE done your homework. You've studied Newman's monumental four-volume ''Life of Richard Wagner.'' You've read Donington's ''Wagner's 'Ring' and Its Symbols.'' You've listened (at times drifted, at times snored) all the way through. ''Das Rheingold,'' ''Die Walkure,'' ''Siegfried,'' ''Gotterdammerung,'' every last note of ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' the ''Ring'' cycle. All four sets, all 15 disks, all 14 hours, 27 minutes, 49 seconds. You've compared conductors, questioned tempos, defended singers. You've rented videos, laid out cash, plunked down plastic. You've been to the shelves. You've canceled classes for lack of sleep. You've prepared.

title: Italian Favorites, With Service to Please
description: WARM is the word for the A Tavola Ristorante in Mineola. From the sincere welcome to the cozy, comfortable surroundings to the solicitous service, it remains the adjective that springs to mind.

title: The Great Divide
description: Korea's Place

title: A Speed Demon Reappears, A Ghost Now at the Wheel
description: OCCASIONALLY, AN OBJECT appears at auction that fuels scholarship as much as it fires up collectors. Faded names are illuminated anew, forgotten exploits are refreshed, reputations are polished, and doctoral dissertations -- and maybe movies of the week -- are born.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NABATOFF, RICHARD
description: NABATOFF - Richard. ''Uncle Richard,'' Southampton sunsets; Sleeping charts; Road D and seven more summers; Time Warner T-shirts; frequent flyers; happy hours; shushing in Aspen; Snowmass Club; Holding Court at Bonnie's; Ute City on me; long chats in Bermuda; PB&J in your pocket; Thanksgiving Day Parade; offpiste in Chamonix; ''chicks dig me''; ''it doesn't get any better than this''; Nabby, you made this world better. We love you and will hold you close in our hearts. Love, your summer house mates and friends.

title: A Luxury Resort For Cape Town
description: Sun International South Africa, a hotel developer best known for its 150-acre Sun City gambling resort in Bophuthatswana, one of several independent black ''homelands'' created by the South African Government during apartheid, has opened the Table Bay, a 330-room luxury hotel in Cape Town. The hotel is in the city's recently restored Victoria and Alfred Waterfront complex, nestled between ocean and mountains. (Prince Alfred was Queen Victoria and Prince Albert's second son.)

title: Touch of Genius
description: TOUCH OF EVIL (1958) is a brilliantly filmed masterpiece of suspense as a narcotics agent (Charlton Heston) and his pretty wife (Janet Leigh) spend their honeymoon in a Mexican border town. Only Orson Welles could have concocted this nightmarish puzzle (from a Whit Masterson novel), and he cast it with many of his friends in half disguise (Marlene Dietrich, Joseph Cotten and Mercedes McCambridge). Front and center, stirring up trouble, is Welles as a vicious Texas sheriff with a jutting midriff who frames a Mexican youth for murder. A cabaret chum (Dietrich) purrs, ''Better lay off the candy bars, baby.'' -- WEDNESDAY at 5 P.M. on AMC. Howard Thompson

title: 93 Die in Algerian Massacre
description: In the latest chapter of the vicious conflict between Islamic fundamentalist rebels and Algerian military authorities, 93 people, including many women and young children, were hacked to death in an all-night massacre in a village south of Algiers on Monday night. Witnesses said the victims included three children below age 5.

title: Arrests in Protest Over Research on Animals
description: More than three dozen demonstrators protesting the use of animals in AIDS research were arrested today at the Yerkes Regional Primate Research Center here.

title: PGA Wants New Television Deals
description: The PGA Tour and television networks will begin negotiations tomorrow in Manhattan intended to create long-term deals beginning with the 1999 season.

title: Inspiration
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed so much Lawrence Block's essay ''The Bumpy Road to Inspiration'' (March 9).

title: Sugar's Sweet Deal
description: An unlikely Congressional pair -- Charles Schumer, a liberal New York Democrat, and Dan Miller, a conservative Florida Republican -- has begun a fresh effort to phase out America's archaic sugar price support program. The program has enriched domestic sugar growers at the expense of ordinary consumers and, in some cases, the environment. Scientists believe that the Florida sugar cane industry's rapid growth over the last 30 years, underwritten in part by the support program, has damaged the ecology of central and southern Florida, including Everglades National Park and Florida Bay, by interrupting the natural flow of clean water.

title: Urban Volunteers Strain to Reach Fragile Lives
description: Ever since George Sydnor 2d, a single father, moved to the struggling north Philadelphia neighborhood of Logan six weeks ago, he has been trying to find a safe and stimulating place for his three children to go after school.

description: Sheila M. Nugent, a lawyer, and George E. Carter, a banker, were married yesterday at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in New Vernon, N.J. Msgr. John Corr officiated.

title: Seeing Pyramids
description: To the Editor: It may be wonderful, as Douglas Jehl suggests in ''What's Doing in Cairo'' (March 23), to approach the Giza Pyramids on horseback, but the biggest thrill is to see them first at night, at the sound-and-light show.

description: You thought you put that big report on top of your desk. But there's so much stuff piled up there that you may never know its fate. title: Correction
description: An article on April 13 about the musicologist Alan Lomax referred imprecisely to the Alan Lomax Archive. While it is housed at Hunter College's M.F.A. Building on West 41st Street in Manhattan, it is not affiliated with the college.

title: In Danbury, Italian Menu Absent Cliches
description: WHEN Bentley's in Danbury was new in 1988, we found it Good, with considerable potential. This homey little storefront is the operation of Richard and Manuela Bentley, proof of the importance of hands-on management, for it has gotten better and better through the years. Recent visits confirm it is now Very Good indeed, remarkable value for reasonable prices.

title: At the Gate: Horse Race of All Horse Races
description: IT isn't the richest race in the world. That's the $4 million Dubai World Cup, run last month. It isn't even the richest race in the United States: several other stakes races award more money. But in glamour, tradition and prestige, the Kentucky Derby, now in its 123d year, has no rival. Every jockey dreams of sitting astride a Derby winner, its neck draped with the traditional blanket of roses. Every trainer dreams of standing in the winner's circle and saying cheese. Every owner, looking deep into the eyes of the 2-year-old horse he just bought, sees a yearlong road to glory leading straight to Churchill Downs on the first Saturday in May. In America, there is only one race, and it's the Derby.

The fair will be sponsored by the New York office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.

description: CAPARROS-Rogelio, on April 17, in Elizabeth, NJ. Former Cuban photojournalist for ''Bohemia'' and UPI Latin American Desk employee. A man of great intelligence and integrity who led an extraordinary life. Beloved husband of Ilona (Siren); father of Miguel and Rosa from marriage to Carmen Montero. Born in Havana, Cuba April 22, 1918. Interred at Woodlawn Park North Cemetery, Miami FL, April 23.

description: Searching for a new weapon in the United States' most important drug battle abroad, the Clinton Administration has been quietly debating proposals to impose stringent economic penalties against Mexico's biggest traffickers.

title: Unlikely City Turned Into a Capital of Chess
description: The last time a Thursday night was sold out at the downtown Hilton here had to be at least a year ago, said Jamal Love, the hotel's assistant manager. But this week, it was packed to the gills on Thursday; even the last-minute cancellations were replaced, he said, and that doesn't happen even on University of Tennessee football weekends.

title: Reviving the Harlem Brownstone
description: GIVING a tour of their new brownstone -- from the unrenovated basement kitchen to the unreconstructed top-floor bedrooms -- Julie Butler and Claude Howard couldn't help but recall the other Harlem houses they had wanted and bid on but somehow didn't get.

description: As the song says, poker players need to know when to hold 'em and know when to fold 'em. And if they're taking part in the Ninety-Nines Annual Poker Run next weekend, they also need to know how to fly a plane.

description: HOW wonderful to be outdoors at this time of year, finding the endless surprises offered to casual and watchful eyes alike.

title: For Some Police and Fire Veterans, an Unwelcome Deadline
description: Charles J. Fortenbacher has been a policeman in Bernards Township for 41 years and he's been chief of police for the past six years. He says most of the people in the community agree he has done a good job. He would like to keep doing that job awhile longer.

title: MetroStars Rally Past Columbus
description: For every one of the Columbus Crew's shots on goal tonight, the MetroStars had two. And they came on a night when the MetroStars' most potent scorers, Giovanni Savarese and Antony De Avila, were not on the field.

title: Clinton Crazy
description: By concentrating on the lunatic fringe, a tiny cadre that is easily dismissed and serves mostly as a useful bogeyman, Philip Weiss's ''Clinton Crazy'' (Feb. 23) missed the real story -- the intense dislike felt for Bill Clinton by mainstream Republicans across the political spectrum. The depth of this antipathy seems to me unusual. The reasons for this are certainly more deserving of discussion than are the motivations of ''Clinton haters'' who think that Vince Foster was murdered on the movie set where the moon landing was faked.

title: Demand for Natural Gas Is Propelling Speculators to Suburbs
description: When Sanford Dvorin began wildcatting for natural gas a few years ago, his endeavor was hardly unusual in Texas. What was unusual was where he was looking: Dallas County.

title: Spain's Green Corner
description: WEDGED into the northwest corner of Spain, bordered by Portugal and isolated by the surrounding sea, Galicia is a green region with more than a dozen fjordlike waterways known as rias. These inlets, often lined by broad, sand beaches, forests of pine, eucalyptus and chestnut, and small farming plots, bring the Atlantic Ocean inland to create some of the most memorable coastal scenery in Spain. The long splendid shoreline divides into the gentle lower estuaries of the provinces of Pontevedra and southern La Coruna (Rias Bajas), and the more abrupt upper estuaries of northern La Coruna and Lugo provinces (Rias Altas).

title: Varmints Begone! Urban Trapper on the Job.
description: THE cable guys and the squirrels showed up in late February, extroverted, chattering, with secret agendas of damage. The cable guys came in waves, some from Time Warner and some from its construction contractor, USA Communications, with blueprints and promises. They were going to rewire the entire block with fiber optics that would improve reception and take us channel surfing right into the millennium. One of them actually said that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, JOHN V.
description: HOGAN-John V. Of Forest Hills and Northport, NY, on April 25, 1997. Husband of Madeleine (nee Miller). Father of Richard J., Douglas R. and Russell P. Grandfather of Caitlin, Ashley, Lesley, Scott, Lindsay and Nora. Graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, attended Lehigh University, member of Sigma Phi Epsilon Fraternity, Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Served in US Army Air Force, 7th Bomb Group in World War II. A patient, generous man. Memorial service at St. Luke's Church, Tuesday, April 29, at 11 AM. Funeral private, Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to St. Luke's Church, Forest Hills, or Boy Scouts of America would be appreciated.

title: For 'Death Futures,' the Playing Field is Slippery
description: BUYING an investment that will pay off only when a terminally ill person dies has a certain morbid quality, but individuals have been doing it for several years. These investors, though, operate in an area in which there have been recent allegations of fraud, and it has become clear that Federal securities protection will not extend to all of them.

title: Eugene Stoner, 74, Designer Of M-16 Rifle and Other Arms
description: Eugene M. Stoner, who developed America's classic assault rifle, the M-16, while tinkering at night in his garage, died on Thursday at his home in Palm City, Fla. He was 74.

title: Mary Day Kent, Edgar Bermudez
description: Mary Day Kent and Edgar Gustavo Bermudez were married last evening in Chestnut Hill, Pa. The Rev. David F. Funkhouser, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Morris Arboretum.

title: Has the Brew Pub Business Gone Flat?
description: THE news has been bad for brew pubs, those combination restaurant-breweries that have sprouted throughout the city in the last few years. Zip City Brewery, at five years old the granddaddy of them all, closed this month. One closed last year, and another has become a rock club.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KHAN, PAUL
description: KHAN-Paul, suddenly, April 21, 1997. Husband and best friend of Grace Adams Khan. Born in Vienna, Austria, November 1923, he was President of Regu-Tech Associates in Mamaroneck, NY, a consulting firm in food safety, quality assurance and regulation. He is survived by his wife of New Rochelle, NY. Services private.

title: Orbiting Ashes
description: The world's first extraterrestrial funeral took place on Monday as ashes from 24 people were sent into orbit on a Pegasus rocket from the Canary Islands. The vials with the ashes will revolve around the earth, fixed to part of the rocket, for an undefined time. Among the ashes were fragments of Gene Roddenberry, the creator of the ''Star Trek'' television series, and those of the iconoclast Timothy Leary.

title: Stores
description: Paul Goldberger is right on the mark with his article ''The Sameness of Things'' (April 6). As a former head merchant at one of the corporations he cites, I had my epiphany on mass-market taste at the Canton Fair in China. Our buyers and product designers were circling the same wares as were the Crate & Barrel crew, the folks from Pier 1, the Pottery Barn contingent, the Conran's crowd. All of us went home to tweak a few things and call it design. No wonder everything looks alike by the time it gets to our homogenized stores!

title: Zaire General Calls for a 'Fight to Death' to Defend the Capital
description: Moving to mount a final stand against rebels rapidly closing in on this capital, the head of Mobutu Sese Seko's Presidential Guard today urged his troops to ''fight to the death'' to defend the city.

title: With Tories Trailing Labor, Major Plays to Voters' Fears
description: So far unable to make a dent in polls that show his Conservative Party lagging badly before national elections on Thursday, Prime Minister John Major today urged voters hearkening to the opposition's call for a change to consider the ''nightmare'' that he says a Labor Government would bring to Britain.

title: Before the TV Movie, There Was a True Story
description: CLIFF and Nancy Perlman recently attended their own wedding. ''I said if somebody is filming my wedding, I want to be invited,'' Mr. Perlman said. So he and his wife were. They journeyed to Los Angeles, where a television movie about their lives was being shot. ''A member of the crew said, 'This is really unusual,' '' Mr. Perlman recalled. ''He said to me, 'Nobody we've done a film about has ever been on the set before. They are usually dead or in jail.' ''

title: Fighting On In the Battle For Equity
description: Lin Dunn, who is 49, was already coaching in 1972 when Title IX was passed. She fought the wars and tells the stories. She can remember when her Austin Peay women's teams had to buy their own meals on the road. They often spent the night in their sleeping bags in the gyms in which they had just played. Friendly opponents spread tumbling mats over the hardwood floors.

title: Pound Ridge Sculpture Honors Oklahoma Dead
description: IF rocks could speak, the white alabaster in ''Unfinished Lives'' by the Pound Ridge sculptor Miles Slater might be saying to the dark granite that it enfolds: ''It's O.K. Let go of the pain.'' The sculpture was the focus of a commemorative ceremony at the Pound Ridge Town House last Saturday to remember the children who perished in the Oklahoma City bombing exactly two years before -- on April 19, 1995.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERESMAN, HELEN CHAFETS
description: MERESMAN-Helen Chafets. On April 25, 1997. Beloved wife of Harry Meresman for 60 years; devoted and cherished mother of Helaine Meresman Barnett and Victor Barnett and Janis Meresman Goldman and Michael Goldman; adored grandmother of Craig and Jennifer Barnett, Roger Barnett, Melissa Goldman, and Lori Goldman; loving sister of Henrietta and Alan Leiner, Selma and Bill Rafsky, and Emanuel Chafets; and loving aunt and great aunt to many nieces and nephews. A woman known for her remarkable beauty, grace, and intellect, she also had a special gift of language that turned conversations into poetry. Her devotion, guidance, and unconditional love helped to define every member of her family and everyone she touched. She remains uniquely loved and irreplaceable. Funeral services April 27, 1997, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 1:15 P.M.

description: A retired Civil Court judge was arrested this week after a struggle with police officers who had approached him after they saw that he was wearing a handgun in a holster, the police said.

Denise C. R. Santomero, president of the board of directors, said the board was looking for a buyer who would lease half the space back to the arts center.

title: In Nature vs. Nature, Nature May Not Win
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, when 170 Michigan schoolchildren were infected with hepatitis A after eating tainted strawberries imported from Mexico, the nation wondered what other viruses and bacteria might be hitching a ride across the border on foodstuffs. Microorganisms, it turns out, are but a tiny part of a growing problem. Every day hordes of foreign insects, plants, and animals infiltrate the United States.

Beloved sister of Edward M. of Trappe, PA, Joan I.L. of Washington, D.C., Ethyl C. of Gilbertsville, PA., Jeremiah F.X. of Center Square, PA., Celestine M. of Park Ford, PA., Brigid M. of Albany, NY., Joachim A. of Center Square, PA., and Patrick A. of Center Square, PA., and Augustine F.X., of Spring Lake, N.J. title: The Long and Winding Road
description: WHEN I was younger, so much younger than today, I spent an inordinate amount of time worrying about whether or not Paul McCartney was dead. I remember poring over the ''Abbey Road'' and ''Sergeant Pepper'' album covers in the late 1960's, searching for death symbols, graveyard icons, and ominous subtexts. While I resisted the temptation to play ''Revolution'' backward to hear the alleged chant of ''Paul is dead'' (my sister told me that I'd be dead if I ruined her turntable), I devoted a good deal of my mental energy and more than a few dollars of my allowance to the investigation, buying every record and fan magazine I could find in an attempt to reassure myself that my beloved Paul had not succumbed to premature mortality.

title: Some Truths About Getting Old Are Only Too Self-Evident
description: THE lot of America's elders has vastly improved over the last few decades. Their income, their health and their longevity are all up. Many men and women in their 60's and 70's today remain vigorous, adventurous and amorous. Last week came word of yet another record-breaking event: the birth of a healthy baby girl to a 63-year-old woman.

title: Peru's Old Problem
description: The daring rescue of 71 hostages at the Japanese Ambassador's residence here this week brought a victorious end to one of Peru's worst terrorist attacks since guerrilla groups first took up arms against the Government two decades ago.

Inspectors from the city's Department of Consumer Affairs have stepped up enforcement in the past few months, fining fruit stands that clutter the sidewalks on the two blocks of 73d and 74th Streets along 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights. Most of the markets are owned by Indian immigrants.

For more than two hours in between, the playwright, August Wilson, crams in the odds, the obstacles and the stakes, the wins and the losses, of a real survival game.

Turner, a Mercer County Democrat, this week in calling for a $12 million increase in the budget of the Division of Youth and Family Services. That would be enough to allow the division, New Jersey's child welfare agency, to hire 440 caseworkers and reduce the average caseload to 27 families, from the present 43, said Micah Rasmussen, a spokesman for the Assembly Democrats.

title: Claiborne Farm Raises Another Derby Favorite
description: Queen Elizabeth once came to lunch at Claiborne Farm. Secretariat was once syndicated for $6.1 million there, reigned as a stallion there and now lies buried there. Bold Ruler and Round Table were born on the same day there. Mr. Prospector still stands there at the advanced age of 27 as the senior sire and head of a family of 205 sons still active as sires and with heirs who have won close to $100 million in racing purses.

description: Andy Pettitte, superb again, is still unbeaten. Paul O'Neill, slugging away once more, is hovering near .400.

title: Dawn Upshaw's Adventures With Today's Songs
description: Most artists who achieve success with mainstream classical-music audiences are reluctant to jeopardize it by taking risks with repertory. Such thinking is nonsense to the soprano Dawn Upshaw. When the opportunity came for her recital debut at Carnegie Hall, she thought of presenting a program of contemporary American music. Her confidence that less adventurous listeners would follow her lead was borne out on Friday night when an enthusiastic audience filled the hall for her program.

title: Strong Growth in PC Industry, Reports Say
description: Despite Wall Street anxieties about the market for home computers, the personal computer industry over all continues to show strong growth, according to two reports to be issued on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILKELLY, KATHLEEN TERESE MCLOUGHLIN, ED.D.
description: KILKELLY-Kathleen Terese McLoughlin, Ed.D., RN, of Rockville Centre, on April 26, 1997. Mrs. Kilkelly was a resident of Rockville Centre, NY, for 32 years. She was a professor of Nursing at Molloy College, Rockville Centre, having taught there for 23 years, was recently serving as president of the faculty. She earned her doctorate and Masters of Education at Columbia University, her MA in Nursing from N.Y.U., and her BA from Molloy College. She received her RN from St. Vincent's School of Nursing. Beloved wife of Edward A., of 38 years. Loving mother of Edward F. of Little Silver, NJ, and Mary Beth Kilkelly-Schmidt of Brooklyn, NY. Cherished grandmother to Molly and Emma Kilkelly and Jack Kilkelly-Schmidt. Dear sister of Elizabeth Murphy of White Plains, NY. Reposing at Macken Mortuary, Inc, 52 Clinton Ave, Rockville Centre, NY, today and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Wednesday, 10 AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village.

title: Jordan Amazes Even Bulls With 55-Point Spectacular
description: The cold, bold scientific facts should probably be presented even before the shimmering artistry: Michael Jordan scored 55 points at the United Center tonight. That was more than half his team's points, as he paced -- no, pulled, pushed, lifted, orally challenged and carried like some kind of magnificent flying spirit -- the Chicago Bulls to a tough 109-104 victory over the Washington Bullets for a 2-0 lead in their three-of-five-game playoff series.

title: Two Vulnerable Front-Runners
description: Six months have passed since President Clinton triumphed with nearly 60 percent of the vote in New York State, and three-quarters of the vote in New York City. Can it be that in such a Democratic redoubt, a Republican Mayor and Republican Governor are sailing toward easy re-election this year and next? For now, at least, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani remains comfortably ahead of his potential opponents in the opinion polls, and the statewide political news has been filled more with candidates saying they do not want to run against Gov. George Pataki than with candidates saying they do.

description: The brief but bustling career of Nellie Bly invites a zingier treatment than tonight's dutifully adoring account, which sounds at times like a girl-reporter story for teen-agers. Along with being among the first female newspaper reporters and, for a while, by far the most famous, the adventurous Nellie, born Elizabeth Jane Cochran, exemplified both the progressive spirit of America's press in the 1880's and its tabloid tendencies.

title: What computer quandary at century's end? With a creative clock, 2000 can be read as 1980, or '72.

Thus, when the century changes over at the year 2000, it will appear to these computers that the year '00 is earlier, rather than later, than other dates in the system. For computers that do things like calculate investment interest or government benefits, for example, this creates a potentially enormous problem.

title: Lott Now Opposes Change in Inflation Adjuster

title: Corrections

title: CHIC BY H.I.S. SETS OFFER OF STOCK IN GERMAN SUBSIDIARY

Chic, a New York maker of jeans and casual clothes, said the initial public offering would consist of 1.92 million shares, which are expected to be sold for about $22.58 apiece. The company said 200,000 additional shares would be available for unanticipated demand. The unit's shares will be listed on the Frankfurt and Munich stock exchanges. Chic said it would use the proceeds from the sale for the repayment of debt and for general corporate purposes.

title: Corrections

title: Experts See Bias In Drug Data

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERST, RICHARD N.
description: KERST-Richard N. The Board of Trustees, administration and medical staff of The Presbyterian Hospital, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center mourn the loss of Richard Nevin Kerst, 83, former President of The Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center, who passed away April 22, 1997. Mr Kerst was a resident of Katonah, N.Y. A graduate of the University of Wisconsin, M. Kerst served in the Pacific during World War II as an officer on the U.S.S. Phoenix. In 1945 he began his career at The Presbyterian Hospital as Assistant Comptroller. Over the next 34 years, Mr Kerst rose to become the hospital's Comptroller, Assistant SecretaryTreasurer, Vice President of Administration, and in 1975, President. From 1977 to 1979, he was Vice Chairman of The Presbyterian Hospital's Board of Trustees. Allen I. Hyman, M.D., Chief of Staff and Medical Director of The Presbyterian Hospital said, '' For many years, Mr. Kerst was a faithful and valued member of the hospital's administration.'' Mr. Kerst was also a member of the Board of the Hecksher Foundation for Children and served on the Board of Directors of the Katonah Museum of Art. Beloved husband of Barbara Clark Kerst; father of R. Duncan Kerst of Portland, OR and Katrena K. Engstrom of Woodbridge, CT; brother of Kenneth Kerst of Heathville, VA; grandfather of Nicholas Engstrom, Cameron Kerst and Allison Kerst. Mr Kerst was pre-deceased by his first wife, Annie Lee Duncan. A memorial service will be held on Monday, June 2, 1997 at 11 AM at the South Salem Presbyterian Church, South Salem, NY. Committal will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 at Jay St, Katonah, NY 10536. The Presbyterian Hospital Daniel B. Burke John J. Mack Co-Chairmen of the Board William T. Speck, M.D. President and C.E.O. Allen I. Hyman, M.D. Chief of Staff

He is survived by his wife Isabelle, daughters Ellen Mayer and Jane Greenman, sister Doris Sabo and five grandchildren. A graduate engineer of New York University, he founded and was President of Precision Electronics of Amityville, N.Y. Our family patriach with extraordinary talents, skills and accomplishments was adored by friends and family. The void he leaves can never be filled. Contributions in his memory may be made to the United Jewish Fund of San Diego or Los Angeles.

title: 3 Women Accuse Investment Concern of Sexual Harassment
description: Three women who worked for a Garden City, N.Y., investment banking and brokerage concern accused top company officers yesterday of creating an environment where sexual harassment was routine and widespread, and at times involved the company's chairman and chief financial officer.

title: Sharp Cat to Skip Derby in Favor of Oaks
description: The trainer D. Wayne Lukas has won the Kentucky Derby the last two years and has captured seven of the last eight Triple Crown races, but his high-powered stable has fired a blank this year.

title: New Intel Chip Set for Games
description: The Intel Corporation has introduced a hardware specification for coin-operated video games based on its coming Pentium II chip, hoping to set a standard for game creation in both arcade and home consoles. It is the chip maker's first foray into coin-operated arcade game technology.

title: Siemens, Alcatel, ABB Suspected of Price Fixing
description: Siemens A.G. and the German units of Alcatel Alsthom S.A. and ABB Asea Brown Boveri are being investigated on suspicion that they fixed prices for electrical cable, the Federal Cartel Office in Germany said yesterday, after the investigation was reported in the financial newpaper Boersen-Zeitung. Siemens, which is Germany's largest electronics company; Alcatel, a French maker of telecommunications equipment, and ABB, the Swiss-Swedish engineering company, had no immediate comment.

During his long career at Warner Bros. and Columbia Pictures, his friendship, humor and creativity enriched may lives. Servcies Wednesday, April 30th, 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Stock Sale by Top WMX Shareholder
description: WMX Technologies Inc., the waste-hauling company, said today that Peter Huizenga, its largest individual shareholder, would sell part of his 1.7 percent stake.

title: No Headline
description: ''We don't want to engage in a fair fight, a contemporary war of attrition. We want to dominate across the full spectrum of conflict, so that if we ever do have to fight, we will win on our terms.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: LINDA McCARTNEY may be well known as a photographer, but her husband, Sir PAUL McCARTNEY, who was knighted last month by Queen Elizabeth II is no slouch behind the camera. A picture of her that he took for his newest compact disk album appeared in The Daily Telegraph of London yesterday.

title: A Fake Gun and an Arrest
description: Terrified gamblers took cover underneath benches and behind walls as a man waving a fake gun roamed the city's casino strip for about 30 minutes Sunday night before a gambler wrestled him to the ground. The man, Wojcieh Dziewomski, 29, of Margate, was first spotted wielding the small black pistol at a busy downtown intersection, then walked into the Atlantic City Medical Center and threatened to shoot people, said Detective Joseph LaTorre, a police spokesman.

title: Zagreb Sends Croat to Trial In The Hague
description: Bowing to pressure from Washington, the Croatian Government today for the first time extradited a Croat wanted by the international war crimes tribunal in The Hague.

title: ARCO (ARC,N)
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company, known as ARCO, said yesterday that its earnings rose nearly 31 percent in the first quarter, as prices rose for its oil and natural gas refining operations and its sales results were strong on the West Coast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BALLON, FREDERICK E. M.
description: BALLON-Frederick E. M. The Board of Directors and Shareholders of 625 Park Avenue and Wallach Management Company mourn the loss of our long time resident and member of the Board of Directors. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family.

title: Landlord Asks Civil Court In Brooklyn to Evict Itself
description: On the surface, the case is as cut-and-dried as a stale tuna on rye. A landlord wants the court to evict a tenant. Hardly unusual.

title: Johnson Is Right at Home in His Old House
description: It was the shot that silenced Charlotte. It was the shot that sealed last night's victory for the Knicks. And it was the shot that lifted a huge burden from Larry Johnson's shoulders.

title: GREAT WESTERN HOLDERS SAID TO BACK MEETING DEADLINE
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company said yesterday that holders of the required majority of shares of the Great Western Financial Corporation voted in favor of requiring Great Western to hold its annual shareholders meeting by May 6. Ahmanson, which is based in Irwindale, Calif., and has made a hostile $6.01 billion takeover bid for Great Western, said the independent inspector appointed by Great Western, CT Corporation Systems, certified the vote in favor of Ahmanson's third consent proposal. On April 24, Great Western said Ahmanson double-counted more than five million votes in its referendum of shareholders. Ahmanson made the hostile bid for Great Western, which has its headquarters in Chatsworth, Calif., on Feb. 17.

title: All Kinds of Bonding
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale Focusing Resources on Strongest of Programs
description: Saying that Yale University cannot afford the comprehensive range of programs that many professors and students want, the university's president has adopted a policy called ''selective excellence'' that is focusing resources on the largest and strongest departments.

title: Local Italian Vote Buoys The Hard-Line Communists
description: As it struggles to keep a year-old promise to make Italy fit for a common European currency, the last thing Prime Minister Romano Prodi's center-left Government needed was more proof of its dependence on a minority party of unreconstructed Communists.

title: Prices for Wheat Slip Again As Rain Aids European Crop
description: Wheat prices fell yesterday for the third time in four trading sessions as rains replenished dry wheat fields in Europe, easing concern that drought would damage crops there.

title: No Wings, Or Prayer, For Hornets
description: FOR a month, it seemed, we heard how the Knicks did not want to play Charlotte. Big grudge. Bad matchup. In the end, the Hornets couldn't get one game. Knicks to Anthony Mason: thanks for the playoff memories, and buzz off.

title: T-Shirt Stand-Ins
description: A T-shirt under a jacket is undoubtedly a classic look, but a newer idea is a halter top or knitted camisole. The effect is more feminine and makes an easy transition to evening.

title: Finding 'Corpuscle' of Electricity Shaped Knowledge of Matter
description: ONE hundred years ago tomorrow, Joseph John Thomson stood before a conclave of scientists at the Royal Institution in Britain and announced his discovery of a ''corpuscle'' of electrically charged matter: the electron.

title: Paxson Communications May Bid for Channel 31
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation, a company that owns television stations that carry infomercials, is in talks to buy WBIS, the New York City television station that is owned by Dow Jones & Company and the ITT Corporation, a person with knowledge of the talks said yesterday. The price is said to be about $250 million.

title: De Klerk Still Works the Crowds, but Few Listen
description: When F. W. de Klerk stepped out of his Mercedes, his hand outstretched, there was no shortage of takers. The workers and patients at the hospital in this black township giggled and jostled for a chance to touch South Africa's former President.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It is not often that fireworks are set off and a marching band performs in the name of a cookbook, but that is the way the Workman publishing company will celebrate the publication of SHEILA LUKINS's new volume, ''U.S.A. Cookbook.'' The party will be held next Tuesday at the Water Club, on 30th Street and the East River, where 350 or so guests will be greeted by the New York All-City Marching Band and will then be treated to a good view of a 20-minute show being put on by Bay Fireworks.

title: Boeing Profit Climbs, but Stock Falls
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that first-quarter earnings more than tripled from a year ago, but the results fell short of investors' expectations and prompted a 6.5 percent drop in Boeing shares.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 15 about an Amsterdam center devoted to American literature and ideas misidentified the first Governor of New Netherlands, the Dutch colony in North America. He was Peter Minuit, not Peter Stuyvesant.

title: Improvising, Out From Stasis and Back
description: Talent gravitates to odd places. The singer Bobby McFerrin, who performed with a group of 10 singers at Town Hall on Friday night, is almost bizarrely gifted. When he improvises, his head is clearly rumbling with melodies; they spring from him. He's an astounding mimic.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THATCHER, JOHN

title: Consciousness Studies: From Stream to Flood
description: AT a small restaurant on West 70th Street in Manhattan, Dr. Piet Hut, an astrophysicist at the Institute for Advanced Studies in Princeton, N.J., has pushed aside his French toast to draw a quick sketch of objective and subjective reality. His drawing, on a yellow pad, shows a stick figure, a chair, the stick figure's experience of the chair, the stick figure's experience of itself and the stick figure's understanding of its experience of the chair and itself.

title: TROOP CUTS LIKELY TO BE MAIN RESULT OF MAJOR REVIEW
description: The Pentagon's most sweeping strategic review since the end of the cold war will almost certainly result in a cut in American troop strength, especially in the Army, and a reduction in the Air Force and Navy budgets for high-technology jet fighters, Pentagon and Congressional officials said today.

title: Even Lemaire Seems Loose As Devils Enjoy the Break
description: The Devils, waiting to learn who will be their next opponent, had more good laughs than good plays in a 45-minute practice today, their first contact with pucks, skates and sticks since the elimination of Montreal two nights ago.

title: INTEGON, HIT BY LOSS, CONSIDERING SALE OF COMPANY
description: After a worse-than-expected first-quarter loss, the Integon Corporation, a writer of insurance for drivers considered riskier than average, said yesterday that it might seek to sell the company. The company said it had hired the New York investment bank Goldman, Sachs & Company to ''review all strategic alternatives available, including the sale of the company.'' Shares of Integon, based in Winston-Salem, N.C., fell $3.875, to $9.50, cutting its market capitalization to around $149 million. Integon lost $33.1 million, or $2.19 a share, from first- quarter operations. Analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. had expected a loss of 9 cents a share on average.

title: People
description: * Tim Gibbon, executive vice president and managing partner for the employment communications group at J. Walter Thompson Singapore.

title: Mayor to End 50-Cent Fare On S.I. Ferry
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would eliminate the 50-cent fare on the Staten Island Ferry starting July 4, saying people who live outside Manhattan should not have to pay extra to travel.

title: Marvel Proposes a Merger With Toy Biz
description: Marvel Entertainment Group Inc., the comic book and trading card company that has been the subject of a battle for control in bankruptcy court, proposed yesterday a reorganization plan that would leave bondholders led by Carl C. Icahn high and dry.

title: New Wireless Shares Inspire Heavy Trading
description: Cable and Wireless Communications P.L.C. surged yesterday on its first day of trading on the London Stock Exchange. Shares in the telecommunications, Internet and television entertainment company rose to 306.5 pence a share, up from their listing price of 294.5 pence. More than 10.6 million shares changed hands.

title: Celebrating an Escapee From Tradition
description: When he was a very young man Lou Harrison jumped ship from the great tradition, like other composers around that time on the West Coast: Henry Cowell, John Cage, Harry Partch, all of whom he knew. Sixty years have gone by, and he hasn't drowned yet. He discovered it wasn't so bad being in the middle of the ocean. You could tread water and admire the view, or you could swim across to other welcoming vessels, other traditions.

title: Irabu Trade Is Approved
description: The Executive Council of Major League Baseball has approved the Hideki Irabu trade between the San Diego Padres and the Yankees, and the commissioner's office in Japan has also given the transaction preliminary approval. But George Steinbrenner was playing his own negotiating game when asked about the Japanese pitcher yesterday.

description: Theratech Inc. said today that it had agreed to reacquire the rights to sell the Androderm male testosterone patch in countries where the British drug maker SmithKline Beecham was not already selling it. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Radio Station Deals
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire three FM radio stations in Little Rock, Ark., from Triathlon Broadcasting Inc., a San Diego broadcasting concern, for about $20 million. Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, also said that it had agreed to acquire two FM stations in Columbia, S.C., from Emerald City Radio Partners, based in Washington, for $5.5 million.

title: Employee Stock Plan Could Extend Garment Company's Life Into a Second Generation
description: To this day, Tony Ardito still can't really say why dress No. 765 -- his company's biggest seller ever -- was such a success. Maybe it was the stretch-over-the-shoulder neck, or the spaghetti-strap belt. He shrugs when he talks about it.

title: Democrat's Kind Words for Giuliani Kindle a Council Race in Brooklyn
description: The scene took place in an intermediate school in the East New York section of Brooklyn, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was holding one of his monthly town hall meetings. Standing before hundreds of neighborhood residents, City Councilwoman Priscilla A. Wooten, who represents most of East New York, took the microphone to offer strong praise of the Mayor in one of the areas where he is least popular.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTON, CHARLES OWENS
description: BURTON-Charles Owens. On April 26th at New York Methodist Hospital. Beloved husband of Edyth. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWIND, JOAN
description: DeWIND-Joan. The Board and staff of the Charles H. Revson Foundation send our profound condolences to the DeWind family on the passing of Joan, wife of Adrian DeWind, former chairman of our Board of Directors. A noted butterfly and moth expert, she was passionately committed to the protection of nature's creatures and the habitats that sustain them. To walk around her garden or picnic with her by a pond was to be led by the elegance of her descriptions into a world inhabited with infinite varieties of life. We will miss her adventuresome, caring spirit. Robert S. Rifkind, Chairman Eli N. Evans, President

title: Supreme Court Rules Against Fusion Tickets by Minor Parties
description: The Supreme Court dealt a setback today to the quest by minor political parties for higher profiles and greater leverage, ruling 6 to 3 that states are not constitutionally required to permit candidates to appear on more than one party's ballot line.

title: Woman Sees Advances For the Disabled Imperiled by Budget Cuts
description: On a brilliant spring day in Brooklyn, a beaming Marilyn Saviola whizzes purposefully along in her motorized wheelchair, weaving among double-parked trucks, pausing to check out a bookstore window, waving to a friend.

description: To the Editor:

title: Cablevision Responds To Charges by a Rival
description: The battle between Cablevision Systems and the Classic Sports Network over the nostalgia sports market is getting so hot that a vintage judge -- Earl Warren? Joseph Wapner? Pigmeat Markham? -- might be required to resolve the dispute.

description: EISENBERG-Donald. Cherished husband of Joanna. Loving father of Lynn, Gail and James. Adoring grandfather of Lindsay, Larry and Meredith. Devoted brother of Malcolm. Funeral service Wednesday, 1PM at I.J. Morris, 1895 Flatbush Ave, Bklyn.

title: Reed's E.R.A. Dips to Best in the Majors
description: Rick Reed was untouchable a year ago, because nobody wanted the former replacement player. He is untouchable again, but now it is because nobody can score on him.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about Sheila Rauch Kennedy and her efforts to overturn the annulment of her marriage to Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, which ended in divorce, referred incorrectly to Mr. Kennedy's seniority within the Kennedy family. He is the oldest son of Senator and Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy; the oldest child is Lieut. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend of Maryland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIETZ, LEW
description: DIETZ-Lew, 90, in Rockport, Maine April 26, 1997. Best known as the author along with Harry Goodridge of ''A Seal Called Andre''. Lew wrote twenty books and hundreds of magazine pieces, almost all of them drawn from Maine life in a sixty year writing career. His wife Denny Winters, a noted painter, died in 1985. A memorial service is planned later in the summer. Laite & Pratt Funeral Home, Camden, Maine 1-800494-3365.

title: Holding Up the Shareholder
description: Colin Powell is exhorting the rich and powerful assembled at the Presidents' Summit in Philadelphia to recruit individuals and corporations for a ''war'' to save ''at risk'' children who ''don't believe in the American Dream.'' President Clinton, Vice President Gore, ex-Presidents, governors, mayors, Fortune 500 C.E.O.'s -- and Oprah -- will sign up to save inner-city youngsters. What substance will come from the politicians and glitterati?

title: Isringhausen's Lung Tested
description: Jason Isringhausen underwent more extensive tests in New York tonight, after diagnostic tests revealed a spot on a lung of the Mets' pitcher, according to people familiar with the examinations.

title: Open Government at City Hall
description: It is hard to believe that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani would still need instruction in a civic responsibility required of his job. But by rebuffing officials, watchdog groups and news organizations seeking basic information about the workings of government, Mr. Giuliani has broken with the tradition of openness that New Yorkers expect from City Hall and has needlessly stirred suspicions that he has something to hide.

title: The Legends of April
description: In April no baseball record seems insurmountable, no goal unachievable. Before the realities of summer and fall intrude, this season offers some especially appealing possibilities. Ken Griffey Jr., the Seattle Mariners' slugger, arrived at Yankee Stadium last evening with 13 home runs, a new April record that puts him well ahead of the pace required to break Roger Maris's season mark of 61. The Yankee pitcher Andy Pettitte collected his fifth victory on Sunday. At that rate he would finish the season with 30-plus. Meanwhile Deion Sanders, who plays for the Cincinnati Reds when he is not in a Dallas Cowboys uniform, had stolen 18 bases through the weekend, the pace needed to make a run at Rickey Henderson's record of 130 steals.

title: China Policy: Politics Rules
description: This was supposed to be the year that a re-elected President Clinton finally got his China policy on track, the year that a bipartisan Congress might make normal trading status for China permanent.

title: Beach Repair Set to Resume
description: After a four-month break, the nation's largest beach replenishment project is set to resume on Thursday, as Government contractors prepare to pump sand onto a 3.3-mile stretch of beach in Long Branch. The United States Army Corps of Engineers, which is in charge of the $1.7 billion, 50-year project to replace sand that erodes from Monmouth County's ocean-front, has already fortified the 5.5 miles of beach north of Long Branch, from Sandy Hook to Monmouth Beach.

title: Asia Society Opens Its First Internet Site

title: Finmeccanica's Stock Falls as Chairman Quits

title: For Parents, Call to Action In Peru Fight
description: THESE should be days of dread for Mark and Rhoda Berenson in their East Side apartment. Common sense suggests so, given the spectacular rescue mission last week ending Peru's long hostage crisis. Political and military hard-liners in that country are riding high, and for now, that has to be bad news for anyone associated with the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru guerrillas who held the Japanese Ambassador's residence in Lima for four months.

The privately held CTB owns several agricultural equipment companies, including Brock Manufacturing, a grain storage business in Indiana. Butler's shares fell 12.5 cents, to $32.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: It's Showtime at Le Cirque

Sirio Maccioni, the restaurant's owner, forgot that he himself had insisted on a judicious pace of seating to allow his new state-of-the-art kitchen to purr at a Zenlike pace. He forgot that the relocated restaurant was not scheduled to open to the public until tomorrow. He could not help himself. On Monday morning, he started giving tables away for the week to anyone who called.

title: Personal Health
description: MELATONIN, the controversial hormone now widely available wherever dietary supplements are sold, has one indisputable role in the body: it, along with bright light, helps set the body's biological clock by acting on a pacemaker in the brain. Released at night by the pineal gland at the base of the brain, melatonin sets body rhythms, including the one that makes you feel sleepy at bedtime and awake during the day.

title: WMX TO BUY BACK 30 MILLION SHARES IN DUTCH AUCTION

WMX, a waste-hauling company, said the offer, which expired at midnight on Monday, was oversubscribed and prorated at 34 percent. The company, based in Oak Brook, Ill., said the stock would be bought for $30 a share. In a Dutch auction, a company sets a price that will enable it to buy back a designated number of shares within a price range. WMX shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $29.875.
