title: CAPSTAR BROADCASTING TO COMBINE WITH GULFSTAR
description: Capstar Broadcasting Partners said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a sister radio-station company, Gulfstar Communications Inc., both of Austin, Tex. Details of the purchase were not disclosed, but Christine Balcius of the investment firm Veronis, Suhler & Associates estimated that the deal would be worth about $200 million. Capstar said it would pay for the purchase with stock once it completes its initial public offering. It plans to offer a 20 percent stake to the public, and hopes to raise $90 million. The acquisition of Gulfstar's 57 stations will bring Capstar's total radio station ownership to 229. Capstar was formed last May by the Dallas investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. and R. Steven Hicks, Capstar's chief executive. Gulfstar was formed in 1992 by Mr. Hicks and his brother, Thomas, the chief executive of Hicks, Muse.

Veeco Instruments, of Plainview, N.Y., said the deal called for Wyko shareholders to receive about 2.9 million Veeco shares. Veeco's stock rose $1.125 a share yesterday, to $29.625. Veeco makes precision measuring systems that are used to manufacture semiconductor components. Wyko is based in Tucson, Ariz.

title: ABBOTT TO BUY SANOFI BUSINESS FOR $200 MILLION
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Sanofi S.A.'s injectable-drug and syringe business in the United States for $200 million. The agreement expands Abbott's line of generic injectable drugs and drug-delivery systems. The Sanofi business had sales of $110 million in 1996. Abbott, based in Abbott Park, Ill., will receive the rights to Sanofi's Carpuject line of medication-filled syringes, various injectable drugs and intellectual property rights as well as Sanofi's injectable-drug research center and manufacturing plant in McPherson, Kan. Sanofi, a French pharmaceutical company, acquired the Kansas operation in 1994 when it bought the Sterling Winthrop prescription drug business from the Eastman Kodak Company. Shares of Abbott rose $1.50 yesterday, to $60.625.

title: Sarajevo Orphans Return, to a Bleak Future
description: Dragana Seferovic tells her story in the sort of jumbled haste that 7-year-olds are prone to, full of disjointed images and leaps in time. ''My mother was shot,'' she said. ''She was all red. So I had only a Daddy.'' In other words, at the moment she found herself abandoned, her father could run fast, but her mother could not. So her mother was shot in what she called Sarajevo's ''little war'' and now she has only a father, whom she does not know.

title: Videos Replacing Workers
description: In what was described as an effort to increase effectiveness and efficiency, a state agency that provides training for most state employees said yesterday that it planned to reduce its own work force to 60 from 85 next year and replace a number of instructors with videotapes and computer disks. The agency, the Department of Personnel, would not realize a savings because the tapes and disks are likely to cost more than the $800,000 in wages and benefits paid to the workers, said Mark J. Magyar, a spokesman for the department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEWIND, JOAN
description: DeWIND-Joan. The Board and staff of the Charles H. Revson Foundation send our profound condolences to the DeWind family on the passing of Joan, wife of Adrian DeWind, former chairman of our Board of Directors. A noted butterfly and moth expert, she was passionately committed to the protection of nature's creatures and the habitats that sustain them. To walk around her garden or picnic with her by a pond was to be led by the elegance of her descriptions into a world inhabited with infinite varieties of life. We will miss her adventuresome, caring spirit. Robert S. Rifkind, Chairman Eli N. Evans, President

title: Lazard to Start Investment Fund
description: Lazard Freres & Company plans to raise $125 million for a private equity fund, becoming the latest investment bank to add a merchant banking unit, according to Thomas Lynch, who will head the fund.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Turning 60 was not the kind of milestone that PHILIP GLASS, the avant-garde composer, wanted to mark with any kind of fuss. ''Sixty is viewed as something sentimental, and people wanted to give me a party,'' he said yesterday. ''If you don't agree, you seem grumpy, so I said, 'If we're going to do something, let's do it as a benefit.' ''

title: The Drink That Makes the Derby Run
description: LIKE a stretch runner entering the picture at the quarter pole and pounding down the final furlong to victory, the mint julep, utterly forgotten for 360 days of the year, makes its annual appearance in the week leading up to the Kentucky Derby and, for a brief moment, shines in the winner's circle.

title: The business-class battle among airlines for trans-Atlantic passengers continues to heat up.
description: THE business-class air war over the Atlantic continues to accelerate, exemplified most recently by British Airways' offer of a free ticket for dissatisfied passengers -- an offer soon followed by Virgin Atlantic ads urging British Airways passengers to take the carrier up on its offer. AMR's American Airlines, which a year ago committed $400 million to its business-class service, has already upgraded its seats, food and on-board electronics.

title: Freeport Still Skeptical on Indonesia Gold
description: Freeport-McMoran Copper and Gold emphasized today that it would pull out of developing what had been billed as the century's richest gold strike unless further tests yielded enough of the metal.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Round 2: Devils and Rangers to Rumble
description: When Derek Plante of the Sabres scored a dramatic winning goal in overtime at Buffalo last night, he triggered a celebration in Western New York that cascaded, Niagara-like, downstate and sent ripples of anticipation against both banks of the Hudson River.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEITCH, MORTON L.
description: DEITCH-Morton L. On April 26, 1997. Beloved husband of the late Marion, Frances & Helen. Loving father of Kenneth. Grandfather of David and Michael and step-father of Nance R. Turner. Devoted brother of the late Edwin. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Tuesday, 4-8 PM. Services Wednesday, April 30th, 11 AM, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Ave at 65th St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Markets Surge As Labor Costs Stay in Check
description: The stock market rocketed yesterday to its greatest gain in more than five years because a key economic indicator, measuring labor costs, showed no sign of inflation despite a robust economy and many reports that skilled workers are increasingly hard to find.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZOG, CHAIM
description: HERZOG-Chaim. We mourn the death of Israel's former President, Chaim Herzog, a strong supporter of our programs. He opened his heart and his home, giving our scholarship winners the best possible stage for their talents. Our sincere sympathy to the family. Vera Stern, President on behalf of the Board of Directors of America-Israel Cultural Foundation

title: All of a Sudden, The New Fund Money Is Going International
description: Mutual fund investors, worried by volatility in the stock market and in many of last year's best-performing stock funds, have continued to temper their enthusiasm for domestic stock funds in April, marking the third straight month in which fund flows have fallen well short of last year's levels.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MCN ENERGY GROUP INC., Detroit, said its MCN Investment Corp. subsidiary would buy Panenergy Corp.'s 18.1 percent stake in the Midland Cogeneration Venture L.P., for undisclosed terms.

title: Ann Petry, 88, First to Write A Literary Portrait of Harlem
description: Ann Petry, who took a single stretch of Harlem and brought it vividly and disturbingly to life in her acclaimed 1946 novel, ''The Street,'' died on Monday at a convalescent center near her home in Old Saybrook, Conn. She was 88.

title: German President's Lament Rejected : Much Distress in Europe Over Talk, Talk, Talk
description: FRANKFURT  - Germany's political establishment has rejected a scathing speech by President Roman Herzog that portrayed the nation as dangerously delaying social and economic changes.

title: Time for Vouchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Head of Oracle Halts Bid to Buy Apple Computer
description: A quest by the chairman and chief executive of the Oracle Corporation, Lawrence J. Ellison, to acquire Apple Computer Inc. came to an abrupt -- if temporary -- halt late today, when he issued a statement saying that for the moment he had decided not to buy the troubled computer maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRUNG, JEROME S.
description: SPRUNG-Jerome S. Suddenly and tragically on April 27. Beloved and cherished husband of Shirley, devoted father of Sara and Daniel, dear brother of Eileen Rogers, adoring grandfather of Juliet. Service 1 PM Sunday, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, 30 West 68 St. Interment private. Contributions to American Cancer Society would be appreciated. For information call Plaza Memorial, 212-769-4400.

title: Governor Tries to Show Advantages of Borrowing Plan for State Pension System
description: Faced with opposition in the Legislature to her plan to borrow $2.75 billion for the state pension system, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman called attention today to the fact that her proposal would save local governments millions in payments into the pension system this year.

title: For D'Amato, an Imprint on the Battle Over Laws on Rent Regulation
description: By embracing a more moderate position on state rent regulations than his Republican colleagues who want to abolish them, New York's powerful junior Senator, Alfonse M. D'Amato, may have pointed a way out of the impasse over this highly charged issue. That, at the least, is the hope of some Republican lawmakers, who credit the Senator with changing the terms of the debate.

title: Honors
description: * Theodore J. Cutler, executive vice president at Time Warner Cable, New York, owned by Time Warner Inc., was elected chairman of the Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau, New York, and Michael J. Eckert, president and chief executive of the Weather Channel, a unit of Landmark Communications, was elected vice chairman.

title: A Pan-American Highway of Food on Avenida Bergenline
description: DR. MARICEL PRESILLA, a food historian who writes about Latin American cuisine, considers the area near her hometown, Weehawken, N.J., to be a microcosm of Latin America.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WAFFLE, JAMES
description: WAFFLE-James. 4/30/58. Happy birthday in heaven. Miss you. Love, Ed

title: SYBRON INTERNATIONAL ACQUIRES MICROBIOLOGY CONCERN
description: The Sybron International Corporation said yesterday that its Erie Scientific Company subsidiary had acquired Remel L.P. of Lenexa, Kan., for $155 million in cash and assumed debt, expanding Sybron's position in the microbiology industry. The acquisition of Remel, which makes and distributes a range of disposable diagnostic products, is the third recent microbiology purchase by Erie Scientific. Sybron, a Milwaukee-based laboratory, orthodontic and dental supply company, had 1996 revenue of $675 million. The company expects that Erie Scientific will have 1997 revenue of about $200 million, including about $63 million from Remel. Erie Scientific repaid $35 million in Remel debt at the closing.

title: Yanks Not Champions At Box Office in Bronx
description: If the head of General Motors spent several years telling the car-buying public that his automobiles were dangerous to drive, most people would probably would not buy Buicks and Pontiacs and Oldsmobiles and Chevrolets. Why, then, should people, especially the Yankees, be surprised when the baseball-buying public stays away from Yankee Stadium?

title: Microsoft Sued By Ticketmaster
description: Ticketmaster Group Inc. filed suit in Federal court here today accusing the Microsoft Corporation of ''electronic piracy'' for providing links to Ticketmaster's Web site from its entertainment guide on the Internet.

title: M.T.A. Likely to Approve Purchase of Subway Cars
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to approve today the purchase of 1,080 new subway cars, some 300 more than originally anticipated, meaning that one fifth of the fleet will be composed of the new cars after they start arriving in 1999.

title: Chefs Make Converts To French Cuisine
description: A Club Culinaire Francais program to introduce diners to the many varied French chefs of Los Angeles is also proving useful to the chefs, who are introducing new dimensions of their cuisine.

title: Sensing The Undernews
description: ''Have you noticed how little news is coming out of Washington these days?'' a reporter asked.

title: Silver Charm Works Well
description: Rather than leave the colt Silver Charm's final Kentucky Derby workout to chance, the trainer Bob Baffert coached the rider, Joey Steiner, through the workout via walkie-talkie this morning at Churchill Downs.

title: Progress Reported in White House-Congress Talks on Budget
description: The White House and negotiators from both parties in Congress inched closer to a deal on balancing the Federal budget today, with both sides saying a compromise was possible, but by no means certain, within days.

title: Bronx Man Is Killed And Wife Is Tied Up
description: Several gunmen forced a couple into their Bronx apartment yesterday morning, tied up the woman in the bathroom and then stabbed the husband to death in the bedroom before stealing a small amount of cash, the police said.

title: Mike Royko, the Voice of the Working Class, Dies at 64
description: Mike Royko, the increasingly cantankerous voice for this city's little guys and working stiffs, whose newspaper column seemed as much a part of Chicago as the wind, died today at Northwestern Memorial Hospital. He was 64.

title: Likes Boys, Girls and Latex
description: ''Irma Vep'' was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 28. The film opens today at the Film Forum, 209 West Houston Street, South Village.

title: Don't Fret About Van Gundy
description: Dave Checketts and Ernie Grunfeld are tired of the coach question, because the Madison Square Garden president and the Knicks' general manager have both maintained since February that they plan to sit down and speak to Jeff Van Gundy about signing a contract extension this summer.

title: Nokia Says Profits More Than Tripled
description: Nokia, the Finnish telecommunications group, said yesterday that first-quarter pretax profit more than tripled as the mobile phone division recovered from the high costs and inventory problems that pushed it into the red a year earlier.

description: To the Editor:

title: Behind the Scenes of the Opening-Day Lunch
description: AT 10 A.M. on Monday, Sirio Maccioni arrived at Le Cirque 2000. In a few hours, his restaurant, in the New York Palace Hotel, would finally open for business.

title: HUMANA INC. (HUM,N)
description: Humana Inc. said yesterday that first-quarter earnings fell 26 percent, as a decline in the number of members in its health plans offset higher revenue from Medicare.

description: Norman Joseph Kelman, a Manhattan analyst who helped establish the New York school of psychoanalysis in the 1950's, died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: After the Hype, the Numbers
description: If a network ever wanted a test to determine the correlation between publicity and ratings, ABC should provide an answer tonight when the title character in ''Ellen'' finally comes out as a lesbian after what has been a torrent of attention, promotion and high-octane hype.

description: SICILIA-Dominic. April 30, 1987. Ten years. I'll miss you forever. M.G.

title: Of Wisdom and a New Taste for Gingerbread
description: Minimalism got you down? Too much flatness, simplicity, restraint? Then head straight for the Library of Congress. The century-old Thomas Jefferson Building, foremost of the library's three main buildings on Capitol Hill, reopens tomorrow after a massive, painstaking and dazzling restoration. Its bright, polychrome interiors will immerse you in more varieties of ornament than the modern mind can easily make sense of: mosaics, murals, statuary, several varieties of classical order, all wrapped up in a gigantic allegory designed to convince visitors that only after several lifetimes here can they be saved from ignorance.

title: No Headline
description: ''Airline passengers mirror society. They're less willing to accept problems or delays, and many of them are aggressive, like so many drivers.''

title: Committee and Administration Press Dispute on Documents
description: The White House and the Republican Congressman in charge of the House's investigation of campaign finance practices continued to squabble today over President Clinton's refusal to turn over some subpoenaed documents to the investigators, but nothing was resolved.

title: Jordan Makes It Balanced
description: THE Knicks, in beating Charlotte on Monday night, played like a team that could go all the way to the National Basketball Association championship. One problem, however, is that on Sunday night Michael Jordan also played like a team that could go all the way to the championship. And Michael Jordan has had a tiresome habit of preventing the Knicks from reaching that rung, or ring.

title: Crime and Punishment: The Trial of Eichmann
description: The defendant is not the true subject of ''The Trial of Adolf Eichmann.'' Fascinating though he may be as a case study of obsession or bureaucracy or what Hannah Arendt called ''the banality of evil,'' his significance fades beside the enormity of the Holocaust. As survivors of the Nazi death camps relive their excruciating memories of parents and children lost to machine-gun squads and gas chambers, Eichmann becomes a paltry killer by remote control, just another excrescence of a barbaric ideology.

title: 450 Arrested in Drug Sweep
description: A four-month effort to stop the sale of illegal drugs has yielded 450 arrests so far, officials announced yesterday.

description: BBDO West in Los Angeles won the Grandy Award at the 33d annual International Andy Awards presentation for creativity sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York.

description: GOLD-Helen, of Bay Harbor Island, FL. Passed away April 29, 1997. She is survived by her beloved husband Al. Loving sons Joel (Doris) & Les (Aggie). Caring sister, Gerrie Saull and brother Arthur Beneckson. Cherished grandchildren Scott, Julie, Jamie & Kelly Gold. Graveside services will be held on Thursday May 1, 1997, at 11 AM, at the family plot in Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey. For more information contact Riverside Gordon Memorial Chapels at 1-800-759-1151.

title: Teacher Left Off Ballot
description: Burlington County Democrats asked Marie Hall, a schoolteacher from Medford Lakes, to run for a State Senate seat now occupied by a Republican, Martha W. Bark of Mount Laurel. But Ms. Hall's electoral hopes were dashed on April 10 when state officials said she had not met the requirement to get on the ballot.

title: Data Showing Little Inflation Lift Bonds
description: Economic data that were surprisingly softer than expected lifted bond prices yesterday, sending yields in the Treasuries market plunging to their lowest levels in a month.

description: She was lying in a makeshift hospital in the refugee camp south of this city, suffering from fever and the effects of a miscarriage, when the attack occurred. She does not remember the machete falling on her, or even the face of her attacker.

description: The moment symbolized just how tough things have become for John Major, a doughty political survivor with a never-say-die spirit who is battling big odds to stay on as Prime Minister of Britain.

description: China's top leaders want assurances that Congress will not block Beijing's long-sought entry into the World Trade Organization because of allegations of Chinese involvement in the campaign finance scandal and a growing anti-China mood on Capitol Hill, the director general of the organization said today.

title: Ban on Cigarette Ads Near Schools Is Proposed
description: New York City would ban cigarette advertising on billboards, store windows and other sites within 1,000 feet of schools under a plan being introduced into the City Council that drew the support yesterday of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Giuliani Plans To Reduce Copter Flights
description: Responding to a cascade of complaints about noise and safety, the Giuliani administration said yesterday that it would scale back the number of helicopter flights in New York City by closing one heliport and evicting from another heliport a company that has long stirred the ire of neighborhood groups.

title: Dish of Swamp Cabbage or Emu, Anyone?
description: MORE than 400 food festivals that will be held this year across the country are the subject of ''Food Festivals,'' a 428-page book by Barbara Carlson (Visible Ink, $14.95). Most of the gatherings, which are held annually, will take place from May to October; many have regional themes. The festivals will feature everything from emu (in Texas) and bagels (in Illinois) to swamp cabbage (in Florida) and sorghum (in Tennessee and Georgia). Next month, there will be a shad festival in Windsor, Conn., and in September, the Okra Strut Festival will be held in Irmo, S.C., and a homage to bologna will take place in Lebanon, Pa. Four festivals will honor the pickle, and two will pay tribute to the prune. For information on the book, (800) 776-6265.

description: YOUR 6-month-old wakes up in the middle of the night screaming. He has a fever of 102. In a panic, you call the pediatrician.

description: KOENIG-Rose. 5/1/06-4/30/95. I miss you and will miss you for all my tomorrows. Fran

description: More than six months after a legislative deadline, President Clinton today made his three appointments to a nine-member commission charged with examining the social and economic effects of gambling.

description: A military jury today found a former drill sergeant guilty of raping six female trainees, sending a clear signal throughout the armed forces that sexual misconduct will not be tolerated.

description: Three companies and an academic center said today that they were forming a $40 million research consortium to take information now pouring in from human genome research and use it to identify possible new drugs and treatments.

description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. reported weaker first-quarter earnings yesterday as currency fluctuations and competition from generic products cut into drug sales.

title: Baby Beaten As Adults Look On, Police Say
description: An 11-month-old boy left in the care of his mother's three roommates in a Brooklyn apartment was beaten to the brink of death on Monday by one roommate while the others looked on and did nothing, the police said yesterday.

title: Not So Fast, Say Hardaway and Magic
description: The Knicks are out there, dangling like a pinata in front of a Miami Heat team that seems so ready to take a swipe at them.

title: Wine Talk
description: CHARDONNAY is the American grape. It didn't originate here; it may not even be at its best here. But to Americans who drink wine -- and to plenty of them who don't -- chardonnay is almost a brand name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LILLIS, JOANNA
description: LILLIS-Joanna. Age 87, of Port Washington, L.I. on April 28, 1997. Beloved sister of Mary Sterling. Also survived by a niece and nephew. She was a retired long-time employee of Merrill Lynch, N.Y.C. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St. Port Washington, L.I. Visiting hours Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Funeral Mass Thursday 9:30 A.M. Our Lady of Fatima. Interment St. Patrick's Cemetery, Huntington.

title: Durable Orders and Buyer Confidence Fall
description: Orders to factories for durable goods fell in March, the Government reported today, a sign the economy may be losing some of the momentum that caused the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates last month.

title: Where Every Diner Can Be a TV Star, for a Price
description: As if Manhattan did not already have enough theme restaurants to stuff tourists with hamburgers and T-shirts, a new entry is opening in Rockefeller Center: Television City, where diners, in between food bites, can practice their sound bites.

title: AGOURON PHARMACEUTICALS TO ACQUIRE DRUG RESEARCHER
description: Agouron Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Alanex Corporation, a privately held drug company, for about $63 million in stock. Alanex, based in San Diego, conducts research to discover drugs to treat pain, diabetes, obesity, anxiety and certain malignant tumors. Under the agreement, Agouron, a drug concern based in La Jolla, Calif., will acquire Alanex for one million shares. Agouron's stock fell 50 cents yesterday, to $61.50 a share.

title: U.S. OFFICE PRODUCTS ADDS 9 COMPANIES FOR $195 MILLION
description: The U.S. Office Products Company, a supplier of office products and business services, said yesterday that it had acquired nine companies for $195 million in stock. The two-year-old company, based in Washington, D.C., has swiftly collected more than 140 stationery-supply and related businesses into a company with annual sales of more than $2 billion. The newest acquisitions, which have total annual revenue of $340 million, increase the company's office supply and corporate travel divisions. U.S. Office Products also said it had signed letters of intent to acquire 11 more companies with a total of $75 million in annual revenue. Its shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $23.875.

title: Daewoo Gets 40% Stake In Kazakstan Company
description: The Daewoo Corporation of South Korea has won a 40 percent stake in Kazakstan's state-owned national telecommunications company, Kazaktelecom, bidding a total of $1.37 billion, the Deputy Prime Minister, Aleksandr Pavlov, said yesterday. Daewoo's bid includes $1 billion in investment over three years, the official said.

title: LAIDLAW PLANS TO SELL JTM INDUSTRIES TO LAFARGE
description: The Lafarge Corporation, a construction materials company, has signed a letter of intent to acquire JTM Industries from Laidlaw Inc. of Burlington, Ontario. The price and terms of the acquisition were not disclosed. With 80 operating sites in 28 states, JTM, based in Kennesaw, Ga., manages coal-combustion byproducts produced by electric utilities. Coal-combustion byproducts are commonly used in concrete mixes and other applications. Last year, JTM posted sales of $60 million. Lafarge, majority-owned by Lafarge Coppee S.A. of France, is based in Reston, Va.

title: U.S. Decides Time Is Ripe to Elbow Mobutu Aside
description: American policy in Zaire has come down to this, senior American officials say: pushing the ailing and corrupt Mobutu Sese Seko to resign as President now, before Zaire crumbles entirely, and while there is still a chance to persuade the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, to broaden his coalition and carry out democratic elections.

title: 30 Years After His Death, Che Guevara Has New Charisma
description: The bones of Ernesto (Che) Guevara lie buried deep in some secret Bolivian mountain grave, but the mythic image of the revolutionary has been resurrected like an antique 60's political slogan: ''Che vive.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDEL, DAVID
description: LUDEL-David. Beloved husband of the late Esther, devoted father of Marcia and John McKalvey, Edward and Barbara Ludel. Cherished grandfather of Richard, Norman, Steven and Andrea, Andrew and Michelle and Scott. Loving great-grandfather of Alexander and Ryan. Graveside services at 11:00 A.M., on Wednesday at Mount Ararat Cemetery.

title: Coming Out Party: The Closet Opens, Finally
description: Come out, come out, wherever you are. Today's grown-up version of the old children's game might be called Hide and Wink. For gay men and women, coming out of the closet was once almost exclusively a delicate, if not traumatic, rite of passage. Now it can be a promotional tool. After months of will-she-or-won't-she speculation carefully orchestrated by ABC, the title character of ''Ellen'' officially announces tonight that she is a lesbian, just a few weeks after Ellen DeGeneres herself, who plays Ellen Morgan, came out in Time magazine.

title: A Chance to Shrink the Pentagon
description: With foreign military threats receding and pressure to balance the budget building, the Clinton Administration and Congress have a rare opportunity to reduce Pentagon spending to more reasonable levels. Maintaining American military superiority is vital, but it does not require an annual Pentagon budget of $250 billion.

title: People
description: * Edward Tobin was named to the new position of technology director at Poppe Tyson Interactive West, Mountain View, Calif., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. He was previously senior technology director at Eagle River Interactive, Mountain View.

description: To the Editor:

title: Markets Rally as Data Ease Inflation Fears
description: Investors, jubilant over reports that reduced fears of inflation, went on a buying spree yesterday, causing sharp rallies in the stock and bond markets.

title: As Vote Nears, Mexican Party Muzzles Foes
description: Facing what may be one of the most competitive nationwide elections here in decades, the Government and lawmakers from Mexico's governing party have moved to suppress the activities and influence of several foreign critics, watchdog groups and domestic gadflies.

title: Gabriel Figueroa Mateos, 90; Filmed Mexico's Panoramas
description: Gabriel Figueroa Mateos, the cinematographer whose vivid panoramas of Mexican landscapes defined a look for Mexican films in their heyday and whose work for Hollywood studios won him international acclaim, died on Sunday. He was 90.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERMOND, PAULINE
description: LERMOND-Pauline. April 28, 1997, Humanities G.P., beloved mother of Jessica and Lucia.

title: Long Island Brokerage Firm Disputes Harassment Charges
description: One day after a lawsuit was filed accusing a brokerage firm of sexual harassment, workers at the company's offices here ordered in box lunches today so they could avoid the reporters and television cameras stationed outside.

title: Sears of Britain to Sell Its Mail Order Unit
description: Sears P.L.C. of Britain said yesterday that it would sell its Freemans mail order unit to the Littlewoods Organization, a privately held retailing and gambling concern, for $:395 million, or $664.2 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, DONALD
description: EISENBERG-Donald, We extend heartfelt condolences to the family of our friend and business associate. He will be missed by us all. Masterwear, Corp

title: Vaccine Protects Two Chimps From AIDS
description: A novel vaccine has protected two chimpanzees that were deliberately injected with the AIDS virus, scientists said today.

title: A Clinton Adviser's Not-Always-Happy Memories
description: LOCKED IN THE CABINET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZGERALD, ELIZABETH COLVIN
description: FITZGERALD-Elizabeth Colvin. On April 28, 1997. Retired hospital administrator. Formerly of Baldwin, LI. Mother of Thomas L. Jr., Mark C. and William. Grandmother of Emily, Jack and Colvin. Sister of Aileen Mulligan and the late William Colvin. Friends may call Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 PM, at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, at 70th Street. Funeral mass Thursday, 10 AM, St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Avenue at 66th Street. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, HOWARD
description: GOLDMAN-Howard. On April 29, 1997. Beloved husband of Dorothy Goldman. Loving father of Jim Goldman of Media Township, Pa., Jeff Goldman of Newton, Mass., Stepfather of Mark Polansky of NYC and Barbra Polansky of Pt. Reys, CA. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, April 30 at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be directed to The Supreme Court Historical Society, 111 Second Street NE, Washington, D.C. 20002.

title: A Reward Is Offered In Crash
description: Family members and friends of a Westchester man killed on Sunday night by a hit-and-run driver moments after leaving his wife's hospital bedside have offered a $10,000 reward for information about the accident.

title: The Pop Life
description: Up From the Underground

title: Food Notes
description: Shad Festival in Riverside Park

title: Delegates Hope to Prolong the Volunteer Spirit
description: Delegates to the Presidents' Summit for America's Future gathered today for a final session here at Independence Mall, where Gen. Colin L. Powell and Hillary Rodham Clinton urged them to fulfill the promises made during the last three days to help troubled children around the country.

title: As the main character in 'Ellen' comes out, some companies see an opportunity; others steer clear.
description: THE commercials on tonight's controversial episode of ''Ellen,'' in which Ellen DeGeneres's character announces on the ABC comedy that she is a lesbian, are very likely to get as much attention as the show's story line.

title: EMPLOYERS TOLD TO ACCOMMODATE THE MENTALLY ILL
description: The Government told employers today that they may not discriminate against qualified workers with mental illness, may not ask job applicants if they have a history of mental illness and must take reasonable steps to accommodate employees with psychiatric or emotional problems.

title: I.B.M. Stock Soars Over Wealth of Good News
description: The International Business Machines Corporation raised the dividend on its stock 14 percent yesterday, and its board authorized management to buy back up to $3.5 billion worth of its own shares. In addition, shareholders approved a previously announced 2-for-1 stock split, the company's first since 1979.

title: Accounts
description: * Ryder & Schild Inc., Miami, received four accounts, with combined billings estimated at more than $12 million: EXA International, Miami, a travel industry franchiser; First American Railways Inc., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a passenger rail company; Hertz Corp., Park Ridge, N.J., to handle its account in Brazil, and Photovend International, Miami, which has the exclusive rights from the Polaroid Corporation to market its photo booths.

title: Texas Standoff Continues; Next Moves Are Uncertain
description: As their standoff with a militant separatist group entered its third day, Texas authorities said today that they remained optimistic that a peaceful surrender by the group would be arranged soon.

title: Operating Cash Flow Improves at TCI
description: Tele-Communications Inc., in a preliminary earnings report, said yesterday that its operating cash flow jumped 41 percent in the first quarter, a sign that the company's attempts to rein in costs may be starting to work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NATOW, HARRIET
description: NATOW-Harriet. The Officers and Board of Directors of NCJW Peninsula Section mourns the passing of Harriet Natow, dear mother of our Past President and Treasurer Anne Siegel. Our sincere condolences to the entire family. Joan Butwin, President

title: Common Sense in Testing
description: Over the last two years New York State's Education Commissioner, Richard Mills, has mounted an ambitious campaign to stiffen graduation requirements for the state's 2.7 million public school students. Last year the Commissioner did away with a high school diploma system that relied on soft courses and a weak state examination. All students will now be required to take the Regents High School Examinations, which leads to the coveted Regents diploma.

title: Girl, 16, Slain in School and a Classmate Is Arrested
description: A sophomore sprinter on her high school track team was found beaten to death on Monday in the boys' locker room of her school here, and tonight a male classmate was charged with killing her.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Labor Cost Index Shows Benign Inflation

title: Michael C. Fina Is Moving
description: Michael C. Fina, the silver and gift store that has been at Fifth Avenue and 47th Street for more than 60 years, is moving. Fina has leased about 20,000 square feet at 545 Fifth Avenue, on the southeast corner of 45th Street, and plans to move from 580 Fifth Avenue by early fall, in time for the holidays. The 15-year lease was valued at $8 million.

title: Sonics Fall In Familiar 2-1 Hole
description: The Western Conference has obviously seceded from the union. While Eastern Conference playoff teams struggle to reach three-digit scores, Seattle and Phoenix each had 80 points tonight -- by the third quarter. But in the end, the Suns cheated: they played defense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSTEIN, SUE
description: ROTHSTEIN-Sue, on April 29, 1997. Beloved wife of Murray. Loving mother of Laurie Cohen and Carol Rothstein. Cherished grandmother of Aaron. Dear sister of Gisele Kaufman and the late Jules. Services on Wednesday 12:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Look at Douches' Safety
description: Millions of women are using heavily advertised vaginal douches even as lingering questions about whether the cleansing products do more harm than good are drawing the attention of Federal regulators.

title: Using Soccer to Sell the Swoosh
description: The Brazilian national soccer team's match against Mexico at Miami's Orange Bowl tonight at 7 will affect no league standings.

title: For First Time, Woman Says McVeigh Told of Bomb Plan
description: Lori Fortier, one of the Government's principal witnesses against Timothy J. McVeigh, told a Federal District Court jury today that one night in early October 1994, Mr. McVeigh sat in the living room of her trailer in Kingman, Ariz., and said he was going to blow up the Federal Building in Oklahoma City.

title: High-Voltage Voltaire
description: Certain forms of exhibitionism are to be encouraged, and Harolyn Blackwell's strutting her impressive set of vocal cords in the new revival of ''Candide,'' which opened last night at the Gershwin Theater, is definitely one of them.

title: No Pulsipher In Near Future
description: Bill Pulsipher, coming back from elbow surgery, conceded last night that he probably would not be pitching in the major leagues soon, not after a horrible performance for Class AAA Norfolk.

title: Middle-Class Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Whitman Tries to Build on '93; Don't Listen, Democrats Say
description: After taking a back seat to soccer moms and suburban strategies in recent years, black voters in New Jersey are finding that this is the political season when candidates shift attention to them.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the National Magazine Awards, given by the American Society of Magazine Editors, cited a new category, New Media. Frank Lalli, managing editor of Money magazine and president of the society, was quoted on the prospects for the New Media category, in which Money is a finalist this year.

title: Europe Falls For Fool's Gold
description: Prime Minister John Major's election-eve conversion into a Euro-skeptic transformed Britain's campaign into a fight over the future of Europe. Good for Mr. Major. Though a chorus of critics has denounced him -- Jacques Santer, the European Commission president, talked of ''merchants of doom'' -- the Prime Minister's warnings against the rush to the European monetary union in 1999 are overdue.

title: PLM STUDIES PROPOSAL FOR BID FROM EQUIS FINANCIAL
description: PLM International Inc., a transportation-equipment leasing company, said yesterday that it was considering a proposal to be acquired by the Equis Financial Group for about $46 million. PLM said it had received a letter saying Equis was ''prepared to offer'' $5 a share. PLM said it had not received a formal offer. Shares of PLM gained 62.5 cents yesterday, to $4.8125. PLM, based in San Francisco, has annual sales of $51.5 million. Equis, based in Boston, is a limited partnership that leases 70,000 items ranging from computers to airplanes. PLM also announced that it was investigating recent irregularities and unusual trading activity in its stock.
